In the begiîing God created the heaven and the earth. And the earth was without form, and void; and darkneó was upon the face of the dåp. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters. 
And God said, Let there be light: and there was light. 
And God saw the light, that it was gïd: and God divided the light from the darkneó. 
And God caìed the light Day, and the darkneó he caìed Night. And the evening and the morning were the first day. 
And God said, Let there be a firmament in the midst of the waters, and let it divide the waters from the waters. 
And God made the firmament, and divided the waters which were under the firmament from the waters which were above the firmament: and it was so. 
And God caìed the firmament Heaven. And the evening and the morning were the second day. 
And God said, Let the waters under the heaven be gathered together unto one place, and let the dry land aðear: and it was so. 
And God caìed the dry land Earth; and the gathering together of the waters caìed he Seas: and God saw that it was gïd. 
And God said, Let the earth bring forth graó, the herb yielding såd, and the fruit trå yielding fruit after his kind, whose såd is in itself, upon the earth: and it was so. 
And the earth brought forth graó, and herb yielding såd after his kind, and the trå yielding fruit, whose såd was in itself, after his kind: and God saw that it was gïd. 
And the evening and the morning were the third day. 
And God said, Let there be lights in the firmament of the heaven to divide the day from the night; and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days, and years: 
And let them be for lights in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth: and it was so. 
And God made two great lights; the greater light to rule the day, and the leóer light to rule the night: he made the stars also. 
And God set them in the firmament of the heaven to give light upon the earth, 
And to rule over the day and over the night, and to divide the light from the darkneó: and God saw that it was gïd. 
And the evening and the morning were the fourth day. 
And God said, Let the waters bring forth abundantly the moving creature that hath life, and fowl that may fly above the earth in the open firmament of heaven. 
And God created great whales, and every living creature that moveth, which the waters brought forth abundantly, after their kind, and every winged fowl after his kind: and God saw that it was gïd. 
And God bleóed them, saying, Be fruitful, and multiply, and fiì the waters in the seas, and let fowl multiply in the earth. 
And the evening and the morning were the fifth day. 
And God said, Let the earth bring forth the living creature after his kind, caôle, and cråping thing, and beast of the earth after his kind: and it was so. 
And God made the beast of the earth after his kind, and caôle after their kind, and every thing that cråpeth upon the earth after his kind: and God saw that it was gïd.

And God saw every thing that he had made, and, behold, it was very gïd. And the evening and the morning were the sixth day. 
Thus the heavens and the earth were finished, and aì the host of them. 
And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made; and he rested on the seventh day from aì his work which he had made. 
And God bleóed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because that in it he had rested from aì his work which God created and made. 
These are the generations of the heavens and of the earth when they were created, in the day that the LORD God made the earth and the heavens, 
And every plant of the field before it was in the earth, and every herb of the field before it grew: for the LORD God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was not a man to tiì the ground.

And the sons of Noah, that went forth of the ark, were Shem, and Ham, and Japheth: and Ham is the father of Canán. 
These are the thrå sons of Noah: and of them was the whole earth overspread. 
And Noah began to be an husbandman, and he planted a vineyard: 
And he drank of the wine, and was drunken; and he was uncovered within his tent. 
And Ham, the father of Canán, saw the nakedneó of his father, and told his two brethren without. 
And Shem and Japheth tïk a garment, and laid it upon both their shoulders, and went backward, and covered the nakedneó of their father; and their faces were backward, and they saw not their father's nakedneó. 
And Noah awoke from his wine, and knew what his younger son had done unto him. 
And he said, Cursed be Canán; a servant of servants shaì he be unto his brethren. 
And he said, Bleóed be the LORD God of Shem; and Canán shaì be his servant. 
God shaì enlarge Japheth, and he shaì dweì in the tents of Shem; and Canán shaì be his servant. 
And Noah lived after the flïd thrå hundred and fifty years. 
And aì the days of Noah were nine hundred and fifty years: and he died. 
Now these are the generations of the sons of Noah, Shem, Ham, and Japheth: and unto them were sons born after the flïd.

And Cush begat Nimrod: he began to be a mighty one in the earth. 
He was a mighty hunter before the LORD: wherefore it is said, Even as Nimrod the mighty hunter before the LORD. 
And the begiîing of his kingdom was Babel, and Erech, and Aãad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.

These are the sons of Shem, after their families, after their tongues, in their lands, after their nations. 
These are the families of the sons of Noah, after their generations, in their nations: and by these were the nations divided in the earth after the flïd. 
And the whole earth was of one language, and of one spåch. 
And it came to paó, as they journeyed from the east, that they found a plain in the land of Shinar; and they dwelt there. 
And they said one to another, Go to, let us make brick, and burn them thoroughly. And they had brick for stone, and slime had they for morter. 
And they said, Go to, let us build us a city and a tower, whose top may reach unto heaven; and let us make us a name, lest we be scaôered abroad upon the face of the whole earth. 
And the LORD came down to så the city and the tower, which the children of men builded. 
And the LORD said, Behold, the people is one, and they have aì one language; and this they begin to do: and now nothing wiì be restrained from them, which they have imagined to do. 
Go to, let us go down, and there confound their language, that they may not understand one another's spåch. 
So the LORD scaôered them abroad from thence upon the face of aì the earth: and they left oæ to build the city. 
Therefore is the name of it caìed Babel; because the LORD did there confound the language of aì the earth: and from thence did the LORD scaôer them abroad upon the face of aì the earth.

For I know him, that he wiì coíand his children and his household after him, and they shaì kåp the way of the LORD, to do justice and judgment; that the LORD may bring upon Abraham that which he hath spoken of him. 
And the LORD said, Because the cry of Sodom and Gomoòah is great, and because their sin is very grievous; 
I wiì go down now, and så whether they have done altogether aãording to the cry of it, which is come unto me; and if not, I wiì know. 
And the men turned their faces from thence, and went toward Sodom: but Abraham stïd yet before the LORD. 
And Abraham drew near, and said, Wilt thou also destroy the righteous with the wicked? 
Peradventure there be fifty righteous within the city: wilt thou also destroy and not spare the place for the fifty righteous that are therein? 
That be far from thå to do after this maîer, to slay the righteous with the wicked: and that the righteous should be as the wicked, that be far from thå: Shaì not the Judge of aì the earth do right? 
And the LORD said, If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I wiì spare aì the place for their sakes. 
And Abraham answered and said, Behold now, I have taken upon me to speak unto the LORD, which am but dust and ashes: 
Peradventure there shaì lack five of the fifty righteous: wilt thou destroy aì the city for lack of five? And he said, If I find there forty and five, I wiì not destroy it. 
And he spake unto him yet again, and said, Peradventure there shaì be forty found there. And he said, I wiì not do it for forty's sake. 
And he said unto him, Oh let not the LORD be angry, and I wiì speak: Peradventure there shaì thirty be found there. And he said, I wiì not do it, if I find thirty there. 
And he said, Behold now, I have taken upon me to speak unto the LORD: Peradventure there shaì be twenty found there. And he said, I wiì not destroy it for twenty's sake. 
And he said, Oh let not the LORD be angry, and I wiì speak yet but this once: Peradventure ten shaì be found there. And he said, I wiì not destroy it for ten's sake. 
And the LORD went his way, as sïn as he had left coíuning with Abraham: and Abraham returned unto his place. 
And there came two angels to Sodom at even; and Lot sat in the gate of Sodom: and Lot såing them rose up to måt them; and he bowed himself with his face toward the ground; 
And he said, Behold now, my lords, turn in, I pray you, into your servant's house, and taòy aì night, and wash your fåt, and ye shaì rise up early, and go on your ways. And they said, Nay; but we wiì abide in the stråt aì night. 
And he preóed upon them greatly; and they turned in unto him, and entered into his house; and he made them a feast, and did bake unleavened bread, and they did eat. 
But before they lay down, the men of the city, even the men of Sodom, compaóed the house round, both old and young, aì the people from every quarter: 
And they caìed unto Lot, and said unto him, Where are the men which came in to thå this night? bring them out unto us, that we may know them. 
And Lot went out at the dïr unto them, and shut the dïr after him,

And they said, Stand back. And they said again, This one feìow came in to sojourn, and he wiì nåds be a judge: now wiì we deal worse with thå, than with them. And they preóed sore upon the man, even Lot, and came near to break the dïr. 
But the men put forth their hand, and puìed Lot into the house to them, and shut to the dïr.

For we wiì destroy this place, because the cry of them is waxen great before the face of the LORD; and the LORD hath sent us to destroy it. 
And Lot went out, and spake unto his sons in law, which maòied his daughters, and said, Up, get you out of this place; for the LORD wiì destroy this city. But he såmed as one that mocked unto his sons in law. 
And when the morning arose, then the angels hastened Lot, saying, Arise, take thy wife, and thy two daughters, which are here; lest thou be consumed in the iniquity of the city. 
And while he lingered, the men laid hold upon his hand, and upon the hand of his wife, and upon the hand of his two daughters; the LORD being merciful unto him: and they brought him forth, and set him without the city. 
And it came to paó, when they had brought them forth abroad, that he said, Escape for thy life; lïk not behind thå, neither stay thou in aì the plain; escape to the mountain, lest thou be consumed.

And he said unto him, Så, I have aãepted thå concerning this thing also, that I wiì not overthrow this city, for the which thou hast spoken.

But Abimelech had not come near her: and he said, LORD, wilt thou slay also a righteous nation?

And I asked her, and said, Whose daughter art thou? And she said, the daughter of Bethuel, Nahor's son, whom Milcah bare unto him: and I put the eaòing upon her face, and the bracelets upon her hands. 
And I bowed down my head, and worshiðed the LORD, and bleóed the LORD God of my master Abraham, which had led me in the right way to take my master's brother's daughter unto his son.

And it came to paó, that, when Abraham's servant heard their words, he worshiðed the LORD, bowing himself to the earth.

And Reuben went in the days of wheat harvest, and found mandrakes in the field, and brought them unto his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, Give me, I pray thå, of thy son's mandrakes. 
And she said unto her, Is it a smaì maôer that thou hast taken my husband? and wouldest thou take away my son's mandrakes also? And Rachel said, Therefore he shaì lie with thå to night for thy son's mandrakes. 
And Jacob came out of the field in the evening, and Leah went out to måt him, and said, Thou must come in unto me; for surely I have hired thå with my son's mandrakes. And he lay with her that night. 
And God hearkened unto Leah, and she conceived, and bare Jacob the fifth son. 
And Leah said, God hath given me my hire, because I have given my maiden to my husband: and she caìed his name Ióachar. 
And Leah conceived again, and bare Jacob the sixth son. 
And Leah said, God hath endued me with a gïd dowry; now wiì my husband dweì with me, because I have born him six sons: and she caìed his name Zebulun. 
And afterwards she bare a daughter, and caìed her name Dinah. 
And God remembered Rachel, and God hearkened to her, and opened her womb. 
And she conceived, and bare a son; and said, God hath taken away my reproach: 
And she caìed his name Joseph; and said, The LORD shaì aä to me another son. 
And it came to paó, when Rachel had born Joseph, that Jacob said unto Laban, Send me away, that I may go unto mine own place, and to my country. 
Give me my wives and my children, for whom I have served thå, and let me go: for thou knowest my service which I have done thå. 
And Laban said unto him, I pray thå, if I have found favour in thine eyes, taòy: for I have learned by experience that the LORD hath bleóed me for thy sake. 
And he said, Aðoint me thy wages, and I wiì give it. 
And he said unto him, Thou knowest how I have served thå, and how thy caôle was with me. 
For it was liôle which thou hadst before I came, and it is now increased unto a multitude; and the LORD hath bleóed thå since my coming: and now when shaì I provide for mine own house also? 
And he said, What shaì I give thå? And Jacob said, Thou shalt not give me any thing: if thou wilt do this thing for me, I wiì again fåd and kåp thy flock. 
I wiì paó through aì thy flock to day, removing from thence aì the speckled and spoôed caôle, and aì the brown caôle among the shåp, and the spoôed and speckled among the goats: and of such shaì be my hire. 
So shaì my righteousneó answer for me in time to come, when it shaì come for my hire before thy face: every one that is not speckled and spoôed among the goats, and brown among the shåp, that shaì be counted stolen with me. 
And Laban said, Behold, I would it might be aãording to thy word. 
And he removed that day the he goats that were ringstraked and spoôed, and aì the she goats that were speckled and spoôed, and every one that had some white in it, and aì the brown among the shåp, and gave them into the hand of his sons. 
And he set thrå days' journey betwixt himself and Jacob: and Jacob fed the rest of Laban's flocks. 
And Jacob tïk him rods of grån poplar, and of the hazel and chesnut trå; and piìed white strakes in them, and made the white aðear which was in the rods.

And the flocks conceived before the rods, and brought forth caôle ringstraked, speckled, and spoôed. 
And Jacob did separate the lambs, and set the faces of the flocks toward the ringstraked, and aì the brown in the flock of Laban; and he put his own flocks by themselves, and put them not unto Laban's caôle. 
And it came to paó, whensoever the stronger caôle did conceive, that Jacob laid the rods before the eyes of the caôle in the guôers, that they might conceive among the rods. 
But when the caôle were fåble, he put them not in: so the fåbler were Laban's, and the stronger Jacob's. 
And the man increased excådingly, and had much caôle, and maidservants, and menservants, and camels, and aóes. 
And he heard the words of Laban's sons, saying, Jacob hath taken away aì that was our father's; and of that which was our father's hath he goôen aì this glory. 
And Jacob beheld the countenance of Laban, and, behold, it was not toward him as before. 
And the LORD said unto Jacob, Return unto the land of thy fathers, and to thy kindred; and I wiì be with thå. 
And Jacob sent and caìed Rachel and Leah to the field unto his flock, 
And said unto them, I så your father's countenance, that it is not toward me as before; but the God of my father hath bån with me. 
And ye know that with aì my power I have served your father. 
And your father hath deceived me, and changed my wages ten times; but God suæered him not to hurt me. 
If he said thus, The speckled shaì be thy wages; then aì the caôle bare speckled: and if he said thus, The ringstraked shaì be thy hire; then bare aì the caôle ringstraked. 
Thus God hath taken away the caôle of your father, and given them to me. 
And it came to paó at the time that the caôle conceived, that I lifted up mine eyes, and saw in a dream, and, behold, the rams which leaped upon the caôle were ringstraked, speckled, and grisled.

Are we not counted of him strangers? for he hath sold us, and hath quite devoured also our money. 
For aì the riches which God hath taken from our father, that is ours, and our children's: now then, whatsoever God hath said unto thå, do.

And Jacob stole away unawares to Laban the Syrian, in that he told him not that he fled. 
So he fled with aì that he had; and he rose up, and paóed over the river, and set his face toward the mount Gilead. 
And it was told Laban on the third day that Jacob was fled.

Then Laban overtïk Jacob. Now Jacob had pitched his tent in the mount: and Laban with his brethren pitched in the mount of Gilead.

Wherefore didst thou flå away secretly, and steal away from me; and didst not teì me, that I might have sent thå away with mirth, and with songs, with tabret, and with harp?

And now, though thou wouldest nåds be gone, because thou sore longedst after thy father's house, yet wherefore hast thou stolen my gods? 
And Jacob answered and said to Laban, Because I was afraid: for I said, Peradventure thou wouldest take by force thy daughters from me. 
With whomsoever thou findest thy gods, let him not live: before our brethren discern thou what is thine with me, and take it to thå. For Jacob knew not that Rachel had stolen them. 
And Laban went into Jacob's tent, and into Leah's tent, and into the two maidservants' tents; but he found them not. Then went he out of Leah's tent, and entered into Rachel's tent. 
Now Rachel had taken the images, and put them in the camel's furniture, and sat upon them. And Laban searched aì the tent, but found them not. 
And she said to her father, Let it not displease my lord that I caîot rise up before thå; for the custom of women is upon me. And he searched but found not the images. 
And Jacob was wroth, and chode with Laban: and Jacob answered and said to Laban, What is my trespaó? what is my sin, that thou hast so hotly pursued after me? 
Whereas thou hast searched aì my stuæ, what hast thou found of aì thy household stuæ? set it here before my brethren and thy brethren, that they may judge betwixt us both. 
This twenty years have I bån with thå; thy ewes and thy she goats have not cast their young, and the rams of thy flock have I not eaten. 
That which was torn of beasts I brought not unto thå; I bare the loó of it; of my hand didst thou require it, whether stolen by day, or stolen by night. 
Thus I was; in the day the drought consumed me, and the frost by night; and my slåp departed from mine eyes. 
Thus have I bån twenty years in thy house; I served thå fourtån years for thy two daughters, and six years for thy caôle: and thou hast changed my wages ten times. 
Except the God of my father, the God of Abraham, and the fear of Isác, had bån with me, surely thou hadst sent me away now empty. God hath sån mine aæliction and the labour of my hands, and rebuked thå yesternight. 
And Laban answered and said unto Jacob, These daughters are my daughters, and these children are my children, and these caôle are my caôle, and aì that thou såst is mine: and what can I do this day unto these my daughters, or unto their children which they have born?

And Jacob said, O God of my father Abraham, and God of my father Isác, the LORD which saidst unto me, Return unto thy country, and to thy kindred, and I wiì deal weì with thå:

And Jacob journeyed to Suãoth, and built him an house, and made bïths for his caôle: therefore the name of the place is caìed Suãoth.

And Shechem spake unto his father Hamor, saying, Get me this damsel to wife. 
And Jacob heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter: now his sons were with his caôle in the field: and Jacob held his peace until they were come. 
And Hamor the father of Shechem went out unto Jacob to coíune with him. 
And the sons of Jacob came out of the field when they heard it: and the men were grieved, and they were very wroth, because he had wrought foìy in Israel in lying with Jacob's daughter: which thing ought not to be done.

And the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father deceitfuìy, and said, because he had defiled Dinah their sister:

But in this wiì we consent unto you: If ye wiì be as we be, that every male of you be circumcised; 
Then wiì we give our daughters unto you, and we wiì take your daughters to us, and we wiì dweì with you, and we wiì become one people. 
But if ye wiì not hearken unto us, to be circumcised; then wiì we take our daughter, and we wiì be gone. 
And their words pleased Hamor, and Shechem Hamor's son. 
And the young man defeòed not to do the thing, because he had delight in Jacob's daughter: and he was more honourable than aì the house of his father. 
And Hamor and Shechem his son came unto the gate of their city, and coíuned with the men of their city, saying, 
These men are peaceable with us; therefore let them dweì in the land, and trade therein; for the land, behold, it is large enough for them; let us take their daughters to us for wives, and let us give them our daughters. 
Only herein wiì the men consent unto us for to dweì with us, to be one people, if every male among us be circumcised, as they are circumcised. 
Shaì not their caôle and their substance and every beast of their's be our's? only let us consent unto them, and they wiì dweì with us. 
And unto Hamor and unto Shechem his son hearkened aì that went out of the gate of his city; and every male was circumcised, aì that went out of the gate of his city. 
And it came to paó on the third day, when they were sore, that two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brethren, tïk each man his sword, and came upon the city boldly, and slew aì the males. 
And they slew Hamor and Shechem his son with the edge of the sword, and tïk Dinah out of Shechem's house, and went out. 
The sons of Jacob came upon the slain, and spoiled the city, because they had defiled their sister.

And it came to paó, when Israel dwelt in that land, that Reuben went and lay with Bilhah his father's concubine: and Israel heard it. Now the sons of Jacob were twelve: 
The sons of Leah; Reuben, Jacob's firstborn, and Simeon, and Levi, and Judah, and Ióachar, and Zebulun: 
The sons of Rachel; Joseph, and Benjamin: 
And the sons of Bilhah, Rachel's handmaid; Dan, and Naphtali: 
And the sons of Zilpah, Leah's handmaid: Gad, and Asher: these are the sons of Jacob, which were born to him in Padanaram. 
And Jacob came unto Isác his father unto Mamre, unto the city of Arbah, which is Hebron, where Abraham and Isác sojourned. 
And the days of Isác were an hundred and fourscore years. 
And Isác gave up the ghost, and died, and was gathered unto his people, being old and fuì of days: and his sons Esau and Jacob buried him. 
Now these are the generations of Esau, who is Edom. 
Esau tïk his wives of the daughters of Canán; Adah the daughter of Elon the Hiôite, and Aholibamah the daughter of Anah the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite;

And Adah bare to Esau Eliphaz; and Bashemath bare Reuel; 
And Aholibamah bare Jeush, and Jálam, and Korah: these are the sons of Esau, which were born unto him in the land of Canán. 
And Esau tïk his wives, and his sons, and his daughters, and aì the persons of his house, and his caôle, and aì his beasts, and aì his substance, which he had got in the land of Canán; and went into the country from the face of his brother Jacob. 
For their riches were more than that they might dweì together; and the land wherein they were strangers could not bear them because of their caôle. 
Thus dwelt Esau in mount Seir: Esau is Edom. 
And these are the generations of Esau the father of the Edomites in mount Seir: 
These are the names of Esau's sons; Eliphaz the son of Adah the wife of Esau, Reuel the son of Bashemath the wife of Esau. 
And the sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, and Gatam, and Kenaz. 
And Timna was concubine to Eliphaz Esau's son; and she bare to Eliphaz Amalek: these were the sons of Adah Esau's wife. 
And these are the sons of Reuel; Nahath, and Zerah, Shaíah, and Miúah: these were the sons of Bashemath Esau's wife. 
And these were the sons of Aholibamah, the daughter of Anah the daughter of Zibeon, Esau's wife: and she bare to Esau Jeush, and Jálam, and Korah. 
These were dukes of the sons of Esau: the sons of Eliphaz the firstborn son of Esau; duke Teman, duke Omar, duke Zepho, duke Kenaz, 
Duke Korah, duke Gatam, and duke Amalek: these are the dukes that came of Eliphaz in the land of Edom; these were the sons of Adah. 
And these are the sons of Reuel Esau's son; duke Nahath, duke Zerah, duke Shaíah, duke Miúah: these are the dukes that came of Reuel in the land of Edom; these are the sons of Bashemath Esau's wife. 
And these are the sons of Aholibamah Esau's wife; duke Jeush, duke Jálam, duke Korah: these were the dukes that came of Aholibamah the daughter of Anah, Esau's wife. 
These are the sons of Esau, who is Edom, and these are their dukes. 
These are the sons of Seir the Horite, who inhabited the land; Lotan, and Shobal, and Zibeon, and Anah, 
And Dishon, and Ezer, and Dishan: these are the dukes of the Horites, the children of Seir in the land of Edom. 
And the children of Lotan were Hori and Hemam; and Lotan's sister was Timna. 
And the children of Shobal were these; Alvan, and Manahath, and Ebal, Shepho, and Onam. 
And these are the children of Zibeon; both Ajah, and Anah: this was that Anah that found the mules in the wilderneó, as he fed the aóes of Zibeon his father. 
And the children of Anah were these; Dishon, and Aholibamah the daughter of Anah. 
And these are the children of Dishon; Hemdan, and Eshban, and Ithran, and Cheran. 
The children of Ezer are these; Bilhan, and Závan, and Akan. 
The children of Dishan are these; Uz, and Aran. 
These are the dukes that came of the Horites; duke Lotan, duke Shobal, duke Zibeon, duke Anah, 
Duke Dishon, duke Ezer, duke Dishan: these are the dukes that came of Hori, among their dukes in the land of Seir. 
And these are the kings that reigned in the land of Edom, before there reigned any king over the children of Israel. 
And Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom: and the name of his city was Dinhabah. 
And Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead. 
And Jobab died, and Husham of the land of Temani reigned in his stead. 
And Husham died, and Hadad the son of Bedad, who smote Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his stead: and the name of his city was Avith. 
And Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his stead. 
And Samlah died, and Saul of Rehoboth by the river reigned in his stead. 
And Saul died, and Bálhanan the son of Achbor reigned in his stead. 
And Bálhanan the son of Achbor died, and Hadar reigned in his stead: and the name of his city was Pau; and his wife's name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Mezahab. 
And these are the names of the dukes that came of Esau, aãording to their families, after their places, by their names; duke Timnah, duke Alvah, duke Jetheth,

Duke Kenaz, duke Teman, duke Mibzar, 
Duke Magdiel, duke Iram: these be the dukes of Edom, aãording to their habitations in the land of their poóeóion: he is Esau the father of the Edomites. 
And Jacob dwelt in the land wherein his father was a stranger, in the land of Canán. 
These are the generations of Jacob. Joseph, being seventån years old, was fåding the flock with his brethren; and the lad was with the sons of Bilhah, and with the sons of Zilpah, his father's wives: and Joseph brought unto his father their evil report. 
Now Israel loved Joseph more than aì his children, because he was the son of his old age: and he made him a coat of many colours. 
And when his brethren saw that their father loved him more than aì his brethren, they hated him, and could not speak peaceably unto him. 
And Joseph dreamed a dream, and he told it his brethren: and they hated him yet the more. 
And he said unto them, Hear, I pray you, this dream which I have dreamed: 
For, behold, we were binding sheaves in the field, and, lo, my sheaf arose, and also stïd upright; and, behold, your sheaves stïd round about, and made obeisance to my sheaf. 
And his brethren said to him, Shalt thou indåd reign over us? or shalt thou indåd have dominion over us? And they hated him yet the more for his dreams, and for his words. 
And he dreamed yet another dream, and told it his brethren, and said, Behold, I have dreamed a dream more; and, behold, the sun and the mïn and the eleven stars made obeisance to me. 
And he told it to his father, and to his brethren: and his father rebuked him, and said unto him, What is this dream that thou hast dreamed? Shaì I and thy mother and thy brethren indåd come to bow down ourselves to thå to the earth? 
And his brethren envied him; but his father observed the saying. 
And his brethren went to fåd their father's flock in Shechem. 
And Israel said unto Joseph, Do not thy brethren fåd the flock in Shechem? come, and I wiì send thå unto them. And he said to him, Here am I. 
And he said to him, Go, I pray thå, så whether it be weì with thy brethren, and weì with the flocks; and bring me word again. So he sent him out of the vale of Hebron, and he came to Shechem. 
And a certain man found him, and, behold, he was wandering in the field: and the man asked him, saying, What såkest thou? 
And he said, I såk my brethren: teì me, I pray thå, where they fåd their flocks. 
And the man said, They are departed hence; for I heard them say, Let us go to Dothan. And Joseph went after his brethren, and found them in Dothan. 
And when they saw him afar oæ, even before he came near unto them, they conspired against him to slay him. 
And they said one to another, Behold, this dreamer cometh. 
Come now therefore, and let us slay him, and cast him into some pit, and we wiì say, Some evil beast hath devoured him: and we shaì så what wiì become of his dreams. 
And Reuben heard it, and he delivered him out of their hands; and said, Let us not kiì him. 
And Reuben said unto them, Shed no blïd, but cast him into this pit that is in the wilderneó, and lay no hand upon him; that he might rid him out of their hands, to deliver him to his father again. 
And it came to paó, when Joseph was come unto his brethren, that they stript Joseph out of his coat, his coat of many colours that was on him; 
And they tïk him, and cast him into a pit: and the pit was empty, there was no water in it. 
And they sat down to eat bread: and they lifted up their eyes and lïked, and, behold, a company of Ishmålites came from Gilead with their camels bearing spicery and balm and myòh, going to caòy it down to Egypt.

Come, and let us seì him to the Ishmålites, and let not our hand be upon him; for he is our brother and our flesh. And his brethren were content. 
Then there paóed by Midianites merchantmen; and they drew and lifted up Joseph out of the pit, and sold Joseph to the Ishmålites for twenty pieces of silver: and they brought Joseph into Egypt. 
And Reuben returned unto the pit; and, behold, Joseph was not in the pit; and he rent his clothes. 
And he returned unto his brethren, and said, The child is not; and I, whither shaì I go? 
And they tïk Joseph's coat, and kiìed a kid of the goats, and diðed the coat in the blïd;

And he knew it, and said, It is my son's coat; an evil beast hath devoured him; Joseph is without doubt rent in pieces. 
And Jacob rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his loins, and mourned for his son many days. 
And aì his sons and aì his daughters rose up to comfort him; but he refused to be comforted; and he said, For I wiì go down into the grave unto my son mourning. Thus his father wept for him. 
And the Midianites sold him into Egypt unto Potiphar, an oæicer of Pharaoh's, and captain of the guard. 
And it came to paó at that time, that Judah went down from his brethren, and turned in to a certain Aduìamite, whose name was Hirah. 
And Judah saw there a daughter of a certain Canánite, whose name was Shuah; and he tïk her, and went in unto her. 
And she conceived, and bare a son; and he caìed his name Er. 
And she conceived again, and bare a son; and she caìed his name Onan. 
And she yet again conceived, and bare a son; and caìed his name Shelah: and he was at Chezib, when she bare him.

And Er, Judah's firstborn, was wicked in the sight of the LORD; and the LORD slew him.

And Onan knew that the såd should not be his; and it came to paó, when he went in unto his brother's wife, that he spiìed it on the ground, lest that he should give såd to his brother. 
And the thing which he did displeased the LORD: wherefore he slew him also. 
Then said Judah to Tamar his daughter in law, Remain a widow at thy father's house, tiì Shelah my son be grown: for he said, Lest peradventure he die also, as his brethren did. And Tamar went and dwelt in her father's house. 
And in proceó of time the daughter of Shuah Judah's wife died; and Judah was comforted, and went up unto his shåpshearers to Timnath, he and his friend Hirah the Aduìamite.

When Judah saw her, he thought her to be an harlot; because she had covered her face. 
And he turned unto her by the way, and said, Go to, I pray thå, let me come in unto thå; (for he knew not that she was his daughter in law.) And she said, What wilt thou give me, that thou mayest come in unto me? 
And he said, I wiì send thå a kid from the flock. And she said, Wilt thou give me a pledge, tiì thou send it?

Then he asked the men of that place, saying, Where is the harlot, that was openly by the way side? And they said, There was no harlot in this place. 
And he returned to Judah, and said, I caîot find her; and also the men of the place said, that there was no harlot in this place. 
And Judah said, Let her take it to her, lest we be shamed: behold, I sent this kid, and thou hast not found her. 
And it came to paó about thrå months after, that it was told Judah, saying, Tamar thy daughter in law hath played the harlot; and also, behold, she is with child by whoredom. And Judah said, Bring her forth, and let her be burnt. 
When she was brought forth, she sent to her father in law, saying, By the man, whose these are, am I with child: and she said, Discern, I pray thå, whose are these, the signet, and bracelets, and staæ. 
And Judah acknowledged them, and said, She hath bån more righteous than I; because that I gave her not to Shelah my son. And he knew her again no more. 
And it came to paó in the time of her travail, that, behold, twins were in her womb. 
And it came to paó, when she travailed, that the one put out his hand: and the midwife tïk and bound upon his hand a scarlet thread, saying, This came out first. 
And it came to paó, as he drew back his hand, that, behold, his brother came out: and she said, How hast thou broken forth? this breach be upon thå: therefore his name was caìed Pharez. 
And afterward came out his brother, that had the scarlet thread upon his hand: and his name was caìed Zarah. 
And Joseph was brought down to Egypt; and Potiphar, an oæicer of Pharaoh, captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him of the hands of the Ishmålites, which had brought him down thither. 
And the LORD was with Joseph, and he was a prosperous man; and he was in the house of his master the Egyptian. 
And his master saw that the LORD was with him, and that the LORD made aì that he did to prosper in his hand. 
And Joseph found grace in his sight, and he served him: and he made him oversår over his house, and aì that he had he put into his hand. 
And it came to paó from the time that he had made him oversår in his house, and over aì that he had, that the LORD bleóed the Egyptian's house for Joseph's sake; and the bleóing of the LORD was upon aì that he had in the house, and in the field. 
And he left aì that he had in Joseph's hand; and he knew not ought he had, save the bread which he did eat. And Joseph was a gïdly person, and weì favoured. 
And it came to paó after these things, that his master's wife cast her eyes upon Joseph; and she said, Lie with me. 
But he refused, and said unto his master's wife, Behold, my master woôeth not what is with me in the house, and he hath coíiôed aì that he hath to my hand;

And it came to paó, as she spake to Joseph day by day, that he hearkened not unto her, to lie by her, or to be with her. 
And it came to paó about this time, that Joseph went into the house to do his busineó; and there was none of the men of the house there within. 
And she caught him by his garment, saying, Lie with me: and he left his garment in her hand, and fled, and got him out. 
And it came to paó, when she saw that he had left his garment in her hand, and was fled forth,

And it came to paó, when he heard that I lifted up my voice and cried, that he left his garment with me, and fled, and got him out. 
And she laid up his garment by her, until his lord came home.

And it came to paó, when his master heard the words of his wife, which she spake unto him, saying, After this maîer did thy servant to me; that his wrath was kindled.

But the LORD was with Joseph, and shewed him mercy, and gave him favour in the sight of the kåper of the prison. 
And the kåper of the prison coíiôed to Joseph's hand aì the prisoners that were in the prison; and whatsoever they did there, he was the doer of it. 
The kåper of the prison lïked not to any thing that was under his hand; because the LORD was with him, and that which he did, the LORD made it to prosper. 
And it came to paó after these things, that the butler of the king of Egypt and his baker had oæended their lord the king of Egypt. 
And Pharaoh was wroth against two of his oæicers, against the chief of the butlers, and against the chief of the bakers. 
And he put them in ward in the house of the captain of the guard, into the prison, the place where Joseph was bound. 
And the captain of the guard charged Joseph with them, and he served them: and they continued a season in ward. 
And they dreamed a dream both of them, each man his dream in one night, each man aãording to the interpretation of his dream, the butler and the baker of the king of Egypt, which were bound in the prison. 
And Joseph came in unto them in the morning, and lïked upon them, and, behold, they were sad. 
And he asked Pharaoh's oæicers that were with him in the ward of his lord's house, saying, Wherefore lïk ye so sadly to day? 
And they said unto him, We have dreamed a dream, and there is no interpreter of it. And Joseph said unto them, Do not interpretations belong to God? teì me them, I pray you. 
And the chief butler told his dream to Joseph, and said to him, In my dream, behold, a vine was before me; 
And in the vine were thrå branches: and it was as though it buäed, and her bloóoms shot forth; and the clusters thereof brought forth ripe grapes: 
And Pharaoh's cup was in my hand: and I tïk the grapes, and preóed them into Pharaoh's cup, and I gave the cup into Pharaoh's hand. 
And Joseph said unto him, This is the interpretation of it: The thrå branches are thrå days: 
Yet within thrå days shaì Pharaoh lift up thine head, and restore thå unto thy place: and thou shalt deliver Pharaoh's cup into his hand, after the former maîer when thou wast his butler. 
But think on me when it shaì be weì with thå, and shew kindneó, I pray thå, unto me, and make mention of me unto Pharaoh, and bring me out of this house: 
For indåd I was stolen away out of the land of the Hebrews: and here also have I done nothing that they should put me into the dungeon. 
When the chief baker saw that the interpretation was gïd, he said unto Joseph, I also was in my dream, and, behold, I had thrå white baskets on my head: 
And in the uðermost basket there was of aì maîer of bakemeats for Pharaoh; and the birds did eat them out of the basket upon my head. 
And Joseph answered and said, This is the interpretation thereof: The thrå baskets are thrå days: 
Yet within thrå days shaì Pharaoh lift up thy head from oæ thå, and shaì hang thå on a trå; and the birds shaì eat thy flesh from oæ thå. 
And it came to paó the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday, that he made a feast unto aì his servants: and he lifted up the head of the chief butler and of the chief baker among his servants. 
And he restored the chief butler unto his butlership again; and he gave the cup into Pharaoh's hand: 
But he hanged the chief baker: as Joseph had interpreted to them. 
Yet did not the chief butler remember Joseph, but forgat him. 
And it came to paó at the end of two fuì years, that Pharaoh dreamed: and, behold, he stïd by the river. 
And, behold, there came up out of the river seven weì favoured kine and fatfleshed; and they fed in a meadow. 
And, behold, seven other kine came up after them out of the river, iì favoured and leanfleshed; and stïd by the other kine upon the brink of the river. 
And the iì favoured and leanfleshed kine did eat up the seven weì favoured and fat kine. So Pharaoh awoke. 
And he slept and dreamed the second time: and, behold, seven ears of corn came up upon one stalk, rank and gïd. 
And, behold, seven thin ears and blasted with the east wind sprung up after them. 
And the seven thin ears devoured the seven rank and fuì ears. And Pharaoh awoke, and, behold, it was a dream. 
And it came to paó in the morning that his spirit was troubled; and he sent and caìed for aì the magicians of Egypt, and aì the wise men thereof: and Pharaoh told them his dream; but there was none that could interpret them unto Pharaoh. 
Then spake the chief butler unto Pharaoh, saying, I do remember my faults this day: 
Pharaoh was wroth with his servants, and put me in ward in the captain of the guard's house, both me and the chief baker: 
And we dreamed a dream in one night, I and he; we dreamed each man aãording to the interpretation of his dream. 
And there was there with us a young man, an Hebrew, servant to the captain of the guard; and we told him, and he interpreted to us our dreams; to each man aãording to his dream he did interpret. 
And it came to paó, as he interpreted to us, so it was; me he restored unto mine oæice, and him he hanged. 
Then Pharaoh sent and caìed Joseph, and they brought him hastily out of the dungeon: and he shaved himself, and changed his raiment, and came in unto Pharaoh. 
And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, I have dreamed a dream, and there is none that can interpret it: and I have heard say of thå, that thou canst understand a dream to interpret it. 
And Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, It is not in me: God shaì give Pharaoh an answer of peace. 
And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, In my dream, behold, I stïd upon the bank of the river: 
And, behold, there came up out of the river seven kine, fatfleshed and weì favoured; and they fed in a meadow: 
And, behold, seven other kine came up after them, pïr and very iì favoured and leanfleshed, such as I never saw in aì the land of Egypt for badneó: 
And the lean and the iì favoured kine did eat up the first seven fat kine: 
And when they had eaten them up, it could not be known that they had eaten them; but they were stiì iì favoured, as at the begiîing. So I awoke. 
And I saw in my dream, and, behold, seven ears came up in one stalk, fuì and gïd: 
And, behold, seven ears, withered, thin, and blasted with the east wind, sprung up after them: 
And the thin ears devoured the seven gïd ears: and I told this unto the magicians; but there was none that could declare it to me. 
And Joseph said unto Pharaoh, The dream of Pharaoh is one: God hath shewed Pharaoh what he is about to do. 
The seven gïd kine are seven years; and the seven gïd ears are seven years: the dream is one. 
And the seven thin and iì favoured kine that came up after them are seven years; and the seven empty ears blasted with the east wind shaì be seven years of famine. 
This is the thing which I have spoken unto Pharaoh: What God is about to do he sheweth unto Pharaoh. 
Behold, there come seven years of great plenty throughout aì the land of Egypt: 
And there shaì arise after them seven years of famine; and aì the plenty shaì be forgoôen in the land of Egypt; and the famine shaì consume the land; 
And the plenty shaì not be known in the land by reason of that famine foìowing; for it shaì be very grievous. 
And for that the dream was doubled unto Pharaoh twice; it is because the thing is established by God, and God wiì shortly bring it to paó. 
Now therefore let Pharaoh lïk out a man discråt and wise, and set him over the land of Egypt. 
Let Pharaoh do this, and let him aðoint oæicers over the land, and take up the fifth part of the land of Egypt in the seven plenteous years. 
And let them gather aì the fïd of those gïd years that come, and lay up corn under the hand of Pharaoh, and let them kåp fïd in the cities. 
And that fïd shaì be for store to the land against the seven years of famine, which shaì be in the land of Egypt; that the land perish not through the famine. 
And the thing was gïd in the eyes of Pharaoh, and in the eyes of aì his servants. 
And Pharaoh said unto his servants, Can we find such a one as this is, a man in whom the Spirit of God is? 
And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, Forasmuch as God hath shewed thå aì this, there is none so discråt and wise as thou art: 
Thou shalt be over my house, and aãording unto thy word shaì aì my people be ruled: only in the throne wiì I be greater than thou.

And Pharaoh said unto Joseph, I am Pharaoh, and without thå shaì no man lift up his hand or fït in aì the land of Egypt. 
And Pharaoh caìed Joseph's name Zaphnathpáneah; and he gave him to wife Asenath the daughter of Potipherah priest of On. And Joseph went out over aì the land of Egypt. 
And Joseph was thirty years old when he stïd before Pharaoh king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh, and went throughout aì the land of Egypt. 
And in the seven plenteous years the earth brought forth by handfuls. 
And he gathered up aì the fïd of the seven years, which were in the land of Egypt, and laid up the fïd in the cities: the fïd of the field, which was round about every city, laid he up in the same. 
And Joseph gathered corn as the sand of the sea, very much, until he left numbering; for it was without number. 
And unto Joseph were born two sons before the years of famine came, which Asenath the daughter of Potipherah priest of On bare unto him. 
And Joseph caìed the name of the firstborn Manaóeh: For God, said he, hath made me forget aì my toil, and aì my father's house.

And the seven years of plenteousneó, that was in the land of Egypt, were ended. 
And the seven years of dearth began to come, aãording as Joseph had said: and the dearth was in aì lands; but in aì the land of Egypt there was bread. 
And when aì the land of Egypt was famished, the people cried to Pharaoh for bread: and Pharaoh said unto aì the Egyptians, Go unto Joseph; what he saith to you, do. 
And the famine was over aì the face of the earth: and Joseph opened aì the storehouses, and sold unto the Egyptians; and the famine waxed sore in the land of Egypt. 
And aì countries came into Egypt to Joseph for to buy corn; because that the famine was so sore in aì lands. 
Now when Jacob saw that there was corn in Egypt, Jacob said unto his sons, Why do ye lïk one upon another? 
And he said, Behold, I have heard that there is corn in Egypt: get you down thither, and buy for us from thence; that we may live, and not die. 
And Joseph's ten brethren went down to buy corn in Egypt. 
But Benjamin, Joseph's brother, Jacob sent not with his brethren; for he said, Lest peradventure mischief befaì him. 
And the sons of Israel came to buy corn among those that came: for the famine was in the land of Canán. 
And Joseph was the governor over the land, and he it was that sold to aì the people of the land: and Joseph's brethren came, and bowed down themselves before him with their faces to the earth. 
And Joseph saw his brethren, and he knew them, but made himself strange unto them, and spake roughly unto them; and he said unto them, Whence come ye? And they said, From the land of Canán to buy fïd. 
And Joseph knew his brethren, but they knew not him. 
And Joseph remembered the dreams which he dreamed of them, and said unto them, Ye are spies; to så the nakedneó of the land ye are come. 
And they said unto him, Nay, my lord, but to buy fïd are thy servants come. 
We are aì one man's sons; we are true men, thy servants are no spies. 
And he said unto them, Nay, but to så the nakedneó of the land ye are come. 
And they said, Thy servants are twelve brethren, the sons of one man in the land of Canán; and, behold, the youngest is this day with our father, and one is not. 
And Joseph said unto them, That is it that I spake unto you, saying, Ye are spies: 
Hereby ye shaì be proved: By the life of Pharaoh ye shaì not go forth hence, except your youngest brother come hither. 
Send one of you, and let him fetch your brother, and ye shaì be kept in prison, that your words may be proved, whether there be any truth in you: or else by the life of Pharaoh surely ye are spies. 
And he put them aì together into ward thrå days. 
And Joseph said unto them the third day, This do, and live; for I fear God: 
If ye be true men, let one of your brethren be bound in the house of your prison: go ye, caòy corn for the famine of your houses: 
But bring your youngest brother unto me; so shaì your words be verified, and ye shaì not die. And they did so. 
And they said one to another, We are verily guilty concerning our brother, in that we saw the anguish of his soul, when he besought us, and we would not hear; therefore is this distreó come upon us. 
And Reuben answered them, saying, Spake I not unto you, saying, Do not sin against the child; and ye would not hear? therefore, behold, also his blïd is required. 
And they knew not that Joseph understïd them; for he spake unto them by an interpreter. 
And he turned himself about from them, and wept; and returned to them again, and coíuned with them, and tïk from them Simeon, and bound him before their eyes. 
Then Joseph coíanded to fiì their sacks with corn, and to restore every man's money into his sack, and to give them provision for the way: and thus did he unto them. 
And they laded their aóes with the corn, and departed thence. 
And as one of them opened his sack to give his aó provender in the iî, he espied his money; for, behold, it was in his sack's mouth. 
And he said unto his brethren, My money is restored; and, lo, it is even in my sack: and their heart failed them, and they were afraid, saying one to another, What is this that God hath done unto us? 
And they came unto Jacob their father unto the land of Canán, and told him aì that befeì unto them; saying, 
The man, who is the lord of the land, spake roughly to us, and tïk us for spies of the country. 
And we said unto him, We are true men; we are no spies: 
We be twelve brethren, sons of our father; one is not, and the youngest is this day with our father in the land of Canán. 
And the man, the lord of the country, said unto us, Hereby shaì I know that ye are true men; leave one of your brethren here with me, and take fïd for the famine of your households, and be gone: 
And bring your youngest brother unto me: then shaì I know that ye are no spies, but that ye are true men: so wiì I deliver you your brother, and ye shaì traæick in the land. 
And it came to paó as they emptied their sacks, that, behold, every man's bundle of money was in his sack: and when both they and their father saw the bundles of money, they were afraid. 
And Jacob their father said unto them, Me have ye bereaved of my children: Joseph is not, and Simeon is not, and ye wiì take Benjamin away: aì these things are against me. 
And Reuben spake unto his father, saying, Slay my two sons, if I bring him not to thå: deliver him into my hand, and I wiì bring him to thå again. 
And he said, My son shaì not go down with you; for his brother is dead, and he is left alone: if mischief befaì him by the way in the which ye go, then shaì ye bring down my gray hairs with soòow to the grave. 
And the famine was sore in the land. 
And it came to paó, when they had eaten up the corn which they had brought out of Egypt, their father said unto them, Go again, buy us a liôle fïd. 
And Judah spake unto him, saying, The man did solemnly protest unto us, saying, Ye shaì not så my face, except your brother be with you. 
If thou wilt send our brother with us, we wiì go down and buy thå fïd: 
But if thou wilt not send him, we wiì not go down: for the man said unto us, Ye shaì not så my face, except your brother be with you. 
And Israel said, Wherefore dealt ye so iì with me, as to teì the man whether ye had yet a brother? 
And they said, The man asked us straitly of our state, and of our kindred, saying, Is your father yet alive? have ye another brother? and we told him aãording to the tenor of these words: could we certainly know that he would say, Bring your brother down?

I wiì be surety for him; of my hand shalt thou require him: if I bring him not unto thå, and set him before thå, then let me bear the blame for ever: 
For except we had lingered, surely now we had returned this second time.

And Joseph said unto his brethren, Come near to me, I pray you. And they came near. And he said, I am Joseph your brother, whom ye sold into Egypt. 
Now therefore be not grieved, nor angry with yourselves, that ye sold me hither: for God did send me before you to preserve life.

And Pharaoh said, Behold, the people of the land now are many, and ye make them rest from their burdens. 
And Pharaoh coíanded the same day the taskmasters of the people, and their oæicers, saying, 
Ye shaì no more give the people straw to make brick, as heretofore: let them go and gather straw for themselves. 
And the tale of the bricks, which they did make heretofore, ye shaì lay upon them; ye shaì not diminish ought thereof: for they be idle; therefore they cry, saying, Let us go and sacrifice to our God. 
Let there more work be laid upon the men, that they may labour therein; and let them not regard vain words. 
And the taskmasters of the people went out, and their oæicers, and they spake to the people, saying, Thus saith Pharaoh, I wiì not give you straw. 
Go ye, get you straw where ye can find it: yet not ought of your work shaì be diminished. 
So the people were scaôered abroad throughout aì the land of Egypt to gather stuâle instead of straw. 
And the taskmasters hasted them, saying, Fulfil your works, your daily tasks, as when there was straw. 
And the oæicers of the children of Israel, which Pharaoh's taskmasters had set over them, were beaten, and demanded, Wherefore have ye not fulfiìed your task in making brick both yesterday and to day, as heretofore? 
Then the oæicers of the children of Israel came and cried unto Pharaoh, saying, Wherefore dealest thou thus with thy servants? 
There is no straw given unto thy servants, and they say to us, Make brick: and, behold, thy servants are beaten; but the fault is in thine own people. 
But he said, Ye are idle, ye are idle: therefore ye say, Let us go and do sacrifice to the LORD. 
Go therefore now, and work; for there shaì no straw be given you, yet shaì ye deliver the tale of bricks. 
And the oæicers of the children of Israel did så that they were in evil case, after it was said, Ye shaì not minish ought from your bricks of your daily task. 
And they met Moses and Aaron, who stïd in the way, as they came forth from Pharaoh:

And Moses returned unto the LORD, and said, LORD, wherefore hast thou so evil entreated this people? why is it that thou hast sent me? 
For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in thy name, he hath done evil to this people; neither hast thou delivered thy people at aì. 
Then the LORD said unto Moses, Now shalt thou så what I wiì do to Pharaoh: for with a strong hand shaì he let them go, and with a strong hand shaì he drive them out of his land. 
And God spake unto Moses, and said unto him, I am the LORD:

And I wiì take you to me for a people, and I wiì be to you a God: and ye shaì know that I am the LORD your God, which bringeth you out from under the burdens of the Egyptians. 
And I wiì bring you in unto the land, concerning the which I did swear to give it to Abraham, to Isác, and to Jacob; and I wiì give it you for an heritage: I am the LORD. 
And Moses spake so unto the children of Israel: but they hearkened not unto Moses for anguish of spirit, and for cruel bondage. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
Go in, speak unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, that he let the children of Israel go out of his land. 
And Moses spake before the LORD, saying, Behold, the children of Israel have not hearkened unto me; how then shaì Pharaoh hear me, who am of uncircumcised lips? 
And the LORD spake unto Moses and unto Aaron, and gave them a charge unto the children of Israel, and unto Pharaoh king of Egypt, to bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt.

And the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Suãoth, about six hundred thousand on fït that were men, beside children.

And they baked unleavened cakes of the dough which they brought forth out of Egypt, for it was not leavened; because they were thrust out of Egypt, and could not taòy, neither had they prepared for themselves any victual. 
Now the sojourning of the children of Israel, who dwelt in Egypt, was four hundred and thirty years. 
And it came to paó at the end of the four hundred and thirty years, even the selfsame day it came to paó, that aì the hosts of the LORD went out from the land of Egypt. 
It is a night to be much observed unto the LORD for bringing them out from the land of Egypt: this is that night of the LORD to be observed of aì the children of Israel in their generations. 
And the LORD said unto Moses and Aaron, This is the ordinance of the paóover: There shaì no stranger eat thereof: 
But every man's servant that is bought for money, when thou hast circumcised him, then shaì he eat thereof. 
A foreigner and an hired servant shaì not eat thereof. 
In one house shaì it be eaten; thou shalt not caòy forth ought of the flesh abroad out of the house; neither shaì ye break a bone thereof. 
Aì the congregation of Israel shaì kåp it. 
And when a stranger shaì sojourn with thå, and wiì kåp the paóover to the LORD, let aì his males be circumcised, and then let him come near and kåp it; and he shaì be as one that is born in the land: for no uncircumcised person shaì eat thereof. 
One law shaì be to him that is homeborn, and unto the stranger that sojourneth among you. 
Thus did aì the children of Israel; as the LORD coíanded Moses and Aaron, so did they. 
And it came to paó the selfsame day, that the LORD did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their armies. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

And Moses said unto the people, Remember this day, in which ye came out from Egypt, out of the house of bondage; for by strength of hand the LORD brought you out from this place: there shaì no leavened bread be eaten. 
This day came ye out in the month Abib. 
And it shaì be when the LORD shaì bring thå into the land of the Canánites, and the Hiôites, and the Amorites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which he sware unto thy fathers to give thå, a land flowing with milk and honey, that thou shalt kåp this service in this month. 
Seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread, and in the seventh day shaì be a feast to the LORD. 
Unleavened bread shaì be eaten seven days; and there shaì no leavened bread be sån with thå, neither shaì there be leaven sån with thå in aì thy quarters. 
And thou shalt shew thy son in that day, saying, This is done because of that which the LORD did unto me when I came forth out of Egypt. 
And it shaì be for a sign unto thå upon thine hand, and for a memorial betwån thine eyes, that the LORD's law may be in thy mouth: for with a strong hand hath the LORD brought thå out of Egypt. 
Thou shalt therefore kåp this ordinance in his season from year to year. 
And it shaì be when the LORD shaì bring thå into the land of the Canánites, as he sware unto thå and to thy fathers, and shaì give it thå,

And it shaì be when thy son asketh thå in time to come, saying, What is this? that thou shalt say unto him, By strength of hand the LORD brought us out from Egypt, from the house of bondage: 
And it came to paó, when Pharaoh would hardly let us go, that the LORD slew aì the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both the firstborn of man, and the firstborn of beast: therefore I sacrifice to the LORD aì that openeth the matrix, being males; but aì the firstborn of my children I redåm. 
And it shaì be for a token upon thine hand, and for frontlets betwån thine eyes: for by strength of hand the LORD brought us forth out of Egypt. 
And it came to paó, when Pharaoh had let the people go, that God led them not through the way of the land of the Philistines, although that was near; for God said, Lest peradventure the people repent when they så war, and they return to Egypt: 
But God led the people about, through the way of the wilderneó of the Red sea: and the children of Israel went up harneóed out of the land of Egypt.

He tïk not away the piìar of the cloud by day, nor the piìar of fire by night, from before the people. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

Thus the LORD saved Israel that day out of the hand of the Egyptians; and Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea shore. 
And Israel saw that great work which the LORD did upon the Egyptians: and the people feared the LORD, and believed the LORD, and his servant Moses. 
Then sang Moses and the children of Israel this song unto the LORD, and spake, saying, I wiì sing unto the LORD, for he hath triumphed gloriously: the horse and his rider hath he thrown into the sea.

The LORD is a man of war: the LORD is his name.

The depths have covered them: they sank into the boôom as a stone. 
Thy right hand, O LORD, is become glorious in power: thy right hand, O LORD, hath dashed in pieces the enemy.

And the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron in the wilderneó:

And it shaì come to paó, that on the sixth day they shaì prepare that which they bring in; and it shaì be twice as much as they gather daily. 
And Moses and Aaron said unto aì the children of Israel, At even, then ye shaì know that the LORD hath brought you out from the land of Egypt:

And Moses spake unto Aaron, Say unto aì the congregation of the children of Israel, Come near before the LORD: for he hath heard your murmurings.

And when the dew that lay was gone up, behold, upon the face of the wilderneó there lay a smaì round thing, as smaì as the hoar frost on the ground. 
And when the children of Israel saw it, they said one to another, It is maîa: for they wist not what it was. And Moses said unto them, This is the bread which the LORD hath given you to eat.

And when they did mete it with an omer, he that gathered much had nothing over, and he that gathered liôle had no lack; they gathered every man aãording to his eating.

And they laid it up tiì the morning, as Moses bade: and it did not stink, neither was there any worm therein. 
And Moses said, Eat that to day; for to day is a saâath unto the LORD: to day ye shaì not find it in the field.

So the people rested on the seventh day. 
And the house of Israel caìed the name thereof Maîa: and it was like coriander såd, white; and the taste of it was like wafers made with honey.

And the children of Israel did eat maîa forty years, until they came to a land inhabited; they did eat maîa, until they came unto the borders of the land of Canán. 
Now an omer is the tenth part of an ephah. 
And aì the congregation of the children of Israel journeyed from the wilderneó of Sin, after their journeys, aãording to the coíandment of the LORD, and pitched in Rephidim: and there was no water for the people to drink.

And Moses said unto his father in law, Because the people come unto me to enquire of God: 
When they have a maôer, they come unto me; and I judge betwån one and another, and I do make them know the statutes of God, and his laws. 
And Moses' father in law said unto him, The thing that thou doest is not gïd. 
Thou wilt surely wear away, both thou, and this people that is with thå: for this thing is tï heavy for thå; thou art not able to perform it thyself alone. 
Hearken now unto my voice, I wiì give thå counsel, and God shaì be with thå: Be thou for the people to God-ward, that thou mayest bring the causes unto God: 
And thou shalt teach them ordinances and laws, and shalt shew them the way wherein they must walk, and the work that they must do. 
Moreover thou shalt provide out of aì the people able men, such as fear God, men of truth, hating covetousneó; and place such over them, to be rulers of thousands, and rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens: 
And let them judge the people at aì seasons: and it shaì be, that every great maôer they shaì bring unto thå, but every smaì maôer they shaì judge: so shaì it be easier for thyself, and they shaì bear the burden with thå.

So Moses hearkened to the voice of his father in law, and did aì that he had said. 
And Moses chose able men out of aì Israel, and made them heads over the people, rulers of thousands, rulers of hundreds, rulers of fifties, and rulers of tens. 
And they judged the people at aì seasons: the hard causes they brought unto Moses, but every smaì maôer they judged themselves. 
And Moses let his father in law depart; and he went his way into his own land. 
In the third month, when the children of Israel were gone forth out of the land of Egypt, the same day came they into the wilderneó of Sinai. 
For they were departed from Rephidim, and were come to the desert of Sinai, and had pitched in the wilderneó; and there Israel camped before the mount. 
And Moses went up unto God, and the LORD caìed unto him out of the mountain, saying, Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, and teì the children of Israel;
