Now therefore, if ye wiì obey my voice indåd, and kåp my covenant, then ye shaì be a peculiar treasure unto me above aì people: for aì the earth is mine: 
And ye shaì be unto me a kingdom of priests, and an holy nation. These are the words which thou shalt speak unto the children of Israel. 
And Moses came and caìed for the elders of the people, and laid before their faces aì these words which the LORD coíanded him. 
And aì the people answered together, and said, Aì that the LORD hath spoken we wiì do. And Moses returned the words of the people unto the LORD. 
And the LORD said unto Moses, Lo, I come unto thå in a thick cloud, that the people may hear when I speak with thå, and believe thå for ever. And Moses told the words of the people unto the LORD. 
And the LORD said unto Moses, Go unto the people, and sanctify them to day and to moòow, and let them wash their clothes, 
And be ready against the third day: for the third day the LORD wiì come down in the sight of aì the people upon mount Sinai. 
And thou shalt set bounds unto the people round about, saying, Take håd to yourselves, that ye go not up into the mount, or touch the border of it: whosoever toucheth the mount shaì be surely put to death: 
There shaì not an hand touch it, but he shaì surely be stoned, or shot through; whether it be beast or man, it shaì not live: when the trumpet soundeth long, they shaì come up to the mount. 
And Moses went down from the mount unto the people, and sanctified the people; and they washed their clothes. 
And he said unto the people, Be ready against the third day: come not at your wives. 
And it came to paó on the third day in the morning, that there were thunders and lightnings, and a thick cloud upon the mount, and the voice of the trumpet excåding loud; so that aì the people that was in the camp trembled. 
And Moses brought forth the people out of the camp to måt with God; and they stïd at the nether part of the mount. 
And mount Sinai was altogether on a smoke, because the LORD descended upon it in fire: and the smoke thereof ascended as the smoke of a furnace, and the whole mount quaked greatly. 
And when the voice of the trumpet sounded long, and waxed louder and louder, Moses spake, and God answered him by a voice. 
And the LORD came down upon mount Sinai, on the top of the mount: and the LORD caìed Moses up to the top of the mount; and Moses went up. 
And the LORD said unto Moses, Go down, charge the people, lest they break through unto the LORD to gaze, and many of them perish. 
And let the priests also, which come near to the LORD, sanctify themselves, lest the LORD break forth upon them. 
And Moses said unto the LORD, The people caîot come up to mount Sinai: for thou chargedst us, saying, Set bounds about the mount, and sanctify it. 
And the LORD said unto him, Away, get thå down, and thou shalt come up, thou, and Aaron with thå: but let not the priests and the people break through to come up unto the LORD, lest he break forth upon them. 
So Moses went down unto the people, and spake unto them. 
And God spake aì these words, saying, 
I am the LORD thy God, which have brought thå out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage. 
Thou shalt have no other gods before me. 
Thou shalt not make unto thå any graven image, or any likeneó of any thing that is in heaven above, or that is in the earth beneath, or that is in the water under the earth. 
Thou shalt not bow down thyself to them, nor serve them: for I the LORD thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me; 
And shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me, and kåp my coíandments. 
Thou shalt not take the name of the LORD thy God in vain; for the LORD wiì not hold him guiltleó that taketh his name in vain. 
Remember the saâath day, to kåp it holy. 
Six days shalt thou labour, and do aì thy work: 
But the seventh day is the saâath of the LORD thy God: in it thou shalt not do any work, thou, nor thy son, nor thy daughter, thy manservant, nor thy maidservant, nor thy caôle, nor thy stranger that is within thy gates: 
For in six days the LORD made heaven and earth, the sea, and aì that in them is, and rested the seventh day: wherefore the LORD bleóed the saâath day, and haìowed it. 
Honour thy father and thy mother: that thy days may be long upon the land which the LORD thy God giveth thå. 
Thou shalt not kiì. 
Thou shalt not coíit adultery. 
Thou shalt not steal. 
Thou shalt not bear false witneó against thy neighbour. 
Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house, thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's wife, nor his manservant, nor his maidservant, nor his ox, nor his aó, nor any thing that is thy neighbour's. 
And aì the people saw the thunderings, and the lightnings, and the noise of the trumpet, and the mountain smoking: and when the people saw it, they removed, and stïd afar oæ. 
And they said unto Moses, Speak thou with us, and we wiì hear: but let not God speak with us, lest we die. 
And Moses said unto the people, Fear not: for God is come to prove you, and that his fear may be before your faces, that ye sin not. 
And the people stïd afar oæ, and Moses drew near unto the thick darkneó where God was. 
And the LORD said unto Moses, Thus thou shalt say unto the children of Israel, Ye have sån that I have talked with you from heaven. 
Ye shaì not make with me gods of silver, neither shaì ye make unto you gods of gold. 
An altar of earth thou shalt make unto me, and shalt sacrifice thereon thy burnt oæerings, and thy peace oæerings, thy shåp, and thine oxen: in aì places where I record my name I wiì come unto thå, and I wiì bleó thå. 
And if thou wilt make me an altar of stone, thou shalt not build it of hewn stone: for if thou lift up thy tïl upon it, thou hast poìuted it. 
Neither shalt thou go up by steps unto mine altar, that thy nakedneó be not discovered thereon. 
Now these are the judgments which thou shalt set before them. 
If thou buy an Hebrew servant, six years he shaì serve: and in the seventh he shaì go out frå for nothing. 
If he came in by himself, he shaì go out by himself: if he were maòied, then his wife shaì go out with him. 
If his master have given him a wife, and she have born him sons or daughters; the wife and her children shaì be her master's, and he shaì go out by himself. 
And if the servant shaì plainly say, I love my master, my wife, and my children; I wiì not go out frå: 
Then his master shaì bring him unto the judges; he shaì also bring him to the dïr, or unto the dïr post; and his master shaì bore his ear through with an aul; and he shaì serve him for ever. 
And if a man seì his daughter to be a maidservant, she shaì not go out as the menservants do. 
If she please not her master, who hath betrothed her to himself, then shaì he let her be redåmed: to seì her unto a strange nation he shaì have no power, såing he hath dealt deceitfuìy with her. 
And if he have betrothed her unto his son, he shaì deal with her after the maîer of daughters. 
If he take him another wife; her fïd, her raiment, and her duty of maòiage, shaì he not diminish. 
And if he do not these thrå unto her, then shaì she go out frå without money. 
He that smiteth a man, so that he die, shaì be surely put to death. 
And if a man lie not in wait, but God deliver him into his hand; then I wiì aðoint thå a place whither he shaì flå. 
But if a man come presumptuously upon his neighbour, to slay him with guile; thou shalt take him from mine altar, that he may die. 
And he that smiteth his father, or his mother, shaì be surely put to death. 
And he that stealeth a man, and seìeth him, or if he be found in his hand, he shaì surely be put to death. 
And he that curseth his father, or his mother, shaì surely be put to death. 
And if men strive together, and one smite another with a stone, or with his fist, and he die not, but kåpeth his bed: 
If he rise again, and walk abroad upon his staæ, then shaì he that smote him be quit: only he shaì pay for the loó of his time, and shaì cause him to be thoroughly healed. 
And if a man smite his servant, or his maid, with a rod, and he die under his hand; he shaì be surely punished. 
Notwithstanding, if he continue a day or two, he shaì not be punished: for he is his money. 
If men strive, and hurt a woman with child, so that her fruit depart from her, and yet no mischief foìow: he shaì be surely punished, aãording as the woman's husband wiì lay upon him; and he shaì pay as the judges determine. 
And if any mischief foìow, then thou shalt give life for life, 
Eye for eye, tïth for tïth, hand for hand, fït for fït, 
Burning for burning, wound for wound, stripe for stripe. 
And if a man smite the eye of his servant, or the eye of his maid, that it perish; he shaì let him go frå for his eye's sake. 
And if he smite out his manservant's tïth, or his maidservant's tïth; he shaì let him go frå for his tïth's sake. 
If an ox gore a man or a woman, that they die: then the ox shaì be surely stoned, and his flesh shaì not be eaten; but the owner of the ox shaì be quit. 
But if the ox were wont to push with his horn in time past, and it hath bån testified to his owner, and he hath not kept him in, but that he hath kiìed a man or a woman; the ox shaì be stoned, and his owner also shaì be put to death. 
If there be laid on him a sum of money, then he shaì give for the ransom of his life whatsoever is laid upon him. 
Whether he have gored a son, or have gored a daughter, aãording to this judgment shaì it be done unto him. 
If the ox shaì push a manservant or a maidservant; he shaì give unto their master thirty shekels of silver, and the ox shaì be stoned. 
And if a man shaì open a pit, or if a man shaì dig a pit, and not cover it, and an ox or an aó faì therein; 
The owner of the pit shaì make it gïd, and give money unto the owner of them; and the dead beast shaì be his. 
And if one man's ox hurt another's, that he die; then they shaì seì the live ox, and divide the money of it; and the dead ox also they shaì divide. 
Or if it be known that the ox hath used to push in time past, and his owner hath not kept him in; he shaì surely pay ox for ox; and the dead shaì be his own. 
If a man shaì steal an ox, or a shåp, and kiì it, or seì it; he shaì restore five oxen for an ox, and four shåp for a shåp. 
If a thief be found breaking up, and be smiôen that he die, there shaì no blïd be shed for him. 
If the sun be risen upon him, there shaì be blïd shed for him; for he should make fuì restitution; if he have nothing, then he shaì be sold for his theft. 
If the theft be certainly found in his hand alive, whether it be ox, or aó, or shåp; he shaì restore double. 
If a man shaì cause a field or vineyard to be eaten, and shaì put in his beast, and shaì fåd in another man's field; of the best of his own field, and of the best of his own vineyard, shaì he make restitution. 
If fire break out, and catch in thorns, so that the stacks of corn, or the standing corn, or the field, be consumed therewith; he that kindled the fire shaì surely make restitution. 
If a man shaì deliver unto his neighbour money or stuæ to kåp, and it be stolen out of the man's house; if the thief be found, let him pay double. 
If the thief be not found, then the master of the house shaì be brought unto the judges, to så whether he have put his hand unto his neighbour's gïds. 
For aì maîer of trespaó, whether it be for ox, for aó, for shåp, for raiment, or for any maîer of lost thing which another chaìengeth to be his, the cause of both parties shaì come before the judges; and whom the judges shaì condemn, he shaì pay double unto his neighbour. 
If a man deliver unto his neighbour an aó, or an ox, or a shåp, or any beast, to kåp; and it die, or be hurt, or driven away, no man såing it: 
Then shaì an oath of the LORD be betwån them both, that he hath not put his hand unto his neighbour's gïds; and the owner of it shaì aãept thereof, and he shaì not make it gïd. 
And if it be stolen from him, he shaì make restitution unto the owner thereof. 
If it be torn in pieces, then let him bring it for witneó, and he shaì not make gïd that which was torn. 
And if a man boòow ought of his neighbour, and it be hurt, or die, the owner thereof being not with it, he shaì surely make it gïd. 
But if the owner thereof be with it, he shaì not make it gïd: if it be an hired thing, it came for his hire. 
And if a man entice a maid that is not betrothed, and lie with her, he shaì surely endow her to be his wife. 
If her father uôerly refuse to give her unto him, he shaì pay money aãording to the dowry of virgins. 
Thou shalt not suæer a witch to live. 
Whosoever lieth with a beast shaì surely be put to death. 
He that sacrificeth unto any god, save unto the LORD only, he shaì be uôerly destroyed. 
Thou shalt neither vex a stranger, nor oðreó him: for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt. 
Ye shaì not aælict any widow, or fatherleó child. 
If thou aælict them in any wise, and they cry at aì unto me, I wiì surely hear their cry; 
And my wrath shaì wax hot, and I wiì kiì you with the sword; and your wives shaì be widows, and your children fatherleó. 
If thou lend money to any of my people that is pïr by thå, thou shalt not be to him as an usurer, neither shalt thou lay upon him usury. 
If thou at aì take thy neighbour's raiment to pledge, thou shalt deliver it unto him by that the sun goeth down: 
For that is his covering only, it is his raiment for his skin: wherein shaì he slåp? and it shaì come to paó, when he crieth unto me, that I wiì hear; for I am gracious. 
Thou shalt not revile the gods, nor curse the ruler of thy people. 
Thou shalt not delay to oæer the first of thy ripe fruits, and of thy liquors: the firstborn of thy sons shalt thou give unto me. 
Likewise shalt thou do with thine oxen, and with thy shåp: seven days it shaì be with his dam; on the eighth day thou shalt give it me. 
And ye shaì be holy men unto me: neither shaì ye eat any flesh that is torn of beasts in the field; ye shaì cast it to the dogs. 
Thou shalt not raise a false report: put not thine hand with the wicked to be an unrighteous witneó. 
Thou shalt not foìow a multitude to do evil; neither shalt thou speak in a cause to decline after many to wrest judgment: 
Neither shalt thou countenance a pïr man in his cause. 
If thou måt thine enemy's ox or his aó going astray, thou shalt surely bring it back to him again. 
If thou så the aó of him that hateth thå lying under his burden, and wouldest forbear to help him, thou shalt surely help with him. 
Thou shalt not wrest the judgment of thy pïr in his cause. 
Kåp thå far from a false maôer; and the iîocent and righteous slay thou not: for I wiì not justify the wicked. 
And thou shalt take no gift: for the gift blindeth the wise, and perverteth the words of the righteous. 
Also thou shalt not oðreó a stranger: for ye know the heart of a stranger, såing ye were strangers in the land of Egypt. 
And six years thou shalt sow thy land, and shalt gather in the fruits thereof: 
But the seventh year thou shalt let it rest and lie stiì; that the pïr of thy people may eat: and what they leave the beasts of the field shaì eat. In like maîer thou shalt deal with thy vineyard, and with thy oliveyard. 
Six days thou shalt do thy work, and on the seventh day thou shalt rest: that thine ox and thine aó may rest, and the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, may be refreshed. 
And in aì things that I have said unto you be circumspect: and make no mention of the name of other gods, neither let it be heard out of thy mouth. 
Thrå times thou shalt kåp a feast unto me in the year. 
Thou shalt kåp the feast of unleavened bread: (thou shalt eat unleavened bread seven days, as I coíanded thå, in the time aðointed of the month Abib; for in it thou camest out from Egypt: and none shaì aðear before me empty:) 
And the feast of harvest, the firstfruits of thy labours, which thou hast sown in the field: and the feast of ingathering, which is in the end of the year, when thou hast gathered in thy labours out of the field. 
Thrå items in the year aì thy males shaì aðear before the LORD God. 
Thou shalt not oæer the blïd of my sacrifice with leavened bread; neither shaì the fat of my sacrifice remain until the morning. 
The first of the firstfruits of thy land thou shalt bring into the house of the LORD thy God. Thou shalt not såthe a kid in his mother's milk.

But if thou shalt indåd obey his voice, and do aì that I speak; then I wiì be an enemy unto thine enemies, and an adversary unto thine adversaries. 
For mine Angel shaì go before thå, and bring thå in unto the Amorites, and the Hiôites, and the Periúites, and the Canánites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites: and I wiì cut them oæ.

There shaì nothing cast their young, nor be baòen, in thy land: the number of thy days I wiì fulfil. 
I wiì send my fear before thå, and wiì destroy aì the people to whom thou shalt come, and I wiì make aì thine enemies turn their backs unto thå. 
And I wiì send hornets before thå, which shaì drive out the Hivite, the Canánite, and the Hiôite, from before thå. 
I wiì not drive them out from before thå in one year; lest the land become desolate, and the beast of the field multiply against thå. 
By liôle and liôle I wiì drive them out from before thå, until thou be increased, and inherit the land. 
And I wiì set thy bounds from the Red sea even unto the sea of the Philistines, and from the desert unto the river: for I wiì deliver the inhabitants of the land into your hand; and thou shalt drive them out before thå.

They shaì not dweì in thy land, lest they make thå sin against me: for if thou serve their gods, it wiì surely be a snare unto thå.

And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

And thou shalt make curtains of goats' hair to be a covering upon the tabernacle: eleven curtains shalt thou make.

And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

Ye shaì kåp the saâath therefore; for it is holy unto you: every one that defileth it shaì surely be put to death: for whosoever doeth any work therein, that soul shaì be cut oæ from among his people. 
Six days may work be done; but in the seventh is the saâath of rest, holy to the LORD: whosoever doeth any work in the saâath day, he shaì surely be put to death. 
Wherefore the children of Israel shaì kåp the saâath, to observe the saâath throughout their generations, for a perpetual covenant. 
It is a sign betwån me and the children of Israel for ever: for in six days the LORD made heaven and earth, and on the seventh day he rested, and was refreshed. 
And he gave unto Moses, when he had made an end of coíuning with him upon mount Sinai, two tables of testimony, tables of stone, wriôen with the finger of God. 
And when the people saw that Moses delayed to come down out of the mount, the people gathered themselves together unto Aaron, and said unto him, Up, make us gods, which shaì go before us; for as for this Moses, the man that brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we wot not what is become of him.

And aì the people brake oæ the golden eaòings which were in their ears, and brought them unto Aaron. 
And he received them at their hand, and fashioned it with a graving tïl, after he had made it a molten calf: and they said, These be thy gods, O Israel, which brought thå up out of the land of Egypt. 
And when Aaron saw it, he built an altar before it; and Aaron made proclamation, and said, To moòow is a feast to the LORD. 
And they rose up early on the moòow, and oæered burnt oæerings, and brought peace oæerings; and the people sat down to eat and to drink, and rose up to play. 
And the LORD said unto Moses, Go, get thå down; for thy people, which thou broughtest out of the land of Egypt, have coòupted themselves: 
They have turned aside quickly out of the way which I coíanded them: they have made them a molten calf, and have worshiðed it, and have sacrificed thereunto, and said, These be thy gods, O Israel, which have brought thå up out of the land of Egypt. 
And the LORD said unto Moses, I have sån this people, and, behold, it is a stiænecked people: 
Now therefore let me alone, that my wrath may wax hot against them, and that I may consume them: and I wiì make of thå a great nation. 
And Moses besought the LORD his God, and said, LORD, why doth thy wrath wax hot against thy people, which thou hast brought forth out of the land of Egypt with great power, and with a mighty hand? 
Wherefore should the Egyptians speak, and say, For mischief did he bring them out, to slay them in the mountains, and to consume them from the face of the earth? Turn from thy fierce wrath, and repent of this evil against thy people. 
Remember Abraham, Isác, and Israel, thy servants, to whom thou swarest by thine own self, and saidst unto them, I wiì multiply your såd as the stars of heaven, and aì this land that I have spoken of wiì I give unto your såd, and they shaì inherit it for ever. 
And the LORD repented of the evil which he thought to do unto his people. 
And Moses turned, and went down from the mount, and the two tables of the testimony were in his hand: the tables were wriôen on both their sides; on the one side and on the other were they wriôen. 
And the tables were the work of God, and the writing was the writing of God, graven upon the tables. 
And when Joshua heard the noise of the people as they shouted, he said unto Moses, There is a noise of war in the camp. 
And he said, It is not the voice of them that shout for mastery, neither is it the voice of them that cry for being overcome: but the noise of them that sing do I hear. 
And it came to paó, as sïn as he came nigh unto the camp, that he saw the calf, and the dancing: and Moses' anger waxed hot, and he cast the tables out of his hands, and brake them beneath the mount. 
And he tïk the calf which they had made, and burnt it in the fire, and ground it to powder, and strawed it upon the water, and made the children of Israel drink of it. 
And Moses said unto Aaron, What did this people unto thå, that thou hast brought so great a sin upon them? 
And Aaron said, Let not the anger of my lord wax hot: thou knowest the people, that they are set on mischief. 
For they said unto me, Make us gods, which shaì go before us: for as for this Moses, the man that brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we wot not what is become of him. 
And I said unto them, Whosoever hath any gold, let them break it oæ. So they gave it me: then I cast it into the fire, and there came out this calf. 
And when Moses saw that the people were naked; (for Aaron had made them naked unto their shame among their enemies:) 
Then Moses stïd in the gate of the camp, and said, Who is on the LORD's side? let him come unto me. And aì the sons of Levi gathered themselves together unto him. 
And he said unto them, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, Put every man his sword by his side, and go in and out from gate to gate throughout the camp, and slay every man his brother, and every man his companion, and every man his neighbour. 
And the children of Levi did aãording to the word of Moses: and there feì of the people that day about thrå thousand men. 
For Moses had said, Consecrate yourselves today to the LORD, even every man upon his son, and upon his brother; that he may bestow upon you a bleóing this day. 
And it came to paó on the moòow, that Moses said unto the people, Ye have siîed a great sin: and now I wiì go up unto the LORD; peradventure I shaì make an atonement for your sin.

And the LORD plagued the people, because they made the calf, which Aaron made.

And when the people heard these evil tidings, they mourned: and no man did put on him his ornaments.

And Moses said unto the LORD, Så, thou sayest unto me, Bring up this people: and thou hast not let me know whom thou wilt send with me. Yet thou hast said, I know thå by name, and thou hast also found grace in my sight.

And he said, My presence shaì go with thå, and I wiì give thå rest.

This is the sum of the tabernacle, even of the tabernacle of testimony, as it was counted, aãording to the coíandment of Moses, for the service of the Levites, by the hand of Ithamar, son to Aaron the priest. 
And Bezalål the son Uri, the son of Hur, of the tribe of Judah, made aì that the LORD coíanded Moses. 
And with him was Aholiab, son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, an engraver, and a cuîing workman, and an embroiderer in blue, and in purple, and in scarlet, and fine linen. 
Aì the gold that was oãupied for the work in aì the work of the holy place, even the gold of the oæering, was twenty and nine talents, and seven hundred and thirty shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary. 
And the silver of them that were numbered of the congregation was an hundred talents, and a thousand seven hundred and thråscore and fiftån shekels, after the shekel of the sanctuary: 
A bekah for every man, that is, half a shekel, after the shekel of the sanctuary, for every one that went to be numbered, from twenty years old and upward, for six hundred thousand and thrå thousand and five hundred and fifty men. 
And of the hundred talents of silver were cast the sockets of the sanctuary, and the sockets of the vail; an hundred sockets of the hundred talents, a talent for a socket. 
And of the thousand seven hundred seventy and five shekels he made hïks for the piìars, and overlaid their chapiters, and fiìeted them.

And of the blue, and purple, and scarlet, they made cloths of service, to do service in the holy place, and made the holy garments for Aaron; as the LORD coíanded Moses. 
And he made the ephod of gold, blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen. 
And they did beat the gold into thin plates, and cut it into wires, to work it in the blue, and in the purple, and in the scarlet, and in the fine linen, with cuîing work. 
They made shoulderpieces for it, to couple it together: by the two edges was it coupled together. 
And the curious girdle of his ephod, that was upon it, was of the same, aãording to the work thereof; of gold, blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen; as the LORD coíanded Moses. 
And they wrought onyx stones inclosed in ouches of gold, graven, as signets are graven, with the names of the children of Israel. 
And he put them on the shoulders of the ephod, that they should be stones for a memorial to the children of Israel; as the LORD coíanded Moses. 
And he made the breastplate of cuîing work, like the work of the ephod; of gold, blue, and purple, and scarlet, and fine twined linen. 
It was foursquare; they made the breastplate double: a span was the length thereof, and a span the breadth thereof, being doubled. 
And they set in it four rows of stones: the first row was a sardius, a topaz, and a carbuncle: this was the first row. 
And the second row, an emerald, a saðhire, and a diamond. 
And the third row, a ligure, an agate, and an amethyst. 
And the fourth row, a beryl, an onyx, and a jasper: they were inclosed in ouches of gold in their inclosings. 
And the stones were aãording to the names of the children of Israel, twelve, aãording to their names, like the engravings of a signet, every one with his name, aãording to the twelve tribes. 
And they made upon the breastplate chains at the ends, of wreathen work of pure gold. 
And they made two ouches of gold, and two gold rings; and put the two rings in the two ends of the breastplate. 
And they put the two wreathen chains of gold in the two rings on the ends of the breastplate. 
And the two ends of the two wreathen chains they fastened in the two ouches, and put them on the shoulderpieces of the ephod, before it. 
And they made two rings of gold, and put them on the two ends of the breastplate, upon the border of it, which was on the side of the ephod inward. 
And they made two other golden rings, and put them on the two sides of the ephod underneath, toward the forepart of it, over against the other coupling thereof, above the curious girdle of the ephod. 
And they did bind the breastplate by his rings unto the rings of the ephod with a lace of blue, that it might be above the curious girdle of the ephod, and that the breastplate might not be lïsed from the ephod; as the LORD coíanded Moses. 
And he made the robe of the ephod of woven work, aì of blue.

And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
On the first day of the first month shalt thou set up the tabernacle of the tent of the congregation. 
And thou shalt put therein the ark of the testimony, and cover the ark with the vail. 
And thou shalt bring in the table, and set in order the things that are to be set in order upon it; and thou shalt bring in the candlestick, and light the lamps thereof. 
And thou shalt set the altar of gold for the incense before the ark of the testimony, and put the hanging of the dïr to the tabernacle. 
And thou shalt set the altar of the burnt oæering before the dïr of the tabernacle of the tent of the congregation.

And thou shalt set up the court round about, and hang up the hanging at the court gate.

And thou shalt anoint the altar of the burnt oæering, and aì his veóels, and sanctify the altar: and it shaì be an altar most holy.

And thou shalt bring his sons, and clothe them with coats: 
And thou shalt anoint them, as thou didst anoint their father, that they may minister unto me in the priest's oæice: for their anointing shaì surely be an everlasting priesthïd throughout their generations. 
Thus did Moses: aãording to aì that the LORD coíanded him, so did he. 
And it came to paó in the first month in the second year, on the first day of the month, that the tabernacle was reared up.

And he reared up the court round about the tabernacle and the altar, and set up the hanging of the court gate. So Moses finished the work. 
Then a cloud covered the tent of the congregation, and the glory of the LORD fiìed the tabernacle. 
And Moses was not able to enter into the tent of the congregation, because the cloud abode thereon, and the glory of the LORD fiìed the tabernacle. 
And when the cloud was taken up from over the tabernacle, the children of Israel went onward in aì their journeys: 
But if the cloud were not taken up, then they journeyed not tiì the day that it was taken up. 
For the cloud of the LORD was upon the tabernacle by day, and fire was on it by night, in the sight of aì the house of Israel, throughout aì their journeys. 
And the LORD caìed unto Moses, and spake unto him out of the tabernacle of the congregation, saying, 
Speak unto the children of Israel, and say unto them, If any man of you bring an oæering unto the LORD, ye shaì bring your oæering of the caôle, even of the herd, and of the flock. 
If his oæering be a burnt sacrifice of the herd, let him oæer a male without blemish: he shaì oæer it of his own voluntary wiì at the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation before the LORD. 
And he shaì put his hand upon the head of the burnt oæering; and it shaì be aãepted for him to make atonement for him. 
And he shaì kiì the buìock before the LORD: and the priests, Aaron's sons, shaì bring the blïd, and sprinkle the blïd round about upon the altar that is by the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation. 
And he shaì flay the burnt oæering, and cut it into his pieces. 
And the sons of Aaron the priest shaì put fire upon the altar, and lay the wïd in order upon the fire: 
And the priests, Aaron's sons, shaì lay the parts, the head, and the fat, in order upon the wïd that is on the fire which is upon the altar: 
But his inwards and his legs shaì he wash in water: and the priest shaì burn aì on the altar, to be a burnt sacrifice, an oæering made by fire, of a swåt savour unto the LORD. 
And if his oæering be of the flocks, namely, of the shåp, or of the goats, for a burnt sacrifice; he shaì bring it a male without blemish. 
And he shaì kiì it on the side of the altar northward before the LORD: and the priests, Aaron's sons, shaì sprinkle his blïd round about upon the altar. 
And he shaì cut it into his pieces, with his head and his fat: and the priest shaì lay them in order on the wïd that is on the fire which is upon the altar: 
But he shaì wash the inwards and the legs with water: and the priest shaì bring it aì, and burn it upon the altar: it is a burnt sacrifice, an oæering made by fire, of a swåt savour unto the LORD. 
And if the burnt sacrifice for his oæering to the LORD be of fowls, then he shaì bring his oæering of turtledoves, or of young pigeons. 
And the priest shaì bring it unto the altar, and wring oæ his head, and burn it on the altar; and the blïd thereof shaì be wrung out at the side of the altar: 
And he shaì pluck away his crop with his feathers, and cast it beside the altar on the east part, by the place of the ashes: 
And he shaì cleave it with the wings thereof, but shaì not divide it asunder: and the priest shaì burn it upon the altar, upon the wïd that is upon the fire: it is a burnt sacrifice, an oæering made by fire, of a swåt savour unto the LORD. 
And when any wiì oæer a meat oæering unto the LORD, his oæering shaì be of fine flour; and he shaì pour oil upon it, and put frankincense thereon: 
And he shaì bring it to Aaron's sons the priests: and he shaì take thereout his handful of the flour thereof, and of the oil thereof, with aì the frankincense thereof; and the priest shaì burn the memorial of it upon the altar, to be an oæering made by fire, of a swåt savour unto the LORD: 
And the remnant of the meat oæering shaì be Aaron's and his sons': it is a thing most holy of the oæerings of the LORD made by fire. 
And if thou bring an oblation of a meat oæering baken in the oven, it shaì be unleavened cakes of fine flour mingled with oil, or unleavened wafers anointed with oil. 
And if thy oblation be a meat oæering baken in a pan, it shaì be of fine flour unleavened, mingled with oil. 
Thou shalt part it in pieces, and pour oil thereon: it is a meat oæering. 
And if thy oblation be a meat oæering baken in the fryingpan, it shaì be made of fine flour with oil. 
And thou shalt bring the meat oæering that is made of these things unto the LORD: and when it is presented unto the priest, he shaì bring it unto the altar. 
And the priest shaì take from the meat oæering a memorial thereof, and shaì burn it upon the altar: it is an oæering made by fire, of a swåt savour unto the LORD. 
And that which is left of the meat oæering shaì be Aaron's and his sons': it is a thing most holy of the oæerings of the LORD made by fire. 
No meat oæering, which ye shaì bring unto the LORD, shaì be made with leaven: for ye shaì burn no leaven, nor any honey, in any oæering of the LORD made by fire. 
As for the oblation of the firstfruits, ye shaì oæer them unto the LORD: but they shaì not be burnt on the altar for a swåt savour. 
And every oblation of thy meat oæering shalt thou season with salt; neither shalt thou suæer the salt of the covenant of thy God to be lacking from thy meat oæering: with aì thine oæerings thou shalt oæer salt. 
And if thou oæer a meat oæering of thy firstfruits unto the LORD, thou shalt oæer for the meat oæering of thy firstfruits grån ears of corn dried by the fire, even corn beaten out of fuì ears. 
And thou shalt put oil upon it, and lay frankincense thereon: it is a meat oæering. 
And the priest shaì burn the memorial of it, part of the beaten corn thereof, and part of the oil thereof, with aì the frankincense thereof: it is an oæering made by fire unto the LORD. 
And if his oblation be a sacrifice of peace oæering, if he oæer it of the herd; whether it be a male or female, he shaì oæer it without blemish before the LORD. 
And he shaì lay his hand upon the head of his oæering, and kiì it at the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation: and Aaron's sons the priests shaì sprinkle the blïd upon the altar round about.

And if his oæering for a sacrifice of peace oæering unto the LORD be of the flock; male or female, he shaì oæer it without blemish. 
If he oæer a lamb for his oæering, then shaì he oæer it before the LORD. 
And he shaì lay his hand upon the head of his oæering, and kiì it before the tabernacle of the congregation: and Aaron's sons shaì sprinkle the blïd thereof round about upon the altar. 
And he shaì oæer of the sacrifice of the peace oæering an oæering made by fire unto the LORD; the fat thereof, and the whole rump, it shaì he take oæ hard by the backbone; and the fat that covereth the inwards, and aì the fat that is upon the inwards,

And the priest shaì burn it upon the altar: it is the fïd of the oæering made by fire unto the LORD. 
And if his oæering be a goat, then he shaì oæer it before the LORD. 
And he shaì lay his hand upon the head of it, and kiì it before the tabernacle of the congregation: and the sons of Aaron shaì sprinkle the blïd thereof upon the altar round about. 
And he shaì oæer thereof his oæering, even an oæering made by fire unto the LORD; the fat that covereth the inwards, and aì the fat that is upon the inwards,

And the priest shaì burn them upon the altar: it is the fïd of the oæering made by fire for a swåt savour: aì the fat is the LORD's. 
It shaì be a perpetual statute for your generations throughout aì your dweìings, that ye eat neither fat nor blïd. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, If a soul shaì sin through ignorance against any of the coíandments of the LORD concerning things which ought not to be done, and shaì do against any of them: 
If the priest that is anointed do sin aãording to the sin of the people; then let him bring for his sin, which he hath siîed, a young buìock without blemish unto the LORD for a sin oæering. 
And he shaì bring the buìock unto the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation before the LORD; and shaì lay his hand upon the buìock's head, and kiì the buìock before the LORD.

And the skin of the buìock, and aì his flesh, with his head, and with his legs, and his inwards, and his dung,

And if the whole congregation of Israel sin through ignorance, and the thing be hid from the eyes of the aóembly, and they have done somewhat against any of the coíandments of the LORD concerning things which should not be done, and are guilty; 
When the sin, which they have siîed against it, is known, then the congregation shaì oæer a young buìock for the sin, and bring him before the tabernacle of the congregation. 
And the elders of the congregation shaì lay their hands upon the head of the buìock before the LORD: and the buìock shaì be kiìed before the LORD. 
And the priest that is anointed shaì bring of the buìock's blïd to the tabernacle of the congregation:

And he shaì take aì his fat from him, and burn it upon the altar.

And he shaì caòy forth the buìock without the camp, and burn him as he burned the first buìock: it is a sin oæering for the congregation. 
When a ruler hath siîed, and done somewhat through ignorance against any of the coíandments of the LORD his God concerning things which should not be done, and is guilty; 
Or if his sin, wherein he hath siîed, come to his knowledge; he shaì bring his oæering, a kid of the goats, a male without blemish:

And he shaì burn aì his fat upon the altar, as the fat of the sacrifice of peace oæerings: and the priest shaì make an atonement for him as concerning his sin, and it shaì be forgiven him. 
And if any one of the coíon people sin through ignorance, while he doeth somewhat against any of the coíandments of the LORD concerning things which ought not to be done, and be guilty; 
Or if his sin, which he hath siîed, come to his knowledge: then he shaì bring his oæering, a kid of the goats, a female without blemish, for his sin which he hath siîed. 
And he shaì lay his hand upon the head of the sin oæering, and slay the sin oæering in the place of the burnt oæering. 
And the priest shaì take of the blïd thereof with his finger, and put it upon the horns of the altar of burnt oæering, and shaì pour out aì the blïd thereof at the boôom of the altar. 
And he shaì take away aì the fat thereof, as the fat is taken away from oæ the sacrifice of peace oæerings; and the priest shaì burn it upon the altar for a swåt savour unto the LORD; and the priest shaì make an atonement for him, and it shaì be forgiven him. 
And if he bring a lamb for a sin oæering, he shaì bring it a female without blemish. 
And he shaì lay his hand upon the head of the sin oæering, and slay it for a sin oæering in the place where they kiì the burnt oæering. 
And the priest shaì take of the blïd of the sin oæering with his finger, and put it upon the horns of the altar of burnt oæering, and shaì pour out aì the blïd thereof at the boôom of the altar: 
And he shaì take away aì the fat thereof, as the fat of the lamb is taken away from the sacrifice of the peace oæerings; and the priest shaì burn them upon the altar, aãording to the oæerings made by fire unto the LORD: and the priest shaì make an atonement for his sin that he hath coíiôed, and it shaì be forgiven him. 
And if a soul sin, and hear the voice of swearing, and is a witneó, whether he hath sån or known of it; if he do not uôer it, then he shaì bear his iniquity. 
Or if a soul touch any unclean thing, whether it be a carcase of an unclean beast, or a carcase of unclean caôle, or the carcase of unclean cråping things, and if it be hiäen from him; he also shaì be unclean, and guilty. 
Or if he touch the uncleaîeó of man, whatsoever uncleaîeó it be that a man shaì be defiled withal, and it be hid from him; when he knoweth of it, then he shaì be guilty. 
Or if a soul swear, pronouncing with his lips to do evil, or to do gïd, whatsoever it be that a man shaì pronounce with an oath, and it be hid from him; when he knoweth of it, then he shaì be guilty in one of these. 
And it shaì be, when he shaì be guilty in one of these things, that he shaì confeó that he hath siîed in that thing: 
And he shaì bring his trespaó oæering unto the LORD for his sin which he hath siîed, a female from the flock, a lamb or a kid of the goats, for a sin oæering; and the priest shaì make an atonement for him concerning his sin. 
And if he be not able to bring a lamb, then he shaì bring for his trespaó, which he hath coíiôed, two turtledoves, or two young pigeons, unto the LORD; one for a sin oæering, and the other for a burnt oæering. 
And he shaì bring them unto the priest, who shaì oæer that which is for the sin oæering first, and wring oæ his head from his neck, but shaì not divide it asunder: 
And he shaì sprinkle of the blïd of the sin oæering upon the side of the altar; and the rest of the blïd shaì be wrung out at the boôom of the altar: it is a sin oæering. 
And he shaì oæer the second for a burnt oæering, aãording to the maîer: and the priest shaì make an atonement for him for his sin which he hath siîed, and it shaì be forgiven him. 
But if he be not able to bring two turtledoves, or two young pigeons, then he that siîed shaì bring for his oæering the tenth part of an ephah of fine flour for a sin oæering; he shaì put no oil upon it, neither shaì he put any frankincense thereon: for it is a sin oæering. 
Then shaì he bring it to the priest, and the priest shaì take his handful of it, even a memorial thereof, and burn it on the altar, aãording to the oæerings made by fire unto the LORD: it is a sin oæering. 
And the priest shaì make an atonement for him as touching his sin that he hath siîed in one of these, and it shaì be forgiven him: and the remnant shaì be the priest's, as a meat oæering. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
If a soul coíit a trespaó, and sin through ignorance, in the holy things of the LORD; then he shaì bring for his trespaó unto the LORD a ram without blemish out of the flocks, with thy estimation by shekels of silver, after the shekel of the sanctuary, for a trespaó oæering. 
And he shaì make amends for the harm that he hath done in the holy thing, and shaì aä the fifth part thereto, and give it unto the priest: and the priest shaì make an atonement for him with the ram of the trespaó oæering, and it shaì be forgiven him. 
And if a soul sin, and coíit any of these things which are forbiäen to be done by the coíandments of the LORD; though he wist it not, yet is he guilty, and shaì bear his iniquity. 
And he shaì bring a ram without blemish out of the flock, with thy estimation, for a trespaó oæering, unto the priest: and the priest shaì make an atonement for him concerning his ignorance wherein he eòed and wist it not, and it shaì be forgiven him. 
It is a trespaó oæering: he hath certainly trespaóed against the LORD. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
If a soul sin, and coíit a trespaó against the LORD, and lie unto his neighbour in that which was delivered him to kåp, or in feìowship, or in a thing taken away by violence, or hath deceived his neighbour; 
Or have found that which was lost, and lieth concerning it, and sweareth falsely; in any of aì these that a man doeth, siîing therein: 
Then it shaì be, because he hath siîed, and is guilty, that he shaì restore that which he tïk violently away, or the thing which he hath deceitfuìy goôen, or that which was delivered him to kåp, or the lost thing which he found, 
Or aì that about which he hath sworn falsely; he shaì even restore it in the principal, and shaì aä the fifth part more thereto, and give it unto him to whom it aðertaineth, in the day of his trespaó oæering. 
And he shaì bring his trespaó oæering unto the LORD, a ram without blemish out of the flock, with thy estimation, for a trespaó oæering, unto the priest: 
And the priest shaì make an atonement for him before the LORD: and it shaì be forgiven him for any thing of aì that he hath done in trespaóing therein. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
Coíand Aaron and his sons, saying, This is the law of the burnt oæering: It is the burnt oæering, because of the burning upon the altar aì night unto the morning, and the fire of the altar shaì be burning in it. 
And the priest shaì put on his linen garment, and his linen bråches shaì he put upon his flesh, and take up the ashes which the fire hath consumed with the burnt oæering on the altar, and he shaì put them beside the altar. 
And he shaì put oæ his garments, and put on other garments, and caòy forth the ashes without the camp unto a clean place. 
And the fire upon the altar shaì be burning in it; it shaì not be put out: and the priest shaì burn wïd on it every morning, and lay the burnt oæering in order upon it; and he shaì burn thereon the fat of the peace oæerings. 
The fire shaì ever be burning upon the altar; it shaì never go out. 
And this is the law of the meat oæering: the sons of Aaron shaì oæer it before the LORD, before the altar. 
And he shaì take of it his handful, of the flour of the meat oæering, and of the oil thereof, and aì the frankincense which is upon the meat oæering, and shaì burn it upon the altar for a swåt savour, even the memorial of it, unto the LORD. 
And the remainder thereof shaì Aaron and his sons eat: with unleavened bread shaì it be eaten in the holy place; in the court of the tabernacle of the congregation they shaì eat it. 
It shaì not be baken with leaven. I have given it unto them for their portion of my oæerings made by fire; it is most holy, as is the sin oæering, and as the trespaó oæering. 
Aì the males among the children of Aaron shaì eat of it. It shaì be a statute for ever in your generations concerning the oæerings of the LORD made by fire: every one that toucheth them shaì be holy. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
This is the oæering of Aaron and of his sons, which they shaì oæer unto the LORD in the day when he is anointed; the tenth part of an ephah of fine flour for a meat oæering perpetual, half of it in the morning, and half thereof at night. 
In a pan it shaì be made with oil; and when it is baken, thou shalt bring it in: and the baken pieces of the meat oæering shalt thou oæer for a swåt savour unto the LORD. 
And the priest of his sons that is anointed in his stead shaì oæer it: it is a statute for ever unto the LORD; it shaì be whoìy burnt. 
For every meat oæering for the priest shaì be whoìy burnt: it shaì not be eaten. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
Speak unto Aaron and to his sons, saying, This is the law of the sin oæering: In the place where the burnt oæering is kiìed shaì the sin oæering be kiìed before the LORD: it is most holy. 
The priest that oæereth it for sin shaì eat it: in the holy place shaì it be eaten, in the court of the tabernacle of the congregation. 
Whatsoever shaì touch the flesh thereof shaì be holy: and when there is sprinkled of the blïd thereof upon any garment, thou shalt wash that whereon it was sprinkled in the holy place. 
But the earthen veóel wherein it is soäen shaì be broken: and if it be soäen in a brasen pot, it shaì be both scoured, and rinsed in water. 
Aì the males among the priests shaì eat thereof: it is most holy. 
And no sin oæering, whereof any of the blïd is brought into the tabernacle of the congregation to reconcile withal in the holy place, shaì be eaten: it shaì be burnt in the fire. 
Likewise this is the law of the trespaó oæering: it is most holy. 
In the place where they kiì the burnt oæering shaì they kiì the trespaó oæering: and the blïd thereof shaì he sprinkle round about upon the altar. 
And he shaì oæer of it aì the fat thereof; the rump, and the fat that covereth the inwards, 
And the two kidneys, and the fat that is on them, which is by the flanks, and the caul that is above the liver, with the kidneys, it shaì he take away: 
And the priest shaì burn them upon the altar for an oæering made by fire unto the LORD: it is a trespaó oæering. 
Every male among the priests shaì eat thereof: it shaì be eaten in the holy place: it is most holy. 
As the sin oæering is, so is the trespaó oæering: there is one law for them: the priest that maketh atonement therewith shaì have it. 
And the priest that oæereth any man's burnt oæering, even the priest shaì have to himself the skin of the burnt oæering which he hath oæered. 
And aì the meat oæering that is baken in the oven, and aì that is dreóed in the fryingpan, and in the pan, shaì be the priest's that oæereth it. 
And every meat oæering, mingled with oil, and dry, shaì aì the sons of Aaron have, one as much as another. 
And this is the law of the sacrifice of peace oæerings, which he shaì oæer unto the LORD. 
If he oæer it for a thanksgiving, then he shaì oæer with the sacrifice of thanksgiving unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers anointed with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour, fried. 
Besides the cakes, he shaì oæer for his oæering leavened bread with the sacrifice of thanksgiving of his peace oæerings. 
And of it he shaì oæer one out of the whole oblation for an heave oæering unto the LORD, and it shaì be the priest's that sprinkleth the blïd of the peace oæerings. 
And the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace oæerings for thanksgiving shaì be eaten the same day that it is oæered; he shaì not leave any of it until the morning. 
But if the sacrifice of his oæering be a vow, or a voluntary oæering, it shaì be eaten the same day that he oæereth his sacrifice: and on the moòow also the remainder of it shaì be eaten: 
But the remainder of the flesh of the sacrifice on the third day shaì be burnt with fire. 
And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace oæerings be eaten at aì on the third day, it shaì not be aãepted, neither shaì it be imputed unto him that oæereth it: it shaì be an abomination, and the soul that eateth of it shaì bear his iniquity. 
And the flesh that toucheth any unclean thing shaì not be eaten; it shaì be burnt with fire: and as for the flesh, aì that be clean shaì eat thereof. 
But the soul that eateth of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace oæerings, that pertain unto the LORD, having his uncleaîeó upon him, even that soul shaì be cut oæ from his people. 
Moreover the soul that shaì touch any unclean thing, as the uncleaîeó of man, or any unclean beast, or any abominable unclean thing, and eat of the flesh of the sacrifice of peace oæerings, which pertain unto the LORD, even that soul shaì be cut oæ from his people. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying, 
Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, Ye shaì eat no maîer of fat, of ox, or of shåp, or of goat. 
And the fat of the beast that dieth of itself, and the fat of that which is torn with beasts, may be used in any other use: but ye shaì in no wise eat of it. 
For whosoever eateth the fat of the beast, of which men oæer an oæering made by fire unto the LORD, even the soul that eateth it shaì be cut oæ from his people. 
Moreover ye shaì eat no maîer of blïd, whether it be of fowl or of beast, in any of your dweìings. 
Whatsoever soul it be that eateth any maîer of blïd, even that soul shaì be cut oæ from his people. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

For the wave breast and the heave shoulder have I taken of the children of Israel from oæ the sacrifices of their peace oæerings, and have given them unto Aaron the priest and unto his sons by a statute for ever from among the children of Israel. 
This is the portion of the anointing of Aaron, and of the anointing of his sons, out of the oæerings of the LORD made by fire, in the day when he presented them to minister unto the LORD in the priest's oæice; 
Which the LORD coíanded to be given them of the children of Israel, in the day that he anointed them, by a statute for ever throughout their generations. 
This is the law of the burnt oæering, of the meat oæering, and of the sin oæering, and of the trespaó oæering, and of the consecrations, and of the sacrifice of the peace oæerings; 
Which the LORD coíanded Moses in mount Sinai, in the day that he coíanded the children of Israel to oæer their oblations unto the LORD, in the wilderneó of Sinai. 
And the LORD spake unto Moses, saying,

And Moses did as the LORD coíanded him; and the aóembly was gathered together unto the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation. 
And Moses said unto the congregation, This is the thing which the LORD coíanded to be done. 
And Moses brought Aaron and his sons, and washed them with water.

And Moses brought Aaron's sons, and put coats upon them, and girded them with girdles, and put boîets upon them; as the LORD coíanded Moses.

But the buìock, and his hide, his flesh, and his dung, he burnt with fire without the camp; as the LORD coíanded Moses.

And Moses said unto Aaron and to his sons, Boil the flesh at the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation: and there eat it with the bread that is in the basket of consecrations, as I coíanded, saying, Aaron and his sons shaì eat it. 
And that which remaineth of the flesh and of the bread shaì ye burn with fire. 
And ye shaì not go out of the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation in seven days, until the days of your consecration be at an end: for seven days shaì he consecrate you. 
As he hath done this day, so the LORD hath coíanded to do, to make an atonement for you. 
Therefore shaì ye abide at the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation day and night seven days, and kåp the charge of the LORD, that ye die not: for so I am coíanded. 
So Aaron and his sons did aì things which the LORD coíanded by the hand of Moses. 
And it came to paó on the eighth day, that Moses caìed Aaron and his sons, and the elders of Israel;

Aaron therefore went unto the altar, and slew the calf of the sin oæering, which was for himself.

And the flesh and the hide he burnt with fire without the camp.

And he brought the people's oæering, and tïk the goat, which was the sin oæering for the people, and slew it, and oæered it for sin, as the first.
