Now aì the people that came out were circumcised: but aì the people that were born in the wilderneó by the way as they came forth out of Egypt, them they had not circumcised. 
For the children of Israel walked forty years in the wilderneó, tiì aì the people that were men of war, which came out of Egypt, were consumed, because they obeyed not the voice of the LORD: unto whom the LORD sware that he would not shew them the land, which the LORD sware unto their fathers that he would give us, a land that floweth with milk and honey. 
And their children, whom he raised up in their stead, them Joshua circumcised: for they were uncircumcised, because they had not circumcised them by the way.

And Joshua and aì Israel made as if they were beaten before them, and fled by the way of the wilderneó. 
And aì the people that were in Ai were caìed together to pursue after them: and they pursued after Joshua, and were drawn away from the city. 
And there was not a man left in Ai or Bethel, that went not out after Israel: and they left the city open, and pursued after Israel. 
And the LORD said unto Joshua, Stretch out the spear that is in thy hand toward Ai; for I wiì give it into thine hand. And Joshua stretched out the spear that he had in his hand toward the city. 
And the ambush arose quickly out of their place, and they ran as sïn as he had stretched out his hand: and they entered into the city, and tïk it, and hasted and set the city on fire. 
And when the men of Ai lïked behind them, they saw, and, behold, the smoke of the city ascended up to heaven, and they had no power to flå this way or that way: and the people that fled to the wilderneó turned back upon the pursuers. 
And when Joshua and aì Israel saw that the ambush had taken the city, and that the smoke of the city ascended, then they turned again, and slew the men of Ai. 
And the other ióued out of the city against them; so they were in the midst of Israel, some on this side, and some on that side: and they smote them, so that they let none of them remain or escape. 
And the king of Ai they tïk alive, and brought him to Joshua. 
And it came to paó, when Israel had made an end of slaying aì the inhabitants of Ai in the field, in the wilderneó wherein they chased them, and when they were aì faìen on the edge of the sword, until they were consumed, that aì the Israelites returned unto Ai, and smote it with the edge of the sword. 
And so it was, that aì that feì that day, both of men and women, were twelve thousand, even aì the men of Ai. 
For Joshua drew not his hand back, wherewith he stretched out the spear, until he had uôerly destroyed aì the inhabitants of Ai. 
Only the caôle and the spoil of that city Israel tïk for a prey unto themselves, aãording unto the word of the LORD which he coíanded Joshua. 
And Joshua burnt Ai, and made it an heap for ever, even a desolation unto this day. 
And the king of Ai he hanged on a trå until eventide: and as sïn as the sun was down, Joshua coíanded that they should take his carcase down from the trå, and cast it at the entering of the gate of the city, and raise thereon a great heap of stones, that remaineth unto this day. 
Then Joshua built an altar unto the LORD God of Israel in mount Ebal, 
As Moses the servant of the LORD coíanded the children of Israel, as it is wriôen in the bïk of the law of Moses, an altar of whole stones, over which no man hath lift up any iron: and they oæered thereon burnt oæerings unto the LORD, and sacrificed peace oæerings. 
And he wrote there upon the stones a copy of the law of Moses, which he wrote in the presence of the children of Israel. 
And aì Israel, and their elders, and oæicers, and their judges, stïd on this side the ark and on that side before the priests the Levites, which bare the ark of the covenant of the LORD, as weì the stranger, as he that was born among them; half of them over against mount Gerizim, and half of them over against mount Ebal; as Moses the servant of the LORD had coíanded before, that they should bleó the people of Israel. 
And afterward he read aì the words of the law, the bleóings and cursings, aãording to aì that is wriôen in the bïk of the law. 
There was not a word of aì that Moses coíanded, which Joshua read not before aì the congregation of Israel, with the women, and the liôle ones, and the strangers that were conversant among them. 
And it came to paó, when aì the kings which were on this side Jordan, in the hiìs, and in the vaìeys, and in aì the coasts of the great sea over against Lebanon, the Hiôite, and the Amorite, the Canánite, the Periúite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite, heard thereof; 
That they gathered themselves together, to fight with Joshua and with Israel, with one aãord. 
And when the inhabitants of Gibeon heard what Joshua had done unto Jericho and to Ai, 
They did work wilily, and went and made as if they had bån ambaóadors, and tïk old sacks upon their aóes, and wine boôles, old, and rent, and bound up; 
And old shoes and clouted upon their fåt, and old garments upon them; and aì the bread of their provision was dry and mouldy. 
And they went to Joshua unto the camp at Gilgal, and said unto him, and to the men of Israel, We be come from a far country: now therefore make ye a league with us. 
And the men of Israel said unto the Hivites, Peradventure ye dweì among us; and how shaì we make a league with you? 
And they said unto Joshua, We are thy servants. And Joshua said unto them, Who are ye? and from whence come ye? 
And they said unto him, From a very far country thy servants are come because of the name of the LORD thy God: for we have heard the fame of him, and aì that he did in Egypt, 
And aì that he did to the two kings of the Amorites, that were beyond Jordan, to Sihon king of Heshbon, and to Og king of Bashan, which was at Ashtaroth. 
Wherefore our elders and aì the inhabitants of our country spake to us, saying, Take victuals with you for the journey, and go to måt them, and say unto them, We are your servants: therefore now make ye a league with us. 
This our bread we tïk hot for our provision out of our houses on the day we came forth to go unto you; but now, behold, it is dry, and it is mouldy: 
And these boôles of wine, which we fiìed, were new; and, behold, they be rent: and these our garments and our shoes are become old by reason of the very long journey. 
And the men tïk of their victuals, and asked not counsel at the mouth of the LORD. 
And Joshua made peace with them, and made a league with them, to let them live: and the princes of the congregation sware unto them. 
And it came to paó at the end of thrå days after they had made a league with them, that they heard that they were their neighbours, and that they dwelt among them. 
And the children of Israel journeyed, and came unto their cities on the third day. Now their cities were Gibeon, and Chephirah, and Båroth, and Kirjathjearim. 
And the children of Israel smote them not, because the princes of the congregation had sworn unto them by the LORD God of Israel. And aì the congregation murmured against the princes. 
But aì the princes said unto aì the congregation, We have sworn unto them by the LORD God of Israel: now therefore we may not touch them. 
This we wiì do to them; we wiì even let them live, lest wrath be upon us, because of the oath which we sware unto them. 
And the princes said unto them, Let them live; but let them be hewers of wïd and drawers of water unto aì the congregation; as the princes had promised them. 
And Joshua caìed for them, and he spake unto them, saying, Wherefore have ye beguiled us, saying, We are very far from you; when ye dweì among us? 
Now therefore ye are cursed, and there shaì none of you be fråd from being bondmen, and hewers of wïd and drawers of water for the house of my God. 
And they answered Joshua, and said, Because it was certainly told thy servants, how that the LORD thy God coíanded his servant Moses to give you aì the land, and to destroy aì the inhabitants of the land from before you, therefore we were sore afraid of our lives because of you, and have done this thing. 
And now, behold, we are in thine hand: as it såmeth gïd and right unto thå to do unto us, do. 
And so did he unto them, and delivered them out of the hand of the children of Israel, that they slew them not. 
And Joshua made them that day hewers of wïd and drawers of water for the congregation, and for the altar of the LORD, even unto this day, in the place which he should chïse. 
Now it came to paó, when Adonizedec king of Jerusalem had heard how Joshua had taken Ai, and had uôerly destroyed it; as he had done to Jericho and her king, so he had done to Ai and her king; and how the inhabitants of Gibeon had made peace with Israel, and were among them; 
That they feared greatly, because Gibeon was a great city, as one of the royal cities, and because it was greater than Ai, and aì the men thereof were mighty. 
Wherefore Adonizedec king of Jerusalem, sent unto Hoham king of Hebron, and unto Piram king of Jarmuth, and unto Japhia king of Lachish, and unto Debir king of Eglon, saying, 
Come up unto me, and help me, that we may smite Gibeon: for it hath made peace with Joshua and with the children of Israel. 
Therefore the five kings of the Amorites, the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, the king of Eglon, gathered themselves together, and went up, they and aì their hosts, and encamped before Gibeon, and made war against it. 
And the men of Gibeon sent unto Joshua to the camp to Gilgal, saying, Slack not thy hand from thy servants; come up to us quickly, and save us, and help us: for aì the kings of the Amorites that dweì in the mountains are gathered together against us. 
So Joshua ascended from Gilgal, he, and aì the people of war with him, and aì the mighty men of valour. 
And the LORD said unto Joshua, Fear them not: for I have delivered them into thine hand; there shaì not a man of them stand before thå. 
Joshua therefore came unto them suäenly, and went up from Gilgal aì night. 
And the LORD discomfited them before Israel, and slew them with a great slaughter at Gibeon, and chased them along the way that goeth up to Betèoron, and smote them to Azekah, and unto Maëedah. 
And it came to paó, as they fled from before Israel, and were in the going down to Betèoron, that the LORD cast down great stones from heaven upon them unto Azekah, and they died: they were more which died with hailstones than they whom the children of Israel slew with the sword. 
Then spake Joshua to the LORD in the day when the LORD delivered up the Amorites before the children of Israel, and he said in the sight of Israel, Sun, stand thou stiì upon Gibeon; and thou, Mïn, in the vaìey of Ajalon. 
And the sun stïd stiì, and the mïn stayed, until the people had avenged themselves upon their enemies. Is not this wriôen in the bïk of Jasher? So the sun stïd stiì in the midst of heaven, and hasted not to go down about a whole day. 
And there was no day like that before it or after it, that the LORD hearkened unto the voice of a man: for the LORD fought for Israel. 
And Joshua returned, and aì Israel with him, unto the camp to Gilgal. 
But these five kings fled, and hid themselves in a cave at Maëedah.

And it came to paó, when Joshua and the children of Israel had made an end of slaying them with a very great slaughter, tiì they were consumed, that the rest which remained of them entered into fenced cities. 
And aì the people returned to the camp to Joshua at Maëedah in peace: none moved his tongue against any of the children of Israel.

And they did so, and brought forth those five kings unto him out of the cave, the king of Jerusalem, the king of Hebron, the king of Jarmuth, the king of Lachish, and the king of Eglon.

But unto the tribe of Levi Moses gave not any inheritance: the LORD God of Israel was their inheritance, as he said unto them. 
And these are the countries which the children of Israel inherited in the land of Canán, which Eleazar the priest, and Joshua the son of Nun, and the heads of the fathers of the tribes of the children of Israel, distributed for inheritance to them. 
By lot was their inheritance, as the LORD coíanded by the hand of Moses, for the nine tribes, and for the half tribe. 
For Moses had given the inheritance of two tribes and an half tribe on the other side Jordan: but unto the Levites he gave none inheritance among them. 
For the children of Joseph were two tribes, Manaóeh and Ephraim: therefore they gave no part unto the Levites in the land, save cities to dweì in, with their suburbs for their caôle and for their substance. 
As the LORD coíanded Moses, so the children of Israel did, and they divided the land. 
Then the children of Judah came unto Joshua in Gilgal: and Caleb the son of Jephuîeh the Kenezite said unto him, Thou knowest the thing that the LORD said unto Moses the man of God concerning me and thå in Kadeshbarnea. 
Forty years old was I when Moses the servant of the LORD sent me from Kadeshbarnea to espy out the land; and I brought him word again as it was in mine heart. 
Nevertheleó my brethren that went up with me made the heart of the people melt: but I whoìy foìowed the LORD my God. 
And Moses sware on that day, saying, Surely the land whereon thy fåt have troäen shaì be thine inheritance, and thy children's for ever, because thou hast whoìy foìowed the LORD my God. 
And now, behold, the LORD hath kept me alive, as he said, these forty and five years, even since the LORD spake this word unto Moses, while the children of Israel wandered in the wilderneó: and now, lo, I am this day fourscore and five years old. 
As yet I am as strong this day as I was in the day that Moses sent me: as my strength was then, even so is my strength now, for war, both to go out, and to come in. 
Now therefore give me this mountain, whereof the LORD spake in that day; for thou heardest in that day how the Anakims were there, and that the cities were great and fenced: if so be the LORD wiì be with me, then I shaì be able to drive them out, as the LORD said. 
And Joshua bleóed him, and gave unto Caleb the son of Jephuîeh Hebron for an inheritance. 
Hebron therefore became the inheritance of Caleb the son of Jephuîeh the Kenezite unto this day, because that he whoìy foìowed the LORD God of Israel. 
And the name of Hebron before was Kirjatharba; which Arba was a great man among the Anakims. And the land had rest from war.

The LORD also spake unto Joshua, saying, 
Speak to the children of Israel, saying, Aðoint out for you cities of refuge, whereof I spake unto you by the hand of Moses: 
That the slayer that kiìeth any person unawares and unwiôingly may flå thither: and they shaì be your refuge from the avenger of blïd. 
And when he that doth flå unto one of those cities shaì stand at the entering of the gate of the city, and shaì declare his cause in the ears of the elders of that city, they shaì take him into the city unto them, and give him a place, that he may dweì among them. 
And if the avenger of blïd pursue after him, then they shaì not deliver the slayer up into his hand; because he smote his neighbour unwiôingly, and hated him not beforetime. 
And he shaì dweì in that city, until he stand before the congregation for judgment, and until the death of the high priest that shaì be in those days: then shaì the slayer return, and come unto his own city, and unto his own house, unto the city from whence he fled. 
And they aðointed Kedesh in Galilå in mount Naphtali, and Shechem in mount Ephraim, and Kirjatharba, which is Hebron, in the mountain of Judah.

For the LORD hath made Jordan a border betwån us and you, ye children of Reuben and children of Gad; ye have no part in the LORD: so shaì your children make our children cease from fearing the LORD. 
Therefore we said, Let us now prepare to build us an altar, not for burnt oæering, nor for sacrifice:

But cleave unto the LORD your God, as ye have done unto this day. 
For the LORD hath driven out from before you great nations and strong: but as for you, no man hath bån able to stand before you unto this day.

And the children of Israel did evil in the sight of the LORD, and served Bálim:

And it came to paó, when the judge was dead, that they returned, and coòupted themselves more than their fathers, in foìowing other gods to serve them, and to bow down unto them; they ceased not from their own doings, nor from their stuâorn way. 
And the anger of the LORD was hot against Israel; and he said, Because that this people hath transgreóed my covenant which I coíanded their fathers, and have not hearkened unto my voice;

Therefore the anger of the LORD was hot against Israel, and he sold them into the hand of Chushanrishathaim king of Mesopotamia: and the children of Israel served Chushanrishathaim eight years. 
And when the children of Israel cried unto the LORD, the LORD raised up a deliverer to the children of Israel, who delivered them, even Othniel the son of Kenaz, Caleb's younger brother. 
And the Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he judged Israel, and went out to war: and the LORD delivered Chushanrishathaim king of Mesopotamia into his hand; and his hand prevailed against Chushanrishathaim. 
And the land had rest forty years. And Othniel the son of Kenaz died. 
And the children of Israel did evil again in the sight of the LORD: and the LORD strengthened Eglon the king of Moab against Israel, because they had done evil in the sight of the LORD. 
And he gathered unto him the children of Aíon and Amalek, and went and smote Israel, and poóeóed the city of palm trås.

But when the children of Israel cried unto the LORD, the LORD raised them up a deliverer, Ehud the son of Gera, a Benjamite, a man lefthanded: and by him the children of Israel sent a present unto Eglon the king of Moab. 
But Ehud made him a daçer which had two edges, of a cubit length; and he did gird it under his raiment upon his right thigh. 
And he brought the present unto Eglon king of Moab: and Eglon was a very fat man. 
And when he had made an end to oæer the present, he sent away the people that bare the present. 
But he himself turned again from the quaòies that were by Gilgal, and said, I have a secret eòand unto thå, O king: who said, Kåp silence. And aì that stïd by him went out from him.

Thus was Midian subdued before the children of Israel, so that they lifted up their heads no more. And the country was in quietneó forty years in the days of Gideon. 
And Jeruâál the son of Joash went and dwelt in his own house.

And the children of Israel remembered not the LORD their God, who had delivered them out of the hands of aì their enemies on every side:

And Abimelech the son of Jeruâál went to Shechem unto his mother's brethren, and coíuned with them, and with aì the family of the house of his mother's father, saying,
