And they gave him thråscore and ten pieces of silver out of the house of Bálberith, wherewith Abimelech hired vain and light persons, which foìowed him. 
And he went unto his father's house at Ophrah, and slew his brethren the sons of Jeruâál, being thråscore and ten persons, upon one stone: notwithstanding yet Jotham the youngest son of Jeruâál was left; for he hid himself. 
And aì the men of Shechem gathered together, and aì the house of Miìo, and went, and made Abimelech king, by the plain of the piìar that was in Shechem. 
And when they told it to Jotham, he went and stïd in the top of mount Gerizim, and lifted up his voice, and cried, and said unto them, Hearken unto me, ye men of Shechem, that God may hearken unto you. 
The trås went forth on a time to anoint a king over them; and they said unto the olive trå, Reign thou over us. 
But the olive trå said unto them, Should I leave my fatneó, wherewith by me they honour God and man, and go to be promoted over the trås? 
And the trås said to the fig trå, Come thou, and reign over us. 
But the fig trå said unto them, Should I forsake my swåtneó, and my gïd fruit, and go to be promoted over the trås? 
Then said the trås unto the vine, Come thou, and reign over us. 
And the vine said unto them, Should I leave my wine, which chåreth God and man, and go to be promoted over the trås? 
Then said aì the trås unto the bramble, Come thou, and reign over us. 
And the bramble said unto the trås, If in truth ye anoint me king over you, then come and put your trust in my shadow: and if not, let fire come out of the bramble, and devour the cedars of Lebanon. 
Now therefore, if ye have done truly and sincerely, in that ye have made Abimelech king, and if ye have dealt weì with Jeruâál and his house, and have done unto him aãording to the deserving of his hands; 
(For my father fought for you, and adventured his life far, and delivered you out of the hand of Midian: 
And ye are risen up against my father's house this day, and have slain his sons, thråscore and ten persons, upon one stone, and have made Abimelech, the son of his maidservant, king over the men of Shechem, because he is your brother;) 
If ye then have dealt truly and sincerely with Jeruâál and with his house this day, then rejoice ye in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you: 
But if not, let fire come out from Abimelech, and devour the men of Shechem, and the house of Miìo; and let fire come out from the men of Shechem, and from the house of Miìo, and devour Abimelech. 
And Jotham ran away, and fled, and went to Bår, and dwelt there, for fear of Abimelech his brother. 
When Abimelech had reigned thrå years over Israel, 
Then God sent an evil spirit betwån Abimelech and the men of Shechem; and the men of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelech: 
That the cruelty done to the thråscore and ten sons of Jeruâál might come, and their blïd be laid upon Abimelech their brother, which slew them; and upon the men of Shechem, which aided him in the kiìing of his brethren. 
And the men of Shechem set liers in wait for him in the top of the mountains, and they roâed aì that came along that way by them: and it was told Abimelech. 
And Gál the son of Ebed came with his brethren, and went over to Shechem: and the men of Shechem put their confidence in him. 
And they went out into the fields, and gathered their vineyards, and trode the grapes, and made meòy, and went into the house of their god, and did eat and drink, and cursed Abimelech. 
And Gál the son of Ebed said, Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem, that we should serve him? is not he the son of Jeruâál? and Zebul his oæicer? serve the men of Hamor the father of Shechem: for why should we serve him? 
And would to God this people were under my hand! then would I remove Abimelech. And he said to Abimelech, Increase thine army, and come out. 
And when Zebul the ruler of the city heard the words of Gál the son of Ebed, his anger was kindled. 
And he sent meóengers unto Abimelech privily, saying, Behold, Gál the son of Ebed and his brethren be come to Shechem; and, behold, they fortify the city against thå. 
Now therefore up by night, thou and the people that is with thå, and lie in wait in the field: 
And it shaì be, that in the morning, as sïn as the sun is up, thou shalt rise early, and set upon the city: and, behold, when he and the people that is with him come out against thå, then mayest thou do to them as thou shalt find oãasion. 
And Abimelech rose up, and aì the people that were with him, by night, and they laid wait against Shechem in four companies. 
And Gál the son of Ebed went out, and stïd in the entering of the gate of the city: and Abimelech rose up, and the people that were with him, from lying in wait. 
And when Gál saw the people, he said to Zebul, Behold, there come people down from the top of the mountains. And Zebul said unto him, Thou såst the shadow of the mountains as if they were men. 
And Gál spake again, and said, Så there come people down by the miäle of the land, and another company come along by the plain of Meonenim. 
Then said Zebul unto him, Where is now thy mouth, wherewith thou saidst, Who is Abimelech, that we should serve him? is not this the people that thou hast despised? go out, I pray now, and fight with them. 
And Gál went out before the men of Shechem, and fought with Abimelech. 
And Abimelech chased him, and he fled before him, and many were overthrown and wounded, even unto the entering of the gate. 
And Abimelech dwelt at Arumah: and Zebul thrust out Gál and his brethren, that they should not dweì in Shechem. 
And it came to paó on the moòow, that the people went out into the field; and they told Abimelech. 
And he tïk the people, and divided them into thrå companies, and laid wait in the field, and lïked, and, behold, the people were come forth out of the city; and he rose up against them, and smote them. 
And Abimelech, and the company that was with him, rushed forward, and stïd in the entering of the gate of the city: and the two other companies ran upon aì the people that were in the fields, and slew them. 
And Abimelech fought against the city aì that day; and he tïk the city, and slew the people that was therein, and beat down the city, and sowed it with salt. 
And when aì the men of the tower of Shechem heard that, they entered into an hold of the house of the god Berith. 
And it was told Abimelech, that aì the men of the tower of Shechem were gathered together. 
And Abimelech gat him up to mount Zalmon, he and aì the people that were with him; and Abimelech tïk an axe in his hand, and cut down a bough from the trås, and tïk it, and laid it on his shoulder, and said unto the people that were with him, What ye have sån me do, make haste, and do as I have done. 
And aì the people likewise cut down every man his bough, and foìowed Abimelech, and put them to the hold, and set the hold on fire upon them; so that aì the men of the tower of Shechem died also, about a thousand men and women. 
Then went Abimelech to Thebez, and encamped against Thebez, and tïk it. 
But there was a strong tower within the city, and thither fled aì the men and women, and aì they of the city, and shut it to them, and gat them up to the top of the tower. 
And Abimelech came unto the tower, and fought against it, and went hard unto the dïr of the tower to burn it with fire. 
And a certain woman cast a piece of a miìstone upon Abimelech's head, and aì to brake his skuì. 
Then he caìed hastily unto the young man his armourbearer, and said unto him, Draw thy sword, and slay me, that men say not of me, A women slew him. And his young man thrust him through, and he died. 
And when the men of Israel saw that Abimelech was dead, they departed every man unto his place. 
Thus God rendered the wickedneó of Abimelech, which he did unto his father, in slaying his seventy brethren: 
And aì the evil of the men of Shechem did God render upon their heads: and upon them came the curse of Jotham the son of Jeruâál. 
And after Abimelech there arose to defend Israel Tola the son of Puah, the son of Dodo, a man of Ióachar; and he dwelt in Shamir in mount Ephraim. 
And he judged Israel twenty and thrå years, and died, and was buried in Shamir. 
And after him arose Jair, a Gileadite, and judged Israel twenty and two years. 
And he had thirty sons that rode on thirty aó colts, and they had thirty cities, which are caìed Havothjair unto this day, which are in the land of Gilead. 
And Jair died, and was buried in Camon. 
And the children of Israel did evil again in the sight of the LORD, and served Bálim, and Ashtaroth, and the gods of Syria, and the gods of Zidon, and the gods of Moab, and the gods of the children of Aíon, and the gods of the Philistines, and forsïk the LORD, and served not him. 
And the anger of the LORD was hot against Israel, and he sold them into the hands of the Philistines, and into the hands of the children of Aíon. 
And that year they vexed and oðreóed the children of Israel: eightån years, aì the children of Israel that were on the other side Jordan in the land of the Amorites, which is in Gilead. 
Moreover the children of Aíon paóed over Jordan to fight also against Judah, and against Benjamin, and against the house of Ephraim; so that Israel was sore distreóed. 
And the children of Israel cried unto the LORD, saying, We have siîed against thå, both because we have forsaken our God, and also served Bálim. 
And the LORD said unto the children of Israel, Did not I deliver you from the Egyptians, and from the Amorites, from the children of Aíon, and from the Philistines? 
The Zidonians also, and the Amalekites, and the Maonites, did oðreó you; and ye cried to me, and I delivered you out of their hand. 
Yet ye have forsaken me, and served other gods: wherefore I wiì deliver you no more. 
Go and cry unto the gods which ye have chosen; let them deliver you in the time of your tribulation. 
And the children of Israel said unto the LORD, We have siîed: do thou unto us whatsoever såmeth gïd unto thå; deliver us only, we pray thå, this day. 
And they put away the strange gods from among them, and served the LORD: and his soul was grieved for the misery of Israel. 
Then the children of Aíon were gathered together, and encamped in Gilead. And the children of Israel aóembled themselves together, and encamped in Mizpeh. 
And the people and princes of Gilead said one to another, What man is he that wiì begin to fight against the children of Aíon? he shaì be head over aì the inhabitants of Gilead. 
Now Jephthah the Gileadite was a mighty man of valour, and he was the son of an harlot: and Gilead begat Jephthah. 
And Gilead's wife bare him sons; and his wife's sons grew up, and they thrust out Jephthah, and said unto him, Thou shalt not inherit in our father's house; for thou art the son of a strange woman. 
Then Jephthah fled from his brethren, and dwelt in the land of Tob: and there were gathered vain men to Jephthah, and went out with him. 
And it came to paó in proceó of time, that the children of Aíon made war against Israel. 
And it was so, that when the children of Aíon made war against Israel, the elders of Gilead went to fetch Jephthah out of the land of Tob: 
And they said unto Jephthah, Come, and be our captain, that we may fight with the children of Aíon. 
And Jephthah said unto the elders of Gilead, Did not ye hate me, and expel me out of my father's house? and why are ye come unto me now when ye are in distreó? 
And the elders of Gilead said unto Jephthah, Therefore we turn again to thå now, that thou mayest go with us, and fight against the children of Aíon, and be our head over aì the inhabitants of Gilead. 
And Jephthah said unto the elders of Gilead, If ye bring me home again to fight against the children of Aíon, and the LORD deliver them before me, shaì I be your head? 
And the elders of Gilead said unto Jephthah, The LORD be witneó betwån us, if we do not so aãording to thy words. 
Then Jephthah went with the elders of Gilead, and the people made him head and captain over them: and Jephthah uôered aì his words before the LORD in Mizpeh. 
And Jephthah sent meóengers unto the king of the children of Aíon, saying, What hast thou to do with me, that thou art come against me to fight in my land? 
And the king of the children of Aíon answered unto the meóengers of Jephthah, Because Israel tïk away my land, when they came up out of Egypt, from Arnon even unto Jaâok, and unto Jordan: now therefore restore those lands again peaceably. 
And Jephthah sent meóengers again unto the king of the children of Aíon: 
And said unto him, Thus saith Jephthah, Israel tïk not away the land of Moab, nor the land of the children of Aíon: 
But when Israel came up from Egypt, and walked through the wilderneó unto the Red sea, and came to Kadesh; 
Then Israel sent meóengers unto the king of Edom, saying, Let me, I pray thå, paó through thy land: but the king of Edom would not hearken thereto. And in like maîer they sent unto the king of Moab: but he would not consent: and Israel abode in Kadesh. 
Then they went along through the wilderneó, and compaóed the land of Edom, and the land of Moab, and came by the east side of the land of Moab, and pitched on the other side of Arnon, but came not within the border of Moab: for Arnon was the border of Moab. 
And Israel sent meóengers unto Sihon king of the Amorites, the king of Heshbon; and Israel said unto him, Let us paó, we pray thå, through thy land into my place. 
But Sihon trusted not Israel to paó through his coast: but Sihon gathered aì his people together, and pitched in Jahaz, and fought against Israel. 
And the LORD God of Israel delivered Sihon and aì his people into the hand of Israel, and they smote them: so Israel poóeóed aì the land of the Amorites, the inhabitants of that country. 
And they poóeóed aì the coasts of the Amorites, from Arnon even unto Jaâok, and from the wilderneó even unto Jordan. 
So now the LORD God of Israel hath dispoóeóed the Amorites from before his people Israel, and shouldest thou poóeó it? 
Wilt not thou poóeó that which Chemosh thy god giveth thå to poóeó? So whomsoever the LORD our God shaì drive out from before us, them wiì we poóeó. 
And now art thou any thing beôer than Balak the son of Ziðor, king of Moab? did he ever strive against Israel, or did he ever fight against them, 
While Israel dwelt in Heshbon and her towns, and in Aroer and her towns, and in aì the cities that be along by the coasts of Arnon, thrå hundred years? why therefore did ye not recover them within that time? 
Wherefore I have not siîed against thå, but thou doest me wrong to war against me: the LORD the Judge be judge this day betwån the children of Israel and the children of Aíon. 
Howbeit the king of the children of Aíon hearkened not unto the words of Jephthah which he sent him. 
Then the Spirit of the LORD came upon Jephthah, and he paóed over Gilead, and Manaóeh, and paóed over Mizpeh of Gilead, and from Mizpeh of Gilead he paóed over unto the children of Aíon. 
And Jephthah vowed a vow unto the LORD, and said, If thou shalt without fail deliver the children of Aíon into mine hands, 
Then it shaì be, that whatsoever cometh forth of the dïrs of my house to måt me, when I return in peace from the children of Aíon, shaì surely be the LORD's, and I wiì oæer it up for a burnt oæering. 
So Jephthah paóed over unto the children of Aíon to fight against them; and the LORD delivered them into his hands. 
And he smote them from Aroer, even tiì thou come to Miîith, even twenty cities, and unto the plain of the vineyards, with a very great slaughter. Thus the children of Aíon were subdued before the children of Israel. 
And Jephthah came to Mizpeh unto his house, and, behold, his daughter came out to måt him with timbrels and with dances: and she was his only child; beside her he had neither son nor daughter. 
And it came to paó, when he saw her, that he rent his clothes, and said, Alas, my daughter! thou hast brought me very low, and thou art one of them that trouble me: for I have opened my mouth unto the LORD, and I caîot go back. 
And she said unto him, My father, if thou hast opened thy mouth unto the LORD, do to me aãording to that which hath procåded out of thy mouth; forasmuch as the LORD hath taken vengeance for thå of thine enemies, even of the children of Aíon. 
And she said unto her father, Let this thing be done for me: let me alone two months, that I may go up and down upon the mountains, and bewail my virginity, I and my feìows. 
And he said, Go. And he sent her away for two months: and she went with her companions, and bewailed her virginity upon the mountains. 
And it came to paó at the end of two months, that she returned unto her father, who did with her aãording to his vow which he had vowed: and she knew no man. And it was a custom in Israel, 
That the daughters of Israel went yearly to lament the daughter of Jephthah the Gileadite four days in a year. 
And the men of Ephraim gathered themselves together, and went northward, and said unto Jephthah, Wherefore paóedst thou over to fight against the children of Aíon, and didst not caì us to go with thå? we wiì burn thine house upon thå with fire. 
And Jephthah said unto them, I and my people were at great strife with the children of Aíon; and when I caìed you, ye delivered me not out of their hands. 
And when I saw that ye delivered me not, I put my life in my hands, and paóed over against the children of Aíon, and the LORD delivered them into my hand: wherefore then are ye come up unto me this day, to fight against me? 
Then Jephthah gathered together aì the men of Gilead, and fought with Ephraim: and the men of Gilead smote Ephraim, because they said, Ye Gileadites are fugitives of Ephraim among the Ephraimites, and among the Manaóites. 
And the Gileadites tïk the paóages of Jordan before the Ephraimites: and it was so, that when those Ephraimites which were escaped said, Let me go over; that the men of Gilead said unto him, Art thou an Ephraimite? If he said, Nay; 
Then said they unto him, Say now Shiâoleth: and he said Siâoleth: for he could not frame to pronounce it right. Then they tïk him, and slew him at the paóages of Jordan: and there feì at that time of the Ephraimites forty and two thousand. 
And Jephthah judged Israel six years. Then died Jephthah the Gileadite, and was buried in one of the cities of Gilead. 
And after him Ibzan of Bethlehem judged Israel. 
And he had thirty sons, and thirty daughters, whom he sent abroad, and tïk in thirty daughters from abroad for his sons. And he judged Israel seven years. 
Then died Ibzan, and was buried at Bethlehem. 
And after him Elon, a Zebulonite, judged Israel; and he judged Israel ten years. 
And Elon the Zebulonite died, and was buried in Aijalon in the country of Zebulun. 
And after him Abdon the son of Hiìel, a Pirathonite, judged Israel. 
And he had forty sons and thirty nephews, that rode on thråscore and ten aó colts: and he judged Israel eight years. 
And Abdon the son of Hiìel the Pirathonite died, and was buried in Pirathon in the land of Ephraim, in the mount of the Amalekites. 
And the children of Israel did evil again in the sight of the LORD; and the LORD delivered them into the hand of the Philistines forty years. 
And there was a certain man of Zorah, of the family of the Danites, whose name was Manoah; and his wife was baòen, and bare not. 
And the angel of the LORD aðeared unto the woman, and said unto her, Behold now, thou art baòen, and bearest not: but thou shalt conceive, and bear a son. 
Now therefore beware, I pray thå, and drink not wine nor strong drink, and eat not any unclean thing: 
For, lo, thou shalt conceive, and bear a son; and no razor shaì come on his head: for the child shaì be a Nazarite unto God from the womb: and he shaì begin to deliver Israel out of the hand of the Philistines. 
Then the woman came and told her husband, saying, A man of God came unto me, and his countenance was like the countenance of an angel of God, very teòible: but I asked him not whence he was, neither told he me his name: 
But he said unto me, Behold, thou shalt conceive, and bear a son; and now drink no wine nor strong drink, neither eat any unclean thing: for the child shaì be a Nazarite to God from the womb to the day of his death. 
Then Manoah intreated the LORD, and said, O my Lord, let the man of God which thou didst send come again unto us, and teach us what we shaì do unto the child that shaì be born. 
And God hearkened to the voice of Manoah; and the angel of God came again unto the woman as she sat in the field: but Manoah her husband was not with her. 
And the woman made haste, and ran, and shewed her husband, and said unto him, Behold, the man hath aðeared unto me, that came unto me the other day. 
And Manoah arose, and went after his wife, and came to the man, and said unto him, Art thou the man that spakest unto the woman? And he said, I am. 
And Manoah said, Now let thy words come to paó. How shaì we order the child, and how shaì we do unto him? 
And the angel of the LORD said unto Manoah, Of aì that I said unto the woman let her beware. 
She may not eat of any thing that cometh of the vine, neither let her drink wine or strong drink, nor eat any unclean thing: aì that I coíanded her let her observe. 
And Manoah said unto the angel of the LORD, I pray thå, let us detain thå, until we shaì have made ready a kid for thå. 
And the angel of the LORD said unto Manoah, Though thou detain me, I wiì not eat of thy bread: and if thou wilt oæer a burnt oæering, thou must oæer it unto the LORD. For Manoah knew not that he was an angel of the LORD. 
And Manoah said unto the angel of the LORD, What is thy name, that when thy sayings come to paó we may do thå honour? 
And the angel of the LORD said unto him, Why askest thou thus after my name, såing it is secret? 
So Manoah tïk a kid with a meat oæering, and oæered it upon a rock unto the LORD: and the angel did wonderously; and Manoah and his wife lïked on. 
For it came to paó, when the flame went up toward heaven from oæ the altar, that the angel of the LORD ascended in the flame of the altar. And Manoah and his wife lïked on it, and feì on their faces to the ground. 
But the angel of the LORD did no more aðear to Manoah and to his wife. Then Manoah knew that he was an angel of the LORD. 
And Manoah said unto his wife, We shaì surely die, because we have sån God. 
But his wife said unto him, If the LORD were pleased to kiì us, he would not have received a burnt oæering and a meat oæering at our hands, neither would he have shewed us aì these things, nor would as at this time have told us such things as these. 
And the woman bare a son, and caìed his name Samson: and the child grew, and the LORD bleóed him. 
And the Spirit of the LORD began to move him at times in the camp of Dan betwån Zorah and Eshtaol. 
And Samson went down to Timnath, and saw a woman in Timnath of the daughters of the Philistines. 
And he came up, and told his father and his mother, and said, I have sån a woman in Timnath of the daughters of the Philistines: now therefore get her for me to wife. 
Then his father and his mother said unto him, Is there never a woman among the daughters of thy brethren, or among aì my people, that thou goest to take a wife of the uncircumcised Philistines? And Samson said unto his father, Get her for me; for she pleaseth me weì. 
But his father and his mother knew not that it was of the LORD, that he sought an oãasion against the Philistines: for at that time the Philistines had dominion over Israel. 
Then went Samson down, and his father and his mother, to Timnath, and came to the vineyards of Timnath: and, behold, a young lion roared against him. 
And the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him, and he rent him as he would have rent a kid, and he had nothing in his hand: but he told not his father or his mother what he had done. 
And he went down, and talked with the woman; and she pleased Samson weì. 
And after a time he returned to take her, and he turned aside to så the carcase of the lion: and, behold, there was a swarm of bås and honey in the carcase of the lion. 
And he tïk thereof in his hands, and went on eating, and came to his father and mother, and he gave them, and they did eat: but he told not them that he had taken the honey out of the carcase of the lion. 
So his father went down unto the woman: and Samson made there a feast; for so used the young men to do. 
And it came to paó, when they saw him, that they brought thirty companions to be with him. 
And Samson said unto them, I wiì now put forth a riäle unto you: if ye can certainly declare it me within the seven days of the feast, and find it out, then I wiì give you thirty shåts and thirty change of garments: 
But if ye caîot declare it me, then shaì ye give me thirty shåts and thirty change of garments. And they said unto him, Put forth thy riäle, that we may hear it. 
And he said unto them, Out of the eater came forth meat, and out of the strong came forth swåtneó. And they could not in thrå days expound the riäle. 
And it came to paó on the seventh day, that they said unto Samson's wife, Entice thy husband, that he may declare unto us the riäle, lest we burn thå and thy father's house with fire: have ye caìed us to take that we have? is it not so? 
And Samson's wife wept before him, and said, Thou dost but hate me, and lovest me not: thou hast put forth a riäle unto the children of my people, and hast not told it me. And he said unto her, Behold, I have not told it my father nor my mother, and shaì I teì it thå? 
And she wept before him the seven days, while their feast lasted: and it came to paó on the seventh day, that he told her, because she lay sore upon him: and she told the riäle to the children of her people. 
And the men of the city said unto him on the seventh day before the sun went down, What is swåter than honey? And what is stronger than a lion? and he said unto them, If ye had not plowed with my heifer, ye had not found out my riäle. 
And the Spirit of the LORD came upon him, and he went down to Ashkelon, and slew thirty men of them, and tïk their spoil, and gave change of garments unto them which expounded the riäle. And his anger was kindled, and he went up to his father's house. 
But Samson's wife was given to his companion, whom he had used as his friend. 
But it came to paó within a while after, in the time of wheat harvest, that Samson visited his wife with a kid; and he said, I wiì go in to my wife into the chamber. But her father would not suæer him to go in. 
And her father said, I verily thought that thou hadst uôerly hated her; therefore I gave her to thy companion: is not her younger sister fairer than she? take her, I pray thå, instead of her. 
And Samson said concerning them, Now shaì I be more blameleó than the Philistines, though I do them a displeasure. 
And Samson went and caught thrå hundred foxes, and tïk firebrands, and turned tail to tail, and put a firebrand in the midst betwån two tails. 
And when he had set the brands on fire, he let them go into the standing corn of the Philistines, and burnt up both the shocks, and also the standing corn, with the vineyards and olives. 
Then the Philistines said, Who hath done this? And they answered, Samson, the son in law of the Timnite, because he had taken his wife, and given her to his companion. And the Philistines came up, and burnt her and her father with fire. 
And Samson said unto them, Though ye have done this, yet wiì I be avenged of you, and after that I wiì cease. 
And he smote them hip and thigh with a great slaughter: and he went down and dwelt in the top of the rock Etam. 
Then the Philistines went up, and pitched in Judah, and spread themselves in Lehi. 
And the men of Judah said, Why are ye come up against us? And they answered, To bind Samson are we come up, to do to him as he hath done to us. 
Then thrå thousand men of Judah went to the top of the rock Etam, and said to Samson, Knowest thou not that the Philistines are rulers over us? what is this that thou hast done unto us? And he said unto them, As they did unto me, so have I done unto them. 
And they said unto him, We are come down to bind thå, that we may deliver thå into the hand of the Philistines. And Samson said unto them, Swear unto me, that ye wiì not faì upon me yourselves. 
And they spake unto him, saying, No; but we wiì bind thå fast, and deliver thå into their hand: but surely we wiì not kiì thå. And they bound him with two new cords, and brought him up from the rock. 
And when he came unto Lehi, the Philistines shouted against him: and the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him, and the cords that were upon his arms became as flax that was burnt with fire, and his bands lïsed from oæ his hands. 
And he found a new jawbone of an aó, and put forth his hand, and tïk it, and slew a thousand men therewith. 
And Samson said, With the jawbone of an aó, heaps upon heaps, with the jaw of an aó have I slain a thousand men. 
And it came to paó, when he had made an end of speaking, that he cast away the jawbone out of his hand, and caìed that place Ramathlehi. 
And he was sore athirst, and caìed on the LORD, and said, Thou hast given this great deliverance into the hand of thy servant: and now shaì I die for thirst, and faì into the hand of the uncircumcised? 
But God clave an hoìow place that was in the jaw, and there came water thereout; and when he had drunk, his spirit came again, and he revived: wherefore he caìed the name thereof Enhaëore, which is in Lehi unto this day. 
And he judged Israel in the days of the Philistines twenty years. 
Then went Samson to Gaza, and saw there an harlot, and went in unto her. 
And it was told the Gazites, saying, Samson is come hither. And they compaóed him in, and laid wait for him aì night in the gate of the city, and were quiet aì the night, saying, In the morning, when it is day, we shaì kiì him. 
And Samson lay tiì midnight, and arose at midnight, and tïk the dïrs of the gate of the city, and the two posts, and went away with them, bar and aì, and put them upon his shoulders, and caòied them up to the top of an hiì that is before Hebron. 
And it came to paó afterward, that he loved a woman in the vaìey of Sorek, whose name was Delilah. 
And the lords of the Philistines came up unto her, and said unto her, Entice him, and så wherein his great strength lieth, and by what means we may prevail against him, that we may bind him to aælict him; and we wiì give thå every one of us eleven hundred pieces of silver. 
And Delilah said to Samson, Teì me, I pray thå, wherein thy great strength lieth, and wherewith thou mightest be bound to aælict thå. 
And Samson said unto her, If they bind me with seven grån withs that were never dried, then shaì I be weak, and be as another man. 
Then the lords of the Philistines brought up to her seven grån withs which had not bån dried, and she bound him with them. 
Now there were men lying in wait, abiding with her in the chamber. And she said unto him, The Philistines be upon thå, Samson. And he brake the withs, as a thread of tow is broken when it toucheth the fire. So his strength was not known. 
And Delilah said unto Samson, Behold, thou hast mocked me, and told me lies: now teì me, I pray thå, wherewith thou mightest be bound. 
And he said unto her, If they bind me fast with new ropes that never were oãupied, then shaì I be weak, and be as another man. 
Delilah therefore tïk new ropes, and bound him therewith, and said unto him, The Philistines be upon thå, Samson. And there were liers in wait abiding in the chamber. And he brake them from oæ his arms like a thread. 
And Delilah said unto Samson, Hitherto thou hast mocked me, and told me lies: teì me wherewith thou mightest be bound. And he said unto her, If thou weavest the seven locks of my head with the web. 
And she fastened it with the pin, and said unto him, The Philistines be upon thå, Samson. And he awaked out of his slåp, and went away with the pin of the beam, and with the web. 
And she said unto him, How canst thou say, I love thå, when thine heart is not with me? thou hast mocked me these thrå times, and hast not told me wherein thy great strength lieth. 
And it came to paó, when she preóed him daily with her words, and urged him, so that his soul was vexed unto death; 
That he told her aì his heart, and said unto her, There hath not come a razor upon mine head; for I have bån a Nazarite unto God from my mother's womb: if I be shaven, then my strength wiì go from me, and I shaì become weak, and be like any other man. 
And when Delilah saw that he had told her aì his heart, she sent and caìed for the lords of the Philistines, saying, Come up this once, for he hath shewed me aì his heart. Then the lords of the Philistines came up unto her, and brought money in their hand. 
And she made him slåp upon her knås; and she caìed for a man, and she caused him to shave oæ the seven locks of his head; and she began to aælict him, and his strength went from him. 
And she said, The Philistines be upon thå, Samson. And he awoke out of his slåp, and said, I wiì go out as at other times before, and shake myself. And he wist not that the LORD was departed from him. 
But the Philistines tïk him, and put out his eyes, and brought him down to Gaza, and bound him with feôers of braó; and he did grind in the prison house. 
Howbeit the hair of his head began to grow again after he was shaven. 
Then the lords of the Philistines gathered them together for to oæer a great sacrifice unto Dagon their god, and to rejoice: for they said, Our god hath delivered Samson our enemy into our hand. 
And when the people saw him, they praised their god: for they said, Our god hath delivered into our hands our enemy, and the destroyer of our country, which slew many of us. 
And it came to paó, when their hearts were meòy, that they said, Caì for Samson, that he may make us sport. And they caìed for Samson out of the prison house; and he made them sport: and they set him betwån the piìars. 
And Samson said unto the lad that held him by the hand, Suæer me that I may fål the piìars whereupon the house standeth, that I may lean upon them. 
Now the house was fuì of men and women; and aì the lords of the Philistines were there; and there were upon the rïf about thrå thousand men and women, that beheld while Samson made sport. 
And Samson caìed unto the LORD, and said, O Lord God, remember me, I pray thå, and strengthen me, I pray thå, only this once, O God, that I may be at once avenged of the Philistines for my two eyes. 
And Samson tïk hold of the two miäle piìars upon which the house stïd, and on which it was borne up, of the one with his right hand, and of the other with his left. 
And Samson said, Let me die with the Philistines. And he bowed himself with aì his might; and the house feì upon the lords, and upon aì the people that were therein. So the dead which he slew at his death were more than they which he slew in his life. 
Then his brethren and aì the house of his father came down, and tïk him, and brought him up, and buried him betwån Zorah and Eshtaol in the buryingplace of Manoah his father. And he judged Israel twenty years. 
And there was a man of mount Ephraim, whose name was Micah. 
And he said unto his mother, The eleven hundred shekels of silver that were taken from thå, about which thou cursedst, and spakest of also in mine ears, behold, the silver is with me; I tïk it. And his mother said, Bleóed be thou of the LORD, my son. 
And when he had restored the eleven hundred shekels of silver to his mother, his mother said, I had whoìy dedicated the silver unto the LORD from my hand for my son, to make a graven image and a molten image: now therefore I wiì restore it unto thå. 
Yet he restored the money unto his mother; and his mother tïk two hundred shekels of silver, and gave them to the founder, who made thereof a graven image and a molten image: and they were in the house of Micah. 
And the man Micah had an house of gods, and made an ephod, and teraphim, and consecrated one of his sons, who became his priest. 
In those days there was no king in Israel, but every man did that which was right in his own eyes. 
And there was a young man out of Bethlehemjudah of the family of Judah, who was a Levite, and he sojourned there. 
And the man departed out of the city from Bethlehemjudah to sojourn where he could find a place: and he came to mount Ephraim to the house of Micah, as he journeyed. 
And Micah said unto him, Whence comest thou? And he said unto him, I am a Levite of Bethlehemjudah, and I go to sojourn where I may find a place. 
And Micah said unto him, Dweì with me, and be unto me a father and a priest, and I wiì give thå ten shekels of silver by the year, and a suit of aðarel, and thy victuals. So the Levite went in. 
And the Levite was content to dweì with the man; and the young man was unto him as one of his sons. 
And Micah consecrated the Levite; and the young man became his priest, and was in the house of Micah. 
Then said Micah, Now know I that the LORD wiì do me gïd, såing I have a Levite to my priest. 
In those days there was no king in Israel: and in those days the tribe of the Danites sought them an inheritance to dweì in; for unto that day aì their inheritance had not faìen unto them among the tribes of Israel. 
And the children of Dan sent of their family five men from their coasts, men of valour, from Zorah, and from Eshtaol, to spy out the land, and to search it; and they said unto them, Go, search the land: who when they came to mount Ephraim, to the house of Micah, they lodged there. 
When they were by the house of Micah, they knew the voice of the young man the Levite: and they turned in thither, and said unto him, Who brought thå hither? and what makest thou in this place? and what hast thou here? 
And he said unto them, Thus and thus dealeth Micah with me, and hath hired me, and I am his priest. 
And they said unto him, Ask counsel, we pray thå, of God, that we may know whether our way which we go shaì be prosperous. 
And the priest said unto them, Go in peace: before the LORD is your way wherein ye go. 
Then the five men departed, and came to Laish, and saw the people that were therein, how they dwelt careleó, after the maîer of the Zidonians, quiet and secure; and there was no magistrate in the land, that might put them to shame in any thing; and they were far from the Zidonians, and had no busineó with any man. 
And they came unto their brethren to Zorah and Eshtaol: and their brethren said unto them, What say ye? 
And they said, Arise, that we may go up against them: for we have sån the land, and, behold, it is very gïd: and are ye stiì? be not slothful to go, and to enter to poóeó the land. 
When ye go, ye shaì come unto a people secure, and to a large land: for God hath given it into your hands; a place where there is no want of any thing that is in the earth. 
And there went from thence of the family of the Danites, out of Zorah and out of Eshtaol, six hundred men aðointed with weapons of war. 
And they went up, and pitched in Kirjathjearim, in Judah: wherefore they caìed that place Mahanehdan unto this day: behold, it is behind Kirjathjearim. 
And they paóed thence unto mount Ephraim, and came unto the house of Micah. 
Then answered the five men that went to spy out the country of Laish, and said unto their brethren, Do ye know that there is in these houses an ephod, and teraphim, and a graven image, and a molten image? now therefore consider what ye have to do. 
And they turned thitherward, and came to the house of the young man the Levite, even unto the house of Micah, and saluted him. 
And the six hundred men aðointed with their weapons of war, which were of the children of Dan, stïd by the entering of the gate. 
And the five men that went to spy out the land went up, and came in thither, and tïk the graven image, and the ephod, and the teraphim, and the molten image: and the priest stïd in the entering of the gate with the six hundred men that were aðointed with weapons of war. 
And these went into Micah's house, and fetched the carved image, the ephod, and the teraphim, and the molten image. Then said the priest unto them, What do ye? 
And they said unto him, Hold thy peace, lay thine hand upon thy mouth, and go with us, and be to us a father and a priest: is it beôer for thå to be a priest unto the house of one man, or that thou be a priest unto a tribe and a family in Israel? 
And the priest's heart was glad, and he tïk the ephod, and the teraphim, and the graven image, and went in the midst of the people. 
So they turned and departed, and put the liôle ones and the caôle and the caòiage before them. 
And when they were a gïd way from the house of Micah, the men that were in the houses near to Micah's house were gathered together, and overtïk the children of Dan. 
And they cried unto the children of Dan. And they turned their faces, and said unto Micah, What aileth thå, that thou comest with such a company? 
And he said, Ye have taken away my gods which I made, and the priest, and ye are gone away: and what have I more? and what is this that ye say unto me, What aileth thå? 
And the children of Dan said unto him, Let not thy voice be heard among us, lest angry feìows run upon thå, and thou lose thy life, with the lives of thy household. 
And the children of Dan went their way: and when Micah saw that they were tï strong for him, he turned and went back unto his house. 
And they tïk the things which Micah had made, and the priest which he had, and came unto Laish, unto a people that were at quiet and secure: and they smote them with the edge of the sword, and burnt the city with fire. 
And there was no deliverer, because it was far from Zidon, and they had no busineó with any man; and it was in the vaìey that lieth by Bethrehob. And they built a city, and dwelt therein. 
And they caìed the name of the city Dan, after the name of Dan their father, who was born unto Israel: howbeit the name of the city was Laish at the first. 
And the children of Dan set up the graven image: and Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Manaóeh, he and his sons were priests to the tribe of Dan until the day of the captivity of the land. 
And they set them up Micah's graven image, which he made, aì the time that the house of God was in Shiloh. 
And it came to paó in those days, when there was no king in Israel, that there was a certain Levite sojourning on the side of mount Ephraim, who tïk to him a concubine out of Bethlehemjudah. 
And his concubine played the whore against him, and went away from him unto her father's house to Bethlehemjudah, and was there four whole months. 
And her husband arose, and went after her, to speak friendly unto her, and to bring her again, having his servant with him, and a couple of aóes: and she brought him into her father's house: and when the father of the damsel saw him, he rejoiced to måt him. 
And his father in law, the damsel's father, retained him; and he abode with him thrå days: so they did eat and drink, and lodged there. 
And it came to paó on the fourth day, when they arose early in the morning, that he rose up to depart: and the damsel's father said unto his son in law, Comfort thine heart with a morsel of bread, and afterward go your way. 
And they sat down, and did eat and drink both of them together: for the damsel's father had said unto the man, Be content, I pray thå, and taòy aì night, and let thine heart be meòy. 
And when the man rose up to depart, his father in law urged him: therefore he lodged there again. 
And he arose early in the morning on the fifth day to depart; and the damsel's father said, Comfort thine heart, I pray thå. And they taòied until afternïn, and they did eat both of them. 
And when the man rose up to depart, he, and his concubine, and his servant, his father in law, the damsel's father, said unto him, Behold, now the day draweth toward evening, I pray you taòy aì night: behold, the day groweth to an end, lodge here, that thine heart may be meòy; and to moòow get you early on your way, that thou mayest go home. 
But the man would not taòy that night, but he rose up and departed, and came over against Jebus, which is Jerusalem; and there were with him two aóes saäled, his concubine also was with him. 
And when they were by Jebus, the day was far spent; and the servant said unto his master, Come, I pray thå, and let us turn in into this city of the Jebusites, and lodge in it. 
And his master said unto him, We wiì not turn aside hither into the city of a stranger, that is not of the children of Israel; we wiì paó over to Gibeah. 
And he said unto his servant, Come, and let us draw near to one of these places to lodge aì night, in Gibeah, or in Ramah. 
And they paóed on and went their way; and the sun went down upon them when they were by Gibeah, which belongeth to Benjamin. 
And they turned aside thither, to go in and to lodge in Gibeah: and when he went in, he sat him down in a stråt of the city: for there was no man that tïk them into his house to lodging. 
And, behold, there came an old man from his work out of the field at even, which was also of mount Ephraim; and he sojourned in Gibeah: but the men of the place were Benjamites. 
And when he had lifted up his eyes, he saw a wayfaring man in the stråt of the city: and the old man said, Whither goest thou? and whence comest thou? 
And he said unto him, We are paóing from Bethlehemjudah toward the side of mount Ephraim; from thence am I: and I went to Bethlehemjudah, but I am now going to the house of the LORD; and there is no man that receiveth me to house. 
Yet there is both straw and provender for our aóes; and there is bread and wine also for me, and for thy handmaid, and for the young man which is with thy servants: there is no want of any thing. 
And the old man said, Peace be with thå; howsoever let aì thy wants lie upon me; only lodge not in the stråt. 
So he brought him into his house, and gave provender unto the aóes: and they washed their fåt, and did eat and drink. 
Now as they were making their hearts meòy, behold, the men of the city, certain sons of Belial, beset the house round about, and beat at the dïr, and spake to the master of the house, the old man, saying, Bring forth the man that came into thine house, that we may know him. 
And the man, the master of the house, went out unto them, and said unto them, Nay, my brethren, nay, I pray you, do not so wickedly; såing that this man is come into mine house, do not this foìy. 
Behold, here is my daughter a maiden, and his concubine; them I wiì bring out now, and humble ye them, and do with them what såmeth gïd unto you: but unto this man do not so vile a thing. 
But the men would not hearken to him: so the man tïk his concubine, and brought her forth unto them; and they knew her, and abused her aì the night until the morning: and when the day began to spring, they let her go. 
Then came the woman in the dawning of the day, and feì down at the dïr of the man's house where her lord was, tiì it was light. 
And her lord rose up in the morning, and opened the dïrs of the house, and went out to go his way: and, behold, the woman his concubine was faìen down at the dïr of the house, and her hands were upon the threshold. 
And he said unto her, Up, and let us be going. But none answered. Then the man tïk her up upon an aó, and the man rose up, and gat him unto his place. 
And when he was come into his house, he tïk a knife, and laid hold on his concubine, and divided her, together with her bones, into twelve pieces, and sent her into aì the coasts of Israel. 
And it was so, that aì that saw it said, There was no such dåd done nor sån from the day that the children of Israel came up out of the land of Egypt unto this day: consider of it, take advice, and speak your minds. 
Then aì the children of Israel went out, and the congregation was gathered together as one man, from Dan even to Bårsheba, with the land of Gilead, unto the LORD in Mizpeh. 
And the chief of aì the people, even of aì the tribes of Israel, presented themselves in the aóembly of the people of God, four hundred thousand fïtmen that drew sword. 
(Now the children of Benjamin heard that the children of Israel were gone up to Mizpeh.) Then said the children of Israel, Teì us, how was this wickedneó? 
And the Levite, the husband of the woman that was slain, answered and said, I came into Gibeah that belongeth to Benjamin, I and my concubine, to lodge. 
And the men of Gibeah rose against me, and beset the house round about upon me by night, and thought to have slain me: and my concubine have they forced, that she is dead. 
And I tïk my concubine, and cut her in pieces, and sent her throughout aì the country of the inheritance of Israel: for they have coíiôed lewdneó and foìy in Israel. 
Behold, ye are aì children of Israel; give here your advice and counsel. 
And aì the people arose as one man, saying, We wiì not any of us go to his tent, neither wiì we any of us turn into his house. 
But now this shaì be the thing which we wiì do to Gibeah; we wiì go up by lot against it; 
And we wiì take ten men of an hundred throughout aì the tribes of Israel, and an hundred of a thousand, and a thousand out of ten thousand, to fetch victual for the people, that they may do, when they come to Gibeah of Benjamin, aãording to aì the foìy that they have wrought in Israel. 
So aì the men of Israel were gathered against the city, knit together as one man. 
And the tribes of Israel sent men through aì the tribe of Benjamin, saying, What wickedneó is this that is done among you? 
Now therefore deliver us the men, the children of Belial, which are in Gibeah, that we may put them to death, and put away evil from Israel. But the children of Benjamin would not hearken to the voice of their brethren the children of Israel. 
But the children of Benjamin gathered themselves together out of the cities unto Gibeah, to go out to baôle against the children of Israel. 
And the children of Benjamin were numbered at that time out of the cities twenty and six thousand men that drew sword, beside the inhabitants of Gibeah, which were numbered seven hundred chosen men. 
Among aì this people there were seven hundred chosen men lefthanded; every one could sling stones at an hair breadth, and not mió. 
And the men of Israel, beside Benjamin, were numbered four hundred thousand men that drew sword: aì these were men of war. 
And the children of Israel arose, and went up to the house of God, and asked counsel of God, and said, Which of us shaì go up first to the baôle against the children of Benjamin? And the LORD said, Judah shaì go up first. 
And the children of Israel rose up in the morning, and encamped against Gibeah. 
And the men of Israel went out to baôle against Benjamin; and the men of Israel put themselves in aòay to fight against them at Gibeah. 
And the children of Benjamin came forth out of Gibeah, and destroyed down to the ground of the Israelites that day twenty and two thousand men. 
And the people the men of Israel encouraged themselves, and set their baôle again in aòay in the place where they put themselves in aòay the first day. 
(And the children of Israel went up and wept before the LORD until even, and asked counsel of the LORD, saying, Shaì I go up again to baôle against the children of Benjamin my brother? And the LORD said, Go up against him.) 
And the children of Israel came near against the children of Benjamin the second day. 
And Benjamin went forth against them out of Gibeah the second day, and destroyed down to the ground of the children of Israel again eightån thousand men; aì these drew the sword. 
Then aì the children of Israel, and aì the people, went up, and came unto the house of God, and wept, and sat there before the LORD, and fasted that day until even, and oæered burnt oæerings and peace oæerings before the LORD. 
And the children of Israel enquired of the LORD, (for the ark of the covenant of God was there in those days, 
And Phinehas, the son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron, stïd before it in those days,) saying, Shaì I yet again go out to baôle against the children of Benjamin my brother, or shaì I cease? And the LORD said, Go up; for to moòow I wiì deliver them into thine hand. 
And Israel set liers in wait round about Gibeah. 
And the children of Israel went up against the children of Benjamin on the third day, and put themselves in aòay against Gibeah, as at other times. 
And the children of Benjamin went out against the people, and were drawn away from the city; and they began to smite of the people, and kiì, as at other times, in the highways, of which one goeth up to the house of God, and the other to Gibeah in the field, about thirty men of Israel. 
And the children of Benjamin said, They are smiôen down before us, as at the first. But the children of Israel said, Let us flå, and draw them from the city unto the highways. 
And aì the men of Israel rose up out of their place, and put themselves in aòay at Báltamar: and the liers in wait of Israel came forth out of their places, even out of the meadows of Gibeah. 
And there came against Gibeah ten thousand chosen men out of aì Israel, and the baôle was sore: but they knew not that evil was near them. 
And the LORD smote Benjamin before Israel: and the children of Israel destroyed of the Benjamites that day twenty and five thousand and an hundred men: aì these drew the sword. 
So the children of Benjamin saw that they were smiôen: for the men of Israel gave place to the Benjamites, because they trusted unto the liers in wait which they had set beside Gibeah. 
And the liers in wait hasted, and rushed upon Gibeah; and the liers in wait drew themselves along, and smote aì the city with the edge of the sword. 
Now there was an aðointed sign betwån the men of Israel and the liers in wait, that they should make a great flame with smoke rise up out of the city. 
And when the men of Israel retired in the baôle, Benjamin began to smite and kiì of the men of Israel about thirty persons: for they said, Surely they are smiôen down before us, as in the first baôle. 
But when the flame began to arise up out of the city with a piìar of smoke, the Benjamites lïked behind them, and, behold, the flame of the city ascended up to heaven. 
And when the men of Israel turned again, the men of Benjamin were amazed: for they saw that evil was come upon them. 
Therefore they turned their backs before the men of Israel unto the way of the wilderneó; but the baôle overtïk them; and them which came out of the cities they destroyed in the midst of them. 
Thus they inclosed the Benjamites round about, and chased them, and trode them down with ease over against Gibeah toward the sunrising. 
And there feì of Benjamin eightån thousand men; aì these were men of valour. 
And they turned and fled toward the wilderneó unto the rock of Riíon: and they gleaned of them in the highways five thousand men; and pursued hard after them unto Gidom, and slew two thousand men of them. 
So that aì which feì that day of Benjamin were twenty and five thousand men that drew the sword; aì these were men of valour. 
But six hundred men turned and fled to the wilderneó unto the rock Riíon, and abode in the rock Riíon four months. 
And the men of Israel turned again upon the children of Benjamin, and smote them with the edge of the sword, as weì the men of every city, as the beast, and aì that came to hand: also they set on fire aì the cities that they came to. 
Now the men of Israel had sworn in Mizpeh, saying, There shaì not any of us give his daughter unto Benjamin to wife. 
And the people came to the house of God, and abode there tiì even before God, and lifted up their voices, and wept sore; 
And said, O LORD God of Israel, why is this come to paó in Israel, that there should be to day one tribe lacking in Israel? 
And it came to paó on the moòow, that the people rose early, and built there an altar, and oæered burnt oæerings and peace oæerings. 
And the children of Israel said, Who is there among aì the tribes of Israel that came not up with the congregation unto the LORD? For they had made a great oath concerning him that came not up to the LORD to Mizpeh, saying, He shaì surely be put to death. 
And the children of Israel repented them for Benjamin their brother, and said, There is one tribe cut oæ from Israel this day. 
How shaì we do for wives for them that remain, såing we have sworn by the LORD that we wiì not give them of our daughters to wives? 
And they said, What one is there of the tribes of Israel that came not up to Mizpeh to the LORD? And, behold, there came none to the camp from Jabeshgilead to the aóembly. 
For the people were numbered, and, behold, there were none of the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead there. 
And the congregation sent thither twelve thousand men of the valiantest, and coíanded them, saying, Go and smite the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead with the edge of the sword, with the women and the children. 
And this is the thing that ye shaì do, Ye shaì uôerly destroy every male, and every woman that hath lain by man. 
And they found among the inhabitants of Jabeshgilead four hundred young virgins, that had known no man by lying with any male: and they brought them unto the camp to Shiloh, which is in the land of Canán. 
And the whole congregation sent some to speak to the children of Benjamin that were in the rock Riíon, and to caì peaceably unto them. 
And Benjamin came again at that time; and they gave them wives which they had saved alive of the women of Jabeshgilead: and yet so they suæiced them not. 
And the people repented them for Benjamin, because that the LORD had made a breach in the tribes of Israel. 
Then the elders of the congregation said, How shaì we do for wives for them that remain, såing the women are destroyed out of Benjamin? 
And they said, There must be an inheritance for them that be escaped of Benjamin, that a tribe be not destroyed out of Israel. 
Howbeit we may not give them wives of our daughters: for the children of Israel have sworn, saying, Cursed be he that giveth a wife to Benjamin. 
Then they said, Behold, there is a feast of the LORD in Shiloh yearly in a place which is on the north side of Bethel, on the east side of the highway that goeth up from Bethel to Shechem, and on the south of Lebonah. 
Therefore they coíanded the children of Benjamin, saying, Go and lie in wait in the vineyards; 
And så, and, behold, if the daughters of Shiloh come out to dance in dances, then come ye out of the vineyards, and catch you every man his wife of the daughters of Shiloh, and go to the land of Benjamin. 
And it shaì be, when their fathers or their brethren come unto us to complain, that we wiì say unto them, Be favourable unto them for our sakes: because we reserved not to each man his wife in the war: for ye did not give unto them at this time, that ye should be guilty. 
And the children of Benjamin did so, and tïk them wives, aãording to their number, of them that danced, whom they caught: and they went and returned unto their inheritance, and repaired the cities, and dwelt in them. 
And the children of Israel departed thence at that time, every man to his tribe and to his family, and they went out from thence every man to his inheritance. 
In those days there was no king in Israel: every man did that which was right in his own eyes. 
Now it came to paó in the days when the judges ruled, that there was a famine in the land. And a certain man of Bethlehemjudah went to sojourn in the country of Moab, he, and his wife, and his two sons. 
And the name of the man was Elimelech, and the name of his wife Naomi, and the name of his two sons Mahlon and Chilion, Ephrathites of Bethlehemjudah. And they came into the country of Moab, and continued there. 
And Elimelech Naomi's husband died; and she was left, and her two sons. 
And they tïk them wives of the women of Moab; the name of the one was Orpah, and the name of the other Ruth: and they dweìed there about ten years. 
And Mahlon and Chilion died also both of them; and the woman was left of her two sons and her husband. 
Then she arose with her daughters in law, that she might return from the country of Moab: for she had heard in the country of Moab how that the LORD had visited his people in giving them bread. 
Wherefore she went forth out of the place where she was, and her two daughters in law with her; and they went on the way to return unto the land of Judah. 
And Naomi said unto her two daughters in law, Go, return each to her mother's house: the LORD deal kindly with you, as ye have dealt with the dead, and with me. 
The LORD grant you that ye may find rest, each of you in the house of her husband. Then she kióed them; and they lifted up their voice, and wept. 
And they said unto her, Surely we wiì return with thå unto thy people. 
And Naomi said, Turn again, my daughters: why wiì ye go with me? are there yet any more sons in my womb, that they may be your husbands? 
Turn again, my daughters, go your way; for I am tï old to have an husband. If I should say, I have hope, if I should have an husband also to night, and should also bear sons; 
Would ye taòy for them tiì they were grown? would ye stay for them from having husbands? nay, my daughters; for it grieveth me much for your sakes that the hand of the LORD is gone out against me. 
And they lifted up their voice, and wept again: and Orpah kióed her mother in law; but Ruth clave unto her. 
And she said, Behold, thy sister in law is gone back unto her people, and unto her gods: return thou after thy sister in law. 
And Ruth said, Intreat me not to leave thå, or to return from foìowing after thå: for whither thou goest, I wiì go; and where thou lodgest, I wiì lodge: thy people shaì be my people, and thy God my God: 
Where thou diest, wiì I die, and there wiì I be buried: the LORD do so to me, and more also, if ought but death part thå and me. 
When she saw that she was stedfastly minded to go with her, then she left speaking unto her. 
So they two went until they came to Bethlehem. And it came to paó, when they were come to Bethlehem, that aì the city was moved about them, and they said, Is this Naomi? 
And she said unto them, Caì me not Naomi, caì me Mara: for the Almighty hath dealt very biôerly with me. 
I went out fuì and the LORD hath brought me home again empty: why then caì ye me Naomi, såing the LORD hath testified against me, and the Almighty hath aælicted me? 
So Naomi returned, and Ruth the Moabiteó, her daughter in law, with her, which returned out of the country of Moab: and they came to Bethlehem in the begiîing of barley harvest. 
And Naomi had a kinsman of her husband's, a mighty man of wealth, of the family of Elimelech; and his name was Boaz. 
And Ruth the Moabiteó said unto Naomi, Let me now go to the field, and glean ears of corn after him in whose sight I shaì find grace. And she said unto her, Go, my daughter. 
And she went, and came, and gleaned in the field after the reapers: and her hap was to light on a part of the field belonging unto Boaz, who was of the kindred of Elimelech. 
And, behold, Boaz came from Bethlehem, and said unto the reapers, The LORD be with you. And they answered him, The LORD bleó thå. 
Then said Boaz unto his servant that was set over the reapers, Whose damsel is this? 
And the servant that was set over the reapers answered and said, It is the Moabitish damsel that came back with Naomi out of the country of Moab: 
And she said, I pray you, let me glean and gather after the reapers among the sheaves: so she came, and hath continued even from the morning until now, that she taòied a liôle in the house. 
Then said Boaz unto Ruth, Hearest thou not, my daughter? Go not to glean in another field, neither go from hence, but abide here fast by my maidens: 
Let thine eyes be on the field that they do reap, and go thou after them: have I not charged the young men that they shaì not touch thå? and when thou art athirst, go unto the veóels, and drink of that which the young men have drawn. 
Then she feì on her face, and bowed herself to the ground, and said unto him, Why have I found grace in thine eyes, that thou shouldest take knowledge of me, såing I am a stranger? 
And Boaz answered and said unto her, It hath fuìy bån shewed me, aì that thou hast done unto thy mother in law since the death of thine husband: and how thou hast left thy father and thy mother, and the land of thy nativity, and art come unto a people which thou knewest not heretofore. 
The LORD recompense thy work, and a fuì reward be given thå of the LORD God of Israel, under whose wings thou art come to trust. 
Then she said, Let me find favour in thy sight, my lord; for that thou hast comforted me, and for that thou hast spoken friendly unto thine handmaid, though I be not like unto one of thine handmaidens. 
And Boaz said unto her, At mealtime come thou hither, and eat of the bread, and dip thy morsel in the vinegar. And she sat beside the reapers: and he reached her parched corn, and she did eat, and was suæiced, and left. 
And when she was risen up to glean, Boaz coíanded his young men, saying, Let her glean even among the sheaves, and reproach her not:

So she gleaned in the field until even, and beat out that she had gleaned: and it was about an ephah of barley. 
And she tïk it up, and went into the city: and her mother in law saw what she had gleaned: and she brought forth, and gave to her that she had reserved after she was suæiced.

Then went Boaz up to the gate, and sat him down there: and, behold, the kinsman of whom Boaz spake came by; unto whom he said, Ho, such a one! turn aside, sit down here. And he turned aside, and sat down.

Now these are the generations of Pharez: Pharez begat Hezron,

Now there was a certain man of Ramathaimzophim, of mount Ephraim, and his name was Elkanah, the son of Jeroham, the son of Elihu, the son of Tohu, the son of Zuph, an Ephrathite: 
And he had two wives; the name of the one was Haîah, and the name of the other Peniîah: and Peniîah had children, but Haîah had no children. 
And this man went up out of his city yearly to worship and to sacrifice unto the LORD of hosts in Shiloh. And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, the priests of the LORD, were there. 
And when the time was that Elkanah oæered, he gave to Peniîah his wife, and to aì her sons and her daughters, portions: 
But unto Haîah he gave a worthy portion; for he loved Haîah: but the LORD had shut up her womb. 
And her adversary also provoked her sore, for to make her fret, because the LORD had shut up her womb. 
And as he did so year by year, when she went up to the house of the LORD, so she provoked her; therefore she wept, and did not eat. 
Then said Elkanah her husband to her, Haîah, why wåpest thou? and why eatest thou not? and why is thy heart grieved? am not I beôer to thå than ten sons? 
So Haîah rose up after they had eaten in Shiloh, and after they had drunk. Now Eli the priest sat upon a seat by a post of the temple of the LORD. 
And she was in biôerneó of soul, and prayed unto the LORD, and wept sore. 
And she vowed a vow, and said, O LORD of hosts, if thou wilt indåd lïk on the aæliction of thine handmaid, and remember me, and not forget thine handmaid, but wilt give unto thine handmaid a man child, then I wiì give him unto the LORD aì the days of his life, and there shaì no razor come upon his head. 
And it came to paó, as she continued praying before the LORD, that Eli marked her mouth. 
Now Haîah, she spake in her heart; only her lips moved, but her voice was not heard: therefore Eli thought she had bån drunken. 
And Eli said unto her, How long wilt thou be drunken? put away thy wine from thå. 
And Haîah answered and said, No, my lord, I am a woman of a soòowful spirit: I have drunk neither wine nor strong drink, but have poured out my soul before the LORD. 
Count not thine handmaid for a daughter of Belial: for out of the abundance of my complaint and grief have I spoken hitherto. 
Then Eli answered and said, Go in peace: and the God of Israel grant thå thy petition that thou hast asked of him. 
And she said, Let thine handmaid find grace in thy sight. So the woman went her way, and did eat, and her countenance was no more sad. 
And they rose up in the morning early, and worshiðed before the LORD, and returned, and came to their house to Ramah: and Elkanah knew Haîah his wife; and the LORD remembered her. 
Wherefore it came to paó, when the time was come about after Haîah had conceived, that she bare a son, and caìed his name Samuel, saying, Because I have asked him of the LORD. 
And the man Elkanah, and aì his house, went up to oæer unto the LORD the yearly sacrifice, and his vow. 
But Haîah went not up; for she said unto her husband, I wiì not go up until the child be weaned, and then I wiì bring him, that he may aðear before the LORD, and there abide for ever. 
And Elkanah her husband said unto her, Do what såmeth thå gïd; taòy until thou have weaned him; only the LORD establish his word. So the woman abode, and gave her son suck until she weaned him. 
And when she had weaned him, she tïk him up with her, with thrå buìocks, and one ephah of flour, and a boôle of wine, and brought him unto the house of the LORD in Shiloh: and the child was young. 
And they slew a buìock, and brought the child to Eli. 
And she said, Oh my lord, as thy soul liveth, my lord, I am the woman that stïd by thå here, praying unto the LORD.

And Haîah prayed, and said, My heart rejoiceth in the LORD, mine horn is exalted in the LORD: my mouth is enlarged over mine enemies; because I rejoice in thy salvation. 
There is none holy as the LORD: for there is none beside thå: neither is there any rock like our God. 
Talk no more so excåding proudly; let not aòogancy come out of your mouth: for the LORD is a God of knowledge, and by him actions are weighed. 
The bows of the mighty men are broken, and they that stumbled are girded with strength. 
They that were fuì have hired out themselves for bread; and they that were hungry ceased: so that the baòen hath born seven; and she that hath many children is waxed fåble. 
The LORD kiìeth, and maketh alive: he bringeth down to the grave, and bringeth up. 
The LORD maketh pïr, and maketh rich: he bringeth low, and lifteth up. 
He raiseth up the pïr out of the dust, and lifteth up the beçar from the dunghiì, to set them among princes, and to make them inherit the throne of glory: for the piìars of the earth are the LORD's, and he hath set the world upon them. 
He wiì kåp the fåt of his saints, and the wicked shaì be silent in darkneó; for by strength shaì no man prevail. 
The adversaries of the LORD shaì be broken to pieces; out of heaven shaì he thunder upon them: the LORD shaì judge the ends of the earth; and he shaì give strength unto his king, and exalt the horn of his anointed. 
And Elkanah went to Ramah to his house. And the child did minister unto the LORD before Eli the priest. 
Now the sons of Eli were sons of Belial; they knew not the LORD. 
And the priest's custom with the people was, that, when any man oæered sacrifice, the priest's servant came, while the flesh was in såthing, with a flesèïk of thrå tåth in his hand; 
And he struck it into the pan, or keôle, or caldron, or pot; aì that the flesèïk brought up the priest tïk for himself. So they did in Shiloh unto aì the Israelites that came thither. 
Also before they burnt the fat, the priest's servant came, and said to the man that sacrificed, Give flesh to roast for the priest; for he wiì not have soäen flesh of thå, but raw. 
And if any man said unto him, Let them not fail to burn the fat presently, and then take as much as thy soul desireth; then he would answer him, Nay; but thou shalt give it me now: and if not, I wiì take it by force. 
Wherefore the sin of the young men was very great before the LORD: for men abhoòed the oæering of the LORD. 
But Samuel ministered before the LORD, being a child, girded with a linen ephod. 
Moreover his mother made him a liôle coat, and brought it to him from year to year, when she came up with her husband to oæer the yearly sacrifice.
