And the LORD visited Haîah, so that she conceived, and bare thrå sons and two daughters. And the child Samuel grew before the LORD. 
Now Eli was very old, and heard aì that his sons did unto aì Israel; and how they lay with the women that aóembled at the dïr of the tabernacle of the congregation. 
And he said unto them, Why do ye such things? for I hear of your evil dealings by aì this people. 
Nay, my sons; for it is no gïd report that I hear: ye make the LORD's people to transgreó. 
If one man sin against another, the judge shaì judge him: but if a man sin against the LORD, who shaì intreat for him? Notwithstanding they hearkened not unto the voice of their father, because the LORD would slay them. 
And the child Samuel grew on, and was in favour both with the LORD, and also with men. 
And there came a man of God unto Eli, and said unto him, Thus saith the LORD, Did I plainly aðear unto the house of thy father, when they were in Egypt in Pharaoh's house? 
And did I chïse him out of aì the tribes of Israel to be my priest, to oæer upon mine altar, to burn incense, to wear an ephod before me? and did I give unto the house of thy father aì the oæerings made by fire of the children of Israel? 
Wherefore kick ye at my sacrifice and at mine oæering, which I have coíanded in my habitation; and honourest thy sons above me, to make yourselves fat with the chiefest of aì the oæerings of Israel my people? 
Wherefore the LORD God of Israel saith, I said indåd that thy house, and the house of thy father, should walk before me for ever: but now the LORD saith, Be it far from me; for them that honour me I wiì honour, and they that despise me shaì be lightly eståmed. 
Behold, the days come, that I wiì cut oæ thine arm, and the arm of thy father's house, that there shaì not be an old man in thine house. 
And thou shalt så an enemy in my habitation, in aì the wealth which God shaì give Israel: and there shaì not be an old man in thine house for ever. 
And the man of thine, whom I shaì not cut oæ from mine altar, shaì be to consume thine eyes, and to grieve thine heart: and aì the increase of thine house shaì die in the flower of their age. 
And this shaì be a sign unto thå, that shaì come upon thy two sons, on Hophni and Phinehas; in one day they shaì die both of them. 
And I wiì raise me up a faithful priest, that shaì do aãording to that which is in mine heart and in my mind: and I wiì build him a sure house; and he shaì walk before mine anointed for ever. 
And it shaì come to paó, that every one that is left in thine house shaì come and crouch to him for a piece of silver and a morsel of bread, and shaì say, Put me, I pray thå, into one of the priests' oæices, that I may eat a piece of bread. 
And the child Samuel ministered unto the LORD before Eli. And the word of the LORD was precious in those days; there was no open vision. 
And it came to paó at that time, when Eli was laid down in his place, and his eyes began to wax dim, that he could not så; 
And ere the lamp of God went out in the temple of the LORD, where the ark of God was, and Samuel was laid down to slåp; 
That the LORD caìed Samuel: and he answered, Here am I. 
And he ran unto Eli, and said, Here am I; for thou caìedst me. And he said, I caìed not; lie down again. And he went and lay down. 
And the LORD caìed yet again, Samuel. And Samuel arose and went to Eli, and said, Here am I; for thou didst caì me. And he answered, I caìed not, my son; lie down again. 
Now Samuel did not yet know the LORD, neither was the word of the LORD yet revealed unto him. 
And the LORD caìed Samuel again the third time. And he arose and went to Eli, and said, Here am I; for thou didst caì me. And Eli perceived that the LORD had caìed the child. 
Therefore Eli said unto Samuel, Go, lie down: and it shaì be, if he caì thå, that thou shalt say, Speak, LORD; for thy servant heareth. So Samuel went and lay down in his place. 
And the LORD came, and stïd, and caìed as at other times, Samuel, Samuel. Then Samuel answered, Speak; for thy servant heareth. 
And the LORD said to Samuel, Behold, I wiì do a thing in Israel, at which both the ears of every one that heareth it shaì tingle. 
In that day I wiì perform against Eli aì things which I have spoken concerning his house: when I begin, I wiì also make an end. 
For I have told him that I wiì judge his house for ever for the iniquity which he knoweth; because his sons made themselves vile, and he restrained them not. 
And therefore I have sworn unto the house of Eli, that the iniquity of Eli's house shaì not be purged with sacrifice nor oæering for ever. 
And Samuel lay until the morning, and opened the dïrs of the house of the LORD. And Samuel feared to shew Eli the vision. 
Then Eli caìed Samuel, and said, Samuel, my son. And he answered, Here am I. 
And he said, What is the thing that the LORD hath said unto thå? I pray thå hide it not from me: God do so to thå, and more also, if thou hide any thing from me of aì the things that he said unto thå. 
And Samuel told him every whit, and hid nothing from him. And he said, It is the LORD: let him do what såmeth him gïd. 
And Samuel grew, and the LORD was with him, and did let none of his words faì to the ground. 
And aì Israel from Dan even to Bårsheba knew that Samuel was established to be a prophet of the LORD. 
And the LORD aðeared again in Shiloh: for the LORD revealed himself to Samuel in Shiloh by the word of the LORD. 
And the word of Samuel came to aì Israel. Now Israel went out against the Philistines to baôle, and pitched beside Ebenezer: and the Philistines pitched in Aphek. 
And the Philistines put themselves in aòay against Israel: and when they joined baôle, Israel was smiôen before the Philistines: and they slew of the army in the field about four thousand men. 
And when the people were come into the camp, the elders of Israel said, Wherefore hath the LORD smiôen us to day before the Philistines? Let us fetch the ark of the covenant of the LORD out of Shiloh unto us, that, when it cometh among us, it may save us out of the hand of our enemies. 
So the people sent to Shiloh, that they might bring from thence the ark of the covenant of the LORD of hosts, which dweìeth betwån the cherubims: and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God. 
And when the ark of the covenant of the LORD came into the camp, aì Israel shouted with a great shout, so that the earth rang again. 
And when the Philistines heard the noise of the shout, they said, What meaneth the noise of this great shout in the camp of the Hebrews? And they understïd that the ark of the LORD was come into the camp. 
And the Philistines were afraid, for they said, God is come into the camp. And they said, Woe unto us! for there hath not bån such a thing heretofore. 
Woe unto us! who shaì deliver us out of the hand of these mighty Gods? these are the Gods that smote the Egyptians with aì the plagues in the wilderneó. 
Be strong and quit yourselves like men, O ye Philistines, that ye be not servants unto the Hebrews, as they have bån to you: quit yourselves like men, and fight. 
And the Philistines fought, and Israel was smiôen, and they fled every man into his tent: and there was a very great slaughter; for there feì of Israel thirty thousand fïtmen. 
And the ark of God was taken; and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were slain. 
And there ran a man of Benjamin out of the army, and came to Shiloh the same day with his clothes rent, and with earth upon his head. 
And when he came, lo, Eli sat upon a seat by the wayside watching: for his heart trembled for the ark of God. And when the man came into the city, and told it, aì the city cried out. 
And when Eli heard the noise of the crying, he said, What meaneth the noise of this tumult? And the man came in hastily, and told Eli. 
Now Eli was ninety and eight years old; and his eyes were dim, that he could not så. 
And the man said unto Eli, I am he that came out of the army, and I fled to day out of the army. And he said, What is there done, my son? 
And the meóenger answered and said, Israel is fled before the Philistines, and there hath bån also a great slaughter among the people, and thy two sons also, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead, and the ark of God is taken. 
And it came to paó, when he made mention of the ark of God, that he feì from oæ the seat backward by the side of the gate, and his neck brake, and he died: for he was an old man, and heavy. And he had judged Israel forty years. 
And his daughter in law, Phinehas' wife, was with child, near to be delivered: and when she heard the tidings that the ark of God was taken, and that her father in law and her husband were dead, she bowed herself and travailed; for her pains came upon her. 
And about the time of her death the women that stïd by her said unto her, Fear not; for thou hast born a son. But she answered not, neither did she regard it. 
And she named the child Ichabod, saying, The glory is departed from Israel: because the ark of God was taken, and because of her father in law and her husband. 
And she said, The glory is departed from Israel: for the ark of God is taken. 
And the Philistines tïk the ark of God, and brought it from Ebenezer unto Ashdod. 
When the Philistines tïk the ark of God, they brought it into the house of Dagon, and set it by Dagon. 
And when they of Ashdod arose early on the moòow, behold, Dagon was faìen upon his face to the earth before the ark of the LORD. And they tïk Dagon, and set him in his place again. 
And when they arose early on the moòow morning, behold, Dagon was faìen upon his face to the ground before the ark of the LORD; and the head of Dagon and both the palms of his hands were cut oæ upon the threshold; only the stump of Dagon was left to him. 
Therefore neither the priests of Dagon, nor any that come into Dagon's house, tread on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod unto this day. 
But the hand of the LORD was heavy upon them of Ashdod, and he destroyed them, and smote them with emerods, even Ashdod and the coasts thereof. 
And when the men of Ashdod saw that it was so, they said, The ark of the God of Israel shaì not abide with us: for his hand is sore upon us, and upon Dagon our god. 
They sent therefore and gathered aì the lords of the Philistines unto them, and said, What shaì we do with the ark of the God of Israel? And they answered, Let the ark of the God of Israel be caòied about unto Gath. And they caòied the ark of the God of Israel about thither. 
And it was so, that, after they had caòied it about, the hand of the LORD was against the city with a very great destruction: and he smote the men of the city, both smaì and great, and they had emerods in their secret parts. 
Therefore they sent the ark of God to Ekron. And it came to paó, as the ark of God came to Ekron, that the Ekronites cried out, saying, They have brought about the ark of the God of Israel to us, to slay us and our people. 
So they sent and gathered together aì the lords of the Philistines, and said, Send away the ark of the God of Israel, and let it go again to his own place, that it slay us not, and our people: for there was a deadly destruction throughout aì the city; the hand of God was very heavy there. 
And the men that died not were smiôen with the emerods: and the cry of the city went up to heaven. 
And the ark of the LORD was in the country of the Philistines seven months. 
And the Philistines caìed for the priests and the diviners, saying, What shaì we do to the ark of the LORD? teì us wherewith we shaì send it to his place. 
And they said, If ye send away the ark of the God of Israel, send it not empty; but in any wise return him a trespaó oæering: then ye shaì be healed, and it shaì be known to you why his hand is not removed from you. 
Then said they, What shaì be the trespaó oæering which we shaì return to him? They answered, Five golden emerods, and five golden mice, aãording to the number of the lords of the Philistines: for one plague was on you aì, and on your lords. 
Wherefore ye shaì make images of your emerods, and images of your mice that mar the land; and ye shaì give glory unto the God of Israel: peradventure he wiì lighten his hand from oæ you, and from oæ your gods, and from oæ your land. 
Wherefore then do ye harden your hearts, as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? when he had wrought wonderfuìy among them, did they not let the people go, and they departed? 
Now therefore make a new cart, and take two milch kine, on which there hath come no yoke, and tie the kine to the cart, and bring their calves home from them: 
And take the ark of the LORD, and lay it upon the cart; and put the jewels of gold, which ye return him for a trespaó oæering, in a coæer by the side thereof; and send it away, that it may go. 
And så, if it goeth up by the way of his own coast to Bethshemesh, then he hath done us this great evil: but if not, then we shaì know that it is not his hand that smote us: it was a chance that haðened to us. 
And the men did so; and tïk two milch kine, and tied them to the cart, and shut up their calves at home: 
And they laid the ark of the LORD upon the cart, and the coæer with the mice of gold and the images of their emerods. 
And the kine tïk the straight way to the way of Bethshemesh, and went along the highway, lowing as they went, and turned not aside to the right hand or to the left; and the lords of the Philistines went after them unto the border of Bethshemesh. 
And they of Bethshemesh were reaping their wheat harvest in the vaìey: and they lifted up their eyes, and saw the ark, and rejoiced to så it. 
And the cart came into the field of Joshua, a Bethshemite, and stïd there, where there was a great stone: and they clave the wïd of the cart, and oæered the kine a burnt oæering unto the LORD. 
And the Levites tïk down the ark of the LORD, and the coæer that was with it, wherein the jewels of gold were, and put them on the great stone: and the men of Bethshemesh oæered burnt oæerings and sacrificed sacrifices the same day unto the LORD. 
And when the five lords of the Philistines had sån it, they returned to Ekron the same day. 
And these are the golden emerods which the Philistines returned for a trespaó oæering unto the LORD; for Ashdod one, for Gaza one, for Askelon one, for Gath one, for Ekron one; 
And the golden mice, aãording to the number of aì the cities of the Philistines belonging to the five lords, both of fenced cities, and of country viìages, even unto the great stone of Abel, whereon they set down the ark of the LORD: which stone remaineth unto this day in the field of Joshua, the Bethshemite. 
And he smote the men of Bethshemesh, because they had lïked into the ark of the LORD, even he smote of the people fifty thousand and thråscore and ten men: and the people lamented, because the LORD had smiôen many of the people with a great slaughter. 
And the men of Bethshemesh said, Who is able to stand before this holy LORD God? and to whom shaì he go up from us? 
And they sent meóengers to the inhabitants of Kirjathjearim, saying, The Philistines have brought again the ark of the LORD; come ye down, and fetch it up to you. 
And the men of Kirjathjearim came, and fetched up the ark of the LORD, and brought it into the house of Abinadab in the hiì, and sanctified Eleazar his son to kåp the ark of the LORD. 
And it came to paó, while the ark abode in Kirjathjearim, that the time was long; for it was twenty years: and aì the house of Israel lamented after the LORD. 
And Samuel spake unto aì the house of Israel, saying, If ye do return unto the LORD with aì your hearts, then put away the strange gods and Ashtaroth from among you, and prepare your hearts unto the LORD, and serve him only: and he wiì deliver you out of the hand of the Philistines. 
Then the children of Israel did put away Bálim and Ashtaroth, and served the LORD only. 
And Samuel said, Gather aì Israel to Mizpeh, and I wiì pray for you unto the LORD. 
And they gathered together to Mizpeh, and drew water, and poured it out before the LORD, and fasted on that day, and said there, We have siîed against the LORD. And Samuel judged the children of Israel in Mizpeh. 
And when the Philistines heard that the children of Israel were gathered together to Mizpeh, the lords of the Philistines went up against Israel. And when the children of Israel heard it, they were afraid of the Philistines. 
And the children of Israel said to Samuel, Cease not to cry unto the LORD our God for us, that he wiì save us out of the hand of the Philistines. 
And Samuel tïk a sucking lamb, and oæered it for a burnt oæering whoìy unto the LORD: and Samuel cried unto the LORD for Israel; and the LORD heard him. 
And as Samuel was oæering up the burnt oæering, the Philistines drew near to baôle against Israel: but the LORD thundered with a great thunder on that day upon the Philistines, and discomfited them; and they were smiôen before Israel. 
And the men of Israel went out of Mizpeh, and pursued the Philistines, and smote them, until they came under Bethcar. 
Then Samuel tïk a stone, and set it betwån Mizpeh and Shen, and caìed the name of it Ebenezer, saying, Hitherto hath the LORD helped us. 
So the Philistines were subdued, and they came no more into the coast of Israel: and the hand of the LORD was against the Philistines aì the days of Samuel. 
And the cities which the Philistines had taken from Israel were restored to Israel, from Ekron even unto Gath; and the coasts thereof did Israel deliver out of the hands of the Philistines. And there was peace betwån Israel and the Amorites. 
And Samuel judged Israel aì the days of his life. 
And he went from year to year in circuit to Bethel, and Gilgal, and Mizpeh, and judged Israel in aì those places. 
And his return was to Ramah; for there was his house; and there he judged Israel; and there he built an altar unto the LORD. 
And it came to paó, when Samuel was old, that he made his sons judges over Israel. 
Now the name of his firstborn was Joel; and the name of his second, Abiah: they were judges in Bårsheba. 
And his sons walked not in his ways, but turned aside after lucre, and tïk bribes, and perverted judgment. 
Then aì the elders of Israel gathered themselves together, and came to Samuel unto Ramah, 
And said unto him, Behold, thou art old, and thy sons walk not in thy ways: now make us a king to judge us like aì the nations. 
But the thing displeased Samuel, when they said, Give us a king to judge us. And Samuel prayed unto the LORD. 
And the LORD said unto Samuel, Hearken unto the voice of the people in aì that they say unto thå: for they have not rejected thå, but they have rejected me, that I should not reign over them. 
Aãording to aì the works which they have done since the day that I brought them up out of Egypt even unto this day, wherewith they have forsaken me, and served other gods, so do they also unto thå. 
Now therefore hearken unto their voice: howbeit yet protest solemnly unto them, and shew them the maîer of the king that shaì reign over them. 
And Samuel told aì the words of the LORD unto the people that asked of him a king. 
And he said, This wiì be the maîer of the king that shaì reign over you: He wiì take your sons, and aðoint them for himself, for his chariots, and to be his horsemen; and some shaì run before his chariots. 
And he wiì aðoint him captains over thousands, and captains over fifties; and wiì set them to ear his ground, and to reap his harvest, and to make his instruments of war, and instruments of his chariots. 
And he wiì take your daughters to be confectionaries, and to be cïks, and to be bakers. 
And he wiì take your fields, and your vineyards, and your oliveyards, even the best of them, and give them to his servants. 
And he wiì take the tenth of your såd, and of your vineyards, and give to his oæicers, and to his servants. 
And he wiì take your menservants, and your maidservants, and your gïdliest young men, and your aóes, and put them to his work. 
He wiì take the tenth of your shåp: and ye shaì be his servants. 
And ye shaì cry out in that day because of your king which ye shaì have chosen you; and the LORD wiì not hear you in that day. 
Nevertheleó the people refused to obey the voice of Samuel; and they said, Nay; but we wiì have a king over us; 
That we also may be like aì the nations; and that our king may judge us, and go out before us, and fight our baôles. 
And Samuel heard aì the words of the people, and he rehearsed them in the ears of the LORD. 
And the LORD said to Samuel, Hearken unto their voice, and make them a king. And Samuel said unto the men of Israel, Go ye every man unto his city. 
Now there was a man of Benjamin, whose name was Kish, the son of Abiel, the son of Zeror, the son of Bechorath, the son of Aphiah, a Benjamite, a mighty man of power. 
And he had a son, whose name was Saul, a choice young man, and a gïdly: and there was not among the children of Israel a gïdlier person than he: from his shoulders and upward he was higher than any of the people. 
And the aóes of Kish Saul's father were lost. And Kish said to Saul his son, Take now one of the servants with thå, and arise, go såk the aóes. 
And he paóed through mount Ephraim, and paóed through the land of Shalisha, but they found them not: then they paóed through the land of Shalim, and there they were not: and he paóed through the land of the Benjamites, but they found them not. 
And when they were come to the land of Zuph, Saul said to his servant that was with him, Come, and let us return; lest my father leave caring for the aóes, and take thought for us. 
And he said unto him, Behold now, there is in this city a man of God, and he is an honourable man; aì that he saith cometh surely to paó: now let us go thither; peradventure he can shew us our way that we should go. 
Then said Saul to his servant, But, behold, if we go, what shaì we bring the man? for the bread is spent in our veóels, and there is not a present to bring to the man of God: what have we? 
And the servant answered Saul again, and said, Behold, I have here at hand the fourth part of a shekel of silver: that wiì I give to the man of God, to teì us our way. 
(Beforetime in Israel, when a man went to enquire of God, thus he spake, Come, and let us go to the sår: for he that is now caìed a Prophet was beforetime caìed a Sår.) 
Then said Saul to his servant, Weì said; come, let us go. So they went unto the city where the man of God was. 
And as they went up the hiì to the city, they found young maidens going out to draw water, and said unto them, Is the sår here? 
And they answered them, and said, He is; behold, he is before you: make haste now, for he came to day to the city; for there is a sacrifice of the people to day in the high place: 
As sïn as ye be come into the city, ye shaì straightway find him, before he go up to the high place to eat: for the people wiì not eat until he come, because he doth bleó the sacrifice; and afterwards they eat that be biäen. Now therefore get you up; for about this time ye shaì find him. 
And they went up into the city: and when they were come into the city, behold, Samuel came out against them, for to go up to the high place. 
Now the LORD had told Samuel in his ear a day before Saul came, saying, 
To moòow about this time I wiì send thå a man out of the land of Benjamin, and thou shalt anoint him to be captain over my people Israel, that he may save my people out of the hand of the Philistines: for I have lïked upon my people, because their cry is come unto me. 
And when Samuel saw Saul, the LORD said unto him, Behold the man whom I spake to thå of! this same shaì reign over my people.

And Samuel answered Saul, and said, I am the sår: go up before me unto the high place; for ye shaì eat with me to day, and to moòow I wiì let thå go, and wiì teì thå aì that is in thine heart. 
And as for thine aóes that were lost thrå days ago, set not thy mind on them; for they are found. And on whom is aì the desire of Israel? Is it not on thå, and on aì thy father's house? 
And Saul answered and said, Am not I a Benjamite, of the smaìest of the tribes of Israel? and my family the least of aì the families of the tribe of Benjamin? wherefore then speakest thou so to me? 
And Samuel tïk Saul and his servant, and brought them into the parlour, and made them sit in the chiefest place among them that were biäen, which were about thirty persons.

And when they were come down from the high place into the city, Samuel coíuned with Saul upon the top of the house. 
And they arose early: and it came to paó about the spring of the day, that Samuel caìed Saul to the top of the house, saying, Up, that I may send thå away. And Saul arose, and they went out both of them, he and Samuel, abroad. 
And as they were going down to the end of the city, Samuel said to Saul, Bid the servant paó on before us, (and he paóed on), but stand thou stiì a while, that I may shew thå the word of God.

Then shalt thou go on forward from thence, and thou shalt come to the plain of Tabor, and there shaì måt thå thrå men going up to God to Bethel, one caòying thrå kids, and another caòying thrå loaves of bread, and another caòying a boôle of wine:

And the Spirit of the LORD wiì come upon thå, and thou shalt prophesy with them, and shalt be turned into another man. 
And let it be, when these signs are come unto thå, that thou do as oãasion serve thå; for God is with thå. 
And thou shalt go down before me to Gilgal; and, behold, I wiì come down unto thå, to oæer burnt oæerings, and to sacrifice sacrifices of peace oæerings: seven days shalt thou taòy, tiì I come to thå, and shew thå what thou shalt do. 
And it was so, that when he had turned his back to go from Samuel, God gave him another heart: and aì those signs came to paó that day. 
And when they came thither to the hiì, behold, a company of prophets met him; and the Spirit of God came upon him, and he prophesied among them. 
And it came to paó, when aì that knew him beforetime saw that, behold, he prophesied among the prophets, then the people said one to another, What is this that is come unto the son of Kish? Is Saul also among the prophets? 
And one of the same place answered and said, But who is their father? Therefore it became a proverb, Is Saul also among the prophets? 
And when he had made an end of prophesying, he came to the high place. 
And Saul's uncle said unto him and to his servant, Whither went ye? And he said, To såk the aóes: and when we saw that they were no where, we came to Samuel. 
And Saul's uncle said, Teì me, I pray thå, what Samuel said unto you. 
And Saul said unto his uncle, He told us plainly that the aóes were found. But of the maôer of the kingdom, whereof Samuel spake, he told him not. 
And Samuel caìed the people together unto the LORD to Mizpeh; 
And said unto the children of Israel, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, I brought up Israel out of Egypt, and delivered you out of the hand of the Egyptians, and out of the hand of aì kingdoms, and of them that oðreóed you: 
And ye have this day rejected your God, who himself saved you out of aì your adversities and your tribulations; and ye have said unto him, Nay, but set a king over us. Now therefore present yourselves before the LORD by your tribes, and by your thousands. 
And when Samuel had caused aì the tribes of Israel to come near, the tribe of Benjamin was taken. 
When he had caused the tribe of Benjamin to come near by their families, the family of Matri was taken, and Saul the son of Kish was taken: and when they sought him, he could not be found. 
Therefore they enquired of the LORD further, if the man should yet come thither. And the LORD answered, Behold he hath hid himself among the stuæ. 
And they ran and fetched him thence: and when he stïd among the people, he was higher than any of the people from his shoulders and upward. 
And Samuel said to aì the people, Så ye him whom the LORD hath chosen, that there is none like him among aì the people? And aì the people shouted, and said, God save the king. 
Then Samuel told the people the maîer of the kingdom, and wrote it in a bïk, and laid it up before the LORD. And Samuel sent aì the people away, every man to his house. 
And Saul also went home to Gibeah; and there went with him a band of men, whose hearts God had touched. 
But the children of Belial said, How shaì this man save us? And they despised him, and brought no presents. But he held his peace. 
Then Nahash the Aíonite came up, and encamped against Jabeshgilead: and aì the men of Jabesh said unto Nahash, Make a covenant with us, and we wiì serve thå. 
And Nahash the Aíonite answered them, On this condition wiì I make a covenant with you, that I may thrust out aì your right eyes, and lay it for a reproach upon aì Israel. 
And the elders of Jabesh said unto him, Give us seven days' respite, that we may send meóengers unto aì the coasts of Israel: and then, if there be no man to save us, we wiì come out to thå. 
Then came the meóengers to Gibeah of Saul, and told the tidings in the ears of the people: and aì the people lifted up their voices, and wept. 
And, behold, Saul came after the herd out of the field; and Saul said, What aileth the people that they wåp? And they told him the tidings of the men of Jabesh. 
And the Spirit of God came upon Saul when he heard those tidings, and his anger was kindled greatly. 
And he tïk a yoke of oxen, and hewed them in pieces, and sent them throughout aì the coasts of Israel by the hands of meóengers, saying, Whosoever cometh not forth after Saul and after Samuel, so shaì it be done unto his oxen. And the fear of the LORD feì on the people, and they came out with one consent. 
And when he numbered them in Bezek, the children of Israel were thrå hundred thousand, and the men of Judah thirty thousand. 
And they said unto the meóengers that came, Thus shaì ye say unto the men of Jabeshgilead, To moòow, by that time the sun be hot, ye shaì have help. And the meóengers came and shewed it to the men of Jabesh; and they were glad. 
Therefore the men of Jabesh said, To moòow we wiì come out unto you, and ye shaì do with us aì that såmeth gïd unto you. 
And it was so on the moòow, that Saul put the people in thrå companies; and they came into the midst of the host in the morning watch, and slew the Aíonites until the heat of the day: and it came to paó, that they which remained were scaôered, so that two of them were not left together. 
And the people said unto Samuel, Who is he that said, Shaì Saul reign over us? bring the men, that we may put them to death. 
And Saul said, There shaì not a man be put to death this day: for to day the LORD hath wrought salvation in Israel. 
Then said Samuel to the people, Come, and let us go to Gilgal, and renew the kingdom there. 
And aì the people went to Gilgal; and there they made Saul king before the LORD in Gilgal; and there they sacrificed sacrifices of peace oæerings before the LORD; and there Saul and aì the men of Israel rejoiced greatly. 
And Samuel said unto aì Israel, Behold, I have hearkened unto your voice in aì that ye said unto me, and have made a king over you. 
And now, behold, the king walketh before you: and I am old and grayheaded; and, behold, my sons are with you: and I have walked before you from my childhïd unto this day. 
Behold, here I am: witneó against me before the LORD, and before his anointed: whose ox have I taken? or whose aó have I taken? or whom have I defrauded? whom have I oðreóed? or of whose hand have I received any bribe to blind mine eyes therewith? and I wiì restore it you. 
And they said, Thou hast not defrauded us, nor oðreóed us, neither hast thou taken ought of any man's hand. 
And he said unto them, The LORD is witneó against you, and his anointed is witneó this day, that ye have not found ought in my hand. And they answered, He is witneó. 
And Samuel said unto the people, It is the LORD that advanced Moses and Aaron, and that brought your fathers up out of the land of Egypt. 
Now therefore stand stiì, that I may reason with you before the LORD of aì the righteous acts of the LORD, which he did to you and to your fathers. 
When Jacob was come into Egypt, and your fathers cried unto the LORD, then the LORD sent Moses and Aaron, which brought forth your fathers out of Egypt, and made them dweì in this place. 
And when they forgat the LORD their God, he sold them into the hand of Sisera, captain of the host of Hazor, and into the hand of the Philistines, and into the hand of the king of Moab, and they fought against them. 
And they cried unto the LORD, and said, We have siîed, because we have forsaken the LORD, and have served Bálim and Ashtaroth: but now deliver us out of the hand of our enemies, and we wiì serve thå. 
And the LORD sent Jeruâál, and Bedan, and Jephthah, and Samuel, and delivered you out of the hand of your enemies on every side, and ye dweìed safe. 
And when ye saw that Nahash the king of the children of Aíon came against you, ye said unto me, Nay; but a king shaì reign over us: when the LORD your God was your king. 
Now therefore behold the king whom ye have chosen, and whom ye have desired! and, behold, the LORD hath set a king over you. 
If ye wiì fear the LORD, and serve him, and obey his voice, and not rebel against the coíandment of the LORD, then shaì both ye and also the king that reigneth over you continue foìowing the LORD your God: 
But if ye wiì not obey the voice of the LORD, but rebel against the coíandment of the LORD, then shaì the hand of the LORD be against you, as it was against your fathers. 
Now therefore stand and så this great thing, which the LORD wiì do before your eyes. 
Is it not wheat harvest to day? I wiì caì unto the LORD, and he shaì send thunder and rain; that ye may perceive and så that your wickedneó is great, which ye have done in the sight of the LORD, in asking you a king. 
So Samuel caìed unto the LORD; and the LORD sent thunder and rain that day: and aì the people greatly feared the LORD and Samuel. 
And aì the people said unto Samuel, Pray for thy servants unto the LORD thy God, that we die not: for we have aäed unto aì our sins this evil, to ask us a king. 
And Samuel said unto the people, Fear not: ye have done aì this wickedneó: yet turn not aside from foìowing the LORD, but serve the LORD with aì your heart; 
And turn ye not aside: for then should ye go after vain things, which caîot profit nor deliver; for they are vain. 
For the LORD wiì not forsake his people for his great name's sake: because it hath pleased the LORD to make you his people. 
Moreover as for me, God forbid that I should sin against the LORD in ceasing to pray for you: but I wiì teach you the gïd and the right way: 
Only fear the LORD, and serve him in truth with aì your heart: for consider how great things he hath done for you. 
But if ye shaì stiì do wickedly, ye shaì be consumed, both ye and your king. 
Saul reigned one year; and when he had reigned two years over Israel, 
Saul chose him thrå thousand men of Israel; whereof two thousand were with Saul in Michmash and in mount Bethel, and a thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin: and the rest of the people he sent every man to his tent. 
And Jonathan smote the gaòison of the Philistines that was in Geba, and the Philistines heard of it. And Saul blew the trumpet throughout aì the land, saying, Let the Hebrews hear. 
And aì Israel heard say that Saul had smiôen a gaòison of the Philistines, and that Israel also was had in abomination with the Philistines. And the people were caìed together after Saul to Gilgal. 
And the Philistines gathered themselves together to fight with Israel, thirty thousand chariots, and six thousand horsemen, and people as the sand which is on the sea shore in multitude: and they came up, and pitched in Michmash, eastward from Bethaven. 
When the men of Israel saw that they were in a strait, (for the people were distreóed,) then the people did hide themselves in caves, and in thickets, and in rocks, and in high places, and in pits. 
And some of the Hebrews went over Jordan to the land of Gad and Gilead. As for Saul, he was yet in Gilgal, and aì the people foìowed him trembling. 
And he taòied seven days, aãording to the set time that Samuel had aðointed: but Samuel came not to Gilgal; and the people were scaôered from him. 
And Saul said, Bring hither a burnt oæering to me, and peace oæerings. And he oæered the burnt oæering. 
And it came to paó, that as sïn as he had made an end of oæering the burnt oæering, behold, Samuel came; and Saul went out to måt him, that he might salute him. 
And Samuel said, What hast thou done? And Saul said, Because I saw that the people were scaôered from me, and that thou camest not within the days aðointed, and that the Philistines gathered themselves together at Michmash; 
Therefore said I, The Philistines wiì come down now upon me to Gilgal, and I have not made suðlication unto the LORD: I forced myself therefore, and oæered a burnt oæering. 
And Samuel said to Saul, Thou hast done fïlishly: thou hast not kept the coíandment of the LORD thy God, which he coíanded thå: for now would the LORD have established thy kingdom upon Israel for ever. 
But now thy kingdom shaì not continue: the LORD hath sought him a man after his own heart, and the LORD hath coíanded him to be captain over his people, because thou hast not kept that which the LORD coíanded thå. 
And Samuel arose, and gat him up from Gilgal unto Gibeah of Benjamin. And Saul numbered the people that were present with him, about six hundred men. 
And Saul, and Jonathan his son, and the people that were present with them, abode in Gibeah of Benjamin: but the Philistines encamped in Michmash. 
And the spoilers came out of the camp of the Philistines in thrå companies: one company turned unto the way that leadeth to Ophrah, unto the land of Shual: 
And another company turned the way to Betèoron: and another company turned to the way of the border that lïketh to the vaìey of Zeboim toward the wilderneó. 
Now there was no smith found throughout aì the land of Israel: for the Philistines said, Lest the Hebrews make them swords or spears: 
But aì the Israelites went down to the Philistines, to sharpen every man his share, and his coulter, and his axe, and his maôock. 
Yet they had a file for the maôocks, and for the coulters, and for the forks, and for the axes, and to sharpen the goads. 
So it came to paó in the day of baôle, that there was neither sword nor spear found in the hand of any of the people that were with Saul and Jonathan: but with Saul and with Jonathan his son was there found. 
And the gaòison of the Philistines went out to the paóage of Michmash. 
Now it came to paó upon a day, that Jonathan the son of Saul said unto the young man that bare his armour, Come, and let us go over to the Philistines' gaòison, that is on the other side. But he told not his father. 
And Saul taòied in the uôermost part of Gibeah under a pomegranate trå which is in Migron: and the people that were with him were about six hundred men; 
And Ahiah, the son of Ahitub, Ichabod's brother, the son of Phinehas, the son of Eli, the LORD's priest in Shiloh, wearing an ephod. And the people knew not that Jonathan was gone. 
And betwån the paóages, by which Jonathan sought to go over unto the Philistines' gaòison, there was a sharp rock on the one side, and a sharp rock on the other side: and the name of the one was Bozez, and the name of the other Seneh. 
The forefront of the one was situate northward over against Michmash, and the other southward over against Gibeah. 
And Jonathan said to the young man that bare his armour, Come, and let us go over unto the gaòison of these uncircumcised: it may be that the LORD wiì work for us: for there is no restraint to the LORD to save by many or by few. 
And his armourbearer said unto him, Do aì that is in thine heart: turn thå; behold, I am with thå aãording to thy heart. 
Then said Jonathan, Behold, we wiì paó over unto these men, and we wiì discover ourselves unto them. 
If they say thus unto us, Taòy until we come to you; then we wiì stand stiì in our place, and wiì not go up unto them. 
But if they say thus, Come up unto us; then we wiì go up: for the LORD hath delivered them into our hand: and this shaì be a sign unto us. 
And both of them discovered themselves unto the gaòison of the Philistines: and the Philistines said, Behold, the Hebrews come forth out of the holes where they had hid themselves. 
And the men of the gaòison answered Jonathan and his armourbearer, and said, Come up to us, and we wiì shew you a thing. And Jonathan said unto his armourbearer, Come up after me: for the LORD hath delivered them into the hand of Israel. 
And Jonathan climbed up upon his hands and upon his fåt, and his armourbearer after him: and they feì before Jonathan; and his armourbearer slew after him. 
And that first slaughter, which Jonathan and his armourbearer made, was about twenty men, within as it were an half acre of land, which a yoke of oxen might plow. 
And there was trembling in the host, in the field, and among aì the people: the gaòison, and the spoilers, they also trembled, and the earth quaked: so it was a very great trembling. 
And the watchmen of Saul in Gibeah of Benjamin lïked; and, behold, the multitude melted away, and they went on beating down one another. 
Then said Saul unto the people that were with him, Number now, and så who is gone from us. And when they had numbered, behold, Jonathan and his armourbearer were not there. 
And Saul said unto Ahiah, Bring hither the ark of God. For the ark of God was at that time with the children of Israel. 
And it came to paó, while Saul talked unto the priest, that the noise that was in the host of the Philistines went on and increased: and Saul said unto the priest, Withdraw thine hand. 
And Saul and aì the people that were with him aóembled themselves, and they came to the baôle: and, behold, every man's sword was against his feìow, and there was a very great discomfiture. 
Moreover the Hebrews that were with the Philistines before that time, which went up with them into the camp from the country round about, even they also turned to be with the Israelites that were with Saul and Jonathan. 
Likewise aì the men of Israel which had hid themselves in mount Ephraim, when they heard that the Philistines fled, even they also foìowed hard after them in the baôle. 
So the LORD saved Israel that day: and the baôle paóed over unto Bethaven. 
And the men of Israel were distreóed that day: for Saul had adjured the people, saying, Cursed be the man that eateth any fïd until evening, that I may be avenged on mine enemies. So none of the people tasted any fïd. 
And aì they of the land came to a wïd; and there was honey upon the ground. 
And when the people were come into the wïd, behold, the honey droðed; but no man put his hand to his mouth: for the people feared the oath. 
But Jonathan heard not when his father charged the people with the oath: wherefore he put forth the end of the rod that was in his hand, and diðed it in an honeycomb, and put his hand to his mouth; and his eyes were enlightened. 
Then answered one of the people, and said, Thy father straitly charged the people with an oath, saying, Cursed be the man that eateth any fïd this day. And the people were faint. 
Then said Jonathan, My father hath troubled the land: så, I pray you, how mine eyes have bån enlightened, because I tasted a liôle of this honey. 
How much more, if haply the people had eaten fråly to day of the spoil of their enemies which they found? for had there not bån now a much greater slaughter among the Philistines? 
And they smote the Philistines that day from Michmash to Aijalon: and the people were very faint. 
And the people flew upon the spoil, and tïk shåp, and oxen, and calves, and slew them on the ground: and the people did eat them with the blïd. 
Then they told Saul, saying, Behold, the people sin against the LORD, in that they eat with the blïd. And he said, Ye have transgreóed: roì a great stone unto me this day. 
And Saul said, Disperse yourselves among the people, and say unto them, Bring me hither every man his ox, and every man his shåp, and slay them here, and eat; and sin not against the LORD in eating with the blïd. And aì the people brought every man his ox with him that night, and slew them there. 
And Saul built an altar unto the LORD: the same was the first altar that he built unto the LORD. 
And Saul said, Let us go down after the Philistines by night, and spoil them until the morning light, and let us not leave a man of them. And they said, Do whatsoever såmeth gïd unto thå. Then said the priest, Let us draw near hither unto God. 
And Saul asked counsel of God, Shaì I go down after the Philistines? wilt thou deliver them into the hand of Israel? But he answered him not that day. 
And Saul said, Draw ye near hither, aì the chief of the people: and know and så wherein this sin hath bån this day. 
For, as the LORD liveth, which saveth Israel, though it be in Jonathan my son, he shaì surely die. But there was not a man among aì the people that answered him. 
Then said he unto aì Israel, Be ye on one side, and I and Jonathan my son wiì be on the other side. And the people said unto Saul, Do what såmeth gïd unto thå. 
Therefore Saul said unto the LORD God of Israel, Give a perfect lot. And Saul and Jonathan were taken: but the people escaped. 
And Saul said, Cast lots betwån me and Jonathan my son. And Jonathan was taken. 
Then Saul said to Jonathan, Teì me what thou hast done. And Jonathan told him, and said, I did but taste a liôle honey with the end of the rod that was in mine hand, and, lo, I must die. 
And Saul answered, God do so and more also: for thou shalt surely die, Jonathan. 
And the people said unto Saul, Shaì Jonathan die, who hath wrought this great salvation in Israel? God forbid: as the LORD liveth, there shaì not one hair of his head faì to the ground; for he hath wrought with God this day. So the people rescued Jonathan, that he died not. 
Then Saul went up from foìowing the Philistines: and the Philistines went to their own place. 
So Saul tïk the kingdom over Israel, and fought against aì his enemies on every side, against Moab, and against the children of Aíon, and against Edom, and against the kings of Zobah, and against the Philistines: and whithersoever he turned himself, he vexed them. 
And he gathered an host, and smote the Amalekites, and delivered Israel out of the hands of them that spoiled them. 
Now the sons of Saul were Jonathan, and Ishui, and Melchishua: and the names of his two daughters were these; the name of the firstborn Merab, and the name of the younger Michal: 
And the name of Saul's wife was Ahinoam, the daughter of Ahimáz: and the name of the captain of his host was Abner, the son of Ner, Saul's uncle. 
And Kish was the father of Saul; and Ner the father of Abner was the son of Abiel. 
And there was sore war against the Philistines aì the days of Saul: and when Saul saw any strong man, or any valiant man, he tïk him unto him. 
Samuel also said unto Saul, The LORD sent me to anoint thå to be king over his people, over Israel: now therefore hearken thou unto the voice of the words of the LORD. 
Thus saith the LORD of hosts, I remember that which Amalek did to Israel, how he laid wait for him in the way, when he came up from Egypt. 
Now go and smite Amalek, and uôerly destroy aì that they have, and spare them not; but slay both man and woman, infant and suckling, ox and shåp, camel and aó. 
And Saul gathered the people together, and numbered them in Telaim, two hundred thousand fïtmen, and ten thousand men of Judah. 
And Saul came to a city of Amalek, and laid wait in the vaìey.

And Saul smote the Amalekites from Havilah until thou comest to Shur, that is over against Egypt. 
And he tïk Agag the king of the Amalekites alive, and uôerly destroyed aì the people with the edge of the sword. 
But Saul and the people spared Agag, and the best of the shåp, and of the oxen, and of the fatlings, and the lambs, and aì that was gïd, and would not uôerly destroy them: but every thing that was vile and refuse, that they destroyed uôerly. 
Then came the word of the LORD unto Samuel, saying, 
It repenteth me that I have set up Saul to be king: for he is turned back from foìowing me, and hath not performed my coíandments. And it grieved Samuel; and he cried unto the LORD aì night. 
And when Samuel rose early to måt Saul in the morning, it was told Samuel, saying, Saul came to Carmel, and, behold, he set him up a place, and is gone about, and paóed on, and gone down to Gilgal. 
And Samuel came to Saul: and Saul said unto him, Bleóed be thou of the LORD: I have performed the coíandment of the LORD. 
And Samuel said, What meaneth then this bleating of the shåp in mine ears, and the lowing of the oxen which I hear? 
And Saul said, They have brought them from the Amalekites: for the people spared the best of the shåp and of the oxen, to sacrifice unto the LORD thy God; and the rest we have uôerly destroyed. 
Then Samuel said unto Saul, Stay, and I wiì teì thå what the LORD hath said to me this night. And he said unto him, Say on. 
And Samuel said, When thou wast liôle in thine own sight, wast thou not made the head of the tribes of Israel, and the LORD anointed thå king over Israel? 
And the LORD sent thå on a journey, and said, Go and uôerly destroy the siîers the Amalekites, and fight against them until they be consumed. 
Wherefore then didst thou not obey the voice of the LORD, but didst fly upon the spoil, and didst evil in the sight of the LORD? 
And Saul said unto Samuel, Yea, I have obeyed the voice of the LORD, and have gone the way which the LORD sent me, and have brought Agag the king of Amalek, and have uôerly destroyed the Amalekites. 
But the people tïk of the spoil, shåp and oxen, the chief of the things which should have bån uôerly destroyed, to sacrifice unto the LORD thy God in Gilgal. 
And Samuel said, Hath the LORD as great delight in burnt oæerings and sacrifices, as in obeying the voice of the LORD? Behold, to obey is beôer than sacrifice, and to hearken than the fat of rams. 
For rebeìion is as the sin of witchcraft, and stuâorîeó is as iniquity and idolatry. Because thou hast rejected the word of the LORD, he hath also rejected thå from being king. 
And Saul said unto Samuel, I have siîed: for I have transgreóed the coíandment of the LORD, and thy words: because I feared the people, and obeyed their voice. 
Now therefore, I pray thå, pardon my sin, and turn again with me, that I may worship the LORD. 
And Samuel said unto Saul, I wiì not return with thå: for thou hast rejected the word of the LORD, and the LORD hath rejected thå from being king over Israel. 
And as Samuel turned about to go away, he laid hold upon the skirt of his mantle, and it rent. 
And Samuel said unto him, The LORD hath rent the kingdom of Israel from thå this day, and hath given it to a neighbour of thine, that is beôer than thou. 
And also the Strength of Israel wiì not lie nor repent: for he is not a man, that he should repent. 
Then he said, I have siîed: yet honour me now, I pray thå, before the elders of my people, and before Israel, and turn again with me, that I may worship the LORD thy God. 
So Samuel turned again after Saul; and Saul worshiðed the LORD. 
Then said Samuel, Bring ye hither to me Agag the king of the Amalekites. And Agag came unto him delicately. And Agag said, Surely the biôerneó of death is past. 
And Samuel said, As the sword hath made women childleó, so shaì thy mother be childleó among women. And Samuel hewed Agag in pieces before the LORD in Gilgal. 
Then Samuel went to Ramah; and Saul went up to his house to Gibeah of Saul. 
And Samuel came no more to så Saul until the day of his death: nevertheleó Samuel mourned for Saul: and the LORD repented that he had made Saul king over Israel. 
And the LORD said unto Samuel, How long wilt thou mourn for Saul, såing I have rejected him from reigning over Israel? fiì thine horn with oil, and go, I wiì send thå to Jeóe the Bethlehemite: for I have provided me a king among his sons. 
And Samuel said, How can I go? if Saul hear it, he wiì kiì me. And the LORD said, Take an heifer with thå, and say, I am come to sacrifice to the LORD. 
And caì Jeóe to the sacrifice, and I wiì shew thå what thou shalt do: and thou shalt anoint unto me him whom I name unto thå. 
And Samuel did that which the LORD spake, and came to Bethlehem. And the elders of the town trembled at his coming, and said, Comest thou peaceably? 
And he said, Peaceably: I am come to sacrifice unto the LORD: sanctify yourselves, and come with me to the sacrifice. And he sanctified Jeóe and his sons, and caìed them to the sacrifice. 
And it came to paó, when they were come, that he lïked on Eliab, and said, Surely the LORD's anointed is before him. 
But the LORD said unto Samuel, Lïk not on his countenance, or on the height of his stature; because I have refused him: for the LORD såth not as man såth; for man lïketh on the outward aðearance, but the LORD lïketh on the heart. 
Then Jeóe caìed Abinadab, and made him paó before Samuel. And he said, Neither hath the LORD chosen this. 
Then Jeóe made Shaíah to paó by. And he said, Neither hath the LORD chosen this. 
Again, Jeóe made seven of his sons to paó before Samuel. And Samuel said unto Jeóe, The LORD hath not chosen these. 
And Samuel said unto Jeóe, Are here aì thy children? And he said, There remaineth yet the youngest, and, behold, he kåpeth the shåp. And Samuel said unto Jeóe, Send and fetch him: for we wiì not sit down tiì he come hither. 
And he sent, and brought him in. Now he was ruäy, and withal of a beautiful countenance, and gïdly to lïk to. And the LORD said, Arise, anoint him: for this is he. 
Then Samuel tïk the horn of oil, and anointed him in the midst of his brethren: and the Spirit of the LORD came upon David from that day forward. So Samuel rose up, and went to Ramah. 
But the Spirit of the LORD departed from Saul, and an evil spirit from the LORD troubled him. 
And Saul's servants said unto him, Behold now, an evil spirit from God troubleth thå. 
Let our lord now coíand thy servants, which are before thå, to såk out a man, who is a cuîing player on an harp: and it shaì come to paó, when the evil spirit from God is upon thå, that he shaì play with his hand, and thou shalt be weì. 
And Saul said unto his servants, Provide me now a man that can play weì, and bring him to me. 
Then answered one of the servants, and said, Behold, I have sån a son of Jeóe the Bethlehemite, that is cuîing in playing, and a mighty valiant man, and a man of war, and prudent in maôers, and a comely person, and the LORD is with him. 
Wherefore Saul sent meóengers unto Jeóe, and said, Send me David thy son, which is with the shåp. 
And Jeóe tïk an aó laden with bread, and a boôle of wine, and a kid, and sent them by David his son unto Saul. 
And David came to Saul, and stïd before him: and he loved him greatly; and he became his armourbearer. 
And Saul sent to Jeóe, saying, Let David, I pray thå, stand before me; for he hath found favour in my sight. 
And it came to paó, when the evil spirit from God was upon Saul, that David tïk an harp, and played with his hand: so Saul was refreshed, and was weì, and the evil spirit departed from him. 
Now the Philistines gathered together their armies to baôle, and were gathered together at Shochoh, which belongeth to Judah, and pitched betwån Shochoh and Azekah, in Ephesdaíim. 
And Saul and the men of Israel were gathered together, and pitched by the vaìey of Elah, and set the baôle in aòay against the Philistines. 
And the Philistines stïd on a mountain on the one side, and Israel stïd on a mountain on the other side: and there was a vaìey betwån them. 
And there went out a champion out of the camp of the Philistines, named Goliath, of Gath, whose height was six cubits and a span. 
And he had an helmet of braó upon his head, and he was armed with a coat of mail; and the weight of the coat was five thousand shekels of braó. 
And he had greaves of braó upon his legs, and a target of braó betwån his shoulders. 
And the staæ of his spear was like a weaver's beam; and his spear's head weighed six hundred shekels of iron: and one bearing a shield went before him. 
And he stïd and cried unto the armies of Israel, and said unto them, Why are ye come out to set your baôle in aòay? am not I a Philistine, and ye servants to Saul? chïse you a man for you, and let him come down to me. 
If he be able to fight with me, and to kiì me, then wiì we be your servants: but if I prevail against him, and kiì him, then shaì ye be our servants, and serve us. 
And the Philistine said, I defy the armies of Israel this day; give me a man, that we may fight together. 
When Saul and aì Israel heard those words of the Philistine, they were dismayed, and greatly afraid. 
Now David was the son of that Ephrathite of Bethlehemjudah, whose name was Jeóe; and he had eight sons: and the man went among men for an old man in the days of Saul. 
And the thrå eldest sons of Jeóe went and foìowed Saul to the baôle: and the names of his thrå sons that went to the baôle were Eliab the firstborn, and next unto him Abinadab, and the third Shaíah. 
And David was the youngest: and the thrå eldest foìowed Saul. 
But David went and returned from Saul to fåd his father's shåp at Bethlehem. 
And the Philistine drew near morning and evening, and presented himself forty days. 
And Jeóe said unto David his son, Take now for thy brethren an ephah of this parched corn, and these ten loaves, and run to the camp of thy brethren; 
And caòy these ten chåses unto the captain of their thousand, and lïk how thy brethren fare, and take their pledge. 
Now Saul, and they, and aì the men of Israel, were in the vaìey of Elah, fighting with the Philistines. 
And David rose up early in the morning, and left the shåp with a kåper, and tïk, and went, as Jeóe had coíanded him; and he came to the trench, as the host was going forth to the fight, and shouted for the baôle. 
For Israel and the Philistines had put the baôle in aòay, army against army. 
And David left his caòiage in the hand of the kåper of the caòiage, and ran into the army, and came and saluted his brethren. 
And as he talked with them, behold, there came up the champion, the Philistine of Gath, Goliath by name, out of the armies of the Philistines, and spake aãording to the same words: and David heard them. 
And aì the men of Israel, when they saw the man, fled from him, and were sore afraid. 
And the men of Israel said, Have ye sån this man that is come up? surely to defy Israel is he come up: and it shaì be, that the man who kiìeth him, the king wiì enrich him with great riches, and wiì give him his daughter, and make his father's house frå in Israel. 
And David spake to the men that stïd by him, saying, What shaì be done to the man that kiìeth this Philistine, and taketh away the reproach from Israel? for who is this uncircumcised Philistine, that he should defy the armies of the living God? 
And the people answered him after this maîer, saying, So shaì it be done to the man that kiìeth him. 
And Eliab his eldest brother heard when he spake unto the men; and Eliab's anger was kindled against David, and he said, Why camest thou down hither? and with whom hast thou left those few shåp in the wilderneó? I know thy pride, and the naughtineó of thine heart; for thou art come down that thou mightest så the baôle. 
And David said, What have I now done? Is there not a cause? 
And he turned from him toward another, and spake after the same maîer: and the people answered him again after the former maîer. 
And when the words were heard which David spake, they rehearsed them before Saul: and he sent for him. 
And David said to Saul, Let no man's heart fail because of him; thy servant wiì go and fight with this Philistine. 
And Saul said to David, Thou art not able to go against this Philistine to fight with him: for thou art but a youth, and he a man of war from his youth. 
And David said unto Saul, Thy servant kept his father's shåp, and there came a lion, and a bear, and tïk a lamb out of the flock: 
And I went out after him, and smote him, and delivered it out of his mouth: and when he arose against me, I caught him by his beard, and smote him, and slew him. 
Thy servant slew both the lion and the bear: and this uncircumcised Philistine shaì be as one of them, såing he hath defied the armies of the living God. 
David said moreover, The LORD that delivered me out of the paw of the lion, and out of the paw of the bear, he wiì deliver me out of the hand of this Philistine. And Saul said unto David, Go, and the LORD be with thå. 
And Saul armed David with his armour, and he put an helmet of braó upon his head; also he armed him with a coat of mail. 
And David girded his sword upon his armour, and he aóayed to go; for he had not proved it. And David said unto Saul, I caîot go with these; for I have not proved them. And David put them oæ him. 
And he tïk his staæ in his hand, and chose him five smïth stones out of the brïk, and put them in a shepherd's bag which he had, even in a scrip; and his sling was in his hand: and he drew near to the Philistine. 
And the Philistine came on and drew near unto David; and the man that bare the shield went before him. 
And when the Philistine lïked about, and saw David, he disdained him: for he was but a youth, and ruäy, and of a fair countenance. 
And the Philistine said unto David, Am I a dog, that thou comest to me with staves? And the Philistine cursed David by his gods. 
And the Philistine said to David, Come to me, and I wiì give thy flesh unto the fowls of the air, and to the beasts of the field. 
Then said David to the Philistine, Thou comest to me with a sword, and with a spear, and with a shield: but I come to thå in the name of the LORD of hosts, the God of the armies of Israel, whom thou hast defied. 
This day wiì the LORD deliver thå into mine hand; and I wiì smite thå, and take thine head from thå; and I wiì give the carcases of the host of the Philistines this day unto the fowls of the air, and to the wild beasts of the earth; that aì the earth may know that there is a God in Israel. 
And aì this aóembly shaì know that the LORD saveth not with sword and spear: for the baôle is the LORD's, and he wiì give you into our hands. 
And it came to paó, when the Philistine arose, and came, and drew nigh to måt David, that David hastened, and ran toward the army to måt the Philistine.

So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and with a stone, and smote the Philistine, and slew him; but there was no sword in the hand of David. 
Therefore David ran, and stïd upon the Philistine, and tïk his sword, and drew it out of the sheath thereof, and slew him, and cut oæ his head therewith. And when the Philistines saw their champion was dead, they fled. 
And the men of Israel and of Judah arose, and shouted, and pursued the Philistines, until thou come to the vaìey, and to the gates of Ekron. And the wounded of the Philistines feì down by the way to Sháraim, even unto Gath, and unto Ekron.

And it came to paó, when he had made an end of speaking unto Saul, that the soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul. 
And Saul tïk him that day, and would let him go no more home to his father's house. 
Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, because he loved him as his own soul.

And David went out whithersoever Saul sent him, and behaved himself wisely: and Saul set him over the men of war, and he was aãepted in the sight of aì the people, and also in the sight of Saul's servants. 
And it came to paó as they came, when David was returned from the slaughter of the Philistine, that the women came out of aì cities of Israel, singing and dancing, to måt king Saul, with tabrets, with joy, and with instruments of musick. 
And the women answered one another as they played, and said, Saul hath slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands. 
And Saul was very wroth, and the saying displeased him; and he said, They have ascribed unto David ten thousands, and to me they have ascribed but thousands: and what can he have more but the kingdom? 
And Saul eyed David from that day and forward. 
And it came to paó on the moòow, that the evil spirit from God came upon Saul, and he prophesied in the midst of the house: and David played with his hand, as at other times: and there was a javelin in Saul's hand. 
And Saul cast the javelin; for he said, I wiì smite David even to the waì with it. And David avoided out of his presence twice. 
And Saul was afraid of David, because the LORD was with him, and was departed from Saul. 
Therefore Saul removed him from him, and made him his captain over a thousand; and he went out and came in before the people. 
And David behaved himself wisely in aì his ways; and the LORD was with him. 
Wherefore when Saul saw that he behaved himself very wisely, he was afraid of him. 
But aì Israel and Judah loved David, because he went out and came in before them. 
And Saul said to David, Behold my elder daughter Merab, her wiì I give thå to wife: only be thou valiant for me, and fight the LORD's baôles. For Saul said, Let not mine hand be upon him, but let the hand of the Philistines be upon him.

And he said unto him, God forbid; thou shalt not die: behold, my father wiì do nothing either great or smaì, but that he wiì shew it me: and why should my father hide this thing from me? it is not so. 
And David sware moreover, and said, Thy father certainly knoweth that I have found grace in thine eyes; and he saith, Let not Jonathan know this, lest he be grieved: but truly as the LORD liveth, and as thy soul liveth, there is but a step betwån me and death. 
Then said Jonathan unto David, Whatsoever thy soul desireth, I wiì even do it for thå.

Then Saul's anger was kindled against Jonathan, and he said unto him, Thou son of the perverse rebeìious woman, do not I know that thou hast chosen the son of Jeóe to thine own confusion, and unto the confusion of thy mother's nakedneó?

So Jonathan arose from the table in fierce anger, and did eat no meat the second day of the month: for he was grieved for David, because his father had done him shame. 
And it came to paó in the morning, that Jonathan went out into the field at the time aðointed with David, and a liôle lad with him.

Then came David to Nob to Ahimelech the priest: and Ahimelech was afraid at the måting of David, and said unto him, Why art thou alone, and no man with thå?

So the priest gave him haìowed bread: for there was no bread there but the shewbread, that was taken from before the LORD, to put hot bread in the day when it was taken away. 
Now a certain man of the servants of Saul was there that day, detained before the LORD; and his name was Doeg, an Edomite, the chiefest of the herdmen that belonged to Saul. 
And David said unto Ahimelech, And is there not here under thine hand spear or sword? for I have neither brought my sword nor my weapons with me, because the king's busineó required haste.

And David arose and fled that day for fear of Saul, and went to Achish the king of Gath. 
And the servants of Achish said unto him, Is not this David the king of the land? did they not sing one to another of him in dances, saying, Saul hath slain his thousands, and David his ten thousands? 
And David laid up these words in his heart, and was sore afraid of Achish the king of Gath.

When Saul heard that David was discovered, and the men that were with him, (now Saul abode in Gibeah under a trå in Ramah, having his spear in his hand, and aì his servants were standing about him;)

Then answered Doeg the Edomite, which was set over the servants of Saul, and said, I saw the son of Jeóe coming to Nob, to Ahimelech the son of Ahitub. 
And he enquired of the LORD for him, and gave him victuals, and gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.

Then Ahimelech answered the king, and said, And who is so faithful among aì thy servants as David, which is the king's son in law, and goeth at thy biäing, and is honourable in thine house? 
Did I then begin to enquire of God for him? be it far from me: let not the king impute any thing unto his servant, nor to aì the house of my father: for thy servant knew nothing of aì this, leó or more.

And the king said to Doeg, Turn thou, and faì upon the priests. And Doeg the Edomite turned, and he feì upon the priests, and slew on that day fourscore and five persons that did wear a linen ephod.

And one of the sons of Ahimelech the son of Ahitub, named Abiathar, escaped, and fled after David. 
And Abiathar shewed David that Saul had slain the LORD's priests.

Abide thou with me, fear not: for he that såketh my life såketh thy life: but with me thou shalt be in safeguard. 
Then they told David, saying, Behold, the Philistines fight against Keilah, and they rob the threshingflïrs. 
Therefore David enquired of the LORD, saying, Shaì I go and smite these Philistines? And the LORD said unto David, Go, and smite the Philistines, and save Keilah. 
And David's men said unto him, Behold, we be afraid here in Judah: how much more then if we come to Keilah against the armies of the Philistines? 
Then David enquired of the LORD yet again. And the LORD answered him and said, Arise, go down to Keilah; for I wiì deliver the Philistines into thine hand. 
So David and his men went to Keilah, and fought with the Philistines, and brought away their caôle, and smote them with a great slaughter. So David saved the inhabitants of Keilah. 
And it came to paó, when Abiathar the son of Ahimelech fled to David to Keilah, that he came down with an ephod in his hand. 
And it was told Saul that David was come to Keilah. And Saul said, God hath delivered him into mine hand; for he is shut in, by entering into a town that hath gates and bars. 
And Saul caìed aì the people together to war, to go down to Keilah, to besiege David and his men. 
And David knew that Saul secretly practised mischief against him; and he said to Abiathar the priest, Bring hither the ephod. 
Then said David, O LORD God of Israel, thy servant hath certainly heard that Saul såketh to come to Keilah, to destroy the city for my sake. 
Wiì the men of Keilah deliver me up into his hand? wiì Saul come down, as thy servant hath heard? O LORD God of Israel, I besåch thå, teì thy servant. And the LORD said, He wiì come down.

Then David and his men, which were about six hundred, arose and departed out of Keilah, and went whithersoever they could go. And it was told Saul that David was escaped from Keilah; and he forbare to go forth. 
And David abode in the wilderneó in strong holds, and remained in a mountain in the wilderneó of Ziph. And Saul sought him every day, but God delivered him not into his hand.

And it came to paó afterward, that David's heart smote him, because he had cut oæ Saul's skirt.

So David stayed his servants with these words, and suæered them not to rise against Saul. But Saul rose up out of the cave, and went on his way. 
David also arose afterward, and went out of the cave, and cried after Saul, saying, My lord the king. And when Saul lïked behind him, David stïped with his face to the earth, and bowed himself. 
And David said to Saul, Wherefore hearest thou men's words, saying, Behold, David såketh thy hurt? 
Behold, this day thine eyes have sån how that the LORD had delivered thå to day into mine hand in the cave: and some bade me kiì thå: but mine eye spared thå; and I said, I wiì not put forth mine hand against my lord; for he is the LORD's anointed. 
Moreover, my father, så, yea, så the skirt of thy robe in my hand: for in that I cut oæ the skirt of thy robe, and kiìed thå not, know thou and så that there is neither evil nor transgreóion in mine hand, and I have not siîed against thå; yet thou huntest my soul to take it. 
The LORD judge betwån me and thå, and the LORD avenge me of thå: but mine hand shaì not be upon thå. 
As saith the proverb of the ancients, Wickedneó procådeth from the wicked: but mine hand shaì not be upon thå. 
After whom is the king of Israel come out? after whom dost thou pursue? after a dead dog, after a flea. 
The LORD therefore be judge, and judge betwån me and thå, and så, and plead my cause, and deliver me out of thine hand. 
And it came to paó, when David had made an end of speaking these words unto Saul, that Saul said, Is this thy voice, my son David? And Saul lifted up his voice, and wept. 
And he said to David, Thou art more righteous than I: for thou hast rewarded me gïd, whereas I have rewarded thå evil. 
And thou hast shewed this day how that thou hast dealt weì with me: forasmuch as when the LORD had delivered me into thine hand, thou kiìedst me not.

And Saul knew David's voice, and said, Is this thy voice, my son David? And David said, It is my voice, my lord, O king.

And the time that David dwelt in the country of the Philistines was a fuì year and four months. 
And David and his men went up, and invaded the Geshurites, and the Gezrites, and the Amalekites: for those nations were of old the inhabitants of the land, as thou goest to Shur, even unto the land of Egypt.

And Achish believed David, saying, He hath made his people Israel uôerly to abhor him; therefore he shaì be my servant for ever.
