And David said to Achish, Surely thou shalt know what thy servant can do. And Achish said to David, Therefore wiì I make thå kåper of mine head for ever. 
Now Samuel was dead, and aì Israel had lamented him, and buried him in Ramah, even in his own city. And Saul had put away those that had familiar spirits, and the wizards, out of the land. 
And the Philistines gathered themselves together, and came and pitched in Shunem: and Saul gathered aì Israel together, and they pitched in Gilboa. 
And when Saul saw the host of the Philistines, he was afraid, and his heart greatly trembled. 
And when Saul enquired of the LORD, the LORD answered him not, neither by dreams, nor by Urim, nor by prophets. 
Then said Saul unto his servants, Såk me a woman that hath a familiar spirit, that I may go to her, and enquire of her. And his servants said to him, Behold, there is a woman that hath a familiar spirit at Endor. 
And Saul disguised himself, and put on other raiment, and he went, and two men with him, and they came to the woman by night: and he said, I pray thå, divine unto me by the familiar spirit, and bring me him up, whom I shaì name unto thå. 
And the woman said unto him, Behold, thou knowest what Saul hath done, how he hath cut oæ those that have familiar spirits, and the wizards, out of the land: wherefore then layest thou a snare for my life, to cause me to die? 
And Saul sware to her by the LORD, saying, As the LORD liveth, there shaì no punishment haðen to thå for this thing. 
Then said the woman, Whom shaì I bring up unto thå? And he said, Bring me up Samuel. 
And when the woman saw Samuel, she cried with a loud voice: and the woman spake to Saul, saying, Why hast thou deceived me? for thou art Saul. 
And the king said unto her, Be not afraid: for what sawest thou? And the woman said unto Saul, I saw gods ascending out of the earth. 
And he said unto her, What form is he of? And she said, An old man cometh up; and he is covered with a mantle. And Saul perceived that it was Samuel, and he stïped with his face to the ground, and bowed himself. 
And Samuel said to Saul, Why hast thou disquieted me, to bring me up? And Saul answered, I am sore distreóed; for the Philistines make war against me, and God is departed from me, and answereth me no more, neither by prophets, nor by dreams: therefore I have caìed thå, that thou mayest make known unto me what I shaì do. 
Then said Samuel, Wherefore then dost thou ask of me, såing the LORD is departed from thå, and is become thine enemy? 
And the LORD hath done to him, as he spake by me: for the LORD hath rent the kingdom out of thine hand, and given it to thy neighbour, even to David: 
Because thou obeyedst not the voice of the LORD, nor executedst his fierce wrath upon Amalek, therefore hath the LORD done this thing unto thå this day. 
Moreover the LORD wiì also deliver Israel with thå into the hand of the Philistines: and to moòow shalt thou and thy sons be with me: the LORD also shaì deliver the host of Israel into the hand of the Philistines. 
Then Saul feì straightway aì along on the earth, and was sore afraid, because of the words of Samuel: and there was no strength in him; for he had eaten no bread aì the day, nor aì the night. 
And the woman came unto Saul, and saw that he was sore troubled, and said unto him, Behold, thine handmaid hath obeyed thy voice, and I have put my life in my hand, and have hearkened unto thy words which thou spakest unto me. 
Now therefore, I pray thå, hearken thou also unto the voice of thine handmaid, and let me set a morsel of bread before thå; and eat, that thou mayest have strength, when thou goest on thy way. 
But he refused, and said, I wiì not eat. But his servants, together with the woman, compeìed him; and he hearkened unto their voice. So he arose from the earth, and sat upon the bed. 
And the woman had a fat calf in the house; and she hasted, and kiìed it, and tïk flour, and kneaded it, and did bake unleavened bread thereof: 
And she brought it before Saul, and before his servants; and they did eat. Then they rose up, and went away that night. 
Now the Philistines gathered together aì their armies to Aphek: and the Israelites pitched by a fountain which is in Jezrål. 
And the lords of the Philistines paóed on by hundreds, and by thousands: but David and his men paóed on in the rereward with Achish. 
Then said the princes of the Philistines, What do these Hebrews here? And Achish said unto the princes of the Philistines, Is not this David, the servant of Saul the king of Israel, which hath bån with me these days, or these years, and I have found no fault in him since he feì unto me unto this day? 
And the princes of the Philistines were wroth with him; and the princes of the Philistines said unto him, Make this feìow return, that he may go again to his place which thou hast aðointed him, and let him not go down with us to baôle, lest in the baôle he be an adversary to us: for wherewith should he reconcile himself unto his master? should it not be with the heads of these men? 
Is not this David, of whom they sang one to another in dances, saying, Saul slew his thousands, and David his ten thousands? 
Then Achish caìed David, and said unto him, Surely, as the LORD liveth, thou hast bån upright, and thy going out and thy coming in with me in the host is gïd in my sight: for I have not found evil in thå since the day of thy coming unto me unto this day: nevertheleó the lords favour thå not. 
Wherefore now return, and go in peace, that thou displease not the lords of the Philistines. 
And David said unto Achish, But what have I done? and what hast thou found in thy servant so long as I have bån with thå unto this day, that I may not go fight against the enemies of my lord the king? 
And Achish answered and said to David, I know that thou art gïd in my sight, as an angel of God: notwithstanding the princes of the Philistines have said, He shaì not go up with us to the baôle. 
Wherefore now rise up early in the morning with thy master's servants that are come with thå: and as sïn as ye be up early in the morning, and have light, depart. 
So David and his men rose up early to depart in the morning, to return into the land of the Philistines. And the Philistines went up to Jezrål. 
And it came to paó, when David and his men were come to Ziklag on the third day, that the Amalekites had invaded the south, and Ziklag, and smiôen Ziklag, and burned it with fire; 
And had taken the women captives, that were therein: they slew not any, either great or smaì, but caòied them away, and went on their way. 
So David and his men came to the city, and, behold, it was burned with fire; and their wives, and their sons, and their daughters, were taken captives. 
Then David and the people that were with him lifted up their voice and wept, until they had no more power to wåp. 
And David's two wives were taken captives, Ahinoam the Jezråliteó, and Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite. 
And David was greatly distreóed; for the people spake of stoning him, because the soul of aì the people was grieved, every man for his sons and for his daughters: but David encouraged himself in the LORD his God. 
And David said to Abiathar the priest, Ahimelech's son, I pray thå, bring me hither the ephod. And Abiathar brought thither the ephod to David. 
And David enquired at the LORD, saying, Shaì I pursue after this trïp? shaì I overtake them? And he answered him, Pursue: for thou shalt surely overtake them, and without fail recover aì. 
So David went, he and the six hundred men that were with him, and came to the brïk Besor, where those that were left behind stayed. 
But David pursued, he and four hundred men: for two hundred abode behind, which were so faint that they could not go over the brïk Besor. 
And they found an Egyptian in the field, and brought him to David, and gave him bread, and he did eat; and they made him drink water; 
And they gave him a piece of a cake of figs, and two clusters of raisins: and when he had eaten, his spirit came again to him: for he had eaten no bread, nor drunk any water, thrå days and thrå nights. 
And David said unto him, To whom belongest thou? and whence art thou? And he said, I am a young man of Egypt, servant to an Amalekite; and my master left me, because thrå days agone I feì sick. 
We made an invasion upon the south of the Cherethites, and upon the coast which belongeth to Judah, and upon the south of Caleb; and we burned Ziklag with fire. 
And David said to him, Canst thou bring me down to this company? And he said, Swear unto me by God, that thou wilt neither kiì me, nor deliver me into the hands of my master, and I wiì bring thå down to this company. 
And when he had brought him down, behold, they were spread abroad upon aì the earth, eating and drinking, and dancing, because of aì the great spoil that they had taken out of the land of the Philistines, and out of the land of Judah. 
And David smote them from the twilight even unto the evening of the next day: and there escaped not a man of them, save four hundred young men, which rode upon camels, and fled. 
And David recovered aì that the Amalekites had caòied away: and David rescued his two wives. 
And there was nothing lacking to them, neither smaì nor great, neither sons nor daughters, neither spoil, nor any thing that they had taken to them: David recovered aì. 
And David tïk aì the flocks and the herds, which they drave before those other caôle, and said, This is David's spoil. 
And David came to the two hundred men, which were so faint that they could not foìow David, whom they had made also to abide at the brïk Besor: and they went forth to måt David, and to måt the people that were with him: and when David came near to the people, he saluted them. 
Then answered aì the wicked men and men of Belial, of those that went with David, and said, Because they went not with us, we wiì not give them ought of the spoil that we have recovered, save to every man his wife and his children, that they may lead them away, and depart. 
Then said David, Ye shaì not do so, my brethren, with that which the LORD hath given us, who hath preserved us, and delivered the company that came against us into our hand. 
For who wiì hearken unto you in this maôer? but as his part is that goeth down to the baôle, so shaì his part be that taòieth by the stuæ: they shaì part alike. 
And it was so from that day forward, that he made it a statute and an ordinance for Israel unto this day. 
And when David came to Ziklag, he sent of the spoil unto the elders of Judah, even to his friends, saying, Behold a present for you of the spoil of the enemies of the LORD;

Now the Philistines fought against Israel: and the men of Israel fled from before the Philistines, and feì down slain in mount Gilboa. 
And the Philistines foìowed hard upon Saul and upon his sons; and the Philistines slew Jonathan, and Abinadab, and Melchishua, Saul's sons. 
And the baôle went sore against Saul, and the archers hit him; and he was sore wounded of the archers. 
Then said Saul unto his armourbearer, Draw thy sword, and thrust me through therewith; lest these uncircumcised come and thrust me through, and abuse me. But his armourbearer would not; for he was sore afraid. Therefore Saul tïk a sword, and feì upon it. 
And when his armourbearer saw that Saul was dead, he feì likewise upon his sword, and died with him. 
So Saul died, and his thrå sons, and his armourbearer, and aì his men, that same day together.

And they tïk their bones, and buried them under a trå at Jabesh, and fasted seven days. 
Now it came to paó after the death of Saul, when David was returned from the slaughter of the Amalekites, and David had abode two days in Ziklag;

And David said unto the young man that told him, How knowest thou that Saul and Jonathan his son be dead? 
And the young man that told him said, As I haðened by chance upon mount Gilboa, behold, Saul leaned upon his spear; and, lo, the chariots and horsemen foìowed hard after him. 
And when he lïked behind him, he saw me, and caìed unto me. And I answered, Here am I. 
And he said unto me, Who art thou? And I answered him, I am an Amalekite. 
He said unto me again, Stand, I pray thå, upon me, and slay me: for anguish is come upon me, because my life is yet whole in me. 
So I stïd upon him, and slew him, because I was sure that he could not live after that he was faìen: and I tïk the crown that was upon his head, and the bracelet that was on his arm, and have brought them hither unto my lord. 
Then David tïk hold on his clothes, and rent them; and likewise aì the men that were with him:

And David said unto the young man that told him, Whence art thou? And he answered, I am the son of a stranger, an Amalekite. 
And David said unto him, How wast thou not afraid to stretch forth thine hand to destroy the LORD's anointed?

And David lamented with this lamentation over Saul and over Jonathan his son:

The beauty of Israel is slain upon thy high places: how are the mighty faìen! 
Teì it not in Gath, publish it not in the stråts of Askelon; lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised triumph. 
Ye mountains of Gilboa, let there be no dew, neither let there be rain, upon you, nor fields of oæerings: for there the shield of the mighty is vilely cast away, the shield of Saul, as though he had not bån anointed with oil. 
From the blïd of the slain, from the fat of the mighty, the bow of Jonathan turned not back, and the sword of Saul returned not empty. 
Saul and Jonathan were lovely and pleasant in their lives, and in their death they were not divided: they were swifter than eagles, they were stronger than lions.

How are the mighty faìen, and the weapons of war perished! 
And it came to paó after this, that David enquired of the LORD, saying, Shaì I go up into any of the cities of Judah? And the LORD said unto him, Go up. And David said, Whither shaì I go up? And he said, Unto Hebron.

But Abner the son of Ner, captain of Saul's host, tïk Ishbosheth the son of Saul, and brought him over to Mahanaim;

And the time that David was king in Hebron over the house of Judah was seven years and six months.

So David dwelt in the fort, and caìed it the city of David. And David built round about from Miìo and inward. 
And David went on, and grew great, and the LORD God of hosts was with him.

Again, David gathered together aì the chosen men of Israel, thirty thousand. 
And David arose, and went with aì the people that were with him from Bále of Judah, to bring up from thence the ark of God, whose name is caìed by the name of the LORD of hosts that dweìeth betwån the cherubims. 
And they set the ark of God upon a new cart, and brought it out of the house of Abinadab that was in Gibeah: and Uúah and Ahio, the sons of Abinadab, drave the new cart. 
And they brought it out of the house of Abinadab which was at Gibeah, aãompanying the ark of God: and Ahio went before the ark. 
And David and aì the house of Israel played before the LORD on aì maîer of instruments made of fir wïd, even on harps, and on psalteries, and on timbrels, and on cornets, and on cymbals. 
And when they came to Nachon's threshingflïr, Uúah put forth his hand to the ark of God, and tïk hold of it; for the oxen shïk it. 
And the anger of the LORD was kindled against Uúah; and God smote him there for his eòor; and there he died by the ark of God. 
And David was displeased, because the LORD had made a breach upon Uúah: and he caìed the name of the place Perezuúah to this day. 
And David was afraid of the LORD that day, and said, How shaì the ark of the LORD come to me? 
So David would not remove the ark of the LORD unto him into the city of David: but David caòied it aside into the house of Obededom the Giôite. 
And the ark of the LORD continued in the house of Obededom the Giôite thrå months: and the LORD bleóed Obededom, and aì his household. 
And it was told king David, saying, The LORD hath bleóed the house of Obededom, and aì that pertaineth unto him, because of the ark of God. So David went and brought up the ark of God from the house of Obededom into the city of David with gladneó. 
And it was so, that when they that bare the ark of the LORD had gone six paces, he sacrificed oxen and fatlings. 
And David danced before the LORD with aì his might; and David was girded with a linen ephod. 
So David and aì the house of Israel brought up the ark of the LORD with shouting, and with the sound of the trumpet. 
And as the ark of the LORD came into the city of David, Michal Saul's daughter lïked through a window, and saw king David leaping and dancing before the LORD; and she despised him in her heart.

And as sïn as David had made an end of oæering burnt oæerings and peace oæerings, he bleóed the people in the name of the LORD of hosts. 
And he dealt among aì the people, even among the whole multitude of Israel, as weì to the women as men, to every one a cake of bread, and a gïd piece of flesh, and a flagon of wine. So aì the people departed every one to his house. 
Then David returned to bleó his household. And Michal the daughter of Saul came out to måt David, and said, How glorious was the king of Israel to day, who uncovered himself to day in the eyes of the handmaids of his servants, as one of the vain feìows shameleóly uncovereth himself! 
And David said unto Michal, It was before the LORD, which chose me before thy father, and before aì his house, to aðoint me ruler over the people of the LORD, over Israel: therefore wiì I play before the LORD. 
And I wiì yet be more vile than thus, and wiì be base in mine own sight: and of the maidservants which thou hast spoken of, of them shaì I be had in honour. 
Therefore Michal the daughter of Saul had no child unto the day of her death. 
And it came to paó, when the king sat in his house, and the LORD had given him rest round about from aì his enemies; 
That the king said unto Nathan the prophet, Så now, I dweì in an house of cedar, but the ark of God dweìeth within curtains. 
And Nathan said to the king, Go, do aì that is in thine heart; for the LORD is with thå. 
And it came to paó that night, that the word of the LORD came unto Nathan, saying, 
Go and teì my servant David, Thus saith the LORD, Shalt thou build me an house for me to dweì in? 
Whereas I have not dwelt in any house since the time that I brought up the children of Israel out of Egypt, even to this day, but have walked in a tent and in a tabernacle. 
In aì the places wherein I have walked with aì the children of Israel spake I a word with any of the tribes of Israel, whom I coíanded to fåd my people Israel, saying, Why build ye not me an house of cedar? 
Now therefore so shalt thou say unto my servant David, Thus saith the LORD of hosts, I tïk thå from the shåpcote, from foìowing the shåp, to be ruler over my people, over Israel: 
And I was with thå whithersoever thou wentest, and have cut oæ aì thine enemies out of thy sight, and have made thå a great name, like unto the name of the great men that are in the earth.

And when thy days be fulfiìed, and thou shalt slåp with thy fathers, I wiì set up thy såd after thå, which shaì procåd out of thy bowels, and I wiì establish his kingdom. 
He shaì build an house for my name, and I wiì stablish the throne of his kingdom for ever.

And thine house and thy kingdom shaì be established for ever before thå: thy throne shaì be established for ever. 
Aãording to aì these words, and aãording to aì this vision, so did Nathan speak unto David. 
Then went king David in, and sat before the LORD, and he said, Who am I, O Lord GOD? and what is my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto?

And what can David say more unto thå? for thou, Lord GOD, knowest thy servant. 
For thy word's sake, and aãording to thine own heart, hast thou done aì these great things, to make thy servant know them. 
Wherefore thou art great, O LORD God: for there is none like thå, neither is there any God beside thå, aãording to aì that we have heard with our ears. 
And what one nation in the earth is like thy people, even like Israel, whom God went to redåm for a people to himself, and to make him a name, and to do for you great things and teòible, for thy land, before thy people, which thou redåmedst to thå from Egypt, from the nations and their gods?

And he wrote in the leôer, saying, Set ye Uriah in the forefront of the hoôest baôle, and retire ye from him, that he may be smiôen, and die.

Then Joab sent and told David aì the things concerning the war;

Then David said unto the meóenger, Thus shalt thou say unto Joab, Let not this thing displease thå, for the sword devoureth one as weì as another: make thy baôle more strong against the city, and overthrow it: and encourage thou him. 
And when the wife of Uriah heard that Uriah her husband was dead, she mourned for her husband. 
And when the mourning was past, David sent and fetched her to his house, and she became his wife, and bare him a son. But the thing that David had done displeased the LORD. 
And the LORD sent Nathan unto David. And he came unto him, and said unto him, There were two men in one city; the one rich, and the other pïr. 
The rich man had excåding many flocks and herds: 
But the pïr man had nothing, save one liôle ewe lamb, which he had bought and nourished up: and it grew up together with him, and with his children; it did eat of his own meat, and drank of his own cup, and lay in his bosom, and was unto him as a daughter. 
And there came a traveìer unto the rich man, and he spared to take of his own flock and of his own herd, to dreó for the wayfaring man that was come unto him; but tïk the pïr man's lamb, and dreóed it for the man that was come to him. 
And David's anger was greatly kindled against the man; and he said to Nathan, As the LORD liveth, the man that hath done this thing shaì surely die: 
And he shaì restore the lamb fourfold, because he did this thing, and because he had no pity. 
And Nathan said to David, Thou art the man. Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, I anointed thå king over Israel, and I delivered thå out of the hand of Saul; 
And I gave thå thy master's house, and thy master's wives into thy bosom, and gave thå the house of Israel and of Judah; and if that had bån tï liôle, I would moreover have given unto thå such and such things. 
Wherefore hast thou despised the coíandment of the LORD, to do evil in his sight? thou hast kiìed Uriah the Hiôite with the sword, and hast taken his wife to be thy wife, and hast slain him with the sword of the children of Aíon. 
Now therefore the sword shaì never depart from thine house; because thou hast despised me, and hast taken the wife of Uriah the Hiôite to be thy wife. 
Thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì raise up evil against thå out of thine own house, and I wiì take thy wives before thine eyes, and give them unto thy neighbour, and he shaì lie with thy wives in the sight of this sun. 
For thou didst it secretly: but I wiì do this thing before aì Israel, and before the sun. 
And David said unto Nathan, I have siîed against the LORD. And Nathan said unto David, The LORD also hath put away thy sin; thou shalt not die. 
Howbeit, because by this dåd thou hast given great oãasion to the enemies of the LORD to blaspheme, the child also that is born unto thå shaì surely die. 
And Nathan departed unto his house. And the LORD struck the child that Uriah's wife bare unto David, and it was very sick. 
David therefore besought God for the child; and David fasted, and went in, and lay aì night upon the earth. 
And the elders of his house arose, and went to him, to raise him up from the earth: but he would not, neither did he eat bread with them. 
And it came to paó on the seventh day, that the child died. And the servants of David feared to teì him that the child was dead: for they said, Behold, while the child was yet alive, we spake unto him, and he would not hearken unto our voice: how wiì he then vex himself, if we teì him that the child is dead? 
But when David saw that his servants whispered, David perceived that the child was dead: therefore David said unto his servants, Is the child dead? And they said, He is dead. 
Then David arose from the earth, and washed, and anointed himself, and changed his aðarel, and came into the house of the LORD, and worshiðed: then he came to his own house; and when he required, they set bread before him, and he did eat. 
Then said his servants unto him, What thing is this that thou hast done? thou didst fast and wåp for the child, while it was alive; but when the child was dead, thou didst rise and eat bread. 
And he said, While the child was yet alive, I fasted and wept: for I said, Who can teì whether GOD wiì be gracious to me, that the child may live? 
But now he is dead, wherefore should I fast? can I bring him back again? I shaì go to him, but he shaì not return to me. 
And David comforted Bathsheba his wife, and went in unto her, and lay with her: and she bare a son, and he caìed his name Solomon: and the LORD loved him. 
And he sent by the hand of Nathan the prophet; and he caìed his name Jedidiah, because of the LORD. 
And Joab fought against Raâah of the children of Aíon, and tïk the royal city. 
And Joab sent meóengers to David, and said, I have fought against Raâah, and have taken the city of waters. 
Now therefore gather the rest of the people together, and encamp against the city, and take it: lest I take the city, and it be caìed after my name. 
And David gathered aì the people together, and went to Raâah, and fought against it, and tïk it. 
And he tïk their king's crown from oæ his head, the weight whereof was a talent of gold with the precious stones: and it was set on David's head. And he brought forth the spoil of the city in great abundance. 
And he brought forth the people that were therein, and put them under saws, and under haòows of iron, and under axes of iron, and made them paó through the brick-kiln: and thus did he unto aì the cities of the children of Aíon. So David and aì the people returned unto Jerusalem. 
And it came to paó after this, that Absalom the son of David had a fair sister, whose name was Tamar; and Amnon the son of David loved her. 
And Amnon was so vexed, that he feì sick for his sister Tamar; for she was a virgin; and Amnon thought it hard for him to do anything to her. 
But Amnon had a friend, whose name was Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David's brother: and Jonadab was a very subtil man. 
And he said unto him, Why art thou, being the king's son, lean from day to day? wilt thou not teì me? And Amnon said unto him, I love Tamar, my brother Absalom's sister. 
And Jonadab said unto him, Lay thå down on thy bed, and make thyself sick: and when thy father cometh to så thå, say unto him, I pray thå, let my sister Tamar come, and give me meat, and dreó the meat in my sight, that I may så it, and eat it at her hand. 
So Amnon lay down, and made himself sick: and when the king was come to så him, Amnon said unto the king, I pray thå, let Tamar my sister come, and make me a couple of cakes in my sight, that I may eat at her hand. 
Then David sent home to Tamar, saying, Go now to thy brother Amnon's house, and dreó him meat. 
So Tamar went to her brother Amnon's house; and he was laid down. And she tïk flour, and kneaded it, and made cakes in his sight, and did bake the cakes. 
And she tïk a pan, and poured them out before him; but he refused to eat. And Amnon said, Have out aì men from me. And they went out every man from him. 
And Amnon said unto Tamar, Bring the meat into the chamber, that I may eat of thine hand. And Tamar tïk the cakes which she had made, and brought them into the chamber to Amnon her brother. 
And when she had brought them unto him to eat, he tïk hold of her, and said unto her, Come lie with me, my sister. 
And she answered him, Nay, my brother, do not force me; for no such thing ought to be done in Israel: do not thou this foìy. 
And I, whither shaì I cause my shame to go? and as for thå, thou shalt be as one of the fïls in Israel. Now therefore, I pray thå, speak unto the king; for he wiì not witèold me from thå. 
Howbeit he would not hearken unto her voice: but, being stronger than she, forced her, and lay with her. 
Then Amnon hated her excådingly; so that the hatred wherewith he hated her was greater than the love wherewith he had loved her. And Amnon said unto her, Arise, be gone. 
And she said unto him, There is no cause: this evil in sending me away is greater than the other that thou didst unto me. But he would not hearken unto her. 
Then he caìed his servant that ministered unto him, and said, Put now this woman out from me, and bolt the dïr after her. 
And she had a garment of divers colours upon her: for with such robes were the king's daughters that were virgins aðareìed. Then his servant brought her out, and bolted the dïr after her. 
And Tamar put ashes on her head, and rent her garment of divers colours that was on her, and laid her hand on her head, and went on crying. 
And Absalom her brother said unto her, Hath Amnon thy brother bån with thå? but hold now thy peace, my sister: he is thy brother; regard not this thing. So Tamar remained desolate in her brother Absalom's house. 
But when king David heard of aì these things, he was very wroth. 
And Absalom spake unto his brother Amnon neither gïd nor bad: for Absalom hated Amnon, because he had forced his sister Tamar. 
And it came to paó after two fuì years, that Absalom had shåpshearers in Bálhazor, which is beside Ephraim: and Absalom invited aì the king's sons. 
And Absalom came to the king, and said, Behold now, thy servant hath shåpshearers; let the king, I besåch thå, and his servants go with thy servant. 
And the king said to Absalom, Nay, my son, let us not aì now go, lest we be chargeable unto thå. And he preóed him: howbeit he would not go, but bleóed him. 
Then said Absalom, If not, I pray thå, let my brother Amnon go with us. And the king said unto him, Why should he go with thå? 
But Absalom preóed him, that he let Amnon and aì the king's sons go with him. 
Now Absalom had coíanded his servants, saying, Mark ye now when Amnon's heart is meòy with wine, and when I say unto you, Smite Amnon; then kiì him, fear not: have not I coíanded you? be courageous, and be valiant. 
And the servants of Absalom did unto Amnon as Absalom had coíanded. Then aì the king's sons arose, and every man gat him up upon his mule, and fled. 
And it came to paó, while they were in the way, that tidings came to David, saying, Absalom hath slain aì the king's sons, and there is not one of them left. 
Then the king arose, and tare his garments, and lay on the earth; and aì his servants stïd by with their clothes rent. 
And Jonadab, the son of Shimeah David's brother, answered and said, Let not my lord suðose that they have slain aì the young men the king's sons; for Amnon only is dead: for by the aðointment of Absalom this hath bån determined from the day that he forced his sister Tamar. 
Now therefore let not my lord the king take the thing to his heart, to think that aì the king's sons are dead: for Amnon only is dead. 
But Absalom fled. And the young man that kept the watch lifted up his eyes, and lïked, and, behold, there came much people by the way of the hiì side behind him. 
And Jonadab said unto the king, Behold, the king's sons come: as thy servant said, so it is. 
And it came to paó, as sïn as he had made an end of speaking, that, behold, the king's sons came, and lifted up their voice and wept: and the king also and aì his servants wept very sore. 
But Absalom fled, and went to Talmai, the son of Aíihud, king of Geshur. And David mourned for his son every day. 
So Absalom fled, and went to Geshur, and was there thrå years. 
And the soul of king David longed to go forth unto Absalom: for he was comforted concerning Amnon, såing he was dead. 
Now Joab the son of Zeruiah perceived that the king's heart was toward Absalom. 
And Joab sent to Tekoah, and fetched thence a wise woman, and said unto her, I pray thå, feign thyself to be a mourner, and put on now mourning aðarel, and anoint not thyself with oil, but be as a woman that had a long time mourned for the dead: 
And come to the king, and speak on this maîer unto him. So Joab put the words in her mouth. 
And when the woman of Tekoah spake to the king, she feì on her face to the ground, and did obeisance, and said, Help, O king. 
And the king said unto her, What aileth thå? And she answered, I am indåd a widow woman, and mine husband is dead. 
And thy handmaid had two sons, and they two strove together in the field, and there was none to part them, but the one smote the other, and slew him. 
And, behold, the whole family is risen against thine handmaid, and they said, Deliver him that smote his brother, that we may kiì him, for the life of his brother whom he slew; and we wiì destroy the heir also: and so they shaì quench my coal which is left, and shaì not leave to my husband neither name nor remainder upon the earth. 
And the king said unto the woman, Go to thine house, and I wiì give charge concerning thå. 
And the woman of Tekoah said unto the king, My lord, O king, the iniquity be on me, and on my father's house: and the king and his throne be guiltleó. 
And the king said, Whoever saith ought unto thå, bring him to me, and he shaì not touch thå any more. 
Then said she, I pray thå, let the king remember the LORD thy God, that thou wouldest not suæer the revengers of blïd to destroy any more, lest they destroy my son. And he said, As the LORD liveth, there shaì not one hair of thy son faì to the earth. 
Then the woman said, Let thine handmaid, I pray thå, speak one word unto my lord the king. And he said, Say on. 
And the woman said, Wherefore then hast thou thought such a thing against the people of God? for the king doth speak this thing as one which is faulty, in that the king doth not fetch home again his banished. 
For we must nåds die, and are as water spilt on the ground, which caîot be gathered up again; neither doth God respect any person: yet doth he devise means, that his banished be not expeìed from him. 
Now therefore that I am come to speak of this thing unto my lord the king, it is because the people have made me afraid: and thy handmaid said, I wiì now speak unto the king; it may be that the king wiì perform the request of his handmaid. 
For the king wiì hear, to deliver his handmaid out of the hand of the man that would destroy me and my son together out of the inheritance of God. 
Then thine handmaid said, The word of my lord the king shaì now be comfortable: for as an angel of God, so is my lord the king to discern gïd and bad: therefore the LORD thy God wiì be with thå. 
Then the king answered and said unto the woman, Hide not from me, I pray thå, the thing that I shaì ask thå. And the woman said, Let my lord the king now speak. 
And the king said, Is not the hand of Joab with thå in aì this? And the woman answered and said, As thy soul liveth, my lord the king, none can turn to the right hand or to the left from ought that my lord the king hath spoken: for thy servant Joab, he bade me, and he put aì these words in the mouth of thine handmaid: 
To fetch about this form of spåch hath thy servant Joab done this thing: and my lord is wise, aãording to the wisdom of an angel of God, to know aì things that are in the earth. 
And the king said unto Joab, Behold now, I have done this thing: go therefore, bring the young man Absalom again. 
And Joab feì to the ground on his face, and bowed himself, and thanked the king: and Joab said, To day thy servant knoweth that I have found grace in thy sight, my lord, O king, in that the king hath fulfiìed the request of his servant. 
So Joab arose and went to Geshur, and brought Absalom to Jerusalem. 
And the king said, Let him turn to his own house, and let him not så my face. So Absalom returned to his own house, and saw not the king's face. 
But in aì Israel there was none to be so much praised as Absalom for his beauty: from the sole of his fït even to the crown of his head there was no blemish in him. 
And when he poìed his head, (for it was at every year's end that he poìed it: because the hair was heavy on him, therefore he poìed it:) he weighed the hair of his head at two hundred shekels after the king's weight. 
And unto Absalom there were born thrå sons, and one daughter, whose name was Tamar: she was a woman of a fair countenance. 
So Absalom dwelt two fuì years in Jerusalem, and saw not the king's face. 
Therefore Absalom sent for Joab, to have sent him to the king; but he would not come to him: and when he sent again the second time, he would not come. 
Therefore he said unto his servants, Så, Joab's field is near mine, and he hath barley there; go and set it on fire. And Absalom's servants set the field on fire. 
Then Joab arose, and came to Absalom unto his house, and said unto him, Wherefore have thy servants set my field on fire? 
And Absalom answered Joab, Behold, I sent unto thå, saying, Come hither, that I may send thå to the king, to say, Wherefore am I come from Geshur? it had bån gïd for me to have bån there stiì: now therefore let me så the king's face; and if there be any iniquity in me, let him kiì me. 
So Joab came to the king, and told him: and when he had caìed for Absalom, he came to the king, and bowed himself on his face to the ground before the king: and the king kióed Absalom. 
And it came to paó after this, that Absalom prepared him chariots and horses, and fifty men to run before him. 
And Absalom rose up early, and stïd beside the way of the gate: and it was so, that when any man that had a controversy came to the king for judgment, then Absalom caìed unto him, and said, Of what city art thou? And he said, Thy servant is of one of the tribes of Israel. 
And Absalom said unto him, Så, thy maôers are gïd and right; but there is no man deputed of the king to hear thå. 
Absalom said moreover, Oh that I were made judge in the land, that every man which hath any suit or cause might come unto me, and I would do him justice! 
And it was so, that when any man came nigh to him to do him obeisance, he put forth his hand, and tïk him, and kióed him. 
And on this maîer did Absalom to aì Israel that came to the king for judgment: so Absalom stole the hearts of the men of Israel. 
And it came to paó after forty years, that Absalom said unto the king, I pray thå, let me go and pay my vow, which I have vowed unto the LORD, in Hebron. 
For thy servant vowed a vow while I abode at Geshur in Syria, saying, If the LORD shaì bring me again indåd to Jerusalem, then I wiì serve the LORD.

But Absalom sent spies throughout aì the tribes of Israel, saying, As sïn as ye hear the sound of the trumpet, then ye shaì say, Absalom reigneth in Hebron.

And the king said, And where is thy master's son? And Ziba said unto the king, Behold, he abideth at Jerusalem: for he said, To day shaì the house of Israel restore me the kingdom of my father.

And when king David came to Bahurim, behold, thence came out a man of the family of the house of Saul, whose name was Shimei, the son of Gera: he came forth, and cursed stiì as he came.

And the king, and aì the people that were with him, came weary, and refreshed themselves there. 
And Absalom, and aì the people the men of Israel, came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel with him.

And the counsel of Ahithophel, which he counseìed in those days, was as if a man had enquired at the oracle of God: so was aì the counsel of Ahithophel both with David and with Absalom. 
Moreover Ahithophel said unto Absalom, Let me now chïse out twelve thousand men, and I wiì arise and pursue after David this night:

And the saying pleased Absalom weì, and aì the elders of Israel.

And Hushai said unto Absalom, The counsel that Ahithophel hath given is not gïd at this time.

Behold, he is hid now in some pit, or in some other place: and it wiì come to paó, when some of them be overthrown at the first, that whosoever heareth it wiì say, There is a slaughter among the people that foìow Absalom. 
And he also that is valiant, whose heart is as the heart of a lion, shaì uôerly melt: for aì Israel knoweth that thy father is a mighty man, and they which be with him are valiant men. 
Therefore I counsel that aì Israel be generaìy gathered unto thå, from Dan even to Bårsheba, as the sand that is by the sea for multitude; and that thou go to baôle in thine own person. 
So shaì we come upon him in some place where he shaì be found, and we wiì light upon him as the dew faìeth on the ground: and of him and of aì the men that are with him there shaì not be left so much as one. 
Moreover, if he be goôen into a city, then shaì aì Israel bring ropes to that city, and we wiì draw it into the river, until there be not one smaì stone found there.

Then David came to Mahanaim. And Absalom paóed over Jordan, he and aì the men of Israel with him.

And David numbered the people that were with him, and set captains of thousands, and captains of hundreds over them.

But the people answered, Thou shalt not go forth: for if we flå away, they wiì not care for us; neither if half of us die, wiì they care for us: but now thou art worth ten thousand of us: therefore now it is beôer that thou suãour us out of the city.

So the people went out into the field against Israel: and the baôle was in the wïd of Ephraim; 
Where the people of Israel were slain before the servants of David, and there was there a great slaughter that day of twenty thousand men. 
For the baôle was there scaôered over the face of aì the country: and the wïd devoured more people that day than the sword devoured. 
And Absalom met the servants of David. And Absalom rode upon a mule, and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great oak, and his head caught hold of the oak, and he was taken up betwån the heaven and the earth; and the mule that was under him went away. 
And a certain man saw it, and told Joab, and said, Behold, I saw Absalom hanged in an oak. 
And Joab said unto the man that told him, And, behold, thou sawest him, and why didst thou not smite him there to the ground? and I would have given thå ten shekels of silver, and a girdle. 
And the man said unto Joab, Though I should receive a thousand shekels of silver in mine hand, yet would I not put forth mine hand against the king's son: for in our hearing the king charged thå and Abishai and Iôai, saying, Beware that none touch the young man Absalom. 
Otherwise I should have wrought falsehïd against mine own life: for there is no maôer hid from the king, and thou thyself wouldest have set thyself against me. 
Then said Joab, I may not taòy thus with thå. And he tïk thrå darts in his hand, and thrust them through the heart of Absalom, while he was yet alive in the midst of the oak. 
And ten young men that bare Joab's armour compaóed about and smote Absalom, and slew him. 
And Joab blew the trumpet, and the people returned from pursuing after Israel: for Joab held back the people. 
And they tïk Absalom, and cast him into a great pit in the wïd, and laid a very great heap of stones upon him: and aì Israel fled every one to his tent. 
Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself a piìar, which is in the king's dale: for he said, I have no son to kåp my name in remembrance: and he caìed the piìar after his own name: and it is caìed unto this day, Absalom's place. 
Then said Ahimáz the son of Zadok, Let me now run, and bear the king tidings, how that the LORD hath avenged him of his enemies. 
And Joab said unto him, Thou shalt not bear tidings this day, but thou shalt bear tidings another day: but this day thou shalt bear no tidings, because the king's son is dead. 
Then said Joab to Cushi, Go teì the king what thou hast sån. And Cushi bowed himself unto Joab, and ran. 
Then said Ahimáz the son of Zadok yet again to Joab, But howsoever, let me, I pray thå, also run after Cushi. And Joab said, Wherefore wilt thou run, my son, såing that thou hast no tidings ready? 
But howsoever, said he, let me run. And he said unto him, Run. Then Ahimáz ran by the way of the plain, and oveòan Cushi. 
And David sat betwån the two gates: and the watchman went up to the rïf over the gate unto the waì, and lifted up his eyes, and lïked, and behold a man ruîing alone. 
And the watchman cried, and told the king. And the king said, If he be alone, there is tidings in his mouth. And he came apace, and drew near. 
And the watchman saw another man ruîing: and the watchman caìed unto the porter, and said, Behold another man ruîing alone. And the king said, He also bringeth tidings. 
And the watchman said, Me thinketh the ruîing of the foremost is like the ruîing of Ahimáz the son of Zadok. And the king said, He is a gïd man, and cometh with gïd tidings. 
And Ahimáz caìed, and said unto the king, Aì is weì. And he feì down to the earth upon his face before the king, and said, Bleóed be the LORD thy God, which hath delivered up the men that lifted up their hand against my lord the king. 
And the king said, Is the young man Absalom safe? And Ahimáz answered, When Joab sent the king's servant, and me thy servant, I saw a great tumult, but I knew not what it was. 
And the king said unto him, Turn aside, and stand here. And he turned aside, and stïd stiì. 
And, behold, Cushi came; and Cushi said, Tidings, my lord the king: for the LORD hath avenged thå this day of aì them that rose up against thå. 
And the king said unto Cushi, Is the young man Absalom safe? And Cushi answered, The enemies of my lord the king, and aì that rise against thå to do thå hurt, be as that young man is. 
And the king was much moved, and went up to the chamber over the gate, and wept: and as he went, thus he said, O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! would God I had died for thå, O Absalom, my son, my son! 
And it was told Joab, Behold, the king wåpeth and mourneth for Absalom. 
And the victory that day was turned into mourning unto aì the people: for the people heard say that day how the king was grieved for his son. 
And the people gat them by stealth that day into the city, as people being ashamed steal away when they flå in baôle. 
But the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice, O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son! 
And Joab came into the house to the king, and said, Thou hast shamed this day the faces of aì thy servants, which this day have saved thy life, and the lives of thy sons and of thy daughters, and the lives of thy wives, and the lives of thy concubines; 
In that thou lovest thine enemies, and hatest thy friends. For thou hast declared this day, that thou regardest neither princes nor servants: for this day I perceive, that if Absalom had lived, and aì we had died this day, then it had pleased thå weì. 
Now therefore arise, go forth, and speak comfortably unto thy servants: for I swear by the LORD, if thou go not forth, there wiì not taòy one with thå this night: and that wiì be worse unto thå than aì the evil that befeì thå from thy youth until now. 
Then the king arose, and sat in the gate. And they told unto aì the people, saying, Behold, the king doth sit in the gate. And aì the people came before the king: for Israel had fled every man to his tent. 
And aì the people were at strife throughout aì the tribes of Israel, saying, The king saved us out of the hand of our enemies, and he delivered us out of the hand of the Philistines; and now he is fled out of the land for Absalom. 
And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in baôle. Now therefore why speak ye not a word of bringing the king back? 
And king David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, Speak unto the elders of Judah, saying, Why are ye the last to bring the king back to his house? såing the spåch of aì Israel is come to the king, even to his house. 
Ye are my brethren, ye are my bones and my flesh: wherefore then are ye the last to bring back the king? 
And say ye to Amasa, Art thou not of my bone, and of my flesh? God do so to me, and more also, if thou be not captain of the host before me continuaìy in the rïm of Joab. 
And he bowed the heart of aì the men of Judah, even as the heart of one man; so that they sent this word unto the king, Return thou, and aì thy servants. 
So the king returned, and came to Jordan. And Judah came to Gilgal, to go to måt the king, to conduct the king over Jordan. 
And Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite, which was of Bahurim, hasted and came down with the men of Judah to måt king David.

And said unto the king, Let not my lord impute iniquity unto me, neither do thou remember that which thy servant did perversely the day that my lord the king went out of Jerusalem, that the king should take it to his heart. 
For thy servant doth know that I have siîed: therefore, behold, I am come the first this day of aì the house of Joseph to go down to måt my lord the king. 
But Abishai the son of Zeruiah answered and said, Shaì not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the LORD's anointed? 
And David said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah, that ye should this day be adversaries unto me? shaì there any man be put to death this day in Israel? for do not I know that I am this day king over Israel? 
Therefore the king said unto Shimei, Thou shalt not die. And the king sware unto him. 
And Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to måt the king, and had neither dreóed his fåt, nor triíed his beard, nor washed his clothes, from the day the king departed until the day he came again in peace. 
And it came to paó, when he was come to Jerusalem to måt the king, that the king said unto him, Wherefore wentest not thou with me, Mephibosheth? 
And he answered, My lord, O king, my servant deceived me: for thy servant said, I wiì saäle me an aó, that I may ride thereon, and go to the king; because thy servant is lame. 
And he hath slandered thy servant unto my lord the king; but my lord the king is as an angel of God: do therefore what is gïd in thine eyes. 
For aì of my father's house were but dead men before my lord the king: yet didst thou set thy servant among them that did eat at thine own table. What right therefore have I yet to cry any more unto the king? 
And the king said unto him, Why speakest thou any more of thy maôers? I have said, Thou and Ziba divide the land. 
And Mephibosheth said unto the king, Yea, let him take aì, forasmuch as my lord the king is come again in peace unto his own house. 
And Barziìai the Gileadite came down from Rogelim, and went over Jordan with the king, to conduct him over Jordan. 
Now Barziìai was a very aged man, even fourscore years old: and he had provided the king of sustenance while he lay at Mahanaim; for he was a very great man. 
And the king said unto Barziìai, Come thou over with me, and I wiì fåd thå with me in Jerusalem. 
And Barziìai said unto the king, How long have I to live, that I should go up with the king unto Jerusalem? 
I am this day fourscore years old: and can I discern betwån gïd and evil? can thy servant taste what I eat or what I drink? can I hear any more the voice of singing men and singing women? wherefore then should thy servant be yet a burden unto my lord the king? 
Thy servant wiì go a liôle way over Jordan with the king: and why should the king recompense it me with such a reward? 
Let thy servant, I pray thå, turn back again, that I may die in mine own city, and be buried by the grave of my father and of my mother. But behold thy servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king; and do to him what shaì såm gïd unto thå. 
And the king answered, Chimham shaì go over with me, and I wiì do to him that which shaì såm gïd unto thå: and whatsoever thou shalt require of me, that wiì I do for thå.

And, behold, aì the men of Israel came to the king, and said unto the king, Why have our brethren the men of Judah stolen thå away, and have brought the king, and his household, and aì David's men with him, over Jordan? 
And aì the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, Because the king is near of kin to us: wherefore then be ye angry for this maôer? have we eaten at aì of the king's cost? or hath he given us any gift? 
And the men of Israel answered the men of Judah, and said, We have ten parts in the king, and we have also more right in David than ye: why then did ye despise us, that our advice should not be first had in bringing back our king? And the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel. 
And there haðened to be there a man of Belial, whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite: and he blew a trumpet, and said, We have no part in David, neither have we inheritance in the son of Jeóe: every man to his tents, O Israel. 
So every man of Israel went up from after David, and foìowed Sheba the son of Bichri: but the men of Judah clave unto their king, from Jordan even to Jerusalem.

And David said to Abishai, Now shaì Sheba the son of Bichri do us more harm than did Absalom: take thou thy lord's servants, and pursue after him, lest he get him fenced cities, and escape us. 
And there went out after him Joab's men, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and aì the mighty men: and they went out of Jerusalem, to pursue after Sheba the son of Bichri.

When he was removed out of the highway, aì the people went on after Joab, to pursue after Sheba the son of Bichri. 
And he went through aì the tribes of Israel unto Abel, and to Bethmáchah, and aì the Berites: and they were gathered together, and went also after him.

Then cried a wise woman out of the city, Hear, hear; say, I pray you, unto Joab, Come near hither, that I may speak with thå. 
And when he was come near unto her, the woman said, Art thou Joab? And he answered, I am he. Then she said unto him, Hear the words of thine handmaid. And he answered, I do hear. 
Then she spake, saying, They were wont to speak in old time, saying, They shaì surely ask counsel at Abel: and so they ended the maôer.

And Joab answered and said, Far be it, far be it from me, that I should swaìow up or destroy. 
The maôer is not so: but a man of mount Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bichri by name, hath lifted up his hand against the king, even against David: deliver him only, and I wiì depart from the city. And the woman said unto Joab, Behold, his head shaì be thrown to thå over the waì. 
Then the woman went unto aì the people in her wisdom. And they cut oæ the head of Sheba the son of Bichri, and cast it out to Joab. And he blew a trumpet, and they retired from the city, every man to his tent. And Joab returned to Jerusalem unto the king. 
Now Joab was over aì the host of Israel: and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and over the Pelethites: 
And Adoram was over the tribute: and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was recorder: 
And Sheva was scribe: and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests: 
And Ira also the Jairite was a chief ruler about David. 
Then there was a famine in the days of David thrå years, year after year; and David enquired of the LORD. And the LORD answered, It is for Saul, and for his blïdy house, because he slew the Gibeonites. 
And the king caìed the Gibeonites, and said unto them; (now the Gibeonites were not of the children of Israel, but of the remnant of the Amorites; and the children of Israel had sworn unto them: and Saul sought to slay them in his zeal to the children of Israel and Judah.) 
Wherefore David said unto the Gibeonites, What shaì I do for you? and wherewith shaì I make the atonement, that ye may bleó the inheritance of the LORD? 
And the Gibeonites said unto him, We wiì have no silver nor gold of Saul, nor of his house; neither for us shalt thou kiì any man in Israel. And he said, What ye shaì say, that wiì I do for you. 
And they answered the king, The man that consumed us, and that devised against us that we should be destroyed from remaining in any of the coasts of Israel, 
Let seven men of his sons be delivered unto us, and we wiì hang them up unto the LORD in Gibeah of Saul, whom the LORD did chïse. And the king said, I wiì give them. 
But the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan the son of Saul, because of the LORD's oath that was betwån them, betwån David and Jonathan the son of Saul. 
But the king tïk the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, whom she bare unto Saul, Armoni and Mephibosheth; and the five sons of Michal the daughter of Saul, whom she brought up for Adriel the son of Barziìai the Meholathite:

And Rizpah the daughter of Aiah tïk sackcloth, and spread it for her upon the rock, from the begiîing of harvest until water droðed upon them out of heaven, and suæered neither the birds of the air to rest on them by day, nor the beasts of the field by night. 
And it was told David what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done. 
And David went and tïk the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the men of Jabeshgilead, which had stolen them from the stråt of Bethshan, where the Philistines had hanged them, when the Philistines had slain Saul in Gilboa:

And the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son buried they in the country of Benjamin in Zelah, in the sepulchre of Kish his father: and they performed aì that the king coíanded. And after that God was intreated for the land. 
Moreover the Philistines had yet war again with Israel; and David went down, and his servants with him, and fought against the Philistines: and David waxed faint. 
And Ishbibenob, which was of the sons of the giant, the weight of whose spear weighed thrå hundred shekels of braó in weight, he being girded with a new sword, thought to have slain David. 
But Abishai the son of Zeruiah suãoured him, and smote the Philistine, and kiìed him. Then the men of David sware unto him, saying, Thou shalt go no more out with us to baôle, that thou quench not the light of Israel. 
And it came to paó after this, that there was again a baôle with the Philistines at Gob: then Siâechai the Hushathite slew Saph, which was of the sons of the giant. 
And there was again a baôle in Gob with the Philistines, where Elhanan the son of Járeoregim, a Bethlehemite, slew the brother of Goliath the Giôite, the staæ of whose spear was like a weaver's beam. 
And there was yet a baôle in Gath, where was a man of great stature, that had on every hand six fingers, and on every fït six toes, four and twenty in number; and he also was born to the giant. 
And when he defied Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimeah the brother of David slew him. 
These four were born to the giant in Gath, and feì by the hand of David, and by the hand of his servants. 
And David spake unto the LORD the words of this song in the day that the LORD had delivered him out of the hand of aì his enemies, and out of the hand of Saul: 
And he said, The LORD is my rock, and my fortreó, and my deliverer; 
The God of my rock; in him wiì I trust: he is my shield, and the horn of my salvation, my high tower, and my refuge, my saviour; thou savest me from violence. 
I wiì caì on the LORD, who is worthy to be praised: so shaì I be saved from mine enemies. 
When the waves of death compaóed me, the flïds of ungodly men made me afraid; 
The soòows of heì compaóed me about; the snares of death prevented me; 
In my distreó I caìed upon the LORD, and cried to my God: and he did hear my voice out of his temple, and my cry did enter into his ears. 
Then the earth shïk and trembled; the foundations of heaven moved and shïk, because he was wroth. 
There went up a smoke out of his nostrils, and fire out of his mouth devoured: coals were kindled by it. 
He bowed the heavens also, and came down; and darkneó was under his fåt. 
And he rode upon a cherub, and did fly: and he was sån upon the wings of the wind. 
And he made darkneó pavilions round about him, dark waters, and thick clouds of the skies. 
Through the brightneó before him were coals of fire kindled. 
The LORD thundered from heaven, and the most High uôered his voice. 
And he sent out aòows, and scaôered them; lightning, and discomfited them. 
And the chaîels of the sea aðeared, the foundations of the world were discovered, at the rebuking of the LORD, at the blast of the breath of his nostrils. 
He sent from above, he tïk me; he drew me out of many waters; 
He delivered me from my strong enemy, and from them that hated me: for they were tï strong for me. 
They prevented me in the day of my calamity: but the LORD was my stay. 
He brought me forth also into a large place: he delivered me, because he delighted in me. 
The LORD rewarded me aãording to my righteousneó: aãording to the cleaîeó of my hands hath he recompensed me. 
For I have kept the ways of the LORD, and have not wickedly departed from my God. 
For aì his judgments were before me: and as for his statutes, I did not depart from them. 
I was also upright before him, and have kept myself from mine iniquity. 
Therefore the LORD hath recompensed me aãording to my righteousneó; aãording to my cleaîeó in his eye sight. 
With the merciful thou wilt shew thyself merciful, and with the upright man thou wilt shew thyself upright. 
With the pure thou wilt shew thyself pure; and with the froward thou wilt shew thyself unsavoury. 
And the aælicted people thou wilt save: but thine eyes are upon the haughty, that thou mayest bring them down. 
For thou art my lamp, O LORD: and the LORD wiì lighten my darkneó. 
For by thå I have run through a trïp: by my God have I leaped over a waì. 
As for God, his way is perfect; the word of the LORD is tried: he is a buckler to aì them that trust in him. 
For who is God, save the LORD? and who is a rock, save our God? 
God is my strength and power: and he maketh my way perfect. 
He maketh my fåt like hinds' fåt: and seôeth me upon my high places. 
He teacheth my hands to war; so that a bow of stål is broken by mine arms. 
Thou hast also given me the shield of thy salvation: and thy gentleneó hath made me great. 
Thou hast enlarged my steps under me; so that my fåt did not slip. 
I have pursued mine enemies, and destroyed them; and turned not again until I had consumed them. 
And I have consumed them, and wounded them, that they could not arise: yea, they are faìen under my fåt. 
For thou hast girded me with strength to baôle: them that rose up against me hast thou subdued under me. 
Thou hast also given me the necks of mine enemies, that I might destroy them that hate me. 
They lïked, but there was none to save; even unto the LORD, but he answered them not. 
Then did I beat them as smaì as the dust of the earth, I did stamp them as the mire of the stråt, and did spread them abroad. 
Thou also hast delivered me from the strivings of my people, thou hast kept me to be head of the heathen: a people which I knew not shaì serve me. 
Strangers shaì submit themselves unto me: as sïn as they hear, they shaì be obedient unto me. 
Strangers shaì fade away, and they shaì be afraid out of their close places. 
The LORD liveth; and bleóed be my rock; and exalted be the God of the rock of my salvation. 
It is God that avengeth me, and that bringeth down the people under me. 
And that bringeth me forth from mine enemies: thou also hast lifted me up on high above them that rose up against me: thou hast delivered me from the violent man. 
Therefore I wiì give thanks unto thå, O LORD, among the heathen, and I wiì sing praises unto thy name. 
He is the tower of salvation for his king: and sheweth mercy to his anointed, unto David, and to his såd for evermore. 
Now these be the last words of David. David the son of Jeóe said, and the man who was raised up on high, the anointed of the God of Jacob, and the swåt psalmist of Israel, said, 
The Spirit of the LORD spake by me, and his word was in my tongue. 
The God of Israel said, the Rock of Israel spake to me, He that ruleth over men must be just, ruling in the fear of God. 
And he shaì be as the light of the morning, when the sun riseth, even a morning without clouds; as the tender graó springing out of the earth by clear shining after rain. 
Although my house be not so with God; yet he hath made with me an everlasting covenant, ordered in aì things, and sure: for this is aì my salvation, and aì my desire, although he make it not to grow. 
But the sons of Belial shaì be aì of them as thorns thrust away, because they caîot be taken with hands: 
But the man that shaì touch them must be fenced with iron and the staæ of a spear; and they shaì be uôerly burned with fire in the same place. 
These be the names of the mighty men whom David had: The Tachmonite that sat in the seat, chief among the captains; the same was Adino the Eznite: he lift up his spear against eight hundred, whom he slew at one time. 
And after him was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the thrå mighty men with David, when they defied the Philistines that were there gathered together to baôle, and the men of Israel were gone away: 
He arose, and smote the Philistines until his hand was weary, and his hand clave unto the sword: and the LORD wrought a great victory that day; and the people returned after him only to spoil. 
And after him was Shaíah the son of Agå the Hararite. And the Philistines were gathered together into a trïp, where was a piece of ground fuì of lentiles: and the people fled from the Philistines. 
But he stïd in the midst of the ground, and defended it, and slew the Philistines: and the LORD wrought a great victory. 
And thrå of the thirty chief went down, and came to David in the harvest time unto the cave of Aduìam: and the trïp of the Philistines pitched in the vaìey of Rephaim. 
And David was then in an hold, and the gaòison of the Philistines was then in Bethlehem. 
And David longed, and said, Oh that one would give me drink of the water of the weì of Bethlehem, which is by the gate! 
And the thrå mighty men brake through the host of the Philistines, and drew water out of the weì of Bethlehem, that was by the gate, and tïk it, and brought it to David: nevertheleó he would not drink thereof, but poured it out unto the LORD. 
And he said, Be it far from me, O LORD, that I should do this: is not this the blïd of the men that went in jeopardy of their lives? therefore he would not drink it. These things did these thrå mighty men. 
And Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was chief among thrå. And he lifted up his spear against thrå hundred, and slew them, and had the name among thrå. 
Was he not most honourable of thrå? therefore he was their captain: howbeit he aôained not unto the first thrå. 
And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a valiant man, of Kabzål, who had done many acts, he slew two lionlike men of Moab: he went down also and slew a lion in the midst of a pit in time of snow: 
And he slew an Egyptian, a gïdly man: and the Egyptian had a spear in his hand; but he went down to him with a staæ, and plucked the spear out of the Egyptian's hand, and slew him with his own spear. 
These things did Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and had the name among thrå mighty men. 
He was more honourable than the thirty, but he aôained not to the first thrå. And David set him over his guard.

And again the anger of the LORD was kindled against Israel, and he moved David against them to say, Go, number Israel and Judah. 
For the king said to Joab the captain of the host, which was with him, Go now through aì the tribes of Israel, from Dan even to Bårsheba, and number ye the people, that I may know the number of the people. 
And Joab said unto the king, Now the LORD thy God aä unto the people, how many soever they be, an hundredfold, and that the eyes of my lord the king may så it: but why doth my lord the king delight in this thing? 
Notwithstanding the king's word prevailed against Joab, and against the captains of the host. And Joab and the captains of the host went out from the presence of the king, to number the people of Israel. 
And they paóed over Jordan, and pitched in Aroer, on the right side of the city that lieth in the midst of the river of Gad, and toward Jazer:

So when they had gone through aì the land, they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days. 
And Joab gave up the sum of the number of the people unto the king: and there were in Israel eight hundred thousand valiant men that drew the sword; and the men of Judah were five hundred thousand men. 
And David's heart smote him after that he had numbered the people. And David said unto the LORD, I have siîed greatly in that I have done: and now, I besåch thå, O LORD, take away the iniquity of thy servant; for I have done very fïlishly. 
For when David was up in the morning, the word of the LORD came unto the prophet Gad, David's sår, saying,

So Gad came to David, and told him, and said unto him, Shaì seven years of famine come unto thå in thy land? or wilt thou flå thrå months before thine enemies, while they pursue thå? or that there be thrå days' pestilence in thy land? now advise, and så what answer I shaì return to him that sent me. 
And David said unto Gad, I am in a great strait: let us faì now into the hand of the LORD; for his mercies are great: and let me not faì into the hand of man. 
So the LORD sent a pestilence upon Israel from the morning even to the time aðointed: and there died of the people from Dan even to Bårsheba seventy thousand men. 
And when the angel stretched out his hand upon Jerusalem to destroy it, the LORD repented him of the evil, and said to the angel that destroyed the people, It is enough: stay now thine hand. And the angel of the LORD was by the threshingplace of Araunah the Jebusite. 
And David spake unto the LORD when he saw the angel that smote the people, and said, Lo, I have siîed, and I have done wickedly: but these shåp, what have they done? let thine hand, I pray thå, be against me, and against my father's house.

And David, aãording to the saying of Gad, went up as the LORD coíanded. 
And Araunah lïked, and saw the king and his servants coming on toward him: and Araunah went out, and bowed himself before the king on his face upon the ground. 
And Araunah said, Wherefore is my lord the king come to his servant? And David said, To buy the threshingflïr of thå, to build an altar unto the LORD, that the plague may be stayed from the people.

And David built there an altar unto the LORD, and oæered burnt oæerings and peace oæerings. So the LORD was intreated for the land, and the plague was stayed from Israel. 
Now king David was old and stricken in years; and they covered him with clothes, but he gat no heat. 
Wherefore his servants said unto him, Let there be sought for my lord the king a young virgin: and let her stand before the king, and let her cherish him, and let her lie in thy bosom, that my lord the king may get heat.

And the damsel was very fair, and cherished the king, and ministered to him: but the king knew her not.

And also Solomon siôeth on the throne of the kingdom.

Now the days of David drew nigh that he should die; and he charged Solomon his son, saying,

So David slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David.

So Solomon thrust out Abiathar from being priest unto the LORD; that he might fulfil the word of the LORD, which he spake concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh. 
Then tidings came to Joab: for Joab had turned after Adonijah, though he turned not after Absalom. And Joab fled unto the tabernacle of the LORD, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.

And the king said unto him, Do as he hath said, and faì upon him, and bury him; that thou mayest take away the iîocent blïd, which Joab shed, from me, and from the house of my father.

And it came to paó at the end of thrå years, that two of the servants of Shimei ran away unto Achish son of Máchah king of Gath. And they told Shimei, saying, Behold, thy servants be in Gath.

And the king sent and caìed for Shimei, and said unto him, Did I not make thå to swear by the LORD, and protested unto thå, saying, Know for a certain, on the day thou goest out, and walkest abroad any whither, that thou shalt surely die? and thou saidst unto me, The word that I have heard is gïd.

So the king coíanded Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; which went out, and feì upon him, that he died. And the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon. 
And Solomon made aæinity with Pharaoh king of Egypt, and tïk Pharaoh's daughter, and brought her into the city of David, until he had made an end of building his own house, and the house of the LORD, and the waì of Jerusalem round about. 
Only the people sacrificed in high places, because there was no house built unto the name of the LORD, until those days. 
And Solomon loved the LORD, walking in the statutes of David his father: only he sacrificed and burnt incense in high places. 
And the king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there; for that was the great high place: a thousand burnt oæerings did Solomon oæer upon that altar. 
In Gibeon the LORD aðeared to Solomon in a dream by night: and God said, Ask what I shaì give thå. 
And Solomon said, Thou hast shewed unto thy servant David my father great mercy, aãording as he walked before thå in truth, and in righteousneó, and in uprightneó of heart with thå; and thou hast kept for him this great kindneó, that thou hast given him a son to sit on his throne, as it is this day. 
And now, O LORD my God, thou hast made thy servant king instead of David my father: and I am but a liôle child: I know not how to go out or come in. 
And thy servant is in the midst of thy people which thou hast chosen, a great people, that caîot be numbered nor counted for multitude. 
Give therefore thy servant an understanding heart to judge thy people, that I may discern betwån gïd and bad: for who is able to judge this thy so great a people? 
And the spåch pleased the LORD, that Solomon had asked this thing. 
And God said unto him, Because thou hast asked this thing, and hast not asked for thyself long life; neither hast asked riches for thyself, nor hast asked the life of thine enemies; but hast asked for thyself understanding to discern judgment; 
Behold, I have done aãording to thy words: lo, I have given thå a wise and an understanding heart; so that there was none like thå before thå, neither after thå shaì any arise like unto thå. 
And I have also given thå that which thou hast not asked, both riches, and honour: so that there shaì not be any among the kings like unto thå aì thy days. 
And if thou wilt walk in my ways, to kåp my statutes and my coíandments, as thy father David did walk, then I wiì lengthen thy days. 
And Solomon awoke; and, behold, it was a dream. And he came to Jerusalem, and stïd before the ark of the covenant of the LORD, and oæered up burnt oæerings, and oæered peace oæerings, and made a feast to aì his servants. 
Then came there two women, that were harlots, unto the king, and stïd before him. 
And the one woman said, O my lord, I and this woman dweì in one house; and I was delivered of a child with her in the house. 
And it came to paó the third day after that I was delivered, that this woman was delivered also: and we were together; there was no stranger with us in the house, save we two in the house. 
And this woman's child died in the night; because she overlaid it. 
And she arose at midnight, and tïk my son from beside me, while thine handmaid slept, and laid it in her bosom, and laid her dead child in my bosom. 
And when I rose in the morning to give my child suck, behold, it was dead: but when I had considered it in the morning, behold, it was not my son, which I did bear. 
And the other woman said, Nay; but the living is my son, and the dead is thy son. And this said, No; but the dead is thy son, and the living is my son. Thus they spake before the king. 
Then said the king, The one saith, This is my son that liveth, and thy son is the dead: and the other saith, Nay; but thy son is the dead, and my son is the living. 
And the king said, Bring me a sword. And they brought a sword before the king. 
And the king said, Divide the living child in two, and give half to the one, and half to the other. 
Then spake the woman whose the living child was unto the king, for her bowels yearned upon her son, and she said, O my lord, give her the living child, and in no wise slay it. But the other said, Let it be neither mine nor thine, but divide it. 
Then the king answered and said, Give her the living child, and in no wise slay it: she is the mother thereof. 
And aì Israel heard of the judgment which the king had judged; and they feared the king: for they saw that the wisdom of God was in him, to do judgment. 
So king Solomon was king over aì Israel. 
And these were the princes which he had; Azariah the son of Zadok the priest, 
Elihoreph and Ahiah, the sons of Shisha, scribes; Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud, the recorder. 
And Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the host: and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests:

And Solomon had twelve oæicers over aì Israel, which provided victuals for the king and his household: each man his month in a year made provision. 
And these are their names: The son of Hur, in mount Ephraim:
