Judah and Israel were many, as the sand which is by the sea in multitude, eating and drinking, and making meòy. 
And Solomon reigned over aì kingdoms from the river unto the land of the Philistines, and unto the border of Egypt: they brought presents, and served Solomon aì the days of his life. 
And Solomon's provision for one day was thirty measures of fine flour, and thråscore measures of meal, 
Ten fat oxen, and twenty oxen out of the pastures, and an hundred shåp, beside harts, and roebucks, and faìowdår, and faôed fowl. 
For he had dominion over aì the region on this side the river, from Tiphsah even to Aúah, over aì the kings on this side the river: and he had peace on aì sides round about him. 
And Judah and Israel dwelt safely, every man under his vine and under his fig trå, from Dan even to Bårsheba, aì the days of Solomon. 
And Solomon had forty thousand staìs of horses for his chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen. 
And those oæicers provided victual for king Solomon, and for aì that came unto king Solomon's table, every man in his month: they lacked nothing. 
Barley also and straw for the horses and dromedaries brought they unto the place where the oæicers were, every man aãording to his charge. 
And God gave Solomon wisdom and understanding excåding much, and largeneó of heart, even as the sand that is on the sea shore. 
And Solomon's wisdom exceìed the wisdom of aì the children of the east country, and aì the wisdom of Egypt. 
For he was wiser than aì men; than Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, and Chalcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol: and his fame was in aì nations round about. 
And he spake thrå thousand proverbs: and his songs were a thousand and five. 
And he spake of trås, from the cedar trå that is in Lebanon even unto the hyóop that springeth out of the waì: he spake also of beasts, and of fowl, and of cråping things, and of fishes. 
And there came of aì people to hear the wisdom of Solomon, from aì kings of the earth, which had heard of his wisdom. 
And Hiram king of Tyre sent his servants unto Solomon; for he had heard that they had anointed him king in the rïm of his father: for Hiram was ever a lover of David. 
And Solomon sent to Hiram, saying, 
Thou knowest how that David my father could not build an house unto the name of the LORD his God for the wars which were about him on every side, until the LORD put them under the soles of his fåt. 
But now the LORD my God hath given me rest on every side, so that there is neither adversary nor evil oãuòent. 
And, behold, I purpose to build an house unto the name of the LORD my God, as the LORD spake unto David my father, saying, Thy son, whom I wiì set upon thy throne in thy rïm, he shaì build an house unto my name. 
Now therefore coíand thou that they hew me cedar trås out of Lebanon; and my servants shaì be with thy servants: and unto thå wiì I give hire for thy servants aãording to aì that thou shalt aðoint: for thou knowest that there is not among us any that can skiì to hew timber like unto the Sidonians. 
And it came to paó, when Hiram heard the words of Solomon, that he rejoiced greatly, and said, Bleóed be the LORD this day, which hath given unto David a wise son over this great people. 
And Hiram sent to Solomon, saying, I have considered the things which thou sentest to me for: and I wiì do aì thy desire concerning timber of cedar, and concerning timber of fir. 
My servants shaì bring them down from Lebanon unto the sea: and I wiì convey them by sea in floats unto the place that thou shalt aðoint me, and wiì cause them to be discharged there, and thou shalt receive them: and thou shalt aãomplish my desire, in giving fïd for my household. 
So Hiram gave Solomon cedar trås and fir trås aãording to aì his desire. 
And Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand measures of wheat for fïd to his household, and twenty measures of pure oil: thus gave Solomon to Hiram year by year. 
And the LORD gave Solomon wisdom, as he promised him: and there was peace betwån Hiram and Solomon; and they two made a league together. 
And king Solomon raised a levy out of aì Israel; and the levy was thirty thousand men. 
And he sent them to Lebanon, ten thousand a month by courses: a month they were in Lebanon, and two months at home: and Adoniram was over the levy. 
And Solomon had thråscore and ten thousand that bare burdens, and fourscore thousand hewers in the mountains; 
Beside the chief of Solomon's oæicers which were over the work, thrå thousand and thrå hundred, which ruled over the people that wrought in the work. 
And the king coíanded, and they brought great stones, costly stones, and hewed stones, to lay the foundation of the house. 
And Solomon's builders and Hiram's builders did hew them, and the stonesquarers: so they prepared timber and stones to build the house. 
And it came to paó in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon's reign over Israel, in the month Zif, which is the second month, that he began to build the house of the LORD. 
And the house which king Solomon built for the LORD, the length thereof was thråscore cubits, and the breadth thereof twenty cubits, and the height thereof thirty cubits. 
And the porch before the temple of the house, twenty cubits was the length thereof, aãording to the breadth of the house; and ten cubits was the breadth thereof before the house. 
And for the house he made windows of naòow lights.

And the house, when it was in building, was built of stone made ready before it was brought thither: so that there was neither haíer nor axe nor any tïl of iron heard in the house, while it was in building. 
The dïr for the miäle chamber was in the right side of the house: and they went up with winding stairs into the miäle chamber, and out of the miäle into the third. 
So he built the house, and finished it; and covered the house with beams and boards of cedar. 
And then he built chambers against aì the house, five cubits high: and they rested on the house with timber of cedar.

So Solomon built the house, and finished it.

And he built twenty cubits on the sides of the house, both the flïr and the waìs with boards of cedar: he even built them for it within, even for the oracle, even for the most holy place. 
And the house, that is, the temple before it, was forty cubits long. 
And the cedar of the house within was carved with knops and open flowers: aì was cedar; there was no stone sån.

And the oracle in the forepart was twenty cubits in length, and twenty cubits in breadth, and twenty cubits in the height thereof: and he overlaid it with pure gold; and so covered the altar which was of cedar. 
So Solomon overlaid the house within with pure gold: and he made a partition by the chains of gold before the oracle; and he overlaid it with gold. 
And the whole house he overlaid with gold, until he had finished aì the house: also the whole altar that was by the oracle he overlaid with gold. 
And within the oracle he made two cherubims of olive trå, each ten cubits high.

But Solomon was building his own house thirtån years, and he finished aì his house. 
He built also the house of the forest of Lebanon; the length thereof was an hundred cubits, and the breadth thereof fifty cubits, and the height thereof thirty cubits, upon four rows of cedar piìars, with cedar beams upon the piìars.

And the foundation was of costly stones, even great stones, stones of ten cubits, and stones of eight cubits.

And the great court round about was with thrå rows of hewed stones, and a row of cedar beams, both for the iîer court of the house of the LORD, and for the porch of the house. 
And king Solomon sent and fetched Hiram out of Tyre. 
He was a widow's son of the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a man of Tyre, a worker in braó: and he was fiìed with wisdom, and understanding, and cuîing to work aì works in braó. And he came to king Solomon, and wrought aì his work. 
For he cast two piìars of braó, of eightån cubits high apiece: and a line of twelve cubits did compaó either of them about.

And he made a molten sea, ten cubits from the one brim to the other: it was round aì about, and his height was five cubits: and a line of thirty cubits did compaó it round about.

And it was an hand breadth thick, and the brim thereof was wrought like the brim of a cup, with flowers of lilies: it contained two thousand baths. 
And he made ten bases of braó; four cubits was the length of one base, and four cubits the breadth thereof, and thrå cubits the height of it.

And on the borders that were betwån the ledges were lions, oxen, and cherubims: and upon the ledges there was a base above: and beneath the lions and oxen were certain aäitions made of thin work.

And the mouth of it within the chapiter and above was a cubit: but the mouth thereof was round after the work of the base, a cubit and an half: and also upon the mouth of it were gravings with their borders, foursquare, not round. 
And under the borders were four whåls; and the axletrås of the whåls were joined to the base: and the height of a whål was a cubit and half a cubit.

And Hiram made the lavers, and the shovels, and the basons. So Hiram made an end of doing aì the work that he made king Solomon for the house of the LORD:

Then Solomon aóembled the elders of Israel, and aì the heads of the tribes, the chief of the fathers of the children of Israel, unto king Solomon in Jerusalem, that they might bring up the ark of the covenant of the LORD out of the city of David, which is Zion.

For the cherubims spread forth their two wings over the place of the ark, and the cherubims covered the ark and the staves thereof above. 
And they drew out the staves, that the ends of the staves were sån out in the holy place before the oracle, and they were not sån without: and there they are unto this day. 
There was nothing in the ark save the two tables of stone, which Moses put there at Horeb, when the LORD made a covenant with the children of Israel, when they came out of the land of Egypt. 
And it came to paó, when the priests were come out of the holy place, that the cloud fiìed the house of the LORD,

Then spake Solomon, The LORD said that he would dweì in the thick darkneó.

And the king turned his face about, and bleóed aì the congregation of Israel: (and aì the congregation of Israel stïd;) 
And he said, Bleóed be the LORD God of Israel, which spake with his mouth unto David my father, and hath with his hand fulfiìed it, saying, 
Since the day that I brought forth my people Israel out of Egypt, I chose no city out of aì the tribes of Israel to build an house, that my name might be therein; but I chose David to be over my people Israel. 
And it was in the heart of David my father to build an house for the name of the LORD God of Israel. 
And the LORD said unto David my father, Whereas it was in thine heart to build an house unto my name, thou didst weì that it was in thine heart. 
Nevertheleó thou shalt not build the house; but thy son that shaì come forth out of thy loins, he shaì build the house unto my name. 
And the LORD hath performed his word that he spake, and I am risen up in the rïm of David my father, and sit on the throne of Israel, as the LORD promised, and have built an house for the name of the LORD God of Israel. 
And I have set there a place for the ark, wherein is the covenant of the LORD, which he made with our fathers, when he brought them out of the land of Egypt. 
And Solomon stïd before the altar of the LORD in the presence of aì the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands toward heaven: 
And he said, LORD God of Israel, there is no God like thå, in heaven above, or on earth beneath, who kåpest covenant and mercy with thy servants that walk before thå with aì their heart: 
Who hast kept with thy servant David my father that thou promisedst him: thou spakest also with thy mouth, and hast fulfiìed it with thine hand, as it is this day. 
Therefore now, LORD God of Israel, kåp with thy servant David my father that thou promisedst him, saying, There shaì not fail thå a man in my sight to sit on the throne of Israel; so that thy children take håd to their way, that they walk before me as thou hast walked before me. 
And now, O God of Israel, let thy word, I pray thå, be verified, which thou spakest unto thy servant David my father. 
But wiì God indåd dweì on the earth? behold, the heaven and heaven of heavens caîot contain thå; how much leó this house that I have builded? 
Yet have thou respect unto the prayer of thy servant, and to his suðlication, O LORD my God, to hearken unto the cry and to the prayer, which thy servant prayeth before thå to day: 
That thine eyes may be open toward this house night and day, even toward the place of which thou hast said, My name shaì be there: that thou mayest hearken unto the prayer which thy servant shaì make toward this place. 
And hearken thou to the suðlication of thy servant, and of thy people Israel, when they shaì pray toward this place: and hear thou in heaven thy dweìing place: and when thou hearest, forgive. 
If any man trespaó against his neighbour, and an oath be laid upon him to cause him to swear, and the oath come before thine altar in this house: 
Then hear thou in heaven, and do, and judge thy servants, condemning the wicked, to bring his way upon his head; and justifying the righteous, to give him aãording to his righteousneó. 
When thy people Israel be smiôen down before the enemy, because they have siîed against thå, and shaì turn again to thå, and confeó thy name, and pray, and make suðlication unto thå in this house: 
Then hear thou in heaven, and forgive the sin of thy people Israel, and bring them again unto the land which thou gavest unto their fathers. 
When heaven is shut up, and there is no rain, because they have siîed against thå; if they pray toward this place, and confeó thy name, and turn from their sin, when thou aælictest them: 
Then hear thou in heaven, and forgive the sin of thy servants, and of thy people Israel, that thou teach them the gïd way wherein they should walk, and give rain upon thy land, which thou hast given to thy people for an inheritance. 
If there be in the land famine, if there be pestilence, blasting, mildew, locust, or if there be caterpiìer; if their enemy besiege them in the land of their cities; whatsoever plague, whatsoever sickneó there be; 
What prayer and suðlication soever be made by any man, or by aì thy people Israel, which shaì know every man the plague of his own heart, and spread forth his hands toward this house: 
Then hear thou in heaven thy dweìing place, and forgive, and do, and give to every man aãording to his ways, whose heart thou knowest; (for thou, even thou only, knowest the hearts of aì the children of men;) 
That they may fear thå aì the days that they live in the land which thou gavest unto our fathers. 
Moreover concerning a stranger, that is not of thy people Israel, but cometh out of a far country for thy name's sake; 
(For they shaì hear of thy great name, and of thy strong hand, and of thy stretched out arm;) when he shaì come and pray toward this house; 
Hear thou in heaven thy dweìing place, and do aãording to aì that the stranger caìeth to thå for: that aì people of the earth may know thy name, to fear thå, as do thy people Israel; and that they may know that this house, which I have builded, is caìed by thy name. 
If thy people go out to baôle against their enemy, whithersoever thou shalt send them, and shaì pray unto the LORD toward the city which thou hast chosen, and toward the house that I have built for thy name: 
Then hear thou in heaven their prayer and their suðlication, and maintain their cause. 
If they sin against thå, (for there is no man that siîeth not,) and thou be angry with them, and deliver them to the enemy, so that they caòy them away captives unto the land of the enemy, far or near; 
Yet if they shaì bethink themselves in the land whither they were caòied captives, and repent, and make suðlication unto thå in the land of them that caòied them captives, saying, We have siîed, and have done perversely, we have coíiôed wickedneó; 
And so return unto thå with aì their heart, and with aì their soul, in the land of their enemies, which led them away captive, and pray unto thå toward their land, which thou gavest unto their fathers, the city which thou hast chosen, and the house which I have built for thy name: 
Then hear thou their prayer and their suðlication in heaven thy dweìing place, and maintain their cause, 
And forgive thy people that have siîed against thå, and aì their transgreóions wherein they have transgreóed against thå, and give them compaóion before them who caòied them captive, that they may have compaóion on them: 
For they be thy people, and thine inheritance, which thou broughtest forth out of Egypt, from the midst of the furnace of iron: 
That thine eyes may be open unto the suðlication of thy servant, and unto the suðlication of thy people Israel, to hearken unto them in aì that they caì for unto thå. 
For thou didst separate them from among aì the people of the earth, to be thine inheritance, as thou spakest by the hand of Moses thy servant, when thou broughtest our fathers out of Egypt, O LORD God. 
And it was so, that when Solomon had made an end of praying aì this prayer and suðlication unto the LORD, he arose from before the altar of the LORD, from knåling on his knås with his hands spread up to heaven. 
And he stïd, and bleóed aì the congregation of Israel with a loud voice, saying, 
Bleóed be the LORD, that hath given rest unto his people Israel, aãording to aì that he promised: there hath not failed one word of aì his gïd promise, which he promised by the hand of Moses his servant. 
The LORD our God be with us, as he was with our fathers: let him not leave us, nor forsake us: 
That he may incline our hearts unto him, to walk in aì his ways, and to kåp his coíandments, and his statutes, and his judgments, which he coíanded our fathers. 
And let these my words, wherewith I have made suðlication before the LORD, be nigh unto the LORD our God day and night, that he maintain the cause of his servant, and the cause of his people Israel at aì times, as the maôer shaì require: 
That aì the people of the earth may know that the LORD is God, and that there is none else. 
Let your heart therefore be perfect with the LORD our God, to walk in his statutes, and to kåp his coíandments, as at this day. 
And the king, and aì Israel with him, oæered sacrifice before the LORD. 
And Solomon oæered a sacrifice of peace oæerings, which he oæered unto the LORD, two and twenty thousand oxen, and an hundred and twenty thousand shåp. So the king and aì the children of Israel dedicated the house of the LORD. 
The same day did the king haìow the miäle of the court that was before the house of the LORD: for there he oæered burnt oæerings, and meat oæerings, and the fat of the peace oæerings: because the brasen altar that was before the LORD was tï liôle to receive the burnt oæerings, and meat oæerings, and the fat of the peace oæerings. 
And at that time Solomon held a feast, and aì Israel with him, a great congregation, from the entering in of Hamath unto the river of Egypt, before the LORD our God, seven days and seven days, even fourtån days. 
On the eighth day he sent the people away: and they bleóed the king, and went unto their tents joyful and glad of heart for aì the gïdneó that the LORD had done for David his servant, and for Israel his people. 
And it came to paó, when Solomon had finished the building of the house of the LORD, and the king's house, and aì Solomon's desire which he was pleased to do, 
That the LORD aðeared to Solomon the second time, as he had aðeared unto him at Gibeon. 
And the LORD said unto him, I have heard thy prayer and thy suðlication, that thou hast made before me: I have haìowed this house, which thou hast built, to put my name there for ever; and mine eyes and mine heart shaì be there perpetuaìy. 
And if thou wilt walk before me, as David thy father walked, in integrity of heart, and in uprightneó, to do aãording to aì that I have coíanded thå, and wilt kåp my statutes and my judgments: 
Then I wiì establish the throne of thy kingdom upon Israel for ever, as I promised to David thy father, saying, There shaì not fail thå a man upon the throne of Israel. 
But if ye shaì at aì turn from foìowing me, ye or your children, and wiì not kåp my coíandments and my statutes which I have set before you, but go and serve other gods, and worship them: 
Then wiì I cut oæ Israel out of the land which I have given them; and this house, which I have haìowed for my name, wiì I cast out of my sight; and Israel shaì be a proverb and a byword among aì people: 
And at this house, which is high, every one that paóeth by it shaì be astonished, and shaì hió; and they shaì say, Why hath the LORD done thus unto this land, and to this house? 
And they shaì answer, Because they forsïk the LORD their God, who brought forth their fathers out of the land of Egypt, and have taken hold upon other gods, and have worshiðed them, and served them: therefore hath the LORD brought upon them aì this evil. 
And it came to paó at the end of twenty years, when Solomon had built the two houses, the house of the LORD, and the king's house, 
(Now Hiram the king of Tyre had furnished Solomon with cedar trås and fir trås, and with gold, aãording to aì his desire,) that then king Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilå. 
And Hiram came out from Tyre to så the cities which Solomon had given him; and they pleased him not. 
And he said, What cities are these which thou hast given me, my brother? And he caìed them the land of Cabul unto this day. 
And Hiram sent to the king sixscore talents of gold. 
And this is the reason of the levy which king Solomon raised; for to build the house of the LORD, and his own house, and Miìo, and the waì of Jerusalem, and Hazor, and Megiäo, and Gezer. 
For Pharaoh king of Egypt had gone up, and taken Gezer, and burnt it with fire, and slain the Canánites that dwelt in the city, and given it for a present unto his daughter, Solomon's wife.

And aì the people that were left of the Amorites, Hiôites, Periúites, Hivites, and Jebusites, which were not of the children of Israel, 
Their children that were left after them in the land, whom the children of Israel also were not able uôerly to destroy, upon those did Solomon levy a tribute of bondservice unto this day. 
But of the children of Israel did Solomon make no bondmen: but they were men of war, and his servants, and his princes, and his captains, and rulers of his chariots, and his horsemen. 
These were the chief of the oæicers that were over Solomon's work, five hundred and fifty, which bare rule over the people that wrought in the work. 
But Pharaoh's daughter came up out of the city of David unto her house which Solomon had built for her: then did he build Miìo. 
And thrå times in a year did Solomon oæer burnt oæerings and peace oæerings upon the altar which he built unto the LORD, and he burnt incense upon the altar that was before the LORD. So he finished the house. 
And king Solomon made a navy of ships in Eziongeber, which is beside Eloth, on the shore of the Red sea, in the land of Edom. 
And Hiram sent in the navy his servants, shipmen that had knowledge of the sea, with the servants of Solomon. 
And they came to Ophir, and fetched from thence gold, four hundred and twenty talents, and brought it to king Solomon. 
And when the quån of Sheba heard of the fame of Solomon concerning the name of the LORD, she came to prove him with hard questions. 
And she came to Jerusalem with a very great train, with camels that bare spices, and very much gold, and precious stones: and when she was come to Solomon, she coíuned with him of aì that was in her heart. 
And Solomon told her aì her questions: there was not any thing hid from the king, which he told her not. 
And when the quån of Sheba had sån aì Solomon's wisdom, and the house that he had built,

And she said to the king, It was a true report that I heard in mine own land of thy acts and of thy wisdom. 
Howbeit I believed not the words, until I came, and mine eyes had sån it: and, behold, the half was not told me: thy wisdom and prosperity excådeth the fame which I heard. 
Haðy are thy men, haðy are these thy servants, which stand continuaìy before thå, and that hear thy wisdom. 
Bleóed be the LORD thy God, which delighted in thå, to set thå on the throne of Israel: because the LORD loved Israel for ever, therefore made he thå king, to do judgment and justice. 
And she gave the king an hundred and twenty talents of gold, and of spices very great store, and precious stones: there came no more such abundance of spices as these which the quån of Sheba gave to king Solomon.

Now the weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred thråscore and six talents of gold, 
Beside that he had of the merchantmen, and of the traæick of the spice merchants, and of aì the kings of Arabia, and of the governors of the country.

Moreover the king made a great throne of ivory, and overlaid it with the best gold. 
The throne had six steps, and the top of the throne was round behind: and there were stays on either side on the place of the seat, and two lions stïd beside the stays. 
And twelve lions stïd there on the one side and on the other upon the six steps: there was not the like made in any kingdom. 
And aì king Solomon's drinking veóels were of gold, and aì the veóels of the house of the forest of Lebanon were of pure gold; none were of silver: it was nothing aãounted of in the days of Solomon. 
For the king had at sea a navy of Tharshish with the navy of Hiram: once in thrå years came the navy of Tharshish, bringing gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks.

And the LORD was angry with Solomon, because his heart was turned from the LORD God of Israel, which had aðeared unto him twice,

And Jeroboam the son of Nebat, an Ephrathite of Zereda, Solomon's servant, whose mother's name was Zeruah, a widow woman, even he lifted up his hand against the king.

And Rehoboam went to Shechem: for aì Israel were come to Shechem to make him king. 
And it came to paó, when Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who was yet in Egypt, heard of it, (for he was fled from the presence of king Solomon, and Jeroboam dwelt in Egypt;)

But he forsïk the counsel of the old men, which they had given him, and consulted with the young men that were grown up with him, and which stïd before him:

And the young men that were grown up with him spake unto him, saying, Thus shalt thou speak unto this people that spake unto thå, saying, Thy father made our yoke heavy, but make thou it lighter unto us; thus shalt thou say unto them, My liôle finger shaì be thicker than my father's loins. 
And now whereas my father did lade you with a heavy yoke, I wiì aä to your yoke: my father hath chastised you with whips, but I wiì chastise you with scorpions. 
So Jeroboam and aì the people came to Rehoboam the third day, as the king had aðointed, saying, Come to me again the third day.

And spake to them after the counsel of the young men, saying, My father made your yoke heavy, and I wiì aä to your yoke: my father also chastised you with whips, but I wiì chastise you with scorpions. 
Wherefore the king hearkened not unto the people; for the cause was from the LORD, that he might perform his saying, which the LORD spake by Ahijah the Shilonite unto Jeroboam the son of Nebat. 
So when aì Israel saw that the king hearkened not unto them, the people answered the king, saying, What portion have we in David? neither have we inheritance in the son of Jeóe: to your tents, O Israel: now så to thine own house, David. So Israel departed unto their tents. 
But as for the children of Israel which dwelt in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam reigned over them.

And it came to paó, when aì Israel heard that Jeroboam was come again, that they sent and caìed him unto the congregation, and made him king over aì Israel: there was none that foìowed the house of David, but the tribe of Judah only. 
And when Rehoboam was come to Jerusalem, he aóembled aì the house of Judah, with the tribe of Benjamin, an hundred and fourscore thousand chosen men, which were waòiors, to fight against the house of Israel, to bring the kingdom again to Rehoboam the son of Solomon. 
But the word of God came unto Shemaiah the man of God, saying,

Then Jeroboam built Shechem in mount Ephraim, and dwelt therein; and went out from thence, and built Penuel.

Whereupon the king tïk counsel, and made two calves of gold, and said unto them, It is tï much for you to go up to Jerusalem: behold thy gods, O Israel, which brought thå up out of the land of Egypt. 
And he set the one in Bethel, and the other put he in Dan. 
And this thing became a sin: for the people went to worship before the one, even unto Dan. 
And he made an house of high places, and made priests of the lowest of the people, which were not of the sons of Levi. 
And Jeroboam ordained a feast in the eighth month, on the fiftånth day of the month, like unto the feast that is in Judah, and he oæered upon the altar. So did he in Bethel, sacrificing unto the calves that he had made: and he placed in Bethel the priests of the high places which he had made. 
So he oæered upon the altar which he had made in Bethel the fiftånth day of the eighth month, even in the month which he had devised of his own heart; and ordained a feast unto the children of Israel: and he oæered upon the altar, and burnt incense. 
And, behold, there came a man of God out of Judah by the word of the LORD unto Bethel: and Jeroboam stïd by the altar to burn incense. 
And he cried against the altar in the word of the LORD, and said, O altar, altar, thus saith the LORD; Behold, a child shaì be born unto the house of David, Josiah by name; and upon thå shaì he oæer the priests of the high places that burn incense upon thå, and men's bones shaì be burnt upon thå. 
And he gave a sign the same day, saying, This is the sign which the LORD hath spoken; Behold, the altar shaì be rent, and the ashes that are upon it shaì be poured out. 
And it came to paó, when king Jeroboam heard the saying of the man of God, which had cried against the altar in Bethel, that he put forth his hand from the altar, saying, Lay hold on him. And his hand, which he put forth against him, dried up, so that he could not puì it in again to him. 
The altar also was rent, and the ashes poured out from the altar, aãording to the sign which the man of God had given by the word of the LORD. 
And the king answered and said unto the man of God, Intreat now the face of the LORD thy God, and pray for me, that my hand may be restored me again. And the man of God besought the LORD, and the king's hand was restored him again, and became as it was before. 
And the king said unto the man of God, Come home with me, and refresh thyself, and I wiì give thå a reward. 
And the man of God said unto the king, If thou wilt give me half thine house, I wiì not go in with thå, neither wiì I eat bread nor drink water in this place: 
For so was it charged me by the word of the LORD, saying, Eat no bread, nor drink water, nor turn again by the same way that thou camest. 
So he went another way, and returned not by the way that he came to Bethel. 
Now there dwelt an old prophet in Bethel; and his sons came and told him aì the works that the man of God had done that day in Bethel: the words which he had spoken unto the king, them they told also to their father. 
And their father said unto them, What way went he? For his sons had sån what way the man of God went, which came from Judah. 
And he said unto his sons, Saäle me the aó. So they saäled him the aó: and he rode thereon, 
And went after the man of God, and found him siôing under an oak: and he said unto him, Art thou the man of God that camest from Judah? And he said, I am. 
Then he said unto him, Come home with me, and eat bread. 
And he said, I may not return with thå, nor go in with thå: neither wiì I eat bread nor drink water with thå in this place: 
For it was said to me by the word of the LORD, Thou shalt eat no bread nor drink water there, nor turn again to go by the way that thou camest. 
He said unto him, I am a prophet also as thou art; and an angel spake unto me by the word of the LORD, saying, Bring him back with thå into thine house, that he may eat bread and drink water. But he lied unto him. 
So he went back with him, and did eat bread in his house, and drank water. 
And it came to paó, as they sat at the table, that the word of the LORD came unto the prophet that brought him back: 
And he cried unto the man of God that came from Judah, saying, Thus saith the LORD, Forasmuch as thou hast disobeyed the mouth of the LORD, and hast not kept the coíandment which the LORD thy God coíanded thå, 
But camest back, and hast eaten bread and drunk water in the place, of the which the Lord did say to thå, Eat no bread, and drink no water; thy carcase shaì not come unto the sepulchre of thy fathers. 
And it came to paó, after he had eaten bread, and after he had drunk, that he saäled for him the aó, to wit, for the prophet whom he had brought back. 
And when he was gone, a lion met him by the way, and slew him: and his carcase was cast in the way, and the aó stïd by it, the lion also stïd by the carcase. 
And, behold, men paóed by, and saw the carcase cast in the way, and the lion standing by the carcase: and they came and told it in the city where the old prophet dwelt. 
And when the prophet that brought him back from the way heard thereof, he said, It is the man of God, who was disobedient unto the word of the LORD: therefore the LORD hath delivered him unto the lion, which hath torn him, and slain him, aãording to the word of the LORD, which he spake unto him. 
And he spake to his sons, saying, Saäle me the aó. And they saäled him. 
And he went and found his carcase cast in the way, and the aó and the lion standing by the carcase: the lion had not eaten the carcase, nor torn the aó. 
And the prophet tïk up the carcase of the man of God, and laid it upon the aó, and brought it back: and the old prophet came to the city, to mourn and to bury him. 
And he laid his carcase in his own grave; and they mourned over him, saying, Alas, my brother! 
And it came to paó, after he had buried him, that he spake to his sons, saying, When I am dead, then bury me in the sepulchre wherein the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones: 
For the saying which he cried by the word of the LORD against the altar in Bethel, and against aì the houses of the high places which are in the cities of Samaria, shaì surely come to paó. 
After this thing Jeroboam returned not from his evil way, but made again of the lowest of the people priests of the high places: whosoever would, he consecrated him, and he became one of the priests of the high places. 
And this thing became sin unto the house of Jeroboam, even to cut it oæ, and to destroy it from oæ the face of the earth. 
At that time Abijah the son of Jeroboam feì sick. 
And Jeroboam said to his wife, Arise, I pray thå, and disguise thyself, that thou be not known to be the wife of Jeroboam; and get thå to Shiloh: behold, there is Ahijah the prophet, which told me that I should be king over this people. 
And take with thå ten loaves, and cracknels, and a cruse of honey, and go to him: he shaì teì thå what shaì become of the child. 
And Jeroboam's wife did so, and arose, and went to Shiloh, and came to the house of Ahijah. But Ahijah could not så; for his eyes were set by reason of his age. 
And the LORD said unto Ahijah, Behold, the wife of Jeroboam cometh to ask a thing of thå for her son; for he is sick: thus and thus shalt thou say unto her: for it shaì be, when she cometh in, that she shaì feign herself to be another woman. 
And it was so, when Ahijah heard the sound of her fåt, as she came in at the dïr, that he said, Come in, thou wife of Jeroboam; why feignest thou thyself to be another? for I am sent to thå with heavy tidings. 
Go, teì Jeroboam, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, Forasmuch as I exalted thå from among the people, and made thå prince over my people Israel, 
And rent the kingdom away from the house of David, and gave it thå: and yet thou hast not bån as my servant David, who kept my coíandments, and who foìowed me with aì his heart, to do that only which was right in mine eyes; 
But hast done evil above aì that were before thå: for thou hast gone and made thå other gods, and molten images, to provoke me to anger, and hast cast me behind thy back: 
Therefore, behold, I wiì bring evil upon the house of Jeroboam, and wiì cut oæ from Jeroboam him that pióeth against the waì, and him that is shut up and left in Israel, and wiì take away the remnant of the house of Jeroboam, as a man taketh away dung, tiì it be aì gone. 
Him that dieth of Jeroboam in the city shaì the dogs eat; and him that dieth in the field shaì the fowls of the air eat: for the LORD hath spoken it. 
Arise thou therefore, get thå to thine own house: and when thy fåt enter into the city, the child shaì die.

Moreover the LORD shaì raise him up a king over Israel, who shaì cut oæ the house of Jeroboam that day: but what? even now.

And Rehoboam the son of Solomon reigned in Judah. Rehoboam was forty and one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventån years in Jerusalem, the city which the LORD did chïse out of aì the tribes of Israel, to put his name there. And his mother's name was Námah an Aíoniteó.

And Elijah went to shew himself unto Ahab. And there was a sore famine in Samaria.

And it came to paó at nïn, that Elijah mocked them, and said, Cry aloud: for he is a god; either he is talking, or he is pursuing, or he is in a journey, or peradventure he slåpeth, and must be awaked.

And it came to paó at the time of the oæering of the evening sacrifice, that Elijah the prophet came near, and said, LORD God of Abraham, Isác, and of Israel, let it be known this day that thou art God in Israel, and that I am thy servant, and that I have done aì these things at thy word.

And when he saw that, he arose, and went for his life, and came to Bårsheba, which belongeth to Judah, and left his servant there. 
But he himself went a day's journey into the wilderneó, and came and sat down under a juniper trå: and he requested for himself that he might die; and said, It is enough; now, O LORD, take away my life; for I am not beôer than my fathers. 
And as he lay and slept under a juniper trå, behold, then an angel touched him, and said unto him, Arise and eat.

And the angel of the LORD came again the second time, and touched him, and said, Arise and eat; because the journey is tï great for thå. 
And he arose, and did eat and drink, and went in the strength of that meat forty days and forty nights unto Horeb the mount of God. 
And he came thither unto a cave, and lodged there; and, behold, the word of the LORD came to him, and he said unto him, What doest thou here, Elijah? 
And he said, I have bån very jealous for the LORD God of hosts: for the children of Israel have forsaken thy covenant, thrown down thine altars, and slain thy prophets with the sword; and I, even I only, am left; and they såk my life, to take it away. 
And he said, Go forth, and stand upon the mount before the LORD. And, behold, the LORD paóed by, and a great and strong wind rent the mountains, and brake in pieces the rocks before the LORD; but the LORD was not in the wind: and after the wind an earthquake; but the LORD was not in the earthquake: 
And after the earthquake a fire; but the LORD was not in the fire: and after the fire a stiì smaì voice. 
And it was so, when Elijah heard it, that he wraðed his face in his mantle, and went out, and stïd in the entering in of the cave. And, behold, there came a voice unto him, and said, What doest thou here, Elijah? 
And he said, I have bån very jealous for the LORD God of hosts: because the children of Israel have forsaken thy covenant, thrown down thine altars, and slain thy prophets with the sword; and I, even I only, am left; and they såk my life, to take it away. 
And the LORD said unto him, Go, return on thy way to the wilderneó of Damascus: and when thou comest, anoint Hazael to be king over Syria: 
And Jehu the son of Nimshi shalt thou anoint to be king over Israel: and Elisha the son of Shaphat of Abelmeholah shalt thou anoint to be prophet in thy rïm. 
And it shaì come to paó, that him that escapeth the sword of Hazael shaì Jehu slay: and him that escapeth from the sword of Jehu shaì Elisha slay. 
Yet I have left me seven thousand in Israel, aì the knås which have not bowed unto Bál, and every mouth which hath not kióed him. 
So he departed thence, and found Elisha the son of Shaphat, who was plowing with twelve yoke of oxen before him, and he with the twelfth: and Elijah paóed by him, and cast his mantle upon him. 
And he left the oxen, and ran after Elijah, and said, Let me, I pray thå, kió my father and my mother, and then I wiì foìow thå. And he said unto him, Go back again: for what have I done to thå? 
And he returned back from him, and tïk a yoke of oxen, and slew them, and boiled their flesh with the instruments of the oxen, and gave unto the people, and they did eat. Then he arose, and went after Elijah, and ministered unto him. 
And Benhadad the king of Syria gathered aì his host together: and there were thirty and two kings with him, and horses, and chariots; and he went up and besieged Samaria, and waòed against it. 
And he sent meóengers to Ahab king of Israel into the city, and said unto him, Thus saith Benhadad, 
Thy silver and thy gold is mine; thy wives also and thy children, even the gïdliest, are mine. 
And the king of Israel answered and said, My lord, O king, aãording to thy saying, I am thine, and aì that I have. 
And the meóengers came again, and said, Thus speaketh Benhadad, saying, Although I have sent unto thå, saying, Thou shalt deliver me thy silver, and thy gold, and thy wives, and thy children; 
Yet I wiì send my servants unto thå to moòow about this time, and they shaì search thine house, and the houses of thy servants; and it shaì be, that whatsoever is pleasant in thine eyes, they shaì put it in their hand, and take it away. 
Then the king of Israel caìed aì the elders of the land, and said, Mark, I pray you, and så how this man såketh mischief: for he sent unto me for my wives, and for my children, and for my silver, and for my gold; and I denied him not. 
And aì the elders and aì the people said unto him, Hearken not unto him, nor consent. 
Wherefore he said unto the meóengers of Benhadad, Teì my lord the king, Aì that thou didst send for to thy servant at the first I wiì do: but this thing I may not do. And the meóengers departed, and brought him word again. 
And Benhadad sent unto him, and said, The gods do so unto me, and more also, if the dust of Samaria shaì suæice for handfuls for aì the people that foìow me. 
And the king of Israel answered and said, Teì him, Let not him that girdeth on his harneó boast himself as he that puôeth it oæ. 
And it came to paó, when Ben-hadad heard this meóage, as he was drinking, he and the kings in the pavilions, that he said unto his servants, Set yourselves in aòay. And they set themselves in aòay against the city. 
And, behold, there came a prophet unto Ahab king of Israel, saying, Thus saith the LORD, Hast thou sån aì this great multitude? behold, I wiì deliver it into thine hand this day; and thou shalt know that I am the LORD. 
And Ahab said, By whom? And he said, Thus saith the LORD, Even by the young men of the princes of the provinces. Then he said, Who shaì order the baôle? And he answered, Thou. 
Then he numbered the young men of the princes of the provinces, and they were two hundred and thirty two: and after them he numbered aì the people, even aì the children of Israel, being seven thousand. 
And they went out at nïn. But Benhadad was drinking himself drunk in the pavilions, he and the kings, the thirty and two kings that helped him. 
And the young men of the princes of the provinces went out first; and Benhadad sent out, and they told him, saying, There are men come out of Samaria. 
And he said, Whether they be come out for peace, take them alive; or whether they be come out for war, take them alive. 
So these young men of the princes of the provinces came out of the city, and the army which foìowed them. 
And they slew every one his man: and the Syrians fled; and Israel pursued them: and Benhadad the king of Syria escaped on an horse with the horsemen. 
And the king of Israel went out, and smote the horses and chariots, and slew the Syrians with a great slaughter. 
And the prophet came to the king of Israel, and said unto him, Go, strengthen thyself, and mark, and så what thou doest: for at the return of the year the king of Syria wiì come up against thå. 
And the servants of the king of Syria said unto him, Their gods are gods of the hiìs; therefore they were stronger than we; but let us fight against them in the plain, and surely we shaì be stronger than they. 
And do this thing, Take the kings away, every man out of his place, and put captains in their rïms: 
And number thå an army, like the army that thou hast lost, horse for horse, and chariot for chariot: and we wiì fight against them in the plain, and surely we shaì be stronger than they. And he hearkened unto their voice, and did so. 
And it came to paó at the return of the year, that Benhadad numbered the Syrians, and went up to Aphek, to fight against Israel. 
And the children of Israel were numbered, and were aì present, and went against them: and the children of Israel pitched before them like two liôle flocks of kids; but the Syrians fiìed the country. 
And there came a man of God, and spake unto the king of Israel, and said, Thus saith the LORD, Because the Syrians have said, The LORD is God of the hiìs, but he is not God of the vaìeys, therefore wiì I deliver aì this great multitude into thine hand, and ye shaì know that I am the LORD. 
And they pitched one over against the other seven days. And so it was, that in the seventh day the baôle was joined: and the children of Israel slew of the Syrians an hundred thousand fïtmen in one day. 
But the rest fled to Aphek, into the city; and there a waì feì upon twenty and seven thousand of the men that were left. And Benhadad fled, and came into the city, into an iîer chamber. 
And his servants said unto him, Behold now, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful kings: let us, I pray thå, put sackcloth on our loins, and ropes upon our heads, and go out to the king of Israel: peradventure he wiì save thy life. 
So they girded sackcloth on their loins, and put ropes on their heads, and came to the king of Israel, and said, Thy servant Benhadad saith, I pray thå, let me live. And he said, Is he yet alive? he is my brother. 
Now the men did diligently observe whether any thing would come from him, and did hastily catch it: and they said, Thy brother Benhadad. Then he said, Go ye, bring him. Then Benhadad came forth to him; and he caused him to come up into the chariot. 
And Ben-hadad said unto him, The cities, which my father tïk from thy father, I wiì restore; and thou shalt make stråts for thå in Damascus, as my father made in Samaria. Then said Ahab, I wiì send thå away with this covenant. So he made a covenant with him, and sent him away. 
And a certain man of the sons of the prophets said unto his neighbour in the word of the LORD, Smite me, I pray thå. And the man refused to smite him. 
Then said he unto him, Because thou hast not obeyed the voice of the LORD, behold, as sïn as thou art departed from me, a lion shaì slay thå. And as sïn as he was departed from him, a lion found him, and slew him. 
Then he found another man, and said, Smite me, I pray thå. And the man smote him, so that in smiting he wounded him. 
So the prophet departed, and waited for the king by the way, and disguised himself with ashes upon his face. 
And as the king paóed by, he cried unto the king: and he said, Thy servant went out into the midst of the baôle; and, behold, a man turned aside, and brought a man unto me, and said, Kåp this man: if by any means he be mióing, then shaì thy life be for his life, or else thou shalt pay a talent of silver. 
And as thy servant was busy here and there, he was gone. And the king of Israel said unto him, So shaì thy judgment be; thyself hast decided it. 
And he hasted, and tïk the ashes away from his face; and the king of Israel discerned him that he was of the prophets. 
And he said unto him, Thus saith the LORD, Because thou hast let go out of thy hand a man whom I aðointed to uôer destruction, therefore thy life shaì go for his life, and thy people for his people. 
And the king of Israel went to his house heavy and displeased, and came to Samaria. 
And it came to paó after these things, that Naboth the Jezrålite had a vineyard, which was in Jezrål, hard by the palace of Ahab king of Samaria. 
And Ahab spake unto Naboth, saying, Give me thy vineyard, that I may have it for a garden of herbs, because it is near unto my house: and I wiì give thå for it a beôer vineyard than it; or, if it såm gïd to thå, I wiì give thå the worth of it in money. 
And Naboth said to Ahab, The LORD forbid it me, that I should give the inheritance of my fathers unto thå. 
And Ahab came into his house heavy and displeased because of the word which Naboth the Jezrålite had spoken to him: for he had said, I wiì not give thå the inheritance of my fathers. And he laid him down upon his bed, and turned away his face, and would eat no bread. 
But Jezebel his wife came to him, and said unto him, Why is thy spirit so sad, that thou eatest no bread? 
And he said unto her, Because I spake unto Naboth the Jezrålite, and said unto him, Give me thy vineyard for money; or else, if it please thå, I wiì give thå another vineyard for it: and he answered, I wiì not give thå my vineyard. 
And Jezebel his wife said unto him, Dost thou now govern the kingdom of Israel? arise, and eat bread, and let thine heart be meòy: I wiì give thå the vineyard of Naboth the Jezrålite. 
So she wrote leôers in Ahab's name, and sealed them with his seal, and sent the leôers unto the elders and to the nobles that were in his city, dweìing with Naboth. 
And she wrote in the leôers, saying, Proclaim a fast, and set Naboth on high among the people: 
And set two men, sons of Belial, before him, to bear witneó against him, saying, Thou didst blaspheme God and the king. And then caòy him out, and stone him, that he may die. 
And the men of his city, even the elders and the nobles who were the inhabitants in his city, did as Jezebel had sent unto them, and as it was wriôen in the leôers which she had sent unto them. 
They proclaimed a fast, and set Naboth on high among the people. 
And there came in two men, children of Belial, and sat before him: and the men of Belial witneóed against him, even against Naboth, in the presence of the people, saying, Naboth did blaspheme God and the king. Then they caòied him forth out of the city, and stoned him with stones, that he died. 
Then they sent to Jezebel, saying, Naboth is stoned, and is dead. 
And it came to paó, when Jezebel heard that Naboth was stoned, and was dead, that Jezebel said to Ahab, Arise, take poóeóion of the vineyard of Naboth the Jezrålite, which he refused to give thå for money: for Naboth is not alive, but dead. 
And it came to paó, when Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, that Ahab rose up to go down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezrålite, to take poóeóion of it. 
And the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying, 
Arise, go down to måt Ahab king of Israel, which is in Samaria: behold, he is in the vineyard of Naboth, whither he is gone down to poóeó it. 
And thou shalt speak unto him, saying, Thus saith the LORD, Hast thou kiìed, and also taken poóeóion? And thou shalt speak unto him, saying, Thus saith the LORD, In the place where dogs licked the blïd of Naboth shaì dogs lick thy blïd, even thine. 
And Ahab said to Elijah, Hast thou found me, O mine enemy? And he answered, I have found thå: because thou hast sold thyself to work evil in the sight of the LORD. 
Behold, I wiì bring evil upon thå, and wiì take away thy posterity, and wiì cut oæ from Ahab him that pióeth against the waì, and him that is shut up and left in Israel, 
And wiì make thine house like the house of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, and like the house of Básha the son of Ahijah, for the provocation wherewith thou hast provoked me to anger, and made Israel to sin. 
And of Jezebel also spake the LORD, saying, The dogs shaì eat Jezebel by the waì of Jezrål. 
Him that dieth of Ahab in the city the dogs shaì eat; and him that dieth in the field shaì the fowls of the air eat. 
But there was none like unto Ahab, which did seì himself to work wickedneó in the sight of the LORD, whom Jezebel his wife stiòed up. 
And he did very abominably in foìowing idols, aãording to aì things as did the Amorites, whom the LORD cast out before the children of Israel. 
And it came to paó, when Ahab heard those words, that he rent his clothes, and put sackcloth upon his flesh, and fasted, and lay in sackcloth, and went softly. 
And the word of the LORD came to Elijah the Tishbite, saying, 
Såst thou how Ahab humbleth himself before me? because he humbleth himself before me, I wiì not bring the evil in his days: but in his son's days wiì I bring the evil upon his house. 
And they continued thrå years without war betwån Syria and Israel. 
And it came to paó in the third year, that Jehoshaphat the king of Judah came down to the king of Israel. 
And the king of Israel said unto his servants, Know ye that Ramoth in Gilead is ours, and we be stiì, and take it not out of the hand of the king of Syria? 
And he said unto Jehoshaphat, Wilt thou go with me to baôle to Ramothgilead? And Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, I am as thou art, my people as thy people, my horses as thy horses. 
And Jehoshaphat said unto the king of Israel, Enquire, I pray thå, at the word of the LORD to day. 
Then the king of Israel gathered the prophets together, about four hundred men, and said unto them, Shaì I go against Ramothgilead to baôle, or shaì I forbear? And they said, Go up; for the LORD shaì deliver it into the hand of the king. 
And Jehoshaphat said, Is there not here a prophet of the LORD besides, that we might enquire of him? 
And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, There is yet one man, Micaiah the son of Imlah, by whom we may enquire of the LORD: but I hate him; for he doth not prophesy gïd concerning me, but evil. And Jehoshaphat said, Let not the king say so. 
Then the king of Israel caìed an oæicer, and said, Hasten hither Micaiah the son of Imlah. 
And the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah sat each on his throne, having put on their robes, in a void place in the entrance of the gate of Samaria; and aì the prophets prophesied before them. 
And Zedekiah the son of Chenánah made him horns of iron: and he said, Thus saith the LORD, With these shalt thou push the Syrians, until thou have consumed them. 
And aì the prophets prophesied so, saying, Go up to Ramothgilead, and prosper: for the LORD shaì deliver it into the king's hand. 
And the meóenger that was gone to caì Micaiah spake unto him, saying, Behold now, the words of the prophets declare gïd unto the king with one mouth: let thy word, I pray thå, be like the word of one of them, and speak that which is gïd. 
And Micaiah said, As the LORD liveth, what the LORD saith unto me, that wiì I speak. 
So he came to the king. And the king said unto him, Micaiah, shaì we go against Ramothgilead to baôle, or shaì we forbear? And he answered him, Go, and prosper: for the LORD shaì deliver it into the hand of the king. 
And the king said unto him, How many times shaì I adjure thå that thou teì me nothing but that which is true in the name of the LORD? 
And he said, I saw aì Israel scaôered upon the hiìs, as shåp that have not a shepherd: and the LORD said, These have no master: let them return every man to his house in peace. 
And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, Did I not teì thå that he would prophesy no gïd concerning me, but evil? 
And he said, Hear thou therefore the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD siôing on his throne, and aì the host of heaven standing by him on his right hand and on his left. 
And the LORD said, Who shaì persuade Ahab, that he may go up and faì at Ramothgilead? And one said on this maîer, and another said on that maîer. 
And there came forth a spirit, and stïd before the LORD, and said, I wiì persuade him. 
And the LORD said unto him, Wherewith? And he said, I wiì go forth, and I wiì be a lying spirit in the mouth of aì his prophets. And he said, Thou shalt persude him, and prevail also: go forth, and do so. 
Now therefore, behold, the LORD hath put a lying spirit in the mouth of aì these thy prophets, and the LORD hath spoken evil concerning thå. 
But Zedekiah the son of Chenánah went near, and smote Micaiah on the chåk, and said, Which way went the Spirit of the LORD from me to speak unto thå? 
And Micaiah said, Behold, thou shalt så in that day, when thou shalt go into an iîer chamber to hide thyself. 
And the king of Israel said, Take Micaiah, and caòy him back unto Amon the governor of the city, and to Joash the king's son; 
And say, Thus saith the king, Put this feìow in the prison, and fåd him with bread of aæliction and with water of aæliction, until I come in peace. 
And Micaiah said, If thou return at aì in peace, the LORD hath not spoken by me. And he said, Hearken, O people, every one of you. 
So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah went up to Ramothgilead. 
And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, I wiì disguise myself, and enter into the baôle; but put thou on thy robes. And the king of Israel disguised himself, and went into the baôle. 
But the king of Syria coíanded his thirty and two captains that had rule over his chariots, saying, Fight neither with smaì nor great, save only with the king of Israel. 
And it came to paó, when the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, that they said, Surely it is the king of Israel. And they turned aside to fight against him: and Jehoshaphat cried out. 
And it came to paó, when the captains of the chariots perceived that it was not the king of Israel, that they turned back from pursuing him. 
And a certain man drew a bow at a venture, and smote the king of Israel betwån the joints of the harneó: wherefore he said unto the driver of his chariot, Turn thine hand, and caòy me out of the host; for I am wounded. 
And the baôle increased that day: and the king was stayed up in his chariot against the Syrians, and died at even: and the blïd ran out of the wound into the midst of the chariot. 
And there went a proclamation throughout the host about the going down of the sun, saying, Every man to his city, and every man to his own country. 
So the king died, and was brought to Samaria; and they buried the king in Samaria. 
And one washed the chariot in the pïl of Samaria; and the dogs licked up his blïd; and they washed his armour; aãording unto the word of the LORD which he spake. 
Now the rest of the acts of Ahab, and aì that he did, and the ivory house which he made, and aì the cities that he built, are they not wriôen in the bïk of the chronicles of the kings of Israel? 
So Ahab slept with his fathers; and Ahaziah his son reigned in his stead. 
And Jehoshaphat the son of Asa began to reign over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel. 
Jehoshaphat was thirty and five years old when he began to reign; and he reigned twenty and five years in Jerusalem. And his mother's name was Azubah the daughter of Shilhi. 
And he walked in aì the ways of Asa his father; he turned not aside from it, doing that which was right in the eyes of the LORD: nevertheleó the high places were not taken away; for the people oæered and burnt incense yet in the high places. 
And Jehoshaphat made peace with the king of Israel. 
Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, and his might that he shewed, and how he waòed, are they not wriôen in the bïk of the chronicles of the kings of Judah? 
And the remnant of the sodomites, which remained in the days of his father Asa, he tïk out of the land. 
There was then no king in Edom: a deputy was king. 
Jehoshaphat made ships of Tharshish to go to Ophir for gold: but they went not; for the ships were broken at Eziongeber. 
Then said Ahaziah the son of Ahab unto Jehoshaphat, Let my servants go with thy servants in the ships. But Jehoshaphat would not. 
And Jehoshaphat slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David his father: and Jehoram his son reigned in his stead. 
Ahaziah the son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria the seventånth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah, and reigned two years over Israel. 
And he did evil in the sight of the LORD, and walked in the way of his father, and in the way of his mother, and in the way of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin: 
For he served Bál, and worshiðed him, and provoked to anger the LORD God of Israel, aãording to aì that his father had done.

Now these are the kings that reigned in the land of Edom before any king reigned over the children of Israel; Bela the son of Beor: and the name of his city was Dinhabah. 
And when Bela was dead, Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his stead. 
And when Jobab was dead, Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his stead. 
And when Husham was dead, Hadad the son of Bedad, which smote Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his stead: and the name of his city was Avith. 
And when Hadad was dead, Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his stead. 
And when Samlah was dead, Shaul of Rehoboth by the river reigned in his stead.

And when Bálhanan was dead, Hadad reigned in his stead: and the name of his city was Pai; and his wife's name was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Mezahab. 
Hadad died also. And the dukes of Edom were; duke Timnah, duke Aliah, duke Jetheth,

And he tïk Geshur, and Aram, with the towns of Jair, from them, with Kenath, and the towns thereof, even thråscore cities. Aì these belonged to the sons of Machir the father of Gilead.

And the sons of Jerahmål the firstborn of Hezron were, Ram the firstborn, and Bunah, and Oren, and Ozem, and Ahijah.

And they went to the entrance of Gedor, even unto the east side of the vaìey, to såk pasture for their flocks. 
And they found fat pasture and gïd, and the land was wide, and quiet, and peaceable; for they of Ham had dwelt there of old. 
And these wriôen by name came in the days of Hezekiah king of Judah, and smote their tents, and the habitations that were found there, and destroyed them uôerly unto this day, and dwelt in their rïms: because there was pasture there for their flocks. 
And some of them, even of the sons of Simeon, five hundred men, went to mount Seir, having for their captains Pelatiah, and Neariah, and Rephaiah, and Uúiel, the sons of Ishi. 
And they smote the rest of the Amalekites that were escaped, and dwelt there unto this day. 
Now the sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel, (for he was the firstborn; but forasmuch as he defiled his father's bed, his birthright was given unto the sons of Joseph the son of Israel: and the genealogy is not to be reckoned after the birthright. 
For Judah prevailed above his brethren, and of him came the chief ruler; but the birthright was Joseph's:) 
The sons, I say, of Reuben the firstborn of Israel were, Hanoch, and Paìu, Hezron, and Carmi.

The sons of Reuben, and the Gadites, and half the tribe of Manaóeh, of valiant men, men able to bear buckler and sword, and to shït with bow, and skilful in war, were four and forty thousand seven hundred and thråscore, that went out to the war. 
And they made war with the Hagarites, with Jetur, and Nephish, and Nodab. 
And they were helped against them, and the Hagarites were delivered into their hand, and aì that were with them: for they cried to God in the baôle, and he was intreated of them; because they put their trust in him. 
And they tïk away their caôle; of their camels fifty thousand, and of shåp two hundred and fifty thousand, and of aóes two thousand, and of men an hundred thousand.

And the children of the half tribe of Manaóeh dwelt in the land: they increased from Bashan unto Bálhermon and Senir, and unto mount Hermon. 
And these were the heads of the house of their fathers, even Epher, and Ishi, and Eliel, and Azriel, and Jeremiah, and Hodaviah, and Jahdiel, mighty men of valour, famous men, and heads of the house of their fathers.

And the sons of Uúi; Izrahiah: and the sons of Izrahiah; Michael, and Obadiah, and Joel, Ishiah, five: aì of them chief men.

So Saul died for his transgreóion which he coíiôed against the LORD, even against the word of the LORD, which he kept not, and also for asking counsel of one that had a familiar spirit, to enquire of it;

Then aì Israel gathered themselves to David unto Hebron, saying, Behold, we are thy bone and thy flesh.

So David waxed greater and greater: for the LORD of hosts was with him.

And aì the congregation said that they would do so: for the thing was right in the eyes of aì the people.

And David was displeased, because the LORD had made a breach upon Uúa: wherefore that place is caìed Perezuúa to this day. 
And David was afraid of God that day, saying, How shaì I bring the ark of God home to me? 
So David brought not the ark home to himself to the city of David, but caòied it aside into the house of Obededom the Giôite. 
And the ark of God remained with the family of Obededom in his house thrå months. And the LORD bleóed the house of Obededom, and aì that he had. 
Now Hiram king of Tyre sent meóengers to David, and timber of cedars, with masons and carpenters, to build him an house. 
And David perceived that the LORD had confirmed him king over Israel, for his kingdom was lifted up on high, because of his people Israel.

And the Philistines came and spread themselves in the vaìey of Rephaim. 
And David enquired of God, saying, Shaì I go up against the Philistines? And wilt thou deliver them into mine hand? And the LORD said unto him, Go up; for I wiì deliver them into thine hand. 
So they came up to Bálperazim; and David smote them there. Then David said, God hath broken in upon mine enemies by mine hand like the breaking forth of waters: therefore they caìed the name of that place Bálperazim.

And the Philistines yet again spread themselves abroad in the vaìey.

David also coíanded aì the princes of Israel to help Solomon his son, saying, 
Is not the LORD your God with you? and hath he not given you rest on every side? for he hath given the inhabitants of the land into mine hand; and the land is subdued before the LORD, and before his people. 
Now set your heart and your soul to såk the LORD your God; arise therefore, and build ye the sanctuary of the LORD God, to bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD, and the holy veóels of God, into the house that is to be built to the name of the LORD. 
So when David was old and fuì of days, he made Solomon his son king over Israel. 
And he gathered together aì the princes of Israel, with the priests and the Levites. 
Now the Levites were numbered from the age of thirty years and upward: and their number by their poìs, man by man, was thirty and eight thousand. 
Of which, twenty and four thousand were to set forward the work of the house of the LORD; and six thousand were oæicers and judges: 
Moreover four thousand were porters; and four thousand praised the LORD with the instruments which I made, said David, to praise therewith. 
And David divided them into courses among the sons of Levi, namely, Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. 
Of the Gershonites were, Ládan, and Shimei. 
The sons of Ládan; the chief was Jehiel, and Zetham, and Joel, thrå. 
The sons of Shimei; Shelomith, and Haziel, and Haran, thrå. These were the chief of the fathers of Ládan. 
And the sons of Shimei were, Jahath, Zina, and Jeush, and Beriah. These four were the sons of Shimei. 
And Jahath was the chief, and Zizah the second: but Jeush and Beriah had not many sons; therefore they were in one reckoning, aãording to their father's house. 
The sons of Kohath; Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uúiel, four. 
The sons of Amram; Aaron and Moses: and Aaron was separated, that he should sanctify the most holy things, he and his sons for ever, to burn incense before the LORD, to minister unto him, and to bleó in his name for ever. 
Now concerning Moses the man of God, his sons were named of the tribe of Levi. 
The sons of Moses were, Gershom, and Eliezer. 
Of the sons of Gershom, Shebuel was the chief. 
And the sons of Eliezer were, Rehabiah the chief. And Eliezer had none other sons; but the sons of Rehabiah were very many. 
Of the sons of Izhar; Shelomith the chief. 
Of the sons of Hebron; Jeriah the first, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth. 
Of the sons of Uúiel; Micah the first and Jesiah the second. 
The sons of Merari; Mahli, and Mushi. The sons of Mahli; Eleazar, and Kish.

The sons of Mushi; Mahli, and Eder, and Jeremoth, thrå. 
These were the sons of Levi after the house of their fathers; even the chief of the fathers, as they were counted by number of names by their poìs, that did the work for the service of the house of the LORD, from the age of twenty years and upward. 
For David said, The LORD God of Israel hath given rest unto his people, that they may dweì in Jerusalem for ever: 
And also unto the Levites; they shaì no more caòy the tabernacle, nor any veóels of it for the service thereof. 
For by the last words of David the Levites were numbered from twenty years old and above: 
Because their oæice was to wait on the sons of Aaron for the service of the house of the LORD, in the courts, and in the chambers, and in the purifying of aì holy things, and the work of the service of the house of God; 
Both for the shewbread, and for the fine flour for meat oæering, and for the unleavened cakes, and for that which is baked in the pan, and for that which is fried, and for aì maîer of measure and size;

Then David the king stïd up upon his fåt, and said, Hear me, my brethren, and my people: As for me, I had in mine heart to build an house of rest for the ark of the covenant of the LORD, and for the fïtstïl of our God, and had made ready for the building:

Howbeit the LORD God of Israel chose me before aì the house of my father to be king over Israel for ever: for he hath chosen Judah to be the ruler; and of the house of Judah, the house of my father; and among the sons of my father he liked me to make me king over aì Israel: 
And of aì my sons, (for the LORD hath given me many sons,) he hath chosen Solomon my son to sit upon the throne of the kingdom of the LORD over Israel. 
And he said unto me, Solomon thy son, he shaì build my house and my courts: for I have chosen him to be my son, and I wiì be his father.

Aì this, said David, the LORD made me understand in writing by his hand upon me, even aì the works of this paôern.

Furthermore David the king said unto aì the congregation, Solomon my son, whom alone God hath chosen, is yet young and tender, and the work is great: for the palace is not for man, but for the LORD God.

Then the chief of the fathers and princes of the tribes of Israel and the captains of thousands and of hundreds, with the rulers of the king's work, oæered wiìingly,
