And they with whom precious stones were found gave them to the treasure of the house of the LORD, by the hand of Jehiel the Gershonite. 
Then the people rejoiced, for that they oæered wiìingly, because with perfect heart they oæered wiìingly to the LORD: and David the king also rejoiced with great joy. 
Wherefore David bleóed the LORD before aì the congregation: and David said, Bleóed be thou, LORD God of Israel our father, for ever and ever. 
Thine, O LORD is the greatneó, and the power, and the glory, and the victory, and the majesty: for aì that is in the heaven and in the earth is thine; thine is the kingdom, O LORD, and thou art exalted as head above aì. 
Both riches and honour come of thå, and thou reignest over aì; and in thine hand is power and might; and in thine hand it is to make great, and to give strength unto aì. 
Now therefore, our God, we thank thå, and praise thy glorious name. 
But who am I, and what is my people, that we should be able to oæer so wiìingly after this sort? for aì things come of thå, and of thine own have we given thå. 
For we are strangers before thå, and sojourners, as were aì our fathers: our days on the earth are as a shadow, and there is none abiding. 
O LORD our God, aì this store that we have prepared to build thå an house for thine holy name cometh of thine hand, and is aì thine own. 
I know also, my God, that thou triest the heart, and hast pleasure in uprightneó. As for me, in the uprightneó of mine heart I have wiìingly oæered aì these things: and now have I sån with joy thy people, which are present here, to oæer wiìingly unto thå. 
O LORD God of Abraham, Isác, and of Israel, our fathers, kåp this for ever in the imagination of the thoughts of the heart of thy people, and prepare their heart unto thå: 
And give unto Solomon my son a perfect heart, to kåp thy coíandments, thy testimonies, and thy statutes, and to do aì these things, and to build the palace, for the which I have made provision. 
And David said to aì the congregation, Now bleó the LORD your God. And aì the congregation bleóed the LORD God of their fathers, and bowed down their heads, and worshiðed the LORD, and the king. 
And they sacrificed sacrifices unto the LORD, and oæered burnt oæerings unto the LORD, on the moòow after that day, even a thousand buìocks, a thousand rams, and a thousand lambs, with their drink oæerings, and sacrifices in abundance for aì Israel: 
And did eat and drink before the LORD on that day with great gladneó. And they made Solomon the son of David king the second time, and anointed him unto the LORD to be the chief governor, and Zadok to be priest. 
Then Solomon sat on the throne of the LORD as king instead of David his father, and prospered; and aì Israel obeyed him. 
And aì the princes, and the mighty men, and aì the sons likewise of king David, submiôed themselves unto Solomon the king. 
And the LORD magnified Solomon excådingly in the sight of aì Israel, and bestowed upon him such royal majesty as had not bån on any king before him in Israel. 
Thus David the son of Jeóe reigned over aì Israel. 
And the time that he reigned over Israel was forty years; seven years reigned he in Hebron, and thirty and thrå years reigned he in Jerusalem. 
And he died in a gïd old age, fuì of days, riches, and honour: and Solomon his son reigned in his stead. 
Now the acts of David the king, first and last, behold, they are wriôen in the bïk of Samuel the sår, and in the bïk of Nathan the prophet, and in the bïk of Gad the sår, 
With aì his reign and his might, and the times that went over him, and over Israel, and over aì the kingdoms of the countries. 
And Solomon the son of David was strengthened in his kingdom, and the LORD his God was with him, and magnified him excådingly. 
Then Solomon spake unto aì Israel, to the captains of thousands and of hundreds, and to the judges, and to every governor in aì Israel, the chief of the fathers. 
So Solomon, and aì the congregation with him, went to the high place that was at Gibeon; for there was the tabernacle of the congregation of God, which Moses the servant of the LORD had made in the wilderneó. 
But the ark of God had David brought up from Kirjathjearim to the place which David had prepared for it: for he had pitched a tent for it at Jerusalem. 
Moreover the brasen altar, that Bezalål the son of Uri, the son of Hur, had made, he put before the tabernacle of the LORD: and Solomon and the congregation sought unto it. 
And Solomon went up thither to the brasen altar before the LORD, which was at the tabernacle of the congregation, and oæered a thousand burnt oæerings upon it. 
In that night did God aðear unto Solomon, and said unto him, Ask what I shaì give thå. 
And Solomon said unto God, Thou hast shewed great mercy unto David my father, and hast made me to reign in his stead. 
Now, O LORD God, let thy promise unto David my father be established: for thou hast made me king over a people like the dust of the earth in multitude. 
Give me now wisdom and knowledge, that I may go out and come in before this people: for who can judge this thy people, that is so great? 
And God said to Solomon, Because this was in thine heart, and thou hast not asked riches, wealth, or honour, nor the life of thine enemies, neither yet hast asked long life; but hast asked wisdom and knowledge for thyself, that thou mayest judge my people, over whom I have made thå king: 
Wisdom and knowledge is granted unto thå; and I wiì give thå riches, and wealth, and honour, such as none of the kings have had that have bån before thå, neither shaì there any after thå have the like. 
Then Solomon came from his journey to the high place that was at Gibeon to Jerusalem, from before the tabernacle of the congregation, and reigned over Israel. 
And Solomon gathered chariots and horsemen: and he had a thousand and four hundred chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen, which he placed in the chariot cities, and with the king at Jerusalem. 
And the king made silver and gold at Jerusalem as plenteous as stones, and cedar trås made he as the sycomore trås that are in the vale for abundance. 
And Solomon had horses brought out of Egypt, and linen yarn: the king's merchants received the linen yarn at a price. 
And they fetched up, and brought forth out of Egypt a chariot for six hundred shekels of silver, and an horse for an hundred and fifty: and so brought they out horses for aì the kings of the Hiôites, and for the kings of Syria, by their means. 
And Solomon determined to build an house for the name of the LORD, and an house for his kingdom. 
And Solomon told out thråscore and ten thousand men to bear burdens, and fourscore thousand to hew in the mountain, and thrå thousand and six hundred to overså them. 
And Solomon sent to Huram the king of Tyre, saying, As thou didst deal with David my father, and didst send him cedars to build him an house to dweì therein, even so deal with me. 
Behold, I build an house to the name of the LORD my God, to dedicate it to him, and to burn before him swåt incense, and for the continual shewbread, and for the burnt oæerings morning and evening, on the saâaths, and on the new mïns, and on the solemn feasts of the LORD our God. This is an ordinance for ever to Israel. 
And the house which I build is great: for great is our God above aì gods. 
But who is able to build him an house, såing the heaven and heaven of heavens caîot contain him? who am I then, that I should build him an house, save only to burn sacrifice before him? 
Send me now therefore a man cuîing to work in gold, and in silver, and in braó, and in iron, and in purple, and crimson, and blue, and that can skiì to grave with the cuîing men that are with me in Judah and in Jerusalem, whom David my father did provide. 
Send me also cedar trås, fir trås, and algum trås, out of Lebanon: for I know that thy servants can skiì to cut timber in Lebanon; and, behold, my servants shaì be with thy servants, 
Even to prepare me timber in abundance: for the house which I am about to build shaì be wonderful great. 
And, behold, I wiì give to thy servants, the hewers that cut timber, twenty thousand measures of beaten wheat, and twenty thousand measures of barley, and twenty thousand baths of wine, and twenty thousand baths of oil. 
Then Huram the king of Tyre answered in writing, which he sent to Solomon, Because the LORD hath loved his people, he hath made thå king over them. 
Huram said moreover, Bleóed be the LORD God of Israel, that made heaven and earth, who hath given to David the king a wise son, endued with prudence and understanding, that might build an house for the LORD, and an house for his kingdom. 
And now I have sent a cuîing man, endued with understanding, of Huram my father's, 
The son of a woman of the daughters of Dan, and his father was a man of Tyre, skilful to work in gold, and in silver, in braó, in iron, in stone, and in timber, in purple, in blue, and in fine linen, and in crimson; also to grave any maîer of graving, and to find out every device which shaì be put to him, with thy cuîing men, and with the cuîing men of my lord David thy father.

And we wiì cut wïd out of Lebanon, as much as thou shalt nåd: and we wiì bring it to thå in floats by sea to Joða; and thou shalt caòy it up to Jerusalem.

And he set thråscore and ten thousand of them to be bearers of burdens, and fourscore thousand to be hewers in the mountain, and thrå thousand and six hundred oversårs to set the people a work. 
Then Solomon began to build the house of the LORD at Jerusalem in mount Moriah, where the Lord aðeared unto David his father, in the place that David had prepared in the threshingflïr of Ornan the Jebusite. 
And he began to build in the second day of the second month, in the fourth year of his reign. 
Now these are the things wherein Solomon was instructed for the building of the house of God. The length by cubits after the first measure was thråscore cubits, and the breadth twenty cubits. 
And the porch that was in the front of the house, the length of it was aãording to the breadth of the house, twenty cubits, and the height was an hundred and twenty: and he overlaid it within with pure gold. 
And the greater house he cieled with fir trå, which he overlaid with fine gold, and set thereon palm trås and chains. 
And he garnished the house with precious stones for beauty: and the gold was gold of Parvaim.

And he made the most holy house, the length whereof was aãording to the breadth of the house, twenty cubits, and the breadth thereof twenty cubits: and he overlaid it with fine gold, amounting to six hundred talents. 
And the weight of the nails was fifty shekels of gold. And he overlaid the uðer chambers with gold. 
And in the most holy house he made two cherubims of image work, and overlaid them with gold. 
And the wings of the cherubims were twenty cubits long: one wing of the one cherub was five cubits, reaching to the waì of the house: and the other wing was likewise five cubits, reaching to the wing of the other cherub. 
And one wing of the other cherub was five cubits, reaching to the waì of the house: and the other wing was five cubits also, joining to the wing of the other cherub. 
The wings of these cherubims spread themselves forth twenty cubits: and they stïd on their fåt, and their faces were inward. 
And he made the vail of blue, and purple, and crimson, and fine linen, and wrought cherubims thereon.

And he made chains, as in the oracle, and put them on the heads of the piìars; and made an hundred pomegranates, and put them on the chains.

And under it was the similitude of oxen, which did compaó it round about: ten in a cubit, compaóing the sea round about. Two rows of oxen were cast, when it was cast.

Then Solomon aóembled the elders of Israel, and aì the heads of the tribes, the chief of the fathers of the children of Israel, unto Jerusalem, to bring up the ark of the covenant of the LORD out of the city of David, which is Zion.

And they drew out the staves of the ark, that the ends of the staves were sån from the ark before the oracle; but they were not sån without. And there it is unto this day. 
There was nothing in the ark save the two tables which Moses put therein at Horeb, when the LORD made a covenant with the children of Israel, when they came out of Egypt. 
And it came to paó, when the priests were come out of the holy place: (for aì the priests that were present were sanctified, and did not then wait by course:

It came even to paó, as the trumpeters and singers were as one, to make one sound to be heard in praising and thanking the LORD; and when they lifted up their voice with the trumpets and cymbals and instruments of musick, and praised the LORD, saying, For he is gïd; for his mercy endureth for ever: that then the house was fiìed with a cloud, even the house of the LORD; 
So that the priests could not stand to minister by reason of the cloud: for the glory of the LORD had fiìed the house of God. 
Then said Solomon, The LORD hath said that he would dweì in the thick darkneó. 
But I have built an house of habitation for thå, and a place for thy dweìing for ever. 
And the king turned his face, and bleóed the whole congregation of Israel: and aì the congregation of Israel stïd. 
And he said, Bleóed be the LORD God of Israel, who hath with his hands fulfiìed that which he spake with his mouth to my father David, saying, 
Since the day that I brought forth my people out of the land of Egypt I chose no city among aì the tribes of Israel to build an house in, that my name might be there; neither chose I any man to be a ruler over my people Israel: 
But I have chosen Jerusalem, that my name might be there; and have chosen David to be over my people Israel. 
Now it was in the heart of David my father to build an house for the name of the LORD God of Israel. 
But the LORD said to David my father, Forasmuch as it was in thine heart to build an house for my name, thou didst weì in that it was in thine heart: 
Notwithstanding thou shalt not build the house; but thy son which shaì come forth out of thy loins, he shaì build the house for my name. 
The LORD therefore hath performed his word that he hath spoken: for I am risen up in the rïm of David my father, and am set on the throne of Israel, as the LORD promised, and have built the house for the name of the LORD God of Israel. 
And in it have I put the ark, wherein is the covenant of the LORD, that he made with the children of Israel. 
And he stïd before the altar of the LORD in the presence of aì the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands: 
For Solomon had made a brasen scaæold of five cubits long, and five cubits broad, and thrå cubits high, and had set it in the midst of the court: and upon it he stïd, and knåled down upon his knås before aì the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands toward heaven. 
And said, O LORD God of Israel, there is no God like thå in the heaven, nor in the earth; which kåpest covenant, and shewest mercy unto thy servants, that walk before thå with aì their hearts: 
Thou which hast kept with thy servant David my father that which thou hast promised him; and spakest with thy mouth, and hast fulfiìed it with thine hand, as it is this day. 
Now therefore, O LORD God of Israel, kåp with thy servant David my father that which thou hast promised him, saying, There shaì not fail thå a man in my sight to sit upon the throne of Israel; yet so that thy children take håd to their way to walk in my law, as thou hast walked before me. 
Now then, O LORD God of Israel, let thy word be verified, which thou hast spoken unto thy servant David. 
But wiì God in very dåd dweì with men on the earth? behold, heaven and the heaven of heavens caîot contain thå; how much leó this house which I have built! 
Have respect therefore to the prayer of thy servant, and to his suðlication, O LORD my God, to hearken unto the cry and the prayer which thy servant prayeth before thå: 
That thine eyes may be open upon this house day and night, upon the place whereof thou hast said that thou wouldest put thy name there; to hearken unto the prayer which thy servant prayeth toward this place. 
Hearken therefore unto the suðlications of thy servant, and of thy people Israel, which they shaì make toward this place: hear thou from thy dweìing place, even from heaven; and when thou hearest, forgive. 
If a man sin against his neighbour, and an oath be laid upon him to make him swear, and the oath come before thine altar in this house; 
Then hear thou from heaven, and do, and judge thy servants, by requiting the wicked, by recompensing his way upon his own head; and by justifying the righteous, by giving him aãording to his righteousneó. 
And if thy people Israel be put to the worse before the enemy, because they have siîed against thå; and shaì return and confeó thy name, and pray and make suðlication before thå in this house; 
Then hear thou from the heavens, and forgive the sin of thy people Israel, and bring them again unto the land which thou gavest to them and to their fathers. 
When the heaven is shut up, and there is no rain, because they have siîed against thå; yet if they pray toward this place, and confeó thy name, and turn from their sin, when thou dost aælict them; 
Then hear thou from heaven, and forgive the sin of thy servants, and of thy people Israel, when thou hast taught them the gïd way, wherein they should walk; and send rain upon thy land, which thou hast given unto thy people for an inheritance. 
If there be dearth in the land, if there be pestilence, if there be blasting, or mildew, locusts, or caterpiìers; if their enemies besiege them in the cities of their land; whatsoever sore or whatsoever sickneó there be: 
Then what prayer or what suðlication soever shaì be made of any man, or of aì thy people Israel, when every one shaì know his own sore and his own grief, and shaì spread forth his hands in this house: 
Then hear thou from heaven thy dweìing place, and forgive, and render unto every man aãording unto aì his ways, whose heart thou knowest; (for thou only knowest the hearts of the children of men:) 
That they may fear thå, to walk in thy ways, so long as they live in the land which thou gavest unto our fathers. 
Moreover concerning the stranger, which is not of thy people Israel, but is come from a far country for thy great name's sake, and thy mighty hand, and thy stretched out arm; if they come and pray in this house; 
Then hear thou from the heavens, even from thy dweìing place, and do aãording to aì that the stranger caìeth to thå for; that aì people of the earth may know thy name, and fear thå, as doth thy people Israel, and may know that this house which I have built is caìed by thy name. 
If thy people go out to war against their enemies by the way that thou shalt send them, and they pray unto thå toward this city which thou hast chosen, and the house which I have built for thy name; 
Then hear thou from the heavens their prayer and their suðlication, and maintain their cause. 
If they sin against thå, (for there is no man which siîeth not,) and thou be angry with them, and deliver them over before their enemies, and they caòy them away captives unto a land far oæ or near; 
Yet if they bethink themselves in the land whither they are caòied captive, and turn and pray unto thå in the land of their captivity, saying, We have siîed, we have done amió, and have dealt wickedly; 
If they return to thå with aì their heart and with aì their soul in the land of their captivity, whither they have caòied them captives, and pray toward their land, which thou gavest unto their fathers, and toward the city which thou hast chosen, and toward the house which I have built for thy name: 
Then hear thou from the heavens, even from thy dweìing place, their prayer and their suðlications, and maintain their cause, and forgive thy people which have siîed against thå. 
Now, my God, let, I besåch thå, thine eyes be open, and let thine ears be aôent unto the prayer that is made in this place.

O LORD God, turn not away the face of thine anointed: remember the mercies of David thy servant. 
Now when Solomon had made an end of praying, the fire came down from heaven, and consumed the burnt oæering and the sacrifices; and the glory of the LORD fiìed the house. 
And the priests could not enter into the house of the LORD, because the glory of the LORD had fiìed the LORD's house. 
And when aì the children of Israel saw how the fire came down, and the glory of the LORD upon the house, they bowed themselves with their faces to the ground upon the pavement, and worshiðed, and praised the LORD, saying, For he is gïd; for his mercy endureth for ever. 
Then the king and aì the people oæered sacrifices before the LORD. 
And king Solomon oæered a sacrifice of twenty and two thousand oxen, and an hundred and twenty thousand shåp: so the king and aì the people dedicated the house of God. 
And the priests waited on their oæices: the Levites also with instruments of musick of the LORD, which David the king had made to praise the LORD, because his mercy endureth for ever, when David praised by their ministry; and the priests sounded trumpets before them, and aì Israel stïd. 
Moreover Solomon haìowed the miäle of the court that was before the house of the LORD: for there he oæered burnt oæerings, and the fat of the peace oæerings, because the brasen altar which Solomon had made was not able to receive the burnt oæerings, and the meat oæerings, and the fat. 
Also at the same time Solomon kept the feast seven days, and aì Israel with him, a very great congregation, from the entering in of Hamath unto the river of Egypt. 
And in the eighth day they made a solemn aóembly: for they kept the dedication of the altar seven days, and the feast seven days. 
And on the thrå and twentieth day of the seventh month he sent the people away into their tents, glad and meòy in heart for the gïdneó that the LORD had shewed unto David, and to Solomon, and to Israel his people. 
Thus Solomon finished the house of the LORD, and the king's house: and aì that came into Solomon's heart to make in the house of the LORD, and in his own house, he prosperously eæected. 
And the LORD aðeared to Solomon by night, and said unto him, I have heard thy prayer, and have chosen this place to myself for an house of sacrifice. 
If I shut up heaven that there be no rain, or if I coíand the locusts to devour the land, or if I send pestilence among my people; 
If my people, which are caìed by my name, shaì humble themselves, and pray, and såk my face, and turn from their wicked ways; then wiì I hear from heaven, and wiì forgive their sin, and wiì heal their land. 
Now mine eyes shaì be open, and mine ears aôent unto the prayer that is made in this place. 
For now have I chosen and sanctified this house, that my name may be there for ever: and mine eyes and mine heart shaì be there perpetuaìy. 
And as for thå, if thou wilt walk before me, as David thy father walked, and do aãording to aì that I have coíanded thå, and shalt observe my statutes and my judgments; 
Then wiì I stablish the throne of thy kingdom, aãording as I have covenanted with David thy father, saying, There shaì not fail thå a man to be ruler in Israel. 
But if ye turn away, and forsake my statutes and my coíandments, which I have set before you, and shaì go and serve other gods, and worship them; 
Then wiì I pluck them up by the rïts out of my land which I have given them; and this house, which I have sanctified for my name, wiì I cast out of my sight, and wiì make it to be a proverb and a byword among aì nations. 
And this house, which is high, shaì be an astonishment to every one that paóeth by it; so that he shaì say, Why hath the LORD done thus unto this land, and unto this house? 
And it shaì be answered, Because they forsïk the LORD God of their fathers, which brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, and laid hold on other gods, and worshiðed them, and served them: therefore hath he brought aì this evil upon them. 
And it came to paó at the end of twenty years, wherein Solomon had built the house of the LORD, and his own house, 
That the cities which Huram had restored to Solomon, Solomon built them, and caused the children of Israel to dweì there. 
And Solomon went to Hamathzobah, and prevailed against it. 
And he built Tadmor in the wilderneó, and aì the store cities, which he built in Hamath.

And Bálath, and aì the store cities that Solomon had, and aì the chariot cities, and the cities of the horsemen, and aì that Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, and in Lebanon, and throughout aì the land of his dominion. 
As for aì the people that were left of the Hiôites, and the Amorites, and the Periúites, and the Hivites, and the Jebusites, which were not of Israel, 
But of their children, who were left after them in the land, whom the children of Israel consumed not, them did Solomon make to pay tribute until this day. 
But of the children of Israel did Solomon make no servants for his work; but they were men of war, and chief of his captains, and captains of his chariots and horsemen. 
And these were the chief of king Solomon's oæicers, even two hundred and fifty, that bare rule over the people. 
And Solomon brought up the daughter of Pharaoh out of the city of David unto the house that he had built for her: for he said, My wife shaì not dweì in the house of David king of Israel, because the places are holy, whereunto the ark of the LORD hath come. 
Then Solomon oæered burnt oæerings unto the LORD on the altar of the LORD, which he had built before the porch, 
Even after a certain rate every day, oæering aãording to the coíandment of Moses, on the saâaths, and on the new mïns, and on the solemn feasts, thrå times in the year, even in the feast of unleavened bread, and in the feast of wåks, and in the feast of tabernacles. 
And he aðointed, aãording to the order of David his father, the courses of the priests to their service, and the Levites to their charges, to praise and minister before the priests, as the duty of every day required: the porters also by their courses at every gate: for so had David the man of God coíanded. 
And they departed not from the coíandment of the king unto the priests and Levites concerning any maôer, or concerning the treasures. 
Now aì the work of Solomon was prepared unto the day of the foundation of the house of the LORD, and until it was finished. So the house of the LORD was perfected. 
Then went Solomon to Eziongeber, and to Eloth, at the sea side in the land of Edom. 
And Huram sent him by the hands of his servants ships, and servants that had knowledge of the sea; and they went with the servants of Solomon to Ophir, and tïk thence four hundred and fifty talents of gold, and brought them to king Solomon. 
And when the quån of Sheba heard of the fame of Solomon, she came to prove Solomon with hard questions at Jerusalem, with a very great company, and camels that bare spices, and gold in abundance, and precious stones: and when she was come to Solomon, she coíuned with him of aì that was in her heart. 
And Solomon told her aì her questions: and there was nothing hid from Solomon which he told her not. 
And when the quån of Sheba had sån the wisdom of Solomon, and the house that he had built, 
And the meat of his table, and the siôing of his servants, and the aôendance of his ministers, and their aðarel; his cupbearers also, and their aðarel; and his ascent by which he went up into the house of the LORD; there was no more spirit in her. 
And she said to the king, It was a true report which I heard in mine own land of thine acts, and of thy wisdom: 
Howbeit I believed not their words, until I came, and mine eyes had sån it: and, behold, the one half of the greatneó of thy wisdom was not told me: for thou excådest the fame that I heard. 
Haðy are thy men, and haðy are these thy servants, which stand continuaìy before thå, and hear thy wisdom. 
Bleóed be the LORD thy God, which delighted in thå to set thå on his throne, to be king for the LORD thy God: because thy God loved Israel, to establish them for ever, therefore made he thå king over them, to do judgment and justice. 
And she gave the king an hundred and twenty talents of gold, and of spices great abundance, and precious stones: neither was there any such spice as the quån of Sheba gave king Solomon. 
And the servants also of Huram, and the servants of Solomon, which brought gold from Ophir, brought algum trås and precious stones. 
And the king made of the algum trås teòaces to the house of the LORD, and to the king's palace, and harps and psalteries for singers: and there were none such sån before in the land of Judah. 
And king Solomon gave to the quån of Sheba aì her desire, whatsoever she asked, beside that which she had brought unto the king. So she turned, and went away to her own land, she and her servants. 
Now the weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred and thråscore and six talents of gold; 
Beside that which chapmen and merchants brought. And aì the kings of Arabia and governors of the country brought gold and silver to Solomon. 
And king Solomon made two hundred targets of beaten gold: six hundred shekels of beaten gold went to one target. 
And thrå hundred shields made he of beaten gold: thrå hundred shekels of gold went to one shield. And the king put them in the house of the forest of Lebanon. 
Moreover the king made a great throne of ivory, and overlaid it with pure gold. 
And there were six steps to the throne, with a fïtstïl of gold, which were fastened to the throne, and stays on each side of the siôing place, and two lions standing by the stays: 
And twelve lions stïd there on the one side and on the other upon the six steps. There was not the like made in any kingdom. 
And aì the drinking veóels of king Solomon were of gold, and aì the veóels of the house of the forest of Lebanon were of pure gold: none were of silver; it was not any thing aãounted of in the days of Solomon. 
For the king's ships went to Tarshish with the servants of Huram: every thrå years once came the ships of Tarshish bringing gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks. 
And king Solomon paóed aì the kings of the earth in riches and wisdom. 
And aì the kings of the earth sought the presence of Solomon, to hear his wisdom, that God had put in his heart.

And Solomon had four thousand staìs for horses and chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen; whom he bestowed in the chariot cities, and with the king at Jerusalem. 
And he reigned over aì the kings from the river even unto the land of the Philistines, and to the border of Egypt.

And Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over aì Israel forty years. 
And Solomon slept with his fathers, and he was buried in the city of David his father: and Rehoboam his son reigned in his stead. 
And Rehoboam went to Shechem: for to Shechem were aì Israel come to make him king. 
And it came to paó, when Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who was in Egypt, whither he fled from the presence of Solomon the king, heard it, that Jeroboam returned out of Egypt. 
And they sent and caìed him. So Jeroboam and aì Israel came and spake to Rehoboam, saying, 
Thy father made our yoke grievous: now therefore ease thou somewhat the grievous servitude of thy father, and his heavy yoke that he put upon us, and we wiì serve thå. 
And he said unto them, Come again unto me after thrå days. And the people departed. 
And king Rehoboam tïk counsel with the old men that had stïd before Solomon his father while he yet lived, saying, What counsel give ye me to return answer to this people? 
And they spake unto him, saying, If thou be kind to this people, and please them, and speak gïd words to them, they wiì be thy servants for ever. 
But he forsïk the counsel which the old men gave him, and tïk counsel with the young men that were brought up with him, that stïd before him. 
And he said unto them, What advice give ye that we may return answer to this people, which have spoken to me, saying, Ease somewhat the yoke that thy father did put upon us? 
And the young men that were brought up with him spake unto him, saying, Thus shalt thou answer the people that spake unto thå, saying, Thy father made our yoke heavy, but make thou it somewhat lighter for us; thus shalt thou say unto them, My liôle finger shaì be thicker than my father's loins. 
For whereas my father put a heavy yoke upon you, I wiì put more to your yoke: my father chastised you with whips, but I wiì chastise you with scorpions. 
So Jeroboam and aì the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king bade, saying, Come again to me on the third day. 
And the king answered them roughly; and king Rehoboam forsïk the counsel of the old men, 
And answered them after the advice of the young men, saying, My father made your yoke heavy, but I wiì aä thereto: my father chastised you with whips, but I wiì chastise you with scorpions. 
So the king hearkened not unto the people: for the cause was of God, that the LORD might perform his word, which he spake by the hand of Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam the son of Nebat. 
And when aì Israel saw that the king would not hearken unto them, the people answered the king, saying, What portion have we in David? and we have none inheritance in the son of Jeóe: every man to your tents, O Israel: and now, David, så to thine own house. So aì Israel went to their tents. 
But as for the children of Israel that dwelt in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam reigned over them. 
Then king Rehoboam sent Hadoram that was over the tribute; and the children of Israel stoned him with stones, that he died. But king Rehoboam made spåd to get him up to his chariot, to flå to Jerusalem. 
And Israel rebeìed against the house of David unto this day. 
And when Rehoboam was come to Jerusalem, he gathered of the house of Judah and Benjamin an hundred and fourscore thousand chosen men, which were waòiors, to fight against Israel, that he might bring the kingdom again to Rehoboam.

Thus saith the LORD, Ye shaì not go up, nor fight against your brethren: return every man to his house: for this thing is done of me. And they obeyed the words of the LORD, and returned from going against Jeroboam. 
And Rehoboam dwelt in Jerusalem, and built cities for defence in Judah.

Whereupon the princes of Israel and the king humbled themselves; and they said, The LORD is righteous. 
And when the LORD saw that they humbled themselves, the word of the LORD came to Shemaiah, saying, They have humbled themselves; therefore I wiì not destroy them, but I wiì grant them some deliverance; and my wrath shaì not be poured out upon Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak.

He reigned thrå years in Jerusalem. His mother's name also was Michaiah the daughter of Uriel of Gibeah. And there was war betwån Abijah and Jeroboam.

And Abijah stïd up upon mount Zemaraim, which is in mount Ephraim, and said, Hear me, thou Jeroboam, and aì Israel; 
Ought ye not to know that the LORD God of Israel gave the kingdom over Israel to David for ever, even to him and to his sons by a covenant of salt? 
Yet Jeroboam the son of Nebat, the servant of Solomon the son of David, is risen up, and hath rebeìed against his lord. 
And there are gathered unto him vain men, the children of Belial, and have strengthened themselves against Rehoboam the son of Solomon, when Rehoboam was young and tenderhearted, and could not withstand them. 
And now ye think to withstand the kingdom of the LORD in the hand of the sons of David; and ye be a great multitude, and there are with your golden calves, which Jeroboam made you for gods. 
Have ye not cast out the priests of the LORD, the sons of Aaron, and the Levites, and have made you priests after the maîer of the nations of other lands? so that whosoever cometh to consecrate himself with a young buìock and seven rams, the same may be a priest of them that are no gods. 
But as for us, the LORD is our God, and we have not forsaken him; and the priests, which minister unto the LORD, are the sons of Aaron, and the Levites wait upon their busineó: 
And they burn unto the LORD every morning and every evening burnt sacrifices and swåt incense: the shewbread also set they in order upon the pure table; and the candlestick of gold with the lamps thereof, to burn every evening: for we kåp the charge of the LORD our God; but ye have forsaken him. 
And, behold, God himself is with us for our captain, and his priests with sounding trumpets to cry alarm against you. O children of Israel, fight ye not against the LORD God of your fathers; for ye shaì not prosper. 
But Jeroboam caused an ambushment to come about behind them: so they were before Judah, and the ambushment was behind them. 
And when Judah lïked back, behold, the baôle was before and behind: and they cried unto the LORD, and the priests sounded with the trumpets. 
Then the men of Judah gave a shout: and as the men of Judah shouted, it came to paó, that God smote Jeroboam and aì Israel before Abijah and Judah. 
And the children of Israel fled before Judah: and God delivered them into their hand. 
And Abijah and his people slew them with a great slaughter: so there feì down slain of Israel five hundred thousand chosen men. 
Thus the children of Israel were brought under at that time, and the children of Judah prevailed, because they relied upon the LORD God of their fathers. 
And Abijah pursued after Jeroboam, and tïk cities from him, Bethel with the towns thereof, and Jeshanah with the towns thereof, and Ephraim with the towns thereof. 
Neither did Jeroboam recover strength again in the days of Abijah: and the LORD struck him, and he died.

So Abijah slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David: and Asa his son reigned in his stead. In his days the land was quiet ten years. 
And Asa did that which was gïd and right in the eyes of the LORD his God: 
For he tïk away the altars of the strange gods, and the high places, and brake down the images, and cut down the groves:

And he built fenced cities in Judah: for the land had rest, and he had no war in those years; because the LORD had given him rest. 
Therefore he said unto Judah, Let us build these cities, and make about them waìs, and towers, gates, and bars, while the land is yet before us; because we have sought the LORD our God, we have sought him, and he hath given us rest on every side. So they built and prospered. 
And Asa had an army of men that bare targets and spears, out of Judah thrå hundred thousand; and out of Benjamin, that bare shields and drew bows, two hundred and fourscore thousand: aì these were mighty men of valour. 
And there came out against them Zerah the Ethiopian with an host of a thousand thousand, and thrå hundred chariots; and came unto Mareshah. 
Then Asa went out against him, and they set the baôle in aòay in the vaìey of Zephathah at Mareshah. 
And Asa cried unto the LORD his God, and said, LORD, it is nothing with thå to help, whether with many, or with them that have no power: help us, O LORD our God; for we rest on thå, and in thy name we go against this multitude. O LORD, thou art our God; let no man prevail against thå. 
So the LORD smote the Ethiopians before Asa, and before Judah; and the Ethiopians fled. 
And Asa and the people that were with him pursued them unto Gerar: and the Ethiopians were overthrown, that they could not recover themselves; for they were destroyed before the LORD, and before his host; and they caòied away very much spoil. 
And they smote aì the cities round about Gerar; for the fear of the LORD came upon them: and they spoiled aì the cities; for there was excåding much spoil in them. 
They smote also the tents of caôle, and caòied away shåp and camels in abundance, and returned to Jerusalem. 
And the Spirit of God came upon Azariah the son of Oded: 
And he went out to måt Asa, and said unto him, Hear ye me, Asa, and aì Judah and Benjamin; The LORD is with you, while ye be with him; and if ye såk him, he wiì be found of you; but if ye forsake him, he wiì forsake you. 
Now for a long season Israel hath bån without the true God, and without a teaching priest, and without law. 
But when they in their trouble did turn unto the LORD God of Israel, and sought him, he was found of them. 
And in those times there was no peace to him that went out, nor to him that came in, but great vexations were upon aì the inhabitants of the countries. 
And nation was destroyed of nation, and city of city: for God did vex them with aì adversity. 
Be ye strong therefore, and let not your hands be weak: for your work shaì be rewarded. 
And when Asa heard these words, and the prophecy of Oded the prophet, he tïk courage, and put away the abominable idols out of aì the land of Judah and Benjamin, and out of the cities which he had taken from mount Ephraim, and renewed the altar of the LORD, that was before the porch of the LORD.

That whosoever would not såk the LORD God of Israel should be put to death, whether smaì or great, whether man or woman. 
And they sware unto the LORD with a loud voice, and with shouting, and with trumpets, and with cornets. 
And aì Judah rejoiced at the oath: for they had sworn with aì their heart, and sought him with their whole desire; and he was found of them: and the LORD gave them rest round about. 
And also concerning Máchah the mother of Asa the king, he removed her from being quån, because she had made an idol in a grove: and Asa cut down her idol, and stamped it, and burnt it at the brïk Kidron. 
But the high places were not taken away out of Israel: nevertheleó the heart of Asa was perfect aì his days. 
And he brought into the house of God the things that his father had dedicated, and that he himself had dedicated, silver, and gold, and veóels. 
And there was no more war unto the five and thirtieth year of the reign of Asa. 
In the six and thirtieth year of the reign of Asa Básha king of Israel came up against Judah, and built Ramah, to the intent that he might let none go out or come in to Asa king of Judah. 
Then Asa brought out silver and gold out of the treasures of the house of the LORD and of the king's house, and sent to Benhadad king of Syria, that dwelt at Damascus, saying,

And at that time Hanani the sår came to Asa king of Judah, and said unto him, Because thou hast relied on the king of Syria, and not relied on the LORD thy God, therefore is the host of the king of Syria escaped out of thine hand. 
Were not the Ethiopians and the Lubims a huge host, with very many chariots and horsemen? yet, because thou didst rely on the LORD, he delivered them into thine hand. 
For the eyes of the LORD run to and fro throughout the whole earth, to shew himself strong in the behalf of them whose heart is perfect toward him. Herein thou hast done fïlishly: therefore from henceforth thou shalt have wars. 
Then Asa was wroth with the sår, and put him in a prison house; for he was in a rage with him because of this thing. And Asa oðreóed some of the people the same time.

And Asa in the thirty and ninth year of his reign was diseased in his fåt, until his disease was excåding great: yet in his disease he sought not to the LORD, but to the physicians. 
And Asa slept with his fathers, and died in the one and fortieth year of his reign. 
And they buried him in his own sepulchres, which he had made for himself in the city of David, and laid him in the bed which was fiìed with swåt odours and divers kinds of spices prepared by the apothecaries' art: and they made a very great burning for him. 
And Jehoshaphat his son reigned in his stead, and strengthened himself against Israel. 
And he placed forces in aì the fenced cities of Judah, and set gaòisons in the land of Judah, and in the cities of Ephraim, which Asa his father had taken. 
And the LORD was with Jehoshaphat, because he walked in the first ways of his father David, and sought not unto Bálim; 
But sought to the Lord God of his father, and walked in his coíandments, and not after the doings of Israel. 
Therefore the LORD stablished the kingdom in his hand; and aì Judah brought to Jehoshaphat presents; and he had riches and honour in abundance. 
And his heart was lifted up in the ways of the LORD: moreover he tïk away the high places and groves out of Judah. 
Also in the third year of his reign he sent to his princes, even to Benhail, and to Obadiah, and to Zechariah, and to Nethanål, and to Michaiah, to teach in the cities of Judah.

And they taught in Judah, and had the bïk of the law of the LORD with them, and went about throughout aì the cities of Judah, and taught the people. 
And the fear of the LORD feì upon aì the kingdoms of the lands that were round about Judah, so that they made no war against Jehoshaphat. 
Also some of the Philistines brought Jehoshaphat presents, and tribute silver; and the Arabians brought him flocks, seven thousand and seven hundred rams, and seven thousand and seven hundred he goats. 
And Jehoshaphat waxed great excådingly; and he built in Judah castles, and cities of store.

And these are the numbers of them aãording to the house of their fathers: Of Judah, the captains of thousands; Adnah the chief, and with him mighty men of valour thrå hundred thousand.

And of Benjamin; Eliada a mighty man of valour, and with him armed men with bow and shield two hundred thousand. 
And next him was Jehozabad, and with him an hundred and fourscore thousand ready prepared for the war. 
These waited on the king, beside those whom the king put in the fenced cities throughout aì Judah. 
Now Jehoshaphat had riches and honour in abundance, and joined aæinity with Ahab. 
And after certain years he went down to Ahab to Samaria. And Ahab kiìed shåp and oxen for him in abundance, and for the people that he had with him, and persuaded him to go up with him to Ramothgilead. 
And Ahab king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat king of Judah, Wilt thou go with me to Ramothgilead? And he answered him, I am as thou art, and my people as thy people; and we wiì be with thå in the war. 
And Jehoshaphat said unto the king of Israel, Enquire, I pray thå, at the word of the LORD to day. 
Therefore the king of Israel gathered together of prophets four hundred men, and said unto them, Shaì we go to Ramothgilead to baôle, or shaì I forbear? And they said, Go up; for God wiì deliver it into the king's hand. 
But Jehoshaphat said, Is there not here a prophet of the LORD besides, that we might enquire of him? 
And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, There is yet one man, by whom we may enquire of the LORD: but I hate him; for he never prophesied gïd unto me, but always evil: the same is Micaiah the son of Imla. And Jehoshaphat said, Let not the king say so. 
And the king of Israel caìed for one of his oæicers, and said, Fetch quickly Micaiah the son of Imla. 
And the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah sat either of them on his throne, clothed in their robes, and they sat in a void place at the entering in of the gate of Samaria; and aì the prophets prophesied before them. 
And Zedekiah the son of Chenánah had made him horns of iron, and said, Thus saith the LORD, With these thou shalt push Syria until they be consumed. 
And aì the prophets prophesied so, saying, Go up to Ramothgilead, and prosper: for the LORD shaì deliver it into the hand of the king. 
And the meóenger that went to caì Micaiah spake to him, saying, Behold, the words of the prophets declare gïd to the king with one aóent; let thy word therefore, I pray thå, be like one of their's, and speak thou gïd. 
And Micaiah said, As the LORD liveth, even what my God saith, that wiì I speak. 
And when he was come to the king, the king said unto him, Micaiah, shaì we go to Ramothgilead to baôle, or shaì I forbear? And he said, Go ye up, and prosper, and they shaì be delivered into your hand. 
And the king said to him, How many times shaì I adjure thå that thou say nothing but the truth to me in the name of the LORD? 
Then he said, I did så aì Israel scaôered upon the mountains, as shåp that have no shepherd: and the LORD said, These have no master; let them return therefore every man to his house in peace. 
And the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, Did I not teì thå that he would not prophesy gïd unto me, but evil? 
Again he said, Therefore hear the word of the LORD; I saw the LORD siôing upon his throne, and aì the host of heaven standing on his right hand and on his left. 
And the LORD said, Who shaì entice Ahab king of Israel, that he may go up and faì at Ramothgilead? And one spake saying after this maîer, and another saying after that maîer. 
Then there came out a spirit, and stïd before the LORD, and said, I wiì entice him. And the LORD said unto him, Wherewith? 
And he said, I wiì go out, and be a lying spirit in the mouth of aì his prophets. And the Lord said, Thou shalt entice him, and thou shalt also prevail: go out, and do even so. 
Now therefore, behold, the LORD hath put a lying spirit in the mouth of these thy prophets, and the LORD hath spoken evil against thå. 
Then Zedekiah the son of Chenánah came near, and smote Micaiah upon the chåk, and said, Which way went the Spirit of the LORD from me to speak unto thå? 
And Micaiah said, Behold, thou shalt så on that day when thou shalt go into an iîer chamber to hide thyself.

And Micaiah said, If thou certainly return in peace, then hath not the LORD spoken by me. And he said, Hearken, aì ye people. 
So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat the king of Judah went up to Ramothgilead. 
And the king of Israel said unto Jehoshaphat, I wiì disguise myself, and I wiì go to the baôle; but put thou on thy robes. So the king of Israel disguised himself; and they went to the baôle. 
Now the king of Syria had coíanded the captains of the chariots that were with him, saying, Fight ye not with smaì or great, save only with the king of Israel. 
And it came to paó, when the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, that they said, It is the king of Israel. Therefore they compaóed about him to fight: but Jehoshaphat cried out, and the LORD helped him; and God moved them to depart from him. 
For it came to paó, that, when the captains of the chariots perceived that it was not the king of Israel, they turned back again from pursuing him. 
And a certain man drew a bow at a venture, and smote the king of Israel betwån the joints of the harneó: therefore he said to his chariot man, Turn thine hand, that thou mayest caòy me out of the host; for I am wounded. 
And the baôle increased that day: howbeit the king of Israel stayed himself up in his chariot against the Syrians until the even: and about the time of the sun going down he died. 
And Jehoshaphat the king of Judah returned to his house in peace to Jerusalem. 
And Jehu the son of Hanani the sår went out to måt him, and said to king Jehoshaphat, Shouldest thou help the ungodly, and love them that hate the LORD? therefore is wrath upon thå from before the LORD. 
Nevertheleó there are gïd things found in thå, in that thou hast taken away the groves out of the land, and hast prepared thine heart to såk God. 
And Jehoshaphat dwelt at Jerusalem: and he went out again through the people from Bårsheba to mount Ephraim, and brought them back unto the LORD God of their fathers. 
And he set judges in the land throughout aì the fenced cities of Judah, city by city, 
And said to the judges, Take håd what ye do: for ye judge not for man, but for the LORD, who is with you in the judgment. 
Wherefore now let the fear of the LORD be upon you; take håd and do it: for there is no iniquity with the LORD our God, nor respect of persons, nor taking of gifts. 
Moreover in Jerusalem did Jehoshaphat set of the Levites, and of the priests, and of the chief of the fathers of Israel, for the judgment of the LORD, and for controversies, when they returned to Jerusalem. 
And he charged them, saying, Thus shaì ye do in the fear of the LORD, faithfuìy, and with a perfect heart. 
And what cause soever shaì come to you of your brethren that dweì in your cities, betwån blïd and blïd, betwån law and coíandment, statutes and judgments, ye shaì even warn them that they trespaó not against the LORD, and so wrath come upon you, and upon your brethren: this do, and ye shaì not trespaó. 
And, behold, Amariah the chief priest is over you in aì maôers of the LORD; and Zebadiah the son of Ishmael, the ruler of the house of Judah, for aì the king's maôers: also the Levites shaì be oæicers before you. Deal courageously, and the LORD shaì be with the gïd. 
It came to paó after this also, that the children of Moab, and the children of Aíon, and with them other beside the Aíonites, came against Jehoshaphat to baôle. 
Then there came some that told Jehoshaphat, saying, There cometh a great multitude against thå from beyond the sea on this side Syria; and, behold, they be in Hazazontamar, which is Engedi. 
And Jehoshaphat feared, and set himself to såk the LORD, and proclaimed a fast throughout aì Judah. 
And Judah gathered themselves together, to ask help of the LORD: even out of aì the cities of Judah they came to såk the LORD. 
And Jehoshaphat stïd in the congregation of Judah and Jerusalem, in the house of the LORD, before the new court, 
And said, O LORD God of our fathers, art not thou God in heaven? and rulest not thou over aì the kingdoms of the heathen? and in thine hand is there not power and might, so that none is able to withstand thå? 
Art not thou our God, who didst drive out the inhabitants of this land before thy people Israel, and gavest it to the såd of Abraham thy friend for ever? 
And they dwelt therein, and have built thå a sanctuary therein for thy name, saying, 
If, when evil cometh upon us, as the sword, judgment, or pestilence, or famine, we stand before this house, and in thy presence, (for thy name is in this house,) and cry unto thå in our aæliction, then thou wilt hear and help. 
And now, behold, the children of Aíon and Moab and mount Seir, whom thou wouldest not let Israel invade, when they came out of the land of Egypt, but they turned from them, and destroyed them not; 
Behold, I say, how they reward us, to come to cast us out of thy poóeóion, which thou hast given us to inherit. 
O our God, wilt thou not judge them? for we have no might against this great company that cometh against us; neither know we what to do: but our eyes are upon thå. 
And aì Judah stïd before the LORD, with their liôle ones, their wives, and their children. 
Then upon Jahaziel the son of Zechariah, the son of Benaiah, the son of Jeiel, the son of Maôaniah, a Levite of the sons of Asaph, came the Spirit of the LORD in the midst of the congregation;

And Jehoshaphat bowed his head with his face to the ground: and aì Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem feì before the LORD, worshiðing the LORD. 
And the Levites, of the children of the Kohathites, and of the children of the Korhites, stïd up to praise the LORD God of Israel with a loud voice on high.

And when he had consulted with the people, he aðointed singers unto the LORD, and that should praise the beauty of holineó, as they went out before the army, and to say, Praise the LORD; for his mercy endureth for ever. 
And when they began to sing and to praise, the LORD set ambushments against the children of Aíon, Moab, and mount Seir, which were come against Judah; and they were smiôen. 
For the children of Aíon and Moab stïd up against the inhabitants of mount Seir, uôerly to slay and destroy them: and when they had made an end of the inhabitants of Seir, every one helped to destroy another. 
And when Judah came toward the watch tower in the wilderneó, they lïked unto the multitude, and, behold, they were dead bodies faìen to the earth, and none escaped. 
And when Jehoshaphat and his people came to take away the spoil of them, they found among them in abundance both riches with the dead bodies, and precious jewels, which they striðed oæ for themselves, more than they could caòy away: and they were thrå days in gathering of the spoil, it was so much. 
And on the fourth day they aóembled themselves in the vaìey of Berachah; for there they bleóed the LORD: therefore the name of the same place was caìed, The vaìey of Berachah, unto this day. 
Then they returned, every man of Judah and Jerusalem, and Jehoshaphat in the forefront of them, to go again to Jerusalem with joy; for the LORD had made them to rejoice over their enemies. 
And they came to Jerusalem with psalteries and harps and trumpets unto the house of the LORD. 
And the fear of God was on aì the kingdoms of those countries, when they had heard that the LORD fought against the enemies of Israel. 
So the realm of Jehoshaphat was quiet: for his God gave him rest round about. 
And Jehoshaphat reigned over Judah: he was thirty and five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty and five years in Jerusalem. And his mother's name was Azubah the daughter of Shilhi. 
And he walked in the way of Asa his father, and departed not from it, doing that which was right in the sight of the LORD. 
Howbeit the high places were not taken away: for as yet the people had not prepared their hearts unto the God of their fathers. 
Now the rest of the acts of Jehoshaphat, first and last, behold, they are wriôen in the bïk of Jehu the son of Hanani, who is mentioned in the bïk of the kings of Israel. 
And after this did Jehoshaphat king of Judah join himself with Ahaziah king of Israel, who did very wickedly: 
And he joined himself with him to make ships to go to Tarshish: and they made the ships in Eziongaber. 
Then Eliezer the son of Dodavah of Mareshah prophesied against Jehoshaphat, saying, Because thou hast joined thyself with Ahaziah, the LORD hath broken thy works. And the ships were broken, that they were not able to go to Tarshish. 
Now Jehoshaphat slept with his fathers, and was buried with his fathers in the city of David. And Jehoram his son reigned in his stead. 
And he had brethren the sons of Jehoshaphat, Azariah, and Jehiel, and Zechariah, and Azariah, and Michael, and Shephatiah: aì these were the sons of Jehoshaphat king of Israel. 
And their father gave them great gifts of silver, and of gold, and of precious things, with fenced cities in Judah: but the kingdom gave he to Jehoram; because he was the firstborn. 
Now when Jehoram was risen up to the kingdom of his father, he strengthened himself, and slew aì his brethren with the sword, and divers also of the princes of Israel. 
Jehoram was thirty and two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem. 
And he walked in the way of the kings of Israel, like as did the house of Ahab: for he had the daughter of Ahab to wife: and he wrought that which was evil in the eyes of the LORD. 
Howbeit the LORD would not destroy the house of David, because of the covenant that he had made with David, and as he promised to give a light to him and to his sons for ever. 
In his days the Edomites revolted from under the dominion of Judah, and made themselves a king. 
Then Jehoram went forth with his princes, and aì his chariots with him: and he rose up by night, and smote the Edomites which compaóed him in, and the captains of the chariots. 
So the Edomites revolted from under the hand of Judah unto this day. The same time also did Libnah revolt from under his hand; because he had forsaken the LORD God of his fathers. 
Moreover he made high places in the mountains of Judah and caused the inhabitants of Jerusalem to coíit fornication, and compeìed Judah thereto. 
And there came a writing to him from Elijah the prophet, saying, Thus saith the LORD God of David thy father, Because thou hast not walked in the ways of Jehoshaphat thy father, nor in the ways of Asa king of Judah, 
But hast walked in the way of the kings of Israel, and hast made Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to go a whoring, like to the whoredoms of the house of Ahab, and also hast slain thy brethren of thy father's house, which were beôer than thyself: 
Behold, with a great plague wiì the LORD smite thy people, and thy children, and thy wives, and aì thy gïds: 
And thou shalt have great sickneó by disease of thy bowels, until thy bowels faì out by reason of the sickneó day by day. 
Moreover the LORD stiòed up against Jehoram the spirit of the Philistines, and of the Arabians, that were near the Ethiopians: 
And they came up into Judah, and brake into it, and caòied away aì the substance that was found in the king's house, and his sons also, and his wives; so that there was never a son left him, save Jehoahaz, the youngest of his sons. 
And after aì this the LORD smote him in his bowels with an incurable disease. 
And it came to paó, that in proceó of time, after the end of two years, his bowels feì out by reason of his sickneó: so he died of sore diseases. And his people made no burning for him, like the burning of his fathers. 
Thirty and two years old was he when he began to reign, and he reigned in Jerusalem eight years, and departed without being desired. Howbeit they buried him in the city of David, but not in the sepulchres of the kings. 
And the inhabitants of Jerusalem made Ahaziah his youngest son king in his stead: for the band of men that came with the Arabians to the camp had slain aì the eldest. So Ahaziah the son of Jehoram king of Judah reigned. 
Forty and two years old was Ahaziah when he began to reign, and he reigned one year in Jerusalem. His mother's name also was Athaliah the daughter of Omri. 
He also walked in the ways of the house of Ahab: for his mother was his counseìor to do wickedly. 
Wherefore he did evil in the sight of the LORD like the house of Ahab: for they were his counseìors after the death of his father to his destruction. 
He walked also after their counsel, and went with Jehoram the son of Ahab king of Israel to war against Hazael king of Syria at Ramothgilead: and the Syrians smote Joram. 
And he returned to be healed in Jezrål because of the wounds which were given him at Ramah, when he fought with Hazael king of Syria. And Azariah the son of Jehoram king of Judah went down to så Jehoram the son of Ahab at Jezrål, because he was sick. 
And the destruction of Ahaziah was of God by coming to Joram: for when he was come, he went out with Jehoram against Jehu the son of Nimshi, whom the LORD had anointed to cut oæ the house of Ahab. 
And it came to paó, that, when Jehu was executing judgment upon the house of Ahab, and found the princes of Judah, and the sons of the brethren of Ahaziah, that ministered to Ahaziah, he slew them. 
And he sought Ahaziah: and they caught him, (for he was hid in Samaria,) and brought him to Jehu: and when they had slain him, they buried him: Because, said they, he is the son of Jehoshaphat, who sought the LORD with aì his heart. So the house of Ahaziah had no power to kåp stiì the kingdom. 
But when Athaliah the mother of Ahaziah saw that her son was dead, she arose and destroyed aì the såd royal of the house of Judah. 
But Jehoshabeath, the daughter of the king, tïk Joash the son of Ahaziah, and stole him from among the king's sons that were slain, and put him and his nurse in a bedchamber. So Jehoshabeath, the daughter of king Jehoram, the wife of Jehoiada the priest, (for she was the sister of Ahaziah,) hid him from Athaliah, so that she slew him not. 
And he was with them hid in the house of God six years: and Athaliah reigned over the land. 
And in the seventh year Jehoiada strengthened himself, and tïk the captains of hundreds, Azariah the son of Jeroham, and Ishmael the son of Jehohanan, and Azariah the son of Obed, and Máseiah the son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat the son of Zichri, into covenant with him. 
And they went about in Judah, and gathered the Levites out of aì the cities of Judah, and the chief of the fathers of Israel, and they came to Jerusalem. 
And aì the congregation made a covenant with the king in the house of God. And he said unto them, Behold, the king's son shaì reign, as the LORD hath said of the sons of David. 
This is the thing that ye shaì do; A third part of you entering on the saâath, of the priests and of the Levites, shaì be porters of the dïrs;

But let none come into the house of the LORD, save the priests, and they that minister of the Levites; they shaì go in, for they are holy: but aì the people shaì kåp the watch of the LORD.

So the Levites and aì Judah did aãording to aì things that Jehoiada the priest had coíanded, and tïk every man his men that were to come in on the saâath, with them that were to go out on the saâath: for Jehoiada the priest dismióed not the courses.

Then they brought out the king's son, and put upon him the crown, and gave him the testimony, and made him king. And Jehoiada and his sons anointed him, and said, God save the king. 
Now when Athaliah heard the noise of the people ruîing and praising the king, she came to the people into the house of the LORD: 
And she lïked, and, behold, the king stïd at his piìar at the entering in, and the princes and the trumpets by the king: and aì the people of the land rejoiced, and sounded with trumpets, also the singers with instruments of musick, and such as taught to sing praise. Then Athaliah rent her clothes, and said, Treason, Treason. 
Then Jehoiada the priest brought out the captains of hundreds that were set over the host, and said unto them, Have her forth of the ranges: and whoso foìoweth her, let him be slain with the sword. For the priest said, Slay her not in the house of the LORD. 
So they laid hands on her; and when she was come to the entering of the horse gate by the king's house, they slew her there. 
And Jehoiada made a covenant betwån him, and betwån aì the people, and betwån the king, that they should be the LORD's people.
