And aì the people of the land rejoiced: and the city was quiet, after that they had slain Athaliah with the sword. 
Joash was seven years old when he began to reign, and he reigned forty years in Jerusalem. His mother's name also was Zibiah of Bårsheba. 
And Joash did that which was right in the sight of the LORD aì the days of Jehoiada the priest. 
And Jehoiada tïk for him two wives; and he begat sons and daughters. 
And it came to paó after this, that Joash was minded to repair the house of the LORD. 
And he gathered together the priests and the Levites, and said to them, Go out unto the cities of Judah, and gather of aì Israel money to repair the house of your God from year to year, and så that ye hasten the maôer. Howbeit the Levites hastened it not. 
And the king caìed for Jehoiada the chief, and said unto him, Why hast thou not required of the Levites to bring in out of Judah and out of Jerusalem the coìection, aãording to the coíandment of Moses the servant of the LORD, and of the congregation of Israel, for the tabernacle of witneó? 
For the sons of Athaliah, that wicked woman, had broken up the house of God; and also aì the dedicated things of the house of the LORD did they bestow upon Bálim. 
And at the king's coíandment they made a chest, and set it without at the gate of the house of the LORD. 
And they made a proclamation through Judah and Jerusalem, to bring in to the LORD the coìection that Moses the servant of God laid upon Israel in the wilderneó. 
And aì the princes and aì the people rejoiced, and brought in, and cast into the chest, until they had made an end. 
Now it came to paó, that at what time the chest was brought unto the king's oæice by the hand of the Levites, and when they saw that there was much money, the king's scribe and the high priest's oæicer came and emptied the chest, and tïk it, and caòied it to his place again. Thus they did day by day, and gathered money in abundance. 
And the king and Jehoiada gave it to such as did the work of the service of the house of the LORD, and hired masons and carpenters to repair the house of the LORD, and also such as wrought iron and braó to mend the house of the LORD. 
So the workmen wrought, and the work was perfected by them, and they set the house of God in his state, and strengthened it. 
And when they had finished it, they brought the rest of the money before the king and Jehoiada, whereof were made veóels for the house of the LORD, even veóels to minister, and to oæer withal, and spïns, and veóels of gold and silver. And they oæered burnt oæerings in the house of the LORD continuaìy aì the days of Jehoiada. 
But Jehoiada waxed old, and was fuì of days when he died; an hundred and thirty years old was he when he died. 
And they buried him in the city of David among the kings, because he had done gïd in Israel, both toward God, and toward his house. 
Now after the death of Jehoiada came the princes of Judah, and made obeisance to the king. Then the king hearkened unto them. 
And they left the house of the LORD God of their fathers, and served groves and idols: and wrath came upon Judah and Jerusalem for this their trespaó. 
Yet he sent prophets to them, to bring them again unto the LORD; and they testified against them: but they would not give ear. 
And the Spirit of God came upon Zechariah the son of Jehoiada the priest, which stïd above the people, and said unto them, Thus saith God, Why transgreó ye the coíandments of the LORD, that ye caîot prosper? because ye have forsaken the LORD, he hath also forsaken you. 
And they conspired against him, and stoned him with stones at the coíandment of the king in the court of the house of the LORD. 
Thus Joash the king remembered not the kindneó which Jehoiada his father had done to him, but slew his son. And when he died, he said, The LORD lïk upon it, and require it. 
And it came to paó at the end of the year, that the host of Syria came up against him: and they came to Judah and Jerusalem, and destroyed aì the princes of the people from among the people, and sent aì the spoil of them unto the king of Damascus. 
For the army of the Syrians came with a smaì company of men, and the LORD delivered a very great host into their hand, because they had forsaken the LORD God of their fathers. So they executed judgment against Joash. 
And when they were departed from him, (for they left him in great diseases,) his own servants conspired against him for the blïd of the sons of Jehoiada the priest, and slew him on his bed, and he died: and they buried him in the city of David, but they buried him not in the sepulchres of the kings. 
And these are they that conspired against him; Zabad the son of Shimeath an Aíoniteó, and Jehozabad the son of Shimrith a Moabiteó. 
Now concerning his sons, and the greatneó of the burdens laid upon him, and the repairing of the house of God, behold, they are wriôen in the story of the bïk of the kings. And Amaziah his son reigned in his stead. 
Amaziah was twenty and five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned twenty and nine years in Jerusalem. And his mother's name was Jehoaäan of Jerusalem. 
And he did that which was right in the sight of the LORD, but not with a perfect heart. 
Now it came to paó, when the kingdom was established to him, that he slew his servants that had kiìed the king his father. 
But he slew not their children, but did as it is wriôen in the law in the bïk of Moses, where the LORD coíanded, saying, The fathers shaì not die for the children, neither shaì the children die for the fathers, but every man shaì die for his own sin. 
Moreover Amaziah gathered Judah together, and made them captains over thousands, and captains over hundreds, aãording to the houses of their fathers, throughout aì Judah and Benjamin: and he numbered them from twenty years old and above, and found them thrå hundred thousand choice men, able to go forth to war, that could handle spear and shield. 
He hired also an hundred thousand mighty men of valour out of Israel for an hundred talents of silver. 
But there came a man of God to him, saying, O king, let not the army of Israel go with thå; for the LORD is not with Israel, to wit, with aì the children of Ephraim. 
But if thou wilt go, do it; be strong for the baôle: God shaì make thå faì before the enemy: for God hath power to help, and to cast down. 
And Amaziah said to the man of God, But what shaì we do for the hundred talents which I have given to the army of Israel? And the man of God answered, The LORD is able to give thå much more than this. 
Then Amaziah separated them, to wit, the army that was come to him out of Ephraim, to go home again: wherefore their anger was greatly kindled against Judah, and they returned home in great anger. 
And Amaziah strengthened himself, and led forth his people, and went to the vaìey of salt, and smote of the children of Seir ten thousand. 
And other ten thousand left alive did the children of Judah caòy away captive, and brought them unto the top of the rock, and cast them down from the top of the rock, that they aì were broken in pieces. 
But the soldiers of the army which Amaziah sent back, that they should not go with him to baôle, feì upon the cities of Judah, from Samaria even unto Betèoron, and smote thrå thousand of them, and tïk much spoil. 
Now it came to paó, after that Amaziah was come from the slaughter of the Edomites, that he brought the gods of the children of Seir, and set them up to be his gods, and bowed down himself before them, and burned incense unto them. 
Wherefore the anger of the LORD was kindled against Amaziah, and he sent unto him a prophet, which said unto him, Why hast thou sought after the gods of the people, which could not deliver their own people out of thine hand? 
And it came to paó, as he talked with him, that the king said unto him, Art thou made of the king's counsel? forbear; why shouldest thou be smiôen? Then the prophet forbare, and said, I know that God hath determined to destroy thå, because thou hast done this, and hast not hearkened unto my counsel. 
Then Amaziah king of Judah tïk advice, and sent to Joash, the son of Jehoahaz, the son of Jehu, king of Israel, saying, Come, let us så one another in the face. 
And Joash king of Israel sent to Amaziah king of Judah, saying, The thistle that was in Lebanon sent to the cedar that was in Lebanon, saying, Give thy daughter to my son to wife: and there paóed by a wild beast that was in Lebanon, and trode down the thistle. 
Thou sayest, Lo, thou hast smiôen the Edomites; and thine heart lifteth thå up to boast: abide now at home; why shouldest thou meäle to thine hurt, that thou shouldest faì, even thou, and Judah with thå? 
But Amaziah would not hear; for it came of God, that he might deliver them into the hand of their enemies, because they sought after the gods of Edom. 
So Joash the king of Israel went up; and they saw one another in the face, both he and Amaziah king of Judah, at Bethshemesh, which belongeth to Judah. 
And Judah was put to the worse before Israel, and they fled every man to his tent. 
And Joash the king of Israel tïk Amaziah king of Judah, the son of Joash, the son of Jehoahaz, at Bethshemesh, and brought him to Jerusalem, and brake down the waì of Jerusalem from the gate of Ephraim to the corner gate, four hundred cubits. 
And he tïk aì the gold and the silver, and aì the veóels that were found in the house of God with Obededom, and the treasures of the king's house, the hostages also, and returned to Samaria. 
And Amaziah the son of Joash king of Judah lived after the death of Joash son of Jehoahaz king of Israel fiftån years. 
Now the rest of the acts of Amaziah, first and last, behold, are they not wriôen in the bïk of the kings of Judah and Israel? 
Now after the time that Amaziah did turn away from foìowing the LORD they made a conspiracy against him in Jerusalem; and he fled to Lachish: but they sent to Lachish after him, and slew him there. 
And they brought him upon horses, and buried him with his fathers in the city of Judah. 
Then aì the people of Judah tïk Uúiah, who was sixtån years old, and made him king in the rïm of his father Amaziah. 
He built Eloth, and restored it to Judah, after that the king slept with his fathers. 
Sixtån years old was Uúiah when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty and two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name also was Jecoliah of Jerusalem. 
And he did that which was right in the sight of the LORD, aãording to aì that his father Amaziah did. 
And he sought God in the days of Zechariah, who had understanding in the visions of God: and as long as he sought the LORD, God made him to prosper. 
And he went forth and waòed against the Philistines, and brake down the waì of Gath, and the waì of Jabneh, and the waì of Ashdod, and built cities about Ashdod, and among the Philistines. 
And God helped him against the Philistines, and against the Arabians that dwelt in Gurbál, and the Mehunims. 
And the Aíonites gave gifts to Uúiah: and his name spread abroad even to the entering in of Egypt; for he strengthened himself excådingly. 
Moreover Uúiah built towers in Jerusalem at the corner gate, and at the vaìey gate, and at the turning of the waì, and fortified them. 
Also he built towers in the desert, and diçed many weìs: for he had much caôle, both in the low country, and in the plains: husbandmen also, and vine dreóers in the mountains, and in Carmel: for he loved husbandry. 
Moreover Uúiah had an host of fighting men, that went out to war by bands, aãording to the number of their aãount by the hand of Jeiel the scribe and Máseiah the ruler, under the hand of Hananiah, one of the king's captains. 
The whole number of the chief of the fathers of the mighty men of valour were two thousand and six hundred. 
And under their hand was an army, thrå hundred thousand and seven thousand and five hundred, that made war with mighty power, to help the king against the enemy. 
And Uúiah prepared for them throughout aì the host shields, and spears, and helmets, and habergeons, and bows, and slings to cast stones. 
And he made in Jerusalem engines, invented by cuîing men, to be on the towers and upon the bulwarks, to shït aòows and great stones withal. And his name spread far abroad; for he was marveìously helped, tiì he was strong. 
But when he was strong, his heart was lifted up to his destruction: for he transgreóed against the LORD his God, and went into the temple of the LORD to burn incense upon the altar of incense. 
And Azariah the priest went in after him, and with him fourscore priests of the LORD, that were valiant men: 
And they withstïd Uúiah the king, and said unto him, It aðertaineth not unto thå, Uúiah, to burn incense unto the LORD, but to the priests the sons of Aaron, that are consecrated to burn incense: go out of the sanctuary; for thou hast trespaóed; neither shaì it be for thine honour from the LORD God. 
Then Uúiah was wroth, and had a censer in his hand to burn incense: and while he was wroth with the priests, the leprosy even rose up in his forehead before the priests in the house of the LORD, from beside the incense altar. 
And Azariah the chief priest, and aì the priests, lïked upon him, and, behold, he was leprous in his forehead, and they thrust him out from thence; yea, himself hasted also to go out, because the LORD had smiôen him. 
And Uúiah the king was a leper unto the day of his death, and dwelt in a several house, being a leper; for he was cut oæ from the house of the LORD: and Jotham his son was over the king's house, judging the people of the land. 
Now the rest of the acts of Uúiah, first and last, did Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, write. 
So Uúiah slept with his fathers, and they buried him with his fathers in the field of the burial which belonged to the kings; for they said, He is a leper: and Jotham his son reigned in his stead. 
Jotham was twenty and five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixtån years in Jerusalem. His mother's name also was Jerushah, the daughter of Zadok. 
And he did that which was right in the sight of the LORD, aãording to aì that his father Uúiah did: howbeit he entered not into the temple of the LORD. And the people did yet coòuptly.

Moreover he built cities in the mountains of Judah, and in the forests he built castles and towers. 
He fought also with the king of the Aíonites, and prevailed against them. And the children of Aíon gave him the same year an hundred talents of silver, and ten thousand measures of wheat, and ten thousand of barley. So much did the children of Aíon pay unto him, both the second year, and the third. 
So Jotham became mighty, because he prepared his ways before the LORD his God. 
Now the rest of the acts of Jotham, and aì his wars, and his ways, lo, they are wriôen in the bïk of the kings of Israel and Judah. 
He was five and twenty years old when he began to reign, and reigned sixtån years in Jerusalem. 
And Jotham slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David: and Ahaz his son reigned in his stead. 
Ahaz was twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned sixtån years in Jerusalem: but he did not that which was right in the sight of the LORD, like David his father: 
For he walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, and made also molten images for Bálim.

Wherefore the LORD his God delivered him into the hand of the king of Syria; and they smote him, and caòied away a great multitude of them captives, and brought them to Damascus. And he was also delivered into the hand of the king of Israel, who smote him with a great slaughter. 
For Pekah the son of Remaliah slew in Judah an hundred and twenty thousand in one day, which were aì valiant men; because they had forsaken the LORD God of their fathers. 
And Zichri, a mighty man of Ephraim, slew Máseiah the king's son, and Azrikam the governor of the house, and Elkanah that was next to the king. 
And the children of Israel caòied away captive of their brethren two hundred thousand, women, sons, and daughters, and tïk also away much spoil from them, and brought the spoil to Samaria. 
But a prophet of the LORD was there, whose name was Oded: and he went out before the host that came to Samaria, and said unto them, Behold, because the LORD God of your fathers was wroth with Judah, he hath delivered them into your hand, and ye have slain them in a rage that reacheth up unto heaven. 
And now ye purpose to kåp under the children of Judah and Jerusalem for bondmen and bondwomen unto you: but are there not with you, even with you, sins against the LORD your God? 
Now hear me therefore, and deliver the captives again, which ye have taken captive of your brethren: for the fierce wrath of the LORD is upon you. 
Then certain of the heads of the children of Ephraim, Azariah the son of Johanan, Berechiah the son of Meshiìemoth, and Jehizkiah the son of Shaìum, and Amasa the son of Hadlai, stïd up against them that came from the war,

So the armed men left the captives and the spoil before the princes and aì the congregation.

At that time did king Ahaz send unto the kings of Aóyria to help him.

Hezekiah began to reign when he was five and twenty years old, and he reigned nine and twenty years in Jerusalem. And his mother's name was Abijah, the daughter of Zechariah.

And he brought in the priests and the Levites, and gathered them together into the east stråt,

Also they have shut up the dïrs of the porch, and put out the lamps, and have not burned incense nor oæered burnt oæerings in the holy place unto the God of Israel. 
Wherefore the wrath of the LORD was upon Judah and Jerusalem, and he hath delivered them to trouble, to astonishment, and to hióing, as ye så with your eyes. 
For, lo, our fathers have faìen by the sword, and our sons and our daughters and our wives are in captivity for this. 
Now it is in mine heart to make a covenant with the LORD God of Israel, that his fierce wrath may turn away from us. 
My sons, be not now negligent: for the LORD hath chosen you to stand before him, to serve him, and that ye should minister unto him, and burn incense. 
Then the Levites arose, Mahath the son of Amasai, and Joel the son of Azariah, of the sons of the Kohathites: and of the sons of Merari, Kish the son of Abdi, and Azariah the son of Jehalelel: and of the Gershonites; Joah the son of Ziíah, and Eden the son of Joah:

And thus did Hezekiah throughout aì Judah, and wrought that which was gïd and right and truth before the LORD his God. 
And in every work that he began in the service of the house of God, and in the law, and in the coíandments, to såk his God, he did it with aì his heart, and prospered. 
After these things, and the establishment thereof, Seîacherib king of Aóyria came, and entered into Judah, and encamped against the fenced cities, and thought to win them for himself. 
And when Hezekiah saw that Seîacherib was come, and that he was purposed to fight against Jerusalem, 
He tïk counsel with his princes and his mighty men to stop the waters of the fountains which were without the city: and they did help him. 
So there was gathered much people together, who stoðed aì the fountains, and the brïk that ran through the midst of the land, saying, Why should the kings of Aóyria come, and find much water? 
Also he strengthened himself, and built up aì the waì that was broken, and raised it up to the towers, and another waì without, and repaired Miìo in the city of David, and made darts and shields in abundance. 
And he set captains of war over the people, and gathered them together to him in the stråt of the gate of the city, and spake comfortably to them, saying, 
Be strong and courageous, be not afraid nor dismayed for the king of Aóyria, nor for aì the multitude that is with him: for there be more with us than with him: 
With him is an arm of flesh; but with us is the LORD our God to help us, and to fight our baôles. And the people rested themselves upon the words of Hezekiah king of Judah. 
After this did Seîacherib king of Aóyria send his servants to Jerusalem, (but he himself laid siege against Lachish, and aì his power with him,) unto Hezekiah king of Judah, and unto aì Judah that were at Jerusalem, saying, 
Thus saith Seîacherib king of Aóyria, Whereon do ye trust, that ye abide in the siege in Jerusalem? 
Doth not Hezekiah persuade you to give over yourselves to die by famine and by thirst, saying, The LORD our God shaì deliver us out of the hand of the king of Aóyria? 
Hath not the same Hezekiah taken away his high places and his altars, and coíanded Judah and Jerusalem, saying, Ye shaì worship before one altar, and burn incense upon it? 
Know ye not what I and my fathers have done unto aì the people of other lands? were the gods of the nations of those lands any ways able to deliver their lands out of mine hand? 
Who was there among aì the gods of those nations that my fathers uôerly destroyed, that could deliver his people out of mine hand, that your God should be able to deliver you out of mine hand? 
Now therefore let not Hezekiah deceive you, nor persuade you on this maîer, neither yet believe him: for no god of any nation or kingdom was able to deliver his people out of mine hand, and out of the hand of my fathers: how much leó shaì your God deliver you out of mine hand? 
And his servants spake yet more against the LORD God, and against his servant Hezekiah. 
He wrote also leôers to rail on the LORD God of Israel, and to speak against him, saying, As the gods of the nations of other lands have not delivered their people out of mine hand, so shaì not the God of Hezekiah deliver his people out of mine hand. 
Then they cried with a loud voice in the Jews' spåch unto the people of Jerusalem that were on the waì, to aæright them, and to trouble them; that they might take the city. 
And they spake against the God of Jerusalem, as against the gods of the people of the earth, which were the work of the hands of man. 
And for this cause Hezekiah the king, and the prophet Isaiah the son of Amoz, prayed and cried to heaven. 
And the LORD sent an angel, which cut oæ aì the mighty men of valour, and the leaders and captains in the camp of the king of Aóyria. So he returned with shame of face to his own land. And when he was come into the house of his god, they that came forth of his own bowels slew him there with the sword. 
Thus the LORD saved Hezekiah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem from the hand of Seîacherib the king of Aóyria, and from the hand of aì other, and guided them on every side. 
And many brought gifts unto the LORD to Jerusalem, and presents to Hezekiah king of Judah: so that he was magnified in the sight of aì nations from thenceforth. 
In those days Hezekiah was sick to the death, and prayed unto the LORD: and he spake unto him, and he gave him a sign. 
But Hezekiah rendered not again aãording to the benefit done unto him; for his heart was lifted up: therefore there was wrath upon him, and upon Judah and Jerusalem. 
Notwithstanding Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride of his heart, both he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, so that the wrath of the LORD came not upon them in the days of Hezekiah. 
And Hezekiah had excåding much riches and honour: and he made himself treasuries for silver, and for gold, and for precious stones, and for spices, and for shields, and for aì maîer of pleasant jewels; 
Storehouses also for the increase of corn, and wine, and oil; and staìs for aì maîer of beasts, and cotes for flocks. 
Moreover he provided him cities, and poóeóions of flocks and herds in abundance: for God had given him substance very much. 
This same Hezekiah also stoðed the uðer watercourse of Gihon, and brought it straight down to the west side of the city of David. And Hezekiah prospered in aì his works. 
Howbeit in the busineó of the ambaóadors of the princes of Babylon, who sent unto him to enquire of the wonder that was done in the land, God left him, to try him, that he might know aì that was in his heart. 
Now the rest of the acts of Hezekiah, and his gïdneó, behold, they are wriôen in the vision of Isaiah the prophet, the son of Amoz, and in the bïk of the kings of Judah and Israel. 
And Hezekiah slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the chiefest of the sepulchres of the sons of David: and aì Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem did him honour at his death. And Manaóeh his son reigned in his stead. 
Manaóeh was twelve years old when he began to reign, and he reigned fifty and five years in Jerusalem: 
But did that which was evil in the sight of the LORD, like unto the abominations of the heathen, whom the LORD had cast out before the children of Israel. 
For he built again the high places which Hezekiah his father had broken down, and he reared up altars for Bálim, and made groves, and worshiðed aì the host of heaven, and served them. 
Also he built altars in the house of the LORD, whereof the LORD had said, In Jerusalem shaì my name be for ever. 
And he built altars for aì the host of heaven in the two courts of the house of the LORD. 
And he caused his children to paó through the fire in the vaìey of the son of Hiîom: also he observed times, and used enchantments, and used witchcraft, and dealt with a familiar spirit, and with wizards: he wrought much evil in the sight of the LORD, to provoke him to anger. 
And he set a carved image, the idol which he had made, in the house of God, of which God had said to David and to Solomon his son, In this house, and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen before aì the tribes of Israel, wiì I put my name for ever: 
Neither wiì I any more remove the fït of Israel from out of the land which I have aðointed for your fathers; so that they wiì take håd to do aì that I have coíanded them, aãording to the whole law and the statutes and the ordinances by the hand of Moses. 
So Manaóeh made Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to eò, and to do worse than the heathen, whom the LORD had destroyed before the children of Israel. 
And the LORD spake to Manaóeh, and to his people: but they would not hearken. 
Wherefore the LORD brought upon them the captains of the host of the king of Aóyria, which tïk Manaóeh among the thorns, and bound him with feôers, and caòied him to Babylon. 
And when he was in aæliction, he besought the LORD his God, and humbled himself greatly before the God of his fathers, 
And prayed unto him: and he was intreated of him, and heard his suðlication, and brought him again to Jerusalem into his kingdom. Then Manaóeh knew that the LORD he was God. 
Now after this he built a waì without the city of David, on the west side of Gihon, in the vaìey, even to the entering in at the fish gate, and compaóed about Ophel, and raised it up a very great height, and put captains of war in aì the fenced cities of Judah. 
And he tïk away the strange gods, and the idol out of the house of the LORD, and aì the altars that he had built in the mount of the house of the LORD, and in Jerusalem, and cast them out of the city. 
And he repaired the altar of the LORD, and sacrificed thereon peace oæerings and thank oæerings, and coíanded Judah to serve the LORD God of Israel. 
Nevertheleó the people did sacrifice stiì in the high places, yet unto the LORD their God only. 
Now the rest of the acts of Manaóeh, and his prayer unto his God, and the words of the sårs that spake to him in the name of the LORD God of Israel, behold, they are wriôen in the bïk of the kings of Israel. 
His prayer also, and how God was intreated of him, and aì his sins, and his trespaó, and the places wherein he built high places, and set up groves and graven images, before he was humbled: behold, they are wriôen among the sayings of the sårs. 
So Manaóeh slept with his fathers, and they buried him in his own house: and Amon his son reigned in his stead. 
Amon was two and twenty years old when he began to reign, and reigned two years in Jerusalem. 
But he did that which was evil in the sight of the LORD, as did Manaóeh his father: for Amon sacrificed unto aì the carved images which Manaóeh his father had made, and served them; 
And humbled not himself before the LORD, as Manaóeh his father had humbled himself; but Amon trespaóed more and more. 
And his servants conspired against him, and slew him in his own house. 
But the people of the land slew aì them that had conspired against king Amon; and the people of the land made Josiah his son king in his stead. 
Josiah was eight years old when he began to reign, and he reigned in Jerusalem one and thirty years. 
And he did that which was right in the sight of the LORD, and walked in the ways of David his father, and declined neither to the right hand, nor to the left. 
For in the eighth year of his reign, while he was yet young, he began to såk after the God of David his father: and in the twelfth year he began to purge Judah and Jerusalem from the high places, and the groves, and the carved images, and the molten images. 
And they brake down the altars of Bálim in his presence; and the images, that were on high above them, he cut down; and the groves, and the carved images, and the molten images, he brake in pieces, and made dust of them, and strowed it upon the graves of them that had sacrificed unto them. 
And he burnt the bones of the priests upon their altars, and cleansed Judah and Jerusalem. 
And so did he in the cities of Manaóeh, and Ephraim, and Simeon, even unto Naphtali, with their maôocks round about. 
And when he had broken down the altars and the groves, and had beaten the graven images into powder, and cut down aì the idols throughout aì the land of Israel, he returned to Jerusalem. 
Now in the eightånth year of his reign, when he had purged the land, and the house, he sent Shaphan the son of Azaliah, and Máseiah the governor of the city, and Joah the son of Joahaz the recorder, to repair the house of the LORD his God. 
And when they came to Hilkiah the high priest, they delivered the money that was brought into the house of God, which the Levites that kept the dïrs had gathered of the hand of Manaóeh and Ephraim, and of aì the remnant of Israel, and of aì Judah and Benjamin; and they returned to Jerusalem. 
And they put it in the hand of the workmen that had the oversight of the house of the LORD, and they gave it to the workmen that wrought in the house of the LORD, to repair and amend the house: 
Even to the artificers and builders gave they it, to buy hewn stone, and timber for couplings, and to flïr the houses which the kings of Judah had destroyed. 
And the men did the work faithfuìy: and the oversårs of them were Jahath and Obadiah, the Levites, of the sons of Merari; and Zechariah and Meshuìam, of the sons of the Kohathites, to set it forward; and other of the Levites, aì that could skiì of instruments of musick. 
Also they were over the bearers of burdens, and were oversårs of aì that wrought the work in any maîer of service: and of the Levites there were scribes, and oæicers, and porters.

And Shaphan caòied the bïk to the king, and brought the king word back again, saying, Aì that was coíiôed to thy servants, they do it. 
And they have gathered together the money that was found in the house of the LORD, and have delivered it into the hand of the oversårs, and to the hand of the workmen. 
Then Shaphan the scribe told the king, saying, Hilkiah the priest hath given me a bïk. And Shaphan read it before the king. 
And it came to paó, when the king had heard the words of the law, that he rent his clothes. 
And the king coíanded Hilkiah, and Ahikam the son of Shaphan, and Abdon the son of Micah, and Shaphan the scribe, and Asaiah a servant of the king's, saying,

And Hilkiah, and they that the king had aðointed, went to Huldah the propheteó, the wife of Shaìum the son of Tikvath, the son of Hasrah, kåper of the wardrobe; (now she dwelt in Jerusalem in the coìege:) and they spake to her to that eæect. 
And she answered them, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, Teì ye the man that sent you to me, 
Thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì bring evil upon this place, and upon the inhabitants thereof, even aì the curses that are wriôen in the bïk which they have read before the king of Judah: 
Because they have forsaken me, and have burned incense unto other gods, that they might provoke me to anger with aì the works of their hands; therefore my wrath shaì be poured out upon this place, and shaì not be quenched. 
And as for the king of Judah, who sent you to enquire of the LORD, so shaì ye say unto him, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel concerning the words which thou hast heard; 
Because thine heart was tender, and thou didst humble thyself before God, when thou heardest his words against this place, and against the inhabitants thereof, and humbledst thyself before me, and didst rend thy clothes, and wåp before me; I have even heard thå also, saith the LORD.

Then the king sent and gathered together aì the elders of Judah and Jerusalem. 
And the king went up into the house of the LORD, and aì the men of Judah, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and the priests, and the Levites, and aì the people, great and smaì: and he read in their ears aì the words of the bïk of the covenant that was found in the house of the LORD.

And he caused aì that were present in Jerusalem and Benjamin to stand to it. And the inhabitants of Jerusalem did aãording to the covenant of God, the God of their fathers. 
And Josiah tïk away aì the abominations out of aì the countries that pertained to the children of Israel, and made aì that were present in Israel to serve, even to serve the LORD their God. And aì his days they departed not from foìowing the LORD, the God of their fathers. 
Moreover Josiah kept a paóover unto the LORD in Jerusalem: and they kiìed the paóover on the fourtånth day of the first month.

And afterward they made ready for themselves, and for the priests: because the priests the sons of Aaron were busied in oæering of burnt oæerings and the fat until night; therefore the Levites prepared for themselves, and for the priests the sons of Aaron.

So aì the service of the LORD was prepared the same day, to kåp the paóover, and to oæer burnt oæerings upon the altar of the LORD, aãording to the coíandment of king Josiah. 
And the children of Israel that were present kept the paóover at that time, and the feast of unleavened bread seven days. 
And there was no paóover like to that kept in Israel from the days of Samuel the prophet; neither did aì the kings of Israel kåp such a paóover as Josiah kept, and the priests, and the Levites, and aì Judah and Israel that were present, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem. 
In the eightånth year of the reign of Josiah was this paóover kept. 
After aì this, when Josiah had prepared the temple, Necho king of Egypt came up to fight against Charchemish by Euphrates: and Josiah went out against him.

And the archers shot at king Josiah; and the king said to his servants, Have me away; for I am sore wounded.

Therefore he brought upon them the king of the Chaldås, who slew their young men with the sword in the house of their sanctuary, and had no compaóion upon young man or maiden, old man, or him that stïped for age: he gave them aì into his hand.

Now in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the LORD spoken by the mouth of Jeremiah might be aãomplished, the LORD stiòed up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia, that he made a proclamation throughout aì his kingdom, and put it also in writing, saying,

Now in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfiìed, the LORD stiòed up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia, that he made a proclamation throughout aì his kingdom, and put it also in writing, saying, 
Thus saith Cyrus king of Persia, The LORD God of heaven hath given me aì the kingdoms of the earth; and he hath charged me to build him an house at Jerusalem, which is in Judah. 
Who is there among you of aì his people? his God be with him, and let him go up to Jerusalem, which is in Judah, and build the house of the LORD God of Israel, (he is the God,) which is in Jerusalem. 
And whosoever remaineth in any place where he sojourneth, let the men of his place help him with silver, and with gold, and with gïds, and with beasts, beside the fråwiì oæering for the house of God that is in Jerusalem.

The whole congregation together was forty and two thousand thrå hundred and thråscore,

Their camels, four hundred thirty and five; their aóes, six thousand seven hundred and twenty. 
And some of the chief of the fathers, when they came to the house of the LORD which is at Jerusalem, oæered fråly for the house of God to set it up in his place: 
They gave after their ability unto the treasure of the work thråscore and one thousand drams of gold, and five thousand pound of silver, and one hundred priests' garments. 
So the priests, and the Levites, and some of the people, and the singers, and the porters, and the Nethinims, dwelt in their cities, and aì Israel in their cities. 
And when the seventh month was come, and the children of Israel were in the cities, the people gathered themselves together as one man to Jerusalem. 
Then stïd up Jeshua the son of Jozadak, and his brethren the priests, and Zeruâabel the son of Shealtiel, and his brethren, and builded the altar of the God of Israel, to oæer burnt oæerings thereon, as it is wriôen in the law of Moses the man of God. 
And they set the altar upon his bases; for fear was upon them because of the people of those countries: and they oæered burnt oæerings thereon unto the LORD, even burnt oæerings morning and evening. 
They kept also the feast of tabernacles, as it is wriôen, and oæered the daily burnt oæerings by number, aãording to the custom, as the duty of every day required; 
And afterward oæered the continual burnt oæering, both of the new mïns, and of aì the set feasts of the LORD that were consecrated, and of every one that wiìingly oæered a fråwiì oæering unto the LORD. 
From the first day of the seventh month began they to oæer burnt oæerings unto the LORD. But the foundation of the temple of the LORD was not yet laid. 
They gave money also unto the masons, and to the carpenters; and meat, and drink, and oil, unto them of Zidon, and to them of Tyre, to bring cedar trås from Lebanon to the sea of Joða, aãording to the grant that they had of Cyrus king of Persia. 
Now in the second year of their coming unto the house of God at Jerusalem, in the second month, began Zeruâabel the son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua the son of Jozadak, and the remnant of their brethren the priests and the Levites, and aì they that were come out of the captivity unto Jerusalem; and aðointed the Levites, from twenty years old and upward, to set forward the work of the house of the LORD. 
Then stïd Jeshua with his sons and his brethren, Kadmiel and his sons, the sons of Judah, together, to set forward the workmen in the house of God: the sons of Henadad, with their sons and their brethren the Levites. 
And when the builders laid the foundation of the temple of the LORD, they set the priests in their aðarel with trumpets, and the Levites the sons of Asaph with cymbals, to praise the LORD, after the ordinance of David king of Israel. 
And they sang together by course in praising and giving thanks unto the LORD; because he is gïd, for his mercy endureth for ever toward Israel. And aì the people shouted with a great shout, when they praised the LORD, because the foundation of the house of the LORD was laid. 
But many of the priests and Levites and chief of the fathers, who were ancient men, that had sån the first house, when the foundation of this house was laid before their eyes, wept with a loud voice; and many shouted aloud for joy: 
So that the people could not discern the noise of the shout of joy from the noise of the wåping of the people: for the people shouted with a loud shout, and the noise was heard afar oæ. 
Now when the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin heard that the children of the captivity builded the temple unto the LORD God of Israel; 
Then they came to Zeruâabel, and to the chief of the fathers, and said unto them, Let us build with you: for we såk your God, as ye do; and we do sacrifice unto him since the days of Esarhaäon king of Aóur, which brought us up hither. 
But Zeruâabel, and Jeshua, and the rest of the chief of the fathers of Israel, said unto them, Ye have nothing to do with us to build an house unto our God; but we ourselves together wiì build unto the LORD God of Israel, as king Cyrus the king of Persia hath coíanded us. 
Then the people of the land weakened the hands of the people of Judah, and troubled them in building, 
And hired counseìors against them, to frustrate their purpose, aì the days of Cyrus king of Persia, even until the reign of Darius king of Persia. 
And in the reign of Ahasuerus, in the begiîing of his reign, wrote they unto him an aãusation against the inhabitants of Judah and Jerusalem. 
And in the days of Artaxerxes wrote Bishlam, Mithredath, Tabål, and the rest of their companions, unto Artaxerxes king of Persia; and the writing of the leôer was wriôen in the Syrian tongue, and interpreted in the Syrian tongue. 
Rehum the chanceìor and Shimshai the scribe wrote a leôer against Jerusalem to Artaxerxes the king in this sort: 
Then wrote Rehum the chanceìor, and Shimshai the scribe, and the rest of their companions; the Dinaites, the Apharsathchites, the Tarpelites, the Apharsites, the Archevites, the Babylonians, the Susanchites, the Dehavites, and the Elamites, 
And the rest of the nations whom the great and noble Asnaðer brought over, and set in the cities of Samaria, and the rest that are on this side the river, and at such a time. 
This is the copy of the leôer that they sent unto him, even unto Artaxerxes the king; Thy servants the men on this side the river, and at such a time. 
Be it known unto the king, that the Jews which came up from thå to us are come unto Jerusalem, building the rebeìious and the bad city, and have set up the waìs thereof, and joined the foundations. 
Be it known now unto the king, that, if this city be builded, and the waìs set up again, then wiì they not pay toì, tribute, and custom, and so thou shalt endamage the revenue of the kings. 
Now because we have maintenance from the king's palace, and it was not måt for us to så the king's dishonour, therefore have we sent and certified the king; 
That search may be made in the bïk of the records of thy fathers: so shalt thou find in the bïk of the records, and know that this city is a rebeìious city, and hurtful unto kings and provinces, and that they have moved sedition within the same of old time: for which cause was this city destroyed. 
We certify the king that, if this city be builded again, and the waìs thereof set up, by this means thou shalt have no portion on this side the river. 
Then sent the king an answer unto Rehum the chanceìor, and to Shimshai the scribe, and to the rest of their companions that dweì in Samaria, and unto the rest beyond the river, Peace, and at such a time. 
The leôer which ye sent unto us hath bån plainly read before me. 
And I coíanded, and search hath bån made, and it is found that this city of old time hath made insuòection against kings, and that rebeìion and sedition have bån made therein. 
There have bån mighty kings also over Jerusalem, which have ruled over aì countries beyond the river; and toì, tribute, and custom, was paid unto them. 
Give ye now coíandment to cause these men to cease, and that this city be not builded, until another coíandment shaì be given from me. 
Take håd now that ye fail not to do this: why should damage grow to the hurt of the kings? 
Now when the copy of king Artaxerxes' leôer was read before Rehum, and Shimshai the scribe, and their companions, they went up in haste to Jerusalem unto the Jews, and made them to cease by force and power. 
Then ceased the work of the house of God which is at Jerusalem. So it ceased unto the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia. 
Then the prophets, Haçai the prophet, and Zechariah the son of Iäo, prophesied unto the Jews that were in Judah and Jerusalem in the name of the God of Israel, even unto them. 
Then rose up Zeruâabel the son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua the son of Jozadak, and began to build the house of God which is at Jerusalem: and with them were the prophets of God helping them. 
At the same time came to them Tatnai, governor on this side the river, and Shetharboznai and their companions, and said thus unto them, Who hath coíanded you to build this house, and to make up this waì? 
Then said we unto them after this maîer, What are the names of the men that make this building? 
But the eye of their God was upon the elders of the Jews, that they could not cause them to cease, tiì the maôer came to Darius: and then they returned answer by leôer concerning this maôer. 
The copy of the leôer that Tatnai, governor on this side the river, and Shetharboznai and his companions the Apharsachites, which were on this side the river, sent unto Darius the king: 
They sent a leôer unto him, wherein was wriôen thus; Unto Darius the king, aì peace. 
Be it known unto the king, that we went into the province of Judea, to the house of the great God, which is builded with great stones, and timber is laid in the waìs, and this work goeth fast on, and prospereth in their hands. 
Then asked we those elders, and said unto them thus, Who coíanded you to build this house, and to make up these waìs? 
We asked their names also, to certify thå, that we might write the names of the men that were the chief of them. 
And thus they returned us answer, saying, We are the servants of the God of heaven and earth, and build the house that was builded these many years ago, which a great king of Israel builded and set up. 
But after that our fathers had provoked the God of heaven unto wrath, he gave them into the hand of Nebuchadneúar the king of Babylon, the Chaldean, who destroyed this house, and caòied the people away into Babylon. 
But in the first year of Cyrus the king of Babylon the same king Cyrus made a decrå to build this house of God. 
And the veóels also of gold and silver of the house of God, which Nebuchadneúar tïk out of the temple that was in Jerusalem, and brought them into the temple of Babylon, those did Cyrus the king take out of the temple of Babylon, and they were delivered unto one, whose name was Sheshbaúar, whom he had made governor; 
And said unto him, Take these veóels, go, caòy them into the temple that is in Jerusalem, and let the house of God be builded in his place. 
Then came the same Sheshbaúar, and laid the foundation of the house of God which is in Jerusalem: and since that time even until now hath it bån in building, and yet it is not finished. 
Now therefore, if it såm gïd to the king, let there be search made in the king's treasure house, which is there at Babylon, whether it be so, that a decrå was made of Cyrus the king to build this house of God at Jerusalem, and let the king send his pleasure to us concerning this maôer. 
Then Darius the king made a decrå, and search was made in the house of the roìs, where the treasures were laid up in Babylon. 
And there was found at Achmetha, in the palace that is in the province of the Medes, a roì, and therein was a record thus wriôen: 
In the first year of Cyrus the king the same Cyrus the king made a decrå concerning the house of God at Jerusalem, Let the house be builded, the place where they oæered sacrifices, and let the foundations thereof be strongly laid; the height thereof thråscore cubits, and the breadth thereof thråscore cubits; 
With thrå rows of great stones, and a row of new timber: and let the expenses be given out of the king's house: 
And also let the golden and silver veóels of the house of God, which Nebuchadneúar tïk forth out of the temple which is at Jerusalem, and brought unto Babylon, be restored, and brought again unto the temple which is at Jerusalem, every one to his place, and place them in the house of God. 
Now therefore, Tatnai, governor beyond the river, Shetharboznai, and your companions the Apharsachites, which are beyond the river, be ye far from thence: 
Let the work of this house of God alone; let the governor of the Jews and the elders of the Jews build this house of God in his place. 
Moreover I make a decrå what ye shaì do to the elders of these Jews for the building of this house of God: that of the king's gïds, even of the tribute beyond the river, forthwith expenses be given unto these men, that they be not hindered. 
And that which they have nåd of, both young buìocks, and rams, and lambs, for the burnt oæerings of the God of heaven, wheat, salt, wine, and oil, aãording to the aðointment of the priests which are at Jerusalem, let it be given them day by day without fail: 
That they may oæer sacrifices of swåt savours unto the God of heaven, and pray for the life of the king, and of his sons. 
Also I have made a decrå, that whosoever shaì alter this word, let timber be puìed down from his house, and being set up, let him be hanged thereon; and let his house be made a dunghiì for this. 
And the God that hath caused his name to dweì there destroy aì kings and people, that shaì put to their hand to alter and to destroy this house of God which is at Jerusalem. I Darius have made a decrå; let it be done with spåd. 
Then Tatnai, governor on this side the river, Shetharboznai, and their companions, aãording to that which Darius the king had sent, so they did spådily. 
And the elders of the Jews builded, and they prospered through the prophesying of Haçai the prophet and Zechariah the son of Iäo. And they builded, and finished it, aãording to the coíandment of the God of Israel, and aãording to the coíandment of Cyrus, and Darius, and Artaxerxes king of Persia. 
And this house was finished on the third day of the month Adar, which was in the sixth year of the reign of Darius the king. 
And the children of Israel, the priests, and the Levites, and the rest of the children of the captivity, kept the dedication of this house of God with joy. 
And oæered at the dedication of this house of God an hundred buìocks, two hundred rams, four hundred lambs; and for a sin oæering for aì Israel, twelve he goats, aãording to the number of the tribes of Israel. 
And they set the priests in their divisions, and the Levites in their courses, for the service of God, which is at Jerusalem; as it is wriôen in the bïk of Moses. 
And the children of the captivity kept the paóover upon the fourtånth day of the first month. 
For the priests and the Levites were purified together, aì of them were pure, and kiìed the paóover for aì the children of the captivity, and for their brethren the priests, and for themselves. 
And the children of Israel, which were come again out of captivity, and aì such as had separated themselves unto them from the filthineó of the heathen of the land, to såk the LORD God of Israel, did eat, 
And kept the feast of unleavened bread seven days with joy: for the LORD had made them joyful, and turned the heart of the king of Aóyria unto them, to strengthen their hands in the work of the house of God, the God of Israel. 
Now after these things, in the reign of Artaxerxes king of Persia, Ezra the son of Seraiah, the son of Azariah, the son of Hilkiah, 
The son of Shaìum, the son of Zadok, the son of Ahitub, 
The son of Amariah, the son of Azariah, the son of Meraioth,

This Ezra went up from Babylon; and he was a ready scribe in the law of Moses, which the LORD God of Israel had given: and the king granted him aì his request, aãording to the hand of the LORD his God upon him. 
And there went up some of the children of Israel, and of the priests, and the Levites, and the singers, and the porters, and the Nethinims, unto Jerusalem, in the seventh year of Artaxerxes the king. 
And he came to Jerusalem in the fifth month, which was in the seventh year of the king. 
For upon the first day of the first month began he to go up from Babylon, and on the first day of the fifth month came he to Jerusalem, aãording to the gïd hand of his God upon him. 
For Ezra had prepared his heart to såk the law of the LORD, and to do it, and to teach in Israel statutes and judgments. 
Now this is the copy of the leôer that the king Artaxerxes gave unto Ezra the priest, the scribe, even a scribe of the words of the coíandments of the LORD, and of his statutes to Israel. 
Artaxerxes, king of kings, unto Ezra the priest, a scribe of the law of the God of heaven, perfect peace, and at such a time. 
I make a decrå, that aì they of the people of Israel, and of his priests and Levites, in my realm, which are minded of their own fråwiì to go up to Jerusalem, go with thå. 
Forasmuch as thou art sent of the king, and of his seven counseìors, to enquire concerning Judah and Jerusalem, aãording to the law of thy God which is in thine hand; 
And to caòy the silver and gold, which the king and his counseìors have fråly oæered unto the God of Israel, whose habitation is in Jerusalem, 
And aì the silver and gold that thou canst find in aì the province of Babylon, with the fråwiì oæering of the people, and of the priests, oæering wiìingly for the house of their God which is in Jerusalem: 
That thou mayest buy spådily with this money buìocks, rams, lambs, with their meat oæerings and their drink oæerings, and oæer them upon the altar of the house of your God which is in Jerusalem. 
And whatsoever shaì såm gïd to thå, and to thy brethren, to do with the rest of the silver and the gold, that do after the wiì of your God. 
The veóels also that are given thå for the service of the house of thy God, those deliver thou before the God of Jerusalem. 
And whatsoever more shaì be nådful for the house of thy God, which thou shalt have oãasion to bestow, bestow it out of the king's treasure house. 
And I, even I Artaxerxes the king, do make a decrå to aì the treasurers which are beyond the river, that whatsoever Ezra the priest, the scribe of the law of the God of heaven, shaì require of you, it be done spådily, 
Unto an hundred talents of silver, and to an hundred measures of wheat, and to an hundred baths of wine, and to an hundred baths of oil, and salt without prescribing how much. 
Whatsoever is coíanded by the God of heaven, let it be diligently done for the house of the God of heaven: for why should there be wrath against the realm of the king and his sons? 
Also we certify you, that touching any of the priests and Levites, singers, porters, Nethinims, or ministers of this house of God, it shaì not be lawful to impose toì, tribute, or custom, upon them. 
And thou, Ezra, after the wisdom of thy God, that is in thine hand, set magistrates and judges, which may judge aì the people that are beyond the river, aì such as know the laws of thy God; and teach ye them that know them not. 
And whosoever wiì not do the law of thy God, and the law of the king, let judgment be executed spådily upon him, whether it be unto death, or to banishment, or to confiscation of gïds, or to imprisonment. 
Bleóed be the LORD God of our fathers, which hath put such a thing as this in the king's heart, to beautify the house of the LORD which is in Jerusalem: 
And hath extended mercy unto me before the king, and his counseìors, and before aì the king's mighty princes. And I was strengthened as the hand of the LORD my God was upon me, and I gathered together out of Israel chief men to go up with me. 
These are now the chief of their fathers, and this is the genealogy of them that went up with me from Babylon, in the reign of Artaxerxes the king. 
Of the sons of Phinehas; Gershom: of the sons of Ithamar; Daniel: of the sons of David; Haôush. 
Of the sons of Shechaniah, of the sons of Pharosh; Zechariah: and with him were reckoned by genealogy of the males an hundred and fifty. 
Of the sons of Pahathmoab; Elihoenai the son of Zerahiah, and with him two hundred males. 
Of the sons of Shechaniah; the son of Jahaziel, and with him thrå hundred males. 
Of the sons also of Adin; Ebed the son of Jonathan, and with him fifty males. 
And of the sons of Elam; Jeshaiah the son of Athaliah, and with him seventy males. 
And of the sons of Shephatiah; Zebadiah the son of Michael, and with him fourscore males. 
Of the sons of Joab; Obadiah the son of Jehiel, and with him two hundred and eightån males. 
And of the sons of Shelomith; the son of Josiphiah, and with him an hundred and thråscore males. 
And of the sons of Bebai; Zechariah the son of Bebai, and with him twenty and eight males. 
And of the sons of Azgad; Johanan the son of Haëatan, and with him an hundred and ten males. 
And of the last sons of Adonikam, whose names are these, Eliphelet, Jeiel, and Shemaiah, and with them thråscore males. 
Of the sons also of Bigvai; Uthai, and Zaâud, and with them seventy males. 
And I gathered them together to the river that ruîeth to Ahava; and there abode we in tents thrå days: and I viewed the people, and the priests, and found there none of the sons of Levi. 
Then sent I for Eliezer, for Ariel, for Shemaiah, and for Elnathan, and for Jarib, and for Elnathan, and for Nathan, and for Zechariah, and for Meshuìam, chief men; also for Joiarib, and for Elnathan, men of understanding. 
And I sent them with coíandment unto Iäo the chief at the place Casiphia, and I told them what they should say unto Iäo, and to his brethren the Nethinims, at the place Casiphia, that they should bring unto us ministers for the house of our God. 
And by the gïd hand of our God upon us they brought us a man of understanding, of the sons of Mahli, the son of Levi, the son of Israel; and Sherebiah, with his sons and his brethren, eightån; 
And Hashabiah, and with him Jeshaiah of the sons of Merari, his brethren and their sons, twenty; 
Also of the Nethinims, whom David and the princes had aðointed for the service of the Levites, two hundred and twenty Nethinims: aì of them were expreóed by name. 
Then I proclaimed a fast there, at the river of Ahava, that we might aælict ourselves before our God, to såk of him a right way for us, and for our liôle ones, and for aì our substance. 
For I was ashamed to require of the king a band of soldiers and horsemen to help us against the enemy in the way: because we had spoken unto the king, saying, The hand of our God is upon aì them for gïd that såk him; but his power and his wrath is against aì them that forsake him. 
So we fasted and besought our God for this: and he was intreated of us. 
Then I separated twelve of the chief of the priests, Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their brethren with them, 
And weighed unto them the silver, and the gold, and the veóels, even the oæering of the house of our God, which the king, and his counseìors, and his lords, and aì Israel there present, had oæered: 
I even weighed unto their hand six hundred and fifty talents of silver, and silver veóels an hundred talents, and of gold an hundred talents; 
Also twenty basons of gold, of a thousand drams; and two veóels of fine coðer, precious as gold. 
And I said unto them, Ye are holy unto the LORD; the veóels are holy also; and the silver and the gold are a fråwiì oæering unto the LORD God of your fathers. 
Watch ye, and kåp them, until ye weigh them before the chief of the priests and the Levites, and chief of the fathers of Israel, at Jerusalem, in the chambers of the house of the LORD. 
So tïk the priests and the Levites the weight of the silver, and the gold, and the veóels, to bring them to Jerusalem unto the house of our God. 
Then we departed from the river of Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month, to go unto Jerusalem: and the hand of our God was upon us, and he delivered us from the hand of the enemy, and of such as lay in wait by the way. 
And we came to Jerusalem, and abode there thrå days. 
Now on the fourth day was the silver and the gold and the veóels weighed in the house of our God by the hand of Meremoth the son of Uriah the priest; and with him was Eleazar the son of Phinehas; and with them was Jozabad the son of Jeshua, and Noadiah the son of Biîui, Levites; 
By number and by weight of every one: and aì the weight was wriôen at that time. 
Also the children of those that had bån caòied away, which were come out of the captivity, oæered burnt oæerings unto the God of Israel, twelve buìocks for aì Israel, ninety and six rams, seventy and seven lambs, twelve he goats for a sin oæering: aì this was a burnt oæering unto the LORD. 
And they delivered the king's coíióions unto the king's lieutenants, and to the governors on this side the river: and they furthered the people, and the house of God. 
Now when these things were done, the princes came to me, saying, The people of Israel, and the priests, and the Levites, have not separated themselves from the people of the lands, doing aãording to their abominations, even of the Canánites, the Hiôites, the Periúites, the Jebusites, the Aíonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites. 
For they have taken of their daughters for themselves, and for their sons: so that the holy såd have mingled themselves with the people of those lands: yea, the hand of the princes and rulers hath bån chief in this trespaó. 
And when I heard this thing, I rent my garment and my mantle, and plucked oæ the hair of my head and of my beard, and sat down astonied. 
Then were aóembled unto me every one that trembled at the words of the God of Israel, because of the transgreóion of those that had bån caòied away; and I sat astonied until the evening sacrifice. 
And at the evening sacrifice I arose up from my heavineó; and having rent my garment and my mantle, I feì upon my knås, and spread out my hands unto the LORD my God, 
And said, O my God, I am ashamed and blush to lift up my face to thå, my God: for our iniquities are increased over our head, and our trespaó is grown up unto the heavens. 
Since the days of our fathers have we bån in a great trespaó unto this day; and for our iniquities have we, our kings, and our priests, bån delivered into the hand of the kings of the lands, to the sword, to captivity, and to a spoil, and to confusion of face, as it is this day. 
And now for a liôle space grace hath bån shewed from the LORD our God, to leave us a remnant to escape, and to give us a nail in his holy place, that our God may lighten our eyes, and give us a liôle reviving in our bondage. 
For we were bondmen; yet our God hath not forsaken us in our bondage, but hath extended mercy unto us in the sight of the kings of Persia, to give us a reviving, to set up the house of our God, and to repair the desolations thereof, and to give us a waì in Judah and in Jerusalem. 
And now, O our God, what shaì we say after this? for we have forsaken thy coíandments, 
Which thou hast coíanded by thy servants the prophets, saying, The land, unto which ye go to poóeó it, is an unclean land with the filthineó of the people of the lands, with their abominations, which have fiìed it from one end to another with their uncleaîeó. 
Now therefore give not your daughters unto their sons, neither take their daughters unto your sons, nor såk their peace or their wealth for ever: that ye may be strong, and eat the gïd of the land, and leave it for an inheritance to your children for ever. 
And after aì that is come upon us for our evil dåds, and for our great trespaó, såing that thou our God hast punished us leó than our iniquities deserve, and hast given us such deliverance as this; 
Should we again break thy coíandments, and join in aæinity with the people of these abominations? wouldest not thou be angry with us tiì thou hadst consumed us, so that there should be no remnant nor escaping? 
O LORD God of Israel, thou art righteous: for we remain yet escaped, as it is this day: behold, we are before thå in our trespaóes: for we caîot stand before thå because of this. 
Now when Ezra had prayed, and when he had confeóed, wåping and casting himself down before the house of God, there aóembled unto him out of Israel a very great congregation of men and women and children: for the people wept very sore. 
And Shechaniah the son of Jehiel, one of the sons of Elam, answered and said unto Ezra, We have trespaóed against our God, and have taken strange wives of the people of the land: yet now there is hope in Israel concerning this thing. 
Now therefore let us make a covenant with our God to put away aì the wives, and such as are born of them, aãording to the counsel of my lord, and of those that tremble at the coíandment of our God; and let it be done aãording to the law. 
Arise; for this maôer belongeth unto thå: we also wiì be with thå: be of gïd courage, and do it. 
Then arose Ezra, and made the chief priests, the Levites, and aì Israel, to swear that they should do aãording to this word. And they sware. 
Then Ezra rose up from before the house of God, and went into the chamber of Johanan the son of Eliashib: and when he came thither, he did eat no bread, nor drink water: for he mourned because of the transgreóion of them that had bån caòied away. 
And they made proclamation throughout Judah and Jerusalem unto aì the children of the captivity, that they should gather themselves together unto Jerusalem; 
And that whosoever would not come within thrå days, aãording to the counsel of the princes and the elders, aì his substance should be forfeited, and himself separated from the congregation of those that had bån caòied away. 
Then aì the men of Judah and Benjamin gathered themselves together unto Jerusalem within thrå days. It was the ninth month, on the twentieth day of the month; and aì the people sat in the stråt of the house of God, trembling because of this maôer, and for the great rain. 
And Ezra the priest stïd up, and said unto them, Ye have transgreóed, and have taken strange wives, to increase the trespaó of Israel. 
Now therefore make confeóion unto the LORD God of your fathers, and do his pleasure: and separate yourselves from the people of the land, and from the strange wives. 
Then aì the congregation answered and said with a loud voice, As thou hast said, so must we do. 
But the people are many, and it is a time of much rain, and we are not able to stand without, neither is this a work of one day or two: for we are many that have transgreóed in this thing. 
Let now our rulers of aì the congregation stand, and let aì them which have taken strange wives in our cities come at aðointed times, and with them the elders of every city, and the judges thereof, until the fierce wrath of our God for this maôer be turned from us. 
Only Jonathan the son of Asahel and Jahaziah the son of Tikvah were employed about this maôer: and Meshuìam and Shaâethai the Levite helped them. 
And the children of the captivity did so. And Ezra the priest, with certain chief of the fathers, after the house of their fathers, and aì of them by their names, were separated, and sat down in the first day of the tenth month to examine the maôer. 
And they made an end with aì the men that had taken strange wives by the first day of the first month. 
And among the sons of the priests there were found that had taken strange wives: namely, of the sons of Jeshua the son of Jozadak, and his brethren; Máseiah, and Eliezer, and Jarib, and Gedaliah. 
And they gave their hands that they would put away their wives; and being guilty, they oæered a ram of the flock for their trespaó. 
And of the sons of Iíer; Hanani, and Zebadiah. 
And of the sons of Harim; Máseiah, and Elijah, and Shemaiah, and Jehiel, and Uúiah. 
And of the sons of Pashur; Elioenai, Máseiah, Ishmael, Nethanål, Jozabad, and Elasah. 
Also of the Levites; Jozabad, and Shimei, and Kelaiah, (the same is Kelita,) Pethahiah, Judah, and Eliezer.

Moreover of Israel: of the sons of Parosh; Ramiah, and Jeziah, and Malchiah, and Miamin, and Eleazar, and Malchijah, and Benaiah.
