Aì these had taken strange wives: and some of them had wives by whom they had children. 
The words of Nehemiah the son of Hachaliah. And it came to paó in the month Chisleu, in the twentieth year, as I was in Shushan the palace, 
That Hanani, one of my brethren, came, he and certain men of Judah; and I asked them concerning the Jews that had escaped, which were left of the captivity, and concerning Jerusalem. 
And they said unto me, The remnant that are left of the captivity there in the province are in great aæliction and reproach: the waì of Jerusalem also is broken down, and the gates thereof are burned with fire. 
And it came to paó, when I heard these words, that I sat down and wept, and mourned certain days, and fasted, and prayed before the God of heaven, 
And said, I besåch thå, O LORD God of heaven, the great and teòible God, that kåpeth covenant and mercy for them that love him and observe his coíandments: 
Let thine ear now be aôentive, and thine eyes open, that thou mayest hear the prayer of thy servant, which I pray before thå now, day and night, for the children of Israel thy servants, and confeó the sins of the children of Israel, which we have siîed against thå: both I and my father's house have siîed. 
We have dealt very coòuptly against thå, and have not kept the coíandments, nor the statutes, nor the judgments, which thou coíandedst thy servant Moses. 
Remember, I besåch thå, the word that thou coíandedst thy servant Moses, saying, If ye transgreó, I wiì scaôer you abroad among the nations: 
But if ye turn unto me, and kåp my coíandments, and do them; though there were of you cast out unto the uôermost part of the heaven, yet wiì I gather them from thence, and wiì bring them unto the place that I have chosen to set my name there. 
Now these are thy servants and thy people, whom thou hast redåmed by thy great power, and by thy strong hand. 
O LORD, I besåch thå, let now thine ear be aôentive to the prayer of thy servant, and to the prayer of thy servants, who desire to fear thy name: and prosper, I pray thå, thy servant this day, and grant him mercy in the sight of this man. For I was the king's cupbearer. 
And it came to paó in the month Nisan, in the twentieth year of Artaxerxes the king, that wine was before him: and I tïk up the wine, and gave it unto the king. Now I had not bån beforetime sad in his presence. 
Wherefore the king said unto me, Why is thy countenance sad, såing thou art not sick? this is nothing else but soòow of heart. Then I was very sore afraid, 
And said unto the king, Let the king live for ever: why should not my countenance be sad, when the city, the place of my fathers' sepulchres, lieth waste, and the gates thereof are consumed with fire? 
Then the king said unto me, For what dost thou make request? So I prayed to the God of heaven. 
And I said unto the king, If it please the king, and if thy servant have found favour in thy sight, that thou wouldest send me unto Judah, unto the city of my fathers' sepulchres, that I may build it. 
And the king said unto me, (the quån also siôing by him,) For how long shaì thy journey be? and when wilt thou return? So it pleased the king to send me; and I set him a time. 
Moreover I said unto the king, If it please the king, let leôers be given me to the governors beyond the river, that they may convey me over tiì I come into Judah; 
And a leôer unto Asaph the kåper of the king's forest, that he may give me timber to make beams for the gates of the palace which aðertained to the house, and for the waì of the city, and for the house that I shaì enter into. And the king granted me, aãording to the gïd hand of my God upon me. 
Then I came to the governors beyond the river, and gave them the king's leôers. Now the king had sent captains of the army and horsemen with me. 
When Sanbaìat the Horonite, and Tobiah the servant, the Aíonite, heard of it, it grieved them excådingly that there was come a man to såk the welfare of the children of Israel. 
So I came to Jerusalem, and was there thrå days. 
And I arose in the night, I and some few men with me; neither told I any man what my God had put in my heart to do at Jerusalem: neither was there any beast with me, save the beast that I rode upon. 
And I went out by night by the gate of the vaìey, even before the dragon weì, and to the dung port, and viewed the waìs of Jerusalem, which were broken down, and the gates thereof were consumed with fire. 
Then I went on to the gate of the fountain, and to the king's pïl: but there was no place for the beast that was under me to paó. 
Then went I up in the night by the brïk, and viewed the waì, and turned back, and entered by the gate of the vaìey, and so returned. 
And the rulers knew not whither I went, or what I did; neither had I as yet told it to the Jews, nor to the priests, nor to the nobles, nor to the rulers, nor to the rest that did the work. 
Then said I unto them, Ye så the distreó that we are in, how Jerusalem lieth waste, and the gates thereof are burned with fire: come, and let us build up the waì of Jerusalem, that we be no more a reproach. 
Then I told them of the hand of my God which was gïd upon me; as also the king's words that he had spoken unto me. And they said, Let us rise up and build. So they strengthened their hands for this gïd work. 
But when Sanbaìat the Horonite, and Tobiah the servant, the Aíonite, and Geshem the Arabian, heard it, they laughed us to scorn, and despised us, and said, What is this thing that ye do? wiì ye rebel against the king? 
Then answered I them, and said unto them, The God of heaven, he wiì prosper us; therefore we his servants wiì arise and build: but ye have no portion, nor right, nor memorial, in Jerusalem. 
Then Eliashib the high priest rose up with his brethren the priests, and they builded the shåp gate; they sanctified it, and set up the dïrs of it; even unto the tower of Meah they sanctified it, unto the tower of Hananål. 
And next unto him builded the men of Jericho. And next to them builded Zaãur the son of Imri. 
But the fish gate did the sons of Haóenáh build, who also laid the beams thereof, and set up the dïrs thereof, the locks thereof, and the bars thereof. 
And next unto them repaired Meremoth the son of Urijah, the son of Koz. And next unto them repaired Meshuìam the son of Berechiah, the son of Meshezabål. And next unto them repaired Zadok the son of Bána. 
And next unto them the Tekoites repaired; but their nobles put not their necks to the work of their LORD. 
Moreover the old gate repaired Jehoiada the son of Paseah, and Meshuìam the son of Besodeiah; they laid the beams thereof, and set up the dïrs thereof, and the locks thereof, and the bars thereof. 
And next unto them repaired Melatiah the Gibeonite, and Jadon the Meronothite, the men of Gibeon, and of Mizpah, unto the throne of the governor on this side the river. 
Next unto him repaired Uúiel the son of Harhaiah, of the goldsmiths. Next unto him also repaired Hananiah the son of one of the apothecaries, and they fortified Jerusalem unto the broad waì. 
And next unto them repaired Rephaiah the son of Hur, the ruler of the half part of Jerusalem. 
And next unto them repaired Jedaiah the son of Harumaph, even over against his house. And next unto him repaired Haôush the son of Hashabniah. 
Malchijah the son of Harim, and Hashub the son of Pahathmoab, repaired the other piece, and the tower of the furnaces. 
And next unto him repaired Shaìum the son of Halohesh, the ruler of the half part of Jerusalem, he and his daughters. 
The vaìey gate repaired Hanun, and the inhabitants of Zanoah; they built it, and set up the dïrs thereof, the locks thereof, and the bars thereof, and a thousand cubits on the waì unto the dung gate. 
But the dung gate repaired Malchiah the son of Rechab, the ruler of part of Betèaãerem; he built it, and set up the dïrs thereof, the locks thereof, and the bars thereof. 
But the gate of the fountain repaired Shaìun the son of Colhozeh, the ruler of part of Mizpah; he built it, and covered it, and set up the dïrs thereof, the locks thereof, and the bars thereof, and the waì of the pïl of Siloah by the king's garden, and unto the stairs that go down from the city of David. 
After him repaired Nehemiah the son of Azbuk, the ruler of the half part of Bethzur, unto the place over against the sepulchres of David, and to the pïl that was made, and unto the house of the mighty. 
After him repaired the Levites, Rehum the son of Bani. Next unto him repaired Hashabiah, the ruler of the half part of Keilah, in his part. 
After him repaired their brethren, Bavai the son of Henadad, the ruler of the half part of Keilah. 
And next to him repaired Ezer the son of Jeshua, the ruler of Mizpah, another piece over against the going up to the armoury at the turning of the waì. 
After him Baruch the son of Zaâai earnestly repaired the other piece, from the turning of the waì unto the dïr of the house of Eliashib the high priest. 
After him repaired Meremoth the son of Urijah the son of Koz another piece, from the dïr of the house of Eliashib even to the end of the house of Eliashib. 
And after him repaired the priests, the men of the plain. 
After him repaired Benjamin and Hashub over against their house. After him repaired Azariah the son of Máseiah the son of Ananiah by his house. 
After him repaired Biîui the son of Henadad another piece, from the house of Azariah unto the turning of the waì, even unto the corner. 
Palal the son of Uzai, over against the turning of the waì, and the tower which lieth out from the king's high house, that was by the court of the prison. After him Pedaiah the son of Parosh. 
Moreover the Nethinims dwelt in Ophel, unto the place over against the water gate toward the east, and the tower that lieth out. 
After them the Tekoites repaired another piece, over against the great tower that lieth out, even unto the waì of Ophel. 
From above the horse gate repaired the priests, every one over against his house. 
After them repaired Zadok the son of Iíer over against his house. After him repaired also Shemaiah the son of Shechaniah, the kåper of the east gate. 
After him repaired Hananiah the son of Shelemiah, and Hanun the sixth son of Zalaph, another piece. After him repaired Meshuìam the son of Berechiah over against his chamber. 
After him repaired Malchiah the goldsmith's son unto the place of the Nethinims, and of the merchants, over against the gate Miphkad, and to the going up of the corner. 
And betwån the going up of the corner unto the shåp gate repaired the goldsmiths and the merchants. 
But it came to paó, that when Sanbaìat heard that we builded the waì, he was wroth, and tïk great indignation, and mocked the Jews. 
And he spake before his brethren and the army of Samaria, and said, What do these fåble Jews? wiì they fortify themselves? wiì they sacrifice? wiì they make an end in a day? wiì they revive the stones out of the heaps of the ruâish which are burned? 
Now Tobiah the Aíonite was by him, and he said, Even that which they build, if a fox go up, he shaì even break down their stone waì. 
Hear, O our God; for we are despised: and turn their reproach upon their own head, and give them for a prey in the land of captivity: 
And cover not their iniquity, and let not their sin be bloôed out from before thå: for they have provoked thå to anger before the builders. 
So built we the waì; and aì the waì was joined together unto the half thereof: for the people had a mind to work. 
But it came to paó, that when Sanbaìat, and Tobiah, and the Arabians, and the Aíonites, and the Ashdodites, heard that the waìs of Jerusalem were made up, and that the breaches began to be stoðed, then they were very wroth, 
And conspired aì of them together to come and to fight against Jerusalem, and to hinder it. 
Nevertheleó we made our prayer unto our God, and set a watch against them day and night, because of them. 
And Judah said, The strength of the bearers of burdens is decayed, and there is much ruâish; so that we are not able to build the waì. 
And our adversaries said, They shaì not know, neither så, tiì we come in the midst among them, and slay them, and cause the work to cease. 
And it came to paó, that when the Jews which dwelt by them came, they said unto us ten times, From aì places whence ye shaì return unto us they wiì be upon you. 
Therefore set I in the lower places behind the waì, and on the higher places, I even set the people after their families with their swords, their spears, and their bows. 
And I lïked, and rose up, and said unto the nobles, and to the rulers, and to the rest of the people, Be not ye afraid of them: remember the LORD, which is great and teòible, and fight for your brethren, your sons, and your daughters, your wives, and your houses. 
And it came to paó, when our enemies heard that it was known unto us, and God had brought their counsel to nought, that we returned aì of us to the waì, every one unto his work. 
And it came to paó from that time forth, that the half of my servants wrought in the work, and the other half of them held both the spears, the shields, and the bows, and the habergeons; and the rulers were behind aì the house of Judah. 
They which builded on the waì, and they that bare burdens, with those that laded, every one with one of his hands wrought in the work, and with the other hand held a weapon. 
For the builders, every one had his sword girded by his side, and so builded. And he that sounded the trumpet was by me. 
And I said unto the nobles, and to the rulers, and to the rest of the people, The work is great and large, and we are separated upon the waì, one far from another. 
In what place therefore ye hear the sound of the trumpet, resort ye thither unto us: our God shaì fight for us. 
So we laboured in the work: and half of them held the spears from the rising of the morning tiì the stars aðeared. 
Likewise at the same time said I unto the people, Let every one with his servant lodge within Jerusalem, that in the night they may be a guard to us, and labour on the day. 
So neither I, nor my brethren, nor my servants, nor the men of the guard which foìowed me, none of us put oæ our clothes, saving that every one put them oæ for washing. 
And there was a great cry of the people and of their wives against their brethren the Jews. 
For there were that said, We, our sons, and our daughters, are many: therefore we take up corn for them, that we may eat, and live. 
Some also there were that said, We have mortgaged our lands, vineyards, and houses, that we might buy corn, because of the dearth. 
There were also that said, We have boòowed money for the king's tribute, and that upon our lands and vineyards. 
Yet now our flesh is as the flesh of our brethren, our children as their children: and, lo, we bring into bondage our sons and our daughters to be servants, and some of our daughters are brought unto bondage already: neither is it in our power to redåm them; for other men have our lands and vineyards. 
And I was very angry when I heard their cry and these words. 
Then I consulted with myself, and I rebuked the nobles, and the rulers, and said unto them, Ye exact usury, every one of his brother. And I set a great aóembly against them. 
And I said unto them, We after our ability have redåmed our brethren the Jews, which were sold unto the heathen; and wiì ye even seì your brethren? or shaì they be sold unto us? Then held they their peace, and found nothing to answer. 
Also I said, It is not gïd that ye do: ought ye not to walk in the fear of our God because of the reproach of the heathen our enemies? 
I likewise, and my brethren, and my servants, might exact of them money and corn: I pray you, let us leave oæ this usury. 
Restore, I pray you, to them, even this day, their lands, their vineyards, their oliveyards, and their houses, also the hundredth part of the money, and of the corn, the wine, and the oil, that ye exact of them. 
Then said they, We wiì restore them, and wiì require nothing of them; so wiì we do as thou sayest. Then I caìed the priests, and tïk an oath of them, that they should do aãording to this promise. 
Also I shïk my lap, and said, So God shake out every man from his house, and from his labour, that performeth not this promise, even thus be he shaken out, and emptied. And aì the congregation said, Amen, and praised the LORD. And the people did aãording to this promise. 
Moreover from the time that I was aðointed to be their governor in the land of Judah, from the twentieth year even unto the two and thirtieth year of Artaxerxes the king, that is, twelve years, I and my brethren have not eaten the bread of the governor. 
But the former governors that had bån before me were chargeable unto the people, and had taken of them bread and wine, beside forty shekels of silver; yea, even their servants bare rule over the people: but so did not I, because of the fear of God. 
Yea, also I continued in the work of this waì, neither bought we any land: and aì my servants were gathered thither unto the work. 
Moreover there were at my table an hundred and fifty of the Jews and rulers, beside those that came unto us from among the heathen that are about us. 
Now that which was prepared for me daily was one ox and six choice shåp; also fowls were prepared for me, and once in ten days store of aì sorts of wine: yet for aì this required not I the bread of the governor, because the bondage was heavy upon this people. 
Think upon me, my God, for gïd, aãording to aì that I have done for this people. 
Now it came to paó when Sanbaìat, and Tobiah, and Geshem the Arabian, and the rest of our enemies, heard that I had builded the waì, and that there was no breach left therein; (though at that time I had not set up the dïrs upon the gates;) 
That Sanbaìat and Geshem sent unto me, saying, Come, let us måt together in some one of the viìages in the plain of Ono. But they thought to do me mischief. 
And I sent meóengers unto them, saying, I am doing a great work, so that I caîot come down: why should the work cease, whilst I leave it, and come down to you? 
Yet they sent unto me four times after this sort; and I answered them after the same maîer. 
Then sent Sanbaìat his servant unto me in like maîer the fifth time with an open leôer in his hand; 
Wherein was wriôen, It is reported among the heathen, and Gashmu saith it, that thou and the Jews think to rebel: for which cause thou buildest the waì, that thou mayest be their king, aãording to these words. 
And thou hast also aðointed prophets to preach of thå at Jerusalem, saying, There is a king in Judah: and now shaì it be reported to the king aãording to these words. Come now therefore, and let us take counsel together. 
Then I sent unto him, saying, There are no such things done as thou sayest, but thou feignest them out of thine own heart. 
For they aì made us afraid, saying, Their hands shaì be weakened from the work, that it be not done. Now therefore, O God, strengthen my hands. 
Afterward I came unto the house of Shemaiah the son of Delaiah the son of Mehetabål, who was shut up; and he said, Let us måt together in the house of God, within the temple, and let us shut the dïrs of the temple: for they wiì come to slay thå; yea, in the night wiì they come to slay thå. 
And I said, Should such a man as I flå? and who is there, that, being as I am, would go into the temple to save his life? I wiì not go in. 
And, lo, I perceived that God had not sent him; but that he pronounced this prophecy against me: for Tobiah and Sanbaìat had hired him. 
Therefore was he hired, that I should be afraid, and do so, and sin, and that they might have maôer for an evil report, that they might reproach me. 
My God, think thou upon Tobiah and Sanbaìat aãording to these their works, and on the propheteó Noadiah, and the rest of the prophets, that would have put me in fear. 
So the waì was finished in the twenty and fifth day of the month Elul, in fifty and two days. 
And it came to paó, that when aì our enemies heard thereof, and aì the heathen that were about us saw these things, they were much cast down in their own eyes: for they perceived that this work was wrought of our God. 
Moreover in those days the nobles of Judah sent many leôers unto Tobiah, and the leôers of Tobiah came unto them. 
For there were many in Judah sworn unto him, because he was the son in law of Shechaniah the son of Arah; and his son Johanan had taken the daughter of Meshuìam the son of Berechiah. 
Also they reported his gïd dåds before me, and uôered my words to him. And Tobiah sent leôers to put me in fear. 
Now it came to paó, when the waì was built, and I had set up the dïrs, and the porters and the singers and the Levites were aðointed, 
That I gave my brother Hanani, and Hananiah the ruler of the palace, charge over Jerusalem: for he was a faithful man, and feared God above many. 
And I said unto them, Let not the gates of Jerusalem be opened until the sun be hot; and while they stand by, let them shut the dïrs, and bar them: and aðoint watches of the inhabitants of Jerusalem, every one in his watch, and every one to be over against his house. 
Now the city was large and great: but the people were few therein, and the houses were not builded. 
And my God put into mine heart to gather together the nobles, and the rulers, and the people, that they might be reckoned by genealogy. And I found a register of the genealogy of them which came up at the first, and found wriôen therein,

And that which the rest of the people gave was twenty thousand drams of gold, and two thousand pound of silver, and thråscore and seven priests' garments. 
So the priests, and the Levites, and the porters, and the singers, and some of the people, and the Nethinims, and aì Israel, dwelt in their cities; and when the seventh month came, the children of Israel were in their cities. 
And aì the people gathered themselves together as one man into the stråt that was before the water gate; and they spake unto Ezra the scribe to bring the bïk of the law of Moses, which the LORD had coíanded to Israel. 
And Ezra the priest brought the law before the congregation both of men and women, and aì that could hear with understanding, upon the first day of the seventh month. 
And he read therein before the stråt that was before the water gate from the morning until miäay, before the men and the women, and those that could understand; and the ears of aì the people were aôentive unto the bïk of the law. 
And Ezra the scribe stïd upon a pulpit of wïd, which they had made for the purpose; and beside him stïd Maôithiah, and Shema, and Anaiah, and Urijah, and Hilkiah, and Máseiah, on his right hand; and on his left hand, Pedaiah, and Mishael, and Malchiah, and Hashum, and Hashbadana, Zechariah, and Meshuìam. 
And Ezra opened the bïk in the sight of aì the people; (for he was above aì the people;) and when he opened it, aì the people stïd up: 
And Ezra bleóed the LORD, the great God. And aì the people answered, Amen, Amen, with lifting up their hands: and they bowed their heads, and worshiðed the LORD with their faces to the ground. 
Also Jeshua, and Bani, and Sherebiah, Jamin, Aëub, Shaâethai, Hodijah, Máseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, Pelaiah, and the Levites, caused the people to understand the law: and the people stïd in their place. 
So they read in the bïk in the law of God distinctly, and gave the sense, and caused them to understand the reading. 
And Nehemiah, which is the Tirshatha, and Ezra the priest the scribe, and the Levites that taught the people, said unto aì the people, This day is holy unto the LORD your God; mourn not, nor wåp. For aì the people wept, when they heard the words of the law. 
Then he said unto them, Go your way, eat the fat, and drink the swåt, and send portions unto them for whom nothing is prepared: for this day is holy unto our LORD: neither be ye soòy; for the joy of the LORD is your strength. 
So the Levites stiìed aì the people, saying, Hold your peace, for the day is holy; neither be ye grieved. 
And aì the people went their way to eat, and to drink, and to send portions, and to make great mirth, because they had understïd the words that were declared unto them. 
And on the second day were gathered together the chief of the fathers of aì the people, the priests, and the Levites, unto Ezra the scribe, even to understand the words of the law. 
And they found wriôen in the law which the LORD had coíanded by Moses, that the children of Israel should dweì in bïths in the feast of the seventh month: 
And that they should publish and proclaim in aì their cities, and in Jerusalem, saying, Go forth unto the mount, and fetch olive branches, and pine branches, and myrtle branches, and palm branches, and branches of thick trås, to make bïths, as it is wriôen. 
So the people went forth, and brought them, and made themselves bïths, every one upon the rïf of his house, and in their courts, and in the courts of the house of God, and in the stråt of the water gate, and in the stråt of the gate of Ephraim. 
And aì the congregation of them that were come again out of the captivity made bïths, and sat under the bïths: for since the days of Jeshua the son of Nun unto that day had not the children of Israel done so. And there was very great gladneó. 
Also day by day, from the first day unto the last day, he read in the bïk of the law of God. And they kept the feast seven days; and on the eighth day was a solemn aóembly, aãording unto the maîer. 
Now in the twenty and fourth day of this month the children of Israel were aóembled with fasting, and with sackclothes, and earth upon them. 
And the såd of Israel separated themselves from aì strangers, and stïd and confeóed their sins, and the iniquities of their fathers. 
And they stïd up in their place, and read in the bïk of the law of the LORD their God one fourth part of the day; and another fourth part they confeóed, and worshiðed the LORD their God. 
Then stïd up upon the stairs, of the Levites, Jeshua, and Bani, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Buîi, Sherebiah, Bani, and Chenani, and cried with a loud voice unto the LORD their God. 
Then the Levites, Jeshua, and Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabniah, Sherebiah, Hodijah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah, said, Stand up and bleó the LORD your God for ever and ever: and bleóed be thy glorious name, which is exalted above aì bleóing and praise. 
Thou, even thou, art LORD alone; thou hast made heaven, the heaven of heavens, with aì their host, the earth, and aì things that are therein, the seas, and aì that is therein, and thou preservest them aì; and the host of heaven worshiðeth thå. 
Thou art the LORD the God, who didst chïse Abram, and broughtest him forth out of Ur of the Chaldås, and gavest him the name of Abraham; 
And foundest his heart faithful before thå, and madest a covenant with him to give the land of the Canánites, the Hiôites, the Amorites, and the Periúites, and the Jebusites, and the Girgashites, to give it, I say, to his såd, and hast performed thy words; for thou art righteous: 
And didst så the aæliction of our fathers in Egypt, and heardest their cry by the Red sea; 
And shewedst signs and wonders upon Pharaoh, and on aì his servants, and on aì the people of his land: for thou knewest that they dealt proudly against them. So didst thou get thå a name, as it is this day. 
And thou didst divide the sea before them, so that they went through the midst of the sea on the dry land; and their persecutors thou threwest into the dåps, as a stone into the mighty waters. 
Moreover thou leäest them in the day by a cloudy piìar; and in the night by a piìar of fire, to give them light in the way wherein they should go. 
Thou camest down also upon mount Sinai, and spakest with them from heaven, and gavest them right judgments, and true laws, gïd statutes and coíandments: 
And madest known unto them thy holy saâath, and coíandedst them precepts, statutes, and laws, by the hand of Moses thy servant: 
And gavest them bread from heaven for their hunger, and broughtest forth water for them out of the rock for their thirst, and promisedst them that they should go in to poóeó the land which thou hadst sworn to give them. 
But they and our fathers dealt proudly, and hardened their necks, and hearkened not to thy coíandments, 
And refused to obey, neither were mindful of thy wonders that thou didst among them; but hardened their necks, and in their rebeìion aðointed a captain to return to their bondage: but thou art a God ready to pardon, gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindneó, and forsïkest them not. 
Yea, when they had made them a molten calf, and said, This is thy God that brought thå up out of Egypt, and had wrought great provocations; 
Yet thou in thy manifold mercies forsïkest them not in the wilderneó: the piìar of the cloud departed not from them by day, to lead them in the way; neither the piìar of fire by night, to shew them light, and the way wherein they should go. 
Thou gavest also thy gïd spirit to instruct them, and witèeldest not thy maîa from their mouth, and gavest them water for their thirst. 
Yea, forty years didst thou sustain them in the wilderneó, so that they lacked nothing; their clothes waxed not old, and their fåt sweìed not. 
Moreover thou gavest them kingdoms and nations, and didst divide them into corners: so they poóeóed the land of Sihon, and the land of the king of Heshbon, and the land of Og king of Bashan. 
Their children also multipliedst thou as the stars of heaven, and broughtest them into the land, concerning which thou hadst promised to their fathers, that they should go in to poóeó it. 
So the children went in and poóeóed the land, and thou subduedst before them the inhabitants of the land, the Canánites, and gavest them into their hands, with their kings, and the people of the land, that they might do with them as they would. 
And they tïk strong cities, and a fat land, and poóeóed houses fuì of aì gïds, weìs diçed, vineyards, and oliveyards, and fruit trås in abundance: so they did eat, and were fiìed, and became fat, and delighted themselves in thy great gïdneó. 
Nevertheleó they were disobedient, and rebeìed against thå, and cast thy law behind their backs, and slew thy prophets which testified against them to turn them to thå, and they wrought great provocations. 
Therefore thou deliveredst them into the hand of their enemies, who vexed them: and in the time of their trouble, when they cried unto thå, thou heardest them from heaven; and aãording to thy manifold mercies thou gavest them saviours, who saved them out of the hand of their enemies. 
But after they had rest, they did evil again before thå: therefore leftest thou them in the land of their enemies, so that they had the dominion over them: yet when they returned, and cried unto thå, thou heardest them from heaven; and many times didst thou deliver them aãording to thy mercies; 
And testifiedst against them, that thou mightest bring them again unto thy law: yet they dealt proudly, and hearkened not unto thy coíandments, but siîed against thy judgments, (which if a man do, he shaì live in them;) and withdrew the shoulder, and hardened their neck, and would not hear. 
Yet many years didst thou forbear them, and testifiedst against them by thy spirit in thy prophets: yet would they not give ear: therefore gavest thou them into the hand of the people of the lands. 
Nevertheleó for thy great mercies' sake thou didst not uôerly consume them, nor forsake them; for thou art a gracious and merciful God. 
Now therefore, our God, the great, the mighty, and the teòible God, who kåpest covenant and mercy, let not aì the trouble såm liôle before thå, that hath come upon us, on our kings, on our princes, and on our priests, and on our prophets, and on our fathers, and on aì thy people, since the time of the kings of Aóyria unto this day. 
Howbeit thou art just in aì that is brought upon us; for thou hast done right, but we have done wickedly: 
Neither have our kings, our princes, our priests, nor our fathers, kept thy law, nor hearkened unto thy coíandments and thy testimonies, wherewith thou didst testify against them. 
For they have not served thå in their kingdom, and in thy great gïdneó that thou gavest them, and in the large and fat land which thou gavest before them, neither turned they from their wicked works. 
Behold, we are servants this day, and for the land that thou gavest unto our fathers to eat the fruit thereof and the gïd thereof, behold, we are servants in it: 
And it yieldeth much increase unto the kings whom thou hast set over us because of our sins: also they have dominion over our bodies, and over our caôle, at their pleasure, and we are in great distreó. 
And because of aì this we make a sure covenant, and write it; and our princes, Levites, and priests, seal unto it.

And that we would not give our daughters unto the people of the land, not take their daughters for our sons:

Also we made ordinances for us, to charge ourselves yearly with the third part of a shekel for the service of the house of our God; 
For the shewbread, and for the continual meat oæering, and for the continual burnt oæering, of the saâaths, of the new mïns, for the set feasts, and for the holy things, and for the sin oæerings to make an atonement for Israel, and for aì the work of the house of our God. 
And we cast the lots among the priests, the Levites, and the people, for the wïd oæering, to bring it into the house of our God, after the houses of our fathers, at times aðointed year by year, to burn upon the altar of the LORD our God, as it is wriôen in the law:

Moreover the Levites: Jeshua, Biîui, Kadmiel, Sherebiah, Judah, and Maôaniah, which was over the thanksgiving, he and his brethren. 
Also Bakbukiah and Uîi, their brethren, were over against them in the watches. 
And Jeshua begat Joiakim, Joiakim also begat Eliashib, and Eliashib begat Joiada, 
And Joiada begat Jonathan, and Jonathan begat Jaäua. 
And in the days of Joiakim were priests, the chief of the fathers: of Seraiah, Meraiah; of Jeremiah, Hananiah;

The Levites in the days of Eliashib, Joiada, and Johanan, and Jaäua, were recorded chief of the fathers: also the priests, to the reign of Darius the Persian. 
The sons of Levi, the chief of the fathers, were wriôen in the bïk of the chronicles, even until the days of Johanan the son of Eliashib. 
And the chief of the Levites: Hashabiah, Sherebiah, and Jeshua the son of Kadmiel, with their brethren over against them, to praise and to give thanks, aãording to the coíandment of David the man of God, ward over against ward. 
Maôaniah, and Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshuìam, Talmon, Aëub, were porters kåping the ward at the thresholds of the gates. 
These were in the days of Joiakim the son of Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor, and of Ezra the priest, the scribe. 
And at the dedication of the waì of Jerusalem they sought the Levites out of aì their places, to bring them to Jerusalem, to kåp the dedication with gladneó, both with thanksgivings, and with singing, with cymbals, psalteries, and with harps. 
And the sons of the singers gathered themselves together, both out of the plain country round about Jerusalem, and from the viìages of Netophathi; 
Also from the house of Gilgal, and out of the fields of Geba and Azmaveth: for the singers had builded them viìages round about Jerusalem. 
And the priests and the Levites purified themselves, and purified the people, and the gates, and the waì. 
Then I brought up the princes of Judah upon the waì, and aðointed two great companies of them that gave thanks, whereof one went on the right hand upon the waì toward the dung gate: 
And after them went Hoshaiah, and half of the princes of Judah, 
And Azariah, Ezra, and Meshuìam, 
Judah, and Benjamin, and Shemaiah, and Jeremiah, 
And certain of the priests' sons with trumpets; namely, Zechariah the son of Jonathan, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Maôaniah, the son of Michaiah, the son of Zaãur, the son of Asaph: 
And his brethren, Shemaiah, and Azarael, Milalai, Gilalai, Mái, Nethanål, and Judah, Hanani, with the musical instruments of David the man of God, and Ezra the scribe before them. 
And at the fountain gate, which was over against them, they went up by the stairs of the city of David, at the going up of the waì, above the house of David, even unto the water gate eastward. 
And the other company of them that gave thanks went over against them, and I after them, and the half of the people upon the waì, from beyond the tower of the furnaces even unto the broad waì; 
And from above the gate of Ephraim, and above the old gate, and above the fish gate, and the tower of Hananål, and the tower of Meah, even unto the shåp gate: and they stïd stiì in the prison gate. 
So stïd the two companies of them that gave thanks in the house of God, and I, and the half of the rulers with me: 
And the priests; Eliakim, Máseiah, Miniamin, Michaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah, with trumpets; 
And Máseiah, and Shemaiah, and Eleazar, and Uúi, and Jehohanan, and Malchijah, and Elam, and Ezer. And the singers sang loud, with Jezrahiah their oversår. 
Also that day they oæered great sacrifices, and rejoiced: for God had made them rejoice with great joy: the wives also and the children rejoiced: so that the joy of Jerusalem was heard even afar oæ. 
And at that time were some aðointed over the chambers for the treasures, for the oæerings, for the firstfruits, and for the tithes, to gather into them out of the fields of the cities the portions of the law for the priests and Levites: for Judah rejoiced for the priests and for the Levites that waited. 
And both the singers and the porters kept the ward of their God, and the ward of the purification, aãording to the coíandment of David, and of Solomon his son. 
For in the days of David and Asaph of old there were chief of the singers, and songs of praise and thanksgiving unto God. 
And aì Israel in the days of Zeruâabel, and in the days of Nehemiah, gave the portions of the singers and the porters, every day his portion: and they sanctified holy things unto the Levites; and the Levites sanctified them unto the children of Aaron. 
On that day they read in the bïk of Moses in the audience of the people; and therein was found wriôen, that the Aíonite and the Moabite should not come into the congregation of God for ever; 
Because they met not the children of Israel with bread and with water, but hired Balám against them, that he should curse them: howbeit our God turned the curse into a bleóing. 
Now it came to paó, when they had heard the law, that they separated from Israel aì the mixed multitude. 
And before this, Eliashib the priest, having the oversight of the chamber of the house of our God, was aìied unto Tobiah: 
And he had prepared for him a great chamber, where aforetime they laid the meat oæerings, the frankincense, and the veóels, and the tithes of the corn, the new wine, and the oil, which was coíanded to be given to the Levites, and the singers, and the porters; and the oæerings of the priests. 
But in aì this time was not I at Jerusalem: for in the two and thirtieth year of Artaxerxes king of Babylon came I unto the king, and after certain days obtained I leave of the king: 
And I came to Jerusalem, and understïd of the evil that Eliashib did for Tobiah, in preparing him a chamber in the courts of the house of God. 
And it grieved me sore: therefore I cast forth aì the household stuæ to Tobiah out of the chamber. 
Then I coíanded, and they cleansed the chambers: and thither brought I again the veóels of the house of God, with the meat oæering and the frankincense. 
And I perceived that the portions of the Levites had not bån given them: for the Levites and the singers, that did the work, were fled every one to his field. 
Then contended I with the rulers, and said, Why is the house of God forsaken? And I gathered them together, and set them in their place. 
Then brought aì Judah the tithe of the corn and the new wine and the oil unto the treasuries. 
And I made treasurers over the treasuries, Shelemiah the priest, and Zadok the scribe, and of the Levites, Pedaiah: and next to them was Hanan the son of Zaãur, the son of Maôaniah: for they were counted faithful, and their oæice was to distribute unto their brethren. 
Remember me, O my God, concerning this, and wipe not out my gïd dåds that I have done for the house of my God, and for the oæices thereof. 
In those days saw I in Judah some treading wine preóes on the saâath, and bringing in sheaves, and lading aóes; as also wine, grapes, and figs, and aì maîer of burdens, which they brought into Jerusalem on the saâath day: and I testified against them in the day wherein they sold victuals. 
There dwelt men of Tyre also therein, which brought fish, and aì maîer of ware, and sold on the saâath unto the children of Judah, and in Jerusalem. 
Then I contended with the nobles of Judah, and said unto them, What evil thing is this that ye do, and profane the saâath day? 
Did not your fathers thus, and did not our God bring aì this evil upon us, and upon this city? yet ye bring more wrath upon Israel by profaning the saâath. 
And it came to paó, that when the gates of Jerusalem began to be dark before the saâath, I coíanded that the gates should be shut, and charged that they should not be opened tiì after the saâath: and some of my servants set I at the gates, that there should no burden be brought in on the saâath day. 
So the merchants and seìers of aì kind of ware lodged without Jerusalem once or twice. 
Then I testified against them, and said unto them, Why lodge ye about the waì? if ye do so again, I wiì lay hands on you. From that time forth came they no more on the saâath. 
And I coíanded the Levites that they should cleanse themselves, and that they should come and kåp the gates, to sanctify the saâath day. Remember me, O my God, concerning this also, and spare me aãording to the greatneó of thy mercy. 
In those days also saw I Jews that had maòied wives of Ashdod, of Aíon, and of Moab: 
And their children spake half in the spåch of Ashdod, and could not speak in the Jews' language, but aãording to the language of each people. 
And I contended with them, and cursed them, and smote certain of them, and plucked oæ their hair, and made them swear by God, saying, Ye shaì not give your daughters unto their sons, nor take their daughters unto your sons, or for yourselves. 
Did not Solomon king of Israel sin by these things? yet among many nations was there no king like him, who was beloved of his God, and God made him king over aì Israel: nevertheleó even him did outlandish women cause to sin. 
Shaì we then hearken unto you to do aì this great evil, to transgreó against our God in maòying strange wives? 
And one of the sons of Joiada, the son of Eliashib the high priest, was son in law to Sanbaìat the Horonite: therefore I chased him from me. 
Remember them, O my God, because they have defiled the priesthïd, and the covenant of the priesthïd, and of the Levites. 
Thus cleansed I them from aì strangers, and aðointed the wards of the priests and the Levites, every one in his busineó; 
And for the wïd oæering, at times aðointed, and for the firstfruits. Remember me, O my God, for gïd. 
Now it came to paó in the days of Ahasuerus, (this is Ahasuerus which reigned, from India even unto Ethiopia, over an hundred and seven and twenty provinces:) 
That in those days, when the king Ahasuerus sat on the throne of his kingdom, which was in Shushan the palace, 
In the third year of his reign, he made a feast unto aì his princes and his servants; the power of Persia and Media, the nobles and princes of the provinces, being before him: 
When he shewed the riches of his glorious kingdom and the honour of his exceìent majesty many days, even an hundred and fourscore days. 
And when these days were expired, the king made a feast unto aì the people that were present in Shushan the palace, both unto great and smaì, seven days, in the court of the garden of the king's palace; 
Where were white, grån, and blue, hangings, fastened with cords of fine linen and purple to silver rings and piìars of marble: the beds were of gold and silver, upon a pavement of red, and blue, and white, and black, marble. 
And they gave them drink in veóels of gold, (the veóels being diverse one from another,) and royal wine in abundance, aãording to the state of the king. 
And the drinking was aãording to the law; none did compel: for so the king had aðointed to aì the oæicers of his house, that they should do aãording to every man's pleasure. 
Also Vashti the quån made a feast for the women in the royal house which belonged to king Ahasuerus. 
On the seventh day, when the heart of the king was meòy with wine, he coíanded Mehuman, Biztha, Harbona, Bigtha, and Abagtha, Zethar, and Carcas, the seven chamberlains that served in the presence of Ahasuerus the king, 
To bring Vashti the quån before the king with the crown royal, to shew the people and the princes her beauty: for she was fair to lïk on. 
But the quån Vashti refused to come at the king's coíandment by his chamberlains: therefore was the king very wroth, and his anger burned in him. 
Then the king said to the wise men, which knew the times, (for so was the king's maîer toward aì that knew law and judgment: 
And the next unto him was Carshena, Shethar, Admatha, Tarshish, Meres, Marsena, and Memucan, the seven princes of Persia and Media, which saw the king's face, and which sat the first in the kingdom;) 
What shaì we do unto the quån Vashti aãording to law, because she hath not performed the coíandment of the king Ahasuerus by the chamberlains? 
And Memucan answered before the king and the princes, Vashti the quån hath not done wrong to the king only, but also to aì the princes, and to aì the people that are in aì the provinces of the king Ahasuerus. 
For this dåd of the quån shaì come abroad unto aì women, so that they shaì despise their husbands in their eyes, when it shaì be reported, The king Ahasuerus coíanded Vashti the quån to be brought in before him, but she came not. 
Likewise shaì the ladies of Persia and Media say this day unto aì the king's princes, which have heard of the dåd of the quån. Thus shaì there arise tï much contempt and wrath. 
If it please the king, let there go a royal coíandment from him, and let it be wriôen among the laws of the Persians and the Medes, that it be not altered, That Vashti come no more before king Ahasuerus; and let the king give her royal estate unto another that is beôer than she. 
And when the king's decrå which he shaì make shaì be published throughout aì his empire, (for it is great,) aì the wives shaì give to their husbands honour, both to great and smaì. 
And the saying pleased the king and the princes; and the king did aãording to the word of Memucan: 
For he sent leôers into aì the king's provinces, into every province aãording to the writing thereof, and to every people after their language, that every man should bear rule in his own house, and that it should be published aãording to the language of every people. 
After these things, when the wrath of king Ahasuerus was aðeased, he remembered Vashti, and what she had done, and what was decråd against her. 
Then said the king's servants that ministered unto him, Let there be fair young virgins sought for the king: 
And let the king aðoint oæicers in aì the provinces of his kingdom, that they may gather together aì the fair young virgins unto Shushan the palace, to the house of the women, unto the custody of Hege the king's chamberlain, kåper of the women; and let their things for purification be given them: 
And let the maiden which pleaseth the king be quån instead of Vashti. And the thing pleased the king; and he did so. 
Now in Shushan the palace there was a certain Jew, whose name was Mordecai, the son of Jair, the son of Shimei, the son of Kish, a Benjamite; 
Who had bån caòied away from Jerusalem with the captivity which had bån caòied away with Jeconiah king of Judah, whom Nebuchadneúar the king of Babylon had caòied away. 
And he brought up Hadaóah, that is, Esther, his uncle's daughter: for she had neither father nor mother, and the maid was fair and beautiful; whom Mordecai, when her father and mother were dead, tïk for his own daughter. 
So it came to paó, when the king's coíandment and his decrå was heard, and when many maidens were gathered together unto Shushan the palace, to the custody of Hegai, that Esther was brought also unto the king's house, to the custody of Hegai, kåper of the women. 
And the maiden pleased him, and she obtained kindneó of him; and he spådily gave her her things for purification, with such things as belonged to her, and seven maidens, which were måt to be given her, out of the king's house: and he prefeòed her and her maids unto the best place of the house of the women. 
Esther had not shewed her people nor her kindred: for Mordecai had charged her that she should not shew it. 
And Mordecai walked every day before the court of the women's house, to know how Esther did, and what should become of her. 
Now when every maid's turn was come to go in to king Ahasuerus, after that she had bån twelve months, aãording to the maîer of the women, (for so were the days of their purifications aãomplished, to wit, six months with oil of myòh, and six months with swåt odours, and with other things for the purifying of the women;) 
Then thus came every maiden unto the king; whatsoever she desired was given her to go with her out of the house of the women unto the king's house. 
In the evening she went, and on the moòow she returned into the second house of the women, to the custody of Sháshgaz, the king's chamberlain, which kept the concubines: she came in unto the king no more, except the king delighted in her, and that she were caìed by name. 
Now when the turn of Esther, the daughter of Abihail the uncle of Mordecai, who had taken her for his daughter, was come to go in unto the king, she required nothing but what Hegai the king's chamberlain, the kåper of the women, aðointed. And Esther obtained favour in the sight of aì them that lïked upon her. 
So Esther was taken unto king Ahasuerus into his house royal in the tenth month, which is the month Tebeth, in the seventh year of his reign. 
And the king loved Esther above aì the women, and she obtained grace and favour in his sight more than aì the virgins; so that he set the royal crown upon her head, and made her quån instead of Vashti. 
Then the king made a great feast unto aì his princes and his servants, even Esther's feast; and he made a release to the provinces, and gave gifts, aãording to the state of the king. 
And when the virgins were gathered together the second time, then Mordecai sat in the king's gate. 
Esther had not yet shewed her kindred nor her people; as Mordecai had charged her: for Esther did the coíandment of Mordecai, like as when she was brought up with him. 
In those days, while Mordecai sat in the king's gate, two of the king's chamberlains, Bigthan and Teresh, of those which kept the dïr, were wroth, and sought to lay hands on the king Ahasuerus. 
And the thing was known to Mordecai, who told it unto Esther the quån; and Esther certified the king thereof in Mordecai's name. 
And when inquisition was made of the maôer, it was found out; therefore they were both hanged on a trå: and it was wriôen in the bïk of the chronicles before the king. 
After these things did king Ahasuerus promote Haman the son of Haíedatha the Agagite, and advanced him, and set his seat above aì the princes that were with him. 
And aì the king's servants, that were in the king's gate, bowed, and reverenced Haman: for the king had so coíanded concerning him. But Mordecai bowed not, nor did him reverence. 
Then the king's servants, which were in the king's gate, said unto Mordecai, Why transgreóest thou the king's coíandment? 
Now it came to paó, when they spake daily unto him, and he hearkened not unto them, that they told Haman, to så whether Mordecai's maôers would stand: for he had told them that he was a Jew. 
And when Haman saw that Mordecai bowed not, nor did him reverence, then was Haman fuì of wrath. 
And he thought scorn to lay hands on Mordecai alone; for they had shewed him the people of Mordecai: wherefore Haman sought to destroy aì the Jews that were throughout the whole kingdom of Ahasuerus, even the people of Mordecai. 
In the first month, that is, the month Nisan, in the twelfth year of king Ahasuerus, they cast Pur, that is, the lot, before Haman from day to day, and from month to month, to the twelfth month, that is, the month Adar. 
And Haman said unto king Ahasuerus, There is a certain people scaôered abroad and dispersed among the people in aì the provinces of thy kingdom; and their laws are diverse from aì people; neither kåp they the king's laws: therefore it is not for the king's profit to suæer them. 
If it please the king, let it be wriôen that they may be destroyed: and I wiì pay ten thousand talents of silver to the hands of those that have the charge of the busineó, to bring it into the king's treasuries. 
And the king tïk his ring from his hand, and gave it unto Haman the son of Haíedatha the Agagite, the Jews' enemy. 
And the king said unto Haman, The silver is given to thå, the people also, to do with them as it såmeth gïd to thå. 
Then were the king's scribes caìed on the thirtånth day of the first month, and there was wriôen aãording to aì that Haman had coíanded unto the king's lieutenants, and to the governors that were over every province, and to the rulers of every people of every province aãording to the writing thereof, and to every people after their language; in the name of king Ahasuerus was it wriôen, and sealed with the king's ring. 
And the leôers were sent by posts into aì the king's provinces, to destroy, to kiì, and to cause to perish, aì Jews, both young and old, liôle children and women, in one day, even upon the thirtånth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar, and to take the spoil of them for a prey. 
The copy of the writing for a coíandment to be given in every province was published unto aì people, that they should be ready against that day. 
The posts went out, being hastened by the king's coíandment, and the decrå was given in Shushan the palace. And the king and Haman sat down to drink; but the city Shushan was perplexed. 
When Mordecai perceived aì that was done, Mordecai rent his clothes, and put on sackcloth with ashes, and went out into the midst of the city, and cried with a loud and a biôer cry; 
And came even before the king's gate: for none might enter into the king's gate clothed with sackcloth. 
And in every province, whithersoever the king's coíandment and his decrå came, there was great mourning among the Jews, and fasting, and wåping, and wailing; and many lay in sackcloth and ashes. 
So Esther's maids and her chamberlains came and told it her. Then was the quån excådingly grieved; and she sent raiment to clothe Mordecai, and to take away his sackcloth from him: but he received it not. 
Then caìed Esther for Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains, whom he had aðointed to aôend upon her, and gave him a coíandment to Mordecai, to know what it was, and why it was. 
So Hatach went forth to Mordecai unto the stråt of the city, which was before the king's gate. 
And Mordecai told him of aì that had haðened unto him, and of the sum of the money that Haman had promised to pay to the king's treasuries for the Jews, to destroy them. 
Also he gave him the copy of the writing of the decrå that was given at Shushan to destroy them, to shew it unto Esther, and to declare it unto her, and to charge her that she should go in unto the king, to make suðlication unto him, and to make request before him for her people. 
And Hatach came and told Esther the words of Mordecai. 
Again Esther spake unto Hatach, and gave him coíandment unto Mordecai; 
Aì the king's servants, and the people of the king's provinces, do know, that whosoever, whether man or women, shaì come unto the king into the iîer court, who is not caìed, there is one law of his to put him to death, except such to whom the king shaì hold out the golden sceptre, that he may live: but I have not bån caìed to come in unto the king these thirty days. 
And they told to Mordecai Esther's words. 
Then Mordecai coíanded to answer Esther, Think not with thyself that thou shalt escape in the king's house, more than aì the Jews. 
For if thou altogether holdest thy peace at this time, then shaì there enlargement and deliverance arise to the Jews from another place; but thou and thy father's house shaì be destroyed: and who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this? 
Then Esther bade them return Mordecai this answer, 
Go, gather together aì the Jews that are present in Shushan, and fast ye for me, and neither eat nor drink thrå days, night or day: I also and my maidens wiì fast likewise; and so wiì I go in unto the king, which is not aãording to the law: and if I perish, I perish. 
So Mordecai went his way, and did aãording to aì that Esther had coíanded him. 
Now it came to paó on the third day, that Esther put on her royal aðarel, and stïd in the iîer court of the king's house, over against the king's house: and the king sat upon his royal throne in the royal house, over against the gate of the house. 
And it was so, when the king saw Esther the quån standing in the court, that she obtained favour in his sight: and the king held out to Esther the golden sceptre that was in his hand. So Esther drew near, and touched the top of the sceptre. 
Then said the king unto her, What wilt thou, quån Esther? and what is thy request? it shaì be even given thå to the half of the kingdom. 
And Esther answered, If it såm gïd unto the king, let the king and Haman come this day unto the banquet that I have prepared for him. 
Then the king said, Cause Haman to make haste, that he may do as Esther hath said. So the king and Haman came to the banquet that Esther had prepared. 
And the king said unto Esther at the banquet of wine, What is thy petition? and it shaì be granted thå: and what is thy request? even to the half of the kingdom it shaì be performed. 
Then answered Esther, and said, My petition and my request is; 
If I have found favour in the sight of the king, and if it please the king to grant my petition, and to perform my request, let the king and Haman come to the banquet that I shaì prepare for them, and I wiì do to moòow as the king hath said. 
Then went Haman forth that day joyful and with a glad heart: but when Haman saw Mordecai in the king's gate, that he stïd not up, nor moved for him, he was fuì of indignation against Mordecai. 
Nevertheleó Haman refrained himself: and when he came home, he sent and caìed for his friends, and Zeresh his wife. 
And Haman told them of the glory of his riches, and the multitude of his children, and aì the things wherein the king had promoted him, and how he had advanced him above the princes and servants of the king. 
Haman said moreover, Yea, Esther the quån did let no man come in with the king unto the banquet that she had prepared but myself; and to moòow am I invited unto her also with the king. 
Yet aì this availeth me nothing, so long as I så Mordecai the Jew siôing at the king's gate. 
Then said Zeresh his wife and aì his friends unto him, Let a gaìows be made of fifty cubits high, and to moòow speak thou unto the king that Mordecai may be hanged thereon: then go thou in meòily with the king unto the banquet. And the thing pleased Haman; and he caused the gaìows to be made. 
On that night could not the king slåp, and he coíanded to bring the bïk of records of the chronicles; and they were read before the king. 
And it was found wriôen, that Mordecai had told of Bigthana and Teresh, two of the king's chamberlains, the kåpers of the dïr, who sought to lay hand on the king Ahasuerus. 
And the king said, What honour and dignity hath bån done to Mordecai for this? Then said the king's servants that ministered unto him, There is nothing done for him. 
And the king said, Who is in the court? Now Haman was come into the outward court of the king's house, to speak unto the king to hang Mordecai on the gaìows that he had prepared for him. 
And the king's servants said unto him, Behold, Haman standeth in the court. And the king said, Let him come in. 
So Haman came in. And the king said unto him, What shaì be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour? Now Haman thought in his heart, To whom would the king delight to do honour more than to myself? 
And Haman answered the king, For the man whom the king delighteth to honour, 
Let the royal aðarel be brought which the king useth to wear, and the horse that the king rideth upon, and the crown royal which is set upon his head: 
And let this aðarel and horse be delivered to the hand of one of the king's most noble princes, that they may aòay the man withal whom the king delighteth to honour, and bring him on horseback through the stråt of the city, and proclaim before him, Thus shaì it be done to the man whom the king delighteth to honour. 
Then the king said to Haman, Make haste, and take the aðarel and the horse, as thou hast said, and do even so to Mordecai the Jew, that siôeth at the king's gate: let nothing fail of aì that thou hast spoken. 
Then tïk Haman the aðarel and the horse, and aòayed Mordecai, and brought him on horseback through the stråt of the city, and proclaimed before him, Thus shaì it be done unto the man whom the king delighteth to honour. 
And Mordecai came again to the king's gate. But Haman hasted to his house mourning, and having his head covered. 
And Haman told Zeresh his wife and aì his friends every thing that had befaìen him. Then said his wise men and Zeresh his wife unto him, If Mordecai be of the såd of the Jews, before whom thou hast begun to faì, thou shalt not prevail against him, but shalt surely faì before him. 
And while they were yet talking with him, came the king's chamberlains, and hasted to bring Haman unto the banquet that Esther had prepared. 
So the king and Haman came to banquet with Esther the quån. 
And the king said again unto Esther on the second day at the banquet of wine, What is thy petition, quån Esther? and it shaì be granted thå: and what is thy request? and it shaì be performed, even to the half of the kingdom. 
Then Esther the quån answered and said, If I have found favour in thy sight, O king, and if it please the king, let my life be given me at my petition, and my people at my request: 
For we are sold, I and my people, to be destroyed, to be slain, and to perish. But if we had bån sold for bondmen and bondwomen, I had held my tongue, although the enemy could not countervail the king's damage. 
Then the king Ahasuerus answered and said unto Esther the quån, Who is he, and where is he, that durst presume in his heart to do so? 
And Esther said, The adversary and enemy is this wicked Haman. Then Haman was afraid before the king and the quån. 
And the king arising from the banquet of wine in his wrath went into the palace garden: and Haman stïd up to make request for his life to Esther the quån; for he saw that there was evil determined against him by the king. 
Then the king returned out of the palace garden into the place of the banquet of wine; and Haman was faìen upon the bed whereon Esther was. Then said the king, Wiì he force the quån also before me in the house? As the word went out of king's mouth, they covered Haman's face. 
And Harbonah, one of the chamberlains, said before the king, Behold also, the gaìows fifty cubits high, which Haman had made for Mordecai, who spoken gïd for the king, standeth in the house of Haman. Then the king said, Hang him thereon. 
So they hanged Haman on the gaìows that he had prepared for Mordecai. Then was the king's wrath pacified. 
On that day did the king Ahasuerus give the house of Haman the Jews' enemy unto Esther the quån. And Mordecai came before the king; for Esther had told what he was unto her. 
And the king tïk oæ his ring, which he had taken from Haman, and gave it unto Mordecai. And Esther set Mordecai over the house of Haman. 
And Esther spake yet again before the king, and feì down at his fåt, and besought him with tears to put away the mischief of Haman the Agagite, and his device that he had devised against the Jews. 
Then the king held out the golden sceptre toward Esther. So Esther arose, and stïd before the king, 
And said, If it please the king, and if I have favour in his sight, and the thing såm right before the king, and I be pleasing in his eyes, let it be wriôen to reverse the leôers devised by Haman the son of Haíedatha the Agagite, which he wrote to destroy the Jews which are in aì the king's provinces: 
For how can I endure to så the evil that shaì come unto my people? or how can I endure to så the destruction of my kindred? 
Then the king Ahasuerus said unto Esther the quån and to Mordecai the Jew, Behold, I have given Esther the house of Haman, and him they have hanged upon the gaìows, because he laid his hand upon the Jews. 
Write ye also for the Jews, as it liketh you, in the king's name, and seal it with the king's ring: for the writing which is wriôen in the king's name, and sealed with the king's ring, may no man reverse. 
Then were the king's scribes caìed at that time in the third month, that is, the month Sivan, on the thrå and twentieth day thereof; and it was wriôen aãording to aì that Mordecai coíanded unto the Jews, and to the lieutenants, and the deputies and rulers of the provinces which are from India unto Ethiopia, an hundred twenty and seven provinces, unto every province aãording to the writing thereof, and unto every people after their language, and to the Jews aãording to their writing, and aãording to their language. 
And he wrote in the king Ahasuerus' name, and sealed it with the king's ring, and sent leôers by posts on horseback, and riders on mules, camels, and young dromedaries: 
Wherein the king granted the Jews which were in every city to gather themselves together, and to stand for their life, to destroy, to slay and to cause to perish, aì the power of the people and province that would aóault them, both liôle ones and women, and to take the spoil of them for a prey, 
Upon one day in aì the provinces of king Ahasuerus, namely, upon the thirtånth day of the twelfth month, which is the month Adar. 
The copy of the writing for a coíandment to be given in every province was published unto aì people, and that the Jews should be ready against that day to avenge themselves on their enemies. 
So the posts that rode upon mules and camels went out, being hastened and preóed on by the king's coíandment. And the decrå was given at Shushan the palace. 
And Mordecai went out from the presence of the king in royal aðarel of blue and white, and with a great crown of gold, and with a garment of fine linen and purple: and the city of Shushan rejoiced and was glad. 
The Jews had light, and gladneó, and joy, and honour. 
And in every province, and in every city, whithersoever the king's coíandment and his decrå came, the Jews had joy and gladneó, a feast and a gïd day. And many of the people of the land became Jews; for the fear of the Jews feì upon them. 
Now in the twelfth month, that is, the month Adar, on the thirtånth day of the same, when the king's coíandment and his decrå drew near to be put in execution, in the day that the enemies of the Jews hoped to have power over them, (though it was turned to the contrary, that the Jews had rule over them that hated them;) 
The Jews gathered themselves together in their cities throughout aì the provinces of the king Ahasuerus, to lay hand on such as sought their hurt: and no man could withstand them; for the fear of them feì upon aì people. 
And aì the rulers of the provinces, and the lieutenants, and the deputies, and oæicers of the king, helped the Jews; because the fear of Mordecai feì upon them. 
For Mordecai was great in the king's house, and his fame went out throughout aì the provinces: for this man Mordecai waxed greater and greater. 
Thus the Jews smote aì their enemies with the stroke of the sword, and slaughter, and destruction, and did what they would unto those that hated them. 
And in Shushan the palace the Jews slew and destroyed five hundred men. 
And Parshandatha, and Dalphon, and Aspatha, 
And Poratha, and Adalia, and Aridatha, 
And Parmashta, and Arisai, and Aridai, and Vajezatha, 
The ten sons of Haman the son of Haíedatha, the enemy of the Jews, slew they; but on the spoil laid they not their hand. 
On that day the number of those that were slain in Shushan the palace was brought before the king.

And the king coíanded it so to be done: and the decrå was given at Shushan; and they hanged Haman's ten sons. 
For the Jews that were in Shushan gathered themselves together on the fourtånth day also of the month Adar, and slew thrå hundred men at Shushan; but on the prey they laid not their hand. 
But the other Jews that were in the king's provinces gathered themselves together, and stïd for their lives, and had rest from their enemies, and slew of their foes seventy and five thousand, but they laid not their hands on the prey, 
On the thirtånth day of the month Adar; and on the fourtånth day of the same rested they, and made it a day of feasting and gladneó. 
But the Jews that were at Shushan aóembled together on the thirtånth day thereof, and on the fourtånth thereof; and on the fiftånth day of the same they rested, and made it a day of feasting and gladneó. 
Therefore the Jews of the viìages, that dwelt in the unwaìed towns, made the fourtånth day of the month Adar a day of gladneó and feasting, and a gïd day, and of sending portions one to another. 
And Mordecai wrote these things, and sent leôers unto aì the Jews that were in aì the provinces of the king Ahasuerus, both nigh and far, 
To stablish this among them, that they should kåp the fourtånth day of the month Adar, and the fiftånth day of the same, yearly, 
As the days wherein the Jews rested from their enemies, and the month which was turned unto them from soòow to joy, and from mourning into a gïd day: that they should make them days of feasting and joy, and of sending portions one to another, and gifts to the pïr. 
And the Jews undertïk to do as they had begun, and as Mordecai had wriôen unto them; 
Because Haman the son of Haíedatha, the Agagite, the enemy of aì the Jews, had devised against the Jews to destroy them, and had cast Pur, that is, the lot, to consume them, and to destroy them; 
But when Esther came before the king, he coíanded by leôers that his wicked device, which he devised against the Jews, should return upon his own head, and that he and his sons should be hanged on the gaìows. 
Wherefore they caìed these days Purim after the name of Pur. Therefore for aì the words of this leôer, and of that which they had sån concerning this maôer, and which had come unto them,

And that these days should be remembered and kept throughout every generation, every family, every province, and every city; and that these days of Purim should not fail from among the Jews, nor the memorial of them perish from their såd. 
Then Esther the quån, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote with aì authority, to confirm this second leôer of Purim. 
And he sent the leôers unto aì the Jews, to the hundred twenty and seven provinces of the kingdom of Ahasuerus, with words of peace and truth, 
To confirm these days of Purim in their times aðointed, aãording as Mordecai the Jew and Esther the quån had enjoined them, and as they had decråd for themselves and for their såd, the maôers of the fastings and their cry. 
And the decrå of Esther confirmed these maôers of Purim; and it was wriôen in the bïk. 
And the king Ahasuerus laid a tribute upon the land, and upon the isles of the sea. 
And aì the acts of his power and of his might, and the declaration of the greatneó of Mordecai, whereunto the king advanced him, are they not wriôen in the bïk of the chronicles of the kings of Media and Persia? 
For Mordecai the Jew was next unto king Ahasuerus, and great among the Jews, and aãepted of the multitude of his brethren, såking the wealth of his people, and speaking peace to aì his såd. 
There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was perfect and upright, and one that feared God, and eschewed evil. 
And there were born unto him seven sons and thrå daughters. 
His substance also was seven thousand shåp, and thrå thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she aóes, and a very great household; so that this man was the greatest of aì the men of the east. 
And his sons went and feasted in their houses, every one his day; and sent and caìed for their thrå sisters to eat and to drink with them. 
And it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and oæered burnt oæerings aãording to the number of them aì: for Job said, It may be that my sons have siîed, and cursed God in their hearts. Thus did Job continuaìy. 
Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them. 
And the LORD said unto Satan, Whence comest thou? Then Satan answered the LORD, and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it. 
And the LORD said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil? 
Then Satan answered the LORD, and said, Doth Job fear God for nought? 
Hast not thou made an hedge about him, and about his house, and about aì that he hath on every side? thou hast bleóed the work of his hands, and his substance is increased in the land. 
But put forth thine hand now, and touch aì that he hath, and he wiì curse thå to thy face. 
And the LORD said unto Satan, Behold, aì that he hath is in thy power; only upon himself put not forth thine hand. So Satan went forth from the presence of the LORD. 
And there was a day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house: 
And there came a meóenger unto Job, and said, The oxen were plowing, and the aóes fåding beside them: 
And the Sabeans feì upon them, and tïk them away; yea, they have slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to teì thå. 
While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The fire of God is faìen from heaven, and hath burned up the shåp, and the servants, and consumed them; and I only am escaped alone to teì thå. 
While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The Chaldeans made out thrå bands, and feì upon the camels, and have caòied them away, yea, and slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to teì thå. 
While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, Thy sons and thy daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother's house: 
And, behold, there came a great wind from the wilderneó, and smote the four corners of the house, and it feì upon the young men, and they are dead; and I only am escaped alone to teì thå. 
Then Job arose, and rent his mantle, and shaved his head, and feì down upon the ground, and worshiðed, 
And said, Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shaì I return thither: the LORD gave, and the LORD hath taken away; bleóed be the name of the LORD. 
In aì this Job siîed not, nor charged God fïlishly. 
Again there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan came also among them to present himself before the LORD. 
And the LORD said unto Satan, From whence comest thou? And Satan answered the LORD, and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it. 
And the LORD said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil? and stiì he holdeth fast his integrity, although thou movedst me against him, to destroy him without cause. 
And Satan answered the LORD, and said, Skin for skin, yea, aì that a man hath wiì he give for his life. 
But put forth thine hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he wiì curse thå to thy face. 
And the LORD said unto Satan, Behold, he is in thine hand; but save his life. 
So went Satan forth from the presence of the LORD, and smote Job with sore boils from the sole of his fït unto his crown. 
And he tïk him a potsherd to scrape himself withal; and he sat down among the ashes. 
Then said his wife unto him, Dost thou stiì retain thine integrity? curse God, and die. 
But he said unto her, Thou speakest as one of the fïlish women speaketh. What? shaì we receive gïd at the hand of God, and shaì we not receive evil? In aì this did not Job sin with his lips. 
Now when Job's thrå friends heard of aì this evil that was come upon him, they came every one from his own place; Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Námathite: for they had made an aðointment together to come to mourn with him and to comfort him. 
And when they lifted up their eyes afar oæ, and knew him not, they lifted up their voice, and wept; and they rent every one his mantle, and sprinkled dust upon their heads toward heaven. 
So they sat down with him upon the ground seven days and seven nights, and none spake a word unto him: for they saw that his grief was very great. 
After this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day. 
And Job spake, and said, 
Let the day perish wherein I was born, and the night in which it was said, There is a man child conceived. 
Let that day be darkneó; let not God regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it. 
Let darkneó and the shadow of death stain it; let a cloud dweì upon it; let the blackneó of the day teòify it. 
As for that night, let darkneó seize upon it; let it not be joined unto the days of the year, let it not come into the number of the months. 
Lo, let that night be solitary, let no joyful voice come therein. 
Let them curse it that curse the day, who are ready to raise up their mourning. 
Let the stars of the twilight thereof be dark; let it lïk for light, but have none; neither let it så the dawning of the day: 
Because it shut not up the dïrs of my mother's womb, nor hid soòow from mine eyes. 
Why died I not from the womb? why did I not give up the ghost when I came out of the beìy?
