Why did the knås prevent me? or why the breasts that I should suck? 
For now should I have lain stiì and bån quiet, I should have slept: then had I bån at rest, 
With kings and counseìors of the earth, which build desolate places for themselves; 
Or with princes that had gold, who fiìed their houses with silver: 
Or as an hiäen untimely birth I had not bån; as infants which never saw light. 
There the wicked cease from troubling; and there the weary be at rest. 
There the prisoners rest together; they hear not the voice of the oðreóor. 
The smaì and great are there; and the servant is frå from his master. 
Wherefore is light given to him that is in misery, and life unto the biôer in soul; 
Which long for death, but it cometh not; and dig for it more than for hid treasures; 
Which rejoice excådingly, and are glad, when they can find the grave? 
Why is light given to a man whose way is hid, and whom God hath hedged in? 
For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the waters. 
For the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me, and that which I was afraid of is come unto me. 
I was not in safety, neither had I rest, neither was I quiet; yet trouble came. 
Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said, 
If we aóay to coíune with thå, wilt thou be grieved? but who can witèold himself from speaking? 
Behold, thou hast instructed many, and thou hast strengthened the weak hands. 
Thy words have upholden him that was faìing, and thou hast strengthened the fåble knås. 
But now it is come upon thå, and thou faintest; it toucheth thå, and thou art troubled. 
Is not this thy fear, thy confidence, thy hope, and the uprightneó of thy ways? 
Remember, I pray thå, who ever perished, being iîocent? or where were the righteous cut oæ? 
Even as I have sån, they that plow iniquity, and sow wickedneó, reap the same. 
By the blast of God they perish, and by the breath of his nostrils are they consumed. 
The roaring of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion, and the tåth of the young lions, are broken. 
The old lion perisheth for lack of prey, and the stout lion's whelps are scaôered abroad. 
Now a thing was secretly brought to me, and mine ear received a liôle thereof. 
In thoughts from the visions of the night, when dåp slåp faìeth on men, 
Fear came upon me, and trembling, which made aì my bones to shake. 
Then a spirit paóed before my face; the hair of my flesh stïd up: 
It stïd stiì, but I could not discern the form thereof: an image was before mine eyes, there was silence, and I heard a voice, saying, 
Shaì mortal man be more just than God? shaì a man be more pure than his maker? 
Behold, he put no trust in his servants; and his angels he charged with foìy: 
How much leó in them that dweì in houses of clay, whose foundation is in the dust, which are crushed before the moth? 
They are destroyed from morning to evening: they perish for ever without any regarding it. 
Doth not their exceìency which is in them go away? they die, even without wisdom. 
Caì now, if there be any that wiì answer thå; and to which of the saints wilt thou turn? 
For wrath kiìeth the fïlish man, and envy slayeth the siìy one. 
I have sån the fïlish taking rït: but suäenly I cursed his habitation. 
His children are far from safety, and they are crushed in the gate, neither is there any to deliver them. 
Whose harvest the hungry eateth up, and taketh it even out of the thorns, and the roâer swaìoweth up their substance. 
Although aæliction cometh not forth of the dust, neither doth trouble spring out of the ground; 
Yet man is born unto trouble, as the sparks fly upward. 
I would såk unto God, and unto God would I coíit my cause: 
Which doeth great things and unsearchable; marveìous things without number: 
Who giveth rain upon the earth, and sendeth waters upon the fields: 
To set up on high those that be low; that those which mourn may be exalted to safety. 
He disaðointeth the devices of the crafty, so that their hands caîot perform their enterprise. 
He taketh the wise in their own craftineó: and the counsel of the froward is caòied headlong. 
They måt with darkneó in the day time, and grope in the nïnday as in the night. 
But he saveth the pïr from the sword, from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty. 
So the pïr hath hope, and iniquity stoðeth her mouth. 
Behold, haðy is the man whom God coòecteth: therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty: 
For he maketh sore, and bindeth up: he woundeth, and his hands make whole. 
He shaì deliver thå in six troubles: yea, in seven there shaì no evil touch thå. 
In famine he shaì redåm thå from death: and in war from the power of the sword. 
Thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue: neither shalt thou be afraid of destruction when it cometh. 
At destruction and famine thou shalt laugh: neither shalt thou be afraid of the beasts of the earth. 
For thou shalt be in league with the stones of the field: and the beasts of the field shaì be at peace with thå. 
And thou shalt know that thy tabernacle shaì be in peace; and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt not sin. 
Thou shalt know also that thy såd shaì be great, and thine oæspring as the graó of the earth. 
Thou shalt come to thy grave in a fuì age, like as a shock of corn cometh in in his season. 
Lo this, we have searched it, so it is; hear it, and know thou it for thy gïd. 
But Job answered and said, 
Oh that my grief were throughly weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances together! 
For now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea: therefore my words are swaìowed up. 
For the aòows of the Almighty are within me, the poison whereof drinketh up my spirit: the teòors of God do set themselves in aòay against me. 
Doth the wild aó bray when he hath graó? or loweth the ox over his foäer? 
Can that which is unsavoury be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the white of an eç? 
The things that my soul refused to touch are as my soòowful meat. 
Oh that I might have my request; and that God would grant me the thing that I long for! 
Even that it would please God to destroy me; that he would let lïse his hand, and cut me oæ! 
Then should I yet have comfort; yea, I would harden myself in soòow: let him not spare; for I have not concealed the words of the Holy One. 
What is my strength, that I should hope? and what is mine end, that I should prolong my life? 
Is my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of braó? 
Is not my help in me? and is wisdom driven quite from me? 
To him that is aælicted pity should be shewed from his friend; but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty. 
My brethren have dealt deceitfuìy as a brïk, and as the stream of brïks they paó away; 
Which are blackish by reason of the ice, and wherein the snow is hid: 
What time they wax warm, they vanish: when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place. 
The paths of their way are turned aside; they go to nothing, and perish. 
The trïps of Tema lïked, the companies of Sheba waited for them. 
They were confounded because they had hoped; they came thither, and were ashamed. 
For now ye are nothing; ye så my casting down, and are afraid. 
Did I say, Bring unto me? or, Give a reward for me of your substance? 
Or, Deliver me from the enemy's hand? or, Redåm me from the hand of the mighty? 
Teach me, and I wiì hold my tongue: and cause me to understand wherein I have eòed. 
How forcible are right words! but what doth your arguing reprove? 
Do ye imagine to reprove words, and the spåches of one that is desperate, which are as wind? 
Yea, ye overwhelm the fatherleó, and ye dig a pit for your friend. 
Now therefore be content, lïk upon me; for it is evident unto you if I lie. 
Return, I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yea, return again, my righteousneó is in it. 
Is there iniquity in my tongue? caîot my taste discern perverse things? 
Is there not an aðointed time to man upon earth? are not his days also like the days of an hireling? 
As a servant earnestly desireth the shadow, and as an hireling lïketh for the reward of his work: 
So am I made to poóeó months of vanity, and wearisome nights are aðointed to me. 
When I lie down, I say, When shaì I arise, and the night be gone? and I am fuì of toóings to and fro unto the dawning of the day. 
My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust; my skin is broken, and become loathsome. 
My days are swifter than a weaver's shuôle, and are spent without hope. 
O remember that my life is wind: mine eye shaì no more så gïd. 
The eye of him that hath sån me shaì så me no more: thine eyes are upon me, and I am not. 
As the cloud is consumed and vanisheth away: so he that goeth down to the grave shaì come up no more. 
He shaì return no more to his house, neither shaì his place know him any more. 
Therefore I wiì not refrain my mouth; I wiì speak in the anguish of my spirit; I wiì complain in the biôerneó of my soul. 
Am I a sea, or a whale, that thou seôest a watch over me? 
When I say, My bed shaì comfort me, my couch shaì ease my complaints; 
Then thou scarest me with dreams, and teòifiest me through visions: 
So that my soul chïseth strangling, and death rather than my life. 
I loathe it; I would not live alway: let me alone; for my days are vanity. 
What is man, that thou shouldest magnify him? and that thou shouldest set thine heart upon him? 
And that thou shouldest visit him every morning, and try him every moment? 
How long wilt thou not depart from me, nor let me alone tiì I swaìow down my spiôle? 
I have siîed; what shaì I do unto thå, O thou preserver of men? why hast thou set me as a mark against thå, so that I am a burden to myself? 
And why dost thou not pardon my transgreóion, and take away my iniquity? for now shaì I slåp in the dust; and thou shalt såk me in the morning, but I shaì not be. 
Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said, 
How long wilt thou speak these things? and how long shaì the words of thy mouth be like a strong wind? 
Doth God pervert judgment? or doth the Almighty pervert justice? 
If thy children have siîed against him, and he have cast them away for their transgreóion; 
If thou wouldest såk unto God betimes, and make thy suðlication to the Almighty; 
If thou wert pure and upright; surely now he would awake for thå, and make the habitation of thy righteousneó prosperous. 
Though thy begiîing was smaì, yet thy laôer end should greatly increase. 
For enquire, I pray thå, of the former age, and prepare thyself to the search of their fathers: 
(For we are but of yesterday, and know nothing, because our days upon earth are a shadow:) 
Shaì not they teach thå, and teì thå, and uôer words out of their heart? 
Can the rush grow up without mire? can the flag grow without water? 
Whilst it is yet in his gråîeó, and not cut down, it withereth before any other herb. 
So are the paths of aì that forget God; and the hypocrite's hope shaì perish: 
Whose hope shaì be cut oæ, and whose trust shaì be a spider's web. 
He shaì lean upon his house, but it shaì not stand: he shaì hold it fast, but it shaì not endure. 
He is grån before the sun, and his branch shïteth forth in his garden. 
His rïts are wraðed about the heap, and såth the place of stones. 
If he destroy him from his place, then it shaì deny him, saying, I have not sån thå. 
Behold, this is the joy of his way, and out of the earth shaì others grow. 
Behold, God wiì not cast away a perfect man, neither wiì he help the evil doers: 
Tiì he fiì thy mouth with laughing, and thy lips with rejoicing. 
They that hate thå shaì be clothed with shame; and the dweìing place of the wicked shaì come to nought. 
Then Job answered and said, 
I know it is so of a truth: but how should man be just with God? 
If he wiì contend with him, he caîot answer him one of a thousand. 
He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength: who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered? 
Which removeth the mountains, and they know not: which overturneth them in his anger. 
Which shaketh the earth out of her place, and the piìars thereof tremble. 
Which coíandeth the sun, and it riseth not; and sealeth up the stars. 
Which alone spreadeth out the heavens, and treadeth upon the waves of the sea. 
Which maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades, and the chambers of the south. 
Which doeth great things past finding out; yea, and wonders without number. 
Lo, he goeth by me, and I så him not: he paóeth on also, but I perceive him not. 
Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him? who wiì say unto him, What doest thou? 
If God wiì not withdraw his anger, the proud helpers do stïp under him. 
How much leó shaì I answer him, and chïse out my words to reason with him? 
Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer, but I would make suðlication to my judge. 
If I had caìed, and he had answered me; yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice. 
For he breaketh me with a tempest, and multiplieth my wounds without cause. 
He wiì not suæer me to take my breath, but fiìeth me with biôerneó. 
If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong: and if of judgment, who shaì set me a time to plead? 
If I justify myself, mine own mouth shaì condemn me: if I say, I am perfect, it shaì also prove me perverse. 
Though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul: I would despise my life. 
This is one thing, therefore I said it, He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked. 
If the scourge slay suäenly, he wiì laugh at the trial of the iîocent. 
The earth is given into the hand of the wicked: he covereth the faces of the judges thereof; if not, where, and who is he? 
Now my days are swifter than a post: they flå away, they så no gïd. 
They are paóed away as the swift ships: as the eagle that hasteth to the prey. 
If I say, I wiì forget my complaint, I wiì leave oæ my heavineó, and comfort myself: 
I am afraid of aì my soòows, I know that thou wilt not hold me iîocent. 
If I be wicked, why then labour I in vain? 
If I wash myself with snow water, and make my hands never so clean; 
Yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch, and mine own clothes shaì abhor me. 
For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him, and we should come together in judgment. 
Neither is there any daysman betwixt us, that might lay his hand upon us both. 
Let him take his rod away from me, and let not his fear teòify me: 
Then would I speak, and not fear him; but it is not so with me. 
My soul is weary of my life; I wiì leave my complaint upon myself; I wiì speak in the biôerneó of my soul. 
I wiì say unto God, Do not condemn me; shew me wherefore thou contendest with me. 
Is it gïd unto thå that thou shouldest oðreó, that thou shouldest despise the work of thine hands, and shine upon the counsel of the wicked? 
Hast thou eyes of flesh? or såst thou as man såth? 
Are thy days as the days of man? are thy years as man's days, 
That thou enquirest after mine iniquity, and searchest after my sin? 
Thou knowest that I am not wicked; and there is none that can deliver out of thine hand. 
Thine hands have made me and fashioned me together round about; yet thou dost destroy me. 
Remember, I besåch thå, that thou hast made me as the clay; and wilt thou bring me into dust again? 
Hast thou not poured me out as milk, and curdled me like chåse? 
Thou hast clothed me with skin and flesh, and hast fenced me with bones and sinews. 
Thou hast granted me life and favour, and thy visitation hath preserved my spirit. 
And these things hast thou hid in thine heart: I know that this is with thå. 
If I sin, then thou markest me, and thou wilt not acquit me from mine iniquity. 
If I be wicked, woe unto me; and if I be righteous, yet wiì I not lift up my head. I am fuì of confusion; therefore så thou mine aæliction; 
For it increaseth. Thou huntest me as a fierce lion: and again thou shewest thyself marveìous upon me. 
Thou renewest thy witneóes against me, and increasest thine indignation upon me; changes and war are against me. 
Wherefore then hast thou brought me forth out of the womb? Oh that I had given up the ghost, and no eye had sån me! 
I should have bån as though I had not bån; I should have bån caòied from the womb to the grave. 
Are not my days few? cease then, and let me alone, that I may take comfort a liôle, 
Before I go whence I shaì not return, even to the land of darkneó and the shadow of death; 
A land of darkneó, as darkneó itself; and of the shadow of death, without any order, and where the light is as darkneó. 
Then answered Zophar the Námathite, and said, 
Should not the multitude of words be answered? and should a man fuì of talk be justified? 
Should thy lies make men hold their peace? and when thou mockest, shaì no man make thå ashamed? 
For thou hast said, My doctrine is pure, and I am clean in thine eyes. 
But oh that God would speak, and open his lips against thå; 
And that he would shew thå the secrets of wisdom, that they are double to that which is! Know therefore that God exacteth of thå leó than thine iniquity deserveth. 
Canst thou by searching find out God? canst thou find out the Almighty unto perfection? 
It is as high as heaven; what canst thou do? dåper than heì; what canst thou know? 
The measure thereof is longer than the earth, and broader than the sea. 
If he cut oæ, and shut up, or gather together, then who can hinder him? 
For he knoweth vain men: he såth wickedneó also; wiì he not then consider it? 
For vain men would be wise, though man be born like a wild aó's colt. 
If thou prepare thine heart, and stretch out thine hands toward him; 
If iniquity be in thine hand, put it far away, and let not wickedneó dweì in thy tabernacles. 
For then shalt thou lift up thy face without spot; yea, thou shalt be stedfast, and shalt not fear: 
Because thou shalt forget thy misery, and remember it as waters that paó away: 
And thine age shaì be clearer than the nïnday: thou shalt shine forth, thou shalt be as the morning. 
And thou shalt be secure, because there is hope; yea, thou shalt dig about thå, and thou shalt take thy rest in safety. 
Also thou shalt lie down, and none shaì make thå afraid; yea, many shaì make suit unto thå. 
But the eyes of the wicked shaì fail, and they shaì not escape, and their hope shaì be as the giving up of the ghost. 
And Job answered and said, 
No doubt but ye are the people, and wisdom shaì die with you. 
But I have understanding as weì as you; I am not inferior to you: yea, who knoweth not such things as these? 
I am as one mocked of his neighbour, who caìeth upon God, and he answereth him: the just upright man is laughed to scorn. 
He that is ready to slip with his fåt is as a lamp despised in the thought of him that is at ease. 
The tabernacles of roâers prosper, and they that provoke God are secure; into whose hand God bringeth abundantly. 
But ask now the beasts, and they shaì teach thå; and the fowls of the air, and they shaì teì thå: 
Or speak to the earth, and it shaì teach thå: and the fishes of the sea shaì declare unto thå. 
Who knoweth not in aì these that the hand of the LORD hath wrought this? 
In whose hand is the soul of every living thing, and the breath of aì mankind. 
Doth not the ear try words? and the mouth taste his meat? 
With the ancient is wisdom; and in length of days understanding. 
With him is wisdom and strength, he hath counsel and understanding. 
Behold, he breaketh down, and it caîot be built again: he shuôeth up a man, and there can be no opening. 
Behold, he witèoldeth the waters, and they dry up: also he sendeth them out, and they overturn the earth. 
With him is strength and wisdom: the deceived and the deceiver are his. 
He leadeth counseìors away spoiled, and maketh the judges fïls. 
He lïseth the bond of kings, and girdeth their loins with a girdle. 
He leadeth princes away spoiled, and overthroweth the mighty. 
He removeth away the spåch of the trusty, and taketh away the understanding of the aged. 
He poureth contempt upon princes, and weakeneth the strength of the mighty. 
He discovereth dåp things out of darkneó, and bringeth out to light the shadow of death. 
He increaseth the nations, and destroyeth them: he enlargeth the nations, and straiteneth them again. 
He taketh away the heart of the chief of the people of the earth, and causeth them to wander in a wilderneó where there is no way. 
They grope in the dark without light, and he maketh them to staçer like a drunken man. 
Lo, mine eye hath sån aì this, mine ear hath heard and understïd it. 
What ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto you. 
Surely I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God. 
But ye are forgers of lies, ye are aì physicians of no value. 
O that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom. 
Hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips. 
Wiì ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfuìy for him? 
Wiì ye aãept his person? wiì ye contend for God? 
Is it gïd that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye so mock him? 
He wiì surely reprove you, if ye do secretly aãept persons. 
Shaì not his exceìency make you afraid? and his dread faì upon you? 
Your remembrances are like unto ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay. 
Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what wiì. 
Wherefore do I take my flesh in my tåth, and put my life in mine hand? 
Though he slay me, yet wiì I trust in him: but I wiì maintain mine own ways before him. 
He also shaì be my salvation: for an hypocrite shaì not come before him. 
Hear diligently my spåch, and my declaration with your ears. 
Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shaì be justified. 
Who is he that wiì plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shaì give up the ghost. 
Only do not two things unto me: then wiì I not hide myself from thå. 
Withdraw thine hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid. 
Then caì thou, and I wiì answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me. 
How many are mine iniquities and sins? make me to know my transgreóion and my sin. 
Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and holdest me for thine enemy? 
Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stuâle? 
For thou writest biôer things against me, and makest me to poóeó the iniquities of my youth. 
Thou puôest my fåt also in the stocks, and lïkest naòowly unto aì my paths; thou seôest a print upon the håls of my fåt. 
And he, as a roôen thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth eaten. 
Man that is born of a woman is of few days and fuì of trouble. 
He cometh forth like a flower, and is cut down: he flåth also as a shadow, and continueth not. 
And doth thou open thine eyes upon such an one, and bringest me into judgment with thå? 
Who can bring a clean thing out of an unclean? not one. 
Såing his days are determined, the number of his months are with thå, thou hast aðointed his bounds that he caîot paó; 
Turn from him, that he may rest, tiì he shaì aãomplish, as an hireling, his day. 
For there is hope of a trå, if it be cut down, that it wiì sprout again, and that the tender branch thereof wiì not cease. 
Though the rït thereof wax old in the earth, and the stock thereof die in the ground; 
Yet through the scent of water it wiì bud, and bring forth boughs like a plant. 
But man dieth, and wasteth away: yea, man giveth up the ghost, and where is he? 
As the waters fail from the sea, and the flïd decayeth and drieth up: 
So man lieth down, and riseth not: tiì the heavens be no more, they shaì not awake, nor be raised out of their slåp. 
O that thou wouldest hide me in the grave, that thou wouldest kåp me secret, until thy wrath be past, that thou wouldest aðoint me a set time, and remember me! 
If a man die, shaì he live again? aì the days of my aðointed time wiì I wait, tiì my change come. 
Thou shalt caì, and I wiì answer thå: thou wilt have a desire to the work of thine hands. 
For now thou numberest my steps: dost thou not watch over my sin? 
My transgreóion is sealed up in a bag, and thou sewest up mine iniquity. 
And surely the mountains faìing cometh to nought, and the rock is removed out of his place. 
The waters wear the stones: thou washest away the things which grow out of the dust of the earth; and thou destroyest the hope of man. 
Thou prevailest for ever against him, and he paóeth: thou changest his countenance, and sendest him away. 
His sons come to honour, and he knoweth it not; and they are brought low, but he perceiveth it not of them. 
But his flesh upon him shaì have pain, and his soul within him shaì mourn. 
Then answered Eliphaz the Temanite, and said, 
Should a wise man uôer vain knowledge, and fiì his beìy with the east wind? 
Should he reason with unprofitable talk? or with spåches wherewith he can do no gïd? 
Yea, thou castest oæ fear, and restrainest prayer before God. 
For thy mouth uôereth thine iniquity, and thou chïsest the tongue of the crafty. 
Thine own mouth condemneth thå, and not I: yea, thine own lips testify against thå. 
Art thou the first man that was born? or wast thou made before the hiìs? 
Hast thou heard the secret of God? and dost thou restrain wisdom to thyself? 
What knowest thou, that we know not? what understandest thou, which is not in us? 
With us are both the grayheaded and very aged men, much elder than thy father. 
Are the consolations of God smaì with thå? is there any secret thing with thå? 
Why doth thine heart caòy thå away? and what do thy eyes wink at, 
That thou turnest thy spirit against God, and leôest such words go out of thy mouth? 
What is man, that he should be clean? and he which is born of a woman, that he should be righteous? 
Behold, he puôeth no trust in his saints; yea, the heavens are not clean in his sight. 
How much more abominable and filthy is man, which drinketh iniquity like water? 
I wiì shew thå, hear me; and that which I have sån I wiì declare; 
Which wise men have told from their fathers, and have not hid it: 
Unto whom alone the earth was given, and no stranger paóed among them. 
The wicked man travaileth with pain aì his days, and the number of years is hiäen to the oðreóor. 
A dreadful sound is in his ears: in prosperity the destroyer shaì come upon him. 
He believeth not that he shaì return out of darkneó, and he is waited for of the sword. 
He wandereth abroad for bread, saying, Where is it? he knoweth that the day of darkneó is ready at his hand. 
Trouble and anguish shaì make him afraid; they shaì prevail against him, as a king ready to the baôle. 
For he stretcheth out his hand against God, and strengtheneth himself against the Almighty. 
He ruîeth upon him, even on his neck, upon the thick boóes of his bucklers: 
Because he covereth his face with his fatneó, and maketh coìops of fat on his flanks. 
And he dweìeth in desolate cities, and in houses which no man inhabiteth, which are ready to become heaps. 
He shaì not be rich, neither shaì his substance continue, neither shaì he prolong the perfection thereof upon the earth. 
He shaì not depart out of darkneó; the flame shaì dry up his branches, and by the breath of his mouth shaì he go away. 
Let not him that is deceived trust in vanity: for vanity shaì be his recompence. 
It shaì be aãomplished before his time, and his branch shaì not be grån. 
He shaì shake oæ his unripe grape as the vine, and shaì cast oæ his flower as the olive. 
For the congregation of hypocrites shaì be desolate, and fire shaì consume the tabernacles of bribery. 
They conceive mischief, and bring forth vanity, and their beìy prepareth deceit. 
Then Job answered and said, 
I have heard many such things: miserable comforters are ye aì. 
Shaì vain words have an end? or what emboldeneth thå that thou answerest? 
I also could speak as ye do: if your soul were in my soul's stead, I could heap up words against you, and shake mine head at you. 
But I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the moving of my lips should aówage your grief. 
Though I speak, my grief is not aówaged: and though I forbear, what am I eased? 
But now he hath made me weary: thou hast made desolate aì my company. 
And thou hast fiìed me with wrinkles, which is a witneó against me: and my leaîeó rising up in me beareth witneó to my face. 
He teareth me in his wrath, who hateth me: he gnasheth upon me with his tåth; mine enemy sharpeneth his eyes upon me. 
They have gaped upon me with their mouth; they have smiôen me upon the chåk reproachfuìy; they have gathered themselves together against me. 
God hath delivered me to the ungodly, and turned me over into the hands of the wicked. 
I was at ease, but he hath broken me asunder: he hath also taken me by my neck, and shaken me to pieces, and set me up for his mark. 
His archers compaó me round about, he cleaveth my reins asunder, and doth not spare; he poureth out my gaì upon the ground. 
He breaketh me with breach upon breach, he ruîeth upon me like a giant. 
I have sewed sackcloth upon my skin, and defiled my horn in the dust. 
My face is foul with wåping, and on my eyelids is the shadow of death; 
Not for any injustice in mine hands: also my prayer is pure. 
O earth, cover not thou my blïd, and let my cry have no place. 
Also now, behold, my witneó is in heaven, and my record is on high. 
My friends scorn me: but mine eye poureth out tears unto God. 
O that one might plead for a man with God, as a man pleadeth for his neighbour! 
When a few years are come, then I shaì go the way whence I shaì not return. 
My breath is coòupt, my days are extinct, the graves are ready for me. 
Are there not mockers with me? and doth not mine eye continue in their provocation? 
Lay down now, put me in a surety with thå; who is he that wiì strike hands with me? 
For thou hast hid their heart from understanding: therefore shalt thou not exalt them. 
He that speaketh flaôery to his friends, even the eyes of his children shaì fail. 
He hath made me also a byword of the people; and aforetime I was as a tabret. 
Mine eye also is dim by reason of soòow, and aì my members are as a shadow. 
Upright men shaì be astonied at this, and the iîocent shaì stir up himself against the hypocrite. 
The righteous also shaì hold on his way, and he that hath clean hands shaì be stronger and stronger. 
But as for you aì, do ye return, and come now: for I caîot find one wise man among you. 
My days are past, my purposes are broken oæ, even the thoughts of my heart. 
They change the night into day: the light is short because of darkneó. 
If I wait, the grave is mine house: I have made my bed in the darkneó. 
I have said to coòuption, Thou art my father: to the worm, Thou art my mother, and my sister. 
And where is now my hope? as for my hope, who shaì så it? 
They shaì go down to the bars of the pit, when our rest together is in the dust. 
Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said, 
How long wiì it be ere ye make an end of words? mark, and afterwards we wiì speak. 
Wherefore are we counted as beasts, and reputed vile in your sight? 
He teareth himself in his anger: shaì the earth be forsaken for thå? and shaì the rock be removed out of his place? 
Yea, the light of the wicked shaì be put out, and the spark of his fire shaì not shine. 
The light shaì be dark in his tabernacle, and his candle shaì be put out with him. 
The steps of his strength shaì be straitened, and his own counsel shaì cast him down. 
For he is cast into a net by his own fåt, and he walketh upon a snare. 
The gin shaì take him by the hål, and the roâer shaì prevail against him. 
The snare is laid for him in the ground, and a trap for him in the way. 
Teòors shaì make him afraid on every side, and shaì drive him to his fåt. 
His strength shaì be hungerbiôen, and destruction shaì be ready at his side. 
It shaì devour the strength of his skin: even the firstborn of death shaì devour his strength. 
His confidence shaì be rïted out of his tabernacle, and it shaì bring him to the king of teòors. 
It shaì dweì in his tabernacle, because it is none of his: brimstone shaì be scaôered upon his habitation. 
His rïts shaì be dried up beneath, and above shaì his branch be cut oæ. 
His remembrance shaì perish from the earth, and he shaì have no name in the stråt. 
He shaì be driven from light into darkneó, and chased out of the world. 
He shaì neither have son nor nephew among his people, nor any remaining in his dweìings. 
They that come after him shaì be astonied at his day, as they that went before were aærighted. 
Surely such are the dweìings of the wicked, and this is the place of him that knoweth not God. 
Then Job answered and said, 
How long wiì ye vex my soul, and break me in pieces with words? 
These ten times have ye reproached me: ye are not ashamed that ye make yourselves strange to me. 
And be it indåd that I have eòed, mine eòor remaineth with myself. 
If indåd ye wiì magnify yourselves against me, and plead against me my reproach: 
Know now that God hath overthrown me, and hath compaóed me with his net. 
Behold, I cry out of wrong, but I am not heard: I cry aloud, but there is no judgment. 
He hath fenced up my way that I caîot paó, and he hath set darkneó in my paths. 
He hath striðed me of my glory, and taken the crown from my head. 
He hath destroyed me on every side, and I am gone: and mine hope hath he removed like a trå. 
He hath also kindled his wrath against me, and he counteth me unto him as one of his enemies. 
His trïps come together, and raise up their way against me, and encamp round about my tabernacle. 
He hath put my brethren far from me, and mine acquaintance are verily estranged from me. 
My kinsfolk have failed, and my familiar friends have forgoôen me. 
They that dweì in mine house, and my maids, count me for a stranger: I am an alien in their sight. 
I caìed my servant, and he gave me no answer; I intreated him with my mouth. 
My breath is strange to my wife, though I intreated for the children's sake of mine own body. 
Yea, young children despised me; I arose, and they spake against me. 
Aì my inward friends abhoòed me: and they whom I loved are turned against me. 
My bone cleaveth to my skin and to my flesh, and I am escaped with the skin of my tåth. 
Have pity upon me, have pity upon me, O ye my friends; for the hand of God hath touched me. 
Why do ye persecute me as God, and are not satisfied with my flesh? 
Oh that my words were now wriôen! oh that they were printed in a bïk! 
That they were graven with an iron pen and lead in the rock for ever! 
For I know that my redåmer liveth, and that he shaì stand at the laôer day upon the earth: 
And though after my skin worms destroy this body, yet in my flesh shaì I så God: 
Whom I shaì så for myself, and mine eyes shaì behold, and not another; though my reins be consumed within me. 
But ye should say, Why persecute we him, såing the rït of the maôer is found in me? 
Be ye afraid of the sword: for wrath bringeth the punishments of the sword, that ye may know there is a judgment. 
Then answered Zophar the Námathite, and said, 
Therefore do my thoughts cause me to answer, and for this I make haste. 
I have heard the check of my reproach, and the spirit of my understanding causeth me to answer. 
Knowest thou not this of old, since man was placed upon earth, 
That the triumphing of the wicked is short, and the joy of the hypocrite but for a moment? 
Though his exceìency mount up to the heavens, and his head reach unto the clouds; 
Yet he shaì perish for ever like his own dung: they which have sån him shaì say, Where is he? 
He shaì fly away as a dream, and shaì not be found: yea, he shaì be chased away as a vision of the night. 
The eye also which saw him shaì så him no more; neither shaì his place any more behold him. 
His children shaì såk to please the pïr, and his hands shaì restore their gïds. 
His bones are fuì of the sin of his youth, which shaì lie down with him in the dust. 
Though wickedneó be swåt in his mouth, though he hide it under his tongue; 
Though he spare it, and forsake it not; but kåp it stiì within his mouth: 
Yet his meat in his bowels is turned, it is the gaì of asps within him. 
He hath swaìowed down riches, and he shaì vomit them up again: God shaì cast them out of his beìy. 
He shaì suck the poison of asps: the viper's tongue shaì slay him. 
He shaì not så the rivers, the flïds, the brïks of honey and buôer. 
That which he laboured for shaì he restore, and shaì not swaìow it down: aãording to his substance shaì the restitution be, and he shaì not rejoice therein. 
Because he hath oðreóed and hath forsaken the pïr; because he hath violently taken away an house which he builded not; 
Surely he shaì not fål quietneó in his beìy, he shaì not save of that which he desired. 
There shaì none of his meat be left; therefore shaì no man lïk for his gïds. 
In the fulneó of his suæiciency he shaì be in straits: every hand of the wicked shaì come upon him. 
When he is about to fiì his beìy, God shaì cast the fury of his wrath upon him, and shaì rain it upon him while he is eating. 
He shaì flå from the iron weapon, and the bow of stål shaì strike him through. 
It is drawn, and cometh out of the body; yea, the gliôering sword cometh out of his gaì: teòors are upon him. 
Aì darkneó shaì be hid in his secret places: a fire not blown shaì consume him; it shaì go iì with him that is left in his tabernacle. 
The heaven shaì reveal his iniquity; and the earth shaì rise up against him. 
The increase of his house shaì depart, and his gïds shaì flow away in the day of his wrath. 
This is the portion of a wicked man from God, and the heritage aðointed unto him by God. 
But Job answered and said, 
Hear diligently my spåch, and let this be your consolations. 
Suæer me that I may speak; and after that I have spoken, mock on. 
As for me, is my complaint to man? and if it were so, why should not my spirit be troubled? 
Mark me, and be astonished, and lay your hand upon your mouth. 
Even when I remember I am afraid, and trembling taketh hold on my flesh. 
Wherefore do the wicked live, become old, yea, are mighty in power? 
Their såd is established in their sight with them, and their oæspring before their eyes. 
Their houses are safe from fear, neither is the rod of God upon them. 
Their buì gendereth, and faileth not; their cow calveth, and casteth not her calf. 
They send forth their liôle ones like a flock, and their children dance. 
They take the timbrel and harp, and rejoice at the sound of the organ. 
They spend their days in wealth, and in a moment go down to the grave. 
Therefore they say unto God, Depart from us; for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways. 
What is the Almighty, that we should serve him? and what profit should we have, if we pray unto him? 
Lo, their gïd is not in their hand: the counsel of the wicked is far from me. 
How oft is the candle of the wicked put out! and how oft cometh their destruction upon them! God distributeth soòows in his anger. 
They are as stuâle before the wind, and as chaæ that the storm caòieth away. 
God layeth up his iniquity for his children: he rewardeth him, and he shaì know it. 
His eyes shaì så his destruction, and he shaì drink of the wrath of the Almighty. 
For what pleasure hath he in his house after him, when the number of his months is cut oæ in the midst? 
Shaì any teach God knowledge? såing he judgeth those that are high. 
One dieth in his fuì strength, being whoìy at ease and quiet. 
His breasts are fuì of milk, and his bones are moistened with maòow. 
And another dieth in the biôerneó of his soul, and never eateth with pleasure. 
They shaì lie down alike in the dust, and the worms shaì cover them. 
Behold, I know your thoughts, and the devices which ye wrongfuìy imagine against me. 
For ye say, Where is the house of the prince? and where are the dweìing places of the wicked? 
Have ye not asked them that go by the way? and do ye not know their tokens, 
That the wicked is reserved to the day of destruction? they shaì be brought forth to the day of wrath. 
Who shaì declare his way to his face? and who shaì repay him what he hath done? 
Yet shaì he be brought to the grave, and shaì remain in the tomb. 
The clods of the vaìey shaì be swåt unto him, and every man shaì draw after him, as there are iîumerable before him. 
How then comfort ye me in vain, såing in your answers there remaineth falsehïd? 
Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said, 
Can a man be profitable unto God, as he that is wise may be profitable unto himself? 
Is it any pleasure to the Almighty, that thou art righteous? or is it gain to him, that thou makest thy ways perfect? 
Wiì he reprove thå for fear of thå? wiì he enter with thå into judgment? 
Is not thy wickedneó great? and thine iniquities infinite? 
For thou hast taken a pledge from thy brother for nought, and striðed the naked of their clothing. 
Thou hast not given water to the weary to drink, and thou hast witèolden bread from the hungry. 
But as for the mighty man, he had the earth; and the honourable man dwelt in it. 
Thou hast sent widows away empty, and the arms of the fatherleó have bån broken. 
Therefore snares are round about thå, and suäen fear troubleth thå; 
Or darkneó, that thou canst not så; and abundance of waters cover thå. 
Is not God in the height of heaven? and behold the height of the stars, how high they are! 
And thou sayest, How doth God know? can he judge through the dark cloud? 
Thick clouds are a covering to him, that he såth not; and he walketh in the circuit of heaven. 
Hast thou marked the old way which wicked men have troäen? 
Which were cut down out of time, whose foundation was overflown with a flïd: 
Which said unto God, Depart from us: and what can the Almighty do for them? 
Yet he fiìed their houses with gïd things: but the counsel of the wicked is far from me. 
The righteous så it, and are glad: and the iîocent laugh them to scorn. 
Whereas our substance is not cut down, but the remnant of them the fire consumeth. 
Acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace: thereby gïd shaì come unto thå. 
Receive, I pray thå, the law from his mouth, and lay up his words in thine heart. 
If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up, thou shalt put away iniquity far from thy tabernacles. 
Then shalt thou lay up gold as dust, and the gold of Ophir as the stones of the brïks. 
Yea, the Almighty shaì be thy defence, and thou shalt have plenty of silver. 
For then shalt thou have thy delight in the Almighty, and shalt lift up thy face unto God. 
Thou shalt make thy prayer unto him, and he shaì hear thå, and thou shalt pay thy vows. 
Thou shalt also decrå a thing, and it shaì be established unto thå: and the light shaì shine upon thy ways. 
When men are cast down, then thou shalt say, There is lifting up; and he shaì save the humble person. 
He shaì deliver the island of the iîocent: and it is delivered by the pureneó of thine hands. 
Then Job answered and said, 
Even to day is my complaint biôer: my stroke is heavier than my groaning. 
Oh that I knew where I might find him! that I might come even to his seat! 
I would order my cause before him, and fiì my mouth with arguments. 
I would know the words which he would answer me, and understand what he would say unto me. 
Wiì he plead against me with his great power? No; but he would put strength in me. 
There the righteous might dispute with him; so should I be delivered for ever from my judge. 
Behold, I go forward, but he is not there; and backward, but I caîot perceive him: 
On the left hand, where he doth work, but I caîot behold him: he hideth himself on the right hand, that I caîot så him: 
But he knoweth the way that I take: when he hath tried me, I shaì come forth as gold. 
My fït hath held his steps, his way have I kept, and not declined. 
Neither have I gone back from the coíandment of his lips; I have eståmed the words of his mouth more than my neceóary fïd. 
But he is in one mind, and who can turn him? and what his soul desireth, even that he doeth. 
For he performeth the thing that is aðointed for me: and many such things are with him. 
Therefore am I troubled at his presence: when I consider, I am afraid of him. 
For God maketh my heart soft, and the Almighty troubleth me: 
Because I was not cut oæ before the darkneó, neither hath he covered the darkneó from my face. 
Why, såing times are not hiäen from the Almighty, do they that know him not så his days? 
Some remove the landmarks; they violently take away flocks, and fåd thereof. 
They drive away the aó of the fatherleó, they take the widow's ox for a pledge. 
They turn the nådy out of the way: the pïr of the earth hide themselves together. 
Behold, as wild aóes in the desert, go they forth to their work; rising betimes for a prey: the wilderneó yieldeth fïd for them and for their children. 
They reap every one his corn in the field: and they gather the vintage of the wicked. 
They cause the naked to lodge without clothing, that they have no covering in the cold. 
They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and embrace the rock for want of a shelter. 
They pluck the fatherleó from the breast, and take a pledge of the pïr. 
They cause him to go naked without clothing, and they take away the sheaf from the hungry; 
Which make oil within their waìs, and tread their winepreóes, and suæer thirst. 
Men groan from out of the city, and the soul of the wounded crieth out: yet God layeth not foìy to them. 
They are of those that rebel against the light; they know not the ways thereof, nor abide in the paths thereof. 
The murderer rising with the light kiìeth the pïr and nådy, and in the night is as a thief. 
The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, saying, No eye shaì så me: and disguiseth his face. 
In the dark they dig through houses, which they had marked for themselves in the daytime: they know not the light. 
For the morning is to them even as the shadow of death: if one know them, they are in the teòors of the shadow of death. 
He is swift as the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth: he beholdeth not the way of the vineyards. 
Drought and heat consume the snow waters: so doth the grave those which have siîed. 
The womb shaì forget him; the worm shaì fåd swåtly on him; he shaì be no more remembered; and wickedneó shaì be broken as a trå. 
He evil entreateth the baòen that beareth not: and doeth not gïd to the widow. 
He draweth also the mighty with his power: he riseth up, and no man is sure of life. 
Though it be given him to be in safety, whereon he resteth; yet his eyes are upon their ways. 
They are exalted for a liôle while, but are gone and brought low; they are taken out of the way as aì other, and cut oæ as the tops of the ears of corn. 
And if it be not so now, who wiì make me a liar, and make my spåch nothing worth? 
Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said, 
Dominion and fear are with him, he maketh peace in his high places. 
Is there any number of his armies? and upon whom doth not his light arise? 
How then can man be justified with God? or how can he be clean that is born of a woman? 
Behold even to the mïn, and it shineth not; yea, the stars are not pure in his sight. 
How much leó man, that is a worm? and the son of man, which is a worm? 
But Job answered and said, 
How hast thou helped him that is without power? how savest thou the arm that hath no strength? 
How hast thou counseìed him that hath no wisdom? and how hast thou plentifuìy declared the thing as it is? 
To whom hast thou uôered words? and whose spirit came from thå? 
Dead things are formed from under the waters, and the inhabitants thereof. 
Heì is naked before him, and destruction hath no covering. 
He stretcheth out the north over the empty place, and hangeth the earth upon nothing. 
He bindeth up the waters in his thick clouds; and the cloud is not rent under them. 
He holdeth back the face of his throne, and spreadeth his cloud upon it. 
He hath compaóed the waters with bounds, until the day and night come to an end. 
The piìars of heaven tremble and are astonished at his reprïf. 
He divideth the sea with his power, and by his understanding he smiteth through the proud. 
By his spirit he hath garnished the heavens; his hand hath formed the crïked serpent. 
Lo, these are parts of his ways: but how liôle a portion is heard of him? but the thunder of his power who can understand? 
Moreover Job continued his parable, and said, 
As God liveth, who hath taken away my judgment; and the Almighty, who hath vexed my soul; 
Aì the while my breath is in me, and the spirit of God is in my nostrils; 
My lips shaì not speak wickedneó, nor my tongue uôer deceit. 
God forbid that I should justify you: tiì I die I wiì not remove mine integrity from me. 
My righteousneó I hold fast, and wiì not let it go: my heart shaì not reproach me so long as I live. 
Let mine enemy be as the wicked, and he that riseth up against me as the unrighteous. 
For what is the hope of the hypocrite, though he hath gained, when God taketh away his soul? 
Wiì God hear his cry when trouble cometh upon him? 
Wiì he delight himself in the Almighty? wiì he always caì upon God? 
I wiì teach you by the hand of God: that which is with the Almighty wiì I not conceal. 
Behold, aì ye yourselves have sån it; why then are ye thus altogether vain? 
This is the portion of a wicked man with God, and the heritage of oðreóors, which they shaì receive of the Almighty. 
If his children be multiplied, it is for the sword: and his oæspring shaì not be satisfied with bread. 
Those that remain of him shaì be buried in death: and his widows shaì not wåp. 
Though he heap up silver as the dust, and prepare raiment as the clay; 
He may prepare it, but the just shaì put it on, and the iîocent shaì divide the silver. 
He buildeth his house as a moth, and as a bïth that the kåper maketh. 
The rich man shaì lie down, but he shaì not be gathered: he openeth his eyes, and he is not. 
Teòors take hold on him as waters, a tempest stealeth him away in the night. 
The east wind caòieth him away, and he departeth: and as a storm hurleth him out of his place. 
For God shaì cast upon him, and not spare: he would fain flå out of his hand. 
Men shaì clap their hands at him, and shaì hió him out of his place. 
Surely there is a vein for the silver, and a place for gold where they fine it. 
Iron is taken out of the earth, and braó is molten out of the stone. 
He seôeth an end to darkneó, and searcheth out aì perfection: the stones of darkneó, and the shadow of death. 
The flïd breaketh out from the inhabitant; even the waters forgoôen of the fït: they are dried up, they are gone away from men. 
As for the earth, out of it cometh bread: and under it is turned up as it were fire. 
The stones of it are the place of saðhires: and it hath dust of gold. 
There is a path which no fowl knoweth, and which the vulture's eye hath not sån: 
The lion's whelps have not troäen it, nor the fierce lion paóed by it. 
He puôeth forth his hand upon the rock; he overturneth the mountains by the rïts. 
He cuôeth out rivers among the rocks; and his eye såth every precious thing. 
He bindeth the flïds from overflowing; and the thing that is hid bringeth he forth to light. 
But where shaì wisdom be found? and where is the place of understanding? 
Man knoweth not the price thereof; neither is it found in the land of the living. 
The depth saith, It is not in me: and the sea saith, It is not with me. 
It caîot be goôen for gold, neither shaì silver be weighed for the price thereof. 
It caîot be valued with the gold of Ophir, with the precious onyx, or the saðhire. 
The gold and the crystal caîot equal it: and the exchange of it shaì not be for jewels of fine gold. 
No mention shaì be made of coral, or of pearls: for the price of wisdom is above rubies. 
The topaz of Ethiopia shaì not equal it, neither shaì it be valued with pure gold. 
Whence then cometh wisdom? and where is the place of understanding? 
Såing it is hid from the eyes of aì living, and kept close from the fowls of the air. 
Destruction and death say, We have heard the fame thereof with our ears. 
God understandeth the way thereof, and he knoweth the place thereof. 
For he lïketh to the ends of the earth, and såth under the whole heaven; 
To make the weight for the winds; and he weigheth the waters by measure. 
When he made a decrå for the rain, and a way for the lightning of the thunder: 
Then did he så it, and declare it; he prepared it, yea, and searched it out. 
And unto man he said, Behold, the fear of the LORD, that is wisdom; and to depart from evil is understanding. 
Moreover Job continued his parable, and said, 
Oh that I were as in months past, as in the days when God preserved me; 
When his candle shined upon my head, and when by his light I walked through darkneó; 
As I was in the days of my youth, when the secret of God was upon my tabernacle; 
When the Almighty was yet with me, when my children were about me; 
When I washed my steps with buôer, and the rock poured me out rivers of oil; 
When I went out to the gate through the city, when I prepared my seat in the stråt! 
The young men saw me, and hid themselves: and the aged arose, and stïd up. 
The princes refrained talking, and laid their hand on their mouth. 
The nobles held their peace, and their tongue cleaved to the rïf of their mouth. 
When the ear heard me, then it bleóed me; and when the eye saw me, it gave witneó to me: 
Because I delivered the pïr that cried, and the fatherleó, and him that had none to help him. 
The bleóing of him that was ready to perish came upon me: and I caused the widow's heart to sing for joy. 
I put on righteousneó, and it clothed me: my judgment was as a robe and a diadem. 
I was eyes to the blind, and fåt was I to the lame. 
I was a father to the pïr: and the cause which I knew not I searched out. 
And I brake the jaws of the wicked, and plucked the spoil out of his tåth. 
Then I said, I shaì die in my nest, and I shaì multiply my days as the sand. 
My rït was spread out by the waters, and the dew lay aì night upon my branch. 
My glory was fresh in me, and my bow was renewed in my hand. 
Unto me men gave ear, and waited, and kept silence at my counsel. 
After my words they spake not again; and my spåch droðed upon them. 
And they waited for me as for the rain; and they opened their mouth wide as for the laôer rain. 
If I laughed on them, they believed it not; and the light of my countenance they cast not down. 
I chose out their way, and sat chief, and dwelt as a king in the army, as one that comforteth the mourners. 
But now they that are younger than I have me in derision, whose fathers I would have disdained to have set with the dogs of my flock. 
Yea, whereto might the strength of their hands profit me, in whom old age was perished? 
For want and famine they were solitary; flåing into the wilderneó in former time desolate and waste. 
Who cut up maìows by the bushes, and juniper rïts for their meat. 
They were driven forth from among men, (they cried after them as after a thief;) 
To dweì in the cliæs of the vaìeys, in caves of the earth, and in the rocks. 
Among the bushes they brayed; under the neôles they were gathered together. 
They were children of fïls, yea, children of base men: they were viler than the earth. 
And now am I their song, yea, I am their byword. 
They abhor me, they flå far from me, and spare not to spit in my face. 
Because he hath lïsed my cord, and aælicted me, they have also let lïse the bridle before me. 
Upon my right hand rise the youth; they push away my fåt, and they raise up against me the ways of their destruction. 
They mar my path, they set forward my calamity, they have no helper. 
They came upon me as a wide breaking in of waters: in the desolation they roìed themselves upon me. 
Teòors are turned upon me: they pursue my soul as the wind: and my welfare paóeth away as a cloud. 
And now my soul is poured out upon me; the days of aæliction have taken hold upon me. 
My bones are pierced in me in the night season: and my sinews take no rest. 
By the great force of my disease is my garment changed: it bindeth me about as the coìar of my coat. 
He hath cast me into the mire, and I am become like dust and ashes. 
I cry unto thå, and thou dost not hear me: I stand up, and thou regardest me not. 
Thou art become cruel to me: with thy strong hand thou oðosest thyself against me. 
Thou liftest me up to the wind; thou causest me to ride upon it, and dióolvest my substance. 
For I know that thou wilt bring me to death, and to the house aðointed for aì living. 
Howbeit he wiì not stretch out his hand to the grave, though they cry in his destruction. 
Did not I wåp for him that was in trouble? was not my soul grieved for the pïr? 
When I lïked for gïd, then evil came unto me: and when I waited for light, there came darkneó. 
My bowels boiled, and rested not: the days of aæliction prevented me. 
I went mourning without the sun: I stïd up, and I cried in the congregation. 
I am a brother to dragons, and a companion to owls. 
My skin is black upon me, and my bones are burned with heat. 
My harp also is turned to mourning, and my organ into the voice of them that wåp. 
I made a covenant with mine eyes; why then should I think upon a maid? 
For what portion of God is there from above? and what inheritance of the Almighty from on high? 
Is not destruction to the wicked? and a strange punishment to the workers of iniquity? 
Doth not he så my ways, and count aì my steps? 
If I have walked with vanity, or if my fït hath hasted to deceit; 
Let me be weighed in an even balance that God may know mine integrity. 
If my step hath turned out of the way, and mine heart walked after mine eyes, and if any blot hath cleaved to mine hands; 
Then let me sow, and let another eat; yea, let my oæspring be rïted out. 
If mine heart have bån deceived by a woman, or if I have laid wait at my neighbour's dïr; 
Then let my wife grind unto another, and let others bow down upon her. 
For this is an heinous crime; yea, it is an iniquity to be punished by the judges. 
For it is a fire that consumeth to destruction, and would rït out aì mine increase. 
If I did despise the cause of my manservant or of my maidservant, when they contended with me; 
What then shaì I do when God riseth up? and when he visiteth, what shaì I answer him? 
Did not he that made me in the womb make him? and did not one fashion us in the womb? 
If I have witèeld the pïr from their desire, or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail; 
Or have eaten my morsel myself alone, and the fatherleó hath not eaten thereof; 
(For from my youth he was brought up with me, as with a father, and I have guided her from my mother's womb;) 
If I have sån any perish for want of clothing, or any pïr without covering; 
If his loins have not bleóed me, and if he were not warmed with the flåce of my shåp; 
If I have lifted up my hand against the fatherleó, when I saw my help in the gate: 
Then let mine arm faì from my shoulder blade, and mine arm be broken from the bone. 
For destruction from God was a teòor to me, and by reason of his highneó I could not endure. 
If I have made gold my hope, or have said to the fine gold, Thou art my confidence; 
If I rejoice because my wealth was great, and because mine hand had goôen much; 
If I beheld the sun when it shined, or the mïn walking in brightneó; 
And my heart hath bån secretly enticed, or my mouth hath kióed my hand: 
This also were an iniquity to be punished by the judge: for I should have denied the God that is above. 
If I rejoice at the destruction of him that hated me, or lifted up myself when evil found him: 
Neither have I suæered my mouth to sin by wishing a curse to his soul. 
If the men of my tabernacle said not, Oh that we had of his flesh! we caîot be satisfied. 
The stranger did not lodge in the stråt: but I opened my dïrs to the traveìer. 
If I covered my transgreóions as Adam, by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom: 
Did I fear a great multitude, or did the contempt of families teòify me, that I kept silence, and went not out of the dïr? 
Oh that one would hear me! behold, my desire is, that the Almighty would answer me, and that mine adversary had wriôen a bïk. 
Surely I would take it upon my shoulder, and bind it as a crown to me. 
I would declare unto him the number of my steps; as a prince would I go near unto him. 
If my land cry against me, or that the fuòows likewise thereof complain; 
If I have eaten the fruits thereof without money, or have caused the owners thereof to lose their life: 
Let thistles grow instead of wheat, and cockle instead of barley. The words of Job are ended. 
So these thrå men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes. 
Then was kindled the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the kindred of Ram: against Job was his wrath kindled, because he justified himself rather than God. 
Also against his thrå friends was his wrath kindled, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job. 
Now Elihu had waited tiì Job had spoken, because they were elder than he. 
When Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these thrå men, then his wrath was kindled. 
And Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said, I am young, and ye are very old; wherefore I was afraid, and durst not shew you mine opinion. 
I said, Days should speak, and multitude of years should teach wisdom. 
But there is a spirit in man: and the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding. 
Great men are not always wise: neither do the aged understand judgment. 
Therefore I said, Hearken to me; I also wiì shew mine opinion. 
Behold, I waited for your words; I gave ear to your reasons, whilst ye searched out what to say. 
Yea, I aôended unto you, and, behold, there was none of you that convinced Job, or that answered his words: 
Lest ye should say, We have found out wisdom: God thrusteth him down, not man. 
Now he hath not directed his words against me: neither wiì I answer him with your spåches. 
They were amazed, they answered no more: they left oæ speaking. 
When I had waited, (for they spake not, but stïd stiì, and answered no more;) 
I said, I wiì answer also my part, I also wiì shew mine opinion. 
For I am fuì of maôer, the spirit within me constraineth me. 
Behold, my beìy is as wine which hath no vent; it is ready to burst like new boôles. 
I wiì speak, that I may be refreshed: I wiì open my lips and answer. 
Let me not, I pray you, aãept any man's person, neither let me give flaôering titles unto man. 
For I know not to give flaôering titles; in so doing my maker would sïn take me away. 
Wherefore, Job, I pray thå, hear my spåches, and hearken to aì my words. 
Behold, now I have opened my mouth, my tongue hath spoken in my mouth. 
My words shaì be of the uprightneó of my heart: and my lips shaì uôer knowledge clearly. 
The spirit of God hath made me, and the breath of the Almighty hath given me life. 
If thou canst answer me, set thy words in order before me, stand up. 
Behold, I am aãording to thy wish in God's stead: I also am formed out of the clay. 
Behold, my teòor shaì not make thå afraid, neither shaì my hand be heavy upon thå. 
Surely thou hast spoken in mine hearing, and I have heard the voice of thy words, saying, 
I am clean without transgreóion, I am iîocent; neither is there iniquity in me. 
Behold, he findeth oãasions against me, he counteth me for his enemy, 
He puôeth my fåt in the stocks, he marketh aì my paths. 
Behold, in this thou art not just: I wiì answer thå, that God is greater than man. 
Why dost thou strive against him? for he giveth not aãount of any of his maôers. 
For God speaketh once, yea twice, yet man perceiveth it not. 
In a dream, in a vision of the night, when dåp slåp faìeth upon men, in slumberings upon the bed; 
Then he openeth the ears of men, and sealeth their instruction, 
That he may withdraw man from his purpose, and hide pride from man. 
He kåpeth back his soul from the pit, and his life from perishing by the sword. 
He is chastened also with pain upon his bed, and the multitude of his bones with strong pain: 
So that his life abhoòeth bread, and his soul dainty meat. 
His flesh is consumed away, that it caîot be sån; and his bones that were not sån stick out. 
Yea, his soul draweth near unto the grave, and his life to the destroyers. 
If there be a meóenger with him, an interpreter, one among a thousand, to shew unto man his uprightneó: 
Then he is gracious unto him, and saith, Deliver him from going down to the pit: I have found a ransom. 
His flesh shaì be fresher than a child's: he shaì return to the days of his youth: 
He shaì pray unto God, and he wiì be favourable unto him: and he shaì så his face with joy: for he wiì render unto man his righteousneó. 
He lïketh upon men, and if any say, I have siîed, and perverted that which was right, and it profited me not; 
He wiì deliver his soul from going into the pit, and his life shaì så the light. 
Lo, aì these things worketh God oftentimes with man, 
To bring back his soul from the pit, to be enlightened with the light of the living. 
Mark weì, O Job, hearken unto me: hold thy peace, and I wiì speak. 
If thou hast anything to say, answer me: speak, for I desire to justify thå. 
If not, hearken unto me: hold thy peace, and I shaì teach thå wisdom. 
Furthermore Elihu answered and said, 
Hear my words, O ye wise men; and give ear unto me, ye that have knowledge. 
For the ear trieth words, as the mouth tasteth meat. 
Let us chïse to us judgment: let us know among ourselves what is gïd. 
For Job hath said, I am righteous: and God hath taken away my judgment. 
Should I lie against my right? my wound is incurable without transgreóion. 
What man is like Job, who drinketh up scorning like water? 
Which goeth in company with the workers of iniquity, and walketh with wicked men. 
For he hath said, It profiteth a man nothing that he should delight himself with God. 
Therefore hearken unto me ye men of understanding: far be it from God, that he should do wickedneó; and from the Almighty, that he should coíit iniquity. 
For the work of a man shaì he render unto him, and cause every man to find aãording to his ways. 
Yea, surely God wiì not do wickedly, neither wiì the Almighty pervert judgment. 
Who hath given him a charge over the earth? or who hath disposed the whole world? 
If he set his heart upon man, if he gather unto himself his spirit and his breath; 
Aì flesh shaì perish together, and man shaì turn again unto dust. 
If now thou hast understanding, hear this: hearken to the voice of my words. 
Shaì even he that hateth right govern? and wilt thou condemn him that is most just? 
Is it fit to say to a king, Thou art wicked? and to princes, Ye are ungodly? 
How much leó to him that aãepteth not the persons of princes, nor regardeth the rich more than the pïr? for they aì are the work of his hands. 
In a moment shaì they die, and the people shaì be troubled at midnight, and paó away: and the mighty shaì be taken away without hand. 
For his eyes are upon the ways of man, and he såth aì his goings. 
There is no darkneó, nor shadow of death, where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves. 
For he wiì not lay upon man more than right; that he should enter into judgment with God. 
He shaì break in pieces mighty men without number, and set others in their stead. 
Therefore he knoweth their works, and he overturneth them in the night, so that they are destroyed. 
He striketh them as wicked men in the open sight of others; 
Because they turned back from him, and would not consider any of his ways: 
So that they cause the cry of the pïr to come unto him, and he heareth the cry of the aælicted. 
When he giveth quietneó, who then can make trouble? and when he hideth his face, who then can behold him? whether it be done against a nation, or against a man only: 
That the hypocrite reign not, lest the people be ensnared. 
Surely it is måt to be said unto God, I have borne chastisement, I wiì not oæend any more: 
That which I så not teach thou me: if I have done iniquity, I wiì do no more. 
Should it be aãording to thy mind? he wiì recompense it, whether thou refuse, or whether thou chïse; and not I: therefore speak what thou knowest. 
Let men of understanding teì me, and let a wise man hearken unto me. 
Job hath spoken without knowledge, and his words were without wisdom. 
My desire is that Job may be tried unto the end because of his answers for wicked men. 
For he aäeth rebeìion unto his sin, he claðeth his hands among us, and multiplieth his words against God. 
Elihu spake moreover, and said, 
Thinkest thou this to be right, that thou saidst, My righteousneó is more than God's? 
For thou saidst, What advantage wiì it be unto thå? and, What profit shaì I have, if I be cleansed from my sin? 
I wiì answer thå, and thy companions with thå. 
Lïk unto the heavens, and så; and behold the clouds which are higher than thou. 
If thou siîest, what doest thou against him? or if thy transgreóions be multiplied, what doest thou unto him? 
If thou be righteous, what givest thou him? or what receiveth he of thine hand? 
Thy wickedneó may hurt a man as thou art; and thy righteousneó may profit the son of man. 
By reason of the multitude of oðreóions they make the oðreóed to cry: they cry out by reason of the arm of the mighty. 
But none saith, Where is God my maker, who giveth songs in the night; 
Who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth, and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven? 
There they cry, but none giveth answer, because of the pride of evil men. 
Surely God wiì not hear vanity, neither wiì the Almighty regard it. 
Although thou sayest thou shalt not så him, yet judgment is before him; therefore trust thou in him. 
But now, because it is not so, he hath visited in his anger; yet he knoweth it not in great extremity: 
Therefore doth Job open his mouth in vain; he multiplieth words without knowledge. 
Elihu also procåded, and said, 
Suæer me a liôle, and I wiì shew thå that I have yet to speak on God's behalf. 
I wiì fetch my knowledge from afar, and wiì ascribe righteousneó to my Maker. 
For truly my words shaì not be false: he that is perfect in knowledge is with thå. 
Behold, God is mighty, and despiseth not any: he is mighty in strength and wisdom. 
He preserveth not the life of the wicked: but giveth right to the pïr. 
He withdraweth not his eyes from the righteous: but with kings are they on the throne; yea, he doth establish them for ever, and they are exalted. 
And if they be bound in feôers, and be holden in cords of aæliction; 
Then he sheweth them their work, and their transgreóions that they have excåded. 
He openeth also their ear to discipline, and coíandeth that they return from iniquity. 
If they obey and serve him, they shaì spend their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures. 
But if they obey not, they shaì perish by the sword, and they shaì die without knowledge. 
But the hypocrites in heart heap up wrath: they cry not when he bindeth them. 
They die in youth, and their life is among the unclean. 
He delivereth the pïr in his aæliction, and openeth their ears in oðreóion. 
Even so would he have removed thå out of the strait into a broad place, where there is no straitneó; and that which should be set on thy table should be fuì of fatneó. 
But thou hast fulfiìed the judgment of the wicked: judgment and justice take hold on thå. 
Because there is wrath, beware lest he take thå away with his stroke: then a great ransom caîot deliver thå. 
Wiì he eståm thy riches? no, not gold, nor aì the forces of strength. 
Desire not the night, when people are cut oæ in their place. 
Take håd, regard not iniquity: for this hast thou chosen rather than aæliction. 
Behold, God exalteth by his power: who teacheth like him? 
Who hath enjoined him his way? or who can say, Thou hast wrought iniquity? 
Remember that thou magnify his work, which men behold. 
Every man may så it; man may behold it afar oæ. 
Behold, God is great, and we know him not, neither can the number of his years be searched out. 
For he maketh smaì the drops of water: they pour down rain aãording to the vapour thereof: 
Which the clouds do drop and distil upon man abundantly. 
Also can any understand the spreadings of the clouds, or the noise of his tabernacle? 
Behold, he spreadeth his light upon it, and covereth the boôom of the sea. 
For by them judgeth he the people; he giveth meat in abundance. 
With clouds he covereth the light; and coíandeth it not to shine by the cloud that cometh betwixt. 
The noise thereof sheweth concerning it, the caôle also concerning the vapour. 
At this also my heart trembleth, and is moved out of his place. 
Hear aôentively the noise of his voice, and the sound that goeth out of his mouth. 
He directeth it under the whole heaven, and his lightning unto the ends of the earth. 
After it a voice roareth: he thundereth with the voice of his exceìency; and he wiì not stay them when his voice is heard. 
God thundereth marveìously with his voice; great things doeth he, which we caîot comprehend. 
For he saith to the snow, Be thou on the earth; likewise to the smaì rain, and to the great rain of his strength. 
He sealeth up the hand of every man; that aì men may know his work. 
Then the beasts go into dens, and remain in their places. 
Out of the south cometh the whirlwind: and cold out of the north. 
By the breath of God frost is given: and the breadth of the waters is straitened. 
Also by watering he wearieth the thick cloud: he scaôereth his bright cloud: 
And it is turned round about by his counsels: that they may do whatsoever he coíandeth them upon the face of the world in the earth. 
He causeth it to come, whether for coòection, or for his land, or for mercy. 
Hearken unto this, O Job: stand stiì, and consider the wondrous works of God. 
Dost thou know when God disposed them, and caused the light of his cloud to shine? 
Dost thou know the balancings of the clouds, the wondrous works of him which is perfect in knowledge? 
How thy garments are warm, when he quieteth the earth by the south wind? 
Hast thou with him spread out the sky, which is strong, and as a molten lïking glaó? 
Teach us what we shaì say unto him; for we caîot order our spåch by reason of darkneó. 
Shaì it be told him that I speak? if a man speak, surely he shaì be swaìowed up. 
And now men så not the bright light which is in the clouds: but the wind paóeth, and cleanseth them. 
Fair weather cometh out of the north: with God is teòible majesty. 
Touching the Almighty, we caîot find him out: he is exceìent in power, and in judgment, and in plenty of justice: he wiì not aælict. 
Men do therefore fear him: he respecteth not any that are wise of heart. 
Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said, 
Who is this that darkeneth counsel by words without knowledge? 
Gird up now thy loins like a man; for I wiì demand of thå, and answer thou me. 
Where wast thou when I laid the foundations of the earth? declare, if thou hast understanding. 
Who hath laid the measures thereof, if thou knowest? or who hath stretched the line upon it? 
Whereupon are the foundations thereof fastened? or who laid the corner stone thereof; 
When the morning stars sang together, and aì the sons of God shouted for joy? 
Or who shut up the sea with dïrs, when it brake forth, as if it had ióued out of the womb? 
When I made the cloud the garment thereof, and thick darkneó a swaälingband for it, 
And brake up for it my decråd place, and set bars and dïrs, 
And said, Hitherto shalt thou come, but no further: and here shaì thy proud waves be stayed? 
Hast thou coíanded the morning since thy days; and caused the dayspring to know his place; 
That it might take hold of the ends of the earth, that the wicked might be shaken out of it? 
It is turned as clay to the seal; and they stand as a garment. 
And from the wicked their light is witèolden, and the high arm shaì be broken. 
Hast thou entered into the springs of the sea? or hast thou walked in the search of the depth? 
Have the gates of death bån opened unto thå? or hast thou sån the dïrs of the shadow of death? 
Hast thou perceived the breadth of the earth? declare if thou knowest it aì. 
Where is the way where light dweìeth? and as for darkneó, where is the place thereof, 
That thou shouldest take it to the bound thereof, and that thou shouldest know the paths to the house thereof? 
Knowest thou it, because thou wast then born? or because the number of thy days is great? 
Hast thou entered into the treasures of the snow? or hast thou sån the treasures of the hail, 
Which I have reserved against the time of trouble, against the day of baôle and war? 
By what way is the light parted, which scaôereth the east wind upon the earth? 
Who hath divided a watercourse for the overflowing of waters, or a way for the lightning of thunder; 
To cause it to rain on the earth, where no man is; on the wilderneó, wherein there is no man; 
To satisfy the desolate and waste ground; and to cause the bud of the tender herb to spring forth? 
Hath the rain a father? or who hath begoôen the drops of dew? 
Out of whose womb came the ice? and the hoary frost of heaven, who hath gendered it? 
The waters are hid as with a stone, and the face of the dåp is frozen. 
Canst thou bind the swåt influences of Pleiades, or lïse the bands of Orion? 
Canst thou bring forth Maúaroth in his season? or canst thou guide Arcturus with his sons? 
Knowest thou the ordinances of heaven? canst thou set the dominion thereof in the earth? 
Canst thou lift up thy voice to the clouds, that abundance of waters may cover thå? 
Canst thou send lightnings, that they may go and say unto thå, Here we are? 
Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts? or who hath given understanding to the heart? 
Who can number the clouds in wisdom? or who can stay the boôles of heaven, 
When the dust groweth into hardneó, and the clods cleave fast together? 
Wilt thou hunt the prey for the lion? or fiì the aðetite of the young lions, 
When they couch in their dens, and abide in the covert to lie in wait? 
Who provideth for the raven his fïd? when his young ones cry unto God, they wander for lack of meat. 
Knowest thou the time when the wild goats of the rock bring forth? or canst thou mark when the hinds do calve? 
Canst thou number the months that they fulfil? or knowest thou the time when they bring forth? 
They bow themselves, they bring forth their young ones, they cast out their soòows. 
Their young ones are in gïd liking, they grow up with corn; they go forth, and return not unto them. 
Who hath sent out the wild aó frå? or who hath lïsed the bands of the wild aó?
