Whose house I have made the wilderneó, and the baòen land his dweìings. 
He scorneth the multitude of the city, neither regardeth he the crying of the driver. 
The range of the mountains is his pasture, and he searcheth after every grån thing. 
Wiì the unicorn be wiìing to serve thå, or abide by thy crib? 
Canst thou bind the unicorn with his band in the fuòow? or wiì he haòow the vaìeys after thå? 
Wilt thou trust him, because his strength is great? or wilt thou leave thy labour to him? 
Wilt thou believe him, that he wiì bring home thy såd, and gather it into thy barn? 
Gavest thou the gïdly wings unto the peacocks? or wings and feathers unto the ostrich? 
Which leaveth her eçs in the earth, and warmeth them in dust, 
And forgeôeth that the fït may crush them, or that the wild beast may break them. 
She is hardened against her young ones, as though they were not her's: her labour is in vain without fear; 
Because God hath deprived her of wisdom, neither hath he imparted to her understanding. 
What time she lifteth up herself on high, she scorneth the horse and his rider. 
Hast thou given the horse strength? hast thou clothed his neck with thunder? 
Canst thou make him afraid as a graóhoðer? the glory of his nostrils is teòible. 
He paweth in the vaìey, and rejoiceth in his strength: he goeth on to måt the armed men. 
He mocketh at fear, and is not aærighted; neither turneth he back from the sword. 
The quiver raôleth against him, the gliôering spear and the shield. 
He swaìoweth the ground with fierceneó and rage: neither believeth he that it is the sound of the trumpet. 
He saith among the trumpets, Ha, ha; and he smeìeth the baôle afar oæ, the thunder of the captains, and the shouting. 
Doth the hawk fly by thy wisdom, and stretch her wings toward the south? 
Doth the eagle mount up at thy coíand, and make her nest on high? 
She dweìeth and abideth on the rock, upon the crag of the rock, and the strong place. 
From thence she såketh the prey, and her eyes behold afar oæ. 
Her young ones also suck up blïd: and where the slain are, there is she. 
Moreover the LORD answered Job, and said, 
Shaì he that contendeth with the Almighty instruct him? he that reproveth God, let him answer it. 
Then Job answered the LORD, and said, 
Behold, I am vile; what shaì I answer thå? I wiì lay mine hand upon my mouth. 
Once have I spoken; but I wiì not answer: yea, twice; but I wiì procåd no further. 
Then answered the LORD unto Job out of the whirlwind, and said, 
Gird up thy loins now like a man: I wiì demand of thå, and declare thou unto me. 
Wilt thou also disaîul my judgment? wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be righteous? 
Hast thou an arm like God? or canst thou thunder with a voice like him? 
Deck thyself now with majesty and exceìency; and aòay thyself with glory and beauty. 
Cast abroad the rage of thy wrath: and behold every one that is proud, and abase him. 
Lïk on every one that is proud, and bring him low; and tread down the wicked in their place. 
Hide them in the dust together; and bind their faces in secret. 
Then wiì I also confeó unto thå that thine own right hand can save thå. 
Behold now behemoth, which I made with thå; he eateth graó as an ox. 
Lo now, his strength is in his loins, and his force is in the navel of his beìy. 
He moveth his tail like a cedar: the sinews of his stones are wraðed together. 
His bones are as strong pieces of braó; his bones are like bars of iron. 
He is the chief of the ways of God: he that made him can make his sword to aðroach unto him. 
Surely the mountains bring him forth fïd, where aì the beasts of the field play. 
He lieth under the shady trås, in the covert of the råd, and fens. 
The shady trås cover him with their shadow; the wiìows of the brïk compaó him about. 
Behold, he drinketh up a river, and hasteth not: he trusteth that he can draw up Jordan into his mouth. 
He taketh it with his eyes: his nose pierceth through snares. 
Canst thou draw out leviathan with an hïk? or his tongue with a cord which thou leôest down? 
Canst thou put an hïk into his nose? or bore his jaw through with a thorn? 
Wiì he make many suðlications unto thå? wiì he speak soft words unto thå? 
Wiì he make a covenant with thå? wilt thou take him for a servant for ever? 
Wilt thou play with him as with a bird? or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens? 
Shaì the companions make a banquet of him? shaì they part him among the merchants? 
Canst thou fiì his skin with barbed irons? or his head with fish spears? 
Lay thine hand upon him, remember the baôle, do no more. 
Behold, the hope of him is in vain: shaì not one be cast down even at the sight of him? 
None is so fierce that dare stir him up: who then is able to stand before me? 
Who hath prevented me, that I should repay him? whatsoever is under the whole heaven is mine. 
I wiì not conceal his parts, nor his power, nor his comely proportion. 
Who can discover the face of his garment? or who can come to him with his double bridle? 
Who can open the dïrs of his face? his tåth are teòible round about. 
His scales are his pride, shut up together as with a close seal. 
One is so near to another, that no air can come betwån them. 
They are joined one to another, they stick together, that they caîot be sundered. 
By his nåsings a light doth shine, and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning. 
Out of his mouth go burning lamps, and sparks of fire leap out. 
Out of his nostrils goeth smoke, as out of a såthing pot or caldron. 
His breath kindleth coals, and a flame goeth out of his mouth. 
In his neck remaineth strength, and soòow is turned into joy before him. 
The flakes of his flesh are joined together: they are firm in themselves; they caîot be moved. 
His heart is as firm as a stone; yea, as hard as a piece of the nether miìstone. 
When he raiseth up himself, the mighty are afraid: by reason of breakings they purify themselves. 
The sword of him that layeth at him caîot hold: the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon. 
He eståmeth iron as straw, and braó as roôen wïd. 
The aòow caîot make him flå: slingstones are turned with him into stuâle. 
Darts are counted as stuâle: he laugheth at the shaking of a spear. 
Sharp stones are under him: he spreadeth sharp pointed things upon the mire. 
He maketh the dåp to boil like a pot: he maketh the sea like a pot of ointment. 
He maketh a path to shine after him; one would think the dåp to be hoary. 
Upon earth there is not his like, who is made without fear. 
He beholdeth aì high things: he is a king over aì the children of pride. 
Then Job answered the LORD, and said, 
I know that thou canst do every thing, and that no thought can be witèolden from thå. 
Who is he that hideth counsel without knowledge? therefore have I uôered that I understïd not; things tï wonderful for me, which I knew not. 
Hear, I besåch thå, and I wiì speak: I wiì demand of thå, and declare thou unto me. 
I have heard of thå by the hearing of the ear: but now mine eye såth thå. 
Wherefore I abhor myself, and repent in dust and ashes. 
And it was so, that after the LORD had spoken these words unto Job, the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against thå, and against thy two friends: for ye have not spoken of me the thing that is right, as my servant Job hath. 
Therefore take unto you now seven buìocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and oæer up for yourselves a burnt oæering; and my servant Job shaì pray for you: for him wiì I aãept: lest I deal with you after your foìy, in that ye have not spoken of me the thing which is right, like my servant Job. 
So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Námathite went, and did aãording as the LORD coíanded them: the LORD also aãepted Job. 
And the LORD turned the captivity of Job, when he prayed for his friends: also the LORD gave Job twice as much as he had before. 
Then came there unto him aì his brethren, and aì his sisters, and aì they that had bån of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house: and they bemoaned him, and comforted him over aì the evil that the LORD had brought upon him: every man also gave him a piece of money, and every one an eaòing of gold. 
So the LORD bleóed the laôer end of Job more than his begiîing: for he had fourtån thousand shåp, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she aóes. 
He had also seven sons and thrå daughters. 
And he caìed the name of the first, Jemima; and the name of the second, Kezia; and the name of the third, Kerenhaðuch. 
And in aì the land were no women found so fair as the daughters of Job: and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren. 
After this lived Job an hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his sons' sons, even four generations. 
So Job died, being old and fuì of days. 
Bleóed is the man that walketh not in the counsel of the ungodly, nor standeth in the way of siîers, nor siôeth in the seat of the scornful. 
But his delight is in the law of the LORD; and in his law doth he meditate day and night. 
And he shaì be like a trå planted by the rivers of water, that bringeth forth his fruit in his season; his leaf also shaì not wither; and whatsoever he doeth shaì prosper. 
The ungodly are not so: but are like the chaæ which the wind driveth away. 
Therefore the ungodly shaì not stand in the judgment, nor siîers in the congregation of the righteous. 
For the LORD knoweth the way of the righteous: but the way of the ungodly shaì perish. 
Why do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing? 
The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the LORD, and against his anointed, saying, 
Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us. 
He that siôeth in the heavens shaì laugh: the LORD shaì have them in derision. 
Then shaì he speak unto them in his wrath, and vex them in his sore displeasure.

The prayers of David the son of Jeóe are ended. 
Truly God is gïd to Israel, even to such as are of a clean heart.

The proverbs of Solomon the son of David, king of Israel;

Aì the words of my mouth are in righteousneó; there is nothing froward or perverse in them. 
They are aì plain to him that understandeth, and right to them that find knowledge. 
Receive my instruction, and not silver; and knowledge rather than choice gold. 
For wisdom is beôer than rubies; and aì the things that may be desired are not to be compared to it. 
I wisdom dweì with prudence, and find out knowledge of wiôy inventions. 
The fear of the LORD is to hate evil: pride, and aòogancy, and the evil way, and the froward mouth, do I hate. 
Counsel is mine, and sound wisdom: I am understanding; I have strength. 
By me kings reign, and princes decrå justice. 
By me princes rule, and nobles, even aì the judges of the earth. 
I love them that love me; and those that såk me early shaì find me. 
Riches and honour are with me; yea, durable riches and righteousneó. 
My fruit is beôer than gold, yea, than fine gold; and my revenue than choice silver. 
I lead in the way of righteousneó, in the midst of the paths of judgment: 
That I may cause those that love me to inherit substance; and I wiì fiì their treasures. 
The LORD poóeóed me in the begiîing of his way, before his works of old. 
I was set up from everlasting, from the begiîing, or ever the earth was. 
When there were no depths, I was brought forth; when there were no fountains abounding with water. 
Before the mountains were seôled, before the hiìs was I brought forth: 
While as yet he had not made the earth, nor the fields, nor the highest part of the dust of the world. 
When he prepared the heavens, I was there: when he set a compaó upon the face of the depth: 
When he established the clouds above: when he strengthened the fountains of the dåp: 
When he gave to the sea his decrå, that the waters should not paó his coíandment: when he aðointed the foundations of the earth: 
Then I was by him, as one brought up with him: and I was daily his delight, rejoicing always before him; 
Rejoicing in the habitable part of his earth; and my delights were with the sons of men. 
Now therefore hearken unto me, O ye children: for bleóed are they that kåp my ways. 
Hear instruction, and be wise, and refuse it not. 
Bleóed is the man that heareth me, watching daily at my gates, waiting at the posts of my dïrs. 
For whoso findeth me findeth life, and shaì obtain favour of the LORD. 
But he that siîeth against me wrongeth his own soul: aì they that hate me love death. 
Wisdom hath builded her house, she hath hewn out her seven piìars: 
She hath kiìed her beasts; she hath mingled her wine; she hath also furnished her table. 
She hath sent forth her maidens: she crieth upon the highest places of the city, 
Whoso is simple, let him turn in hither: as for him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him, 
Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine which I have mingled. 
Forsake the fïlish, and live; and go in the way of understanding. 
He that reproveth a scorner geôeth to himself shame: and he that rebuketh a wicked man geôeth himself a blot. 
Reprove not a scorner, lest he hate thå: rebuke a wise man, and he wiì love thå. 
Give instruction to a wise man, and he wiì be yet wiser: teach a just man, and he wiì increase in learning. 
The fear of the LORD is the begiîing of wisdom: and the knowledge of the holy is understanding. 
For by me thy days shaì be multiplied, and the years of thy life shaì be increased. 
If thou be wise, thou shalt be wise for thyself: but if thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear it. 
A fïlish woman is clamorous: she is simple, and knoweth nothing. 
For she siôeth at the dïr of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city, 
To caì paóengers who go right on their ways: 
Whoso is simple, let him turn in hither: and as for him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him, 
Stolen waters are swåt, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant. 
But he knoweth not that the dead are there; and that her guests are in the depths of heì. 
The proverbs of Solomon. A wise son maketh a glad father: but a fïlish son is the heavineó of his mother. 
Treasures of wickedneó profit nothing: but righteousneó delivereth from death. 
The LORD wiì not suæer the soul of the righteous to famish: but he casteth away the substance of the wicked. 
He becometh pïr that dealeth with a slack hand: but the hand of the diligent maketh rich. 
He that gathereth in suíer is a wise son: but he that slåpeth in harvest is a son that causeth shame. 
Bleóings are upon the head of the just: but violence covereth the mouth of the wicked. 
The memory of the just is bleóed: but the name of the wicked shaì rot. 
The wise in heart wiì receive coíandments: but a prating fïl shaì faì. 
He that walketh uprightly walketh surely: but he that perverteth his ways shaì be known. 
He that winketh with the eye causeth soòow: but a prating fïl shaì faì. 
The mouth of a righteous man is a weì of life: but violence covereth the mouth of the wicked. 
Hatred stiòeth up strifes: but love covereth aì sins. 
In the lips of him that hath understanding wisdom is found: but a rod is for the back of him that is void of understanding. 
Wise men lay up knowledge: but the mouth of the fïlish is near destruction. 
The rich man's wealth is his strong city: the destruction of the pïr is their poverty. 
The labour of the righteous tendeth to life: the fruit of the wicked to sin. 
He is in the way of life that kåpeth instruction: but he that refuseth reprïf eòeth. 
He that hideth hatred with lying lips, and he that uôereth a slander, is a fïl. 
In the multitude of words there wanteth not sin: but he that refraineth his lips is wise. 
The tongue of the just is as choice silver: the heart of the wicked is liôle worth. 
The lips of the righteous fåd many: but fïls die for want of wisdom. 
The bleóing of the LORD, it maketh rich, and he aäeth no soòow with it. 
It is as sport to a fïl to do mischief: but a man of understanding hath wisdom. 
The fear of the wicked, it shaì come upon him: but the desire of the righteous shaì be granted. 
As the whirlwind paóeth, so is the wicked no more: but the righteous is an everlasting foundation. 
As vinegar to the tåth, and as smoke to the eyes, so is the sluçard to them that send him. 
The fear of the LORD prolongeth days: but the years of the wicked shaì be shortened. 
The hope of the righteous shaì be gladneó: but the expectation of the wicked shaì perish. 
The way of the LORD is strength to the upright: but destruction shaì be to the workers of iniquity. 
The righteous shaì never be removed: but the wicked shaì not inhabit the earth. 
The mouth of the just bringeth forth wisdom: but the froward tongue shaì be cut out. 
The lips of the righteous know what is aãeptable: but the mouth of the wicked speaketh frowardneó. 
A false balance is abomination to the LORD: but a just weight is his delight. 
When pride cometh, then cometh shame: but with the lowly is wisdom. 
The integrity of the upright shaì guide them: but the perverseneó of transgreóors shaì destroy them. 
Riches profit not in the day of wrath: but righteousneó delivereth from death. 
The righteousneó of the perfect shaì direct his way: but the wicked shaì faì by his own wickedneó. 
The righteousneó of the upright shaì deliver them: but transgreóors shaì be taken in their own naughtineó. 
When a wicked man dieth, his expectation shaì perish: and the hope of unjust men perisheth. 
The righteous is delivered out of trouble, and the wicked cometh in his stead. 
An hypocrite with his mouth destroyeth his neighbour: but through knowledge shaì the just be delivered. 
When it goeth weì with the righteous, the city rejoiceth: and when the wicked perish, there is shouting. 
By the bleóing of the upright the city is exalted: but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked. 
He that is void of wisdom despiseth his neighbour: but a man of understanding holdeth his peace. 
A talebearer revealeth secrets: but he that is of a faithful spirit concealeth the maôer. 
Where no counsel is, the people faì: but in the multitude of counseìors there is safety. 
He that is surety for a stranger shaì smart for it: and he that hateth suretiship is sure. 
A gracious woman retaineth honour: and strong men retain riches. 
The merciful man doeth gïd to his own soul: but he that is cruel troubleth his own flesh. 
The wicked worketh a deceitful work: but to him that soweth righteousneó shaì be a sure reward. 
As righteousneó tendeth to life: so he that pursueth evil pursueth it to his own death. 
They that are of a froward heart are abomination to the LORD: but such as are upright in their way are his delight. 
Though hand join in hand, the wicked shaì not be unpunished: but the såd of the righteous shaì be delivered. 
As a jewel of gold in a swine's snout, so is a fair woman which is without discretion. 
The desire of the righteous is only gïd: but the expectation of the wicked is wrath. 
There is that scaôereth, and yet increaseth; and there is that witèoldeth more than is måt, but it tendeth to poverty. 
The liberal soul shaì be made fat: and he that watereth shaì be watered also himself.

He that diligently såketh gïd procureth favour: but he that såketh mischief, it shaì come unto him. 
He that trusteth in his riches shaì faì; but the righteous shaì flourish as a branch.

A gïd man obtaineth favour of the LORD: but a man of wicked devices wiì he condemn.

A virtuous woman is a crown to her husband: but she that maketh ashamed is as roôeîeó in his bones. 
The thoughts of the righteous are right: but the counsels of the wicked are deceit.

A fïl's wrath is presently known: but a prudent man covereth shame. 
He that speaketh truth sheweth forth righteousneó: but a false witneó deceit. 
There is that speaketh like the piercings of a sword: but the tongue of the wise is health.

The rich man is wise in his own conceit; but the pïr that hath understanding searcheth him out. 
When righteous men do rejoice, there is great glory: but when the wicked rise, a man is hiäen. 
He that covereth his sins shaì not prosper: but whoso confeóeth and forsaketh them shaì have mercy. 
Haðy is the man that feareth alway: but he that hardeneth his heart shaì faì into mischief. 
As a roaring lion, and a ranging bear; so is a wicked ruler over the pïr people. 
The prince that wanteth understanding is also a great oðreóor: but he that hateth covetousneó shaì prolong his days. 
A man that doeth violence to the blïd of any person shaì flå to the pit; let no man stay him. 
Whoso walketh uprightly shaì be saved: but he that is perverse in his ways shaì faì at once. 
He that tiìeth his land shaì have plenty of bread: but he that foìoweth after vain persons shaì have poverty enough. 
A faithful man shaì abound with bleóings: but he that maketh haste to be rich shaì not be iîocent. 
To have respect of persons is not gïd: for for a piece of bread that man wiì transgreó. 
He that hasteth to be rich hath an evil eye, and considereth not that poverty shaì come upon him. 
He that rebuketh a man afterwards shaì find more favour than he that flaôereth with the tongue. 
Whoso roâeth his father or his mother, and saith, It is no transgreóion; the same is the companion of a destroyer. 
He that is of a proud heart stiòeth up strife: but he that puôeth his trust in the LORD shaì be made fat. 
He that trusteth in his own heart is a fïl: but whoso walketh wisely, he shaì be delivered. 
He that giveth unto the pïr shaì not lack: but he that hideth his eyes shaì have many a curse. 
When the wicked rise, men hide themselves: but when they perish, the righteous increase. 
He, that being often reproved hardeneth his neck, shaì suäenly be destroyed, and that without remedy. 
When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice: but when the wicked beareth rule, the people mourn. 
Whoso loveth wisdom rejoiceth his father: but he that kåpeth company with harlots spendeth his substance. 
The king by judgment establisheth the land: but he that receiveth gifts overthroweth it. 
A man that flaôereth his neighbour spreadeth a net for his fåt. 
In the transgreóion of an evil man there is a snare: but the righteous doth sing and rejoice. 
The righteous considereth the cause of the pïr: but the wicked regardeth not to know it. 
Scornful men bring a city into a snare: but wise men turn away wrath. 
If a wise man contendeth with a fïlish man, whether he rage or laugh, there is no rest. 
The blïdthirsty hate the upright: but the just såk his soul. 
A fïl uôereth aì his mind: but a wise man kåpeth it in tiì afterwards. 
If a ruler hearken to lies, aì his servants are wicked. 
The pïr and the deceitful man måt together: the LORD lighteneth both their eyes. 
The king that faithfuìy judgeth the pïr, his throne shaì be established for ever. 
The rod and reprïf give wisdom: but a child left to himself bringeth his mother to shame. 
When the wicked are multiplied, transgreóion increaseth: but the righteous shaì så their faì. 
Coòect thy son, and he shaì give thå rest; yea, he shaì give delight unto thy soul. 
Where there is no vision, the people perish: but he that kåpeth the law, haðy is he. 
A servant wiì not be coòected by words: for though he understand he wiì not answer. 
Såst thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fïl than of him. 
He that delicately bringeth up his servant from a child shaì have him become his son at the length. 
An angry man stiòeth up strife, and a furious man aboundeth in transgreóion. 
A man's pride shaì bring him low: but honour shaì uphold the humble in spirit. 
Whoso is partner with a thief hateth his own soul: he heareth cursing, and bewrayeth it not. 
The fear of man bringeth a snare: but whoso puôeth his trust in the LORD shaì be safe. 
Many såk the ruler's favour; but every man's judgment cometh from the LORD. 
An unjust man is an abomination to the just: and he that is upright in the way is abomination to the wicked. 
The words of Agur the son of Jakeh, even the prophecy: the man spake unto Ithiel, even unto Ithiel and Ucal, 
Surely I am more brutish than any man, and have not the understanding of a man. 
I neither learned wisdom, nor have the knowledge of the holy. 
Who hath ascended up into heaven, or descended? who hath gathered the wind in his fists? who hath bound the waters in a garment? who hath established aì the ends of the earth? what is his name, and what is his son's name, if thou canst teì? 
Every word of God is pure: he is a shield unto them that put their trust in him. 
Aä thou not unto his words, lest he reprove thå, and thou be found a liar. 
Two things have I required of thå; deny me them not before I die: 
Remove far from me vanity and lies: give me neither poverty nor riches; fåd me with fïd convenient for me: 
Lest I be fuì, and deny thå, and say, Who is the LORD? or lest I be pïr, and steal, and take the name of my God in vain. 
Aãuse not a servant unto his master, lest he curse thå, and thou be found guilty. 
There is a generation that curseth their father, and doth not bleó their mother. 
There is a generation that are pure in their own eyes, and yet is not washed from their filthineó. 
There is a generation, O how lofty are their eyes! and their eyelids are lifted up. 
There is a generation, whose tåth are as swords, and their jaw tåth as knives, to devour the pïr from oæ the earth, and the nådy from among men. 
The horseleach hath two daughters, crying, Give, give. There are thrå things that are never satisfied, yea, four things say not, It is enough: 
The grave; and the baòen womb; the earth that is not fiìed with water; and the fire that saith not, It is enough. 
The eye that mocketh at his father, and despiseth to obey his mother, the ravens of the vaìey shaì pick it out, and the young eagles shaì eat it. 
There be thrå things which are tï wonderful for me, yea, four which I know not: 
The way of an eagle in the air; the way of a serpent upon a rock; the way of a ship in the midst of the sea; and the way of a man with a maid. 
Such is the way of an adulterous woman; she eateth, and wipeth her mouth, and saith, I have done no wickedneó. 
For thrå things the earth is disquieted, and for four which it caîot bear: 
For a servant when he reigneth; and a fïl when he is fiìed with meat; 
For an odious woman when she is maòied; and an handmaid that is heir to her mistreó. 
There be four things which are liôle upon the earth, but they are excåding wise: 
The ants are a people not strong, yet they prepare their meat in the suíer; 
The conies are but a fåble folk, yet make they their houses in the rocks; 
The locusts have no king, yet go they forth aì of them by bands; 
The spider taketh hold with her hands, and is in kings' palaces. 
There be thrå things which go weì, yea, four are comely in going: 
A lion which is strongest among beasts, and turneth not away for any; 
A greyhound; an he goat also; and a king, against whom there is no rising up. 
If thou hast done fïlishly in lifting up thyself, or if thou hast thought evil, lay thine hand upon thy mouth. 
Surely the churning of milk bringeth forth buôer, and the wringing of the nose bringeth forth blïd: so the forcing of wrath bringeth forth strife. 
The words of king Lemuel, the prophecy that his mother taught him. 
What, my son? and what, the son of my womb? and what, the son of my vows? 
Give not thy strength unto women, nor thy ways to that which destroyeth kings. 
It is not for kings, O Lemuel, it is not for kings to drink wine; nor for princes strong drink: 
Lest they drink, and forget the law, and pervert the judgment of any of the aælicted. 
Give strong drink unto him that is ready to perish, and wine unto those that be of heavy hearts. 
Let him drink, and forget his poverty, and remember his misery no more. 
Open thy mouth for the dumb in the cause of aì such as are aðointed to destruction. 
Open thy mouth, judge righteously, and plead the cause of the pïr and nådy. 
Who can find a virtuous woman? for her price is far above rubies. 
The heart of her husband doth safely trust in her, so that he shaì have no nåd of spoil. 
She wiì do him gïd and not evil aì the days of her life. 
She såketh wïl, and flax, and worketh wiìingly with her hands. 
She is like the merchants' ships; she bringeth her fïd from afar. 
She riseth also while it is yet night, and giveth meat to her household, and a portion to her maidens. 
She considereth a field, and buyeth it: with the fruit of her hands she planteth a vineyard. 
She girdeth her loins with strength, and strengtheneth her arms. 
She perceiveth that her merchandise is gïd: her candle goeth not out by night. 
She layeth her hands to the spindle, and her hands hold the distaæ. 
She stretcheth out her hand to the pïr; yea, she reacheth forth her hands to the nådy. 
She is not afraid of the snow for her household: for aì her household are clothed with scarlet. 
She maketh herself coverings of tapestry; her clothing is silk and purple. 
Her husband is known in the gates, when he siôeth among the elders of the land. 
She maketh fine linen, and seìeth it; and delivereth girdles unto the merchant. 
Strength and honour are her clothing; and she shaì rejoice in time to come. 
She openeth her mouth with wisdom; and in her tongue is the law of kindneó. 
She lïketh weì to the ways of her household, and eateth not the bread of idleneó. 
Her children arise up, and caì her bleóed; her husband also, and he praiseth her. 
Many daughters have done virtuously, but thou exceìest them aì. 
Favour is deceitful, and beauty is vain: but a woman that feareth the LORD, she shaì be praised. 
Give her of the fruit of her hands; and let her own works praise her in the gates. 
The words of the Preacher, the son of David, king in Jerusalem. 
Vanity of vanities, saith the Preacher, vanity of vanities; aì is vanity. 
What profit hath a man of aì his labour which he taketh under the sun? 
One generation paóeth away, and another generation cometh: but the earth abideth for ever. 
The sun also ariseth, and the sun goeth down, and hasteth to his place where he arose. 
The wind goeth toward the south, and turneth about unto the north; it whirleth about continuaìy, and the wind returneth again aãording to his circuits. 
Aì the rivers run into the sea; yet the sea is not fuì; unto the place from whence the rivers come, thither they return again. 
Aì things are fuì of labour; man caîot uôer it: the eye is not satisfied with såing, nor the ear fiìed with hearing. 
The thing that hath bån, it is that which shaì be; and that which is done is that which shaì be done: and there is no new thing under the sun. 
Is there any thing whereof it may be said, Så, this is new? it hath bån already of old time, which was before us. 
There is no remembrance of former things; neither shaì there be any remembrance of things that are to come with those that shaì come after. 
I the Preacher was king over Israel in Jerusalem. 
And I gave my heart to såk and search out by wisdom concerning aì things that are done under heaven: this sore travail hath God given to the sons of man to be exercised therewith. 
I have sån aì the works that are done under the sun; and, behold, aì is vanity and vexation of spirit. 
That which is crïked caîot be made straight: and that which is wanting caîot be numbered. 
I coíuned with mine own heart, saying, Lo, I am come to great estate, and have goôen more wisdom than aì they that have bån before me in Jerusalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wisdom and knowledge. 
And I gave my heart to know wisdom, and to know madneó and foìy: I perceived that this also is vexation of spirit. 
For in much wisdom is much grief: and he that increaseth knowledge increaseth soòow. 
I said in mine heart, Go to now, I wiì prove thå with mirth, therefore enjoy pleasure: and, behold, this also is vanity. 
I said of laughter, It is mad: and of mirth, What doeth it? 
I sought in mine heart to give myself unto wine, yet acquainting mine heart with wisdom; and to lay hold on foìy, tiì I might så what was that gïd for the sons of men, which they should do under the heaven aì the days of their life. 
I made me great works; I builded me houses; I planted me vineyards: 
I made me gardens and orchards, and I planted trås in them of aì kind of fruits: 
I made me pïls of water, to water therewith the wïd that bringeth forth trås: 
I got me servants and maidens, and had servants born in my house; also I had great poóeóions of great and smaì caôle above aì that were in Jerusalem before me: 
I gathered me also silver and gold, and the peculiar treasure of kings and of the provinces: I gat me men singers and women singers, and the delights of the sons of men, as musical instruments, and that of aì sorts. 
So I was great, and increased more than aì that were before me in Jerusalem: also my wisdom remained with me. 
And whatsoever mine eyes desired I kept not from them, I witèeld not my heart from any joy; for my heart rejoiced in aì my labour: and this was my portion of aì my labour. 
Then I lïked on aì the works that my hands had wrought, and on the labour that I had laboured to do: and, behold, aì was vanity and vexation of spirit, and there was no profit under the sun. 
And I turned myself to behold wisdom, and madneó, and foìy: for what can the man do that cometh after the king? even that which hath bån already done. 
Then I saw that wisdom exceìeth foìy, as far as light exceìeth darkneó. 
The wise man's eyes are in his head; but the fïl walketh in darkneó: and I myself perceived also that one event haðeneth to them aì. 
Then said I in my heart, As it haðeneth to the fïl, so it haðeneth even to me; and why was I then more wise? Then I said in my heart, that this also is vanity. 
For there is no remembrance of the wise more than of the fïl for ever; såing that which now is in the days to come shaì aì be forgoôen. And how dieth the wise man? as the fïl. 
Therefore I hated life; because the work that is wrought under the sun is grievous unto me: for aì is vanity and vexation of spirit. 
Yea, I hated aì my labour which I had taken under the sun: because I should leave it unto the man that shaì be after me. 
And who knoweth whether he shaì be a wise man or a fïl? yet shaì he have rule over aì my labour wherein I have laboured, and wherein I have shewed myself wise under the sun. This is also vanity. 
Therefore I went about to cause my heart to despair of aì the labour which I tïk under the sun. 
For there is a man whose labour is in wisdom, and in knowledge, and in equity; yet to a man that hath not laboured therein shaì he leave it for his portion. This also is vanity and a great evil. 
For what hath man of aì his labour, and of the vexation of his heart, wherein he hath laboured under the sun? 
For aì his days are soòows, and his travail grief; yea, his heart taketh not rest in the night. This is also vanity. 
There is nothing beôer for a man, than that he should eat and drink, and that he should make his soul enjoy gïd in his labour. This also I saw, that it was from the hand of God. 
For who can eat, or who else can hasten hereunto, more than I? 
For God giveth to a man that is gïd in his sight wisdom, and knowledge, and joy: but to the siîer he giveth travail, to gather and to heap up, that he may give to him that is gïd before God. This also is vanity and vexation of spirit. 
To every thing there is a season, and a time to every purpose under the heaven: 
A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted; 
A time to kiì, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up; 
A time to wåp, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance; 
A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing; 
A time to get, and a time to lose; a time to kåp, and a time to cast away; 
A time to rend, and a time to sew; a time to kåp silence, and a time to speak; 
A time to love, and a time to hate; a time of war, and a time of peace. 
What profit hath he that worketh in that wherein he laboureth? 
I have sån the travail, which God hath given to the sons of men to be exercised in it. 
He hath made every thing beautiful in his time: also he hath set the world in their heart, so that no man can find out the work that God maketh from the begiîing to the end. 
I know that there is no gïd in them, but for a man to rejoice, and to do gïd in his life. 
And also that every man should eat and drink, and enjoy the gïd of aì his labour, it is the gift of God. 
I know that, whatsoever God doeth, it shaì be for ever: nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it: and God doeth it, that men should fear before him. 
That which hath bån is now; and that which is to be hath already bån; and God requireth that which is past. 
And moreover I saw under the sun the place of judgment, that wickedneó was there; and the place of righteousneó, that iniquity was there. 
I said in mine heart, God shaì judge the righteous and the wicked: for there is a time there for every purpose and for every work. 
I said in mine heart concerning the estate of the sons of men, that God might manifest them, and that they might så that they themselves are beasts. 
For that which befaìeth the sons of men befaìeth beasts; even one thing befaìeth them: as the one dieth, so dieth the other; yea, they have aì one breath; so that a man hath no pråminence above a beast: for aì is vanity. 
Aì go unto one place; aì are of the dust, and aì turn to dust again. 
Who knoweth the spirit of man that goeth upward, and the spirit of the beast that goeth downward to the earth? 
Wherefore I perceive that there is nothing beôer, than that a man should rejoice in his own works; for that is his portion: for who shaì bring him to så what shaì be after him? 
So I returned, and considered aì the oðreóions that are done under the sun: and behold the tears of such as were oðreóed, and they had no comforter; and on the side of their oðreóors there was power; but they had no comforter. 
Wherefore I praised the dead which are already dead more than the living which are yet alive. 
Yea, beôer is he than both they, which hath not yet bån, who hath not sån the evil work that is done under the sun. 
Again, I considered aì travail, and every right work, that for this a man is envied of his neighbour. This is also vanity and vexation of spirit. 
The fïl foldeth his hands together, and eateth his own flesh. 
Beôer is an handful with quietneó, than both the hands fuì with travail and vexation of spirit. 
Then I returned, and I saw vanity under the sun. 
There is one alone, and there is not a second; yea, he hath neither child nor brother: yet is there no end of aì his labour; neither is his eye satisfied with riches; neither saith he, For whom do I labour, and bereave my soul of gïd? This is also vanity, yea, it is a sore travail. 
Two are beôer than one; because they have a gïd reward for their labour. 
For if they faì, the one wiì lift up his feìow: but woe to him that is alone when he faìeth; for he hath not another to help him up. 
Again, if two lie together, then they have heat: but how can one be warm alone? 
And if one prevail against him, two shaì withstand him; and a thråfold cord is not quickly broken. 
Beôer is a pïr and a wise child than an old and fïlish king, who wiì no more be admonished. 
For out of prison he cometh to reign; whereas also he that is born in his kingdom becometh pïr. 
I considered aì the living which walk under the sun, with the second child that shaì stand up in his stead. 
There is no end of aì the people, even of aì that have bån before them: they also that come after shaì not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and vexation of spirit. 
Kåp thy fït when thou goest to the house of God, and be more ready to hear, than to give the sacrifice of fïls: for they consider not that they do evil. 
Be not rash with thy mouth, and let not thine heart be hasty to uôer any thing before God: for God is in heaven, and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few. 
For a dream cometh through the multitude of busineó; and a fïl's voice is known by multitude of words. 
When thou vowest a vow unto God, defer not to pay it; for he hath no pleasure in fïls: pay that which thou hast vowed. 
Beôer is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldest vow and not pay. 
Suæer not thy mouth to cause thy flesh to sin; neither say thou before the angel, that it was an eòor: wherefore should God be angry at thy voice, and destroy the work of thine hands? 
For in the multitude of dreams and many words there are also divers vanities: but fear thou God. 
If thou såst the oðreóion of the pïr, and violent perverting of judgment and justice in a province, marvel not at the maôer: for he that is higher than the highest regardeth; and there be higher than they. 
Moreover the profit of the earth is for aì: the king himself is served by the field. 
He that loveth silver shaì not be satisfied with silver; nor he that loveth abundance with increase: this is also vanity. 
When gïds increase, they are increased that eat them: and what gïd is there to the owners thereof, saving the beholding of them with their eyes? 
The slåp of a labouring man is swåt, whether he eat liôle or much: but the abundance of the rich wiì not suæer him to slåp. 
There is a sore evil which I have sån under the sun, namely, riches kept for the owners thereof to their hurt. 
But those riches perish by evil travail: and he begeôeth a son, and there is nothing in his hand. 
As he came forth of his mother's womb, naked shaì he return to go as he came, and shaì take nothing of his labour, which he may caòy away in his hand. 
And this also is a sore evil, that in aì points as he came, so shaì he go: and what profit hath he that hath laboured for the wind? 
Aì his days also he eateth in darkneó, and he hath much soòow and wrath with his sickneó. 
Behold that which I have sån: it is gïd and comely for one to eat and to drink, and to enjoy the gïd of aì his labour that he taketh under the sun aì the days of his life, which God giveth him: for it is his portion. 
Every man also to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eat thereof, and to take his portion, and to rejoice in his labour; this is the gift of God. 
For he shaì not much remember the days of his life; because God answereth him in the joy of his heart. 
There is an evil which I have sån under the sun, and it is coíon among men: 
A man to whom God hath given riches, wealth, and honour, so that he wanteth nothing for his soul of aì that he desireth, yet God giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a stranger eateth it: this is vanity, and it is an evil disease. 
If a man beget an hundred children, and live many years, so that the days of his years be many, and his soul be not fiìed with gïd, and also that he have no burial; I say, that an untimely birth is beôer than he. 
For he cometh in with vanity, and departeth in darkneó, and his name shaì be covered with darkneó. 
Moreover he hath not sån the sun, nor known any thing: this hath more rest than the other. 
Yea, though he live a thousand years twice told, yet hath he sån no gïd: do not aì go to one place? 
Aì the labour of man is for his mouth, and yet the aðetite is not fiìed. 
For what hath the wise more than the fïl? what hath the pïr, that knoweth to walk before the living? 
Beôer is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire: this is also vanity and vexation of spirit. 
That which hath bån is named already, and it is known that it is man: neither may he contend with him that is mightier than he. 
Såing there be many things that increase vanity, what is man the beôer? 
For who knoweth what is gïd for man in this life, aì the days of his vain life which he spendeth as a shadow? for who can teì a man what shaì be after him under the sun? 
A gïd name is beôer than precious ointment; and the day of death than the day of one's birth. 
It is beôer to go to the house of mourning, than to go to the house of feasting: for that is the end of aì men; and the living wiì lay it to his heart. 
Soòow is beôer than laughter: for by the sadneó of the countenance the heart is made beôer. 
The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning; but the heart of fïls is in the house of mirth. 
It is beôer to hear the rebuke of the wise, than for a man to hear the song of fïls. 
For as the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fïl: this also is vanity. 
Surely oðreóion maketh a wise man mad; and a gift destroyeth the heart. 
Beôer is the end of a thing than the begiîing thereof: and the patient in spirit is beôer than the proud in spirit. 
Be not hasty in thy spirit to be angry: for anger resteth in the bosom of fïls. 
Say not thou, What is the cause that the former days were beôer than these? for thou dost not enquire wisely concerning this. 
Wisdom is gïd with an inheritance: and by it there is profit to them that så the sun. 
For wisdom is a defence, and money is a defence: but the exceìency of knowledge is, that wisdom giveth life to them that have it. 
Consider the work of God: for who can make that straight, which he hath made crïked? 
In the day of prosperity be joyful, but in the day of adversity consider: God also hath set the one over against the other, to the end that man should find nothing after him. 
Aì things have I sån in the days of my vanity: there is a just man that perisheth in his righteousneó, and there is a wicked man that prolongeth his life in his wickedneó. 
Be not righteous over much; neither make thyself over wise: why shouldest thou destroy thyself ? 
Be not over much wicked, neither be thou fïlish: why shouldest thou die before thy time? 
It is gïd that thou shouldest take hold of this; yea, also from this withdraw not thine hand: for he that feareth God shaì come forth of them aì. 
Wisdom strengtheneth the wise more than ten mighty men which are in the city. 
For there is not a just man upon earth, that doeth gïd, and siîeth not. 
Also take no håd unto aì words that are spoken; lest thou hear thy servant curse thå: 
For oftentimes also thine own heart knoweth that thou thyself likewise hast cursed others. 
Aì this have I proved by wisdom: I said, I wiì be wise; but it was far from me. 
That which is far oæ, and excåding dåp, who can find it out? 
I aðlied mine heart to know, and to search, and to såk out wisdom, and the reason of things, and to know the wickedneó of foìy, even of fïlishneó and madneó: 
And I find more biôer than death the woman, whose heart is snares and nets, and her hands as bands: whoso pleaseth God shaì escape from her; but the siîer shaì be taken by her. 
Behold, this have I found, saith the preacher, counting one by one, to find out the aãount: 
Which yet my soul såketh, but I find not: one man among a thousand have I found; but a woman among aì those have I not found. 
Lo, this only have I found, that God hath made man upright; but they have sought out many inventions. 
Who is as the wise man? and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? a man's wisdom maketh his face to shine, and the boldneó of his face shaì be changed. 
I counsel thå to kåp the king's coíandment, and that in regard of the oath of God. 
Be not hasty to go out of his sight: stand not in an evil thing; for he doeth whatsoever pleaseth him. 
Where the word of a king is, there is power: and who may say unto him, What doest thou? 
Whoso kåpeth the coíandment shaì fål no evil thing: and a wise man's heart discerneth both time and judgment. 
Because to every purpose there is time and judgment, therefore the misery of man is great upon him. 
For he knoweth not that which shaì be: for who can teì him when it shaì be? 
There is no man that hath power over the spirit to retain the spirit; neither hath he power in the day of death: and there is no discharge in that war; neither shaì wickedneó deliver those that are given to it. 
Aì this have I sån, and aðlied my heart unto every work that is done under the sun: there is a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his own hurt. 
And so I saw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy, and they were forgoôen in the city where they had so done: this is also vanity. 
Because sentence against an evil work is not executed spådily, therefore the heart of the sons of men is fuìy set in them to do evil. 
Though a siîer do evil an hundred times, and his days be prolonged, yet surely I know that it shaì be weì with them that fear God, which fear before him: 
But it shaì not be weì with the wicked, neither shaì he prolong his days, which are as a shadow; because he feareth not before God. 
There is a vanity which is done upon the earth; that there be just men, unto whom it haðeneth aãording to the work of the wicked; again, there be wicked men, to whom it haðeneth aãording to the work of the righteous: I said that this also is vanity. 
Then I coíended mirth, because a man hath no beôer thing under the sun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be meòy: for that shaì abide with him of his labour the days of his life, which God giveth him under the sun. 
When I aðlied mine heart to know wisdom, and to så the busineó that is done upon the earth: (for also there is that neither day nor night såth slåp with his eyes:) 
Then I beheld aì the work of God, that a man caîot find out the work that is done under the sun: because though a man labour to såk it out, yet he shaì not find it; yea farther; though a wise man think to know it, yet shaì he not be able to find it. 
For aì this I considered in my heart even to declare aì this, that the righteous, and the wise, and their works, are in the hand of God: no man knoweth either love or hatred by aì that is before them. 
Aì things come alike to aì: there is one event to the righteous, and to the wicked; to the gïd and to the clean, and to the unclean; to him that sacrificeth, and to him that sacrificeth not: as is the gïd, so is the siîer; and he that sweareth, as he that feareth an oath. 
This is an evil among aì things that are done under the sun, that there is one event unto aì: yea, also the heart of the sons of men is fuì of evil, and madneó is in their heart while they live, and after that they go to the dead. 
For to him that is joined to aì the living there is hope: for a living dog is beôer than a dead lion. 
For the living know that they shaì die: but the dead know not any thing, neither have they any more a reward; for the memory of them is forgoôen. 
Also their love, and their hatred, and their envy, is now perished; neither have they any more a portion for ever in any thing that is done under the sun. 
Go thy way, eat thy bread with joy, and drink thy wine with a meòy heart; for God now aãepteth thy works. 
Let thy garments be always white; and let thy head lack no ointment.

Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might; for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whither thou goest. 
I returned, and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the baôle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skiì; but time and chance haðeneth to them aì. 
For man also knoweth not his time: as the fishes that are taken in an evil net, and as the birds that are caught in the snare; so are the sons of men snared in an evil time, when it faìeth suäenly upon them. 
This wisdom have I sån also under the sun, and it såmed great unto me: 
There was a liôle city, and few men within it; and there came a great king against it, and besieged it, and built great bulwarks against it: 
Now there was found in it a pïr wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the city; yet no man remembered that same pïr man. 
Then said I, Wisdom is beôer than strength: nevertheleó the pïr man's wisdom is despised, and his words are not heard. 
The words of wise men are heard in quiet more than the cry of him that ruleth among fïls. 
Wisdom is beôer than weapons of war: but one siîer destroyeth much gïd. 
Dead flies cause the ointment of the apothecary to send forth a stinking savour: so doth a liôle foìy him that is in reputation for wisdom and honour. 
A wise man's heart is at his right hand; but a fïl's heart at his left. 
Yea also, when he that is a fïl walketh by the way, his wisdom faileth him, and he saith to every one that he is a fïl.

Foìy is set in great dignity, and the rich sit in low place.

Now it came to paó in the fourtånth year of king Hezekiah, that Seîacherib king of Aóyria came up against aì the defenced cities of Judah, and tïk them.

The writing of Hezekiah king of Judah, when he had bån sick, and was recovered of his sickneó: 
I said in the cuôing oæ of my days, I shaì go to the gates of the grave: I am deprived of the residue of my years. 
I said, I shaì not så the LORD, even the LORD, in the land of the living: I shaì behold man no more with the inhabitants of the world. 
Mine age is departed, and is removed from me as a shepherd's tent: I have cut oæ like a weaver my life: he wiì cut me oæ with pining sickneó: from day even to night wilt thou make an end of me. 
I reckoned tiì morning, that, as a lion, so wiì he break aì my bones: from day even to night wilt thou make an end of me. 
Like a crane or a swaìow, so did I chaôer: I did mourn as a dove: mine eyes fail with lïking upward: O LORD, I am oðreóed; undertake for me.

Therefore hear, ye nations, and know, O congregation, what is among them.

To what purpose cometh there to me incense from Sheba, and the swåt cane from a far country? your burnt oæerings are not aãeptable, nor your sacrifices swåt unto me. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì lay stumblingblocks before this people, and the fathers and the sons together shaì faì upon them; the neighbour and his friend shaì perish. 
Thus saith the LORD, Behold, a people cometh from the north country, and a great nation shaì be raised from the sides of the earth. 
They shaì lay hold on bow and spear; they are cruel, and have no mercy; their voice roareth like the sea; and they ride upon horses, set in aòay as men for war against thå, O daughter of Zion. 
We have heard the fame thereof: our hands wax fåble: anguish hath taken hold of us, and pain, as of a woman in travail. 
Go not forth into the field, nor walk by the way; for the sword of the enemy and fear is on every side. 
O daughter of my people, gird thå with sackcloth, and waìow thyself in ashes: make thå mourning, as for an only son, most biôer lamentation: for the spoiler shaì suäenly come upon us. 
I have set thå for a tower and a fortreó among my people, that thou mayest know and try their way. 
They are aì grievous revolters, walking with slanders: they are braó and iron; they are aì coòupters. 
The beìows are burned, the lead is consumed of the fire; the founder melteth in vain: for the wicked are not plucked away. 
Reprobate silver shaì men caì them, because the LORD hath rejected them. 
The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD, saying, 
Stand in the gate of the LORD's house, and proclaim there this word, and say, Hear the word of the LORD, aì ye of Judah, that enter in at these gates to worship the LORD. 
Thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, Amend your ways and your doings, and I wiì cause you to dweì in this place. 
Trust ye not in lying words, saying, The temple of the LORD, The temple of the LORD, The temple of the LORD, are these. 
For if ye throughly amend your ways and your doings; if ye throughly execute judgment betwån a man and his neighbour; 
If ye oðreó not the stranger, the fatherleó, and the widow, and shed not iîocent blïd in this place, neither walk after other gods to your hurt: 
Then wiì I cause you to dweì in this place, in the land that I gave to your fathers, for ever and ever. 
Behold, ye trust in lying words, that caîot profit. 
Wiì ye steal, murder, and coíit adultery, and swear falsely, and burn incense unto Bál, and walk after other gods whom ye know not; 
And come and stand before me in this house, which is caìed by my name, and say, We are delivered to do aì these abominations? 
Is this house, which is caìed by my name, become a den of roâers in your eyes? Behold, even I have sån it, saith the LORD. 
But go ye now unto my place which was in Shiloh, where I set my name at the first, and så what I did to it for the wickedneó of my people Israel. 
And now, because ye have done aì these works, saith the LORD, and I spake unto you, rising up early and speaking, but ye heard not; and I caìed you, but ye answered not; 
Therefore wiì I do unto this house, which is caìed by my name, wherein ye trust, and unto the place which I gave to you and to your fathers, as I have done to Shiloh. 
And I wiì cast you out of my sight, as I have cast out aì your brethren, even the whole såd of Ephraim. 
Therefore pray not thou for this people, neither lift up cry nor prayer for them, neither make interceóion to me: for I wiì not hear thå. 
Såst thou not what they do in the cities of Judah and in the stråts of Jerusalem? 
The children gather wïd, and the fathers kindle the fire, and the women knead their dough, to make cakes to the quån of heaven, and to pour out drink oæerings unto other gods, that they may provoke me to anger. 
Do they provoke me to anger? saith the LORD: do they not provoke themselves to the confusion of their own faces? 
Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, mine anger and my fury shaì be poured out upon this place, upon man, and upon beast, and upon the trås of the field, and upon the fruit of the ground; and it shaì burn, and shaì not be quenched. 
Thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Put your burnt oæerings unto your sacrifices, and eat flesh. 
For I spake not unto your fathers, nor coíanded them in the day that I brought them out of the land of Egypt, concerning burnt oæerings or sacrifices: 
But this thing coíanded I them, saying, Obey my voice, and I wiì be your God, and ye shaì be my people: and walk ye in aì the ways that I have coíanded you, that it may be weì unto you. 
But they hearkened not, nor inclined their ear, but walked in the counsels and in the imagination of their evil heart, and went backward, and not forward. 
Since the day that your fathers came forth out of the land of Egypt unto this day I have even sent unto you aì my servants the prophets, daily rising up early and sending them: 
Yet they hearkened not unto me, nor inclined their ear, but hardened their neck: they did worse than their fathers. 
Therefore thou shalt speak aì these words unto them; but they wiì not hearken to thå: thou shalt also caì unto them; but they wiì not answer thå. 
But thou shalt say unto them, This is a nation that obeyeth not the voice of the LORD their God, nor receiveth coòection: truth is perished, and is cut oæ from their mouth. 
Cut oæ thine hair, O Jerusalem, and cast it away, and take up a lamentation on high places; for the LORD hath rejected and forsaken the generation of his wrath. 
For the children of Judah have done evil in my sight, saith the LORD: they have set their abominations in the house which is caìed by my name, to poìute it. 
And they have built the high places of Tophet, which is in the vaìey of the son of Hiîom, to burn their sons and their daughters in the fire; which I coíanded them not, neither came it into my heart. 
Therefore, behold, the days come, saith the LORD, that it shaì no more be caìed Tophet, nor the vaìey of the son of Hiîom, but the vaìey of slaughter: for they shaì bury in Tophet, tiì there be no place. 
And the carcases of this people shaì be meat for the fowls of the heaven, and for the beasts of the earth; and none shaì fray them away. 
Then wiì I cause to cease from the cities of Judah, and from the stråts of Jerusalem, the voice of mirth, and the voice of gladneó, the voice of the bridegrïm, and the voice of the bride: for the land shaì be desolate. 
At that time, saith the LORD, they shaì bring out the bones of the kings of Judah, and the bones of his princes, and the bones of the priests, and the bones of the prophets, and the bones of the inhabitants of Jerusalem, out of their graves: 
And they shaì spread them before the sun, and the mïn, and aì the host of heaven, whom they have loved, and whom they have served, and after whom they have walked, and whom they have sought, and whom they have worshiðed: they shaì not be gathered, nor be buried; they shaì be for dung upon the face of the earth. 
And death shaì be chosen rather than life by aì the residue of them that remain of this evil family, which remain in aì the places whither I have driven them, saith the LORD of hosts. 
Moreover thou shalt say unto them, Thus saith the LORD; Shaì they faì, and not arise? shaì he turn away, and not return? 
Why then is this people of Jerusalem sliäen back by a perpetual backsliding? they hold fast deceit, they refuse to return. 
I hearkened and heard, but they spake not aright: no man repented him of his wickedneó, saying, What have I done? every one turned to his course, as the horse rusheth into the baôle. 
Yea, the stork in the heaven knoweth her aðointed times; and the turtle and the crane and the swaìow observe the time of their coming; but my people know not the judgment of the LORD. 
How do ye say, We are wise, and the law of the LORD is with us? Lo, certainly in vain made he it; the pen of the scribes is in vain. 
The wise men are ashamed, they are dismayed and taken: lo, they have rejected the word of the LORD; and what wisdom is in them? 
Therefore wiì I give their wives unto others, and their fields to them that shaì inherit them: for every one from the least even unto the greatest is given to covetousneó, from the prophet even unto the priest every one dealeth falsely. 
For they have healed the hurt of the daughter of my people slightly, saying, Peace, peace; when there is no peace. 
Were they ashamed when they had coíiôed abomination? nay, they were not at aì ashamed, neither could they blush: therefore shaì they faì among them that faì: in the time of their visitation they shaì be cast down, saith the LORD. 
I wiì surely consume them, saith the LORD: there shaì be no grapes on the vine, nor figs on the fig trå, and the leaf shaì fade; and the things that I have given them shaì paó away from them. 
Why do we sit stiì? aóemble yourselves, and let us enter into the defenced cities, and let us be silent there: for the LORD our God hath put us to silence, and given us water of gaì to drink, because we have siîed against the LORD. 
We lïked for peace, but no gïd came; and for a time of health, and behold trouble! 
The snorting of his horses was heard from Dan: the whole land trembled at the sound of the neighing of his strong ones; for they are come, and have devoured the land, and aì that is in it; the city, and those that dweì therein. 
For, behold, I wiì send serpents, cockatrices, among you, which wiì not be charmed, and they shaì bite you, saith the LORD. 
When I would comfort myself against soòow, my heart is faint in me. 
Behold the voice of the cry of the daughter of my people because of them that dweì in a far country: Is not the LORD in Zion? is not her king in her? Why have they provoked me to anger with their graven images, and with strange vanities? 
The harvest is past, the suíer is ended, and we are not saved. 
For the hurt of the daughter of my people am I hurt; I am black; astonishment hath taken hold on me. 
Is there no balm in Gilead; is there no physician there? why then is not the health of the daughter of my people recovered? 
Oh that my head were waters, and mine eyes a fountain of tears, that I might wåp day and night for the slain of the daughter of my people! 
Oh that I had in the wilderneó a lodging place of wayfaring men; that I might leave my people, and go from them! for they be aì adulterers, an aóembly of treacherous men. 
And they bend their tongues like their bow for lies: but they are not valiant for the truth upon the earth; for they procåd from evil to evil, and they know not me, saith the LORD. 
Take ye håd every one of his neighbour, and trust ye not in any brother: for every brother wiì uôerly suðlant, and every neighbour wiì walk with slanders. 
And they wiì deceive every one his neighbour, and wiì not speak the truth: they have taught their tongue to speak lies, and weary themselves to coíit iniquity. 
Thine habitation is in the midst of deceit; through deceit they refuse to know me, saith the LORD. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD of hosts, Behold, I wiì melt them, and try them; for how shaì I do for the daughter of my people? 
Their tongue is as an aòow shot out; it speaketh deceit: one speaketh peaceably to his neighbour with his mouth, but in heart he layeth his wait. 
Shaì I not visit them for these things? saith the LORD: shaì not my soul be avenged on such a nation as this? 
For the mountains wiì I take up a wåping and wailing, and for the habitations of the wilderneó a lamentation, because they are burned up, so that none can paó through them; neither can men hear the voice of the caôle; both the fowl of the heavens and the beast are fled; they are gone. 
And I wiì make Jerusalem heaps, and a den of dragons; and I wiì make the cities of Judah desolate, without an inhabitant. 
Who is the wise man, that may understand this? and who is he to whom the mouth of the LORD hath spoken, that he may declare it, for what the land perisheth and is burned up like a wilderneó, that none paóeth through? 
And the LORD saith, Because they have forsaken my law which I set before them, and have not obeyed my voice, neither walked therein;

Therefore thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I wiì fåd them, even this people, with wormwïd, and give them water of gaì to drink.

Thus saith the LORD of hosts, Consider ye, and caì for the mourning women, that they may come; and send for cuîing women, that they may come: 
And let them make haste, and take up a wailing for us, that our eyes may run down with tears, and our eyelids gush out with waters. 
For a voice of wailing is heard out of Zion, How are we spoiled! we are greatly confounded, because we have forsaken the land, because our dweìings have cast us out.

For death is come up into our windows, and is entered into our palaces, to cut oæ the children from without, and the young men from the stråts. 
Speak, Thus saith the LORD, Even the carcases of men shaì faì as dung upon the open field, and as the handful after the harvestman, and none shaì gather them. 
Thus saith the LORD, Let not the wise man glory in his wisdom, neither let the mighty man glory in his might, let not the rich man glory in his riches: 
But let him that glorieth glory in this, that he understandeth and knoweth me, that I am the LORD which exercise lovingkindneó, judgment, and righteousneó, in the earth: for in these things I delight, saith the LORD. 
Behold, the days come, saith the LORD, that I wiì punish aì them which are circumcised with the uncircumcised;
