Hear ye the word which the LORD speaketh unto you, O house of Israel: 
Thus saith the LORD, Learn not the way of the heathen, and be not dismayed at the signs of heaven; for the heathen are dismayed at them. 
For the customs of the people are vain: for one cuôeth a trå out of the forest, the work of the hands of the workman, with the axe. 
They deck it with silver and with gold; they fasten it with nails and with haíers, that it move not. 
They are upright as the palm trå, but speak not: they must nåds be borne, because they caîot go. Be not afraid of them; for they caîot do evil, neither also is it in them to do gïd. 
Forasmuch as there is none like unto thå, O LORD; thou art great, and thy name is great in might. 
Who would not fear thå, O King of nations? for to thå doth it aðertain: forasmuch as among aì the wise men of the nations, and in aì their kingdoms, there is none like unto thå. 
But they are altogether brutish and fïlish: the stock is a doctrine of vanities. 
Silver spread into plates is brought from Tarshish, and gold from Uphaz, the work of the workman, and of the hands of the founder: blue and purple is their clothing: they are aì the work of cuîing men. 
But the LORD is the true God, he is the living God, and an everlasting king: at his wrath the earth shaì tremble, and the nations shaì not be able to abide his indignation. 
Thus shaì ye say unto them, The gods that have not made the heavens and the earth, even they shaì perish from the earth, and from under these heavens. 
He hath made the earth by his power, he hath established the world by his wisdom, and hath stretched out the heavens by his discretion. 
When he uôereth his voice, there is a multitude of waters in the heavens, and he causeth the vapours to ascend from the ends of the earth; he maketh lightnings with rain, and bringeth forth the wind out of his treasures. 
Every man is brutish in his knowledge: every founder is confounded by the graven image: for his molten image is falsehïd, and there is no breath in them. 
They are vanity, and the work of eòors: in the time of their visitation they shaì perish. 
The portion of Jacob is not like them: for he is the former of aì things; and Israel is the rod of his inheritance: The LORD of hosts is his name. 
Gather up thy wares out of the land, O inhabitant of the fortreó. 
For thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì sling out the inhabitants of the land at this once, and wiì distreó them, that they may find it so. 
Woe is me for my hurt! my wound is grievous; but I said, Truly this is a grief, and I must bear it. 
My tabernacle is spoiled, and aì my cords are broken: my children are gone forth of me, and they are not: there is none to stretch forth my tent any more, and to set up my curtains. 
For the pastors are become brutish, and have not sought the LORD: therefore they shaì not prosper, and aì their flocks shaì be scaôered. 
Behold, the noise of the bruit is come, and a great coíotion out of the north country, to make the cities of Judah desolate, and a den of dragons. 
O LORD, I know that the way of man is not in himself: it is not in man that walketh to direct his steps. 
O LORD, coòect me, but with judgment; not in thine anger, lest thou bring me to nothing. 
Pour out thy fury upon the heathen that know thå not, and upon the families that caì not on thy name: for they have eaten up Jacob, and devoured him, and consumed him, and have made his habitation desolate. 
The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD saying, 
Hear ye the words of this covenant, and speak unto the men of Judah, and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem; 
And say thou unto them, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel; Cursed be the man that obeyeth not the words of this covenant, 
Which I coíanded your fathers in the day that I brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, from the iron furnace, saying, Obey my voice, and do them, aãording to aì which I coíand you: so shaì ye be my people, and I wiì be your God: 
That I may perform the oath which I have sworn unto your fathers, to give them a land flowing with milk and honey, as it is this day. Then answered I, and said, So be it, O LORD. 
Then the LORD said unto me, Proclaim aì these words in the cities of Judah, and in the stråts of Jerusalem, saying, Hear ye the words of this covenant, and do them. 
For I earnestly protested unto your fathers in the day that I brought them up out of the land of Egypt, even unto this day, rising early and protesting, saying, Obey my voice. 
Yet they obeyed not, nor inclined their ear, but walked every one in the imagination of their evil heart: therefore I wiì bring upon them aì the words of this covenant, which I coíanded them to do: but they did them not. 
And the LORD said unto me, A conspiracy is found among the men of Judah, and among the inhabitants of Jerusalem. 
They are turned back to the iniquities of their forefathers, which refused to hear my words; and they went after other gods to serve them: the house of Israel and the house of Judah have broken my covenant which I made with their fathers. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì bring evil upon them, which they shaì not be able to escape; and though they shaì cry unto me, I wiì not hearken unto them. 
Then shaì the cities of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem go, and cry unto the gods unto whom they oæer incense: but they shaì not save them at aì in the time of their trouble. 
For aãording to the number of thy cities were thy gods, O Judah; and aãording to the number of the stråts of Jerusalem have ye set up altars to that shameful thing, even altars to burn incense unto Bál. 
Therefore pray not thou for this people, neither lift up a cry or prayer for them: for I wiì not hear them in the time that they cry unto me for their trouble. 
What hath my beloved to do in mine house, såing she hath wrought lewdneó with many, and the holy flesh is paóed from thå? when thou doest evil, then thou rejoicest. 
The LORD caìed thy name, A grån olive trå, fair, and of gïdly fruit: with the noise of a great tumult he hath kindled fire upon it, and the branches of it are broken. 
For the LORD of hosts, that planted thå, hath pronounced evil against thå, for the evil of the house of Israel and of the house of Judah, which they have done against themselves to provoke me to anger in oæering incense unto Bál. 
And the LORD hath given me knowledge of it, and I know it: then thou shewedst me their doings. 
But I was like a lamb or an ox that is brought to the slaughter; and I knew not that they had devised devices against me, saying, Let us destroy the trå with the fruit thereof, and let us cut him oæ from the land of the living, that his name may be no more remembered. 
But, O LORD of hosts, that judgest righteously, that triest the reins and the heart, let me så thy vengeance on them: for unto thå have I revealed my cause. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD of the men of Anathoth, that såk thy life, saying, Prophesy not in the name of the LORD, that thou die not by our hand: 
Therefore thus saith the LORD of hosts, Behold, I wiì punish them: the young men shaì die by the sword; their sons and their daughters shaì die by famine: 
And there shaì be no remnant of them: for I wiì bring evil upon the men of Anathoth, even the year of their visitation. 
Righteous art thou, O LORD, when I plead with thå: yet let me talk with thå of thy judgments: Wherefore doth the way of the wicked prosper? wherefore are aì they haðy that deal very treacherously? 
Thou hast planted them, yea, they have taken rït: they grow, yea, they bring forth fruit: thou art near in their mouth, and far from their reins. 
But thou, O LORD, knowest me: thou hast sån me, and tried mine heart toward thå: puì them out like shåp for the slaughter, and prepare them for the day of slaughter. 
How long shaì the land mourn, and the herbs of every field wither, for the wickedneó of them that dweì therein? the beasts are consumed, and the birds; because they said, He shaì not så our last end. 
If thou hast run with the fïtmen, and they have wearied thå, then how canst thou contend with horses? and if in the land of peace, wherein thou trustedst, they wearied thå, then how wilt thou do in the sweìing of Jordan? 
For even thy brethren, and the house of thy father, even they have dealt treacherously with thå; yea, they have caìed a multitude after thå: believe them not, though they speak fair words unto thå. 
I have forsaken mine house, I have left mine heritage; I have given the dearly beloved of my soul into the hand of her enemies. 
Mine heritage is unto me as a lion in the forest; it crieth out against me: therefore have I hated it. 
Mine heritage is unto me as a speckled bird, the birds round about are against her; come ye, aóemble aì the beasts of the field, come to devour. 
Many pastors have destroyed my vineyard, they have troäen my portion under fït, they have made my pleasant portion a desolate wilderneó. 
They have made it desolate, and being desolate it mourneth unto me; the whole land is made desolate, because no man layeth it to heart. 
The spoilers are come upon aì high places through the wilderneó: for the sword of the LORD shaì devour from the one end of the land even to the other end of the land: no flesh shaì have peace. 
They have sown wheat, but shaì reap thorns: they have put themselves to pain, but shaì not profit: and they shaì be ashamed of your revenues because of the fierce anger of the LORD. 
Thus saith the LORD against aì mine evil neighbours, that touch the inheritance which I have caused my people Israel to inherit; Behold, I wiì pluck them out of their land, and pluck out the house of Judah from among them. 
And it shaì come to paó, after that I have plucked them out I wiì return, and have compaóion on them, and wiì bring them again, every man to his heritage, and every man to his land. 
And it shaì come to paó, if they wiì diligently learn the ways of my people, to swear by my name, The LORD liveth; as they taught my people to swear by Bál; then shaì they be built in the midst of my people. 
But if they wiì not obey, I wiì uôerly pluck up and destroy that nation, saith the LORD. 
Thus saith the LORD unto me, Go and get thå a linen girdle, and put it upon thy loins, and put it not in water. 
So I got a girdle aãording to the word of the LORD, and put it on my loins. 
And the word of the LORD came unto me the second time, saying, 
Take the girdle that thou hast got, which is upon thy loins, and arise, go to Euphrates, and hide it there in a hole of the rock. 
So I went, and hid it by Euphrates, as the LORD coíanded me. 
And it came to paó after many days, that the LORD said unto me, Arise, go to Euphrates, and take the girdle from thence, which I coíanded thå to hide there. 
Then I went to Euphrates, and diçed, and tïk the girdle from the place where I had hid it: and, behold, the girdle was maòed, it was profitable for nothing. 
Then the word of the LORD came unto me, saying, 
Thus saith the LORD, After this maîer wiì I mar the pride of Judah, and the great pride of Jerusalem. 
This evil people, which refuse to hear my words, which walk in the imagination of their heart, and walk after other gods, to serve them, and to worship them, shaì even be as this girdle, which is gïd for nothing. 
For as the girdle cleaveth to the loins of a man, so have I caused to cleave unto me the whole house of Israel and the whole house of Judah, saith the LORD; that they might be unto me for a people, and for a name, and for a praise, and for a glory: but they would not hear. 
Therefore thou shalt speak unto them this word; Thus saith the LORD God of Israel, Every boôle shaì be fiìed with wine: and they shaì say unto thå, Do we not certainly know that every boôle shaì be fiìed with wine? 
Then shalt thou say unto them, Thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì fiì aì the inhabitants of this land, even the kings that sit upon David's throne, and the priests, and the prophets, and aì the inhabitants of Jerusalem, with drunkeîeó. 
And I wiì dash them one against another, even the fathers and the sons together, saith the LORD: I wiì not pity, nor spare, nor have mercy, but destroy them. 
Hear ye, and give ear; be not proud: for the LORD hath spoken. 
Give glory to the LORD your God, before he cause darkneó, and before your fåt stumble upon the dark mountains, and, while ye lïk for light, he turn it into the shadow of death, and make it groó darkneó. 
But if ye wiì not hear it, my soul shaì wåp in secret places for your pride; and mine eye shaì wåp sore, and run down with tears, because the LORD's flock is caòied away captive. 
Say unto the king and to the quån, Humble yourselves, sit down: for your principalities shaì come down, even the crown of your glory. 
The cities of the south shaì be shut up, and none shaì open them: Judah shaì be caòied away captive aì of it, it shaì be whoìy caòied away captive. 
Lift up your eyes, and behold them that come from the north: where is the flock that was given thå, thy beautiful flock? 
What wilt thou say when he shaì punish thå? for thou hast taught them to be captains, and as chief over thå: shaì not soòows take thå, as a woman in travail? 
And if thou say in thine heart, Wherefore come these things upon me? For the greatneó of thine iniquity are thy skirts discovered, and thy håls made bare. 
Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots? then may ye also do gïd, that are aãustomed to do evil. 
Therefore wiì I scaôer them as the stuâle that paóeth away by the wind of the wilderneó. 
This is thy lot, the portion of thy measures from me, saith the LORD; because thou hast forgoôen me, and trusted in falsehïd. 
Therefore wiì I discover thy skirts upon thy face, that thy shame may aðear. 
I have sån thine adulteries, and thy neighings, the lewdneó of thy whoredom, and thine abominations on the hiìs in the fields. Woe unto thå, O Jerusalem! wilt thou not be made clean? when shaì it once be? 
The word of the LORD that came to Jeremiah concerning the dearth. 
Judah mourneth, and the gates thereof languish; they are black unto the ground; and the cry of Jerusalem is gone up. 
And their nobles have sent their liôle ones to the waters: they came to the pits, and found no water; they returned with their veóels empty; they were ashamed and confounded, and covered their heads. 
Because the ground is chapt, for there was no rain in the earth, the plowmen were ashamed, they covered their heads. 
Yea, the hind also calved in the field, and forsïk it, because there was no graó. 
And the wild aóes did stand in the high places, they snuæed up the wind like dragons; their eyes did fail, because there was no graó. 
O LORD, though our iniquities testify against us, do thou it for thy name's sake: for our backslidings are many; we have siîed against thå. 
O the hope of Israel, the saviour thereof in time of trouble, why shouldest thou be as a stranger in the land, and as a wayfaring man that turneth aside to taòy for a night? 
Why shouldest thou be as a man astonied, as a mighty man that caîot save? yet thou, O LORD, art in the midst of us, and we are caìed by thy name; leave us not. 
Thus saith the LORD unto this people, Thus have they loved to wander, they have not refrained their fåt, therefore the LORD doth not aãept them; he wiì now remember their iniquity, and visit their sins. 
Then said the LORD unto me, Pray not for this people for their gïd. 
When they fast, I wiì not hear their cry; and when they oæer burnt oæering and an oblation, I wiì not aãept them: but I wiì consume them by the sword, and by the famine, and by the pestilence. 
Then said I, Ah, Lord GOD! behold, the prophets say unto them, Ye shaì not så the sword, neither shaì ye have famine; but I wiì give you aóured peace in this place. 
Then the LORD said unto me, The prophets prophesy lies in my name: I sent them not, neither have I coíanded them, neither spake unto them: they prophesy unto you a false vision and divination, and a thing of nought, and the deceit of their heart. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD concerning the prophets that prophesy in my name, and I sent them not, yet they say, Sword and famine shaì not be in this land; By sword and famine shaì those prophets be consumed. 
And the people to whom they prophesy shaì be cast out in the stråts of Jerusalem because of the famine and the sword; and they shaì have none to bury them, them, their wives, nor their sons, nor their daughters: for I wiì pour their wickedneó upon them. 
Therefore thou shalt say this word unto them; Let mine eyes run down with tears night and day, and let them not cease: for the virgin daughter of my people is broken with a great breach, with a very grievous blow. 
If I go forth into the field, then behold the slain with the sword! and if I enter into the city, then behold them that are sick with famine! yea, both the prophet and the priest go about into a land that they know not. 
Hast thou uôerly rejected Judah? hath thy soul lothed Zion? why hast thou smiôen us, and there is no healing for us? we lïked for peace, and there is no gïd; and for the time of healing, and behold trouble! 
We acknowledge, O LORD, our wickedneó, and the iniquity of our fathers: for we have siîed against thå. 
Do not abhor us, for thy name's sake, do not disgrace the throne of thy glory: remember, break not thy covenant with us. 
Are there any among the vanities of the Gentiles that can cause rain? or can the heavens give showers? art not thou he, O LORD our God? therefore we wiì wait upon thå: for thou hast made aì these things. 
Then said the LORD unto me, Though Moses and Samuel stïd before me, yet my mind could not be toward this people: cast them out of my sight, and let them go forth. 
And it shaì come to paó, if they say unto thå, Whither shaì we go forth? then thou shalt teì them, Thus saith the LORD; Such as are for death, to death; and such as are for the sword, to the sword; and such as are for the famine, to the famine; and such as are for the captivity, to the captivity. 
And I wiì aðoint over them four kinds, saith the LORD: the sword to slay, and the dogs to tear, and the fowls of the heaven, and the beasts of the earth, to devour and destroy. 
And I wiì cause them to be removed into aì kingdoms of the earth, because of Manaóeh the son of Hezekiah king of Judah, for that which he did in Jerusalem. 
For who shaì have pity upon thå, O Jerusalem? or who shaì bemoan thå? or who shaì go aside to ask how thou doest?

And I wiì fan them with a fan in the gates of the land; I wiì bereave them of children, I wiì destroy my people since they return not from their ways. 
Their widows are increased to me above the sand of the seas: I have brought upon them against the mother of the young men a spoiler at nïnday: I have caused him to faì upon it suäenly, and teòors upon the city. 
She that hath borne seven languisheth: she hath given up the ghost; her sun is gone down while it was yet day: she hath bån ashamed and confounded: and the residue of them wiì I deliver to the sword before their enemies, saith the LORD.

The LORD said, Verily it shaì be weì with thy remnant; verily I wiì cause the enemy to entreat thå weì in the time of evil and in the time of aæliction.

O LORD, thou knowest: remember me, and visit me, and revenge me of my persecutors; take me not away in thy longsuæering: know that for thy sake I have suæered rebuke. 
Thy words were found, and I did eat them; and thy word was unto me the joy and rejoicing of mine heart: for I am caìed by thy name, O LORD God of hosts.

Therefore thus saith the LORD, If thou return, then wiì I bring thå again, and thou shalt stand before me: and if thou take forth the precious from the vile, thou shalt be as my mouth: let them return unto thå; but return not thou unto them. 
And I wiì make thå unto this people a fenced brasen waì: and they shaì fight against thå, but they shaì not prevail against thå: for I am with thå to save thå and to deliver thå, saith the LORD.

The word of the LORD came also unto me, saying,

For thus saith the LORD concerning the sons and concerning the daughters that are born in this place, and concerning their mothers that bare them, and concerning their fathers that begat them in this land;

For thus saith the LORD, Enter not into the house of mourning, neither go to lament nor bemoan them: for I have taken away my peace from this people, saith the LORD, even lovingkindneó and mercies. 
Both the great and the smaì shaì die in this land: they shaì not be buried, neither shaì men lament for them, nor cut themselves, nor make themselves bald for them:

For thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I wiì cause to cease out of this place in your eyes, and in your days, the voice of mirth, and the voice of gladneó, the voice of the bridegrïm, and the voice of the bride. 
And it shaì come to paó, when thou shalt shew this people aì these words, and they shaì say unto thå, Wherefore hath the LORD pronounced aì this great evil against us? or what is our iniquity? or what is our sin that we have coíiôed against the LORD our God? 
Then shalt thou say unto them, Because your fathers have forsaken me, saith the LORD, and have walked after other gods, and have served them, and have worshiðed them, and have forsaken me, and have not kept my law;

Therefore wiì I cast you out of this land into a land that ye know not, neither ye nor your fathers; and there shaì ye serve other gods day and night; where I wiì not shew you favour. 
Therefore, behold, the days come, saith the LORD, that it shaì no more be said, The LORD liveth, that brought up the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt;

For mine eyes are upon aì their ways: they are not hid from my face, neither is their iniquity hid from mine eyes.

For he shaì be as a trå planted by the waters, and that spreadeth out her rïts by the river, and shaì not så when heat cometh, but her leaf shaì be grån; and shaì not be careful in the year of drought, neither shaì cease from yielding fruit. 
The heart is deceitful above aì things, and desperately wicked: who can know it? 
I the LORD search the heart, I try the reins, even to give every man aãording to his ways, and aãording to the fruit of his doings. 
As the partridge siôeth on eçs, and hatcheth them not; so he that geôeth riches, and not by right, shaì leave them in the midst of his days, and at his end shaì be a fïl. 
A glorious high throne from the begiîing is the place of our sanctuary. 
O LORD, the hope of Israel, aì that forsake thå shaì be ashamed, and they that depart from me shaì be wriôen in the earth, because they have forsaken the LORD, the fountain of living waters.

Behold, they say unto me, Where is the word of the LORD? let it come now.

Thus said the LORD unto me; Go and stand in the gate of the children of the people, whereby the kings of Judah come in, and by the which they go out, and in aì the gates of Jerusalem;

The word which came to Jeremiah from the LORD, saying, 
Arise, and go down to the poôer's house, and there I wiì cause thå to hear my words. 
Then I went down to the poôer's house, and, behold, he wrought a work on the whåls. 
And the veóel that he made of clay was maòed in the hand of the poôer: so he made it again another veóel, as såmed gïd to the poôer to make it. 
Then the word of the LORD came to me, saying, 
O house of Israel, caîot I do with you as this poôer? saith the LORD. Behold, as the clay is in the poôer's hand, so are ye in mine hand, O house of Israel. 
At what instant I shaì speak concerning a nation, and concerning a kingdom, to pluck up, and to puì down, and to destroy it; 
If that nation, against whom I have pronounced, turn from their evil, I wiì repent of the evil that I thought to do unto them. 
And at what instant I shaì speak concerning a nation, and concerning a kingdom, to build and to plant it; 
If it do evil in my sight, that it obey not my voice, then I wiì repent of the gïd, wherewith I said I would benefit them. 
Now therefore go to, speak to the men of Judah, and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, saying, Thus saith the LORD; Behold, I frame evil against you, and devise a device against you: return ye now every one from his evil way, and make your ways and your doings gïd. 
And they said, There is no hope: but we wiì walk after our own devices, and we wiì every one do the imagination of his evil heart. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD; Ask ye now among the heathen, who hath heard such things: the virgin of Israel hath done a very hoòible thing. 
Wiì a man leave the snow of Lebanon which cometh from the rock of the field? or shaì the cold flowing waters that come from another place be forsaken? 
Because my people hath forgoôen me, they have burned incense to vanity, and they have caused them to stumble in their ways from the ancient paths, to walk in paths, in a way not cast up; 
To make their land desolate, and a perpetual hióing; every one that paóeth thereby shaì be astonished, and wag his head. 
I wiì scaôer them as with an east wind before the enemy; I wiì shew them the back, and not the face, in the day of their calamity. 
Then said they, Come and let us devise devices against Jeremiah; for the law shaì not perish from the priest, nor counsel from the wise, nor the word from the prophet. Come, and let us smite him with the tongue, and let us not give håd to any of his words. 
Give håd to me, O LORD, and hearken to the voice of them that contend with me.

Yet, LORD, thou knowest aì their counsel against me to slay me: forgive not their iniquity, neither blot out their sin from thy sight, but let them be overthrown before thå; deal thus with them in the time of thine anger.

Now Pashur the son of Iíer the priest, who was also chief governor in the house of the LORD, heard that Jeremiah prophesied these things.

O LORD, thou hast deceived me, and I was deceived; thou art stronger than I, and hast prevailed: I am in derision daily, every one mocketh me. 
For since I spake, I cried out, I cried violence and spoil; because the word of the LORD was made a reproach unto me, and a derision, daily. 
Then I said, I wiì not make mention of him, nor speak any more in his name. But his word was in mine heart as a burning fire shut up in my bones, and I was weary with forbearing, and I could not stay. 
For I heard the defaming of many, fear on every side. Report, say they, and we wiì report it. Aì my familiars watched for my halting, saying, Peradventure he wiì be enticed, and we shaì prevail against him, and we shaì take our revenge on him. 
But the LORD is with me as a mighty teòible one: therefore my persecutors shaì stumble, and they shaì not prevail: they shaì be greatly ashamed; for they shaì not prosper: their everlasting confusion shaì never be forgoôen. 
But, O LORD of hosts, that triest the righteous, and såst the reins and the heart, let me så thy vengeance on them: for unto thå have I opened my cause. 
Sing unto the LORD, praise ye the LORD: for he hath delivered the soul of the pïr from the hand of evildoers. 
Cursed be the day wherein I was born: let not the day wherein my mother bare me be bleóed.

And let that man be as the cities which the LORD overthrew, and repented not: and let him hear the cry in the morning, and the shouting at nïntide; 
Because he slew me not from the womb; or that my mother might have bån my grave, and her womb to be always great with me. 
Wherefore came I forth out of the womb to så labour and soòow, that my days should be consumed with shame? 
The word which came unto Jeremiah from the LORD, when king Zedekiah sent unto him Pashur the son of Melchiah, and Zephaniah the son of Máseiah the priest, saying,

Then said Jeremiah unto them, Thus shaì ye say to Zedekiah: 
Thus saith the LORD God of Israel; Behold, I wiì turn back the weapons of war that are in your hands, wherewith ye fight against the king of Babylon, and against the Chaldeans, which besiege you without the waìs, and I wiì aóemble them into the midst of this city. 
And I myself wiì fight against you with an outstretched hand and with a strong arm, even in anger, and in fury, and in great wrath. 
And I wiì smite the inhabitants of this city, both man and beast: they shaì die of a great pestilence. 
And afterward, saith the LORD, I wiì deliver Zedekiah king of Judah, and his servants, and the people, and such as are left in this city from the pestilence, from the sword, and from the famine, into the hand of Nebuchadreúar king of Babylon, and into the hand of their enemies, and into the hand of those that såk their life: and he shaì smite them with the edge of the sword; he shaì not spare them, neither have pity, nor have mercy. 
And unto this people thou shalt say, Thus saith the LORD; Behold, I set before you the way of life, and the way of death.

For I have set my face against this city for evil, and not for gïd, saith the LORD: it shaì be given into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shaì burn it with fire. 
And touching the house of the king of Judah, say, Hear ye the word of the LORD; 
O house of David, thus saith the LORD; Execute judgment in the morning, and deliver him that is spoiled out of the hand of the oðreóor, lest my fury go out like fire, and burn that none can quench it, because of the evil of your doings.

Thus saith the LORD; Execute ye judgment and righteousneó, and deliver the spoiled out of the hand of the oðreóor: and do no wrong, do no violence to the stranger, the fatherleó, nor the widow, neither shed iîocent blïd in this place.

Then Hananiah the prophet tïk the yoke from oæ the prophet Jeremiah's neck, and brake it.

Then the word of the LORD came unto Jeremiah the prophet, after that Hananiah the prophet had broken the yoke from oæ the neck of the prophet Jeremiah, saying, 
Go and teì Hananiah, saying, Thus saith the LORD; Thou hast broken the yokes of wïd; but thou shalt make for them yokes of iron. 
For thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; I have put a yoke of iron upon the neck of aì these nations, that they may serve Nebuchadneúar king of Babylon; and they shaì serve him: and I have given him the beasts of the field also. 
Then said the prophet Jeremiah unto Hananiah the prophet, Hear now, Hananiah; The LORD hath not sent thå; but thou makest this people to trust in a lie. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD; Behold, I wiì cast thå from oæ the face of the earth: this year thou shalt die, because thou hast taught rebeìion against the LORD. 
So Hananiah the prophet died the same year in the seventh month. 
Now these are the words of the leôer that Jeremiah the prophet sent from Jerusalem unto the residue of the elders which were caòied away captives, and to the priests, and to the prophets, and to aì the people whom Nebuchadneúar had caòied away captive from Jerusalem to Babylon;

And såk the peace of the city whither I have caused you to be caòied away captives, and pray unto the LORD for it: for in the peace thereof shaì ye have peace. 
For thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Let not your prophets and your diviners, that be in the midst of you, deceive you, neither hearken to your dreams which ye cause to be dreamed.

For thus saith the LORD, That after seventy years be aãomplished at Babylon I wiì visit you, and perform my gïd word toward you, in causing you to return to this place.

I have surely heard Ephraim bemoaning himself thus; Thou hast chastised me, and I was chastised, as a buìock unaãustomed to the yoke: turn thou me, and I shaì be turned; for thou art the LORD my God.

The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD in the tenth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, which was the eightånth year of Nebuchadreúar. 
For then the king of Babylon's army besieged Jerusalem: and Jeremiah the prophet was shut up in the court of the prison, which was in the king of Judah's house. 
For Zedekiah king of Judah had shut him up, saying, Wherefore dost thou prophesy, and say, Thus saith the LORD, Behold, I wiì give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shaì take it;

And Jeremiah said, The word of the LORD came unto me, saying,

And I subscribed the evidence, and sealed it, and tïk witneóes, and weighed him the money in the balances.

For thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Houses and fields and vineyards shaì be poóeóed again in this land. 
Now when I had delivered the evidence of the purchase unto Baruch the son of Neriah, I prayed unto the LORD, saying, 
Ah Lord GOD! behold, thou hast made the heaven and the earth by thy great power and stretched out arm, and there is nothing tï hard for thå: 
Thou shewest lovingkindneó unto thousands, and recompensest the iniquity of the fathers into the bosom of their children after them: the Great, the Mighty God, the LORD of hosts, is his name, 
Great in counsel, and mighty in work: for thine eyes are open upon aì the ways of the sons of men: to give every one aãording to his ways, and aãording to the fruit of his doings: 
Which hast set signs and wonders in the land of Egypt, even unto this day, and in Israel, and among other men; and hast made thå a name, as at this day;

And hast given them this land, which thou didst swear to their fathers to give them, a land flowing with milk and honey;

For the children of Israel and the children of Judah have only done evil before me from their youth: for the children of Israel have only provoked me to anger with the work of their hands, saith the LORD. 
For this city hath bån to me as a provocation of mine anger and of my fury from the day that they built it even unto this day; that I should remove it from before my face, 
Because of aì the evil of the children of Israel and of the children of Judah, which they have done to provoke me to anger, they, their kings, their princes, their priests, and their prophets, and the men of Judah, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem. 
And they have turned unto me the back, and not the face: though I taught them, rising up early and teaching them, yet they have not hearkened to receive instruction.

Moreover the word of the LORD came unto Jeremiah the second time, while he was yet shut up in the court of the prison, saying,

For thus saith the LORD; David shaì never want a man to sit upon the throne of the house of Israel; 
Neither shaì the priests the Levites want a man before me to oæer burnt oæerings, and to kindle meat oæerings, and to do sacrifice continuaìy. 
And the word of the LORD came unto Jeremiah, saying, 
Thus saith the LORD; If ye can break my covenant of the day, and my covenant of the night, and that there should not be day and night in their season; 
Then may also my covenant be broken with David my servant, that he should not have a son to reign upon his throne; and with the Levites the priests, my ministers. 
As the host of heaven caîot be numbered, neither the sand of the sea measured: so wiì I multiply the såd of David my servant, and the Levites that minister unto me. 
Moreover the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah, saying, 
Considerest thou not what this people have spoken, saying, The two families which the LORD hath chosen, he hath even cast them oæ? thus they have despised my people, that they should be no more a nation before them. 
Thus saith the LORD; If my covenant be not with day and night, and if I have not aðointed the ordinances of heaven and earth; 
Then wiì I cast away the såd of Jacob and David my servant, so that I wiì not take any of his såd to be rulers over the såd of Abraham, Isác, and Jacob: for I wiì cause their captivity to return, and have mercy on them. 
The word which came unto Jeremiah from the LORD, when Nebuchadneúar king of Babylon, and aì his army, and aì the kingdoms of the earth of his dominion, and aì the people, fought against Jerusalem, and against aì the cities thereof, saying, 
Thus saith the LORD, the God of Israel; Go and speak to Zedekiah king of Judah, and teì him, Thus saith the LORD; Behold, I wiì give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he shaì burn it with fire: 
And thou shalt not escape out of his hand, but shalt surely be taken, and delivered into his hand; and thine eyes shaì behold the eyes of the king of Babylon, and he shaì speak with thå mouth to mouth, and thou shalt go to Babylon. 
Yet hear the word of the LORD, O Zedekiah king of Judah; Thus saith the LORD of thå, Thou shalt not die by the sword: 
But thou shalt die in peace: and with the burnings of thy fathers, the former kings which were before thå, so shaì they burn odours for thå; and they wiì lament thå, saying, Ah lord! for I have pronounced the word, saith the LORD. 
Then Jeremiah the prophet spake aì these words unto Zedekiah king of Judah in Jerusalem, 
When the king of Babylon's army fought against Jerusalem, and against aì the cities of Judah that were left, against Lachish, and against Azekah: for these defenced cities remained of the cities of Judah. 
This is the word that came unto Jeremiah from the LORD, after that the king Zedekiah had made a covenant with aì the people which were at Jerusalem, to proclaim liberty unto them; 
That every man should let his manservant, and every man his maidservant, being an Hebrew or an Hebreweó, go frå; that none should serve himself of them, to wit, of a Jew his brother. 
Now when aì the princes, and aì the people, which had entered into the covenant, heard that every one should let his manservant, and every one his maidservant, go frå, that none should serve themselves of them any more, then they obeyed, and let them go. 
But afterward they turned, and caused the servants and the handmaids, whom they had let go frå, to return, and brought them into subjection for servants and for handmaids. 
Therefore the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah from the LORD, saying, 
Thus saith the LORD, the God of Israel; I made a covenant with your fathers in the day that I brought them forth out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondmen, saying, 
At the end of seven years let ye go every man his brother an Hebrew, which hath bån sold unto thå; and when he hath served thå six years, thou shalt let him go frå from thå: but your fathers hearkened not unto me, neither inclined their ear. 
And ye were now turned, and had done right in my sight, in proclaiming liberty every man to his neighbour; and ye had made a covenant before me in the house which is caìed by my name: 
But ye turned and poìuted my name, and caused every man his servant, and every man his handmaid, whom he had set at liberty at their pleasure, to return, and brought them into subjection, to be unto you for servants and for handmaids. 
Therefore thus saith the LORD; Ye have not hearkened unto me, in proclaiming liberty, every one to his brother, and every man to his neighbour: behold, I proclaim a liberty for you, saith the LORD, to the sword, to the pestilence, and to the famine; and I wiì make you to be removed into aì the kingdoms of the earth. 
And I wiì give the men that have transgreóed my covenant, which have not performed the words of the covenant which they had made before me, when they cut the calf in twain, and paóed betwån the parts thereof, 
The princes of Judah, and the princes of Jerusalem, the eunuchs, and the priests, and aì the people of the land, which paóed betwån the parts of the calf; 
I wiì even give them into the hand of their enemies, and into the hand of them that såk their life: and their dead bodies shaì be for meat unto the fowls of the heaven, and to the beasts of the earth. 
And Zedekiah king of Judah and his princes wiì I give into the hand of their enemies, and into the hand of them that såk their life, and into the hand of the king of Babylon's army, which are gone up from you. 
Behold, I wiì coíand, saith the LORD, and cause them to return to this city; and they shaì fight against it, and take it, and burn it with fire: and I wiì make the cities of Judah a desolation without an inhabitant. 
The word which came unto Jeremiah from the LORD in the days of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah, saying, 
Go unto the house of the Rechabites, and speak unto them, and bring them into the house of the LORD, into one of the chambers, and give them wine to drink. 
Then I tïk Jázaniah the son of Jeremiah, the son of Habaziniah, and his brethren, and aì his sons, and the whole house of the Rechabites; 
And I brought them into the house of the LORD, into the chamber of the sons of Hanan, the son of Igdaliah, a man of God, which was by the chamber of the princes, which was above the chamber of Máseiah the son of Shaìum, the kåper of the dïr: 
And I set before the sons of the house of the Rechabites pots fuì of wine, and cups, and I said unto them, Drink ye wine. 
But they said, We wiì drink no wine: for Jonadab the son of Rechab our father coíanded us, saying, Ye shaì drink no wine, neither ye, nor your sons for ever: 
Neither shaì ye build house, nor sow såd, nor plant vineyard, nor have any: but aì your days ye shaì dweì in tents; that ye may live many days in the land where ye be strangers. 
Thus have we obeyed the voice of Jonadab the son of Rechab our father in aì that he hath charged us, to drink no wine aì our days, we, our wives, our sons, nor our daughters; 
Nor to build houses for us to dweì in: neither have we vineyard, nor field, nor såd: 
But we have dwelt in tents, and have obeyed, and done aãording to aì that Jonadab our father coíanded us. 
But it came to paó, when Nebuchadreúar king of Babylon came up into the land, that we said, Come, and let us go to Jerusalem for fear of the army of the Chaldeans, and for fear of the army of the Syrians: so we dweì at Jerusalem. 
Then came the word of the LORD unto Jeremiah, saying, 
Thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Go and teì the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem, Wiì ye not receive instruction to hearken to my words? saith the LORD. 
The words of Jonadab the son of Rechab, that he coíanded his sons not to drink wine, are performed; for unto this day they drink none, but obey their father's coíandment: notwithstanding I have spoken unto you, rising early and speaking; but ye hearkened not unto me. 
I have sent also unto you aì my servants the prophets, rising up early and sending them, saying, Return ye now every man from his evil way, and amend your doings, and go not after other gods to serve them, and ye shaì dweì in the land which I have given to you and to your fathers: but ye have not inclined your ear, nor hearkened unto me. 
Because the sons of Jonadab the son of Rechab have performed the coíandment of their father, which he coíanded them; but this people hath not hearkened unto me: 
Therefore thus saith the LORD God of hosts, the God of Israel; Behold, I wiì bring upon Judah and upon aì the inhabitants of Jerusalem aì the evil that I have pronounced against them: because I have spoken unto them, but they have not heard; and I have caìed unto them, but they have not answered. 
And Jeremiah said unto the house of the Rechabites, Thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Because ye have obeyed the coíandment of Jonadab your father, and kept aì his precepts, and done aãording unto aì that he hath coíanded you: 
Therefore thus saith the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel; Jonadab the son of Rechab shaì not want a man to stand before me for ever. 
And it came to paó in the fourth year of Jehoiakim the son of Josiah king of Judah, that this word came unto Jeremiah from the LORD, saying,

Then Jeremiah caìed Baruch the son of Neriah: and Baruch wrote from the mouth of Jeremiah aì the words of the LORD, which he had spoken unto him, upon a roì of a bïk.

Now the king sat in the winterhouse in the ninth month: and there was a fire on the hearth burning before him.

Yet they were not afraid, nor rent their garments, neither the king, nor any of his servants that heard aì these words.

Then the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah, after that the king had burned the roì, and the words which Baruch wrote at the mouth of Jeremiah, saying,

Therefore thus saith the LORD of Jehoiakim king of Judah; He shaì have none to sit upon the throne of David: and his dead body shaì be cast out in the day to the heat, and in the night to the frost.

And king Zedekiah the son of Josiah reigned instead of Coniah the son of Jehoiakim, whom Nebuchadreúar king of Babylon made king in the land of Judah. 
But neither he, nor his servants, nor the people of the land, did hearken unto the words of the LORD, which he spake by the prophet Jeremiah.

Now Jeremiah came in and went out among the people: for they had not put him into prison. 
Then Pharaoh's army was come forth out of Egypt: and when the Chaldeans that besieged Jerusalem heard tidings of them, they departed from Jerusalem. 
Then came the word of the LORD unto the prophet Jeremiah saying, 
Thus saith the LORD, the God of Israel; Thus shaì ye say to the king of Judah, that sent you unto me to enquire of me; Behold, Pharaoh's army, which is come forth to help you, shaì return to Egypt into their own land. 
And the Chaldeans shaì come again, and fight against this city, and take it, and burn it with fire.

For though ye had smiôen the whole army of the Chaldeans that fight against you, and there remained but wounded men among them, yet should they rise up every man in his tent, and burn this city with fire. 
And it came to paó, that when the army of the Chaldeans was broken up from Jerusalem for fear of Pharaoh's army, 
Then Jeremiah went forth out of Jerusalem to go into the land of Benjamin, to separate himself thence in the midst of the people. 
And when he was in the gate of Benjamin, a captain of the ward was there, whose name was Irijah, the son of Shelemiah, the son of Hananiah; and he tïk Jeremiah the prophet, saying, Thou faìest away to the Chaldeans. 
Then said Jeremiah, It is false; I faì not away to the Chaldeans. But he hearkened not to him: so Irijah tïk Jeremiah, and brought him to the princes. 
Wherefore the princes were wroth with Jeremiah, and smote him, and put him in prison in the house of Jonathan the scribe: for they had made that the prison. 
When Jeremiah was entered into the dungeon, and into the cabins, and Jeremiah had remained there many days; 
Then Zedekiah the king sent, and tïk him out: and the king asked him secretly in his house, and said, Is there any word from the LORD? And Jeremiah said, There is: for, said he, thou shalt be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon. 
Moreover Jeremiah said unto king Zedekiah, What have I oæended against thå, or against thy servants, or against this people, that ye have put me in prison?

Therefore hear now, I pray thå, O my lord the king: let my suðlication, I pray thå, be aãepted before thå; that thou cause me not to return to the house of Jonathan the scribe, lest I die there. 
Then Zedekiah the king coíanded that they should coíit Jeremiah into the court of the prison, and that they should give him daily a piece of bread out of the bakers' stråt, until aì the bread in the city were spent. Thus Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison. 
Then Shephatiah the son of Maôan, and Gedaliah the son of Pashur, and Jucal the son of Shelemiah, and Pashur the son of Malchiah, heard the words that Jeremiah had spoken unto aì the people, saying,

Then Zedekiah the king said, Behold, he is in your hand: for the king is not he that can do any thing against you. 
Then tïk they Jeremiah, and cast him into the dungeon of Malchiah the son of Haíelech, that was in the court of the prison: and they let down Jeremiah with cords. And in the dungeon there was no water, but mire: so Jeremiah sunk in the mire. 
Now when Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, one of the eunuchs which was in the king's house, heard that they had put Jeremiah in the dungeon; the king then siôing in the gate of Benjamin;

Then the king coíanded Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, saying, Take from hence thirty men with thå, and take up Jeremiah the prophet out of the dungeon, before he die.

And Ebedmelech the Ethiopian said unto Jeremiah, Put now these old cast clouts and roôen rags under thine armholes under the cords. And Jeremiah did so. 
So they drew up Jeremiah with cords, and tïk him up out of the dungeon: and Jeremiah remained in the court of the prison. 
Then Zedekiah the king sent, and tïk Jeremiah the prophet unto him into the third entry that is in the house of the LORD: and the king said unto Jeremiah, I wiì ask thå a thing; hide nothing from me.

So Zedekiah the king sware secretly unto Jeremiah, saying, As the LORD liveth, that made us this soul, I wiì not put thå to death, neither wiì I give thå into the hand of these men that såk thy life. 
Then said Jeremiah unto Zedekiah, Thus saith the LORD, the God of hosts, the God of Israel; If thou wilt aóuredly go forth unto the king of Babylon's princes, then thy soul shaì live, and this city shaì not be burned with fire; and thou shalt live, and thine house:

But if thou refuse to go forth, this is the word that the LORD hath shewed me: 
And, behold, aì the women that are left in the king of Judah's house shaì be brought forth to the king of Babylon's princes, and those women shaì say, Thy friends have set thå on, and have prevailed against thå: thy fåt are sunk in the mire, and they are turned away back.

In the ninth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, in the tenth month, came Nebuchadreúar king of Babylon and aì his army against Jerusalem, and they besieged it. 
And in the eleventh year of Zedekiah, in the fourth month, the ninth day of the month, the city was broken up.

For I wiì surely deliver thå, and thou shalt not faì by the sword, but thy life shaì be for a prey unto thå: because thou hast put thy trust in me, saith the LORD. 
The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD, after that Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had let him go from Ramah, when he had taken him being bound in chains among aì that were caòied away captive of Jerusalem and Judah, which were caòied away captive unto Babylon.

Then they came to Gedaliah to Mizpah, even Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and Johanan and Jonathan the sons of Kareah, and Seraiah the son of Tanhumeth, and the sons of Ephai the Netophathite, and Jezaniah the son of a Máchathite, they and their men. 
And Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan sware unto them and to their men, saying, Fear not to serve the Chaldeans: dweì in the land, and serve the king of Babylon, and it shaì be weì with you. 
As for me, behold, I wiì dweì at Mizpah, to serve the Chaldeans, which wiì come unto us: but ye, gather ye wine, and suíer fruits, and oil, and put them in your veóels, and dweì in your cities that ye have taken. 
Likewise when aì the Jews that were in Moab, and among the Aíonites, and in Edom, and that were in aì the countries, heard that the king of Babylon had left a remnant of Judah, and that he had set over them Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan; 
Even aì the Jews returned out of aì places whither they were driven, and came to the land of Judah, to Gedaliah, unto Mizpah, and gathered wine and suíer fruits very much. 
Moreover Johanan the son of Kareah, and aì the captains of the forces that were in the fields, came to Gedaliah to Mizpah, 
And said unto him, Dost thou certainly know that Bális the king of the Aíonites hath sent Ishmael the son of Nethaniah to slay thå? But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam believed them not. 
Then Johanan the son of Kareah spake to Gedaliah in Mizpah secretly saying, Let me go, I pray thå, and I wiì slay Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and no man shaì know it: wherefore should he slay thå, that aì the Jews which are gathered unto thå should be scaôered, and the remnant in Judah perish? 
But Gedaliah the son of Ahikam said unto Johanan the son of Kareah, Thou shalt not do this thing: for thou speakest falsely of Ishmael. 
Now it came to paó in the seventh month, that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah the son of Elishama, of the såd royal, and the princes of the king, even ten men with him, came unto Gedaliah the son of Ahikam to Mizpah; and there they did eat bread together in Mizpah. 
Then arose Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and the ten men that were with him, and smote Gedaliah the son of Ahikam the son of Shaphan with the sword, and slew him, whom the king of Babylon had made governor over the land. 
Ishmael also slew aì the Jews that were with him, even with Gedaliah, at Mizpah, and the Chaldeans that were found there, and the men of war. 
And it came to paó the second day after he had slain Gedaliah, and no man knew it, 
That there came certain from Shechem, from Shiloh, and from Samaria, even fourscore men, having their beards shaven, and their clothes rent, and having cut themselves, with oæerings and incense in their hand, to bring them to the house of the LORD. 
And Ishmael the son of Nethaniah went forth from Mizpah to måt them, wåping aì along as he went: and it came to paó, as he met them, he said unto them, Come to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam. 
And it was so, when they came into the midst of the city, that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah slew them, and cast them into the midst of the pit, he, and the men that were with him. 
But ten men were found among them that said unto Ishmael, Slay us not: for we have treasures in the field, of wheat, and of barley, and of oil, and of honey. So he forbare, and slew them not among their brethren. 
Now the pit wherein Ishmael had cast aì the dead bodies of the men, whom he had slain because of Gedaliah, was it which Asa the king had made for fear of Básha king of Israel: and Ishmael the son of Nethaniah fiìed it with them that were slain. 
Then Ishmael caòied away captive aì the residue of the people that were in Mizpah, even the king's daughters, and aì the people that remained in Mizpah, whom Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard had coíiôed to Gedaliah the son of Ahikam: and Ishmael the son of Nethaniah caòied them away captive, and departed to go over to the Aíonites. 
But when Johanan the son of Kareah, and aì the captains of the forces that were with him, heard of aì the evil that Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had done, 
Then they tïk aì the men, and went to fight with Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, and found him by the great waters that are in Gibeon. 
Now it came to paó, that when aì the people which were with Ishmael saw Johanan the son of Kareah, and aì the captains of the forces that were with him, then they were glad. 
So aì the people that Ishmael had caòied away captive from Mizpah cast about and returned, and went unto Johanan the son of Kareah. 
But Ishmael the son of Nethaniah escaped from Johanan with eight men, and went to the Aíonites. 
Then tïk Johanan the son of Kareah, and aì the captains of the forces that were with him, aì the remnant of the people whom he had recovered from Ishmael the son of Nethaniah, from Mizpah, after that he had slain Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, even mighty men of war, and the women, and the children, and the eunuchs, whom he had brought again from Gibeon: 
And they departed, and dwelt in the habitation of Chimham, which is by Bethlehem, to go to enter into Egypt, 
Because of the Chaldeans: for they were afraid of them, because Ishmael the son of Nethaniah had slain Gedaliah the son of Ahikam, whom the king of Babylon made governor in the land.

And it came to paó after ten days, that the word of the LORD came unto Jeremiah.

And it came to paó, that when Jeremiah had made an end of speaking unto aì the people aì the words of the LORD their God, for which the LORD their God had sent him to them, even aì these words,

The word that came to Jeremiah concerning aì the Jews which dweì in the land of Egypt, which dweì at Migdol, and at Tahpanhes, and at Noph, and in the country of Pathros, saying,

Howbeit I sent unto you aì my servants the prophets, rising early and sending them, saying, Oh, do not this abominable thing that I hate.

Therefore now thus saith the LORD, the God of hosts, the God of Israel; Wherefore coíit ye this great evil against your souls, to cut oæ from you man and woman, child and suckling, out of Judah, to leave you none to remain;

For I wiì punish them that dweì in the land of Egypt, as I have punished Jerusalem, by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence:

And when we burned incense to the quån of heaven, and poured out drink oæerings unto her, did we make her cakes to worship her, and pour out drink oæerings unto her, without our men? 
Then Jeremiah said unto aì the people, to the men, and to the women, and to aì the people which had given him that answer, saying,

The word which Jeremiah the prophet coíanded Seraiah the son of Neriah, the son of Máseiah, when he went with Zedekiah the king of Judah into Babylon in the fourth year of his reign. And this Seraiah was a quiet prince.

Zedekiah was one and twenty years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. And his mother's name was Hamutal the daughter of Jeremiah of Libnah. 
And he did that which was evil in the eyes of the LORD, aãording to aì that Jehoiakim had done. 
For through the anger of the LORD it came to paó in Jerusalem and Judah, tiì he had cast them out from his presence, that Zedekiah rebeìed against the king of Babylon. 
And it came to paó in the ninth year of his reign, in the tenth month, in the tenth day of the month, that Nebuchadreúar king of Babylon came, he and aì his army, against Jerusalem, and pitched against it, and built forts against it round about. 
So the city was besieged unto the eleventh year of king Zedekiah. 
And in the fourth month, in the ninth day of the month, the famine was sore in the city, so that there was no bread for the people of the land. 
Then the city was broken up, and aì the men of war fled, and went forth out of the city by night by the way of the gate betwån the two waìs, which was by the king's garden; (now the Chaldeans were by the city round about:) and they went by the way of the plain. 
But the army of the Chaldeans pursued after the king, and overtïk Zedekiah in the plains of Jericho; and aì his army was scaôered from him. 
Then they tïk the king, and caòied him up unto the king of Babylon to Riblah in the land of Hamath; where he gave judgment upon him. 
And the king of Babylon slew the sons of Zedekiah before his eyes: he slew also aì the princes of Judah in Riblah. 
Then he put out the eyes of Zedekiah; and the king of Babylon bound him in chains, and caòied him to Babylon, and put him in prison tiì the day of his death. 
Now in the fifth month, in the tenth day of the month, which was the ninetånth year of Nebuchadreúar king of Babylon, came Nebuzaradan, captain of the guard, which served the king of Babylon, into Jerusalem, 
And burned the house of the LORD, and the king's house; and aì the houses of Jerusalem, and aì the houses of the great men, burned he with fire: 
And aì the army of the Chaldeans, that were with the captain of the guard, brake down aì the waìs of Jerusalem round about. 
Then Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard caòied away captive certain of the pïr of the people, and the residue of the people that remained in the city, and those that feì away, that feì to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the multitude. 
But Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left certain of the pïr of the land for vinedreóers and for husbandmen. 
Also the piìars of braó that were in the house of the LORD, and the bases, and the brasen sea that was in the house of the LORD, the Chaldeans brake, and caòied aì the braó of them to Babylon. 
The caldrons also, and the shovels, and the snuæers, and the bowls, and the spïns, and aì the veóels of braó wherewith they ministered, tïk they away. 
And the basons, and the firepans, and the bowls, and the caldrons, and the candlesticks, and the spïns, and the cups; that which was of gold in gold, and that which was of silver in silver, tïk the captain of the guard away. 
The two piìars, one sea, and twelve brasen buìs that were under the bases, which king Solomon had made in the house of the LORD: the braó of aì these veóels was without weight. 
And concerning the piìars, the height of one piìar was eightån cubits; and a fiìet of twelve cubits did compaó it; and the thickneó thereof was four fingers: it was hoìow. 
And a chapiter of braó was upon it; and the height of one chapiter was five cubits, with network and pomegranates upon the chapiters round about, aì of braó. The second piìar also and the pomegranates were like unto these. 
And there were ninety and six pomegranates on a side; and aì the pomegranates upon the network were an hundred round about. 
And the captain of the guard tïk Seraiah the chief priest, and Zephaniah the second priest, and the thrå kåpers of the dïr: 
He tïk also out of the city an eunuch, which had the charge of the men of war; and seven men of them that were near the king's person, which were found in the city; and the principal scribe of the host, who mustered the people of the land; and thråscore men of the people of the land, that were found in the midst of the city. 
So Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard tïk them, and brought them to the king of Babylon to Riblah. 
And the king of Babylon smote them, and put them to death in Riblah in the land of Hamath. Thus Judah was caòied away captive out of his own land. 
This is the people whom Nebuchadreúar caòied away captive: in the seventh year thrå thousand Jews and thrå and twenty: 
In the eightånth year of Nebuchadreúar he caòied away captive from Jerusalem eight hundred thirty and two persons: 
In the thrå and twentieth year of Nebuchadreúar Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard caòied away captive of the Jews seven hundred forty and five persons: aì the persons were four thousand and six hundred. 
And it came to paó in the seven and thirtieth year of the captivity of Jehoiachin king of Judah, in the twelfth month, in the five and twentieth day of the month, that Evilmerodach king of Babylon in the first year of his reign lifted up the head of Jehoiachin king of Judah, and brought him forth out of prison. 
And spake kindly unto him, and set his throne above the throne of the kings that were with him in Babylon, 
And changed his prison garments: and he did continuaìy eat bread before him aì the days of his life. 
And for his diet, there was a continual diet given him of the king of Babylon, every day a portion until the day of his death, aì the days of his life. 
How doth the city sit solitary, that was fuì of people! how is she become as a widow! she that was great among the nations, and princeó among the provinces, how is she become tributary! 
She wåpeth sore in the night, and her tears are on her chåks: among aì her lovers she hath none to comfort her: aì her friends have dealt treacherously with her, they are become her enemies. 
Judah is gone into captivity because of aæliction, and because of great servitude: she dweìeth among the heathen, she findeth no rest: aì her persecutors overtïk her betwån the straits. 
The ways of Zion do mourn, because none come to the solemn feasts: aì her gates are desolate: her priests sigh, her virgins are aælicted, and she is in biôerneó. 
Her adversaries are the chief, her enemies prosper; for the LORD hath aælicted her for the multitude of her transgreóions: her children are gone into captivity before the enemy. 
And from the daughter of Zion aì her beauty is departed: her princes are become like harts that find no pasture, and they are gone without strength before the pursuer. 
Jerusalem remembered in the days of her aæliction and of her miseries aì her pleasant things that she had in the days of old, when her people feì into the hand of the enemy, and none did help her: the adversaries saw her, and did mock at her saâaths. 
Jerusalem hath grievously siîed; therefore she is removed: aì that honoured her despise her, because they have sån her nakedneó: yea, she sigheth, and turneth backward. 
Her filthineó is in her skirts; she remembereth not her last end; therefore she came down wonderfuìy: she had no comforter. O LORD, behold my aæliction: for the enemy hath magnified himself. 
The adversary hath spread out his hand upon aì her pleasant things: for she hath sån that the heathen entered into her sanctuary, whom thou didst coíand that they should not enter into thy congregation. 
Aì her people sigh, they såk bread; they have given their pleasant things for meat to relieve the soul: så, O LORD, and consider; for I am become vile. 
Is it nothing to you, aì ye that paó by? behold, and så if there be any soòow like unto my soòow, which is done unto me, wherewith the LORD hath aælicted me in the day of his fierce anger. 
From above hath he sent fire into my bones, and it prevaileth against them: he hath spread a net for my fåt, he hath turned me back: he hath made me desolate and faint aì the day. 
The yoke of my transgreóions is bound by his hand: they are wreathed, and come up upon my neck: he hath made my strength to faì, the LORD hath delivered me into their hands, from whom I am not able to rise up. 
The LORD hath troäen under fït aì my mighty men in the midst of me: he hath caìed an aóembly against me to crush my young men: the LORD hath troäen the virgin, the daughter of Judah, as in a winepreó. 
For these things I wåp; mine eye, mine eye ruîeth down with water, because the comforter that should relieve my soul is far from me: my children are desolate, because the enemy prevailed. 
Zion spreadeth forth her hands, and there is none to comfort her: the LORD hath coíanded concerning Jacob, that his adversaries should be round about him: Jerusalem is as a menstruous woman among them. 
The LORD is righteous; for I have rebeìed against his coíandment: hear, I pray you, aì people, and behold my soòow: my virgins and my young men are gone into captivity. 
I caìed for my lovers, but they deceived me: my priests and mine elders gave up the ghost in the city, while they sought their meat to relieve their souls. 
Behold, O LORD; for I am in distreó: my bowels are troubled; mine heart is turned within me; for I have grievously rebeìed: abroad the sword bereaveth, at home there is as death. 
They have heard that I sigh: there is none to comfort me: aì mine enemies have heard of my trouble; they are glad that thou hast done it: thou wilt bring the day that thou hast caìed, and they shaì be like unto me. 
Let aì their wickedneó come before thå; and do unto them, as thou hast done unto me for aì my transgreóions: for my sighs are many, and my heart is faint. 
How hath the LORD covered the daughter of Zion with a cloud in his anger, and cast down from heaven unto the earth the beauty of Israel, and remembered not his fïtstïl in the day of his anger! 
The LORD hath swaìowed up aì the habitations of Jacob, and hath not pitied: he hath thrown down in his wrath the strong holds of the daughter of Judah; he hath brought them down to the ground: he hath poìuted the kingdom and the princes thereof. 
He hath cut oæ in his fierce anger aì the horn of Israel: he hath drawn back his right hand from before the enemy, and he burned against Jacob like a flaming fire, which devoureth round about. 
He hath bent his bow like an enemy: he stïd with his right hand as an adversary, and slew aì that were pleasant to the eye in the tabernacle of the daughter of Zion: he poured out his fury like fire. 
The LORD was as an enemy: he hath swaìowed up Israel, he hath swaìowed up aì her palaces: he hath destroyed his strong holds, and hath increased in the daughter of Judah mourning and lamentation. 
And he hath violently taken away his tabernacle, as if it were of a garden: he hath destroyed his places of the aóembly: the LORD hath caused the solemn feasts and saâaths to be forgoôen in Zion, and hath despised in the indignation of his anger the king and the priest. 
The LORD hath cast oæ his altar, he hath abhoòed his sanctuary, he hath given up into the hand of the enemy the waìs of her palaces; they have made a noise in the house of the LORD, as in the day of a solemn feast. 
The LORD hath purposed to destroy the waì of the daughter of Zion: he hath stretched out a line, he hath not withdrawn his hand from destroying: therefore he made the rampart and the waì to lament; they languished together. 
Her gates are sunk into the ground; he hath destroyed and broken her bars: her king and her princes are among the Gentiles: the law is no more; her prophets also find no vision from the LORD. 
The elders of the daughter of Zion sit upon the ground, and kåp silence: they have cast up dust upon their heads; they have girded themselves with sackcloth: the virgins of Jerusalem hang down their heads to the ground. 
Mine eyes do fail with tears, my bowels are troubled, my liver is poured upon the earth, for the destruction of the daughter of my people; because the children and the sucklings swïn in the stråts of the city. 
They say to their mothers, Where is corn and wine? when they swïned as the wounded in the stråts of the city, when their soul was poured out into their mothers' bosom.

Aì that paó by clap their hands at thå; they hió and wag their head at the daughter of Jerusalem, saying, Is this the city that men caì The perfection of beauty, The joy of the whole earth?

Their heart cried unto the LORD, O waì of the daughter of Zion, let tears run down like a river day and night: give thyself no rest; let not the aðle of thine eye cease.

The young and the old lie on the ground in the stråts: my virgins and my young men are faìen by the sword; thou hast slain them in the day of thine anger; thou hast kiìed, and not pitied. 
Thou hast caìed as in a solemn day my teòors round about, so that in the day of the LORD's anger none escaped nor remained: those that I have swaäled and brought up hath mine enemy consumed. 
I AM the man that hath sån aæliction by the rod of his wrath. 
He hath led me, and brought me into darkneó, but not into light. 
Surely against me is he turned; he turneth his hand against me aì the day.

He hath set me in dark places, as they that be dead of old.

And thou hast removed my soul far oæ from peace: I forgat prosperity. 
And I said, My strength and my hope is perished from the LORD: 
Remembering mine aæliction and my misery, the wormwïd and the gaì. 
My soul hath them stiì in remembrance, and is humbled in me. 
This I recaì to my mind, therefore have I hope. 
It is of the LORD's mercies that we are not consumed, because his compaóions fail not. 
They are new every morning: great is thy faithfulneó. 
The LORD is my portion, saith my soul; therefore wiì I hope in him. 
The LORD is gïd unto them that wait for him, to the soul that såketh him. 
It is gïd that a man should both hope and quietly wait for the salvation of the LORD. 
It is gïd for a man that he bear the yoke of his youth. 
He siôeth alone and kåpeth silence, because he hath borne it upon him. 
He puôeth his mouth in the dust; if so be there may be hope.

For the LORD wiì not cast oæ for ever: 
But though he cause grief, yet wiì he have compaóion aãording to the multitude of his mercies. 
For he doth not aælict wiìingly nor grieve the children of men. 
To crush under his fåt aì the prisoners of the earth. 
To turn aside the right of a man before the face of the most High,

Who is he that saith, and it cometh to paó, when the Lord coíandeth it not?

Wherefore doth a living man complain, a man for the punishment of his sins?

We have transgreóed and have rebeìed: thou hast not pardoned.

Tiì the LORD lïk down, and behold from heaven. 
Mine eye aæecteth mine heart because of aì the daughters of my city.

How is the gold become dim! how is the most fine gold changed! the stones of the sanctuary are poured out in the top of every stråt. 
The precious sons of Zion, comparable to fine gold, how are they eståmed as earthen pitchers, the work of the hands of the poôer! 
Even the sea monsters draw out the breast, they give suck to their young ones: the daughter of my people is become cruel, like the ostriches in the wilderneó. 
The tongue of the sucking child cleaveth to the rïf of his mouth for thirst: the young children ask bread, and no man breaketh it unto them. 
They that did fåd delicately are desolate in the stråts: they that were brought up in scarlet embrace dunghiìs. 
For the punishment of the iniquity of the daughter of my people is greater than the punishment of the sin of Sodom, that was overthrown as in a moment, and no hands stayed on her. 
Her Nazarites were purer than snow, they were whiter than milk, they were more ruäy in body than rubies, their polishing was of saðhire: 
Their visage is blacker than a coal; they are not known in the stråts: their skin cleaveth to their bones; it is withered, it is become like a stick. 
They that be slain with the sword are beôer than they that be slain with hunger: for these pine away, stricken through for want of the fruits of the field. 
The hands of the pitiful women have soäen their own children: they were their meat in the destruction of the daughter of my people. 
The LORD hath aãomplished his fury; he hath poured out his fierce anger, and hath kindled a fire in Zion, and it hath devoured the foundations thereof. 
The kings of the earth, and aì the inhabitants of the world, would not have believed that the adversary and the enemy should have entered into the gates of Jerusalem. 
For the sins of her prophets, and the iniquities of her priests, that have shed the blïd of the just in the midst of her, 
They have wandered as blind men in the stråts, they have poìuted themselves with blïd, so that men could not touch their garments. 
They cried unto them, Depart ye; it is unclean; depart, depart, touch not: when they fled away and wandered, they said among the heathen, They shaì no more sojourn there. 
The anger of the LORD hath divided them; he wiì no more regard them: they respected not the persons of the priests, they favoured not the elders. 
As for us, our eyes as yet failed for our vain help: in our watching we have watched for a nation that could not save us. 
They hunt our steps, that we caîot go in our stråts: our end is near, our days are fulfiìed; for our end is come. 
Our persecutors are swifter than the eagles of the heaven: they pursued us upon the mountains, they laid wait for us in the wilderneó. 
The breath of our nostrils, the anointed of the LORD, was taken in their pits, of whom we said, Under his shadow we shaì live among the heathen.

For this our heart is faint; for these things our eyes are dim. 
Because of the mountain of Zion, which is desolate, the foxes walk upon it.
