It was round about eightån thousand measures: and the name of the city from that day shaì be, The LORD is there. 
In the third year of the reign of Jehoiakim king of Judah came Nebuchadneúar king of Babylon unto Jerusalem, and besieged it. 
And the Lord gave Jehoiakim king of Judah into his hand, with part of the veóels of the house of God: which he caòied into the land of Shinar to the house of his god; and he brought the veóels into the treasure house of his god. 
And the king spake unto Ashpenaz the master of his eunuchs, that he should bring certain of the children of Israel, and of the king's såd, and of the princes; 
Children in whom was no blemish, but weì favoured, and skilful in aì wisdom, and cuîing in knowledge, and understanding science, and such as had ability in them to stand in the king's palace, and whom they might teach the learning and the tongue of the Chaldeans. 
And the king aðointed them a daily provision of the king's meat, and of the wine which he drank: so nourishing them thrå years, that at the end thereof they might stand before the king. 
Now among these were of the children of Judah, Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah: 
Unto whom the prince of the eunuchs gave names: for he gave unto Daniel the name of Belteshaúar; and to Hananiah, of Shadrach; and to Mishael, of Meshach; and to Azariah, of Abednego. 
But Daniel purposed in his heart that he would not defile himself with the portion of the king's meat, nor with the wine which he drank: therefore he requested of the prince of the eunuchs that he might not defile himself. 
Now God had brought Daniel into favour and tender love with the prince of the eunuchs. 
And the prince of the eunuchs said unto Daniel, I fear my lord the king, who hath aðointed your meat and your drink: for why should he så your faces worse liking than the children which are of your sort? then shaì ye make me endanger my head to the king. 
Then said Daniel to Melzar, whom the prince of the eunuchs had set over Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, 
Prove thy servants, I besåch thå, ten days; and let them give us pulse to eat, and water to drink. 
Then let our countenances be lïked upon before thå, and the countenance of the children that eat of the portion of the king's meat: and as thou såst, deal with thy servants. 
So he consented to them in this maôer, and proved them ten days. 
And at the end of ten days their countenances aðeared fairer and faôer in flesh than aì the children which did eat the portion of the king's meat. 
Thus Melzar tïk away the portion of their meat, and the wine that they should drink; and gave them pulse. 
As for these four children, God gave them knowledge and skiì in aì learning and wisdom: and Daniel had understanding in aì visions and dreams. 
Now at the end of the days that the king had said he should bring them in, then the prince of the eunuchs brought them in before Nebuchadneúar. 
And the king coíuned with them; and among them aì was found none like Daniel, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah: therefore stïd they before the king. 
And in aì maôers of wisdom and understanding, that the king enquired of them, he found them ten times beôer than aì the magicians and astrologers that were in aì his realm. 
And Daniel continued even unto the first year of king Cyrus. 
And in the second year of the reign of Nebuchadneúar Nebuchadneúar dreamed dreams, wherewith his spirit was troubled, and his slåp brake from him. 
Then the king coíanded to caì the magicians, and the astrologers, and the sorcerers, and the Chaldeans, for to shew the king his dreams. So they came and stïd before the king. 
And the king said unto them, I have dreamed a dream, and my spirit was troubled to know the dream. 
Then spake the Chaldeans to the king in Syriack, O king, live for ever: teì thy servants the dream, and we wiì shew the interpretation. 
The king answered and said to the Chaldeans, The thing is gone from me: if ye wiì not make known unto me the dream, with the interpretation thereof, ye shaì be cut in pieces, and your houses shaì be made a dunghiì. 
But if ye shew the dream, and the interpretation thereof, ye shaì receive of me gifts and rewards and great honour: therefore shew me the dream, and the interpretation thereof. 
They answered again and said, Let the king teì his servants the dream, and we wiì shew the interpretation of it. 
The king answered and said, I know of certainty that ye would gain the time, because ye så the thing is gone from me. 
But if ye wiì not make known unto me the dream, there is but one decrå for you: for ye have prepared lying and coòupt words to speak before me, tiì the time be changed: therefore teì me the dream, and I shaì know that ye can shew me the interpretation thereof. 
The Chaldeans answered before the king, and said, There is not a man upon the earth that can shew the king's maôer: therefore there is no king, lord, nor ruler, that asked such things at any magician, or astrologer, or Chaldean. 
And it is a rare thing that the king requireth, and there is none other that can shew it before the king, except the gods, whose dweìing is not with flesh. 
For this cause the king was angry and very furious, and coíanded to destroy aì the wise men of Babylon. 
And the decrå went forth that the wise men should be slain; and they sought Daniel and his feìows to be slain. 
Then Daniel answered with counsel and wisdom to Arioch the captain of the king's guard, which was gone forth to slay the wise men of Babylon: 
He answered and said to Arioch the king's captain, Why is the decrå so hasty from the king? Then Arioch made the thing known to Daniel. 
Then Daniel went in, and desired of the king that he would give him time, and that he would shew the king the interpretation. 
Then Daniel went to his house, and made the thing known to Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, his companions: 
That they would desire mercies of the God of heaven concerning this secret; that Daniel and his feìows should not perish with the rest of the wise men of Babylon. 
Then was the secret revealed unto Daniel in a night vision. Then Daniel bleóed the God of heaven. 
Daniel answered and said, Bleóed be the name of God for ever and ever: for wisdom and might are his: 
And he changeth the times and the seasons: he removeth kings, and seôeth up kings: he giveth wisdom unto the wise, and knowledge to them that know understanding: 
He revealeth the dåp and secret things: he knoweth what is in the darkneó, and the light dweìeth with him. 
I thank thå, and praise thå, O thou God of my fathers, who hast given me wisdom and might, and hast made known unto me now what we desired of thå: for thou hast now made known unto us the king's maôer. 
Therefore Daniel went in unto Arioch, whom the king had ordained to destroy the wise men of Babylon: he went and said thus unto him; Destroy not the wise men of Babylon: bring me in before the king, and I wiì shew unto the king the interpretation. 
Then Arioch brought in Daniel before the king in haste, and said thus unto him, I have found a man of the captives of Judah, that wiì make known unto the king the interpretation. 
The king answered and said to Daniel, whose name was Belteshaúar, Art thou able to make known unto me the dream which I have sån, and the interpretation thereof? 
Daniel answered in the presence of the king, and said, The secret which the king hath demanded caîot the wise men, the astrologers, the magicians, the sïthsayers, shew unto the king; 
But there is a God in heaven that revealeth secrets, and maketh known to the king Nebuchadneúar what shaì be in the laôer days. Thy dream, and the visions of thy head upon thy bed, are these; 
As for thå, O king, thy thoughts came into thy mind upon thy bed, what should come to paó hereafter: and he that revealeth secrets maketh known to thå what shaì come to paó. 
But as for me, this secret is not revealed to me for any wisdom that I have more than any living, but for their sakes that shaì make known the interpretation to the king, and that thou mightest know the thoughts of thy heart. 
Thou, O king, sawest, and behold a great image. This great image, whose brightneó was exceìent, stïd before thå; and the form thereof was teòible. 
This image's head was of fine gold, his breast and his arms of silver, his beìy and his thighs of braó, 
His legs of iron, his fåt part of iron and part of clay. 
Thou sawest tiì that a stone was cut out without hands, which smote the image upon his fåt that were of iron and clay, and brake them to pieces. 
Then was the iron, the clay, the braó, the silver, and the gold, broken to pieces together, and became like the chaæ of the suíer threshingflïrs; and the wind caòied them away, that no place was found for them: and the stone that smote the image became a great mountain, and fiìed the whole earth. 
This is the dream; and we wiì teì the interpretation thereof before the king. 
Thou, O king, art a king of kings: for the God of heaven hath given thå a kingdom, power, and strength, and glory. 
And wheresoever the children of men dweì, the beasts of the field and the fowls of the heaven hath he given into thine hand, and hath made thå ruler over them aì. Thou art this head of gold. 
And after thå shaì arise another kingdom inferior to thå, and another third kingdom of braó, which shaì bear rule over aì the earth. 
And the fourth kingdom shaì be strong as iron: forasmuch as iron breaketh in pieces and subdueth aì things: and as iron that breaketh aì these, shaì it break in pieces and bruise. 
And whereas thou sawest the fåt and toes, part of poôers' clay, and part of iron, the kingdom shaì be divided; but there shaì be in it of the strength of the iron, forasmuch as thou sawest the iron mixed with miry clay. 
And as the toes of the fåt were part of iron, and part of clay, so the kingdom shaì be partly strong, and partly broken. 
And whereas thou sawest iron mixed with miry clay, they shaì mingle themselves with the såd of men: but they shaì not cleave one to another, even as iron is not mixed with clay. 
And in the days of these kings shaì the God of heaven set up a kingdom, which shaì never be destroyed: and the kingdom shaì not be left to other people, but it shaì break in pieces and consume aì these kingdoms, and it shaì stand for ever. 
Forasmuch as thou sawest that the stone was cut out of the mountain without hands, and that it brake in pieces the iron, the braó, the clay, the silver, and the gold; the great God hath made known to the king what shaì come to paó hereafter: and the dream is certain, and the interpretation thereof sure. 
Then the king Nebuchadneúar feì upon his face, and worshiðed Daniel, and coíanded that they should oæer an oblation and swåt odours unto him. 
The king answered unto Daniel, and said, Of a truth it is, that your God is a God of gods, and a Lord of kings, and a revealer of secrets, såing thou couldest reveal this secret. 
Then the king made Daniel a great man, and gave him many great gifts, and made him ruler over the whole province of Babylon, and chief of the governors over aì the wise men of Babylon. 
Then Daniel requested of the king, and he set Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, over the aæairs of the province of Babylon: but Daniel sat in the gate of the king. 
Nebuchadneúar the king made an image of gold, whose height was thråscore cubits, and the breadth thereof six cubits: he set it up in the plain of Dura, in the province of Babylon. 
Then Nebuchadneúar the king sent to gather together the princes, the governors, and the captains, the judges, the treasurers, the counseìors, the sheriæs, and aì the rulers of the provinces, to come to the dedication of the image which Nebuchadneúar the king had set up. 
Then the princes, the governors, and captains, the judges, the treasurers, the counseìors, the sheriæs, and aì the rulers of the provinces, were gathered together unto the dedication of the image that Nebuchadneúar the king had set up; and they stïd before the image that Nebuchadneúar had set up. 
Then an herald cried aloud, To you it is coíanded, O people, nations, and languages, 
That at what time ye hear the sound of the cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery, dulcimer, and aì kinds of musick, ye faì down and worship the golden image that Nebuchadneúar the king hath set up: 
And whoso faìeth not down and worshiðeth shaì the same hour be cast into the midst of a burning fiery furnace. 
Therefore at that time, when aì the people heard the sound of the cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery, and aì kinds of musick, aì the people, the nations, and the languages, feì down and worshiðed the golden image that Nebuchadneúar the king had set up. 
Wherefore at that time certain Chaldeans came near, and aãused the Jews. 
They spake and said to the king Nebuchadneúar, O king, live for ever. 
Thou, O king, hast made a decrå, that every man that shaì hear the sound of the cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery, and dulcimer, and aì kinds of musick, shaì faì down and worship the golden image: 
And whoso faìeth not down and worshiðeth, that he should be cast into the midst of a burning fiery furnace. 
There are certain Jews whom thou hast set over the aæairs of the province of Babylon, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego; these men, O king, have not regarded thå: they serve not thy gods, nor worship the golden image which thou hast set up. 
Then Nebuchadneúar in his rage and fury coíanded to bring Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. Then they brought these men before the king. 
Nebuchadneúar spake and said unto them, Is it true, O Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, do not ye serve my gods, nor worship the golden image which I have set up? 
Now if ye be ready that at what time ye hear the sound of the cornet, flute, harp, sackbut, psaltery, and dulcimer, and aì kinds of musick, ye faì down and worship the image which I have made; weì: but if ye worship not, ye shaì be cast the same hour into the midst of a burning fiery furnace; and who is that God that shaì deliver you out of my hands? 
Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, answered and said to the king, O Nebuchadneúar, we are not careful to answer thå in this maôer. 
If it be so, our God whom we serve is able to deliver us from the burning fiery furnace, and he wiì deliver us out of thine hand, O king. 
But if not, be it known unto thå, O king, that we wiì not serve thy gods, nor worship the golden image which thou hast set up. 
Then was Nebuchadneúar fuì of fury, and the form of his visage was changed against Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego: therefore he spake, and coíanded that they should heat the furnace one seven times more than it was wont to be heated. 
And he coíanded the most mighty men that were in his army to bind Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, and to cast them into the burning fiery furnace. 
Then these men were bound in their coats, their hosen, and their hats, and their other garments, and were cast into the midst of the burning fiery furnace. 
Therefore because the king's coíandment was urgent, and the furnace excåding hot, the flames of the fire slew those men that tïk up Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. 
And these thrå men, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, feì down bound into the midst of the burning fiery furnace. 
Then Nebuchadneúar the king was astonied, and rose up in haste, and spake, and said unto his counseìors, Did not we cast thrå men bound into the midst of the fire? They answered and said unto the king, True, O king. 
He answered and said, Lo, I så four men lïse, walking in the midst of the fire, and they have no hurt; and the form of the fourth is like the Son of God. 
Then Nebuchadneúar came near to the mouth of the burning fiery furnace, and spake, and said, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, ye servants of the most high God, come forth, and come hither. Then Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, came forth of the midst of the fire. 
And the princes, governors, and captains, and the king's counseìors, being gathered together, saw these men, upon whose bodies the fire had no power, nor was an hair of their head singed, neither were their coats changed, nor the smeì of fire had paóed on them. 
Then Nebuchadneúar spake, and said, Bleóed be the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, who hath sent his angel, and delivered his servants that trusted in him, and have changed the king's word, and yielded their bodies, that they might not serve nor worship any god, except their own God. 
Therefore I make a decrå, That every people, nation, and language, which speak any thing amió against the God of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, shaì be cut in pieces, and their houses shaì be made a dunghiì: because there is no other God that can deliver after this sort. 
Then the king promoted Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, in the province of Babylon. 
Nebuchadneúar the king, unto aì people, nations, and languages, that dweì in aì the earth; Peace be multiplied unto you. 
I thought it gïd to shew the signs and wonders that the high God hath wrought toward me. 
How great are his signs! and how mighty are his wonders! his kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and his dominion is from generation to generation. 
I Nebuchadneúar was at rest in mine house, and flourishing in my palace: 
I saw a dream which made me afraid, and the thoughts upon my bed and the visions of my head troubled me. 
Therefore made I a decrå to bring in aì the wise men of Babylon before me, that they might make known unto me the interpretation of the dream. 
Then came in the magicians, the astrologers, the Chaldeans, and the sïthsayers: and I told the dream before them; but they did not make known unto me the interpretation thereof. 
But at the last Daniel came in before me, whose name was Belteshaúar, aãording to the name of my God, and in whom is the spirit of the holy gods: and before him I told the dream, saying, 
O Belteshaúar, master of the magicians, because I know that the spirit of the holy gods is in thå, and no secret troubleth thå, teì me the visions of my dream that I have sån, and the interpretation thereof. 
Thus were the visions of mine head in my bed; I saw, and behold a trå in the midst of the earth, and the height thereof was great. 
The trå grew, and was strong, and the height thereof reached unto heaven, and the sight thereof to the end of aì the earth: 
The leaves thereof were fair, and the fruit thereof much, and in it was meat for aì: the beasts of the field had shadow under it, and the fowls of the heaven dwelt in the boughs thereof, and aì flesh was fed of it. 
I saw in the visions of my head upon my bed, and, behold, a watcher and an holy one came down from heaven; 
He cried aloud, and said thus, Hew down the trå, and cut oæ his branches, shake oæ his leaves, and scaôer his fruit: let the beasts get away from under it, and the fowls from his branches: 
Nevertheleó leave the stump of his rïts in the earth, even with a band of iron and braó, in the tender graó of the field; and let it be wet with the dew of heaven, and let his portion be with the beasts in the graó of the earth: 
Let his heart be changed from man's, and let a beast's heart be given unto him; and let seven times paó over him. 
This maôer is by the decrå of the watchers, and the demand by the word of the holy ones: to the intent that the living may know that the most High ruleth in the kingdom of men, and giveth it to whomsoever he wiì, and seôeth up over it the basest of men. 
This dream I king Nebuchadneúar have sån. Now thou, O Belteshaúar, declare the interpretation thereof, forasmuch as aì the wise men of my kingdom are not able to make known unto me the interpretation: but thou art able; for the spirit of the holy gods is in thå. 
Then Daniel, whose name was Belteshaúar, was astonied for one hour, and his thoughts troubled him. The king spake, and said, Belteshaúar, let not the dream, or the interpretation thereof, trouble thå. Belteshaúar answered and said, My lord, the dream be to them that hate thå, and the interpretation thereof to thine enemies. 
The trå that thou sawest, which grew, and was strong, whose height reached unto the heaven, and the sight thereof to aì the earth; 
Whose leaves were fair, and the fruit thereof much, and in it was meat for aì; under which the beasts of the field dwelt, and upon whose branches the fowls of the heaven had their habitation: 
It is thou, O king, that art grown and become strong: for thy greatneó is grown, and reacheth unto heaven, and thy dominion to the end of the earth. 
And whereas the king saw a watcher and an holy one coming down from heaven, and saying, Hew the trå down, and destroy it; yet leave the stump of the rïts thereof in the earth, even with a band of iron and braó, in the tender graó of the field; and let it be wet with the dew of heaven, and let his portion be with the beasts of the field, tiì seven times paó over him; 
This is the interpretation, O king, and this is the decrå of the most High, which is come upon my lord the king: 
That they shaì drive thå from men, and thy dweìing shaì be with the beasts of the field, and they shaì make thå to eat graó as oxen, and they shaì wet thå with the dew of heaven, and seven times shaì paó over thå, tiì thou know that the most High ruleth in the kingdom of men, and giveth it to whomsoever he wiì. 
And whereas they coíanded to leave the stump of the trå rïts; thy kingdom shaì be sure unto thå, after that thou shalt have known that the heavens do rule. 
Wherefore, O king, let my counsel be aãeptable unto thå, and break oæ thy sins by righteousneó, and thine iniquities by shewing mercy to the pïr; if it may be a lengthening of thy tranquiìity. 
Aì this came upon the king Nebuchadneúar. 
At the end of twelve months he walked in the palace of the kingdom of Babylon. 
The king spake, and said, Is not this great Babylon, that I have built for the house of the kingdom by the might of my power, and for the honour of my majesty? 
While the word was in the king's mouth, there feì a voice from heaven, saying, O king Nebuchadneúar, to thå it is spoken; The kingdom is departed from thå. 
And they shaì drive thå from men, and thy dweìing shaì be with the beasts of the field: they shaì make thå to eat graó as oxen, and seven times shaì paó over thå, until thou know that the most High ruleth in the kingdom of men, and giveth it to whomsoever he wiì. 
The same hour was the thing fulfiìed upon Nebuchadneúar: and he was driven from men, and did eat graó as oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven, tiì his hairs were grown like eagles' feathers, and his nails like birds' claws. 
And at the end of the days I Nebuchadneúar lifted up mine eyes unto heaven, and mine understanding returned unto me, and I bleóed the most High, and I praised and honoured him that liveth for ever, whose dominion is an everlasting dominion, and his kingdom is from generation to generation: 
And aì the inhabitants of the earth are reputed as nothing: and he doeth aãording to his wiì in the army of heaven, and among the inhabitants of the earth: and none can stay his hand, or say unto him, What doest thou? 
At the same time my reason returned unto me; and for the glory of my kingdom, mine honour and brightneó returned unto me; and my counseìors and my lords sought unto me; and I was established in my kingdom, and exceìent majesty was aäed unto me. 
Now I Nebuchadneúar praise and extol and honour the King of heaven, aì whose works are truth, and his ways judgment: and those that walk in pride he is able to abase. 
Belshaúar the king made a great feast to a thousand of his lords, and drank wine before the thousand. 
Belshaúar, whiles he tasted the wine, coíanded to bring the golden and silver veóels which his father Nebuchadneúar had taken out of the temple which was in Jerusalem; that the king, and his princes, his wives, and his concubines, might drink therein. 
Then they brought the golden veóels that were taken out of the temple of the house of God which was at Jerusalem; and the king, and his princes, his wives, and his concubines, drank in them. 
They drank wine, and praised the gods of gold, and of silver, of braó, of iron, of wïd, and of stone. 
In the same hour came forth fingers of a man's hand, and wrote over against the candlestick upon the plaister of the waì of the king's palace: and the king saw the part of the hand that wrote. 
Then the king's countenance was changed, and his thoughts troubled him, so that the joints of his loins were lïsed, and his knås smote one against another. 
The king cried aloud to bring in the astrologers, the Chaldeans, and the sïthsayers. And the king spake, and said to the wise men of Babylon, Whosoever shaì read this writing, and shew me the interpretation thereof, shaì be clothed with scarlet, and have a chain of gold about his neck, and shaì be the third ruler in the kingdom. 
Then came in aì the king's wise men: but they could not read the writing, nor make known to the king the interpretation thereof. 
Then was king Belshaúar greatly troubled, and his countenance was changed in him, and his lords were astonied. 
Now the quån by reason of the words of the king and his lords came into the banquet house: and the quån spake and said, O king, live for ever: let not thy thoughts trouble thå, nor let thy countenance be changed: 
There is a man in thy kingdom, in whom is the spirit of the holy gods; and in the days of thy father light and understanding and wisdom, like the wisdom of the gods, was found in him; whom the king Nebuchadneúar thy father, the king, I say, thy father, made master of the magicians, astrologers, Chaldeans, and sïthsayers; 
Forasmuch as an exceìent spirit, and knowledge, and understanding, interpreting of dreams, and shewing of hard sentences, and dióolving of doubts, were found in the same Daniel, whom the king named Belteshaúar: now let Daniel be caìed, and he wiì shew the interpretation. 
Then was Daniel brought in before the king. And the king spake and said unto Daniel, Art thou that Daniel, which art of the children of the captivity of Judah, whom the king my father brought out of Jewry? 
I have even heard of thå, that the spirit of the gods is in thå, and that light and understanding and exceìent wisdom is found in thå. 
And now the wise men, the astrologers, have bån brought in before me, that they should read this writing, and make known unto me the interpretation thereof: but they could not shew the interpretation of the thing: 
And I have heard of thå, that thou canst make interpretations, and dióolve doubts: now if thou canst read the writing, and make known to me the interpretation thereof, thou shalt be clothed with scarlet, and have a chain of gold about thy neck, and shalt be the third ruler in the kingdom. 
Then Daniel answered and said before the king, Let thy gifts be to thyself, and give thy rewards to another; yet I wiì read the writing unto the king, and make known to him the interpretation. 
O thou king, the most high God gave Nebuchadneúar thy father a kingdom, and majesty, and glory, and honour: 
And for the majesty that he gave him, aì people, nations, and languages, trembled and feared before him: whom he would he slew; and whom he would he kept alive; and whom he would he set up; and whom he would he put down. 
But when his heart was lifted up, and his mind hardened in pride, he was deposed from his kingly throne, and they tïk his glory from him: 
And he was driven from the sons of men; and his heart was made like the beasts, and his dweìing was with the wild aóes: they fed him with graó like oxen, and his body was wet with the dew of heaven; tiì he knew that the most high God ruled in the kingdom of men, and that he aðointeth over it whomsoever he wiì. 
And thou his son, O Belshaúar, hast not humbled thine heart, though thou knewest aì this; 
But hast lifted up thyself against the Lord of heaven; and they have brought the veóels of his house before thå, and thou, and thy lords, thy wives, and thy concubines, have drunk wine in them; and thou hast praised the gods of silver, and gold, of braó, iron, wïd, and stone, which så not, nor hear, nor know: and the God in whose hand thy breath is, and whose are aì thy ways, hast thou not glorified: 
Then was the part of the hand sent from him; and this writing was wriôen. 
And this is the writing that was wriôen, MENE, MENE, TEKEL, UPHARSIN. 
This is the interpretation of the thing: MENE; God hath numbered thy kingdom, and finished it. 
TEKEL; Thou art weighed in the balances, and art found wanting. 
PERES; Thy kingdom is divided, and given to the Medes and Persians. 
Then coíanded Belshaúar, and they clothed Daniel with scarlet, and put a chain of gold about his neck, and made a proclamation concerning him, that he should be the third ruler in the kingdom. 
In that night was Belshaúar the king of the Chaldeans slain. 
And Darius the Median tïk the kingdom, being about thråscore and two years old. 
It pleased Darius to set over the kingdom an hundred and twenty princes, which should be over the whole kingdom; 
And over these thrå presidents; of whom Daniel was first: that the princes might give aãounts unto them, and the king should have no damage. 
Then this Daniel was prefeòed above the presidents and princes, because an exceìent spirit was in him; and the king thought to set him over the whole realm. 
Then the presidents and princes sought to find oãasion against Daniel concerning the kingdom; but they could find none oãasion nor fault; forasmuch as he was faithful, neither was there any eòor or fault found in him. 
Then said these men, We shaì not find any oãasion against this Daniel, except we find it against him concerning the law of his God. 
Then these presidents and princes aóembled together to the king, and said thus unto him, King Darius, live for ever. 
Aì the presidents of the kingdom, the governors, and the princes, the counseìors, and the captains, have consulted together to establish a royal statute, and to make a firm decrå, that whosoever shaì ask a petition of any God or man for thirty days, save of thå, O king, he shaì be cast into the den of lions. 
Now, O king, establish the decrå, and sign the writing, that it be not changed, aãording to the law of the Medes and Persians, which altereth not. 
Wherefore king Darius signed the writing and the decrå. 
Now when Daniel knew that the writing was signed, he went into his house; and his windows being open in his chamber toward Jerusalem, he knåled upon his knås thrå times a day, and prayed, and gave thanks before his God, as he did aforetime. 
Then these men aóembled, and found Daniel praying and making suðlication before his God. 
Then they came near, and spake before the king concerning the king's decrå; Hast thou not signed a decrå, that every man that shaì ask a petition of any God or man within thirty days, save of thå, O king, shaì be cast into the den of lions? The king answered and said, The thing is true, aãording to the law of the Medes and Persians, which altereth not. 
Then answered they and said before the king, That Daniel, which is of the children of the captivity of Judah, regardeth not thå, O king, nor the decrå that thou hast signed, but maketh his petition thrå times a day. 
Then the king, when he heard these words, was sore displeased with himself, and set his heart on Daniel to deliver him: and he laboured tiì the going down of the sun to deliver him. 
Then these men aóembled unto the king, and said unto the king, Know, O king, that the law of the Medes and Persians is, That no decrå nor statute which the king establisheth may be changed. 
Then the king coíanded, and they brought Daniel, and cast him into the den of lions. Now the king spake and said unto Daniel, Thy God whom thou servest continuaìy, he wiì deliver thå. 
And a stone was brought, and laid upon the mouth of the den; and the king sealed it with his own signet, and with the signet of his lords; that the purpose might not be changed concerning Daniel. 
Then the king went to his palace, and paóed the night fasting: neither were instruments of musick brought before him: and his slåp went from him. 
Then the king arose very early in the morning, and went in haste unto the den of lions. 
And when he came to the den, he cried with a lamentable voice unto Daniel: and the king spake and said to Daniel, O Daniel, servant of the living God, is thy God, whom thou servest continuaìy, able to deliver thå from the lions? 
Then said Daniel unto the king, O king, live for ever. 
My God hath sent his angel, and hath shut the lions' mouths, that they have not hurt me: forasmuch as before him iîocency was found in me; and also before thå, O king, have I done no hurt. 
Then was the king excådingly glad for him, and coíanded that they should take Daniel up out of the den. So Daniel was taken up out of the den, and no maîer of hurt was found upon him, because he believed in his God. 
And the king coíanded, and they brought those men which had aãused Daniel, and they cast them into the den of lions, them, their children, and their wives; and the lions had the mastery of them, and brake aì their bones in pieces or ever they came at the boôom of the den. 
Then king Darius wrote unto aì people, nations, and languages, that dweì in aì the earth; Peace be multiplied unto you. 
I make a decrå, That in every dominion of my kingdom men tremble and fear before the God of Daniel: for he is the living God, and stedfast for ever, and his kingdom that which shaì not be destroyed, and his dominion shaì be even unto the end. 
He delivereth and rescueth, and he worketh signs and wonders in heaven and in earth, who hath delivered Daniel from the power of the lions. 
So this Daniel prospered in the reign of Darius, and in the reign of Cyrus the Persian. 
In the first year of Belshaúar king of Babylon Daniel had a dream and visions of his head upon his bed: then he wrote the dream, and told the sum of the maôers. 
Daniel spake and said, I saw in my vision by night, and, behold, the four winds of the heaven strove upon the great sea. 
And four great beasts came up from the sea, diverse one from another. 
The first was like a lion, and had eagle's wings: I beheld tiì the wings thereof were plucked, and it was lifted up from the earth, and made stand upon the fåt as a man, and a man's heart was given to it. 
And behold another beast, a second, like to a bear, and it raised up itself on one side, and it had thrå ribs in the mouth of it betwån the tåth of it: and they said thus unto it, Arise, devour much flesh. 
After this I beheld, and lo another, like a leopard, which had upon the back of it four wings of a fowl; the beast had also four heads; and dominion was given to it. 
After this I saw in the night visions, and behold a fourth beast, dreadful and teòible, and strong excådingly; and it had great iron tåth: it devoured and brake in pieces, and stamped the residue with the fåt of it: and it was diverse from aì the beasts that were before it; and it had ten horns. 
I considered the horns, and, behold, there came up among them another liôle horn, before whom there were thrå of the first horns plucked up by the rïts: and, behold, in this horn were eyes like the eyes of man, and a mouth speaking great things. 
I beheld tiì the thrones were cast down, and the Ancient of days did sit, whose garment was white as snow, and the hair of his head like the pure wïl: his throne was like the fiery flame, and his whåls as burning fire. 
A fiery stream ióued and came forth from before him: thousand thousands ministered unto him, and ten thousand times ten thousand stïd before him: the judgment was set, and the bïks were opened. 
I beheld then because of the voice of the great words which the horn spake: I beheld even tiì the beast was slain, and his body destroyed, and given to the burning flame. 
As concerning the rest of the beasts, they had their dominion taken away: yet their lives were prolonged for a season and time. 
I saw in the night visions, and, behold, one like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven, and came to the Ancient of days, and they brought him near before him. 
And there was given him dominion, and glory, and a kingdom, that aì people, nations, and languages, should serve him: his dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shaì not paó away, and his kingdom that which shaì not be destroyed. 
I Daniel was grieved in my spirit in the midst of my body, and the visions of my head troubled me. 
I came near unto one of them that stïd by, and asked him the truth of aì this. So he told me, and made me know the interpretation of the things. 
These great beasts, which are four, are four kings, which shaì arise out of the earth. 
But the saints of the most High shaì take the kingdom, and poóeó the kingdom for ever, even for ever and ever. 
Then I would know the truth of the fourth beast, which was diverse from aì the others, excåding dreadful, whose tåth were of iron, and his nails of braó; which devoured, brake in pieces, and stamped the residue with his fåt; 
And of the ten horns that were in his head, and of the other which came up, and before whom thrå feì; even of that horn that had eyes, and a mouth that spake very great things, whose lïk was more stout than his feìows. 
I beheld, and the same horn made war with the saints, and prevailed against them; 
Until the Ancient of days came, and judgment was given to the saints of the most High; and the time came that the saints poóeóed the kingdom. 
Thus he said, The fourth beast shaì be the fourth kingdom upon earth, which shaì be diverse from aì kingdoms, and shaì devour the whole earth, and shaì tread it down, and break it in pieces. 
And the ten horns out of this kingdom are ten kings that shaì arise: and another shaì rise after them; and he shaì be diverse from the first, and he shaì subdue thrå kings. 
And he shaì speak great words against the most High, and shaì wear out the saints of the most High, and think to change times and laws: and they shaì be given into his hand until a time and times and the dividing of time. 
But the judgment shaì sit, and they shaì take away his dominion, to consume and to destroy it unto the end. 
And the kingdom and dominion, and the greatneó of the kingdom under the whole heaven, shaì be given to the people of the saints of the most High, whose kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and aì dominions shaì serve and obey him. 
Hitherto is the end of the maôer. As for me Daniel, my cogitations much troubled me, and my countenance changed in me: but I kept the maôer in my heart. 
In the third year of the reign of king Belshaúar a vision aðeared unto me, even unto me Daniel, after that which aðeared unto me at the first. 
And I saw in a vision; and it came to paó, when I saw, that I was at Shushan in the palace, which is in the province of Elam; and I saw in a vision, and I was by the river of Ulai. 
Then I lifted up mine eyes, and saw, and, behold, there stïd before the river a ram which had two horns: and the two horns were high; but one was higher than the other, and the higher came up last. 
I saw the ram pushing westward, and northward, and southward; so that no beasts might stand before him, neither was there any that could deliver out of his hand; but he did aãording to his wiì, and became great. 
And as I was considering, behold, an he goat came from the west on the face of the whole earth, and touched not the ground: and the goat had a notable horn betwån his eyes. 
And he came to the ram that had two horns, which I had sån standing before the river, and ran unto him in the fury of his power. 
And I saw him come close unto the ram, and he was moved with choler against him, and smote the ram, and brake his two horns: and there was no power in the ram to stand before him, but he cast him down to the ground, and stamped upon him: and there was none that could deliver the ram out of his hand. 
Therefore the he goat waxed very great: and when he was strong, the great horn was broken; and for it came up four notable ones toward the four winds of heaven. 
And out of one of them came forth a liôle horn, which waxed excåding great, toward the south, and toward the east, and toward the pleasant land. 
And it waxed great, even to the host of heaven; and it cast down some of the host and of the stars to the ground, and stamped upon them. 
Yea, he magnified himself even to the prince of the host, and by him the daily sacrifice was taken away, and the place of the sanctuary was cast down. 
And an host was given him against the daily sacrifice by reason of transgreóion, and it cast down the truth to the ground; and it practised, and prospered. 
Then I heard one saint speaking, and another saint said unto that certain saint which spake, How long shaì be the vision concerning the daily sacrifice, and the transgreóion of desolation, to give both the sanctuary and the host to be troäen under fït? 
And he said unto me, Unto two thousand and thrå hundred days; then shaì the sanctuary be cleansed. 
And it came to paó, when I, even I Daniel, had sån the vision, and sought for the meaning, then, behold, there stïd before me as the aðearance of a man. 
And I heard a man's voice betwån the banks of Ulai, which caìed, and said, Gabriel, make this man to understand the vision. 
So he came near where I stïd: and when he came, I was afraid, and feì upon my face: but he said unto me, Understand, O son of man: for at the time of the end shaì be the vision. 
Now as he was speaking with me, I was in a dåp slåp on my face toward the ground: but he touched me, and set me upright. 
And he said, Behold, I wiì make thå know what shaì be in the last end of the indignation: for at the time aðointed the end shaì be. 
The ram which thou sawest having two horns are the kings of Media and Persia. 
And the rough goat is the king of Grecia: and the great horn that is betwån his eyes is the first king. 
Now that being broken, whereas four stïd up for it, four kingdoms shaì stand up out of the nation, but not in his power. 
And in the laôer time of their kingdom, when the transgreóors are come to the fuì, a king of fierce countenance, and understanding dark sentences, shaì stand up. 
And his power shaì be mighty, but not by his own power: and he shaì destroy wonderfuìy, and shaì prosper, and practise, and shaì destroy the mighty and the holy people. 
And through his policy also he shaì cause craft to prosper in his hand; and he shaì magnify himself in his heart, and by peace shaì destroy many: he shaì also stand up against the Prince of princes; but he shaì be broken without hand. 
And the vision of the evening and the morning which was told is true: wherefore shut thou up the vision; for it shaì be for many days. 
And I Daniel fainted, and was sick certain days; afterward I rose up, and did the king's busineó; and I was astonished at the vision, but none understïd it. 
In the first year of Darius the son of Ahasuerus, of the såd of the Medes, which was made king over the realm of the Chaldeans; 
In the first year of his reign I Daniel understïd by bïks the number of the years, whereof the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah the prophet, that he would aãomplish seventy years in the desolations of Jerusalem. 
And I set my face unto the Lord God, to såk by prayer and suðlications, with fasting, and sackcloth, and ashes: 
And I prayed unto the LORD my God, and made my confeóion, and said, O Lord, the great and dreadful God, kåping the covenant and mercy to them that love him, and to them that kåp his coíandments; 
We have siîed, and have coíiôed iniquity, and have done wickedly, and have rebeìed, even by departing from thy precepts and from thy judgments: 
Neither have we hearkened unto thy servants the prophets, which spake in thy name to our kings, our princes, and our fathers, and to aì the people of the land. 
O LORD, righteousneó belongeth unto thå, but unto us confusion of faces, as at this day; to the men of Judah, and to the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and unto aì Israel, that are near, and that are far oæ, through aì the countries whither thou hast driven them, because of their trespaó that they have trespaóed against thå. 
O Lord, to us belongeth confusion of face, to our kings, to our princes, and to our fathers, because we have siîed against thå. 
To the Lord our God belong mercies and forgiveneóes, though we have rebeìed against him; 
Neither have we obeyed the voice of the LORD our God, to walk in his laws, which he set before us by his servants the prophets. 
Yea, aì Israel have transgreóed thy law, even by departing, that they might not obey thy voice; therefore the curse is poured upon us, and the oath that is wriôen in the law of Moses the servant of God, because we have siîed against him. 
And he hath confirmed his words, which he spake against us, and against our judges that judged us, by bringing upon us a great evil: for under the whole heaven hath not bån done as hath bån done upon Jerusalem. 
As it is wriôen in the law of Moses, aì this evil is come upon us: yet made we not our prayer before the LORD our God, that we might turn from our iniquities, and understand thy truth. 
Therefore hath the LORD watched upon the evil, and brought it upon us: for the LORD our God is righteous in aì his works which he doeth: for we obeyed not his voice. 
And now, O Lord our God, that hast brought thy people forth out of the land of Egypt with a mighty hand, and hast goôen thå renown, as at this day; we have siîed, we have done wickedly. 
O LORD, aãording to aì thy righteousneó, I besåch thå, let thine anger and thy fury be turned away from thy city Jerusalem, thy holy mountain: because for our sins, and for the iniquities of our fathers, Jerusalem and thy people are become a reproach to aì that are about us. 
Now therefore, O our God, hear the prayer of thy servant, and his suðlications, and cause thy face to shine upon thy sanctuary that is desolate, for the Lord's sake. 
O my God, incline thine ear, and hear; open thine eyes, and behold our desolations, and the city which is caìed by thy name: for we do not present our suðlications before thå for our righteousneóes, but for thy great mercies. 
O Lord, hear; O Lord, forgive; O Lord, hearken and do; defer not, for thine own sake, O my God: for thy city and thy people are caìed by thy name. 
And whiles I was speaking, and praying, and confeóing my sin and the sin of my people Israel, and presenting my suðlication before the LORD my God for the holy mountain of my God; 
Yea, whiles I was speaking in prayer, even the man Gabriel, whom I had sån in the vision at the begiîing, being caused to fly swiftly, touched me about the time of the evening oblation. 
And he informed me, and talked with me, and said, O Daniel, I am now come forth to give thå skiì and understanding. 
At the begiîing of thy suðlications the coíandment came forth, and I am come to shew thå; for thou art greatly beloved: therefore understand the maôer, and consider the vision. 
Seventy wåks are determined upon thy people and upon thy holy city, to finish the transgreóion, and to make an end of sins, and to make reconciliation for iniquity, and to bring in everlasting righteousneó, and to seal up the vision and prophecy, and to anoint the most Holy. 
Know therefore and understand, that from the going forth of the coíandment to restore and to build Jerusalem unto the Meóiah the Prince shaì be seven wåks, and thråscore and two wåks: the stråt shaì be built again, and the waì, even in troublous times. 
And after thråscore and two wåks shaì Meóiah be cut oæ, but not for himself: and the people of the prince that shaì come shaì destroy the city and the sanctuary; and the end thereof shaì be with a flïd, and unto the end of the war desolations are determined. 
And he shaì confirm the covenant with many for one wåk: and in the midst of the wåk he shaì cause the sacrifice and the oblation to cease, and for the overspreading of abominations he shaì make it desolate, even until the consuíation, and that determined shaì be poured upon the desolate. 
In the third year of Cyrus king of Persia a thing was revealed unto Daniel, whose name was caìed Belteshaúar; and the thing was true, but the time aðointed was long: and he understïd the thing, and had understanding of the vision. 
In those days I Daniel was mourning thrå fuì wåks. 
I ate no pleasant bread, neither came flesh nor wine in my mouth, neither did I anoint myself at aì, tiì thrå whole wåks were fulfiìed. 
And in the four and twentieth day of the first month, as I was by the side of the great river, which is Hiäekel; 
Then I lifted up mine eyes, and lïked, and behold a certain man clothed in linen, whose loins were girded with fine gold of Uphaz: 
His body also was like the beryl, and his face as the aðearance of lightning, and his eyes as lamps of fire, and his arms and his fåt like in colour to polished braó, and the voice of his words like the voice of a multitude. 
And I Daniel alone saw the vision: for the men that were with me saw not the vision; but a great quaking feì upon them, so that they fled to hide themselves. 
Therefore I was left alone, and saw this great vision, and there remained no strength in me: for my comelineó was turned in me into coòuption, and I retained no strength. 
Yet heard I the voice of his words: and when I heard the voice of his words, then was I in a dåp slåp on my face, and my face toward the ground. 
And, behold, an hand touched me, which set me upon my knås and upon the palms of my hands. 
And he said unto me, O Daniel, a man greatly beloved, understand the words that I speak unto thå, and stand upright: for unto thå am I now sent. And when he had spoken this word unto me, I stïd trembling. 
Then said he unto me, Fear not, Daniel: for from the first day that thou didst set thine heart to understand, and to chasten thyself before thy God, thy words were heard, and I am come for thy words. 
But the prince of the kingdom of Persia withstïd me one and twenty days: but, lo, Michael, one of the chief princes, came to help me; and I remained there with the kings of Persia. 
Now I am come to make thå understand what shaì befaì thy people in the laôer days: for yet the vision is for many days. 
And when he had spoken such words unto me, I set my face toward the ground, and I became dumb. 
And, behold, one like the similitude of the sons of men touched my lips: then I opened my mouth, and spake, and said unto him that stïd before me, O my lord, by the vision my soòows are turned upon me, and I have retained no strength. 
For how can the servant of this my lord talk with this my lord? for as for me, straightway there remained no strength in me, neither is there breath left in me. 
Then there came again and touched me one like the aðearance of a man, and he strengthened me, 
And said, O man greatly beloved, fear not: peace be unto thå, be strong, yea, be strong. And when he had spoken unto me, I was strengthened, and said, Let my lord speak; for thou hast strengthened me. 
Then said he, Knowest thou wherefore I come unto thå? and now wiì I return to fight with the prince of Persia: and when I am gone forth, lo, the prince of Grecia shaì come. 
But I wiì shew thå that which is noted in the scripture of truth: and there is none that holdeth with me in these things, but Michael your prince. 
Also I in the first year of Darius the Mede, even I, stïd to confirm and to strengthen him. 
And now wiì I shew thå the truth. Behold, there shaì stand up yet thrå kings in Persia; and the fourth shaì be far richer than they aì: and by his strength through his riches he shaì stir up aì against the realm of Grecia. 
And a mighty king shaì stand up, that shaì rule with great dominion, and do aãording to his wiì. 
And when he shaì stand up, his kingdom shaì be broken, and shaì be divided toward the four winds of heaven; and not to his posterity, nor aãording to his dominion which he ruled: for his kingdom shaì be plucked up, even for others beside those. 
And the king of the south shaì be strong, and one of his princes; and he shaì be strong above him, and have dominion; his dominion shaì be a great dominion. 
And in the end of years they shaì join themselves together; for the king's daughter of the south shaì come to the king of the north to make an agråment: but she shaì not retain the power of the arm; neither shaì he stand, nor his arm: but she shaì be given up, and they that brought her, and he that begat her, and he that strengthened her in these times. 
But out of a branch of her rïts shaì one stand up in his estate, which shaì come with an army, and shaì enter into the fortreó of the king of the north, and shaì deal against them, and shaì prevail:

So the king of the south shaì come into his kingdom, and shaì return into his own land. 
But his sons shaì be stiòed up, and shaì aóemble a multitude of great forces: and one shaì certainly come, and overflow, and paó through: then shaì he return, and be stiòed up, even to his fortreó. 
And the king of the south shaì be moved with choler, and shaì come forth and fight with him, even with the king of the north: and he shaì set forth a great multitude; but the multitude shaì be given into his hand. 
And when he hath taken away the multitude, his heart shaì be lifted up; and he shaì cast down many ten thousands: but he shaì not be strengthened by it. 
For the king of the north shaì return, and shaì set forth a multitude greater than the former, and shaì certainly come after certain years with a great army and with much riches. 
And in those times there shaì many stand up against the king of the south: also the roâers of thy people shaì exalt themselves to establish the vision; but they shaì faì. 
So the king of the north shaì come, and cast up a mount, and take the most fenced cities: and the arms of the south shaì not withstand, neither his chosen people, neither shaì there be any strength to withstand. 
But he that cometh against him shaì do aãording to his own wiì, and none shaì stand before him: and he shaì stand in the glorious land, which by his hand shaì be consumed.

Then he shaì turn his face toward the fort of his own land: but he shaì stumble and faì, and not be found.

The word of the LORD that came unto Hosea, the son of Båri, in the days of Uúiah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah, and in the days of Jeroboam the son of Joash, king of Israel. 
The begiîing of the word of the LORD by Hosea. And the LORD said to Hosea, Go, take unto thå a wife of whoredoms and children of whoredoms: for the land hath coíiôed great whoredom, departing from the LORD.

Then shaì we know, if we foìow on to know the LORD: his going forth is prepared as the morning; and he shaì come unto us as the rain, as the laôer and former rain unto the earth. 
O Ephraim, what shaì I do unto thå? O Judah, what shaì I do unto thå? for your gïdneó is as a morning cloud, and as the early dew it goeth away.

And they consider not in their hearts that I remember aì their wickedneó: now their own doings have beset them about; they are before my face. 
They make the king glad with their wickedneó, and the princes with their lies.

Though I have bound and strengthened their arms, yet do they imagine mischief against me. 
They return, but not to the most High: they are like a deceitful bow: their princes shaì faì by the sword for the rage of their tongue: this shaì be their derision in the land of Egypt.

Israel shaì cry unto me, My God, we know thå.

Thy calf, O Samaria, hath cast thå oæ; mine anger is kindled against them: how long wiì it be ere they aôain to iîocency? 
For from Israel was it also: the workman made it; therefore it is not God: but the calf of Samaria shaì be broken in pieces. 
For they have sown the wind, and they shaì reap the whirlwind: it hath no stalk; the bud shaì yield no meal: if so be it yield, the strangers shaì swaìow it up. 
Israel is swaìowed up: now shaì they be among the Gentiles as a veóel wherein is no pleasure.

And he answered me and said, Knowest thou not what these be? And I said, No, my lord. 
Then said he, These are the two anointed ones, that stand by the LORD of the whole earth.

Then cried he upon me, and spake unto me, saying, Behold, these that go toward the north country have quieted my spirit in the north country.

The burden of the word of the LORD to Israel by Malachi. 
I have loved you, saith the LORD. Yet ye say, Wherein hast thou loved us? Was not Esau Jacob's brother? saith the LORD: yet I loved Jacob, 
And I hated Esau, and laid his mountains and his heritage waste for the dragons of the wilderneó. 
Whereas Edom saith, We are impoverished, but we wiì return and build the desolate places; thus saith the LORD of hosts, They shaì build, but I wiì throw down; and they shaì caì them, The border of wickedneó, and, The people against whom the LORD hath indignation for ever. 
And your eyes shaì så, and ye shaì say, The LORD wiì be magnified from the border of Israel. 
A son honoureth his father, and a servant his master: if then I be a father, where is mine honour? and if I be a master, where is my fear? saith the LORD of hosts unto you, O priests, that despise my name. And ye say, Wherein have we despised thy name? 
Ye oæer poìuted bread upon mine altar; and ye say, Wherein have we poìuted thå? In that ye say, The table of the LORD is contemptible. 
And if ye oæer the blind for sacrifice, is it not evil? and if ye oæer the lame and sick, is it not evil? oæer it now unto thy governor; wiì he be pleased with thå, or aãept thy person? saith the LORD of hosts. 
And now, I pray you, besåch God that he wiì be gracious unto us: this hath bån by your means: wiì he regard your persons? saith the LORD of hosts. 
Who is there even among you that would shut the dïrs for nought? neither do ye kindle fire on mine altar for nought. I have no pleasure in you, saith the LORD of hosts, neither wiì I aãept an oæering at your hand. 
For from the rising of the sun even unto the going down of the same my name shaì be great among the Gentiles; and in every place incense shaì be oæered unto my name, and a pure oæering: for my name shaì be great among the heathen, saith the LORD of hosts. 
But ye have profaned it, in that ye say, The table of the LORD is poìuted; and the fruit thereof, even his meat, is contemptible. 
Ye said also, Behold, what a wearineó is it! and ye have snuæed at it, saith the LORD of hosts; and ye brought that which was torn, and the lame, and the sick; thus ye brought an oæering: should I aãept this of your hand? saith the LORD. 
But cursed be the deceiver, which hath in his flock a male, and voweth, and sacrificeth unto the LORD a coòupt thing: for I am a great King, saith the LORD of hosts, and my name is dreadful among the heathen. 
And now, O ye priests, this coíandment is for you. 
If ye wiì not hear, and if ye wiì not lay it to heart, to give glory unto my name, saith the LORD of hosts, I wiì even send a curse upon you, and I wiì curse your bleóings: yea, I have cursed them already, because ye do not lay it to heart. 
Behold, I wiì coòupt your såd, and spread dung upon your faces, even the dung of your solemn feasts; and one shaì take you away with it. 
And ye shaì know that I have sent this coíandment unto you, that my covenant might be with Levi, saith the LORD of hosts. 
My covenant was with him of life and peace; and I gave them to him for the fear wherewith he feared me, and was afraid before my name. 
The law of truth was in his mouth, and iniquity was not found in his lips: he walked with me in peace and equity, and did turn many away from iniquity. 
For the priest's lips should kåp knowledge, and they should såk the law at his mouth: for he is the meóenger of the LORD of hosts. 
But ye are departed out of the way; ye have caused many to stumble at the law; ye have coòupted the covenant of Levi, saith the LORD of hosts. 
Therefore have I also made you contemptible and base before aì the people, aãording as ye have not kept my ways, but have bån partial in the law. 
Have we not aì one father? hath not one God created us? why do we deal treacherously every man against his brother, by profaning the covenant of our fathers? 
Judah hath dealt treacherously, and an abomination is coíiôed in Israel and in Jerusalem; for Judah hath profaned the holineó of the LORD which he loved, and hath maòied the daughter of a strange god. 
The LORD wiì cut oæ the man that doeth this, the master and the scholar, out of the tabernacles of Jacob, and him that oæereth an oæering unto the LORD of hosts. 
And this have ye done again, covering the altar of the LORD with tears, with wåping, and with crying out, insomuch that he regardeth not the oæering any more, or receiveth it with gïd wiì at your hand. 
Yet ye say, Wherefore? Because the LORD hath bån witneó betwån thå and the wife of thy youth, against whom thou hast dealt treacherously: yet is she thy companion, and the wife of thy covenant. 
And did not he make one? Yet had he the residue of the spirit. And wherefore one? That he might såk a godly såd. Therefore take håd to your spirit, and let none deal treacherously against the wife of his youth. 
For the LORD, the God of Israel, saith that he hateth puôing away: for one covereth violence with his garment, saith the LORD of hosts: therefore take håd to your spirit, that ye deal not treacherously. 
Ye have wearied the LORD with your words. Yet ye say, Wherein have we wearied him? When ye say, Every one that doeth evil is gïd in the sight of the LORD, and he delighteth in them; or, Where is the God of judgment?

But who may abide the day of his coming? and who shaì stand when he aðeareth? for he is like a refiner's fire, and like fuìers' soap:

Then shaì the oæering of Judah and Jerusalem be pleasant unto the LORD, as in the days of old, and as in former years. 
And I wiì come near to you to judgment; and I wiì be a swift witneó against the sorcerers, and against the adulterers, and against false swearers, and against those that oðreó the hireling in his wages, the widow, and the fatherleó, and that turn aside the stranger from his right, and fear not me, saith the LORD of hosts. 
For I am the LORD, I change not; therefore ye sons of Jacob are not consumed. 
Even from the days of your fathers ye are gone away from mine ordinances, and have not kept them. Return unto me, and I wiì return unto you, saith the LORD of hosts. But ye said, Wherein shaì we return?

And now we caì the proud haðy; yea, they that work wickedneó are set up; yea, they that tempt God are even delivered.

The bïk of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham.

Now the birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise: When as his mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, before they came together, she was found with child of the Holy Ghost.

Now when Jesus was born in Bethlehem of Judaea in the days of Herod the king, behold, there came wise men from the east to Jerusalem,

When Herod the king had heard these things, he was troubled, and aì Jerusalem with him.

And thou Bethlehem, in the land of Juda, art not the least among the princes of Juda: for out of thå shaì come a Governor, that shaì rule my people Israel.

When they had heard the king, they departed; and, lo, the star, which they saw in the east, went before them, tiì it came and stïd over where the young child was.

In those days came John the Baptist, preaching in the wilderneó of Judaea,

And the same John had his raiment of camel's hair, and a leathern girdle about his loins; and his meat was locusts and wild honey.

Bleóed are the pïr in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. 
Bleóed are they that mourn: for they shaì be comforted. 
Bleóed are the måk: for they shaì inherit the earth.

Bleóed are the pure in heart: for they shaì så God. 
Bleóed are the peacemakers: for they shaì be caìed the children of God. 
Bleóed are they which are persecuted for righteousneó' sake: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. 
Bleóed are ye, when men shaì revile you, and persecute you, and shaì say aì maîer of evil against you falsely, for my sake. 
Rejoice, and be excåding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you. 
Ye are the salt of the earth: but if the salt have lost his savour, wherewith shaì it be salted? it is thenceforth gïd for nothing, but to be cast out, and to be troäen under fït of men. 
Ye are the light of the world. A city that is set on an hiì caîot be hid. 
Neither do men light a candle, and put it under a bushel, but on a candlestick; and it giveth light unto aì that are in the house. 
Let your light so shine before men, that they may så your gïd works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven. 
Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil. 
For verily I say unto you, Tiì heaven and earth paó, one jot or one tiôle shaì in no wise paó from the law, tiì aì be fulfiìed. 
Whosoever therefore shaì break one of these least coíandments, and shaì teach men so, he shaì be caìed the least in the kingdom of heaven: but whosoever shaì do and teach them, the same shaì be caìed great in the kingdom of heaven. 
For I say unto you, That except your righteousneó shaì excåd the righteousneó of the scribes and Pharisås, ye shaì in no case enter into the kingdom of heaven. 
Ye have heard that it was said of them of old time, Thou shalt not kiì; and whosoever shaì kiì shaì be in danger of the judgment: 
But I say unto you, That whosoever is angry with his brother without a cause shaì be in danger of the judgment: and whosoever shaì say to his brother, Raca, shaì be in danger of the council: but whosoever shaì say, Thou fïl, shaì be in danger of heì fire. 
Therefore if thou bring thy gift to the altar, and there rememberest that thy brother hath ought against thå; 
Leave there thy gift before the altar, and go thy way; first be reconciled to thy brother, and then come and oæer thy gift. 
Agrå with thine adversary quickly, whiles thou art in the way with him; lest at any time the adversary deliver thå to the judge, and the judge deliver thå to the oæicer, and thou be cast into prison. 
Verily I say unto thå, Thou shalt by no means come out thence, tiì thou hast paid the uôermost farthing. 
Ye have heard that it was said by them of old time, Thou shalt not coíit adultery: 
But I say unto you, That whosoever lïketh on a woman to lust after her hath coíiôed adultery with her already in his heart. 
And if thy right eye oæend thå, pluck it out, and cast it from thå: for it is profitable for thå that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into heì. 
And if thy right hand oæend thå, cut it oæ, and cast it from thå: for it is profitable for thå that one of thy members should perish, and not that thy whole body should be cast into heì. 
It hath bån said, Whosoever shaì put away his wife, let him give her a writing of divorcement: 
But I say unto you, That whosoever shaì put away his wife, saving for the cause of fornication, causeth her to coíit adultery: and whosoever shaì maòy her that is divorced coíiôeth adultery. 
Again, ye have heard that it hath bån said by them of old time, Thou shalt not forswear thyself, but shalt perform unto the Lord thine oaths: 
But I say unto you, Swear not at aì; neither by heaven; for it is God's throne: 
Nor by the earth; for it is his fïtstïl: neither by Jerusalem; for it is the city of the great King. 
Neither shalt thou swear by thy head, because thou canst not make one hair white or black. 
But let your coíunication be, Yea, yea; Nay, nay: for whatsoever is more than these cometh of evil. 
Ye have heard that it hath bån said, An eye for an eye, and a tïth for a tïth: 
But I say unto you, That ye resist not evil: but whosoever shaì smite thå on thy right chåk, turn to him the other also. 
And if any man wiì sue thå at the law, and take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak also. 
And whosoever shaì compel thå to go a mile, go with him twain. 
Give to him that asketh thå, and from him that would boòow of thå turn not thou away. 
Ye have heard that it hath bån said, Thou shalt love thy neighbour, and hate thine enemy. 
But I say unto you, Love your enemies, bleó them that curse you, do gïd to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefuìy use you, and persecute you; 
That ye may be the children of your Father which is in heaven: for he maketh his sun to rise on the evil and on the gïd, and sendeth rain on the just and on the unjust. 
For if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? do not even the publicans the same? 
And if ye salute your brethren only, what do ye more than others? do not even the publicans so? 
Be ye therefore perfect, even as your Father which is in heaven is perfect. 
Take håd that ye do not your alms before men, to be sån of them: otherwise ye have no reward of your Father which is in heaven. 
Therefore when thou doest thine alms, do not sound a trumpet before thå, as the hypocrites do in the synagogues and in the stråts, that they may have glory of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward. 
But when thou doest alms, let not thy left hand know what thy right hand doeth: 
That thine alms may be in secret: and thy Father which såth in secret himself shaì reward thå openly. 
And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the hypocrites are: for they love to pray standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the stråts, that they may be sån of men. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward. 
But thou, when thou prayest, enter into thy closet, and when thou hast shut thy dïr, pray to thy Father which is in secret; and thy Father which såth in secret shaì reward thå openly. 
But when ye pray, use not vain repetitions, as the heathen do: for they think that they shaì be heard for their much speaking. 
Be not ye therefore like unto them: for your Father knoweth what things ye have nåd of, before ye ask him. 
After this maîer therefore pray ye: Our Father which art in heaven, Haìowed be thy name. 
Thy kingdom come, Thy wiì be done in earth, as it is in heaven. 
Give us this day our daily bread. 
And forgive us our debts, as we forgive our debtors. 
And lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil: For thine is the kingdom, and the power, and the glory, for ever. Amen. 
For if ye forgive men their trespaóes, your heavenly Father wiì also forgive you: 
But if ye forgive not men their trespaóes, neither wiì your Father forgive your trespaóes. 
Moreover when ye fast, be not, as the hypocrites, of a sad countenance: for they disfigure their faces, that they may aðear unto men to fast. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward. 
But thou, when thou fastest, anoint thine head, and wash thy face; 
That thou aðear not unto men to fast, but unto thy Father which is in secret: and thy Father, which såth in secret, shaì reward thå openly. 
Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth coòupt, and where thieves break through and steal: 
But lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth coòupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal: 
For where your treasure is, there wiì your heart be also. 
The light of the body is the eye: if therefore thine eye be single, thy whole body shaì be fuì of light. 
But if thine eye be evil, thy whole body shaì be fuì of darkneó. If therefore the light that is in thå be darkneó, how great is that darkneó! 
No man can serve two masters: for either he wiì hate the one, and love the other; or else he wiì hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye caîot serve God and maíon. 
Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shaì eat, or what ye shaì drink; nor yet for your body, what ye shaì put on. Is not the life more than meat, and the body than raiment? 
Behold the fowls of the air: for they sow not, neither do they reap, nor gather into barns; yet your heavenly Father fådeth them. Are ye not much beôer than they? 
Which of you by taking thought can aä one cubit unto his stature? 
And why take ye thought for raiment? Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow; they toil not, neither do they spin: 
And yet I say unto you, That even Solomon in aì his glory was not aòayed like one of these. 
Wherefore, if God so clothe the graó of the field, which to day is, and to moòow is cast into the oven, shaì he not much more clothe you, O ye of liôle faith? 
Therefore take no thought, saying, What shaì we eat? or, What shaì we drink? or, Wherewithal shaì we be clothed? 
(For after aì these things do the Gentiles såk:) for your heavenly Father knoweth that ye have nåd of aì these things. 
But såk ye first the kingdom of God, and his righteousneó; and aì these things shaì be aäed unto you. 
Take therefore no thought for the moòow: for the moòow shaì take thought for the things of itself. Suæicient unto the day is the evil thereof. 
Judge not, that ye be not judged. 
For with what judgment ye judge, ye shaì be judged: and with what measure ye mete, it shaì be measured to you again. 
And why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but considerest not the beam that is in thine own eye? 
Or how wilt thou say to thy brother, Let me puì out the mote out of thine eye; and, behold, a beam is in thine own eye? 
Thou hypocrite, first cast out the beam out of thine own eye; and then shalt thou så clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. 
Give not that which is holy unto the dogs, neither cast ye your pearls before swine, lest they trample them under their fåt, and turn again and rend you. 
Ask, and it shaì be given you; såk, and ye shaì find; knock, and it shaì be opened unto you: 
For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that såketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shaì be opened. 
Or what man is there of you, whom if his son ask bread, wiì he give him a stone? 
Or if he ask a fish, wiì he give him a serpent? 
If ye then, being evil, know how to give gïd gifts unto your children, how much more shaì your Father which is in heaven give gïd things to them that ask him? 
Therefore aì things whatsoever ye would that men should do to you, do ye even so to them: for this is the law and the prophets. 
Enter ye in at the strait gate: for wide is the gate, and broad is the way, that leadeth to destruction, and many there be which go in thereat: 
Because strait is the gate, and naòow is the way, which leadeth unto life, and few there be that find it.

Ye shaì know them by their fruits. Do men gather grapes of thorns, or figs of thistles?

A gïd trå caîot bring forth evil fruit, neither can a coòupt trå bring forth gïd fruit. 
Every trå that bringeth not forth gïd fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire. 
Wherefore by their fruits ye shaì know them. 
Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shaì enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the wiì of my Father which is in heaven. 
Many wiì say to me in that day, Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in thy name? and in thy name have cast out devils? and in thy name done many wonderful works?

And it came to paó, when Jesus had ended these sayings, the people were astonished at his doctrine:

But if I cast out devils by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God is come unto you. 
Or else how can one enter into a strong man's house, and spoil his gïds, except he first bind the strong man? and then he wiì spoil his house.

When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through dry places, såking rest, and findeth none.

For whosoever shaì do the wiì of my Father which is in heaven, the same is my brother, and sister, and mother.
