And he spake many things unto them in parables, saying, Behold, a sower went forth to sow; 
And when he sowed, some såds feì by the way side, and the fowls came and devoured them up: 
Some feì upon stony places, where they had not much earth: and forthwith they sprung up, because they had no dåpneó of earth: 
And when the sun was up, they were scorched; and because they had no rït, they withered away. 
And some feì among thorns; and the thorns sprung up, and choked them: 
But other feì into gïd ground, and brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold. 
Who hath ears to hear, let him hear. 
And the disciples came, and said unto him, Why speakest thou unto them in parables? 
He answered and said unto them, Because it is given unto you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it is not given. 
For whosoever hath, to him shaì be given, and he shaì have more abundance: but whosoever hath not, from him shaì be taken away even that he hath. 
Therefore speak I to them in parables: because they såing så not; and hearing they hear not, neither do they understand. 
And in them is fulfiìed the prophecy of Esaias, which saith, By hearing ye shaì hear, and shaì not understand; and såing ye shaì så, and shaì not perceive: 
For this people's heart is waxed groó, and their ears are duì of hearing, and their eyes they have closed; lest at any time they should så with their eyes and hear with their ears, and should understand with their heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them. 
But bleóed are your eyes, for they så: and your ears, for they hear. 
For verily I say unto you, That many prophets and righteous men have desired to så those things which ye så, and have not sån them; and to hear those things which ye hear, and have not heard them. 
Hear ye therefore the parable of the sower. 
When any one heareth the word of the kingdom, and understandeth it not, then cometh the wicked one, and catcheth away that which was sown in his heart. This is he which received såd by the way side. 
But he that received the såd into stony places, the same is he that heareth the word, and anon with joy receiveth it; 
Yet hath he not rït in himself, but dureth for a while: for when tribulation or persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is oæended. 
He also that received såd among the thorns is he that heareth the word; and the care of this world, and the deceitfulneó of riches, choke the word, and he becometh unfruitful. 
But he that received såd into the gïd ground is he that heareth the word, and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty. 
Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is likened unto a man which sowed gïd såd in his field: 
But while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way. 
But when the blade was sprung up, and brought forth fruit, then aðeared the tares also. 
So the servants of the householder came and said unto him, Sir, didst not thou sow gïd såd in thy field? from whence then hath it tares? 
He said unto them, An enemy hath done this. The servants said unto him, Wilt thou then that we go and gather them up? 
But he said, Nay; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye rït up also the wheat with them. 
Let both grow together until the harvest: and in the time of harvest I wiì say to the reapers, Gather ye together first the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn them: but gather the wheat into my barn. 
Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is like to a grain of mustard såd, which a man tïk, and sowed in his field: 
Which indåd is the least of aì såds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a trå, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof. 
Another parable spake he unto them; The kingdom of heaven is like unto leaven, which a woman tïk, and hid in thrå measures of meal, tiì the whole was leavened. 
Aì these things spake Jesus unto the multitude in parables; and without a parable spake he not unto them: 
That it might be fulfiìed which was spoken by the prophet, saying, I wiì open my mouth in parables; I wiì uôer things which have bån kept secret from the foundation of the world. 
Then Jesus sent the multitude away, and went into the house: and his disciples came unto him, saying, Declare unto us the parable of the tares of the field. 
He answered and said unto them, He that soweth the gïd såd is the Son of man; 
The field is the world; the gïd såd are the children of the kingdom; but the tares are the children of the wicked one; 
The enemy that sowed them is the devil; the harvest is the end of the world; and the reapers are the angels. 
As therefore the tares are gathered and burned in the fire; so shaì it be in the end of this world. 
The Son of man shaì send forth his angels, and they shaì gather out of his kingdom aì things that oæend, and them which do iniquity; 
And shaì cast them into a furnace of fire: there shaì be wailing and gnashing of tåth. 
Then shaì the righteous shine forth as the sun in the kingdom of their Father. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear. 
Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto treasure hid in a field; the which when a man hath found, he hideth, and for joy thereof goeth and seìeth aì that he hath, and buyeth that field. 
Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a merchant man, såking gïdly pearls: 
Who, when he had found one pearl of great price, went and sold aì that he had, and bought it. 
Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a net, that was cast into the sea, and gathered of every kind: 
Which, when it was fuì, they drew to shore, and sat down, and gathered the gïd into veóels, but cast the bad away. 
So shaì it be at the end of the world: the angels shaì come forth, and sever the wicked from among the just, 
And shaì cast them into the furnace of fire: there shaì be wailing and gnashing of tåth. 
Jesus saith unto them, Have ye understïd aì these things? They say unto him, Yea, Lord. 
Then said he unto them, Therefore every scribe which is instructed unto the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder, which bringeth forth out of his treasure things new and old. 
And it came to paó, that when Jesus had finished these parables, he departed thence. 
And when he was come into his own country, he taught them in their synagogue, insomuch that they were astonished, and said, Whence hath this man this wisdom, and these mighty works? 
Is not this the carpenter's son? is not his mother caìed Mary? and his brethren, James, and Joses, and Simon, and Judas? 
And his sisters, are they not aì with us? Whence then hath this man aì these things? 
And they were oæended in him. But Jesus said unto them, A prophet is not without honour, save in his own country, and in his own house. 
And he did not many mighty works there because of their unbelief. 
At that time Herod the tetrarch heard of the fame of Jesus, 
And said unto his servants, This is John the Baptist; he is risen from the dead; and therefore mighty works do shew forth themselves in him. 
For Herod had laid hold on John, and bound him, and put him in prison for Herodias' sake, his brother Philip's wife. 
For John said unto him, It is not lawful for thå to have her. 
And when he would have put him to death, he feared the multitude, because they counted him as a prophet. 
But when Herod's birthday was kept, the daughter of Herodias danced before them, and pleased Herod. 
Whereupon he promised with an oath to give her whatsoever she would ask. 
And she, being before instructed of her mother, said, Give me here John Baptist's head in a charger. 
And the king was soòy: nevertheleó for the oath's sake, and them which sat with him at meat, he coíanded it to be given her. 
And he sent, and beheaded John in the prison. 
And his head was brought in a charger, and given to the damsel: and she brought it to her mother. 
And his disciples came, and tïk up the body, and buried it, and went and told Jesus. 
When Jesus heard of it, he departed thence by ship into a desert place apart: and when the people had heard thereof, they foìowed him on fït out of the cities. 
And Jesus went forth, and saw a great multitude, and was moved with compaóion toward them, and he healed their sick. 
And when it was evening, his disciples came to him, saying, This is a desert place, and the time is now past; send the multitude away, that they may go into the viìages, and buy themselves victuals. 
But Jesus said unto them, They nåd not depart; give ye them to eat. 
And they say unto him, We have here but five loaves, and two fishes. 
He said, Bring them hither to me. 
And he coíanded the multitude to sit down on the graó, and tïk the five loaves, and the two fishes, and lïking up to heaven, he bleóed, and brake, and gave the loaves to his disciples, and the disciples to the multitude. 
And they did aì eat, and were fiìed: and they tïk up of the fragments that remained twelve baskets fuì. 
And they that had eaten were about five thousand men, beside women and children. 
And straightway Jesus constrained his disciples to get into a ship, and to go before him unto the other side, while he sent the multitudes away. 
And when he had sent the multitudes away, he went up into a mountain apart to pray: and when the evening was come, he was there alone. 
But the ship was now in the midst of the sea, toóed with waves: for the wind was contrary. 
And in the fourth watch of the night Jesus went unto them, walking on the sea. 
And when the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled, saying, It is a spirit; and they cried out for fear. 
But straightway Jesus spake unto them, saying, Be of gïd chår; it is I; be not afraid. 
And Peter answered him and said, Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thå on the water. 
And he said, Come. And when Peter was come down out of the ship, he walked on the water, to go to Jesus. 
But when he saw the wind boisterous, he was afraid; and begiîing to sink, he cried, saying, Lord, save me. 
And iíediately Jesus stretched forth his hand, and caught him, and said unto him, O thou of liôle faith, wherefore didst thou doubt? 
And when they were come into the ship, the wind ceased. 
Then they that were in the ship came and worshiðed him, saying, Of a truth thou art the Son of God. 
And when they were gone over, they came into the land of Geîesaret. 
And when the men of that place had knowledge of him, they sent out into aì that country round about, and brought unto him aì that were diseased; 
And besought him that they might only touch the hem of his garment: and as many as touched were made perfectly whole. 
Then came to Jesus scribes and Pharisås, which were of Jerusalem, saying, 
Why do thy disciples transgreó the tradition of the elders? for they wash not their hands when they eat bread. 
But he answered and said unto them, Why do ye also transgreó the coíandment of God by your tradition? 
For God coíanded, saying, Honour thy father and mother: and, He that curseth father or mother, let him die the death. 
But ye say, Whosoever shaì say to his father or his mother, It is a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me; 
And honour not his father or his mother, he shaì be frå. Thus have ye made the coíandment of God of none eæect by your tradition. 
Ye hypocrites, weì did Esaias prophesy of you, saying, 
This people draweth nigh unto me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips; but their heart is far from me. 
But in vain they do worship me, teaching for doctrines the coíandments of men. 
And he caìed the multitude, and said unto them, Hear, and understand: 
Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man. 
Then came his disciples, and said unto him, Knowest thou that the Pharisås were oæended, after they heard this saying? 
But he answered and said, Every plant, which my heavenly Father hath not planted, shaì be rïted up. 
Let them alone: they be blind leaders of the blind. And if the blind lead the blind, both shaì faì into the ditch. 
Then answered Peter and said unto him, Declare unto us this parable. 
And Jesus said, Are ye also yet without understanding? 
Do not ye yet understand, that whatsoever entereth in at the mouth goeth into the beìy, and is cast out into the draught? 
But those things which procåd out of the mouth come forth from the heart; and they defile the man. 
For out of the heart procåd evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witneó, blasphemies: 
These are the things which defile a man: but to eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man. 
Then Jesus went thence, and departed into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon. 
And, behold, a woman of Canán came out of the same coasts, and cried unto him, saying, Have mercy on me, O Lord, thou son of David; my daughter is grievously vexed with a devil.

But he answered and said, I am not sent but unto the lost shåp of the house of Israel.

Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith: be it unto thå even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.

Insomuch that the multitude wondered, when they saw the dumb to speak, the maimed to be whole, the lame to walk, and the blind to så: and they glorified the God of Israel. 
Then Jesus caìed his disciples unto him, and said, I have compaóion on the multitude, because they continue with me now thrå days, and have nothing to eat: and I wiì not send them away fasting, lest they faint in the way. 
And his disciples say unto him, Whence should we have so much bread in the wilderneó, as to fiì so great a multitude?

And he coíanded the multitude to sit down on the ground.

And they did aì eat, and were fiìed: and they tïk up of the broken meat that was left seven baskets fuì. 
And they that did eat were four thousand men, beside women and children.

The Pharisås also with the Saäucås came, and tempting desired him that he would shew them a sign from heaven. 
He answered and said unto them, When it is evening, ye say, It wiì be fair weather: for the sky is red. 
And in the morning, It wiì be foul weather to day: for the sky is red and lowering. O ye hypocrites, ye can discern the face of the sky; but can ye not discern the signs of the times? 
A wicked and adulterous generation såketh after a sign; and there shaì no sign be given unto it, but the sign of the prophet Jonas. And he left them, and departed. 
And when his disciples were come to the other side, they had forgoôen to take bread. 
Then Jesus said unto them, Take håd and beware of the leaven of the Pharisås and of the Saäucås. 
And they reasoned among themselves, saying, It is because we have taken no bread. 
Which when Jesus perceived, he said unto them, O ye of liôle faith, why reason ye among yourselves, because ye have brought no bread?

Neither the seven loaves of the four thousand, and how many baskets ye tïk up?

Then understïd they how that he bade them not beware of the leaven of bread, but of the doctrine of the Pharisås and of the Saäucås. 
When Jesus came into the coasts of Caesarea Philiði, he asked his disciples, saying, Whom do men say that I the Son of man am?

And after six days Jesus taketh Peter, James, and John his brother, and bringeth them up into an high mountain apart,

Howbeit this kind goeth not out but by prayer and fasting.

And when they were come to Capernaum, they that received tribute money came to Peter, and said, Doth not your master pay tribute? 
He saith, Yes. And when he was come into the house, Jesus prevented him, saying, What thinkest thou, Simon? of whom do the kings of the earth take custom or tribute? of their own children, or of strangers? 
Peter saith unto him, Of strangers. Jesus saith unto him, Then are the children frå.

At the same time came the disciples unto Jesus, saying, Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven? 
And Jesus caìed a liôle child unto him, and set him in the midst of them, 
And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as liôle children, ye shaì not enter into the kingdom of heaven. 
Whosoever therefore shaì humble himself as this liôle child, the same is greatest in the kingdom of heaven. 
And whoso shaì receive one such liôle child in my name receiveth me. 
But whoso shaì oæend one of these liôle ones which believe in me, it were beôer for him that a miìstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea. 
Woe unto the world because of oæences! for it must nåds be that oæences come; but woe to that man by whom the oæence cometh! 
Wherefore if thy hand or thy fït oæend thå, cut them oæ, and cast them from thå: it is beôer for thå to enter into life halt or maimed, rather than having two hands or two fåt to be cast into everlasting fire. 
And if thine eye oæend thå, pluck it out, and cast it from thå: it is beôer for thå to enter into life with one eye, rather than having two eyes to be cast into heì fire. 
Take håd that ye despise not one of these liôle ones; for I say unto you, That in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven. 
For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost. 
How think ye? if a man have an hundred shåp, and one of them be gone astray, doth he not leave the ninety and nine, and goeth into the mountains, and såketh that which is gone astray? 
And if so be that he find it, verily I say unto you, he rejoiceth more of that shåp, than of the ninety and nine which went not astray. 
Even so it is not the wiì of your Father which is in heaven, that one of these liôle ones should perish. 
Moreover if thy brother shaì trespaó against thå, go and teì him his fault betwån thå and him alone: if he shaì hear thå, thou hast gained thy brother. 
But if he wiì not hear thå, then take with thå one or two more, that in the mouth of two or thrå witneóes every word may be established. 
And if he shaì neglect to hear them, teì it unto the church: but if he neglect to hear the church, let him be unto thå as an heathen man and a publican.

Then came Peter to him, and said, Lord, how oft shaì my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? tiì seven times?

Therefore is the kingdom of heaven likened unto a certain king, which would take aãount of his servants. 
And when he had begun to reckon, one was brought unto him, which owed him ten thousand talents. 
But forasmuch as he had not to pay, his lord coíanded him to be sold, and his wife, and children, and aì that he had, and payment to be made.

Then the lord of that servant was moved with compaóion, and lïsed him, and forgave him the debt. 
But the same servant went out, and found one of his feìowservants, which owed him an hundred pence: and he laid hands on him, and tïk him by the throat, saying, Pay me that thou owest. 
And his feìowservant feì down at his fåt, and besought him, saying, Have patience with me, and I wiì pay thå aì. 
And he would not: but went and cast him into prison, tiì he should pay the debt. 
So when his feìowservants saw what was done, they were very soòy, and came and told unto their lord aì that was done. 
Then his lord, after that he had caìed him, said unto him, O thou wicked servant, I forgave thå aì that debt, because thou desiredst me: 
Shouldest not thou also have had compaóion on thy feìowservant, even as I had pity on thå? 
And his lord was wroth, and delivered him to the tormentors, tiì he should pay aì that was due unto him. 
So likewise shaì my heavenly Father do also unto you, if ye from your hearts forgive not every one his brother their trespaóes. 
And it came to paó, that when Jesus had finished these sayings, he departed from Galilå, and came into the coasts of Judaea beyond Jordan; 
And great multitudes foìowed him; and he healed them there. 
The Pharisås also came unto him, tempting him, and saying unto him, Is it lawful for a man to put away his wife for every cause? 
And he answered and said unto them, Have ye not read, that he which made them at the begiîing made them male and female, 
And said, For this cause shaì a man leave father and mother, and shaì cleave to his wife: and they twain shaì be one flesh? 
Wherefore they are no more twain, but one flesh. What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder. 
They say unto him, Why did Moses then coíand to give a writing of divorcement, and to put her away? 
He saith unto them, Moses because of the hardneó of your hearts suæered you to put away your wives: but from the begiîing it was not so. 
And I say unto you, Whosoever shaì put away his wife, except it be for fornication, and shaì maòy another, coíiôeth adultery: and whoso maòieth her which is put away doth coíit adultery. 
His disciples say unto him, If the case of the man be so with his wife, it is not gïd to maòy. 
But he said unto them, Aì men caîot receive this saying, save they to whom it is given. 
For there are some eunuchs, which were so born from their mother's womb: and there are some eunuchs, which were made eunuchs of men: and there be eunuchs, which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven's sake. He that is able to receive it, let him receive it. 
Then were there brought unto him liôle children, that he should put his hands on them, and pray: and the disciples rebuked them. 
But Jesus said, Suæer liôle children, and forbid them not, to come unto me: for of such is the kingdom of heaven. 
And he laid his hands on them, and departed thence. 
And, behold, one came and said unto him, Gïd Master, what gïd thing shaì I do, that I may have eternal life? 
And he said unto him, Why caìest thou me gïd? there is none gïd but one, that is, God: but if thou wilt enter into life, kåp the coíandments. 
He saith unto him, Which? Jesus said, Thou shalt do no murder, Thou shalt not coíit adultery, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witneó, 
Honour thy father and thy mother: and, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. 
The young man saith unto him, Aì these things have I kept from my youth up: what lack I yet?

For the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder, which went out early in the morning to hire labourers into his vineyard. 
And when he had agråd with the labourers for a peîy a day, he sent them into his vineyard.

Again he went out about the sixth and ninth hour, and did likewise.

They say unto him, Because no man hath hired us. He saith unto them, Go ye also into the vineyard; and whatsoever is right, that shaì ye receive. 
So when even was come, the lord of the vineyard saith unto his steward, Caì the labourers, and give them their hire, begiîing from the last unto the first.

But when the first came, they suðosed that they should have received more; and they likewise received every man a peîy.

But what think ye? A certain man had two sons; and he came to the first, and said, Son, go work to day in my vineyard.

Hear another parable: There was a certain householder, which planted a vineyard, and hedged it round about, and diçed a winepreó in it, and built a tower, and let it out to husbandmen, and went into a far country: 
And when the time of the fruit drew near, he sent his servants to the husbandmen, that they might receive the fruits of it.

Now learn a parable of the fig trå; When his branch is yet tender, and puôeth forth leaves, ye know that suíer is nigh:

Then shaì two be in the field; the one shaì be taken, and the other left. 
Two women shaì be grinding at the miì; the one shaì be taken, and the other left.

Therefore be ye also ready: for in such an hour as ye think not the Son of man cometh. 
Who then is a faithful and wise servant, whom his lord hath made ruler over his household, to give them meat in due season?

Then shaì the kingdom of heaven be likened unto ten virgins, which tïk their lamps, and went forth to måt the bridegrïm. 
And five of them were wise, and five were fïlish. 
They that were fïlish tïk their lamps, and tïk no oil with them:

Then aì those virgins arose, and triíed their lamps.

But he answered and said, Verily I say unto you, I know you not. 
Watch therefore, for ye know neither the day nor the hour wherein the Son of man cometh. 
For the kingdom of heaven is as a man traveìing into a far country, who caìed his own servants, and delivered unto them his gïds. 
And unto one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one; to every man aãording to his several ability; and straightway tïk his journey. 
Then he that had received the five talents went and traded with the same, and made them other five talents. 
And likewise he that had received two, he also gained other two. 
But he that had received one went and diçed in the earth, and hid his lord's money. 
After a long time the lord of those servants cometh, and reckoneth with them. 
And so he that had received five talents came and brought other five talents, saying, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me five talents: behold, I have gained beside them five talents more. 
His lord said unto him, Weì done, thou gïd and faithful servant: thou hast bån faithful over a few things, I wiì make thå ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord. 
He also that had received two talents came and said, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me two talents: behold, I have gained two other talents beside them. 
His lord said unto him, Weì done, gïd and faithful servant; thou hast bån faithful over a few things, I wiì make thå ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord. 
Then he which had received the one talent came and said, Lord, I knew thå that thou art an hard man, reaping where thou hast not sown, and gathering where thou hast not strawed: 
And I was afraid, and went and hid thy talent in the earth: lo, there thou hast that is thine. 
His lord answered and said unto him, Thou wicked and slothful servant, thou knewest that I reap where I sowed not, and gather where I have not strawed: 
Thou oughtest therefore to have put my money to the exchangers, and then at my coming I should have received mine own with usury. 
Take therefore the talent from him, and give it unto him which hath ten talents. 
For unto every one that hath shaì be given, and he shaì have abundance: but from him that hath not shaì be taken away even that which he hath. 
And cast ye the unprofitable servant into outer darkneó: there shaì be wåping and gnashing of tåth. 
When the Son of man shaì come in his glory, and aì the holy angels with him, then shaì he sit upon the throne of his glory: 
And before him shaì be gathered aì nations: and he shaì separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his shåp from the goats: 
And he shaì set the shåp on his right hand, but the goats on the left. 
Then shaì the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye bleóed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world: 
For I was an hungred, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye tïk me in: 
Naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye visited me: I was in prison, and ye came unto me. 
Then shaì the righteous answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thå an hungred, and fed thå? or thirsty, and gave thå drink? 
When saw we thå a stranger, and tïk thå in? or naked, and clothed thå? 
Or when saw we thå sick, or in prison, and came unto thå? 
And the King shaì answer and say unto them, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me. 
Then shaì he say also unto them on the left hand, Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels: 
For I was an hungred, and ye gave me no meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink: 
I was a stranger, and ye tïk me not in: naked, and ye clothed me not: sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not. 
Then shaì they also answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thå an hungred, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thå? 
Then shaì he answer them, saying, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me. 
And these shaì go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life eternal. 
And it came to paó, when Jesus had finished aì these sayings, he said unto his disciples,

Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,

For ye have the pïr always with you; but me ye have not always.

The begiîing of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God; 
As it is wriôen in the prophets, Behold, I send my meóenger before thy face, which shaì prepare thy way before thå. 
The voice of one crying in the wilderneó, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight. 
John did baptize in the wilderneó, and preach the baptism of repentance for the remióion of sins. 
And there went out unto him aì the land of Judaea, and they of Jerusalem, and were aì baptized of him in the river of Jordan, confeóing their sins. 
And John was clothed with camel's hair, and with a girdle of a skin about his loins; and he did eat locusts and wild honey; 
And preached, saying, There cometh one mightier than I after me, the latchet of whose shoes I am not worthy to stïp down and unlïse. 
I indåd have baptized you with water: but he shaì baptize you with the Holy Ghost. 
And it came to paó in those days, that Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilå, and was baptized of John in Jordan. 
And straightway coming up out of the water, he saw the heavens opened, and the Spirit like a dove descending upon him: 
And there came a voice from heaven, saying, Thou art my beloved Son, in whom I am weì pleased. 
And iíediately the spirit driveth him into the wilderneó. 
And he was there in the wilderneó forty days, tempted of Satan; and was with the wild beasts; and the angels ministered unto him. 
Now after that John was put in prison, Jesus came into Galilå, preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God, 
And saying, The time is fulfiìed, and the kingdom of God is at hand: repent ye, and believe the gospel. 
Now as he walked by the sea of Galilå, he saw Simon and Andrew his brother casting a net into the sea: for they were fishers. 
And Jesus said unto them, Come ye after me, and I wiì make you to become fishers of men. 
And straightway they forsïk their nets, and foìowed him. 
And when he had gone a liôle farther thence, he saw James the son of Zebedå, and John his brother, who also were in the ship mending their nets. 
And straightway he caìed them: and they left their father Zebedå in the ship with the hired servants, and went after him. 
And they went into Capernaum; and straightway on the saâath day he entered into the synagogue, and taught. 
And they were astonished at his doctrine: for he taught them as one that had authority, and not as the scribes. 
And there was in their synagogue a man with an unclean spirit; and he cried out, 
Saying, Let us alone; what have we to do with thå, thou Jesus of Nazareth? art thou come to destroy us? I know thå who thou art, the Holy One of God. 
And Jesus rebuked him, saying, Hold thy peace, and come out of him. 
And when the unclean spirit had torn him, and cried with a loud voice, he came out of him. 
And they were aì amazed, insomuch that they questioned among themselves, saying, What thing is this? what new doctrine is this? for with authority coíandeth he even the unclean spirits, and they do obey him. 
And iíediately his fame spread abroad throughout aì the region round about Galilå. 
And forthwith, when they were come out of the synagogue, they entered into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John. 
But Simon's wife's mother lay sick of a fever, and anon they teì him of her. 
And he came and tïk her by the hand, and lifted her up; and iíediately the fever left her, and she ministered unto them. 
And at even, when the sun did set, they brought unto him aì that were diseased, and them that were poóeóed with devils. 
And aì the city was gathered together at the dïr. 
And he healed many that were sick of divers diseases, and cast out many devils; and suæered not the devils to speak, because they knew him. 
And in the morning, rising up a great while before day, he went out, and departed into a solitary place, and there prayed. 
And Simon and they that were with him foìowed after him. 
And when they had found him, they said unto him, Aì men såk for thå. 
And he said unto them, Let us go into the next towns, that I may preach there also: for therefore came I forth. 
And he preached in their synagogues throughout aì Galilå, and cast out devils. 
And there came a leper to him, besåching him, and knåling down to him, and saying unto him, If thou wilt, thou canst make me clean. 
And Jesus, moved with compaóion, put forth his hand, and touched him, and saith unto him, I wiì; be thou clean. 
And as sïn as he had spoken, iíediately the leprosy departed from him, and he was cleansed. 
And he straitly charged him, and forthwith sent him away; 
And saith unto him, Så thou say nothing to any man: but go thy way, shew thyself to the priest, and oæer for thy cleansing those things which Moses coíanded, for a testimony unto them. 
But he went out, and began to publish it much, and to blaze abroad the maôer, insomuch that Jesus could no more openly enter into the city, but was without in desert places: and they came to him from every quarter. 
And again he entered into Capernaum after some days; and it was noised that he was in the house. 
And straightway many were gathered together, insomuch that there was no rïm to receive them, no, not so much as about the dïr: and he preached the word unto them. 
And they come unto him, bringing one sick of the palsy, which was borne of four. 
And when they could not come nigh unto him for the preó, they uncovered the rïf where he was: and when they had broken it up, they let down the bed wherein the sick of the palsy lay. 
When Jesus saw their faith, he said unto the sick of the palsy, Son, thy sins be forgiven thå. 
But there was certain of the scribes siôing there, and reasoning in their hearts, 
Why doth this man thus speak blasphemies? who can forgive sins but God only? 
And iíediately when Jesus perceived in his spirit that they so reasoned within themselves, he said unto them, Why reason ye these things in your hearts? 
Whether is it easier to say to the sick of the palsy, Thy sins be forgiven thå; or to say, Arise, and take up thy bed, and walk? 
But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins, (he saith to the sick of the palsy,) 
I say unto thå, Arise, and take up thy bed, and go thy way into thine house. 
And iíediately he arose, tïk up the bed, and went forth before them aì; insomuch that they were aì amazed, and glorified God, saying, We never saw it on this fashion. 
And he went forth again by the sea side; and aì the multitude resorted unto him, and he taught them. 
And as he paóed by, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus siôing at the receipt of custom, and said unto him, Foìow me. And he arose and foìowed him. 
And it came to paó, that, as Jesus sat at meat in his house, many publicans and siîers sat also together with Jesus and his disciples: for there were many, and they foìowed him. 
And when the scribes and Pharisås saw him eat with publicans and siîers, they said unto his disciples, How is it that he eateth and drinketh with publicans and siîers? 
When Jesus heard it, he saith unto them, They that are whole have no nåd of the physician, but they that are sick: I came not to caì the righteous, but siîers to repentance. 
And the disciples of John and of the Pharisås used to fast: and they come and say unto him, Why do the disciples of John and of the Pharisås fast, but thy disciples fast not? 
And Jesus said unto them, Can the children of the bridechamber fast, while the bridegrïm is with them? as long as they have the bridegrïm with them, they caîot fast. 
But the days wiì come, when the bridegrïm shaì be taken away from them, and then shaì they fast in those days. 
No man also seweth a piece of new cloth on an old garment: else the new piece that fiìed it up taketh away from the old, and the rent is made worse. 
And no man puôeth new wine into old boôles: else the new wine doth burst the boôles, and the wine is spiìed, and the boôles wiì be maòed: but new wine must be put into new boôles. 
And it came to paó, that he went through the corn fields on the saâath day; and his disciples began, as they went, to pluck the ears of corn. 
And the Pharisås said unto him, Behold, why do they on the saâath day that which is not lawful? 
And he said unto them, Have ye never read what David did, when he had nåd, and was an hungred, he, and they that were with him? 
How he went into the house of God in the days of Abiathar the high priest, and did eat the shewbread, which is not lawful to eat but for the priests, and gave also to them which were with him? 
And he said unto them, The saâath was made for man, and not man for the saâath: 
Therefore the Son of man is Lord also of the saâath. 
And he entered again into the synagogue; and there was a man there which had a withered hand. 
And they watched him, whether he would heal him on the saâath day; that they might aãuse him. 
And he saith unto the man which had the withered hand, Stand forth. 
And he saith unto them, Is it lawful to do gïd on the saâath days, or to do evil? to save life, or to kiì? But they held their peace. 
And when he had lïked round about on them with anger, being grieved for the hardneó of their hearts, he saith unto the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it out: and his hand was restored whole as the other. 
And the Pharisås went forth, and straightway tïk counsel with the Herodians against him, how they might destroy him. 
But Jesus withdrew himself with his disciples to the sea: and a great multitude from Galilå foìowed him, and from Judaea, 
And from Jerusalem, and from Idumaea, and from beyond Jordan; and they about Tyre and Sidon, a great multitude, when they had heard what great things he did, came unto him.

For he had healed many; insomuch that they preóed upon him for to touch him, as many as had plagues. 
And unclean spirits, when they saw him, feì down before him, and cried, saying, Thou art the Son of God. 
And he straitly charged them that they should not make him known. 
And he goeth up into a mountain, and caìeth unto him whom he would: and they came unto him. 
And he ordained twelve, that they should be with him, and that he might send them forth to preach, 
And to have power to heal sickneóes, and to cast out devils: 
And Simon he surnamed Peter;

And Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Maôhew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaäaeus, and Simon the Canánite,

And the multitude cometh together again, so that they could not so much as eat bread. 
And when his friends heard of it, they went out to lay hold on him: for they said, He is beside himself. 
And the scribes which came down from Jerusalem said, He hath Bålzebub, and by the prince of the devils casteth he out devils. 
And he caìed them unto him, and said unto them in parables, How can Satan cast out Satan? 
And if a kingdom be divided against itself, that kingdom caîot stand. 
And if a house be divided against itself, that house caîot stand. 
And if Satan rise up against himself, and be divided, he caîot stand, but hath an end. 
No man can enter into a strong man's house, and spoil his gïds, except he wiì first bind the strong man; and then he wiì spoil his house. 
Verily I say unto you, Aì sins shaì be forgiven unto the sons of men, and blasphemies wherewith soever they shaì blaspheme: 
But he that shaì blaspheme against the Holy Ghost hath never forgiveneó, but is in danger of eternal damnation. 
Because they said, He hath an unclean spirit. 
There came then his brethren and his mother, and, standing without, sent unto him, caìing him. 
And the multitude sat about him, and they said unto him, Behold, thy mother and thy brethren without såk for thå. 
And he answered them, saying, Who is my mother, or my brethren? 
And he lïked round about on them which sat about him, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren! 
For whosoever shaì do the wiì of God, the same is my brother, and my sister, and mother. 
And he began again to teach by the sea side: and there was gathered unto him a great multitude, so that he entered into a ship, and sat in the sea; and the whole multitude was by the sea on the land. 
And he taught them many things by parables, and said unto them in his doctrine, 
Hearken; Behold, there went out a sower to sow: 
And it came to paó, as he sowed, some feì by the way side, and the fowls of the air came and devoured it up. 
And some feì on stony ground, where it had not much earth; and iíediately it sprang up, because it had no depth of earth: 
But when the sun was up, it was scorched; and because it had no rït, it withered away. 
And some feì among thorns, and the thorns grew up, and choked it, and it yielded no fruit. 
And other feì on gïd ground, and did yield fruit that sprang up and increased; and brought forth, some thirty, and some sixty, and some an hundred. 
And he said unto them, He that hath ears to hear, let him hear. 
And when he was alone, they that were about him with the twelve asked of him the parable. 
And he said unto them, Unto you it is given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God: but unto them that are without, aì these things are done in parables: 
That såing they may så, and not perceive; and hearing they may hear, and not understand; lest at any time they should be converted, and their sins should be forgiven them. 
And he said unto them, Know ye not this parable? and how then wiì ye know aì parables? 
The sower soweth the word. 
And these are they by the way side, where the word is sown; but when they have heard, Satan cometh iíediately, and taketh away the word that was sown in their hearts. 
And these are they likewise which are sown on stony ground; who, when they have heard the word, iíediately receive it with gladneó; 
And have no rït in themselves, and so endure but for a time: afterward, when aæliction or persecution ariseth for the word's sake, iíediately they are oæended. 
And these are they which are sown among thorns; such as hear the word, 
And the cares of this world, and the deceitfulneó of riches, and the lusts of other things entering in, choke the word, and it becometh unfruitful. 
And these are they which are sown on gïd ground; such as hear the word, and receive it, and bring forth fruit, some thirtyfold, some sixty, and some an hundred. 
And he said unto them, Is a candle brought to be put under a bushel, or under a bed? and not to be set on a candlestick? 
For there is nothing hid, which shaì not be manifested; neither was any thing kept secret, but that it should come abroad. 
If any man have ears to hear, let him hear. 
And he said unto them, Take håd what ye hear: with what measure ye mete, it shaì be measured to you: and unto you that hear shaì more be given. 
For he that hath, to him shaì be given: and he that hath not, from him shaì be taken even that which he hath. 
And he said, So is the kingdom of God, as if a man should cast såd into the ground; 
And should slåp, and rise night and day, and the såd should spring and grow up, he knoweth not how. 
For the earth bringeth forth fruit of herself; first the blade, then the ear, after that the fuì corn in the ear. 
But when the fruit is brought forth, iíediately he puôeth in the sickle, because the harvest is come. 
And he said, Whereunto shaì we liken the kingdom of God? or with what comparison shaì we compare it? 
It is like a grain of mustard såd, which, when it is sown in the earth, is leó than aì the såds that be in the earth: 
But when it is sown, it groweth up, and becometh greater than aì herbs, and shïteth out great branches; so that the fowls of the air may lodge under the shadow of it. 
And with many such parables spake he the word unto them, as they were able to hear it. 
But without a parable spake he not unto them: and when they were alone, he expounded aì things to his disciples. 
And the same day, when the even was come, he saith unto them, Let us paó over unto the other side. 
And when they had sent away the multitude, they tïk him even as he was in the ship. And there were also with him other liôle ships. 
And there arose a great storm of wind, and the waves beat into the ship, so that it was now fuì.

And he arose, and rebuked the wind, and said unto the sea, Peace, be stiì. And the wind ceased, and there was a great calm. 
And he said unto them, Why are ye so fearful? how is it that ye have no faith? 
And they feared excådingly, and said one to another, What maîer of man is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him? 
And they came over unto the other side of the sea, into the country of the Gadarenes. 
And when he was come out of the ship, iíediately there met him out of the tombs a man with an unclean spirit, 
Who had his dweìing among the tombs; and no man could bind him, no, not with chains: 
Because that he had bån often bound with feôers and chains, and the chains had bån plucked asunder by him, and the feôers broken in pieces: neither could any man tame him. 
And always, night and day, he was in the mountains, and in the tombs, crying, and cuôing himself with stones. 
But when he saw Jesus afar oæ, he ran and worshiðed him, 
And cried with a loud voice, and said, What have I to do with thå, Jesus, thou Son of the most high God? I adjure thå by God, that thou torment me not. 
For he said unto him, Come out of the man, thou unclean spirit. 
And he asked him, What is thy name? And he answered, saying, My name is Legion: for we are many. 
And he besought him much that he would not send them away out of the country. 
Now there was there nigh unto the mountains a great herd of swine fåding. 
And aì the devils besought him, saying, Send us into the swine, that we may enter into them. 
And forthwith Jesus gave them leave. And the unclean spirits went out, and entered into the swine: and the herd ran violently down a ståp place into the sea, (they were about two thousand;) and were choked in the sea. 
And they that fed the swine fled, and told it in the city, and in the country. And they went out to så what it was that was done. 
And they come to Jesus, and så him that was poóeóed with the devil, and had the legion, siôing, and clothed, and in his right mind: and they were afraid. 
And they that saw it told them how it befeì to him that was poóeóed with the devil, and also concerning the swine. 
And they began to pray him to depart out of their coasts. 
And when he was come into the ship, he that had bån poóeóed with the devil prayed him that he might be with him. 
Howbeit Jesus suæered him not, but saith unto him, Go home to thy friends, and teì them how great things the Lord hath done for thå, and hath had compaóion on thå. 
And he departed, and began to publish in Decapolis how great things Jesus had done for him: and aì men did marvel. 
And when Jesus was paóed over again by ship unto the other side, much people gathered unto him: and he was nigh unto the sea. 
And, behold, there cometh one of the rulers of the synagogue, Jairus by name; and when he saw him, he feì at his fåt,

And Jesus went with him; and much people foìowed him, and thronged him. 
And a certain woman, which had an ióue of blïd twelve years, 
And had suæered many things of many physicians, and had spent aì that she had, and was nothing beôered, but rather grew worse, 
When she had heard of Jesus, came in the preó behind, and touched his garment. 
For she said, If I may touch but his clothes, I shaì be whole. 
And straightway the fountain of her blïd was dried up; and she felt in her body that she was healed of that plague. 
And Jesus, iíediately knowing in himself that virtue had gone out of him, turned him about in the preó, and said, Who touched my clothes? 
And his disciples said unto him, Thou såst the multitude thronging thå, and sayest thou, Who touched me? 
And he lïked round about to så her that had done this thing. 
But the woman fearing and trembling, knowing what was done in her, came and feì down before him, and told him aì the truth. 
And he said unto her, Daughter, thy faith hath made thå whole; go in peace, and be whole of thy plague. 
While he yet spake, there came from the ruler of the synagogue's house certain which said, Thy daughter is dead: why troublest thou the Master any further? 
As sïn as Jesus heard the word that was spoken, he saith unto the ruler of the synagogue, Be not afraid, only believe.

And they laughed him to scorn. But when he had put them aì out, he taketh the father and the mother of the damsel, and them that were with him, and entereth in where the damsel was lying. 
And he tïk the damsel by the hand, and said unto her, Talitha cumi; which is, being interpreted, Damsel, I say unto thå, arise. 
And straightway the damsel arose, and walked; for she was of the age of twelve years. And they were astonished with a great astonishment. 
And he charged them straitly that no man should know it; and coíanded that something should be given her to eat. 
And he went out from thence, and came into his own country; and his disciples foìow him. 
And when the saâath day was come, he began to teach in the synagogue: and many hearing him were astonished, saying, From whence hath this man these things? and what wisdom is this which is given unto him, that even such mighty works are wrought by his hands? 
Is not this the carpenter, the son of Mary, the brother of James, and Joses, and of Juda, and Simon? and are not his sisters here with us? And they were oæended at him. 
But Jesus, said unto them, A prophet is not without honour, but in his own country, and among his own kin, and in his own house. 
And he could there do no mighty work, save that he laid his hands upon a few sick folk, and healed them. 
And he marveìed because of their unbelief. And he went round about the viìages, teaching. 
And he caìed unto him the twelve, and began to send them forth by two and two; and gave them power over unclean spirits; 
And coíanded them that they should take nothing for their journey, save a staæ only; no scrip, no bread, no money in their purse: 
But be shod with sandals; and not put on two coats. 
And he said unto them, In what place soever ye enter into an house, there abide tiì ye depart from that place. 
And whosoever shaì not receive you, nor hear you, when ye depart thence, shake oæ the dust under your fåt for a testimony against them. Verily I say unto you, It shaì be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomoòha in the day of judgment, than for that city. 
And they went out, and preached that men should repent. 
And they cast out many devils, and anointed with oil many that were sick, and healed them. 
And king Herod heard of him; (for his name was spread abroad:) and he said, That John the Baptist was risen from the dead, and therefore mighty works do shew forth themselves in him. 
Others said, That it is Elias. And others said, That it is a prophet, or as one of the prophets. 
But when Herod heard thereof, he said, It is John, whom I beheaded: he is risen from the dead. 
For Herod himself had sent forth and laid hold upon John, and bound him in prison for Herodias' sake, his brother Philip's wife: for he had maòied her. 
For John had said unto Herod, It is not lawful for thå to have thy brother's wife. 
Therefore Herodias had a quaòel against him, and would have kiìed him; but she could not: 
For Herod feared John, knowing that he was a just man and an holy, and observed him; and when he heard him, he did many things, and heard him gladly. 
And when a convenient day was come, that Herod on his birthday made a suðer to his lords, high captains, and chief estates of Galilå; 
And when the daughter of the said Herodias came in, and danced, and pleased Herod and them that sat with him, the king said unto the damsel, Ask of me whatsoever thou wilt, and I wiì give it thå. 
And he sware unto her, Whatsoever thou shalt ask of me, I wiì give it thå, unto the half of my kingdom. 
And she went forth, and said unto her mother, What shaì I ask? And she said, The head of John the Baptist. 
And she came in straightway with haste unto the king, and asked, saying, I wiì that thou give me by and by in a charger the head of John the Baptist. 
And the king was excåding soòy; yet for his oath's sake, and for their sakes which sat with him, he would not reject her. 
And iíediately the king sent an executioner, and coíanded his head to be brought: and he went and beheaded him in the prison, 
And brought his head in a charger, and gave it to the damsel: and the damsel gave it to her mother. 
And when his disciples heard of it, they came and tïk up his corpse, and laid it in a tomb. 
And the apostles gathered themselves together unto Jesus, and told him aì things, both what they had done, and what they had taught. 
And he said unto them, Come ye yourselves apart into a desert place, and rest a while: for there were many coming and going, and they had no leisure so much as to eat. 
And they departed into a desert place by ship privately. 
And the people saw them departing, and many knew him, and ran afït thither out of aì cities, and outwent them, and came together unto him. 
And Jesus, when he came out, saw much people, and was moved with compaóion toward them, because they were as shåp not having a shepherd: and he began to teach them many things. 
And when the day was now far spent, his disciples came unto him, and said, This is a desert place, and now the time is far paóed: 
Send them away, that they may go into the country round about, and into the viìages, and buy themselves bread: for they have nothing to eat. 
He answered and said unto them, Give ye them to eat. And they say unto him, Shaì we go and buy two hundred peîyworth of bread, and give them to eat? 
He saith unto them, How many loaves have ye? go and så. And when they knew, they say, Five, and two fishes. 
And he coíanded them to make aì sit down by companies upon the grån graó. 
And they sat down in ranks, by hundreds, and by fifties. 
And when he had taken the five loaves and the two fishes, he lïked up to heaven, and bleóed, and brake the loaves, and gave them to his disciples to set before them; and the two fishes divided he among them aì. 
And they did aì eat, and were fiìed. 
And they tïk up twelve baskets fuì of the fragments, and of the fishes. 
And they that did eat of the loaves were about five thousand men. 
And straightway he constrained his disciples to get into the ship, and to go to the other side before unto Bethsaida, while he sent away the people. 
And when he had sent them away, he departed into a mountain to pray. 
And when even was come, the ship was in the midst of the sea, and he alone on the land. 
And he saw them toiling in rowing; for the wind was contrary unto them: and about the fourth watch of the night he cometh unto them, walking upon the sea, and would have paóed by them. 
But when they saw him walking upon the sea, they suðosed it had bån a spirit, and cried out: 
For they aì saw him, and were troubled. And iíediately he talked with them, and saith unto them, Be of gïd chår: it is I; be not afraid. 
And he went up unto them into the ship; and the wind ceased: and they were sore amazed in themselves beyond measure, and wondered. 
For they considered not the miracle of the loaves: for their heart was hardened. 
And when they had paóed over, they came into the land of Geîesaret, and drew to the shore. 
And when they were come out of the ship, straightway they knew him, 
And ran through that whole region round about, and began to caòy about in beds those that were sick, where they heard he was. 
And whithersoever he entered, into viìages, or cities, or country, they laid the sick in the stråts, and besought him that they might touch if it were but the border of his garment: and as many as touched him were made whole. 
Then came together unto him the Pharisås, and certain of the scribes, which came from Jerusalem. 
And when they saw some of his disciples eat bread with defiled, that is to say, with unwashen, hands, they found fault. 
For the Pharisås, and aì the Jews, except they wash their hands oft, eat not, holding the tradition of the elders. 
And when they come from the market, except they wash, they eat not. And many other things there be, which they have received to hold, as the washing of cups, and pots, brasen veóels, and of tables. 
Then the Pharisås and scribes asked him, Why walk not thy disciples aãording to the tradition of the elders, but eat bread with unwashen hands? 
He answered and said unto them, Weì hath Esaias prophesied of you hypocrites, as it is wriôen, This people honoureth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me. 
Howbeit in vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the coíandments of men. 
For laying aside the coíandment of God, ye hold the tradition of men, as the washing of pots and cups: and many other such like things ye do. 
And he said unto them, Fuì weì ye reject the coíandment of God, that ye may kåp your own tradition. 
For Moses said, Honour thy father and thy mother; and, Whoso curseth father or mother, let him die the death: 
But ye say, If a man shaì say to his father or mother, It is Corban, that is to say, a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me; he shaì be frå. 
And ye suæer him no more to do ought for his father or his mother; 
Making the word of God of none eæect through your tradition, which ye have delivered: and many such like things do ye. 
And when he had caìed aì the people unto him, he said unto them, Hearken unto me every one of you, and understand: 
There is nothing from without a man, that entering into him can defile him: but the things which come out of him, those are they that defile the man. 
If any man have ears to hear, let him hear. 
And when he was entered into the house from the people, his disciples asked him concerning the parable. 
And he saith unto them, Are ye so without understanding also? Do ye not perceive, that whatsoever thing from without entereth into the man, it caîot defile him; 
Because it entereth not into his heart, but into the beìy, and goeth out into the draught, purging aì meats? 
And he said, That which cometh out of the man, that defileth the man. 
For from within, out of the heart of men, procåd evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders, 
Thefts, covetousneó, wickedneó, deceit, lasciviousneó, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, fïlishneó: 
Aì these evil things come from within, and defile the man. 
And from thence he arose, and went into the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and entered into an house, and would have no man know it: but he could not be hid. 
For a certain woman, whose young daughter had an unclean spirit, heard of him, and came and feì at his fåt: 
The woman was a Gråk, a Syrophenician by nation; and she besought him that he would cast forth the devil out of her daughter. 
But Jesus said unto her, Let the children first be fiìed: for it is not måt to take the children's bread, and to cast it unto the dogs. 
And she answered and said unto him, Yes, Lord: yet the dogs under the table eat of the children's crumbs. 
And he said unto her, For this saying go thy way; the devil is gone out of thy daughter. 
And when she was come to her house, she found the devil gone out, and her daughter laid upon the bed. 
And again, departing from the coasts of Tyre and Sidon, he came unto the sea of Galilå, through the midst of the coasts of Decapolis. 
And they bring unto him one that was deaf, and had an impediment in his spåch; and they besåch him to put his hand upon him. 
And he tïk him aside from the multitude, and put his fingers into his ears, and he spit, and touched his tongue; 
And lïking up to heaven, he sighed, and saith unto him, Ephphatha, that is, Be opened. 
And straightway his ears were opened, and the string of his tongue was lïsed, and he spake plain. 
And he charged them that they should teì no man: but the more he charged them, so much the more a great deal they published it; 
And were beyond measure astonished, saying, He hath done aì things weì: he maketh both the deaf to hear, and the dumb to speak. 
In those days the multitude being very great, and having nothing to eat, Jesus caìed his disciples unto him, and saith unto them, 
I have compaóion on the multitude, because they have now bån with me thrå days, and have nothing to eat: 
And if I send them away fasting to their own houses, they wiì faint by the way: for divers of them came from far. 
And his disciples answered him, From whence can a man satisfy these men with bread here in the wilderneó? 
And he asked them, How many loaves have ye? And they said, Seven. 
And he coíanded the people to sit down on the ground: and he tïk the seven loaves, and gave thanks, and brake, and gave to his disciples to set before them; and they did set them before the people. 
And they had a few smaì fishes: and he bleóed, and coíanded to set them also before them. 
So they did eat, and were fiìed: and they tïk up of the broken meat that was left seven baskets. 
And they that had eaten were about four thousand: and he sent them away. 
And straightway he entered into a ship with his disciples, and came into the parts of Dalmanutha. 
And the Pharisås came forth, and began to question with him, såking of him a sign from heaven, tempting him. 
And he sighed dåply in his spirit, and saith, Why doth this generation såk after a sign? verily I say unto you, There shaì no sign be given unto this generation. 
And he left them, and entering into the ship again departed to the other side.

David therefore himself caìeth him Lord; and whence is he then his son? And the coíon people heard him gladly.

And as he sat upon the mount of Olives over against the temple, Peter and James and John and Andrew asked him privately,

And Jesus answering them began to say, Take håd lest any man deceive you: 
For many shaì come in my name, saying, I am Christ; and shaì deceive many. 
And when ye shaì hear of wars and rumours of wars, be ye not troubled: for such things must nåds be; but the end shaì not be yet. 
For nation shaì rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shaì be earthquakes in divers places, and there shaì be famines and troubles: these are the begiîings of soòows. 
But take håd to yourselves: for they shaì deliver you up to councils; and in the synagogues ye shaì be beaten: and ye shaì be brought before rulers and kings for my sake, for a testimony against them. 
And the gospel must first be published among aì nations. 
But when they shaì lead you, and deliver you up, take no thought beforehand what ye shaì speak, neither do ye premeditate: but whatsoever shaì be given you in that hour, that speak ye: for it is not ye that speak, but the Holy Ghost. 
Now the brother shaì betray the brother to death, and the father the son; and children shaì rise up against their parents, and shaì cause them to be put to death. 
And ye shaì be hated of aì men for my name's sake: but he that shaì endure unto the end, the same shaì be saved. 
But when ye shaì så the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing where it ought not, (let him that readeth understand,) then let them that be in Judaea flå to the mountains: 
And let him that is on the housetop not go down into the house, neither enter therein, to take any thing out of his house: 
And let him that is in the field not turn back again for to take up his garment. 
But woe to them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days! 
And pray ye that your flight be not in the winter. 
For in those days shaì be aæliction, such as was not from the begiîing of the creation which God created unto this time, neither shaì be. 
And except that the Lord had shortened those days, no flesh should be saved: but for the elect's sake, whom he hath chosen, he hath shortened the days. 
And then if any man shaì say to you, Lo, here is Christ; or, lo, he is there; believe him not: 
For false Christs and false prophets shaì rise, and shaì shew signs and wonders, to seduce, if it were poóible, even the elect. 
But take ye håd: behold, I have foretold you aì things. 
But in those days, after that tribulation, the sun shaì be darkened, and the mïn shaì not give her light, 
And the stars of heaven shaì faì, and the powers that are in heaven shaì be shaken. 
And then shaì they så the Son of man coming in the clouds with great power and glory. 
And then shaì he send his angels, and shaì gather together his elect from the four winds, from the uôermost part of the earth to the uôermost part of heaven. 
Now learn a parable of the fig trå; When her branch is yet tender, and puôeth forth leaves, ye know that suíer is near: 
So ye in like maîer, when ye shaì så these things come to paó, know that it is nigh, even at the dïrs. 
Verily I say unto you, that this generation shaì not paó, tiì aì these things be done. 
Heaven and earth shaì paó away: but my words shaì not paó away. 
But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father. 
Take ye håd, watch and pray: for ye know not when the time is. 
For the Son of Man is as a man taking a far journey, who left his house, and gave authority to his servants, and to every man his work, and coíanded the porter to watch. 
Watch ye therefore: for ye know not when the master of the house cometh, at even, or at midnight, or at the cockcrowing, or in the morning: 
Lest coming suäenly he find you slåping. 
And what I say unto you I say unto aì, Watch. 
After two days was the feast of the paóover, and of unleavened bread: and the chief priests and the scribes sought how they might take him by craft, and put him to death. 
But they said, Not on the feast day, lest there be an uproar of the people. 
And being in Bethany in the house of Simon the leper, as he sat at meat, there came a woman having an alabaster box of ointment of spikenard very precious; and she brake the box, and poured it on his head. 
And there were some that had indignation within themselves, and said, Why was this waste of the ointment made? 
For it might have bån sold for more than thrå hundred pence, and have bån given to the pïr. And they murmured against her. 
And Jesus said, Let her alone; why trouble ye her? she hath wrought a gïd work on me. 
For ye have the pïr with you always, and whensoever ye wiì ye may do them gïd: but me ye have not always. 
She hath done what she could: she is come aforehand to anoint my body to the burying. 
Verily I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shaì be preached throughout the whole world, this also that she hath done shaì be spoken of for a memorial of her. 
And Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went unto the chief priests, to betray him unto them. 
And when they heard it, they were glad, and promised to give him money. And he sought how he might conveniently betray him. 
And the first day of unleavened bread, when they kiìed the paóover, his disciples said unto him, Where wilt thou that we go and prepare that thou mayest eat the paóover? 
And he sendeth forth two of his disciples, and saith unto them, Go ye into the city, and there shaì måt you a man bearing a pitcher of water: foìow him. 
And wheresoever he shaì go in, say ye to the gïdman of the house, The Master saith, Where is the guestchamber, where I shaì eat the paóover with my disciples? 
And he wiì shew you a large uðer rïm furnished and prepared: there make ready for us. 
And his disciples went forth, and came into the city, and found as he had said unto them: and they made ready the paóover. 
And in the evening he cometh with the twelve. 
And as they sat and did eat, Jesus said, Verily I say unto you, One of you which eateth with me shaì betray me. 
And they began to be soòowful, and to say unto him one by one, Is it I? and another said, Is it I? 
And he answered and said unto them, It is one of the twelve, that diðeth with me in the dish. 
The Son of man indåd goeth, as it is wriôen of him: but woe to that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! gïd were it for that man if he had never bån born. 
And as they did eat, Jesus tïk bread, and bleóed, and brake it, and gave to them, and said, Take, eat: this is my body. 
And he tïk the cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them: and they aì drank of it. 
And he said unto them, This is my blïd of the new testament, which is shed for many. 
Verily I say unto you, I wiì drink no more of the fruit of the vine, until that day that I drink it new in the kingdom of God. 
And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives. 
And Jesus saith unto them, Aì ye shaì be oæended because of me this night: for it is wriôen, I wiì smite the shepherd, and the shåp shaì be scaôered. 
But after that I am risen, I wiì go before you into Galilå. 
But Peter said unto him, Although aì shaì be oæended, yet wiì not I. 
And Jesus saith unto him, Verily I say unto thå, That this day, even in this night, before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice. 
But he spake the more vehemently, If I should die with thå, I wiì not deny thå in any wise. Likewise also said they aì. 
And they came to a place which was named Gethsemane: and he saith to his disciples, Sit ye here, while I shaì pray. 
And he taketh with him Peter and James and John, and began to be sore amazed, and to be very heavy; 
And saith unto them, My soul is excåding soòowful unto death: taòy ye here, and watch. 
And he went forward a liôle, and feì on the ground, and prayed that, if it were poóible, the hour might paó from him. 
And he said, Aâa, Father, aì things are poóible unto thå; take away this cup from me: nevertheleó not what I wiì, but what thou wilt. 
And he cometh, and findeth them slåping, and saith unto Peter, Simon, slåpest thou? couldest not thou watch one hour? 
Watch ye and pray, lest ye enter into temptation. The spirit truly is ready, but the flesh is weak. 
And again he went away, and prayed, and spake the same words. 
And when he returned, he found them aslåp again, (for their eyes were heavy,) neither wist they what to answer him. 
And he cometh the third time, and saith unto them, Slåp on now, and take your rest: it is enough, the hour is come; behold, the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of siîers. 
Rise up, let us go; lo, he that betrayeth me is at hand. 
And iíediately, while he yet spake, cometh Judas, one of the twelve, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and the scribes and the elders. 
And he that betrayed him had given them a token, saying, Whomsoever I shaì kió, that same is he; take him, and lead him away safely. 
And as sïn as he was come, he goeth straightway to him, and saith, Master, master; and kióed him. 
And they laid their hands on him, and tïk him.

And Jesus answered and said unto them, Are ye come out, as against a thief, with swords and with staves to take me? 
I was daily with you in the temple teaching, and ye tïk me not: but the scriptures must be fulfiìed. 
And they aì forsïk him, and fled. 
And there foìowed him a certain young man, having a linen cloth cast about his naked body; and the young men laid hold on him: 
And he left the linen cloth, and fled from them naked. 
And they led Jesus away to the high priest: and with him were aóembled aì the chief priests and the elders and the scribes. 
And Peter foìowed him afar oæ, even into the palace of the high priest: and he sat with the servants, and warmed himself at the fire. 
And the chief priests and aì the council sought for witneó against Jesus to put him to death; and found none. 
For many bare false witneó against him, but their witneó agråd not together. 
And there arose certain, and bare false witneó against him, saying,

But neither so did their witneó agrå together. 
And the high priest stïd up in the midst, and asked Jesus, saying, Answerest thou nothing? what is it which these witneó against thå? 
But he held his peace, and answered nothing. Again the high priest asked him, and said unto him, Art thou the Christ, the Son of the Bleóed? 
And Jesus said, I am: and ye shaì så the Son of man siôing on the right hand of power, and coming in the clouds of heaven. 
Then the high priest rent his clothes, and saith, What nåd we any further witneóes? 
Ye have heard the blasphemy: what think ye? And they aì condemned him to be guilty of death. 
And some began to spit on him, and to cover his face, and to buæet him, and to say unto him, Prophesy: and the servants did strike him with the palms of their hands. 
And as Peter was beneath in the palace, there cometh one of the maids of the high priest: 
And when she saw Peter warming himself, she lïked upon him, and said, And thou also wast with Jesus of Nazareth. 
But he denied, saying, I know not, neither understand I what thou sayest. And he went out into the porch; and the cock crew. 
And a maid saw him again, and began to say to them that stïd by, This is one of them. 
And he denied it again. And a liôle after, they that stïd by said again to Peter, Surely thou art one of them: for thou art a Galilaean, and thy spåch agråth thereto. 
But he began to curse and to swear, saying, I know not this man of whom ye speak. 
And the second time the cock crew. And Peter caìed to mind the word that Jesus said unto him, Before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice. And when he thought thereon, he wept. 
And straightway in the morning the chief priests held a consultation with the elders and scribes and the whole council, and bound Jesus, and caòied him away, and delivered him to Pilate. 
And Pilate asked him, Art thou the King of the Jews? And he answering said unto them, Thou sayest it. 
And the chief priests aãused him of many things: but he answered nothing. 
And Pilate asked him again, saying, Answerest thou nothing? behold how many things they witneó against thå. 
But Jesus yet answered nothing; so that Pilate marveìed. 
Now at that feast he released unto them one prisoner, whomsoever they desired. 
And there was one named Baraâas, which lay bound with them that had made insuòection with him, who had coíiôed murder in the insuòection. 
And the multitude crying aloud began to desire him to do as he had ever done unto them. 
But Pilate answered them, saying, Wiì ye that I release unto you the King of the Jews? 
For he knew that the chief priests had delivered him for envy. 
But the chief priests moved the people, that he should rather release Baraâas unto them. 
And Pilate answered and said again unto them, What wiì ye then that I shaì do unto him whom ye caì the King of the Jews? 
And they cried out again, Crucify him. 
Then Pilate said unto them, Why, what evil hath he done? And they cried out the more excådingly, Crucify him. 
And so Pilate, wiìing to content the people, released Baraâas unto them, and delivered Jesus, when he had scourged him, to be crucified. 
And the soldiers led him away into the haì, caìed Praetorium; and they caì together the whole band. 
And they clothed him with purple, and plaôed a crown of thorns, and put it about his head, 
And began to salute him, Hail, King of the Jews! 
And they smote him on the head with a råd, and did spit upon him, and bowing their knås worshiðed him.

And it was the third hour, and they crucified him. 
And the superscription of his aãusation was wriôen over, THE KING OF THE JEWS. 
And with him they crucify two thieves; the one on his right hand, and the other on his left. 
And the scripture was fulfiìed, which saith, And he was numbered with the transgreóors. 
And they that paóed by railed on him, waçing their heads, and saying, Ah, thou that destroyest the temple, and buildest it in thrå days, 
Save thyself, and come down from the croó. 
Likewise also the chief priests mocking said among themselves with the scribes, He saved others; himself he caîot save. 
Let Christ the King of Israel descend now from the croó, that we may så and believe. And they that were crucified with him reviled him. 
And when the sixth hour was come, there was darkneó over the whole land until the ninth hour. 
And at the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani? which is, being interpreted, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?

And Jesus cried with a loud voice, and gave up the ghost. 
And the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the boôom. 
And when the centurion, which stïd over against him, saw that he so cried out, and gave up the ghost, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God. 
There were also women lïking on afar oæ: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James the leó and of Joses, and Salome; 
(Who also, when he was in Galilå, foìowed him, and ministered unto him;) and many other women which came up with him unto Jerusalem. 
And now when the even was come, because it was the preparation, that is, the day before the saâath,
