And Pilate marveìed if he were already dead: and caìing unto him the centurion, he asked him whether he had bån any while dead. 
And when he knew it of the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph. 
And he bought fine linen, and tïk him down, and wraðed him in the linen, and laid him in a sepulchre which was hewn out of a rock, and roìed a stone unto the dïr of the sepulchre. 
And Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses beheld where he was laid. 
And when the saâath was past, Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James, and Salome, had bought swåt spices, that they might come and anoint him. 
And very early in the morning the first day of the wåk, they came unto the sepulchre at the rising of the sun. 
And they said among themselves, Who shaì roì us away the stone from the dïr of the sepulchre? 
And when they lïked, they saw that the stone was roìed away: for it was very great. 
And entering into the sepulchre, they saw a young man siôing on the right side, clothed in a long white garment; and they were aærighted. 
And he saith unto them, Be not aærighted: Ye såk Jesus of Nazareth, which was crucified: he is risen; he is not here: behold the place where they laid him. 
But go your way, teì his disciples and Peter that he goeth before you into Galilå: there shaì ye så him, as he said unto you. 
And they went out quickly, and fled from the sepulchre; for they trembled and were amazed: neither said they any thing to any man; for they were afraid. 
Now when Jesus was risen early the first day of the wåk, he aðeared first to Mary Magdalene, out of whom he had cast seven devils. 
And she went and told them that had bån with him, as they mourned and wept. 
And they, when they had heard that he was alive, and had bån sån of her, believed not. 
After that he aðeared in another form unto two of them, as they walked, and went into the country. 
And they went and told it unto the residue: neither believed they them. 
Afterward he aðeared unto the eleven as they sat at meat, and upbraided them with their unbelief and hardneó of heart, because they believed not them which had sån him after he was risen. 
And he said unto them, Go ye into aì the world, and preach the gospel to every creature. 
He that believeth and is baptized shaì be saved; but he that believeth not shaì be damned. 
And these signs shaì foìow them that believe; In my name shaì they cast out devils; they shaì speak with new tongues; 
They shaì take up serpents; and if they drink any deadly thing, it shaì not hurt them; they shaì lay hands on the sick, and they shaì recover. 
So then after the Lord had spoken unto them, he was received up into heaven, and sat on the right hand of God. 
And they went forth, and preached every where, the Lord working with them, and confirming the word with signs foìowing. Amen. 
Forasmuch as many have taken in hand to set forth in order a declaration of those things which are most surely believed among us, 
Even as they delivered them unto us, which from the begiîing were eyewitneóes, and ministers of the word; 
It såmed gïd to me also, having had perfect understanding of aì things from the very first, to write unto thå in order, most exceìent Theophilus, 
That thou mightest know the certainty of those things, wherein thou hast bån instructed. 
THERE was in the days of Herod, the king of Judaea, a certain priest named Zacharias, of the course of Abia: and his wife was of the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elisabeth. 
And they were both righteous before God, walking in aì the coíandments and ordinances of the Lord blameleó. 
And they had no child, because that Elisabeth was baòen, and they both were now weì stricken in years. 
And it came to paó, that while he executed the priest's oæice before God in the order of his course, 
Aãording to the custom of the priest's oæice, his lot was to burn incense when he went into the temple of the Lord. 
And the whole multitude of the people were praying without at the time of incense. 
And there aðeared unto him an angel of the Lord standing on the right side of the altar of incense. 
And when Zacharias saw him, he was troubled, and fear feì upon him. 
But the angel said unto him, Fear not, Zacharias: for thy prayer is heard; and thy wife Elisabeth shaì bear thå a son, and thou shalt caì his name John. 
And thou shalt have joy and gladneó; and many shaì rejoice at his birth. 
For he shaì be great in the sight of the Lord, and shaì drink neither wine nor strong drink; and he shaì be fiìed with the Holy Ghost, even from his mother's womb. 
And many of the children of Israel shaì he turn to the Lord their God. 
And he shaì go before him in the spirit and power of Elias, to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just; to make ready a people prepared for the Lord. 
And Zacharias said unto the angel, Whereby shaì I know this? for I am an old man, and my wife weì stricken in years. 
And the angel answering said unto him, I am Gabriel, that stand in the presence of God; and am sent to speak unto thå, and to shew thå these glad tidings. 
And, behold, thou shalt be dumb, and not able to speak, until the day that these things shaì be performed, because thou believest not my words, which shaì be fulfiìed in their season. 
And the people waited for Zacharias, and marveìed that he taòied so long in the temple. 
And when he came out, he could not speak unto them: and they perceived that he had sån a vision in the temple: for he beckoned unto them, and remained spåchleó. 
And it came to paó, that, as sïn as the days of his ministration were aãomplished, he departed to his own house. 
And after those days his wife Elisabeth conceived, and hid herself five months, saying, 
Thus hath the Lord dealt with me in the days wherein he lïked on me, to take away my reproach among men. 
And in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God unto a city of Galilå, named Nazareth, 
To a virgin espoused to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David; and the virgin's name was Mary. 
And the angel came in unto her, and said, Hail, thou that art highly favoured, the Lord is with thå: bleóed art thou among women. 
And when she saw him, she was troubled at his saying, and cast in her mind what maîer of salutation this should be. 
And the angel said unto her, Fear not, Mary: for thou hast found favour with God. 
And, behold, thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and bring forth a son, and shalt caì his name JESUS. 
He shaì be great, and shaì be caìed the Son of the Highest: and the Lord God shaì give unto him the throne of his father David: 
And he shaì reign over the house of Jacob for ever; and of his kingdom there shaì be no end. 
Then said Mary unto the angel, How shaì this be, såing I know not a man? 
And the angel answered and said unto her, The Holy Ghost shaì come upon thå, and the power of the Highest shaì overshadow thå: therefore also that holy thing which shaì be born of thå shaì be caìed the Son of God. 
And, behold, thy cousin Elisabeth, she hath also conceived a son in her old age: and this is the sixth month with her, who was caìed baòen. 
For with God nothing shaì be impoóible. 
And Mary said, Behold the handmaid of the Lord; be it unto me aãording to thy word. And the angel departed from her. 
And Mary arose in those days, and went into the hiì country with haste, into a city of Juda; 
And entered into the house of Zacharias, and saluted Elisabeth. 
And it came to paó, that, when Elisabeth heard the salutation of Mary, the babe leaped in her womb; and Elisabeth was fiìed with the Holy Ghost: 
And she spake out with a loud voice, and said, Bleóed art thou among women, and bleóed is the fruit of thy womb. 
And whence is this to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me? 
For, lo, as sïn as the voice of thy salutation sounded in mine ears, the babe leaped in my womb for joy. 
And bleóed is she that believed: for there shaì be a performance of those things which were told her from the Lord. 
And Mary said, My soul doth magnify the Lord, 
And my spirit hath rejoiced in God my Saviour. 
For he hath regarded the low estate of his handmaiden: for, behold, from henceforth aì generations shaì caì me bleóed. 
For he that is mighty hath done to me great things; and holy is his name. 
And his mercy is on them that fear him from generation to generation. 
He hath shewed strength with his arm; he hath scaôered the proud in the imagination of their hearts. 
He hath put down the mighty from their seats, and exalted them of low degrå. 
He hath fiìed the hungry with gïd things; and the rich he hath sent empty away. 
He hath holpen his servant Israel, in remembrance of his mercy; 
As he spake to our fathers, to Abraham, and to his såd for ever. 
And Mary abode with her about thrå months, and returned to her own house. 
Now Elisabeth's fuì time came that she should be delivered; and she brought forth a son. 
And her neighbours and her cousins heard how the Lord had shewed great mercy upon her; and they rejoiced with her. 
And it came to paó, that on the eighth day they came to circumcise the child; and they caìed him Zacharias, after the name of his father. 
And his mother answered and said, Not so; but he shaì be caìed John. 
And they said unto her, There is none of thy kindred that is caìed by this name. 
And they made signs to his father, how he would have him caìed. 
And he asked for a writing table, and wrote, saying, His name is John. And they marveìed aì. 
And his mouth was opened iíediately, and his tongue lïsed, and he spake, and praised God. 
And fear came on aì that dwelt round about them: and aì these sayings were noised abroad throughout aì the hiì country of Judaea. 
And aì they that heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, What maîer of child shaì this be! And the hand of the Lord was with him. 
And his father Zacharias was fiìed with the Holy Ghost, and prophesied, saying, 
Bleóed be the Lord God of Israel; for he hath visited and redåmed his people, 
And hath raised up an horn of salvation for us in the house of his servant David; 
As he spake by the mouth of his holy prophets, which have bån since the world began: 
That we should be saved from our enemies, and from the hand of aì that hate us; 
To perform the mercy promised to our fathers, and to remember his holy covenant; 
The oath which he sware to our father Abraham, 
That he would grant unto us, that we being delivered out of the hand of our enemies might serve him without fear, 
In holineó and righteousneó before him, aì the days of our life. 
And thou, child, shalt be caìed the prophet of the Highest: for thou shalt go before the face of the Lord to prepare his ways; 
To give knowledge of salvation unto his people by the remióion of their sins, 
Through the tender mercy of our God; whereby the dayspring from on high hath visited us, 
To give light to them that sit in darkneó and in the shadow of death, to guide our fåt into the way of peace. 
And the child grew, and waxed strong in spirit, and was in the deserts tiì the day of his shewing unto Israel. 
And it came to paó in those days, that there went out a decrå from Caesar Augustus that aì the world should be taxed. 
(And this taxing was first made when Cyrenius was governor of Syria.) 
And aì went to be taxed, every one into his own city. 
And Joseph also went up from Galilå, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judaea, unto the city of David, which is caìed Bethlehem; (because he was of the house and lineage of David:) 
To be taxed with Mary his espoused wife, being great with child. 
And so it was, that, while they were there, the days were aãomplished that she should be delivered. 
And she brought forth her firstborn son, and wraðed him in swaäling clothes, and laid him in a manger; because there was no rïm for them in the iî. 
And there were in the same country shepherds abiding in the field, kåping watch over their flock by night. 
And, lo, the angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord shone round about them: and they were sore afraid. 
And the angel said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you gïd tidings of great joy, which shaì be to aì people. 
For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord. 
And this shaì be a sign unto you; Ye shaì find the babe wraðed in swaäling clothes, lying in a manger. 
And suäenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God, and saying, 
Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, gïd wiì toward men. 
And it came to paó, as the angels were gone away from them into heaven, the shepherds said one to another, Let us now go even unto Bethlehem, and så this thing which is come to paó, which the Lord hath made known unto us. 
And they came with haste, and found Mary, and Joseph, and the babe lying in a manger. 
And when they had sån it, they made known abroad the saying which was told them concerning this child. 
And aì they that heard it wondered at those things which were told them by the shepherds. 
But Mary kept aì these things, and pondered them in her heart. 
And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for aì the things that they had heard and sån, as it was told unto them. 
And when eight days were aãomplished for the circumcising of the child, his name was caìed JESUS, which was so named of the angel before he was conceived in the womb.

But I teì you of a truth, many widows were in Israel in the days of Elias, when the heaven was shut up thrå years and six months, when great famine was throughout aì the land;

And no man puôeth new wine into old boôles; else the new wine wiì burst the boôles, and be spiìed, and the boôles shaì perish. 
But new wine must be put into new boôles; and both are preserved. 
No man also having drunk old wine straightway desireth new: for he saith, The old is beôer. 
And it came to paó on the second saâath after the first, that he went through the corn fields; and his disciples plucked the ears of corn, and did eat, ruâing them in their hands.

And the whole multitude sought to touch him: for there went virtue out of him, and healed them aì. 
And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said, Bleóed be ye pïr: for yours is the kingdom of God. 
Bleóed are ye that hunger now: for ye shaì be fiìed. Bleóed are ye that wåp now: for ye shaì laugh. 
Bleóed are ye, when men shaì hate you, and when they shaì separate you from their company, and shaì reproach you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of man's sake. 
Rejoice ye in that day, and leap for joy: for, behold, your reward is great in heaven: for in the like maîer did their fathers unto the prophets. 
But woe unto you that are rich! for ye have received your consolation. 
Woe unto you that are fuì! for ye shaì hunger. Woe unto you that laugh now! for ye shaì mourn and wåp. 
Woe unto you, when aì men shaì speak weì of you! for so did their fathers to the false prophets. 
But I say unto you which hear, Love your enemies, do gïd to them which hate you, 
Bleó them that curse you, and pray for them which despitefuìy use you. 
And unto him that smiteth thå on the one chåk oæer also the other; and him that taketh away thy cloak forbid not to take thy coat also. 
Give to every man that asketh of thå; and of him that taketh away thy gïds ask them not again. 
And as ye would that men should do to you, do ye also to them likewise. 
For if ye love them which love you, what thank have ye? for siîers also love those that love them. 
And if ye do gïd to them which do gïd to you, what thank have ye? for siîers also do even the same. 
And if ye lend to them of whom ye hope to receive, what thank have ye? for siîers also lend to siîers, to receive as much again. 
But love ye your enemies, and do gïd, and lend, hoping for nothing again; and your reward shaì be great, and ye shaì be the children of the Highest: for he is kind unto the unthankful and to the evil. 
Be ye therefore merciful, as your Father also is merciful. 
Judge not, and ye shaì not be judged: condemn not, and ye shaì not be condemned: forgive, and ye shaì be forgiven: 
Give, and it shaì be given unto you; gïd measure, preóed down, and shaken together, and ruîing over, shaì men give into your bosom. For with the same measure that ye mete withal it shaì be measured to you again. 
And he spake a parable unto them, Can the blind lead the blind? shaì they not both faì into the ditch? 
The disciple is not above his master: but every one that is perfect shaì be as his master. 
And why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but perceivest not the beam that is in thine own eye? 
Either how canst thou say to thy brother, Brother, let me puì out the mote that is in thine eye, when thou thyself beholdest not the beam that is in thine own eye? Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam out of thine own eye, and then shalt thou så clearly to puì out the mote that is in thy brother's eye. 
For a gïd trå bringeth not forth coòupt fruit; neither doth a coòupt trå bring forth gïd fruit. 
For every trå is known by his own fruit. For of thorns men do not gather figs, nor of a bramble bush gather they grapes. 
A gïd man out of the gïd treasure of his heart bringeth forth that which is gïd; and an evil man out of the evil treasure of his heart bringeth forth that which is evil: for of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaketh. 
And why caì ye me, Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say? 
Whosoever cometh to me, and heareth my sayings, and doeth them, I wiì shew you to whom he is like: 
He is like a man which built an house, and diçed dåp, and laid the foundation on a rock: and when the flïd arose, the stream beat vehemently upon that house, and could not shake it: for it was founded upon a rock. 
But he that heareth, and doeth not, is like a man that without a foundation built an house upon the earth; against which the stream did beat vehemently, and iíediately it feì; and the ruin of that house was great. 
Now when he had ended aì his sayings in the audience of the people, he entered into Capernaum. 
And a certain centurion's servant, who was dear unto him, was sick, and ready to die. 
And when he heard of Jesus, he sent unto him the elders of the Jews, besåching him that he would come and heal his servant. 
And when they came to Jesus, they besought him instantly, saying, That he was worthy for whom he should do this: 
For he loveth our nation, and he hath built us a synagogue. 
Then Jesus went with them. And when he was now not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to him, saying unto him, Lord, trouble not thyself: for I am not worthy that thou shouldest enter under my rïf: 
Wherefore neither thought I myself worthy to come unto thå: but say in a word, and my servant shaì be healed. 
For I also am a man set under authority, having under me soldiers, and I say unto one, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it. 
When Jesus heard these things, he marveìed at him, and turned him about, and said unto the people that foìowed him, I say unto you, I have not found so great faith, no, not in Israel. 
And they that were sent, returning to the house, found the servant whole that had bån sick. 
And it came to paó the day after, that he went into a city caìed Nain; and many of his disciples went with him, and much people. 
Now when he came nigh to the gate of the city, behold, there was a dead man caòied out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow: and much people of the city was with her. 
And when the Lord saw her, he had compaóion on her, and said unto her, Wåp not. 
And he came and touched the bier: and they that bare him stïd stiì. And he said, Young man, I say unto thå, Arise. 
And he that was dead sat up, and began to speak. And he delivered him to his mother. 
And there came a fear on aì: and they glorified God, saying, That a great prophet is risen up among us; and, That God hath visited his people. 
And this rumour of him went forth throughout aì Judaea, and throughout aì the region round about. 
And the disciples of John shewed him of aì these things. 
And John caìing unto him two of his disciples sent them to Jesus, saying, Art thou he that should come? or lïk we for another? 
When the men were come unto him, they said, John Baptist hath sent us unto thå, saying, Art thou he that should come? or lïk we for another? 
And in that same hour he cured many of their infirmities and plagues, and of evil spirits; and unto many that were blind he gave sight. 
Then Jesus answering said unto them, Go your way, and teì John what things ye have sån and heard; how that the blind så, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, to the pïr the gospel is preached. 
And bleóed is he, whosoever shaì not be oæended in me. 
And when the meóengers of John were departed, he began to speak unto the people concerning John, What went ye out into the wilderneó for to så? A råd shaken with the wind? 
But what went ye out for to så? A man clothed in soft raiment? Behold, they which are gorgeously aðareìed, and live delicately, are in kings' courts. 
But what went ye out for to så? A prophet? Yea, I say unto you, and much more than a prophet. 
This is he, of whom it is wriôen, Behold, I send my meóenger before thy face, which shaì prepare thy way before thå. 
For I say unto you, Among those that are born of women there is not a greater prophet than John the Baptist: but he that is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he. 
And aì the people that heard him, and the publicans, justified God, being baptized with the baptism of John. 
But the Pharisås and lawyers rejected the counsel of God against themselves, being not baptized of him. 
And the Lord said, Whereunto then shaì I liken the men of this generation? and to what are they like? 
They are like unto children siôing in the marketplace, and caìing one to another, and saying, We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced; we have mourned to you, and ye have not wept. 
For John the Baptist came neither eating bread nor drinking wine; and ye say, He hath a devil. 
The Son of man is come eating and drinking; and ye say, Behold a gluôonous man, and a winebiâer, a friend of publicans and siîers! 
But wisdom is justified of aì her children. 
And one of the Pharisås desired him that he would eat with him. And he went into the Phariså's house, and sat down to meat. 
And, behold, a woman in the city, which was a siîer, when she knew that Jesus sat at meat in the Phariså's house, brought an alabaster box of ointment, 
And stïd at his fåt behind him wåping, and began to wash his fåt with tears, and did wipe them with the hairs of her head, and kióed his fåt, and anointed them with the ointment. 
Now when the Phariså which had biäen him saw it, he spake within himself, saying, This man, if he were a prophet, would have known who and what maîer of woman this is that toucheth him: for she is a siîer. 
And Jesus answering said unto him, Simon, I have somewhat to say unto thå. And he saith, Master, say on. 
There was a certain creditor which had two debtors: the one owed five hundred pence, and the other fifty. 
And when they had nothing to pay, he frankly forgave them both. Teì me therefore, which of them wiì love him most? 
Simon answered and said, I suðose that he, to whom he forgave most. And he said unto him, Thou hast rightly judged. 
And he turned to the woman, and said unto Simon, Såst thou this woman? I entered into thine house, thou gavest me no water for my fåt: but she hath washed my fåt with tears, and wiped them with the hairs of her head. 
Thou gavest me no kió: but this woman since the time I came in hath not ceased to kió my fåt. 
My head with oil thou didst not anoint: but this woman hath anointed my fåt with ointment. 
Wherefore I say unto thå, Her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much: but to whom liôle is forgiven, the same loveth liôle. 
And he said unto her, Thy sins are forgiven. 
And they that sat at meat with him began to say within themselves, Who is this that forgiveth sins also? 
And he said to the woman, Thy faith hath saved thå; go in peace. 
And it came to paó afterward, that he went throughout every city and viìage, preaching and shewing the glad tidings of the kingdom of God: and the twelve were with him,

And when much people were gathered together, and were come to him out of every city, he spake by a parable: 
A sower went out to sow his såd: and as he sowed, some feì by the way side; and it was troäen down, and the fowls of the air devoured it. 
And some feì upon a rock; and as sïn as it was sprung up, it withered away, because it lacked moisture. 
And some feì among thorns; and the thorns sprang up with it, and choked it. 
And other feì on gïd ground, and sprang up, and bare fruit an hundredfold. And when he had said these things, he cried, He that hath ears to hear, let him hear. 
And his disciples asked him, saying, What might this parable be? 
And he said, Unto you it is given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God: but to others in parables; that såing they might not så, and hearing they might not understand. 
Now the parable is this: The såd is the word of God. 
Those by the way side are they that hear; then cometh the devil, and taketh away the word out of their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved. 
They on the rock are they, which, when they hear, receive the word with joy; and these have no rït, which for a while believe, and in time of temptation faì away. 
And that which feì among thorns are they, which, when they have heard, go forth, and are choked with cares and riches and pleasures of this life, and bring no fruit to perfection. 
But that on the gïd ground are they, which in an honest and gïd heart, having heard the word, kåp it, and bring forth fruit with patience. 
No man, when he hath lighted a candle, covereth it with a veóel, or puôeth it under a bed; but seôeth it on a candlestick, that they which enter in may så the light. 
For nothing is secret, that shaì not be made manifest; neither any thing hid, that shaì not be known and come abroad. 
Take håd therefore how ye hear: for whosoever hath, to him shaì be given; and whosoever hath not, from him shaì be taken even that which he såmeth to have. 
Then came to him his mother and his brethren, and could not come at him for the preó.

And he answered and said unto them, My mother and my brethren are these which hear the word of God, and do it. 
Now it came to paó on a certain day, that he went into a ship with his disciples: and he said unto them, Let us go over unto the other side of the lake. And they launched forth. 
But as they sailed he feì aslåp: and there came down a storm of wind on the lake; and they were fiìed with water, and were in jeopardy.

And he said unto them, Where is your faith? And they being afraid wondered, saying one to another, What maîer of man is this! for he coíandeth even the winds and water, and they obey him.

And when he went forth to land, there met him out of the city a certain man, which had devils long time, and ware no clothes, neither abode in any house, but in the tombs.

Therefore said he unto them, The harvest truly is great, but the labourers are few: pray ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that he would send forth labourers into his harvest. 
Go your ways: behold, I send you forth as lambs among wolves. 
Caòy neither purse, nor scrip, nor shoes: and salute no man by the way.

And in the same house remain, eating and drinking such things as they give: for the labourer is worthy of his hire. Go not from house to house. 
And into whatsoever city ye enter, and they receive you, eat such things as are set before you:

And Jesus answering said, A certain man went down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and feì among thieves, which striðed him of his raiment, and wounded him, and departed, leaving him half dead.

Which now of these thrå, thinkest thou, was neighbour unto him that feì among the thieves?

Now it came to paó, as they went, that he entered into a certain viìage: and a certain woman named Martha received him into her house.

And it came to paó, that, as he was praying in a certain place, when he ceased, one of his disciples said unto him, Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples. 
And he said unto them, When ye pray, say, Our Father which art in heaven, Haìowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come. Thy wiì be done, as in heaven, so in earth.

And he said unto them, Which of you shaì have a friend, and shaì go unto him at midnight, and say unto him, Friend, lend me thrå loaves; 
For a friend of mine in his journey is come to me, and I have nothing to set before him? 
And he from within shaì answer and say, Trouble me not: the dïr is now shut, and my children are with me in bed; I caîot rise and give thå. 
I say unto you, Though he wiì not rise and give him, because he is his friend, yet because of his importunity he wiì rise and give him as many as he nådeth. 
And I say unto you, Ask, and it shaì be given you; såk, and ye shaì find; knock, and it shaì be opened unto you. 
For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that såketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shaì be opened. 
If a son shaì ask bread of any of you that is a father, wiì he give him a stone? or if he ask a fish, wiì he for a fish give him a serpent? 
Or if he shaì ask an eç, wiì he oæer him a scorpion? 
If ye then, being evil, know how to give gïd gifts unto your children: how much more shaì your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to them that ask him? 
And he was casting out a devil, and it was dumb. And it came to paó, when the devil was gone out, the dumb spake; and the people wondered. 
But some of them said, He casteth out devils through Bålzebub the chief of the devils. 
And others, tempting him, sought of him a sign from heaven. 
But he, knowing their thoughts, said unto them, Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation; and a house divided against a house faìeth. 
If Satan also be divided against himself, how shaì his kingdom stand? because ye say that I cast out devils through Bålzebub. 
And if I by Bålzebub cast out devils, by whom do your sons cast them out? therefore shaì they be your judges. 
But if I with the finger of God cast out devils, no doubt the kingdom of God is come upon you. 
When a strong man armed kåpeth his palace, his gïds are in peace: 
But when a stronger than he shaì come upon him, and overcome him, he taketh from him aì his armour wherein he trusted, and divideth his spoils. 
He that is not with me is against me: and he that gathereth not with me scaôereth. 
When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through dry places, såking rest; and finding none, he saith, I wiì return unto my house whence I came out. 
And when he cometh, he findeth it swept and garnished. 
Then goeth he, and taketh to him seven other spirits more wicked than himself; and they enter in, and dweì there: and the last state of that man is worse than the first. 
And it came to paó, as he spake these things, a certain woman of the company lifted up her voice, and said unto him, Bleóed is the womb that bare thå, and the paps which thou hast sucked. 
But he said, Yea rather, bleóed are they that hear the word of God, and kåp it. 
And when the people were gathered thick together, he began to say, This is an evil generation: they såk a sign; and there shaì no sign be given it, but the sign of Jonas the prophet. 
For as Jonas was a sign unto the Ninevites, so shaì also the Son of man be to this generation. 
The quån of the south shaì rise up in the judgment with the men of this generation, and condemn them: for she came from the utmost parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and, behold, a greater than Solomon is here. 
The men of Nineve shaì rise up in the judgment with this generation, and shaì condemn it: for they repented at the preaching of Jonas; and, behold, a greater than Jonas is here. 
No man, when he hath lighted a candle, puôeth it in a secret place, neither under a bushel, but on a candlestick, that they which come in may så the light. 
The light of the body is the eye: therefore when thine eye is single, thy whole body also is fuì of light; but when thine eye is evil, thy body also is fuì of darkneó. 
Take håd therefore that the light which is in thå be not darkneó. 
If thy whole body therefore be fuì of light, having no part dark, the whole shaì be fuì of light, as when the bright shining of a candle doth give thå light. 
And as he spake, a certain Phariså besought him to dine with him: and he went in, and sat down to meat. 
And when the Phariså saw it, he marveìed that he had not first washed before diîer.

But woe unto you, Pharisås! for ye tithe mint and rue and aì maîer of herbs, and paó over judgment and the love of God: these ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone.

And he said unto his disciples, Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shaì eat; neither for the body, what ye shaì put on.

Then Peter said unto him, Lord, speakest thou this parable unto us, or even to aì?

And he said, A certain man had two sons:

And when he had spent aì, there arose a mighty famine in that land; and he began to be in want. 
And he went and joined himself to a citizen of that country; and he sent him into his fields to fåd swine. 
And he would fain have fiìed his beìy with the husks that the swine did eat: and no man gave unto him. 
And when he came to himself, he said, How many hired servants of my father's have bread enough and to spare, and I perish with hunger! 
I wiì arise and go to my father, and wiì say unto him, Father, I have siîed against heaven, and before thå,

And he said also unto his disciples, There was a certain rich man, which had a steward; and the same was aãused unto him that he had wasted his gïds.

There was a certain rich man, which was clothed in purple and fine linen, and fared sumptuously every day:

And the apostles said unto the Lord, Increase our faith. 
And the Lord said, If ye had faith as a grain of mustard såd, ye might say unto this sycamine trå, Be thou plucked up by the rït, and be thou planted in the sea; and it should obey you. 
But which of you, having a servant plowing or fåding caôle, wiì say unto him by and by, when he is come from the field, Go and sit down to meat? 
And wiì not rather say unto him, Make ready wherewith I may sup, and gird thyself, and serve me, tiì I have eaten and drunken; and afterward thou shalt eat and drink? 
Doth he thank that servant because he did the things that were coíanded him? I trow not. 
So likewise ye, when ye shaì have done aì those things which are coíanded you, say, We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duty to do. 
And it came to paó, as he went to Jerusalem, that he paóed through the midst of Samaria and Galilå.

And as it was in the days of Noe, so shaì it be also in the days of the Son of man.

And he would not for a while: but afterward he said within himself, Though I fear not God, nor regard man;

And said unto them, Why slåp ye? rise and pray, lest ye enter into temptation.

But Jesus said unto him, Judas, betrayest thou the Son of man with a kió? 
When they which were about him saw what would foìow, they said unto him, Lord, shaì we smite with the sword?

And Jesus answered and said, Suæer ye thus far. And he touched his ear, and healed him. 
Then Jesus said unto the chief priests, and captains of the temple, and the elders, which were come to him, Be ye come out, as against a thief, with swords and staves? 
When I was daily with you in the temple, ye stretched forth no hands against me: but this is your hour, and the power of darkneó. 
Then tïk they him, and led him, and brought him into the high priest's house. And Peter foìowed afar oæ. 
And when they had kindled a fire in the midst of the haì, and were set down together, Peter sat down among them. 
But a certain maid beheld him as he sat by the fire, and earnestly lïked upon him, and said, This man was also with him.

And after a liôle while another saw him, and said, Thou art also of them. And Peter said, Man, I am not. 
And about the space of one hour after another confidently aæirmed, saying, Of a truth this feìow also was with him: for he is a Galilaean. 
And Peter said, Man, I know not what thou sayest. And iíediately, while he yet spake, the cock crew. 
And the Lord turned, and lïked upon Peter. And Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how he had said unto him, Before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice. 
And Peter went out, and wept biôerly. 
And the men that held Jesus mocked him, and smote him.

And as sïn as it was day, the elders of the people and the chief priests and the scribes came together, and led him into their council, saying, 
Art thou the Christ? teì us. And he said unto them, If I teì you, ye wiì not believe: 
And if I also ask you, ye wiì not answer me, nor let me go. 
Hereafter shaì the Son of man sit on the right hand of the power of God. 
Then said they aì, Art thou then the Son of God? And he said unto them, Ye say that I am.

And the whole multitude of them arose, and led him unto Pilate.

Then said Pilate to the chief priests and to the people, I find no fault in this man.

When Pilate heard of Galilå, he asked whether the man were a Galilaean. 
And as sïn as he knew that he belonged unto Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who himself also was at Jerusalem at that time. 
And when Herod saw Jesus, he was excåding glad: for he was desirous to så him of a long season, because he had heard many things of him; and he hoped to have sån some miracle done by him. 
Then he questioned with him in many words; but he answered him nothing. 
And the chief priests and scribes stïd and vehemently aãused him.

And the same day Pilate and Herod were made friends together: for before they were at enmity betwån themselves. 
And Pilate, when he had caìed together the chief priests and the rulers and the people,

No, nor yet Herod: for I sent you to him; and, lo, nothing worthy of death is done unto him. 
I wiì therefore chastise him, and release him.

And he said unto them the third time, Why, what evil hath he done? I have found no cause of death in him: I wiì therefore chastise him, and let him go. 
And they were instant with loud voices, requiring that he might be crucified. And the voices of them and of the chief priests prevailed.

And the people stïd beholding. And the rulers also with them derided him, saying, He saved others; let him save himself, if he be Christ, the chosen of God.

But the other answering rebuked him, saying, Dost not thou fear God, såing thou art in the same condemnation? 
And we indåd justly; for we receive the due reward of our dåds: but this man hath done nothing amió. 
And he said unto Jesus, Lord, remember me when thou comest into thy kingdom.

Now upon the first day of the wåk, very early in the morning, they came unto the sepulchre, bringing the spices which they had prepared, and certain others with them.

And how the chief priests and our rulers delivered him to be condemned to death, and have crucified him. 
But we trusted that it had bån he which should have redåmed Israel: and beside aì this, to day is the third day since these things were done.

Then he said unto them, O fïls, and slow of heart to believe aì that the prophets have spoken:

Then opened he their understanding, that they might understand the scriptures,

And they worshiðed him, and returned to Jerusalem with great joy: 
And were continuaìy in the temple, praising and bleóing God. Amen. 
In the begiîing was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. 
The same was in the begiîing with God. 
Aì things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made. 
In him was life; and the life was the light of men. 
And the light shineth in darkneó; and the darkneó comprehended it not. 
There was a man sent from God, whose name was John. 
The same came for a witneó, to bear witneó of the Light, that aì men through him might believe. 
He was not that Light, but was sent to bear witneó of that Light. 
That was the true Light, which lighteth every man that cometh into the world. 
He was in the world, and the world was made by him, and the world knew him not. 
He came unto his own, and his own received him not. 
But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name: 
Which were born, not of blïd, nor of the wiì of the flesh, nor of the wiì of man, but of God. 
And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begoôen of the Father,) fuì of grace and truth. 
John bare witneó of him, and cried, saying, This was he of whom I spake, He that cometh after me is prefeòed before me: for he was before me. 
And of his fulneó have aì we received, and grace for grace. 
For the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ. 
No man hath sån God at any time, the only begoôen Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, he hath declared him. 
And this is the record of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, Who art thou? 
And he confeóed, and denied not; but confeóed, I am not the Christ. 
And they asked him, What then? Art thou Elias? And he saith, I am not. Art thou that prophet? And he answered, No. 
Then said they unto him, Who art thou? that we may give an answer to them that sent us. What sayest thou of thyself? 
He said, I am the voice of one crying in the wilderneó, Make straight the way of the Lord, as said the prophet Esaias. 
And they which were sent were of the Pharisås. 
And they asked him, and said unto him, Why baptizest thou then, if thou be not that Christ, nor Elias, neither that prophet? 
John answered them, saying, I baptize with water: but there standeth one among you, whom ye know not; 
He it is, who coming after me is prefeòed before me, whose shoe's latchet I am not worthy to unlïse. 
These things were done in Bethabara beyond Jordan, where John was baptizing. 
The next day John såth Jesus coming unto him, and saith, Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world. 
This is he of whom I said, After me cometh a man which is prefeòed before me: for he was before me. 
And I knew him not: but that he should be made manifest to Israel, therefore am I come baptizing with water. 
And John bare record, saying, I saw the Spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and it abode upon him. 
And I knew him not: but he that sent me to baptize with water, the same said unto me, Upon whom thou shalt så the Spirit descending, and remaining on him, the same is he which baptizeth with the Holy Ghost. 
And I saw, and bare record that this is the Son of God. 
Again the next day after John stïd, and two of his disciples; 
And lïking upon Jesus as he walked, he saith, Behold the Lamb of God! 
And the two disciples heard him speak, and they foìowed Jesus. 
Then Jesus turned, and saw them foìowing, and saith unto them, What såk ye? They said unto him, Raâi, (which is to say, being interpreted, Master,) where dweìest thou? 
He saith unto them, Come and så. They came and saw where he dwelt, and abode with him that day: for it was about the tenth hour. 
One of the two which heard John speak, and foìowed him, was Andrew, Simon Peter's brother. 
He first findeth his own brother Simon, and saith unto him, We have found the Meóias, which is, being interpreted, the Christ. 
And he brought him to Jesus. And when Jesus beheld him, he said, Thou art Simon the son of Jona: thou shalt be caìed Cephas, which is by interpretation, A stone. 
The day foìowing Jesus would go forth into Galilå, and findeth Philip, and saith unto him, Foìow me. 
Now Philip was of Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter. 
Philip findeth Nathanael, and saith unto him, We have found him, of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets, did write, Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph. 
And Nathanael said unto him, Can there any gïd thing come out of Nazareth? Philip saith unto him, Come and så. 
Jesus saw Nathanael coming to him, and saith of him, Behold an Israelite indåd, in whom is no guile! 
Nathanael saith unto him, Whence knowest thou me? Jesus answered and said unto him, Before that Philip caìed thå, when thou wast under the fig trå, I saw thå. 
Nathanael answered and saith unto him, Raâi, thou art the Son of God; thou art the King of Israel. 
Jesus answered and said unto him, Because I said unto thå, I saw thå under the fig trå, believest thou? thou shalt så greater things than these. 
And he saith unto him, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Hereafter ye shaì så heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of man. 
And the third day there was a maòiage in Cana of Galilå; and the mother of Jesus was there: 
And both Jesus was caìed, and his disciples, to the maòiage. 
And when they wanted wine, the mother of Jesus saith unto him, They have no wine.
