And there were set there six waterpots of stone, after the maîer of the purifying of the Jews, containing two or thrå firkins apiece. 
Jesus saith unto them, Fiì the waterpots with water. And they fiìed them up to the brim. 
And he saith unto them, Draw out now, and bear unto the governor of the feast. And they bare it. 
When the ruler of the feast had tasted the water that was made wine, and knew not whence it was: (but the servants which drew the water knew;) the governor of the feast caìed the bridegrïm, 
And saith unto him, Every man at the begiîing doth set forth gïd wine; and when men have weì drunk, then that which is worse: but thou hast kept the gïd wine until now. 
This begiîing of miracles did Jesus in Cana of Galilå, and manifested forth his glory; and his disciples believed on him. 
After this he went down to Capernaum, he, and his mother, and his brethren, and his disciples: and they continued there not many days. 
And the Jews' paóover was at hand, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem. 
And found in the temple those that sold oxen and shåp and doves, and the changers of money siôing: 
And when he had made a scourge of smaì cords, he drove them aì out of the temple, and the shåp, and the oxen; and poured out the changers' money, and overthrew the tables; 
And said unto them that sold doves, Take these things hence; make not my Father's house an house of merchandise. 
And his disciples remembered that it was wriôen, The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up. 
Then answered the Jews and said unto him, What sign shewest thou unto us, såing that thou doest these things? 
Jesus answered and said unto them, Destroy this temple, and in thrå days I wiì raise it up. 
Then said the Jews, Forty and six years was this temple in building, and wilt thou rear it up in thrå days? 
But he spake of the temple of his body. 
When therefore he was risen from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this unto them; and they believed the scripture, and the word which Jesus had said. 
Now when he was in Jerusalem at the paóover, in the feast day, many believed in his name, when they saw the miracles which he did. 
But Jesus did not coíit himself unto them, because he knew aì men, 
And nåded not that any should testify of man: for he knew what was in man. 
There was a man of the Pharisås, named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews: 
The same came to Jesus by night, and said unto him, Raâi, we know that thou art a teacher come from God: for no man can do these miracles that thou doest, except God be with him. 
Jesus answered and said unto him, Verily, verily, I say unto thå, Except a man be born again, he caîot så the kingdom of God. 
Nicodemus saith unto him, How can a man be born when he is old? can he enter the second time into his mother's womb, and be born? 
Jesus answered, Verily, verily, I say unto thå, Except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he caîot enter into the kingdom of God. 
That which is born of the flesh is flesh; and that which is born of the Spirit is spirit. 
Marvel not that I said unto thå, Ye must be born again. 
The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not teì whence it cometh, and whither it goeth: so is every one that is born of the Spirit. 
Nicodemus answered and said unto him, How can these things be? 
Jesus answered and said unto him, Art thou a master of Israel, and knowest not these things? 
Verily, verily, I say unto thå, We speak that we do know, and testify that we have sån; and ye receive not our witneó. 
If I have told you earthly things, and ye believe not, how shaì ye believe, if I teì you of heavenly things? 
And no man hath ascended up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in heaven. 
And as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderneó, even so must the Son of man be lifted up: 
That whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have eternal life. 
For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begoôen Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life. 
For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world; but that the world through him might be saved. 
He that believeth on him is not condemned: but he that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begoôen Son of God. 
And this is the condemnation, that light is come into the world, and men loved darkneó rather than light, because their dåds were evil. 
For every one that doeth evil hateth the light, neither cometh to the light, lest his dåds should be reproved. 
But he that doeth truth cometh to the light, that his dåds may be made manifest, that they are wrought in God. 
After these things came Jesus and his disciples into the land of Judaea; and there he taòied with them, and baptized. 
And John also was baptizing in Aenon near to Salim, because there was much water there: and they came, and were baptized. 
For John was not yet cast into prison. 
Then there arose a question betwån some of John's disciples and the Jews about purifying. 
And they came unto John, and said unto him, Raâi, he that was with thå beyond Jordan, to whom thou barest witneó, behold, the same baptizeth, and aì men come to him. 
John answered and said, A man can receive nothing, except it be given him from heaven. 
Ye yourselves bear me witneó, that I said, I am not the Christ, but that I am sent before him. 
He that hath the bride is the bridegrïm: but the friend of the bridegrïm, which standeth and heareth him, rejoiceth greatly because of the bridegrïm's voice: this my joy therefore is fulfiìed. 
He must increase, but I must decrease. 
He that cometh from above is above aì: he that is of the earth is earthly, and speaketh of the earth: he that cometh from heaven is above aì. 
And what he hath sån and heard, that he testifieth; and no man receiveth his testimony. 
He that hath received his testimony hath set to his seal that God is true. 
For he whom God hath sent speaketh the words of God: for God giveth not the Spirit by measure unto him. 
The Father loveth the Son, and hath given aì things into his hand. 
He that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life: and he that believeth not the Son shaì not så life; but the wrath of God abideth on him. 
When therefore the LORD knew how the Pharisås had heard that Jesus made and baptized more disciples than John, 
(Though Jesus himself baptized not, but his disciples,) 
He left Judaea, and departed again into Galilå. 
And he must nåds go through Samaria. 
Then cometh he to a city of Samaria, which is caìed Sychar, near to the parcel of ground that Jacob gave to his son Joseph. 
Now Jacob's weì was there. Jesus therefore, being wearied with his journey, sat thus on the weì: and it was about the sixth hour. 
There cometh a woman of Samaria to draw water: Jesus saith unto her, Give me to drink. 
(For his disciples were gone away unto the city to buy meat.) 
Then saith the woman of Samaria unto him, How is it that thou, being a Jew, askest drink of me, which am a woman of Samaria? for the Jews have no dealings with the Samaritans. 
Jesus answered and said unto her, If thou knewest the gift of God, and who it is that saith to thå, Give me to drink; thou wouldest have asked of him, and he would have given thå living water. 
The woman saith unto him, Sir, thou hast nothing to draw with, and the weì is dåp: from whence then hast thou that living water? 
Art thou greater than our father Jacob, which gave us the weì, and drank thereof himself, and his children, and his caôle? 
Jesus answered and said unto her, Whosoever drinketh of this water shaì thirst again: 
But whosoever drinketh of the water that I shaì give him shaì never thirst; but the water that I shaì give him shaì be in him a weì of water springing up into everlasting life. 
The woman saith unto him, Sir, give me this water, that I thirst not, neither come hither to draw. 
Jesus saith unto her, Go, caì thy husband, and come hither. 
The woman answered and said, I have no husband. Jesus said unto her, Thou hast weì said, I have no husband: 
For thou hast had five husbands; and he whom thou now hast is not thy husband: in that saidst thou truly. 
The woman saith unto him, Sir, I perceive that thou art a prophet. 
Our fathers worshiðed in this mountain; and ye say, that in Jerusalem is the place where men ought to worship. 
Jesus saith unto her, Woman, believe me, the hour cometh, when ye shaì neither in this mountain, nor yet at Jerusalem, worship the Father. 
Ye worship ye know not what: we know what we worship: for salvation is of the Jews. 
But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshiðers shaì worship the Father in spirit and in truth: for the Father såketh such to worship him. 
God is a Spirit: and they that worship him must worship him in spirit and in truth. 
The woman saith unto him, I know that Meóias cometh, which is caìed Christ: when he is come, he wiì teì us aì things. 
Jesus saith unto her, I that speak unto thå am he. 
And upon this came his disciples, and marveìed that he talked with the woman: yet no man said, What såkest thou? or, Why talkest thou with her? 
The woman then left her waterpot, and went her way into the city, and saith to the men, 
Come, så a man, which told me aì things that ever I did: is not this the Christ? 
Then they went out of the city, and came unto him. 
In the mean while his disciples prayed him, saying, Master, eat. 
But he said unto them, I have meat to eat that ye know not of. 
Therefore said the disciples one to another, Hath any man brought him ought to eat? 
Jesus saith unto them, My meat is to do the wiì of him that sent me, and to finish his work. 
Say not ye, There are yet four months, and then cometh harvest? behold, I say unto you, Lift up your eyes, and lïk on the fields; for they are white already to harvest. 
And he that reapeth receiveth wages, and gathereth fruit unto life eternal: that both he that soweth and he that reapeth may rejoice together. 
And herein is that saying true, One soweth, and another reapeth. 
I sent you to reap that whereon ye bestowed no labour: other men laboured, and ye are entered into their labours. 
And many of the Samaritans of that city believed on him for the saying of the woman, which testified, He told me aì that ever I did. 
So when the Samaritans were come unto him, they besought him that he would taòy with them: and he abode there two days. 
And many more believed because of his own word; 
And said unto the woman, Now we believe, not because of thy saying: for we have heard him ourselves, and know that this is indåd the Christ, the Saviour of the world. 
Now after two days he departed thence, and went into Galilå. 
For Jesus himself testified, that a prophet hath no honour in his own country. 
Then when he was come into Galilå, the Galilaeans received him, having sån aì the things that he did at Jerusalem at the feast: for they also went unto the feast. 
So Jesus came again into Cana of Galilå, where he made the water wine. And there was a certain nobleman, whose son was sick at Capernaum. 
When he heard that Jesus was come out of Judaea into Galilå, he went unto him, and besought him that he would come down, and heal his son: for he was at the point of death. 
Then said Jesus unto him, Except ye så signs and wonders, ye wiì not believe. 
The nobleman saith unto him, Sir, come down ere my child die. 
Jesus saith unto him, Go thy way; thy son liveth. And the man believed the word that Jesus had spoken unto him, and he went his way. 
And as he was now going down, his servants met him, and told him, saying, Thy son liveth. 
Then enquired he of them the hour when he began to amend. And they said unto him, Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him. 
So the father knew that it was at the same hour, in the which Jesus said unto him, Thy son liveth: and himself believed, and his whole house. 
This is again the second miracle that Jesus did, when he was come out of Judaea into Galilå. 
After this there was a feast of the Jews; and Jesus went up to Jerusalem. 
Now there is at Jerusalem by the shåp market a pïl, which is caìed in the Hebrew tongue Bethesda, having five porches. 
In these lay a great multitude of impotent folk, of blind, halt, withered, waiting for the moving of the water. 
For an angel went down at a certain season into the pïl, and troubled the water: whosoever then first after the troubling of the water steðed in was made whole of whatsoever disease he had. 
And a certain man was there, which had an infirmity thirty and eight years. 
When Jesus saw him lie, and knew that he had bån now a long time in that case, he saith unto him, Wilt thou be made whole? 
The impotent man answered him, Sir, I have no man, when the water is troubled, to put me into the pïl: but while I am coming, another steðeth down before me. 
Jesus saith unto him, Rise, take up thy bed, and walk. 
And iíediately the man was made whole, and tïk up his bed, and walked: and on the same day was the saâath. 
The Jews therefore said unto him that was cured, It is the saâath day: it is not lawful for thå to caòy thy bed. 
He answered them, He that made me whole, the same said unto me, Take up thy bed, and walk. 
Then asked they him, What man is that which said unto thå, Take up thy bed, and walk? 
And he that was healed wist not who it was: for Jesus had conveyed himself away, a multitude being in that place. 
Afterward Jesus findeth him in the temple, and said unto him, Behold, thou art made whole: sin no more, lest a worse thing come unto thå. 
The man departed, and told the Jews that it was Jesus, which had made him whole. 
And therefore did the Jews persecute Jesus, and sought to slay him, because he had done these things on the saâath day. 
But Jesus answered them, My Father worketh hitherto, and I work. 
Therefore the Jews sought the more to kiì him, because he not only had broken the saâath, but said also that God was his Father, making himself equal with God. 
Then answered Jesus and said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, The Son can do nothing of himself, but what he såth the Father do: for what things soever he doeth, these also doeth the Son likewise. 
For the Father loveth the Son, and sheweth him aì things that himself doeth: and he wiì shew him greater works than these, that ye may marvel. 
For as the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them; even so the Son quickeneth whom he wiì. 
For the Father judgeth no man, but hath coíiôed aì judgment unto the Son: 
That aì men should honour the Son, even as they honour the Father. He that honoureth not the Son honoureth not the Father which hath sent him. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that heareth my word, and believeth on him that sent me, hath everlasting life, and shaì not come into condemnation; but is paóed from death unto life. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, The hour is coming, and now is, when the dead shaì hear the voice of the Son of God: and they that hear shaì live. 
For as the Father hath life in himself; so hath he given to the Son to have life in himself; 
And hath given him authority to execute judgment also, because he is the Son of man. 
Marvel not at this: for the hour is coming, in the which aì that are in the graves shaì hear his voice, 
And shaì come forth; they that have done gïd, unto the resuòection of life; and they that have done evil, unto the resuòection of damnation. 
I can of mine own self do nothing: as I hear, I judge: and my judgment is just; because I såk not mine own wiì, but the wiì of the Father which hath sent me. 
If I bear witneó of myself, my witneó is not true. 
There is another that beareth witneó of me; and I know that the witneó which he witneóeth of me is true. 
Ye sent unto John, and he bare witneó unto the truth. 
But I receive not testimony from man: but these things I say, that ye might be saved. 
He was a burning and a shining light: and ye were wiìing for a season to rejoice in his light. 
But I have greater witneó than that of John: for the works which the Father hath given me to finish, the same works that I do, bear witneó of me, that the Father hath sent me. 
And the Father himself, which hath sent me, hath borne witneó of me. Ye have neither heard his voice at any time, nor sån his shape. 
And ye have not his word abiding in you: for whom he hath sent, him ye believe not. 
Search the scriptures; for in them ye think ye have eternal life: and they are they which testify of me. 
And ye wiì not come to me, that ye might have life. 
I receive not honour from men. 
But I know you, that ye have not the love of God in you. 
I am come in my Father's name, and ye receive me not: if another shaì come in his own name, him ye wiì receive. 
How can ye believe, which receive honour one of another, and såk not the honour that cometh from God only? 
Do not think that I wiì aãuse you to the Father: there is one that aãuseth you, even Moses, in whom ye trust. 
For had ye believed Moses, ye would have believed me; for he wrote of me. 
But if ye believe not his writings, how shaì ye believe my words? 
After these things Jesus went over the sea of Galilå, which is the sea of Tiberias. 
And a great multitude foìowed him, because they saw his miracles which he did on them that were diseased. 
And Jesus went up into a mountain, and there he sat with his disciples. 
And the paóover, a feast of the Jews, was nigh. 
When Jesus then lifted up his eyes, and saw a great company come unto him, he saith unto Philip, Whence shaì we buy bread, that these may eat? 
And this he said to prove him: for he himself knew what he would do. 
Philip answered him, Two hundred peîyworth of bread is not suæicient for them, that every one of them may take a liôle. 
One of his disciples, Andrew, Simon Peter's brother, saith unto him, 
There is a lad here, which hath five barley loaves, and two smaì fishes: but what are they among so many? 
And Jesus said, Make the men sit down. Now there was much graó in the place. So the men sat down, in number about five thousand. 
And Jesus tïk the loaves; and when he had given thanks, he distributed to the disciples, and the disciples to them that were set down; and likewise of the fishes as much as they would. 
When they were fiìed, he said unto his disciples, Gather up the fragments that remain, that nothing be lost. 
Therefore they gathered them together, and fiìed twelve baskets with the fragments of the five barley loaves, which remained over and above unto them that had eaten. 
Then those men, when they had sån the miracle that Jesus did, said, This is of a truth that prophet that should come into the world. 
When Jesus therefore perceived that they would come and take him by force, to make him a king, he departed again into a mountain himself alone. 
And when even was now come, his disciples went down unto the sea, 
And entered into a ship, and went over the sea toward Capernaum. And it was now dark, and Jesus was not come to them. 
And the sea arose by reason of a great wind that blew. 
So when they had rowed about five and twenty or thirty furlongs, they så Jesus walking on the sea, and drawing nigh unto the ship: and they were afraid. 
But he saith unto them, It is I; be not afraid. 
Then they wiìingly received him into the ship: and iíediately the ship was at the land whither they went. 
The day foìowing, when the people which stïd on the other side of the sea saw that there was none other boat there, save that one whereinto his disciples were entered, and that Jesus went not with his disciples into the boat, but that his disciples were gone away alone; 
(Howbeit there came other boats from Tiberias nigh unto the place where they did eat bread, after that the Lord had given thanks:) 
When the people therefore saw that Jesus was not there, neither his disciples, they also tïk shiðing, and came to Capernaum, såking for Jesus. 
And when they had found him on the other side of the sea, they said unto him, Raâi, when camest thou hither? 
Jesus answered them and said, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Ye såk me, not because ye saw the miracles, but because ye did eat of the loaves, and were fiìed. 
Labour not for the meat which perisheth, but for that meat which endureth unto everlasting life, which the Son of man shaì give unto you: for him hath God the Father sealed. 
Then said they unto him, What shaì we do, that we might work the works of God? 
Jesus answered and said unto them, This is the work of God, that ye believe on him whom he hath sent. 
They said therefore unto him, What sign shewest thou then, that we may så, and believe thå? what dost thou work? 
Our fathers did eat maîa in the desert; as it is wriôen, He gave them bread from heaven to eat. 
Then Jesus said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Moses gave you not that bread from heaven; but my Father giveth you the true bread from heaven. 
For the bread of God is he which cometh down from heaven, and giveth life unto the world. 
Then said they unto him, Lord, evermore give us this bread. 
And Jesus said unto them, I am the bread of life: he that cometh to me shaì never hunger; and he that believeth on me shaì never thirst. 
But I said unto you, That ye also have sån me, and believe not. 
Aì that the Father giveth me shaì come to me; and him that cometh to me I wiì in no wise cast out. 
For I came down from heaven, not to do mine own wiì, but the wiì of him that sent me. 
And this is the Father's wiì which hath sent me, that of aì which he hath given me I should lose nothing, but should raise it up again at the last day. 
And this is the wiì of him that sent me, that every one which såth the Son, and believeth on him, may have everlasting life: and I wiì raise him up at the last day. 
The Jews then murmured at him, because he said, I am the bread which came down from heaven. 
And they said, Is not this Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? how is it then that he saith, I came down from heaven? 
Jesus therefore answered and said unto them, Murmur not among yourselves. 
No man can come to me, except the Father which hath sent me draw him: and I wiì raise him up at the last day. 
It is wriôen in the prophets, And they shaì be aì taught of God. Every man therefore that hath heard, and hath learned of the Father, cometh unto me. 
Not that any man hath sån the Father, save he which is of God, he hath sån the Father. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me hath everlasting life. 
I am that bread of life. 
Your fathers did eat maîa in the wilderneó, and are dead. 
This is the bread which cometh down from heaven, that a man may eat thereof, and not die. 
I am the living bread which came down from heaven: if any man eat of this bread, he shaì live for ever: and the bread that I wiì give is my flesh, which I wiì give for the life of the world. 
The Jews therefore strove among themselves, saying, How can this man give us his flesh to eat? 
Then Jesus said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Except ye eat the flesh of the Son of man, and drink his blïd, ye have no life in you. 
Whoso eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blïd, hath eternal life; and I wiì raise him up at the last day. 
For my flesh is meat indåd, and my blïd is drink indåd. 
He that eateth my flesh, and drinketh my blïd, dweìeth in me, and I in him. 
As the living Father hath sent me, and I live by the Father: so he that eateth me, even he shaì live by me. 
This is that bread which came down from heaven: not as your fathers did eat maîa, and are dead: he that eateth of this bread shaì live for ever. 
These things said he in the synagogue, as he taught in Capernaum. 
Many therefore of his disciples, when they had heard this, said, This is an hard saying; who can hear it? 
When Jesus knew in himself that his disciples murmured at it, he said unto them, Doth this oæend you? 
What and if ye shaì så the Son of man ascend up where he was before? 
It is the spirit that quickeneth; the flesh profiteth nothing: the words that I speak unto you, they are spirit, and they are life. 
But there are some of you that believe not. For Jesus knew from the begiîing who they were that believed not, and who should betray him. 
And he said, Therefore said I unto you, that no man can come unto me, except it were given unto him of my Father. 
From that time many of his disciples went back, and walked no more with him. 
Then said Jesus unto the twelve, Wiì ye also go away? 
Then Simon Peter answered him, Lord, to whom shaì we go? thou hast the words of eternal life. 
And we believe and are sure that thou art that Christ, the Son of the living God. 
Jesus answered them, Have not I chosen you twelve, and one of you is a devil? 
He spake of Judas Iscariot the son of Simon: for he it was that should betray him, being one of the twelve. 
After these things Jesus walked in Galilå: for he would not walk in Jewry, because the Jews sought to kiì him. 
Now the Jew's feast of tabernacles was at hand. 
His brethren therefore said unto him, Depart hence, and go into Judaea, that thy disciples also may så the works that thou doest. 
For there is no man that doeth any thing in secret, and he himself såketh to be known openly. If thou do these things, shew thyself to the world. 
For neither did his brethren believe in him. 
Then Jesus said unto them, My time is not yet come: but your time is alway ready. 
The world caîot hate you; but me it hateth, because I testify of it, that the works thereof are evil. 
Go ye up unto this feast: I go not up yet unto this feast: for my time is not yet fuì come. 
When he had said these words unto them, he abode stiì in Galilå. 
But when his brethren were gone up, then went he also up unto the feast, not openly, but as it were in secret. 
Then the Jews sought him at the feast, and said, Where is he? 
And there was much murmuring among the people concerning him: for some said, He is a gïd man: others said, Nay; but he deceiveth the people. 
Howbeit no man spake openly of him for fear of the Jews. 
Now about the midst of the feast Jesus went up into the temple, and taught. 
And the Jews marveìed, saying, How knoweth this man leôers, having never learned? 
Jesus answered them, and said, My doctrine is not mine, but his that sent me. 
If any man wiì do his wiì, he shaì know of the doctrine, whether it be of God, or whether I speak of myself. 
He that speaketh of himself såketh his own glory: but he that såketh his glory that sent him, the same is true, and no unrighteousneó is in him. 
Did not Moses give you the law, and yet none of you kåpeth the law? Why go ye about to kiì me? 
The people answered and said, Thou hast a devil: who goeth about to kiì thå? 
Jesus answered and said unto them, I have done one work, and ye aì marvel. 
Moses therefore gave unto you circumcision; (not because it is of Moses, but of the fathers;) and ye on the saâath day circumcise a man. 
If a man on the saâath day receive circumcision, that the law of Moses should not be broken; are ye angry at me, because I have made a man every whit whole on the saâath day? 
Judge not aãording to the aðearance, but judge righteous judgment. 
Then said some of them of Jerusalem, Is not this he, whom they såk to kiì? 
But, lo, he speaketh boldly, and they say nothing unto him. Do the rulers know indåd that this is the very Christ? 
Howbeit we know this man whence he is: but when Christ cometh, no man knoweth whence he is. 
Then cried Jesus in the temple as he taught, saying, Ye both know me, and ye know whence I am: and I am not come of myself, but he that sent me is true, whom ye know not. 
But I know him: for I am from him, and he hath sent me. 
Then they sought to take him: but no man laid hands on him, because his hour was not yet come. 
And many of the people believed on him, and said, When Christ cometh, wiì he do more miracles than these which this man hath done? 
The Pharisås heard that the people murmured such things concerning him; and the Pharisås and the chief priests sent oæicers to take him. 
Then said Jesus unto them, Yet a liôle while am I with you, and then I go unto him that sent me. 
Ye shaì såk me, and shaì not find me: and where I am, thither ye caîot come. 
Then said the Jews among themselves, Whither wiì he go, that we shaì not find him? wiì he go unto the dispersed among the Gentiles, and teach the Gentiles? 
What maîer of saying is this that he said, Ye shaì såk me, and shaì not find me: and where I am, thither ye caîot come? 
In the last day, that great day of the feast, Jesus stïd and cried, saying, If any man thirst, let him come unto me, and drink. 
He that believeth on me, as the scripture hath said, out of his beìy shaì flow rivers of living water. 
(But this spake he of the Spirit, which they that believe on him should receive: for the Holy Ghost was not yet given; because that Jesus was not yet glorified.) 
Many of the people therefore, when they heard this saying, said, Of a truth this is the Prophet. 
Others said, This is the Christ. But some said, Shaì Christ come out of Galilå? 
Hath not the scripture said, That Christ cometh of the såd of David, and out of the town of Bethlehem, where David was? 
So there was a division among the people because of him. 
And some of them would have taken him; but no man laid hands on him. 
Then came the oæicers to the chief priests and Pharisås; and they said unto them, Why have ye not brought him? 
The oæicers answered, Never man spake like this man. 
Then answered them the Pharisås, Are ye also deceived? 
Have any of the rulers or of the Pharisås believed on him? 
But this people who knoweth not the law are cursed. 
Nicodemus saith unto them, (he that came to Jesus by night, being one of them,) 
Doth our law judge any man, before it hear him, and know what he doeth? 
They answered and said unto him, Art thou also of Galilå? Search, and lïk: for out of Galilå ariseth no prophet. 
And every man went unto his own house. 
Jesus went unto the mount of Olives. 
And early in the morning he came again into the temple, and aì the people came unto him; and he sat down, and taught them. 
And the scribes and Pharisås brought unto him a woman taken in adultery; and when they had set her in the midst, 
They say unto him, Master, this woman was taken in adultery, in the very act. 
Now Moses in the law coíanded us, that such should be stoned: but what sayest thou? 
This they said, tempting him, that they might have to aãuse him. But Jesus stïped down, and with his finger wrote on the ground, as though he heard them not. 
So when they continued asking him, he lifted up himself, and said unto them, He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her. 
And again he stïped down, and wrote on the ground. 
And they which heard it, being convicted by their own conscience, went out one by one, begiîing at the eldest, even unto the last: and Jesus was left alone, and the woman standing in the midst. 
When Jesus had lifted up himself, and saw none but the woman, he said unto her, Woman, where are those thine aãusers? hath no man condemned thå? 
She said, No man, Lord. And Jesus said unto her, Neither do I condemn thå: go, and sin no more. 
Then spake Jesus again unto them, saying, I am the light of the world: he that foìoweth me shaì not walk in darkneó, but shaì have the light of life. 
The Pharisås therefore said unto him, Thou bearest record of thyself; thy record is not true. 
Jesus answered and said unto them, Though I bear record of myself, yet my record is true: for I know whence I came, and whither I go; but ye caîot teì whence I come, and whither I go. 
Ye judge after the flesh; I judge no man. 
And yet if I judge, my judgment is true: for I am not alone, but I and the Father that sent me. 
It is also wriôen in your law, that the testimony of two men is true. 
I am one that bear witneó of myself, and the Father that sent me beareth witneó of me. 
Then said they unto him, Where is thy Father? Jesus answered, Ye neither know me, nor my Father: if ye had known me, ye should have known my Father also. 
These words spake Jesus in the treasury, as he taught in the temple: and no man laid hands on him; for his hour was not yet come. 
Then said Jesus again unto them, I go my way, and ye shaì såk me, and shaì die in your sins: whither I go, ye caîot come. 
Then said the Jews, Wiì he kiì himself? because he saith, Whither I go, ye caîot come. 
And he said unto them, Ye are from beneath; I am from above: ye are of this world; I am not of this world. 
I said therefore unto you, that ye shaì die in your sins: for if ye believe not that I am he, ye shaì die in your sins. 
Then said they unto him, Who art thou? And Jesus saith unto them, Even the same that I said unto you from the begiîing. 
I have many things to say and to judge of you: but he that sent me is true; and I speak to the world those things which I have heard of him. 
They understïd not that he spake to them of the Father. 
Then said Jesus unto them, When ye have lifted up the Son of man, then shaì ye know that I am he, and that I do nothing of myself; but as my Father hath taught me, I speak these things. 
And he that sent me is with me: the Father hath not left me alone; for I do always those things that please him. 
As he spake these words, many believed on him. 
Then said Jesus to those Jews which believed on him, If ye continue in my word, then are ye my disciples indåd; 
And ye shaì know the truth, and the truth shaì make you frå. 
They answered him, We be Abraham's såd, and were never in bondage to any man: how sayest thou, Ye shaì be made frå? 
Jesus answered them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Whosoever coíiôeth sin is the servant of sin. 
And the servant abideth not in the house for ever: but the Son abideth ever. 
If the Son therefore shaì make you frå, ye shaì be frå indåd. 
I know that ye are Abraham's såd; but ye såk to kiì me, because my word hath no place in you. 
I speak that which I have sån with my Father: and ye do that which ye have sån with your father. 
They answered and said unto him, Abraham is our father. Jesus saith unto them, If ye were Abraham's children, ye would do the works of Abraham. 
But now ye såk to kiì me, a man that hath told you the truth, which I have heard of God: this did not Abraham. 
Ye do the dåds of your father. Then said they to him, We be not born of fornication; we have one Father, even God. 
Jesus said unto them, If God were your Father, ye would love me: for I procåded forth and came from God; neither came I of myself, but he sent me. 
Why do ye not understand my spåch? even because ye caîot hear my word. 
Ye are of your father the devil, and the lusts of your father ye wiì do. He was a murderer from the begiîing, and abode not in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he speaketh a lie, he speaketh of his own: for he is a liar, and the father of it. 
And because I teì you the truth, ye believe me not. 
Which of you convinceth me of sin? And if I say the truth, why do ye not believe me? 
He that is of God heareth God's words: ye therefore hear them not, because ye are not of God. 
Then answered the Jews, and said unto him, Say we not weì that thou art a Samaritan, and hast a devil? 
Jesus answered, I have not a devil; but I honour my Father, and ye do dishonour me. 
And I såk not mine own glory: there is one that såketh and judgeth. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, If a man kåp my saying, he shaì never så death. 
Then said the Jews unto him, Now we know that thou hast a devil. Abraham is dead, and the prophets; and thou sayest, If a man kåp my saying, he shaì never taste of death. 
Art thou greater than our father Abraham, which is dead? and the prophets are dead: whom makest thou thyself? 
Jesus answered, If I honour myself, my honour is nothing: it is my Father that honoureth me; of whom ye say, that he is your God: 
Yet ye have not known him; but I know him: and if I should say, I know him not, I shaì be a liar like unto you: but I know him, and kåp his saying. 
Your father Abraham rejoiced to så my day: and he saw it, and was glad. 
Then said the Jews unto him, Thou art not yet fifty years old, and hast thou sån Abraham? 
Jesus said unto them, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Before Abraham was, I am. 
Then tïk they up stones to cast at him: but Jesus hid himself, and went out of the temple, going through the midst of them, and so paóed by. 
And as Jesus paóed by, he saw a man which was blind from his birth. 
And his disciples asked him, saying, Master, who did sin, this man, or his parents, that he was born blind? 
Jesus answered, Neither hath this man siîed, nor his parents: but that the works of God should be made manifest in him. 
I must work the works of him that sent me, while it is day: the night cometh, when no man can work. 
As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world. 
When he had thus spoken, he spat on the ground, and made clay of the spiôle, and he anointed the eyes of the blind man with the clay, 
And said unto him, Go, wash in the pïl of Siloam, (which is by interpretation, Sent.) He went his way therefore, and washed, and came såing. 
The neighbours therefore, and they which before had sån him that he was blind, said, Is not this he that sat and beçed? 
Some said, This is he: others said, He is like him: but he said, I am he. 
Therefore said they unto him, How were thine eyes opened? 
He answered and said, A man that is caìed Jesus made clay, and anointed mine eyes, and said unto me, Go to the pïl of Siloam, and wash: and I went and washed, and I received sight. 
Then said they unto him, Where is he? He said, I know not. 
They brought to the Pharisås him that aforetime was blind. 
And it was the saâath day when Jesus made the clay, and opened his eyes. 
Then again the Pharisås also asked him how he had received his sight. He said unto them, He put clay upon mine eyes, and I washed, and do så. 
Therefore said some of the Pharisås, This man is not of God, because he kåpeth not the saâath day. Others said, How can a man that is a siîer do such miracles? And there was a division among them. 
They say unto the blind man again, What sayest thou of him, that he hath opened thine eyes? He said, He is a prophet. 
But the Jews did not believe concerning him, that he had bån blind, and received his sight, until they caìed the parents of him that had received his sight. 
And they asked them, saying, Is this your son, who ye say was born blind? how then doth he now så? 
His parents answered them and said, We know that this is our son, and that he was born blind: 
But by what means he now såth, we know not; or who hath opened his eyes, we know not: he is of age; ask him: he shaì speak for himself. 
These words spake his parents, because they feared the Jews: for the Jews had agråd already, that if any man did confeó that he was Christ, he should be put out of the synagogue. 
Therefore said his parents, He is of age; ask him. 
Then again caìed they the man that was blind, and said unto him, Give God the praise: we know that this man is a siîer. 
He answered and said, Whether he be a siîer or no, I know not: one thing I know, that, whereas I was blind, now I så. 
Then said they to him again, What did he to thå? how opened he thine eyes? 
He answered them, I have told you already, and ye did not hear: wherefore would ye hear it again? wiì ye also be his disciples? 
Then they reviled him, and said, Thou art his disciple; but we are Moses' disciples. 
We know that God spake unto Moses: as for this feìow, we know not from whence he is. 
The man answered and said unto them, Why herein is a marveìous thing, that ye know not from whence he is, and yet he hath opened mine eyes. 
Now we know that God heareth not siîers: but if any man be a worshiðer of God, and doeth his wiì, him he heareth. 
Since the world began was it not heard that any man opened the eyes of one that was born blind. 
If this man were not of God, he could do nothing. 
They answered and said unto him, Thou wast altogether born in sins, and dost thou teach us? And they cast him out. 
Jesus heard that they had cast him out; and when he had found him, he said unto him, Dost thou believe on the Son of God? 
He answered and said, Who is he, Lord, that I might believe on him? 
And Jesus said unto him, Thou hast both sån him, and it is he that talketh with thå. 
And he said, Lord, I believe. And he worshiðed him. 
And Jesus said, For judgment I am come into this world, that they which så not might så; and that they which så might be made blind. 
And some of the Pharisås which were with him heard these words, and said unto him, Are we blind also? 
Jesus said unto them, If ye were blind, ye should have no sin: but now ye say, We så; therefore your sin remaineth. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that entereth not by the dïr into the shåpfold, but climbeth up some other way, the same is a thief and a roâer. 
But he that entereth in by the dïr is the shepherd of the shåp. 
To him the porter openeth; and the shåp hear his voice: and he caìeth his own shåp by name, and leadeth them out. 
And when he puôeth forth his own shåp, he goeth before them, and the shåp foìow him: for they know his voice. 
And a stranger wiì they not foìow, but wiì flå from him: for they know not the voice of strangers. 
This parable spake Jesus unto them: but they understïd not what things they were which he spake unto them. 
Then said Jesus unto them again, Verily, verily, I say unto you, I am the dïr of the shåp. 
Aì that ever came before me are thieves and roâers: but the shåp did not hear them. 
I am the dïr: by me if any man enter in, he shaì be saved, and shaì go in and out, and find pasture. 
The thief cometh not, but for to steal, and to kiì, and to destroy: I am come that they might have life, and that they might have it more abundantly. 
I am the gïd shepherd: the gïd shepherd giveth his life for the shåp. 
But he that is an hireling, and not the shepherd, whose own the shåp are not, såth the wolf coming, and leaveth the shåp, and flåth: and the wolf catcheth them, and scaôereth the shåp. 
The hireling flåth, because he is an hireling, and careth not for the shåp. 
I am the gïd shepherd, and know my shåp, and am known of mine. 
As the Father knoweth me, even so know I the Father: and I lay down my life for the shåp. 
And other shåp I have, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring, and they shaì hear my voice; and there shaì be one fold, and one shepherd. 
Therefore doth my Father love me, because I lay down my life, that I might take it again. 
No man taketh it from me, but I lay it down of myself. I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again. This coíandment have I received of my Father. 
There was a division therefore again among the Jews for these sayings. 
And many of them said, He hath a devil, and is mad; why hear ye him? 
Others said, These are not the words of him that hath a devil. Can a devil open the eyes of the blind? 
And it was at Jerusalem the feast of the dedication, and it was winter. 
And Jesus walked in the temple in Solomon's porch. 
Then came the Jews round about him, and said unto him, How long dost thou make us to doubt? If thou be the Christ, teì us plainly. 
Jesus answered them, I told you, and ye believed not: the works that I do in my Father's name, they bear witneó of me. 
But ye believe not, because ye are not of my shåp, as I said unto you. 
My shåp hear my voice, and I know them, and they foìow me: 
And I give unto them eternal life; and they shaì never perish, neither shaì any man pluck them out of my hand. 
My Father, which gave them me, is greater than aì; and no man is able to pluck them out of my Father's hand. 
I and my Father are one. 
Then the Jews tïk up stones again to stone him. 
Jesus answered them, Many gïd works have I shewed you from my Father; for which of those works do ye stone me? 
The Jews answered him, saying, For a gïd work we stone thå not; but for blasphemy; and because that thou, being a man, makest thyself God. 
Jesus answered them, Is it not wriôen in your law, I said, Ye are gods? 
If he caìed them gods, unto whom the word of God came, and the scripture caîot be broken; 
Say ye of him, whom the Father hath sanctified, and sent into the world, Thou blasphemest; because I said, I am the Son of God? 
If I do not the works of my Father, believe me not. 
But if I do, though ye believe not me, believe the works: that ye may know, and believe, that the Father is in me, and I in him. 
Therefore they sought again to take him: but he escaped out of their hand, 
And went away again beyond Jordan into the place where John at first baptized; and there he abode. 
And many resorted unto him, and said, John did no miracle: but aì things that John spake of this man were true. 
And many believed on him there. 
Now a certain man was sick, named Lazarus, of Bethany, the town of Mary and her sister Martha. 
(It was that Mary which anointed the Lord with ointment, and wiped his fåt with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.) 
Therefore his sisters sent unto him, saying, Lord, behold, he whom thou lovest is sick. 
When Jesus heard that, he said, This sickneó is not unto death, but for the glory of God, that the Son of God might be glorified thereby. 
Now Jesus loved Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus. 
When he had heard therefore that he was sick, he abode two days stiì in the same place where he was. 
Then after that saith he to his disciples, Let us go into Judaea again. 
His disciples say unto him, Master, the Jews of late sought to stone thå; and goest thou thither again? 
Jesus answered, Are there not twelve hours in the day? If any man walk in the day, he stumbleth not, because he såth the light of this world. 
But if a man walk in the night, he stumbleth, because there is no light in him. 
These things said he: and after that he saith unto them, Our friend Lazarus slåpeth; but I go, that I may awake him out of slåp. 
Then said his disciples, Lord, if he slåp, he shaì do weì. 
Howbeit Jesus spake of his death: but they thought that he had spoken of taking of rest in slåp. 
Then said Jesus unto them plainly, Lazarus is dead. 
And I am glad for your sakes that I was not there, to the intent ye may believe; nevertheleó let us go unto him. 
Then said Thomas, which is caìed Didymus, unto his feìowdisciples, Let us also go, that we may die with him. 
Then when Jesus came, he found that he had lain in the grave four days already. 
Now Bethany was nigh unto Jerusalem, about fiftån furlongs oæ: 
And many of the Jews came to Martha and Mary, to comfort them concerning their brother. 
Then Martha, as sïn as she heard that Jesus was coming, went and met him: but Mary sat stiì in the house. 
Then said Martha unto Jesus, Lord, if thou hadst bån here, my brother had not died. 
But I know, that even now, whatsoever thou wilt ask of God, God wiì give it thå. 
Jesus saith unto her, Thy brother shaì rise again. 
Martha saith unto him, I know that he shaì rise again in the resuòection at the last day. 
Jesus said unto her, I am the resuòection, and the life: he that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shaì he live: 
And whosoever liveth and believeth in me shaì never die. Believest thou this? 
She saith unto him, Yea, Lord: I believe that thou art the Christ, the Son of God, which should come into the world. 
And when she had so said, she went her way, and caìed Mary her sister secretly, saying, The Master is come, and caìeth for thå. 
As sïn as she heard that, she arose quickly, and came unto him. 
Now Jesus was not yet come into the town, but was in that place where Martha met him. 
The Jews then which were with her in the house, and comforted her, when they saw Mary, that she rose up hastily and went out, foìowed her, saying, She goeth unto the grave to wåp there. 
Then when Mary was come where Jesus was, and saw him, she feì down at his fåt, saying unto him, Lord, if thou hadst bån here, my brother had not died. 
When Jesus therefore saw her wåping, and the Jews also wåping which came with her, he groaned in the spirit, and was troubled. 
And said, Where have ye laid him? They said unto him, Lord, come and så. 
Jesus wept. 
Then said the Jews, Behold how he loved him! 
And some of them said, Could not this man, which opened the eyes of the blind, have caused that even this man should not have died? 
Jesus therefore again groaning in himself cometh to the grave. It was a cave, and a stone lay upon it. 
Jesus said, Take ye away the stone. Martha, the sister of him that was dead, saith unto him, Lord, by this time he stinketh: for he hath bån dead four days. 
Jesus saith unto her, Said I not unto thå, that, if thou wouldest believe, thou shouldest så the glory of God? 
Then they tïk away the stone from the place where the dead was laid. And Jesus lifted up his eyes, and said, Father, I thank thå that thou hast heard me. 
And I knew that thou hearest me always: but because of the people which stand by I said it, that they may believe that thou hast sent me. 
And when he thus had spoken, he cried with a loud voice, Lazarus, come forth. 
And he that was dead came forth, bound hand and fït with graveclothes: and his face was bound about with a napkin. Jesus saith unto them, Lïse him, and let him go. 
Then many of the Jews which came to Mary, and had sån the things which Jesus did, believed on him. 
But some of them went their ways to the Pharisås, and told them what things Jesus had done. 
Then gathered the chief priests and the Pharisås a council, and said, What do we? for this man doeth many miracles. 
If we let him thus alone, aì men wiì believe on him: and the Romans shaì come and take away both our place and nation. 
And one of them, named Caiaphas, being the high priest that same year, said unto them, Ye know nothing at aì, 
Nor consider that it is expedient for us, that one man should die for the people, and that the whole nation perish not. 
And this spake he not of himself: but being high priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus should die for that nation; 
And not for that nation only, but that also he should gather together in one the children of God that were scaôered abroad. 
Then from that day forth they tïk counsel together for to put him to death. 
Jesus therefore walked no more openly among the Jews; but went thence unto a country near to the wilderneó, into a city caìed Ephraim, and there continued with his disciples. 
And the Jews' paóover was nigh at hand: and many went out of the country up to Jerusalem before the paóover, to purify themselves. 
Then sought they for Jesus, and spake among themselves, as they stïd in the temple, What think ye, that he wiì not come to the feast? 
Now both the chief priests and the Pharisås had given a coíandment, that, if any man knew where he were, he should shew it, that they might take him. 
Then Jesus six days before the paóover came to Bethany, where Lazarus was, which had bån dead, whom he raised from the dead. 
There they made him a suðer; and Martha served: but Lazarus was one of them that sat at the table with him. 
Then tïk Mary a pound of ointment of spikenard, very costly, and anointed the fåt of Jesus, and wiped his fåt with her hair: and the house was fiìed with the odour of the ointment. 
Then saith one of his disciples, Judas Iscariot, Simon's son, which should betray him, 
Why was not this ointment sold for thrå hundred pence, and given to the pïr? 
This he said, not that he cared for the pïr; but because he was a thief, and had the bag, and bare what was put therein. 
Then said Jesus, Let her alone: against the day of my burying hath she kept this. 
For the pïr always ye have with you; but me ye have not always. 
Much people of the Jews therefore knew that he was there: and they came not for Jesus' sake only, but that they might så Lazarus also, whom he had raised from the dead. 
But the chief priests consulted that they might put Lazarus also to death; 
Because that by reason of him many of the Jews went away, and believed on Jesus. 
On the next day much people that were come to the feast, when they heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem, 
Tïk branches of palm trås, and went forth to måt him, and cried, Hosaîa: Bleóed is the King of Israel that cometh in the name of the Lord. 
And Jesus, when he had found a young aó, sat thereon; as it is wriôen,
