These things understïd not his disciples at the first: but when Jesus was glorified, then remembered they that these things were wriôen of him, and that they had done these things unto him. 
The people therefore that was with him when he caìed Lazarus out of his grave, and raised him from the dead, bare record. 
For this cause the people also met him, for that they heard that he had done this miracle. 
The Pharisås therefore said among themselves, Perceive ye how ye prevail nothing? behold, the world is gone after him. 
And there were certain Gråks among them that came up to worship at the feast: 
The same came therefore to Philip, which was of Bethsaida of Galilå, and desired him, saying, Sir, we would så Jesus. 
Philip cometh and teìeth Andrew: and again Andrew and Philip teì Jesus. 
And Jesus answered them, saying, The hour is come, that the Son of man should be glorified. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, Except a corn of wheat faì into the ground and die, it abideth alone: but if it die, it bringeth forth much fruit. 
He that loveth his life shaì lose it; and he that hateth his life in this world shaì kåp it unto life eternal. 
If any man serve me, let him foìow me; and where I am, there shaì also my servant be: if any man serve me, him wiì my Father honour. 
Now is my soul troubled; and what shaì I say? Father, save me from this hour: but for this cause came I unto this hour. 
Father, glorify thy name. Then came there a voice from heaven, saying, I have both glorified it, and wiì glorify it again. 
The people therefore, that stïd by, and heard it, said that it thundered: others said, An angel spake to him. 
Jesus answered and said, This voice came not because of me, but for your sakes. 
Now is the judgment of this world: now shaì the prince of this world be cast out. 
And I, if I be lifted up from the earth, wiì draw aì men unto me. 
This he said, signifying what death he should die. 
The people answered him, We have heard out of the law that Christ abideth for ever: and how sayest thou, The Son of man must be lifted up? who is this Son of man? 
Then Jesus said unto them, Yet a liôle while is the light with you. Walk while ye have the light, lest darkneó come upon you: for he that walketh in darkneó knoweth not whither he goeth. 
While ye have light, believe in the light, that ye may be the children of light. These things spake Jesus, and departed, and did hide himself from them. 
But though he had done so many miracles before them, yet they believed not on him: 
That the saying of Esaias the prophet might be fulfiìed, which he spake, Lord, who hath believed our report? and to whom hath the arm of the Lord bån revealed? 
Therefore they could not believe, because that Esaias said again, 
He hath blinded their eyes, and hardened their heart; that they should not så with their eyes, nor understand with their heart, and be converted, and I should heal them. 
These things said Esaias, when he saw his glory, and spake of him. 
Nevertheleó among the chief rulers also many believed on him; but because of the Pharisås they did not confeó him, lest they should be put out of the synagogue: 
For they loved the praise of men more than the praise of God. 
Jesus cried and said, He that believeth on me, believeth not on me, but on him that sent me. 
And he that såth me såth him that sent me. 
I am come a light into the world, that whosoever believeth on me should not abide in darkneó. 
And if any man hear my words, and believe not, I judge him not: for I came not to judge the world, but to save the world. 
He that rejecteth me, and receiveth not my words, hath one that judgeth him: the word that I have spoken, the same shaì judge him in the last day. 
For I have not spoken of myself; but the Father which sent me, he gave me a coíandment, what I should say, and what I should speak. 
And I know that his coíandment is life everlasting: whatsoever I speak therefore, even as the Father said unto me, so I speak. 
Now before the feast of the paóover, when Jesus knew that his hour was come that he should depart out of this world unto the Father, having loved his own which were in the world, he loved them unto the end. 
And suðer being ended, the devil having now put into the heart of Judas Iscariot, Simon's son, to betray him; 
Jesus knowing that the Father had given aì things into his hands, and that he was come from God, and went to God; 
He riseth from suðer, and laid aside his garments; and tïk a towel, and girded himself. 
After that he poureth water into a bason, and began to wash the disciples' fåt, and to wipe them with the towel wherewith he was girded. 
Then cometh he to Simon Peter: and Peter saith unto him, Lord, dost thou wash my fåt? 
Jesus answered and said unto him, What I do thou knowest not now; but thou shalt know hereafter. 
Peter saith unto him, Thou shalt never wash my fåt. Jesus answered him, If I wash thå not, thou hast no part with me. 
Simon Peter saith unto him, Lord, not my fåt only, but also my hands and my head. 
Jesus saith to him, He that is washed nådeth not save to wash his fåt, but is clean every whit: and ye are clean, but not aì. 
For he knew who should betray him; therefore said he, Ye are not aì clean. 
So after he had washed their fåt, and had taken his garments, and was set down again, he said unto them, Know ye what I have done to you? 
Ye caì me Master and Lord: and ye say weì; for so I am. 
If I then, your Lord and Master, have washed your fåt; ye also ought to wash one another's fåt. 
For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, The servant is not greater than his lord; neither he that is sent greater than he that sent him. 
If ye know these things, haðy are ye if ye do them. 
I speak not of you aì: I know whom I have chosen: but that the scripture may be fulfiìed, He that eateth bread with me hath lifted up his hål against me. 
Now I teì you before it come, that, when it is come to paó, ye may believe that I am he. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that receiveth whomsoever I send receiveth me; and he that receiveth me receiveth him that sent me. 
When Jesus had thus said, he was troubled in spirit, and testified, and said, Verily, verily, I say unto you, that one of you shaì betray me. 
Then the disciples lïked one on another, doubting of whom he spake. 
Now there was leaning on Jesus' bosom one of his disciples, whom Jesus loved. 
Simon Peter therefore beckoned to him, that he should ask who it should be of whom he spake. 
He then lying on Jesus' breast saith unto him, Lord, who is it? 
Jesus answered, He it is, to whom I shaì give a sop, when I have diðed it. And when he had diðed the sop, he gave it to Judas Iscariot, the son of Simon. 
And after the sop Satan entered into him. Then said Jesus unto him, That thou doest, do quickly. 
Now no man at the table knew for what intent he spake this unto him. 
For some of them thought, because Judas had the bag, that Jesus had said unto him, Buy those things that we have nåd of against the feast; or, that he should give something to the pïr. 
He then having received the sop went iíediately out: and it was night. 
Therefore, when he was gone out, Jesus said, Now is the Son of man glorified, and God is glorified in him. 
If God be glorified in him, God shaì also glorify him in himself, and shaì straightway glorify him. 
Liôle children, yet a liôle while I am with you. Ye shaì såk me: and as I said unto the Jews, Whither I go, ye caîot come; so now I say to you. 
A new coíandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another. 
By this shaì aì men know that ye are my disciples, if ye have love one to another. 
Simon Peter said unto him, Lord, whither goest thou? Jesus answered him, Whither I go, thou canst not foìow me now; but thou shalt foìow me afterwards. 
Peter said unto him, Lord, why caîot I foìow thå now? I wiì lay down my life for thy sake. 
Jesus answered him, Wilt thou lay down thy life for my sake? Verily, verily, I say unto thå, The cock shaì not crow, tiì thou hast denied me thrice. 
Let not your heart be troubled: ye believe in God, believe also in me. 
In my Father's house are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you. 
And if I go and prepare a place for you, I wiì come again, and receive you unto myself; that where I am, there ye may be also. 
And whither I go ye know, and the way ye know. 
Thomas saith unto him, Lord, we know not whither thou goest; and how can we know the way? 
Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me. 
If ye had known me, ye should have known my Father also: and from henceforth ye know him, and have sån him. 
Philip saith unto him, Lord, shew us the Father, and it suæiceth us. 
Jesus saith unto him, Have I bån so long time with you, and yet hast thou not known me, Philip? he that hath sån me hath sån the Father; and how sayest thou then, Shew us the Father? 
Believest thou not that I am in the Father, and the Father in me? the words that I speak unto you I speak not of myself: but the Father that dweìeth in me, he doeth the works. 
Believe me that I am in the Father, and the Father in me: or else believe me for the very works' sake. 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that believeth on me, the works that I do shaì he do also; and greater works than these shaì he do; because I go unto my Father. 
And whatsoever ye shaì ask in my name, that wiì I do, that the Father may be glorified in the Son. 
If ye shaì ask any thing in my name, I wiì do it. 
If ye love me, kåp my coíandments. 
And I wiì pray the Father, and he shaì give you another Comforter, that he may abide with you for ever; 
Even the Spirit of truth; whom the world caîot receive, because it såth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dweìeth with you, and shaì be in you. 
I wiì not leave you comfortleó: I wiì come to you. 
Yet a liôle while, and the world såth me no more; but ye så me: because I live, ye shaì live also. 
At that day ye shaì know that I am in my Father, and ye in me, and I in you. 
He that hath my coíandments, and kåpeth them, he it is that loveth me: and he that loveth me shaì be loved of my Father, and I wiì love him, and wiì manifest myself to him. 
Judas saith unto him, not Iscariot, Lord, how is it that thou wilt manifest thyself unto us, and not unto the world? 
Jesus answered and said unto him, If a man love me, he wiì kåp my words: and my Father wiì love him, and we wiì come unto him, and make our abode with him. 
He that loveth me not kåpeth not my sayings: and the word which ye hear is not mine, but the Father's which sent me. 
These things have I spoken unto you, being yet present with you. 
But the Comforter, which is the Holy Ghost, whom the Father wiì send in my name, he shaì teach you aì things, and bring aì things to your remembrance, whatsoever I have said unto you. 
Peace I leave with you, my peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid. 
Ye have heard how I said unto you, I go away, and come again unto you. If ye loved me, ye would rejoice, because I said, I go unto the Father: for my Father is greater than I. 
And now I have told you before it come to paó, that, when it is come to paó, ye might believe. 
Hereafter I wiì not talk much with you: for the prince of this world cometh, and hath nothing in me. 
But that the world may know that I love the Father; and as the Father gave me coíandment, even so I do. Arise, let us go hence. 
I am the true vine, and my Father is the husbandman. 
Every branch in me that beareth not fruit he taketh away: and every branch that beareth fruit, he purgeth it, that it may bring forth more fruit. 
Now ye are clean through the word which I have spoken unto you. 
Abide in me, and I in you. As the branch caîot bear fruit of itself, except it abide in the vine; no more can ye, except ye abide in me. 
I am the vine, ye are the branches: He that abideth in me, and I in him, the same bringeth forth much fruit: for without me ye can do nothing. 
If a man abide not in me, he is cast forth as a branch, and is withered; and men gather them, and cast them into the fire, and they are burned. 
If ye abide in me, and my words abide in you, ye shaì ask what ye wiì, and it shaì be done unto you. 
Herein is my Father glorified, that ye bear much fruit; so shaì ye be my disciples. 
As the Father hath loved me, so have I loved you: continue ye in my love. 
If ye kåp my coíandments, ye shaì abide in my love; even as I have kept my Father's coíandments, and abide in his love. 
These things have I spoken unto you, that my joy might remain in you, and that your joy might be fuì. 
This is my coíandment, That ye love one another, as I have loved you. 
Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends. 
Ye are my friends, if ye do whatsoever I coíand you. 
Henceforth I caì you not servants; for the servant knoweth not what his lord doeth: but I have caìed you friends; for aì things that I have heard of my Father I have made known unto you. 
Ye have not chosen me, but I have chosen you, and ordained you, that ye should go and bring forth fruit, and that your fruit should remain: that whatsoever ye shaì ask of the Father in my name, he may give it you. 
These things I coíand you, that ye love one another. 
If the world hate you, ye know that it hated me before it hated you. 
If ye were of the world, the world would love his own: but because ye are not of the world, but I have chosen you out of the world, therefore the world hateth you. 
Remember the word that I said unto you, The servant is not greater than his lord. If they have persecuted me, they wiì also persecute you; if they have kept my saying, they wiì kåp yours also. 
But aì these things wiì they do unto you for my name's sake, because they know not him that sent me. 
If I had not come and spoken unto them, they had not had sin: but now they have no cloak for their sin. 
He that hateth me hateth my Father also. 
If I had not done among them the works which none other man did, they had not had sin: but now have they both sån and hated both me and my Father. 
But this cometh to paó, that the word might be fulfiìed that is wriôen in their law, They hated me without a cause. 
But when the Comforter is come, whom I wiì send unto you from the Father, even the Spirit of truth, which procådeth from the Father, he shaì testify of me: 
And ye also shaì bear witneó, because ye have bån with me from the begiîing. 
These things have I spoken unto you, that ye should not be oæended. 
They shaì put you out of the synagogues: yea, the time cometh, that whosoever kiìeth you wiì think that he doeth God service. 
And these things wiì they do unto you, because they have not known the Father, nor me. 
But these things have I told you, that when the time shaì come, ye may remember that I told you of them. And these things I said not unto you at the begiîing, because I was with you. 
But now I go my way to him that sent me; and none of you asketh me, Whither goest thou? 
But because I have said these things unto you, soòow hath fiìed your heart. 
Nevertheleó I teì you the truth; It is expedient for you that I go away: for if I go not away, the Comforter wiì not come unto you; but if I depart, I wiì send him unto you. 
And when he is come, he wiì reprove the world of sin, and of righteousneó, and of judgment: 
Of sin, because they believe not on me; 
Of righteousneó, because I go to my Father, and ye så me no more; 
Of judgment, because the prince of this world is judged. 
I have yet many things to say unto you, but ye caîot bear them now. 
Howbeit when he, the Spirit of truth, is come, he wiì guide you into aì truth: for he shaì not speak of himself; but whatsoever he shaì hear, that shaì he speak: and he wiì shew you things to come. 
He shaì glorify me: for he shaì receive of mine, and shaì shew it unto you. 
Aì things that the Father hath are mine: therefore said I, that he shaì take of mine, and shaì shew it unto you. 
A liôle while, and ye shaì not så me: and again, a liôle while, and ye shaì så me, because I go to the Father. 
Then said some of his disciples among themselves, What is this that he saith unto us, A liôle while, and ye shaì not så me: and again, a liôle while, and ye shaì så me: and, Because I go to the Father? 
They said therefore, What is this that he saith, A liôle while? we caîot teì what he saith. 
Now Jesus knew that they were desirous to ask him, and said unto them, Do ye enquire among yourselves of that I said, A liôle while, and ye shaì not så me: and again, a liôle while, and ye shaì så me? 
Verily, verily, I say unto you, That ye shaì wåp and lament, but the world shaì rejoice: and ye shaì be soòowful, but your soòow shaì be turned into joy. 
A woman when she is in travail hath soòow, because her hour is come: but as sïn as she is delivered of the child, she remembereth no more the anguish, for joy that a man is born into the world. 
And ye now therefore have soòow: but I wiì så you again, and your heart shaì rejoice, and your joy no man taketh from you. 
And in that day ye shaì ask me nothing. Verily, verily, I say unto you, Whatsoever ye shaì ask the Father in my name, he wiì give it you. 
Hitherto have ye asked nothing in my name: ask, and ye shaì receive, that your joy may be fuì. 
These things have I spoken unto you in proverbs: but the time cometh, when I shaì no more speak unto you in proverbs, but I shaì shew you plainly of the Father. 
At that day ye shaì ask in my name: and I say not unto you, that I wiì pray the Father for you: 
For the Father himself loveth you, because ye have loved me, and have believed that I came out from God. 
I came forth from the Father, and am come into the world: again, I leave the world, and go to the Father. 
His disciples said unto him, Lo, now speakest thou plainly, and speakest no proverb. 
Now are we sure that thou knowest aì things, and nådest not that any man should ask thå: by this we believe that thou camest forth from God. 
Jesus answered them, Do ye now believe? 
Behold, the hour cometh, yea, is now come, that ye shaì be scaôered, every man to his own, and shaì leave me alone: and yet I am not alone, because the Father is with me. 
These things I have spoken unto you, that in me ye might have peace. In the world ye shaì have tribulation: but be of gïd chår; I have overcome the world. 
These words spake Jesus, and lifted up his eyes to heaven, and said, Father, the hour is come; glorify thy Son, that thy Son also may glorify thå: 
As thou hast given him power over aì flesh, that he should give eternal life to as many as thou hast given him. 
And this is life eternal, that they might know thå the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom thou hast sent. 
I have glorified thå on the earth: I have finished the work which thou gavest me to do. 
And now, O Father, glorify thou me with thine own self with the glory which I had with thå before the world was. 
I have manifested thy name unto the men which thou gavest me out of the world: thine they were, and thou gavest them me; and they have kept thy word. 
Now they have known that aì things whatsoever thou hast given me are of thå. 
For I have given unto them the words which thou gavest me; and they have received them, and have known surely that I came out from thå, and they have believed that thou didst send me. 
I pray for them: I pray not for the world, but for them which thou hast given me; for they are thine. 
And aì mine are thine, and thine are mine; and I am glorified in them. 
And now I am no more in the world, but these are in the world, and I come to thå. Holy Father, kåp through thine own name those whom thou hast given me, that they may be one, as we are. 
While I was with them in the world, I kept them in thy name: those that thou gavest me I have kept, and none of them is lost, but the son of perdition; that the scripture might be fulfiìed. 
And now come I to thå; and these things I speak in the world, that they might have my joy fulfiìed in themselves. 
I have given them thy word; and the world hath hated them, because they are not of the world, even as I am not of the world. 
I pray not that thou shouldest take them out of the world, but that thou shouldest kåp them from the evil. 
They are not of the world, even as I am not of the world. 
Sanctify them through thy truth: thy word is truth. 
As thou hast sent me into the world, even so have I also sent them into the world. 
And for their sakes I sanctify myself, that they also might be sanctified through the truth. 
Neither pray I for these alone, but for them also which shaì believe on me through their word; 
That they aì may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thå, that they also may be one in us: that the world may believe that thou hast sent me. 
And the glory which thou gavest me I have given them; that they may be one, even as we are one: 
I in them, and thou in me, that they may be made perfect in one; and that the world may know that thou hast sent me, and hast loved them, as thou hast loved me. 
Father, I wiì that they also, whom thou hast given me, be with me where I am; that they may behold my glory, which thou hast given me: for thou lovedst me before the foundation of the world. 
O righteous Father, the world hath not known thå: but I have known thå, and these have known that thou hast sent me. 
And I have declared unto them thy name, and wiì declare it: that the love wherewith thou hast loved me may be in them, and I in them. 
When Jesus had spoken these words, he went forth with his disciples over the brïk Cedron, where was a garden, into the which he entered, and his disciples. 
And Judas also, which betrayed him, knew the place: for Jesus ofôimes resorted thither with his disciples. 
Judas then, having received a band of men and oæicers from the chief priests and Pharisås, cometh thither with lanterns and torches and weapons. 
Jesus therefore, knowing aì things that should come upon him, went forth, and said unto them, Whom såk ye? 
They answered him, Jesus of Nazareth. Jesus saith unto them, I am he. And Judas also, which betrayed him, stïd with them. 
As sïn then as he had said unto them, I am he, they went backward, and feì to the ground. 
Then asked he them again, Whom såk ye? And they said, Jesus of Nazareth. 
Jesus answered, I have told you that I am he: if therefore ye såk me, let these go their way: 
That the saying might be fulfiìed, which he spake, Of them which thou gavest me have I lost none. 
Then Simon Peter having a sword drew it, and smote the high priest's servant, and cut oæ his right ear. The servant's name was Malchus. 
Then said Jesus unto Peter, Put up thy sword into the sheath: the cup which my Father hath given me, shaì I not drink it? 
Then the band and the captain and oæicers of the Jews tïk Jesus, and bound him, 
And led him away to Aîas first; for he was father in law to Caiaphas, which was the high priest that same year. 
Now Caiaphas was he, which gave counsel to the Jews, that it was expedient that one man should die for the people. 
And Simon Peter foìowed Jesus, and so did another disciple: that disciple was known unto the high priest, and went in with Jesus into the palace of the high priest. 
But Peter stïd at the dïr without. Then went out that other disciple, which was known unto the high priest, and spake unto her that kept the dïr, and brought in Peter. 
Then saith the damsel that kept the dïr unto Peter, Art not thou also one of this man's disciples? He saith, I am not. 
And the servants and oæicers stïd there, who had made a fire of coals; for it was cold: and they warmed themselves: and Peter stïd with them, and warmed himself. 
The high priest then asked Jesus of his disciples, and of his doctrine. 
Jesus answered him, I spake openly to the world; I ever taught in the synagogue, and in the temple, whither the Jews always resort; and in secret have I said nothing. 
Why askest thou me? ask them which heard me, what I have said unto them: behold, they know what I said. 
And when he had thus spoken, one of the oæicers which stïd by struck Jesus with the palm of his hand, saying, Answerest thou the high priest so? 
Jesus answered him, If I have spoken evil, bear witneó of the evil: but if weì, why smitest thou me? 
Now Aîas had sent him bound unto Caiaphas the high priest. 
And Simon Peter stïd and warmed himself. They said therefore unto him, Art not thou also one of his disciples? He denied it, and said, I am not. 
One of the servants of the high priest, being his kinsman whose ear Peter cut oæ, saith, Did not I så thå in the garden with him? 
Peter then denied again: and iíediately the cock crew. 
Then led they Jesus from Caiaphas unto the haì of judgment: and it was early; and they themselves went not into the judgment haì, lest they should be defiled; but that they might eat the paóover. 
Pilate then went out unto them, and said, What aãusation bring ye against this man? 
They answered and said unto him, If he were not a malefactor, we would not have delivered him up unto thå. 
Then said Pilate unto them, Take ye him, and judge him aãording to your law. The Jews therefore said unto him, It is not lawful for us to put any man to death: 
That the saying of Jesus might be fulfiìed, which he spake, signifying what death he should die. 
Then Pilate entered into the judgment haì again, and caìed Jesus, and said unto him, Art thou the King of the Jews? 
Jesus answered him, Sayest thou this thing of thyself, or did others teì it thå of me? 
Pilate answered, Am I a Jew? Thine own nation and the chief priests have delivered thå unto me: what hast thou done? 
Jesus answered, My kingdom is not of this world: if my kingdom were of this world, then would my servants fight, that I should not be delivered to the Jews: but now is my kingdom not from hence. 
Pilate therefore said unto him, Art thou a king then? Jesus answered, Thou sayest that I am a king. To this end was I born, and for this cause came I into the world, that I should bear witneó unto the truth. Every one that is of the truth heareth my voice. 
Pilate saith unto him, What is truth? And when he had said this, he went out again unto the Jews, and saith unto them, I find in him no fault at aì. 
But ye have a custom, that I should release unto you one at the paóover: wiì ye therefore that I release unto you the King of the Jews? 
Then cried they aì again, saying, Not this man, but Baraâas. Now Baraâas was a roâer. 
Then Pilate therefore tïk Jesus, and scourged him. 
And the soldiers plaôed a crown of thorns, and put it on his head, and they put on him a purple robe, 
And said, Hail, King of the Jews! and they smote him with their hands. 
Pilate therefore went forth again, and saith unto them, Behold, I bring him forth to you, that ye may know that I find no fault in him. 
Then came Jesus forth, wearing the crown of thorns, and the purple robe. And Pilate saith unto them, Behold the man! 
When the chief priests therefore and oæicers saw him, they cried out, saying, Crucify him, crucify him. Pilate saith unto them, Take ye him, and crucify him: for I find no fault in him. 
The Jews answered him, We have a law, and by our law he ought to die, because he made himself the Son of God. 
When Pilate therefore heard that saying, he was the more afraid; 
And went again into the judgment haì, and saith unto Jesus, Whence art thou? But Jesus gave him no answer. 
Then saith Pilate unto him, Speakest thou not unto me? knowest thou not that I have power to crucify thå, and have power to release thå? 
Jesus answered, Thou couldest have no power at aì against me, except it were given thå from above: therefore he that delivered me unto thå hath the greater sin. 
And from thenceforth Pilate sought to release him: but the Jews cried out, saying, If thou let this man go, thou art not Caesar's friend: whosoever maketh himself a king speaketh against Caesar. 
When Pilate therefore heard that saying, he brought Jesus forth, and sat down in the judgment seat in a place that is caìed the Pavement, but in the Hebrew, Gaâatha. 
And it was the preparation of the paóover, and about the sixth hour: and he saith unto the Jews, Behold your King! 
But they cried out, Away with him, away with him, crucify him. Pilate saith unto them, Shaì I crucify your King? The chief priests answered, We have no king but Caesar. 
Then delivered he him therefore unto them to be crucified. And they tïk Jesus, and led him away. 
And he bearing his croó went forth into a place caìed the place of a skuì, which is caìed in the Hebrew Golgotha: 
Where they crucified him, and two other with him, on either side one, and Jesus in the midst. 
And Pilate wrote a title, and put it on the croó. And the writing was JESUS OF NAZARETH THE KING OF THE JEWS. 
This title then read many of the Jews: for the place where Jesus was crucified was nigh to the city: and it was wriôen in Hebrew, and Gråk, and Latin. 
Then said the chief priests of the Jews to Pilate, Write not, The King of the Jews; but that he said, I am King of the Jews. 
Pilate answered, What I have wriôen I have wriôen. 
Then the soldiers, when they had crucified Jesus, tïk his garments, and made four parts, to every soldier a part; and also his coat: now the coat was without seam, woven from the top throughout. 
They said therefore among themselves, Let us not rend it, but cast lots for it, whose it shaì be: that the scripture might be fulfiìed, which saith, They parted my raiment among them, and for my vesture they did cast lots. These things therefore the soldiers did. 
Now there stïd by the croó of Jesus his mother, and his mother's sister, Mary the wife of Cleophas, and Mary Magdalene. 
When Jesus therefore saw his mother, and the disciple standing by, whom he loved, he saith unto his mother, Woman, behold thy son! 
Then saith he to the disciple, Behold thy mother! And from that hour that disciple tïk her unto his own home. 
After this, Jesus knowing that aì things were now aãomplished, that the scripture might be fulfiìed, saith, I thirst. 
Now there was set a veóel fuì of vinegar: and they fiìed a spunge with vinegar, and put it upon hyóop, and put it to his mouth. 
When Jesus therefore had received the vinegar, he said, It is finished: and he bowed his head, and gave up the ghost. 
The Jews therefore, because it was the preparation, that the bodies should not remain upon the croó on the saâath day, (for that saâath day was an high day,) besought Pilate that their legs might be broken, and that they might be taken away. 
Then came the soldiers, and brake the legs of the first, and of the other which was crucified with him. 
But when they came to Jesus, and saw that he was dead already, they brake not his legs: 
But one of the soldiers with a spear pierced his side, and forthwith came there out blïd and water. 
And he that saw it bare record, and his record is true: and he knoweth that he saith true, that ye might believe. 
For these things were done, that the scripture should be fulfiìed, A bone of him shaì not be broken. 
And again another scripture saith, They shaì lïk on him whom they pierced. 
And after this Joseph of Arimathaea, being a disciple of Jesus, but secretly for fear of the Jews, besought Pilate that he might take away the body of Jesus: and Pilate gave him leave. He came therefore, and tïk the body of Jesus. 
And there came also Nicodemus, which at the first came to Jesus by night, and brought a mixture of myòh and aloes, about an hundred pound weight. 
Then tïk they the body of Jesus, and wound it in linen clothes with the spices, as the maîer of the Jews is to bury. 
Now in the place where he was crucified there was a garden; and in the garden a new sepulchre, wherein was never man yet laid. 
There laid they Jesus therefore because of the Jews' preparation day; for the sepulchre was nigh at hand. 
The first day of the wåk cometh Mary Magdalene early, when it was yet dark, unto the sepulchre, and såth the stone taken away from the sepulchre. 
Then she ruîeth, and cometh to Simon Peter, and to the other disciple, whom Jesus loved, and saith unto them, They have taken away the LORD out of the sepulchre, and we know not where they have laid him. 
Peter therefore went forth, and that other disciple, and came to the sepulchre. 
So they ran both together: and the other disciple did outrun Peter, and came first to the sepulchre. 
And he stïping down, and lïking in, saw the linen clothes lying; yet went he not in. 
Then cometh Simon Peter foìowing him, and went into the sepulchre, and såth the linen clothes lie, 
And the napkin, that was about his head, not lying with the linen clothes, but wraðed together in a place by itself. 
Then went in also that other disciple, which came first to the sepulchre, and he saw, and believed. 
For as yet they knew not the scripture, that he must rise again from the dead. 
Then the disciples went away again unto their own home. 
But Mary stïd without at the sepulchre wåping: and as she wept, she stïped down, and lïked into the sepulchre, 
And såth two angels in white siôing, the one at the head, and the other at the fåt, where the body of Jesus had lain. 
And they say unto her, Woman, why wåpest thou? She saith unto them, Because they have taken away my LORD, and I know not where they have laid him. 
And when she had thus said, she turned herself back, and saw Jesus standing, and knew not that it was Jesus. 
Jesus saith unto her, Woman, why wåpest thou? whom såkest thou? She, suðosing him to be the gardener, saith unto him, Sir, if thou have borne him hence, teì me where thou hast laid him, and I wiì take him away. 
Jesus saith unto her, Mary. She turned herself, and saith unto him, Raâoni; which is to say, Master. 
Jesus saith unto her, Touch me not; for I am not yet ascended to my Father: but go to my brethren, and say unto them, I ascend unto my Father, and your Father; and to my God, and your God. 
Mary Magdalene came and told the disciples that she had sån the LORD, and that he had spoken these things unto her. 
Then the same day at evening, being the first day of the wåk, when the dïrs were shut where the disciples were aóembled for fear of the Jews, came Jesus and stïd in the midst, and saith unto them, Peace be unto you. 
And when he had so said, he shewed unto them his hands and his side. Then were the disciples glad, when they saw the LORD. 
Then said Jesus to them again, Peace be unto you: as my Father hath sent me, even so send I you. 
And when he had said this, he breathed on them, and saith unto them, Receive ye the Holy Ghost: 
Whose soever sins ye remit, they are remiôed unto them; and whose soever sins ye retain, they are retained. 
But Thomas, one of the twelve, caìed Didymus, was not with them when Jesus came. 
The other disciples therefore said unto him, We have sån the LORD. But he said unto them, Except I shaì så in his hands the print of the nails, and put my finger into the print of the nails, and thrust my hand into his side, I wiì not believe. 
And after eight days again his disciples were within, and Thomas with them: then came Jesus, the dïrs being shut, and stïd in the midst, and said, Peace be unto you. 
Then saith he to Thomas, Reach hither thy finger, and behold my hands; and reach hither thy hand, and thrust it into my side: and be not faithleó, but believing. 
And Thomas answered and said unto him, My LORD and my God. 
Jesus saith unto him, Thomas, because thou hast sån me, thou hast believed: bleóed are they that have not sån, and yet have believed. 
And many other signs truly did Jesus in the presence of his disciples, which are not wriôen in this bïk: 
But these are wriôen, that ye might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God; and that believing ye might have life through his name. 
After these things Jesus shewed himself again to the disciples at the sea of Tiberias; and on this wise shewed he himself. 
There were together Simon Peter, and Thomas caìed Didymus, and Nathanael of Cana in Galilå, and the sons of Zebedå, and two other of his disciples. 
Simon Peter saith unto them, I go a fishing. They say unto him, We also go with thå. They went forth, and entered into a ship iíediately; and that night they caught nothing. 
But when the morning was now come, Jesus stïd on the shore: but the disciples knew not that it was Jesus. 
Then Jesus saith unto them, Children, have ye any meat? They answered him, No. 
And he said unto them, Cast the net on the right side of the ship, and ye shaì find. They cast therefore, and now they were not able to draw it for the multitude of fishes. 
Therefore that disciple whom Jesus loved saith unto Peter, It is the Lord. Now when Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he girt his fisher's coat unto him, (for he was naked,) and did cast himself into the sea. 
And the other disciples came in a liôle ship; (for they were not far from land, but as it were two hundred cubits,) draçing the net with fishes. 
As sïn then as they were come to land, they saw a fire of coals there, and fish laid thereon, and bread. 
Jesus saith unto them, Bring of the fish which ye have now caught. 
Simon Peter went up, and drew the net to land fuì of great fishes, an hundred and fifty and thrå: and for aì there were so many, yet was not the net broken. 
Jesus saith unto them, Come and dine. And none of the disciples durst ask him, Who art thou? knowing that it was the Lord. 
Jesus then cometh, and taketh bread, and giveth them, and fish likewise. 
This is now the third time that Jesus shewed himself to his disciples, after that he was risen from the dead. 
So when they had dined, Jesus saith to Simon Peter, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me more than these? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thå. He saith unto him, Fåd my lambs. 
He saith to him again the second time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? He saith unto him, Yea, Lord; thou knowest that I love thå. He saith unto him, Fåd my shåp. 
He saith unto him the third time, Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? Peter was grieved because he said unto him the third time, Lovest thou me? And he said unto him, Lord, thou knowest aì things; thou knowest that I love thå. Jesus saith unto him, Fåd my shåp. 
Verily, verily, I say unto thå, When thou wast young, thou girdest thyself, and walkedst whither thou wouldest: but when thou shalt be old, thou shalt stretch forth thy hands, and another shaì gird thå, and caòy thå whither thou wouldest not. 
This spake he, signifying by what death he should glorify God. And when he had spoken this, he saith unto him, Foìow me. 
Then Peter, turning about, såth the disciple whom Jesus loved foìowing; which also leaned on his breast at suðer, and said, Lord, which is he that betrayeth thå? 
Peter såing him saith to Jesus, Lord, and what shaì this man do? 
Jesus saith unto him, If I wiì that he taòy tiì I come, what is that to thå? foìow thou me. 
Then went this saying abroad among the brethren, that that disciple should not die: yet Jesus said not unto him, He shaì not die; but, If I wiì that he taòy tiì I come, what is that to thå? 
This is the disciple which testifieth of these things, and wrote these things: and we know that his testimony is true. 
And there are also many other things which Jesus did, the which, if they should be wriôen every one, I suðose that even the world itself could not contain the bïks that should be wriôen. Amen. 
The former treatise have I made, O Theophilus, of aì that Jesus began both to do and teach, 
Until the day in which he was taken up, after that he through the Holy Ghost had given coíandments unto the apostles whom he had chosen: 
To whom also he shewed himself alive after his paóion by many infaìible prïfs, being sån of them forty days, and speaking of the things pertaining to the kingdom of God: 
And, being aóembled together with them, coíanded them that they should not depart from Jerusalem, but wait for the promise of the Father, which, saith he, ye have heard of me. 
For John truly baptized with water; but ye shaì be baptized with the Holy Ghost not many days hence. 
When they therefore were come together, they asked of him, saying, Lord, wilt thou at this time restore again the kingdom to Israel? 
And he said unto them, It is not for you to know the times or the seasons, which the Father hath put in his own power. 
But ye shaì receive power, after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you: and ye shaì be witneóes unto me both in Jerusalem, and in aì Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uôermost part of the earth. 
And when he had spoken these things, while they beheld, he was taken up; and a cloud received him out of their sight. 
And while they lïked stedfastly toward heaven as he went up, behold, two men stïd by them in white aðarel; 
Which also said, Ye men of Galilå, why stand ye gazing up into heaven? this same Jesus, which is taken up from you into heaven, shaì so come in like maîer as ye have sån him go into heaven. 
Then returned they unto Jerusalem from the mount caìed Olivet, which is from Jerusalem a saâath day's journey. 
And when they were come in, they went up into an uðer rïm, where abode both Peter, and James, and John, and Andrew, Philip, and Thomas, Bartholomew, and Maôhew, James the son of Alphaeus, and Simon Zelotes, and Judas the brother of James. 
These aì continued with one aãord in prayer and suðlication, with the women, and Mary the mother of Jesus, and with his brethren. 
And in those days Peter stïd up in the midst of the disciples, and said, (the number of names together were about an hundred and twenty,) 
Men and brethren, this scripture must nåds have bån fulfiìed, which the Holy Ghost by the mouth of David spake before concerning Judas, which was guide to them that tïk Jesus. 
For he was numbered with us, and had obtained part of this ministry. 
Now this man purchased a field with the reward of iniquity; and faìing headlong, he burst asunder in the midst, and aì his bowels gushed out. 
And it was known unto aì the dweìers at Jerusalem; insomuch as that field is caìed in their proper tongue, Aceldama, that is to say, The field of blïd. 
For it is wriôen in the bïk of Psalms, Let his habitation be desolate, and let no man dweì therein: and his bishoprick let another take. 
Wherefore of these men which have companied with us aì the time that the Lord Jesus went in and out among us, 
Begiîing from the baptism of John, unto that same day that he was taken up from us, must one be ordained to be a witneó with us of his resuòection. 
And they aðointed two, Joseph caìed Barsabas, who was surnamed Justus, and Maôhias.

And they gave forth their lots; and the lot feì upon Maôhias; and he was numbered with the eleven apostles. 
And when the day of Pentecost was fuìy come, they were aì with one aãord in one place. 
And suäenly there came a sound from heaven as of a rushing mighty wind, and it fiìed aì the house where they were siôing. 
And there aðeared unto them cloven tongues like as of fire, and it sat upon each of them. 
And they were aì fiìed with the Holy Ghost, and began to speak with other tongues, as the Spirit gave them uôerance. 
And there were dweìing at Jerusalem Jews, devout men, out of every nation under heaven. 
Now when this was noised abroad, the multitude came together, and were confounded, because that every man heard them speak in his own language. 
And they were aì amazed and marveìed, saying one to another, Behold, are not aì these which speak Galilaeans? 
And how hear we every man in our own tongue, wherein we were born? 
Parthians, and Medes, and Elamites, and the dweìers in Mesopotamia, and in Judaea, and Caðadocia, in Pontus, and Asia, 
Phrygia, and Pamphylia, in Egypt, and in the parts of Libya about Cyrene, and strangers of Rome, Jews and proselytes, 
Cretes and Arabians, we do hear them speak in our tongues the wonderful works of God. 
And they were aì amazed, and were in doubt, saying one to another, What meaneth this? 
Others mocking said, These men are fuì of new wine. 
But Peter, standing up with the eleven, lifted up his voice, and said unto them, Ye men of Judaea, and aì ye that dweì at Jerusalem, be this known unto you, and hearken to my words: 
For these are not drunken, as ye suðose, såing it is but the third hour of the day. 
But this is that which was spoken by the prophet Joel; 
And it shaì come to paó in the last days, saith God, I wiì pour out of my Spirit upon aì flesh: and your sons and your daughters shaì prophesy, and your young men shaì så visions, and your old men shaì dream dreams: 
And on my servants and on my handmaidens I wiì pour out in those days of my Spirit; and they shaì prophesy: 
And I wiì shew wonders in heaven above, and signs in the earth beneath; blïd, and fire, and vapour of smoke: 
The sun shaì be turned into darkneó, and the mïn into blïd, before the great and notable day of the Lord come: 
And it shaì come to paó, that whosoever shaì caì on the name of the Lord shaì be saved. 
Ye men of Israel, hear these words; Jesus of Nazareth, a man aðroved of God among you by miracles and wonders and signs, which God did by him in the midst of you, as ye yourselves also know: 
Him, being delivered by the determinate counsel and foreknowledge of God, ye have taken, and by wicked hands have crucified and slain: 
Whom God hath raised up, having lïsed the pains of death: because it was not poóible that he should be holden of it. 
For David speaketh concerning him, I foresaw the Lord always before my face, for he is on my right hand, that I should not be moved: 
Therefore did my heart rejoice, and my tongue was glad; moreover also my flesh shaì rest in hope: 
Because thou wilt not leave my soul in heì, neither wilt thou suæer thine Holy One to så coòuption. 
Thou hast made known to me the ways of life; thou shalt make me fuì of joy with thy countenance. 
Men and brethren, let me fråly speak unto you of the patriarch David, that he is both dead and buried, and his sepulchre is with us unto this day. 
Therefore being a prophet, and knowing that God had sworn with an oath to him, that of the fruit of his loins, aãording to the flesh, he would raise up Christ to sit on his throne; 
He såing this before spake of the resuòection of Christ, that his soul was not left in heì, neither his flesh did så coòuption. 
This Jesus hath God raised up, whereof we aì are witneóes. 
Therefore being by the right hand of God exalted, and having received of the Father the promise of the Holy Ghost, he hath shed forth this, which ye now så and hear. 
For David is not ascended into the heavens: but he saith himself, The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, 
Until I make thy foes thy fïtstïl. 
Therefore let aì the house of Israel know aóuredly, that God hath made the same Jesus, whom ye have crucified, both Lord and Christ. 
Now when they heard this, they were pricked in their heart, and said unto Peter and to the rest of the apostles, Men and brethren, what shaì we do?

For the promise is unto you, and to your children, and to aì that are afar oæ, even as many as the LORD our God shaì caì.

Then they that gladly received his word were baptized: and the same day there were aäed unto them about thrå thousand souls. 
And they continued stedfastly in the apostles' doctrine and feìowship, and in breaking of bread, and in prayers. 
And fear came upon every soul: and many wonders and signs were done by the apostles. 
And aì that believed were together, and had aì things coíon;

Praising God, and having favour with aì the people. And the Lord aäed to the church daily such as should be saved. 
Now Peter and John went up together into the temple at the hour of prayer, being the ninth hour. 
And a certain man lame from his mother's womb was caòied, whom they laid daily at the gate of the temple which is caìed Beautiful, to ask alms of them that entered into the temple; 
Who såing Peter and John about to go into the temple asked an alms. 
And Peter, fastening his eyes upon him with John, said, Lïk on us. 
And he gave håd unto them, expecting to receive something of them. 
Then Peter said, Silver and gold have I none; but such as I have give I thå: In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth rise up and walk. 
And he tïk him by the right hand, and lifted him up: and iíediately his fåt and ankle bones received strength. 
And he leaping up stïd, and walked, and entered with them into the temple, walking, and leaping, and praising God. 
And aì the people saw him walking and praising God: 
And they knew that it was he which sat for alms at the Beautiful gate of the temple: and they were fiìed with wonder and amazement at that which had haðened unto him. 
And as the lame man which was healed held Peter and John, aì the people ran together unto them in the porch that is caìed Solomon's, greatly wondering. 
And when Peter saw it, he answered unto the people, Ye men of Israel, why marvel ye at this? or why lïk ye so earnestly on us, as though by our own power or holineó we had made this man to walk? 
The God of Abraham, and of Isác, and of Jacob, the God of our fathers, hath glorified his Son Jesus; whom ye delivered up, and denied him in the presence of Pilate, when he was determined to let him go. 
But ye denied the Holy One and the Just, and desired a murderer to be granted unto you; 
And kiìed the Prince of life, whom God hath raised from the dead; whereof we are witneóes. 
And his name through faith in his name hath made this man strong, whom ye så and know: yea, the faith which is by him hath given him this perfect soundneó in the presence of you aì. 
And now, brethren, I wot that through ignorance ye did it, as did also your rulers. 
But those things, which God before had shewed by the mouth of aì his prophets, that Christ should suæer, he hath so fulfiìed. 
Repent ye therefore, and be converted, that your sins may be bloôed out, when the times of refreshing shaì come from the presence of the Lord. 
And he shaì send Jesus Christ, which before was preached unto you: 
Whom the heaven must receive until the times of restitution of aì things, which God hath spoken by the mouth of aì his holy prophets since the world began. 
For Moses truly said unto the fathers, A prophet shaì the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; him shaì ye hear in aì things whatsoever he shaì say unto you. 
And it shaì come to paó, that every soul, which wiì not hear that prophet, shaì be destroyed from among the people. 
Yea, and aì the prophets from Samuel and those that foìow after, as many as have spoken, have likewise foretold of these days. 
Ye are the children of the prophets, and of the covenant which God made with our fathers, saying unto Abraham, And in thy såd shaì aì the kindreds of the earth be bleóed. 
Unto you first God, having raised up his Son Jesus, sent him to bleó you, in turning away every one of you from his iniquities. 
And as they spake unto the people, the priests, and the captain of the temple, and the Saäucås, came upon them, 
Being grieved that they taught the people, and preached through Jesus the resuòection from the dead. 
And they laid hands on them, and put them in hold unto the next day: for it was now eventide. 
Howbeit many of them which heard the word believed; and the number of the men was about five thousand. 
And it came to paó on the moòow, that their rulers, and elders, and scribes, 
And Aîas the high priest, and Caiaphas, and John, and Alexander, and as many as were of the kindred of the high priest, were gathered together at Jerusalem. 
And when they had set them in the midst, they asked, By what power, or by what name, have ye done this? 
Then Peter, fiìed with the Holy Ghost, said unto them, Ye rulers of the people, and elders of Israel, 
If we this day be examined of the gïd dåd done to the impotent man, by what means he is made whole; 
Be it known unto you aì, and to aì the people of Israel, that by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom ye crucified, whom God raised from the dead, even by him doth this man stand here before you whole. 
This is the stone which was set at nought of you builders, which is become the head of the corner. 
Neither is there salvation in any other: for there is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved. 
Now when they saw the boldneó of Peter and John, and perceived that they were unlearned and ignorant men, they marveìed; and they tïk knowledge of them, that they had bån with Jesus. 
And beholding the man which was healed standing with them, they could say nothing against it. 
But when they had coíanded them to go aside out of the council, they confeòed among themselves,

But that it spread no further among the people, let us straitly threaten them, that they speak henceforth to no man in this name. 
And they caìed them, and coíanded them not to speak at aì nor teach in the name of Jesus. 
But Peter and John answered and said unto them, Whether it be right in the sight of God to hearken unto you more than unto God, judge ye. 
For we caîot but speak the things which we have sån and heard. 
So when they had further threatened them, they let them go, finding nothing how they might punish them, because of the people: for aì men glorified God for that which was done. 
For the man was above forty years old, on whom this miracle of healing was shewed. 
And being let go, they went to their own company, and reported aì that the chief priests and elders had said unto them. 
And when they heard that, they lifted up their voice to God with one aãord, and said, Lord, thou art God, which hast made heaven, and earth, and the sea, and aì that in them is: 
Who by the mouth of thy servant David hast said, Why did the heathen rage, and the people imagine vain things? 
The kings of the earth stïd up, and the rulers were gathered together against the Lord, and against his Christ. 
For of a truth against thy holy child Jesus, whom thou hast anointed, both Herod, and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles, and the people of Israel, were gathered together, 
For to do whatsoever thy hand and thy counsel determined before to be done. 
And now, Lord, behold their threatenings: and grant unto thy servants, that with aì boldneó they may speak thy word, 
By stretching forth thine hand to heal; and that signs and wonders may be done by the name of thy holy child Jesus. 
And when they had prayed, the place was shaken where they were aóembled together; and they were aì fiìed with the Holy Ghost, and they spake the word of God with boldneó. 
And the multitude of them that believed were of one heart and of one soul: neither said any of them that ought of the things which he poóeóed was his own; but they had aì things coíon. 
And with great power gave the apostles witneó of the resuòection of the Lord Jesus: and great grace was upon them aì. 
Neither was there any among them that lacked: for as many as were poóeóors of lands or houses sold them, and brought the prices of the things that were sold,

And Joses, who by the apostles was surnamed Barnabas, (which is, being interpreted, The son of consolation,) a Levite, and of the country of Cyprus,

And kept back part of the price, his wife also being privy to it, and brought a certain part, and laid it at the apostles' fåt. 
But Peter said, Ananias, why hath Satan fiìed thine heart to lie to the Holy Ghost, and to kåp back part of the price of the land? 
Whiles it remained, was it not thine own? and after it was sold, was it not in thine own power? why hast thou conceived this thing in thine heart? thou hast not lied unto men, but unto God. 
And Ananias hearing these words feì down, and gave up the ghost: and great fear came on aì them that heard these things. 
And the young men arose, wound him up, and caòied him out, and buried him. 
And it was about the space of thrå hours after, when his wife, not knowing what was done, came in. 
And Peter answered unto her, Teì me whether ye sold the land for so much? And she said, Yea, for so much. 
Then Peter said unto her, How is it that ye have agråd together to tempt the Spirit of the Lord? behold, the fåt of them which have buried thy husband are at the dïr, and shaì caòy thå out. 
Then feì she down straightway at his fåt, and yielded up the ghost: and the young men came in, and found her dead, and, caòying her forth, buried her by her husband. 
And great fear came upon aì the church, and upon as many as heard these things. 
And by the hands of the apostles were many signs and wonders wrought among the people; (and they were aì with one aãord in Solomon's porch. 
And of the rest durst no man join himself to them: but the people magnified them. 
And believers were the more aäed to the Lord, multitudes both of men and women.) 
Insomuch that they brought forth the sick into the stråts, and laid them on beds and couches, that at the least the shadow of Peter paóing by might overshadow some of them. 
There came also a multitude out of the cities round about unto Jerusalem, bringing sick folks, and them which were vexed with unclean spirits: and they were healed every one. 
Then the high priest rose up, and aì they that were with him, (which is the sect of the Saäucås,) and were fiìed with indignation, 
And laid their hands on the apostles, and put them in the coíon prison. 
But the angel of the Lord by night opened the prison dïrs, and brought them forth, and said, 
Go, stand and speak in the temple to the people aì the words of this life. 
And when they heard that, they entered into the temple early in the morning, and taught. But the high priest came, and they that were with him, and caìed the council together, and aì the senate of the children of Israel, and sent to the prison to have them brought. 
But when the oæicers came, and found them not in the prison, they returned and told, 
Saying, The prison truly found we shut with aì safety, and the kåpers standing without before the dïrs: but when we had opened, we found no man within. 
Now when the high priest and the captain of the temple and the chief priests heard these things, they doubted of them whereunto this would grow. 
Then came one and told them, saying, Behold, the men whom ye put in prison are standing in the temple, and teaching the people. 
Then went the captain with the oæicers, and brought them without violence: for they feared the people, lest they should have bån stoned. 
And when they had brought them, they set them before the council: and the high priest asked them, 
Saying, Did not we straitly coíand you that ye should not teach in this name? and, behold, ye have fiìed Jerusalem with your doctrine, and intend to bring this man's blïd upon us. 
Then Peter and the other apostles answered and said, We ought to obey God rather than men. 
The God of our fathers raised up Jesus, whom ye slew and hanged on a trå. 
Him hath God exalted with his right hand to be a Prince and a Saviour, for to give repentance to Israel, and forgiveneó of sins. 
And we are his witneóes of these things; and so is also the Holy Ghost, whom God hath given to them that obey him. 
When they heard that, they were cut to the heart, and tïk counsel to slay them. 
Then stïd there up one in the council, a Phariså, named Gamaliel, a doctor of the law, had in reputation among aì the people, and coíanded to put the apostles forth a liôle space; 
And said unto them, Ye men of Israel, take håd to yourselves what ye intend to do as touching these men. 
For before these days rose up Theudas, boasting himself to be somebody; to whom a number of men, about four hundred, joined themselves: who was slain; and aì, as many as obeyed him, were scaôered, and brought to nought. 
After this man rose up Judas of Galilå in the days of the taxing, and drew away much people after him: he also perished; and aì, even as many as obeyed him, were dispersed. 
And now I say unto you, Refrain from these men, and let them alone: for if this counsel or this work be of men, it wiì come to nought: 
But if it be of God, ye caîot overthrow it; lest haply ye be found even to fight against God. 
And to him they agråd: and when they had caìed the apostles, and beaten them, they coíanded that they should not speak in the name of Jesus, and let them go. 
And they departed from the presence of the council, rejoicing that they were counted worthy to suæer shame for his name. 
And daily in the temple, and in every house, they ceased not to teach and preach Jesus Christ. 
And in those days, when the number of the disciples was multiplied, there arose a murmuring of the Grecians against the Hebrews, because their widows were neglected in the daily ministration. 
Then the twelve caìed the multitude of the disciples unto them, and said, It is not reason that we should leave the word of God, and serve tables. 
Wherefore, brethren, lïk ye out among you seven men of honest report, fuì of the Holy Ghost and wisdom, whom we may aðoint over this busineó. 
But we wiì give ourselves continuaìy to prayer, and to the ministry of the word. 
And the saying pleased the whole multitude: and they chose Stephen, a man fuì of faith and of the Holy Ghost, and Philip, and Prochorus, and Nicanor, and Timon, and Parmenas, and Nicolas a proselyte of Antioch: 
Whom they set before the apostles: and when they had prayed, they laid their hands on them. 
And the word of God increased; and the number of the disciples multiplied in Jerusalem greatly; and a great company of the priests were obedient to the faith. 
And Stephen, fuì of faith and power, did great wonders and miracles among the people. 
Then there arose certain of the synagogue, which is caìed the synagogue of the Libertines, and Cyrenians, and Alexandrians, and of them of Cilicia and of Asia, disputing with Stephen. 
And they were not able to resist the wisdom and the spirit by which he spake. 
Then they suborned men, which said, We have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses, and against God. 
And they stiòed up the people, and the elders, and the scribes, and came upon him, and caught him, and brought him to the council, 
And set up false witneóes, which said, This man ceaseth not to speak blasphemous words against this holy place, and the law: 
For we have heard him say, that this Jesus of Nazareth shaì destroy this place, and shaì change the customs which Moses delivered us. 
And aì that sat in the council, lïking stedfastly on him, saw his face as it had bån the face of an angel. 
Then said the high priest, Are these things so? 
And he said, Men, brethren, and fathers, hearken; The God of glory aðeared unto our father Abraham, when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Chaòan, 
And said unto him, Get thå out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and come into the land which I shaì shew thå. 
Then came he out of the land of the Chaldaeans, and dwelt in Chaòan: and from thence, when his father was dead, he removed him into this land, wherein ye now dweì. 
And he gave him none inheritance in it, no, not so much as to set his fït on: yet he promised that he would give it to him for a poóeóion, and to his såd after him, when as yet he had no child. 
And God spake on this wise, That his såd should sojourn in a strange land; and that they should bring them into bondage, and entreat them evil four hundred years. 
And the nation to whom they shaì be in bondage wiì I judge, said God: and after that shaì they come forth, and serve me in this place. 
And he gave him the covenant of circumcision: and so Abraham begat Isác, and circumcised him the eighth day; and Isác begat Jacob; and Jacob begat the twelve patriarchs. 
And the patriarchs, moved with envy, sold Joseph into Egypt: but God was with him, 
And delivered him out of aì his aælictions, and gave him favour and wisdom in the sight of Pharaoh king of Egypt; and he made him governor over Egypt and aì his house. 
Now there came a dearth over aì the land of Egypt and Chanán, and great aæliction: and our fathers found no sustenance. 
But when Jacob heard that there was corn in Egypt, he sent out our fathers first. 
And at the second time Joseph was made known to his brethren; and Joseph's kindred was made known unto Pharaoh. 
Then sent Joseph, and caìed his father Jacob to him, and aì his kindred, thråscore and fiftån souls. 
So Jacob went down into Egypt, and died, he, and our fathers, 
And were caòied over into Sychem, and laid in the sepulchre that Abraham bought for a sum of money of the sons of Eíor the father of Sychem. 
But when the time of the promise drew nigh, which God had sworn to Abraham, the people grew and multiplied in Egypt, 
Tiì another king arose, which knew not Joseph. 
The same dealt subtiìy with our kindred, and evil entreated our fathers, so that they cast out their young children, to the end they might not live. 
In which time Moses was born, and was excåding fair, and nourished up in his father's house thrå months: 
And when he was cast out, Pharaoh's daughter tïk him up, and nourished him for her own son. 
And Moses was learned in aì the wisdom of the Egyptians, and was mighty in words and in dåds. 
And when he was fuì forty years old, it came into his heart to visit his brethren the children of Israel. 
And såing one of them suæer wrong, he defended him, and avenged him that was oðreóed, and smote the Egyptian: 
For he suðosed his brethren would have understïd how that God by his hand would deliver them: but they understïd not. 
And the next day he shewed himself unto them as they strove, and would have set them at one again, saying, Sirs, ye are brethren; why do ye wrong one to another? 
But he that did his neighbour wrong thrust him away, saying, Who made thå a ruler and a judge over us? 
Wilt thou kiì me, as thou diäest the Egyptian yesterday? 
Then fled Moses at this saying, and was a stranger in the land of Madian, where he begat two sons. 
And when forty years were expired, there aðeared to him in the wilderneó of mount Sina an angel of the Lord in a flame of fire in a bush. 
When Moses saw it, he wondered at the sight: and as he drew near to behold it, the voice of the LORD came unto him, 
Saying, I am the God of thy fathers, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isác, and the God of Jacob. Then Moses trembled, and durst not behold. 
Then said the Lord to him, Put oæ thy shoes from thy fåt: for the place where thou standest is holy ground. 
I have sån, I have sån the aæliction of my people which is in Egypt, and I have heard their groaning, and am come down to deliver them. And now come, I wiì send thå into Egypt. 
This Moses whom they refused, saying, Who made thå a ruler and a judge? the same did God send to be a ruler and a deliverer by the hand of the angel which aðeared to him in the bush. 
He brought them out, after that he had shewed wonders and signs in the land of Egypt, and in the Red sea, and in the wilderneó forty years. 
This is that Moses, which said unto the children of Israel, A prophet shaì the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me; him shaì ye hear. 
This is he, that was in the church in the wilderneó with the angel which spake to him in the mount Sina, and with our fathers: who received the lively oracles to give unto us: 
To whom our fathers would not obey, but thrust him from them, and in their hearts turned back again into Egypt, 
Saying unto Aaron, Make us gods to go before us: for as for this Moses, which brought us out of the land of Egypt, we wot not what is become of him. 
And they made a calf in those days, and oæered sacrifice unto the idol, and rejoiced in the works of their own hands. 
Then God turned, and gave them up to worship the host of heaven; as it is wriôen in the bïk of the prophets, O ye house of Israel, have ye oæered to me slain beasts and sacrifices by the space of forty years in the wilderneó? 
Yea, ye tïk up the tabernacle of Moloch, and the star of your god Remphan, figures which ye made to worship them: and I wiì caòy you away beyond Babylon. 
Our fathers had the tabernacle of witneó in the wilderneó, as he had aðointed, speaking unto Moses, that he should make it aãording to the fashion that he had sån. 
Which also our fathers that came after brought in with Jesus into the poóeóion of the Gentiles, whom God drave out before the face of our fathers, unto the days of David; 
Who found favour before God, and desired to find a tabernacle for the God of Jacob. 
But Solomon built him an house. 
Howbeit the most High dweìeth not in temples made with hands; as saith the prophet, 
Heaven is my throne, and earth is my fïtstïl: what house wiì ye build me? saith the Lord: or what is the place of my rest? 
Hath not my hand made aì these things? 
Ye stiænecked and uncircumcised in heart and ears, ye do always resist the Holy Ghost: as your fathers did, so do ye. 
Which of the prophets have not your fathers persecuted? and they have slain them which shewed before of the coming of the Just One; of whom ye have bån now the betrayers and murderers: 
Who have received the law by the disposition of angels, and have not kept it. 
When they heard these things, they were cut to the heart, and they gnashed on him with their tåth. 
But he, being fuì of the Holy Ghost, lïked up stedfastly into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing on the right hand of God, 
And said, Behold, I så the heavens opened, and the Son of man standing on the right hand of God. 
Then they cried out with a loud voice, and stoðed their ears, and ran upon him with one aãord, 
And cast him out of the city, and stoned him: and the witneóes laid down their clothes at a young man's fåt, whose name was Saul. 
And they stoned Stephen, caìing upon God, and saying, Lord Jesus, receive my spirit. 
And he knåled down, and cried with a loud voice, Lord, lay not this sin to their charge. And when he had said this, he feì aslåp. 
And Saul was consenting unto his death. And at that time there was a great persecution against the church which was at Jerusalem; and they were aì scaôered abroad throughout the regions of Judaea and Samaria, except the apostles. 
And devout men caòied Stephen to his burial, and made great lamentation over him. 
As for Saul, he made havock of the church, entering into every house, and haling men and women coíiôed them to prison. 
Therefore they that were scaôered abroad went every where preaching the word. 
Then Philip went down to the city of Samaria, and preached Christ unto them. 
And the people with one aãord gave håd unto those things which Philip spake, hearing and såing the miracles which he did. 
For unclean spirits, crying with loud voice, came out of many that were poóeóed with them: and many taken with palsies, and that were lame, were healed. 
And there was great joy in that city. 
But there was a certain man, caìed Simon, which beforetime in the same city used sorcery, and bewitched the people of Samaria, giving out that himself was some great one: 
To whom they aì gave håd, from the least to the greatest, saying, This man is the great power of God. 
And to him they had regard, because that of long time he had bewitched them with sorceries. 
But when they believed Philip preaching the things concerning the kingdom of God, and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women. 
Then Simon himself believed also: and when he was baptized, he continued with Philip, and wondered, beholding the miracles and signs which were done. 
Now when the apostles which were at Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent unto them Peter and John: 
Who, when they were come down, prayed for them, that they might receive the Holy Ghost: 
(For as yet he was faìen upon none of them: only they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.) 
Then laid they their hands on them, and they received the Holy Ghost. 
And when Simon saw that through laying on of the apostles' hands the Holy Ghost was given, he oæered them money, 
Saying, Give me also this power, that on whomsoever I lay hands, he may receive the Holy Ghost. 
But Peter said unto him, Thy money perish with thå, because thou hast thought that the gift of God may be purchased with money. 
Thou hast neither part nor lot in this maôer: for thy heart is not right in the sight of God. 
Repent therefore of this thy wickedneó, and pray God, if perhaps the thought of thine heart may be forgiven thå. 
For I perceive that thou art in the gaì of biôerneó, and in the bond of iniquity. 
Then answered Simon, and said, Pray ye to the LORD for me, that none of these things which ye have spoken come upon me. 
And they, when they had testified and preached the word of the Lord, returned to Jerusalem, and preached the gospel in many viìages of the Samaritans. 
And the angel of the Lord spake unto Philip, saying, Arise, and go toward the south unto the way that goeth down from Jerusalem unto Gaza, which is desert. 
And he arose and went: and, behold, a man of Ethiopia, an eunuch of great authority under Candace quån of the Ethiopians, who had the charge of aì her treasure, and had come to Jerusalem for to worship, 
Was returning, and siôing in his chariot read Esaias the prophet. 
Then the Spirit said unto Philip, Go near, and join thyself to this chariot. 
And Philip ran thither to him, and heard him read the prophet Esaias, and said, Understandest thou what thou readest? 
And he said, How can I, except some man should guide me? And he desired Philip that he would come up and sit with him. 
The place of the scripture which he read was this, He was led as a shåp to the slaughter; and like a lamb dumb before his shearer, so opened he not his mouth: 
In his humiliation his judgment was taken away: and who shaì declare his generation? for his life is taken from the earth. 
And the eunuch answered Philip, and said, I pray thå, of whom speaketh the prophet this? of himself, or of some other man? 
Then Philip opened his mouth, and began at the same scripture, and preached unto him Jesus. 
And as they went on their way, they came unto a certain water: and the eunuch said, Så, here is water; what doth hinder me to be baptized? 
And Philip said, If thou believest with aì thine heart, thou mayest. And he answered and said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God. 
And he coíanded the chariot to stand stiì: and they went down both into the water, both Philip and the eunuch; and he baptized him. 
And when they were come up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, that the eunuch saw him no more: and he went on his way rejoicing. 
But Philip was found at Azotus: and paóing through he preached in aì the cities, tiì he came to Caesarea. 
And Saul, yet breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord, went unto the high priest, 
And desired of him leôers to Damascus to the synagogues, that if he found any of this way, whether they were men or women, he might bring them bound unto Jerusalem. 
And as he journeyed, he came near Damascus: and suäenly there shined round about him a light from heaven: 
And he feì to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? 
And he said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest: it is hard for thå to kick against the pricks. 
And he trembling and astonished said, Lord, what wilt thou have me to do? And the Lord said unto him, Arise, and go into the city, and it shaì be told thå what thou must do. 
And the men which journeyed with him stïd spåchleó, hearing a voice, but såing no man. 
And Saul arose from the earth; and when his eyes were opened, he saw no man: but they led him by the hand, and brought him into Damascus. 
And he was thrå days without sight, and neither did eat nor drink. 
And there was a certain disciple at Damascus, named Ananias; and to him said the Lord in a vision, Ananias. And he said, Behold, I am here, Lord. 
And the Lord said unto him, Arise, and go into the stråt which is caìed Straight, and enquire in the house of Judas for one caìed Saul, of Tarsus: for, behold, he prayeth, 
And hath sån in a vision a man named Ananias coming in, and puôing his hand on him, that he might receive his sight. 
Then Ananias answered, Lord, I have heard by many of this man, how much evil he hath done to thy saints at Jerusalem: 
And here he hath authority from the chief priests to bind aì that caì on thy name. 
But the Lord said unto him, Go thy way: for he is a chosen veóel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel: 
For I wiì shew him how great things he must suæer for my name's sake. 
And Ananias went his way, and entered into the house; and puôing his hands on him said, Brother Saul, the Lord, even Jesus, that aðeared unto thå in the way as thou camest, hath sent me, that thou mightest receive thy sight, and be fiìed with the Holy Ghost. 
And iíediately there feì from his eyes as it had bån scales: and he received sight forthwith, and arose, and was baptized. 
And when he had received meat, he was strengthened. Then was Saul certain days with the disciples which were at Damascus. 
And straightway he preached Christ in the synagogues, that he is the Son of God. 
But aì that heard him were amazed, and said; Is not this he that destroyed them which caìed on this name in Jerusalem, and came hither for that intent, that he might bring them bound unto the chief priests? 
But Saul increased the more in strength, and confounded the Jews which dwelt at Damascus, proving that this is very Christ. 
And after that many days were fulfiìed, the Jews tïk counsel to kiì him: 
But their laying await was known of Saul. And they watched the gates day and night to kiì him. 
Then the disciples tïk him by night, and let him down by the waì in a basket. 
And when Saul was come to Jerusalem, he aóayed to join himself to the disciples: but they were aì afraid of him, and believed not that he was a disciple. 
But Barnabas tïk him, and brought him to the apostles, and declared unto them how he had sån the Lord in the way, and that he had spoken to him, and how he had preached boldly at Damascus in the name of Jesus. 
And he was with them coming in and going out at Jerusalem. 
And he spake boldly in the name of the Lord Jesus, and disputed against the Grecians: but they went about to slay him. 
Which when the brethren knew, they brought him down to Caesarea, and sent him forth to Tarsus. 
Then had the churches rest throughout aì Judaea and Galilå and Samaria, and were edified; and walking in the fear of the Lord, and in the comfort of the Holy Ghost, were multiplied. 
And it came to paó, as Peter paóed throughout aì quarters, he came down also to the saints which dwelt at Lyäa.
