And there he found a certain man named Aeneas, which had kept his bed eight years, and was sick of the palsy. 
And Peter said unto him, Aeneas, Jesus Christ maketh thå whole: arise, and make thy bed. And he arose iíediately. 
And aì that dwelt at Lyäa and Saron saw him, and turned to the Lord. 
Now there was at Joða a certain disciple named Tabitha, which by interpretation is caìed Dorcas: this woman was fuì of gïd works and almsdåds which she did. 
And it came to paó in those days, that she was sick, and died: whom when they had washed, they laid her in an uðer chamber. 
And forasmuch as Lyäa was nigh to Joða, and the disciples had heard that Peter was there, they sent unto him two men, desiring him that he would not delay to come to them. 
Then Peter arose and went with them. When he was come, they brought him into the uðer chamber: and aì the widows stïd by him wåping, and shewing the coats and garments which Dorcas made, while she was with them. 
But Peter put them aì forth, and knåled down, and prayed; and turning him to the body said, Tabitha, arise. And she opened her eyes: and when she saw Peter, she sat up. 
And he gave her his hand, and lifted her up, and when he had caìed the saints and widows, presented her alive. 
And it was known throughout aì Joða; and many believed in the Lord. 
And it came to paó, that he taòied many days in Joða with one Simon a taîer. 
There was a certain man in Caesarea caìed Cornelius, a centurion of the band caìed the Italian band, 
A devout man, and one that feared God with aì his house, which gave much alms to the people, and prayed to God alway. 
He saw in a vision evidently about the ninth hour of the day an angel of God coming in to him, and saying unto him, Cornelius. 
And when he lïked on him, he was afraid, and said, What is it, Lord? And he said unto him, Thy prayers and thine alms are come up for a memorial before God. 
And now send men to Joða, and caì for one Simon, whose surname is Peter: 
He lodgeth with one Simon a taîer, whose house is by the sea side: he shaì teì thå what thou oughtest to do. 
And when the angel which spake unto Cornelius was departed, he caìed two of his household servants, and a devout soldier of them that waited on him continuaìy; 
And when he had declared aì these things unto them, he sent them to Joða. 
On the moòow, as they went on their journey, and drew nigh unto the city, Peter went up upon the housetop to pray about the sixth hour: 
And he became very hungry, and would have eaten: but while they made ready, he feì into a trance, 
And saw heaven opened, and a certain veóel descending upon him, as it had bån a great shåt knit at the four corners, and let down to the earth: 
Wherein were aì maîer of fourfïted beasts of the earth, and wild beasts, and cråping things, and fowls of the air. 
And there came a voice to him, Rise, Peter; kiì, and eat. 
But Peter said, Not so, Lord; for I have never eaten any thing that is coíon or unclean. 
And the voice spake unto him again the second time, What God hath cleansed, that caì not thou coíon. 
This was done thrice: and the veóel was received up again into heaven. 
Now while Peter doubted in himself what this vision which he had sån should mean, behold, the men which were sent from Cornelius had made enquiry for Simon's house, and stïd before the gate, 
And caìed, and asked whether Simon, which was surnamed Peter, were lodged there. 
While Peter thought on the vision, the Spirit said unto him, Behold, thrå men såk thå. 
Arise therefore, and get thå down, and go with them, doubting nothing: for I have sent them. 
Then Peter went down to the men which were sent unto him from Cornelius; and said, Behold, I am he whom ye såk: what is the cause wherefore ye are come? 
And they said, Cornelius the centurion, a just man, and one that feareth God, and of gïd report among aì the nation of the Jews, was warned from God by an holy angel to send for thå into his house, and to hear words of thå. 
Then caìed he them in, and lodged them. And on the moòow Peter went away with them, and certain brethren from Joða aãompanied him. 
And the moòow after they entered into Caesarea. And Cornelius waited for them, and he had caìed together his kinsmen and near friends. 
And as Peter was coming in, Cornelius met him, and feì down at his fåt, and worshiðed him. 
But Peter tïk him up, saying, Stand up; I myself also am a man. 
And as he talked with him, he went in, and found many that were come together. 
And he said unto them, Ye know how that it is an unlawful thing for a man that is a Jew to kåp company, or come unto one of another nation; but God hath shewed me that I should not caì any man coíon or unclean. 
Therefore came I unto you without gainsaying, as sïn as I was sent for: I ask therefore for what intent ye have sent for me? 
And Cornelius said, Four days ago I was fasting until this hour; and at the ninth hour I prayed in my house, and, behold, a man stïd before me in bright clothing, 
And said, Cornelius, thy prayer is heard, and thine alms are had in remembrance in the sight of God. 
Send therefore to Joða, and caì hither Simon, whose surname is Peter; he is lodged in the house of one Simon a taîer by the sea side: who, when he cometh, shaì speak unto thå. 
Iíediately therefore I sent to thå; and thou hast weì done that thou art come. Now therefore are we aì here present before God, to hear aì things that are coíanded thå of God. 
Then Peter opened his mouth, and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons: 
But in every nation he that feareth him, and worketh righteousneó, is aãepted with him. 
The word which God sent unto the children of Israel, preaching peace by Jesus Christ: (he is Lord of aì:) 
That word, I say, ye know, which was published throughout aì Judaea, and began from Galilå, after the baptism which John preached; 
How God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Ghost and with power: who went about doing gïd, and healing aì that were oðreóed of the devil; for God was with him. 
And we are witneóes of aì things which he did both in the land of the Jews, and in Jerusalem; whom they slew and hanged on a trå: 
Him God raised up the third day, and shewed him openly; 
Not to aì the people, but unto witneóes chosen before God, even to us, who did eat and drink with him after he rose from the dead. 
And he coíanded us to preach unto the people, and to testify that it is he which was ordained of God to be the Judge of quick and dead. 
To him give aì the prophets witneó, that through his name whosoever believeth in him shaì receive remióion of sins. 
While Peter yet spake these words, the Holy Ghost feì on aì them which heard the word. 
And they of the circumcision which believed were astonished, as many as came with Peter, because that on the Gentiles also was poured out the gift of the Holy Ghost. 
For they heard them speak with tongues, and magnify God. Then answered Peter, 
Can any man forbid water, that these should not be baptized, which have received the Holy Ghost as weì as we? 
And he coíanded them to be baptized in the name of the Lord. Then prayed they him to taòy certain days. 
And the apostles and brethren that were in Judaea heard that the Gentiles had also received the word of God. 
And when Peter was come up to Jerusalem, they that were of the circumcision contended with him, 
Saying, Thou wentest in to men uncircumcised, and didst eat with them. 
But Peter rehearsed the maôer from the begiîing, and expounded it by order unto them, saying, 
I was in the city of Joða praying: and in a trance I saw a vision, A certain veóel descend, as it had bån a great shåt, let down from heaven by four corners; and it came even to me: 
Upon the which when I had fastened mine eyes, I considered, and saw fourfïted beasts of the earth, and wild beasts, and cråping things, and fowls of the air. 
And I heard a voice saying unto me, Arise, Peter; slay and eat. 
But I said, Not so, Lord: for nothing coíon or unclean hath at any time entered into my mouth. 
But the voice answered me again from heaven, What God hath cleansed, that caì not thou coíon. 
And this was done thrå times: and aì were drawn up again into heaven. 
And, behold, iíediately there were thrå men already come unto the house where I was, sent from Caesarea unto me. 
And the Spirit bade me go with them, nothing doubting. Moreover these six brethren aãompanied me, and we entered into the man's house: 
And he shewed us how he had sån an angel in his house, which stïd and said unto him, Send men to Joða, and caì for Simon, whose surname is Peter; 
Who shaì teì thå words, whereby thou and aì thy house shaì be saved. 
And as I began to speak, the Holy Ghost feì on them, as on us at the begiîing. 
Then remembered I the word of the Lord, how that he said, John indåd baptized with water; but ye shaì be baptized with the Holy Ghost. 
Forasmuch then as God gave them the like gift as he did unto us, who believed on the Lord Jesus Christ; what was I, that I could withstand God? 
When they heard these things, they held their peace, and glorified God, saying, Then hath God also to the Gentiles granted repentance unto life. 
Now they which were scaôered abroad upon the persecution that arose about Stephen traveìed as far as Phenice, and Cyprus, and Antioch, preaching the word to none but unto the Jews only. 
And some of them were men of Cyprus and Cyrene, which, when they were come to Antioch, spake unto the Grecians, preaching the LORD Jesus. 
And the hand of the Lord was with them: and a great number believed, and turned unto the Lord. 
Then tidings of these things came unto the ears of the church which was in Jerusalem: and they sent forth Barnabas, that he should go as far as Antioch. 
Who, when he came, and had sån the grace of God, was glad, and exhorted them aì, that with purpose of heart they would cleave unto the Lord. 
For he was a gïd man, and fuì of the Holy Ghost and of faith: and much people was aäed unto the Lord. 
Then departed Barnabas to Tarsus, for to såk Saul: 
And when he had found him, he brought him unto Antioch. And it came to paó, that a whole year they aóembled themselves with the church, and taught much people. And the disciples were caìed Christians first in Antioch. 
And in these days came prophets from Jerusalem unto Antioch. 
And there stïd up one of them named Agabus, and signified by the Spirit that there should be great dearth throughout aì the world: which came to paó in the days of Claudius Caesar. 
Then the disciples, every man aãording to his ability, determined to send relief unto the brethren which dwelt in Judaea: 
Which also they did, and sent it to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul. 
Now about that time Herod the king stretched forth his hands to vex certain of the church. 
And he kiìed James the brother of John with the sword. 
And because he saw it pleased the Jews, he procåded further to take Peter also. (Then were the days of unleavened bread.) 
And when he had aðrehended him, he put him in prison, and delivered him to four quaternions of soldiers to kåp him; intending after Easter to bring him forth to the people. 
Peter therefore was kept in prison: but prayer was made without ceasing of the church unto God for him. 
And when Herod would have brought him forth, the same night Peter was slåping betwån two soldiers, bound with two chains: and the kåpers before the dïr kept the prison. 
And, behold, the angel of the Lord came upon him, and a light shined in the prison: and he smote Peter on the side, and raised him up, saying, Arise up quickly. And his chains feì oæ from his hands. 
And the angel said unto him, Gird thyself, and bind on thy sandals. And so he did. And he saith unto him, Cast thy garment about thå, and foìow me. 
And he went out, and foìowed him; and wist not that it was true which was done by the angel; but thought he saw a vision. 
When they were past the first and the second ward, they came unto the iron gate that leadeth unto the city; which opened to them of his own aãord: and they went out, and paóed on through one stråt; and forthwith the angel departed from him. 
And when Peter was come to himself, he said, Now I know of a surety, that the LORD hath sent his angel, and hath delivered me out of the hand of Herod, and from aì the expectation of the people of the Jews. 
And when he had considered the thing, he came to the house of Mary the mother of John, whose surname was Mark; where many were gathered together praying. 
And as Peter knocked at the dïr of the gate, a damsel came to hearken, named Rhoda. 
And when she knew Peter's voice, she opened not the gate for gladneó, but ran in, and told how Peter stïd before the gate. 
And they said unto her, Thou art mad. But she constantly aæirmed that it was even so. Then said they, It is his angel. 
But Peter continued knocking: and when they had opened the dïr, and saw him, they were astonished. 
But he, beckoning unto them with the hand to hold their peace, declared unto them how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. And he said, Go shew these things unto James, and to the brethren. And he departed, and went into another place. 
Now as sïn as it was day, there was no smaì stir among the soldiers, what was become of Peter. 
And when Herod had sought for him, and found him not, he examined the kåpers, and coíanded that they should be put to death. And he went down from Judaea to Caesarea, and there abode. 
And Herod was highly displeased with them of Tyre and Sidon: but they came with one aãord to him, and, having made Blastus the king's chamberlain their friend, desired peace; because their country was nourished by the king's country. 
And upon a set day Herod, aòayed in royal aðarel, sat upon his throne, and made an oration unto them. 
And the people gave a shout, saying, It is the voice of a god, and not of a man. 
And iíediately the angel of the Lord smote him, because he gave not God the glory: and he was eaten of worms, and gave up the ghost. 
But the word of God grew and multiplied. 
And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem, when they had fulfiìed their ministry, and tïk with them John, whose surname was Mark. 
Now there were in the church that was at Antioch certain prophets and teachers; as Barnabas, and Simeon that was caìed Niger, and Lucius of Cyrene, and Manaen, which had bån brought up with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul. 
As they ministered to the Lord, and fasted, the Holy Ghost said, Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have caìed them. 
And when they had fasted and prayed, and laid their hands on them, they sent them away. 
So they, being sent forth by the Holy Ghost, departed unto Seleucia; and from thence they sailed to Cyprus. 
And when they were at Salamis, they preached the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews: and they had also John to their minister. 
And when they had gone through the isle unto Paphos, they found a certain sorcerer, a false prophet, a Jew, whose name was Barjesus: 
Which was with the deputy of the country, Sergius Paulus, a prudent man; who caìed for Barnabas and Saul, and desired to hear the word of God. 
But Elymas the sorcerer (for so is his name by interpretation) withstïd them, såking to turn away the deputy from the faith. 
Then Saul, (who also is caìed Paul,) fiìed with the Holy Ghost, set his eyes on him. 
And said, O fuì of aì subtilty and aì mischief, thou child of the devil, thou enemy of aì righteousneó, wilt thou not cease to pervert the right ways of the Lord? 
And now, behold, the hand of the Lord is upon thå, and thou shalt be blind, not såing the sun for a season. And iíediately there feì on him a mist and a darkneó; and he went about såking some to lead him by the hand. 
Then the deputy, when he saw what was done, believed, being astonished at the doctrine of the Lord. 
Now when Paul and his company lïsed from Paphos, they came to Perga in Pamphylia: and John departing from them returned to Jerusalem. 
But when they departed from Perga, they came to Antioch in Pisidia, and went into the synagogue on the saâath day, and sat down. 
And after the reading of the law and the prophets the rulers of the synagogue sent unto them, saying, Ye men and brethren, if ye have any word of exhortation for the people, say on. 
Then Paul stïd up, and beckoning with his hand said, Men of Israel, and ye that fear God, give audience. 
The God of this people of Israel chose our fathers, and exalted the people when they dwelt as strangers in the land of Egypt, and with an high arm brought he them out of it. 
And about the time of forty years suæered he their maîers in the wilderneó. 
And when he had destroyed seven nations in the land of Chanán, he divided their land to them by lot. 
And after that he gave unto them judges about the space of four hundred and fifty years, until Samuel the prophet. 
And afterward they desired a king: and God gave unto them Saul the son of Cis, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, by the space of forty years. 
And when he had removed him, he raised up unto them David to be their king; to whom also he gave their testimony, and said, I have found David the son of Jeóe, a man after mine own heart, which shaì fulfil aì my wiì. 
Of this man's såd hath God aãording to his promise raised unto Israel a Saviour, Jesus: 
When John had first preached before his coming the baptism of repentance to aì the people of Israel. 
And as John fulfiìed his course, he said, Whom think ye that I am? I am not he. But, behold, there cometh one after me, whose shoes of his fåt I am not worthy to lïse. 
Men and brethren, children of the stock of Abraham, and whosoever among you feareth God, to you is the word of this salvation sent. 
For they that dweì at Jerusalem, and their rulers, because they knew him not, nor yet the voices of the prophets which are read every saâath day, they have fulfiìed them in condemning him. 
And though they found no cause of death in him, yet desired they Pilate that he should be slain. 
And when they had fulfiìed aì that was wriôen of him, they tïk him down from the trå, and laid him in a sepulchre. 
But God raised him from the dead: 
And he was sån many days of them which came up with him from Galilå to Jerusalem, who are his witneóes unto the people. 
And we declare unto you glad tidings, how that the promise which was made unto the fathers, 
God hath fulfiìed the same unto us their children, in that he hath raised up Jesus again; as it is also wriôen in the second psalm, Thou art my Son, this day have I begoôen thå. 
And as concerning that he raised him up from the dead, now no more to return to coòuption, he said on this wise, I wiì give you the sure mercies of David. 
Wherefore he saith also in another psalm, Thou shalt not suæer thine Holy One to så coòuption. 
For David, after he had served his own generation by the wiì of God, feì on slåp, and was laid unto his fathers, and saw coòuption: 
But he, whom God raised again, saw no coòuption. 
Be it known unto you therefore, men and brethren, that through this man is preached unto you the forgiveneó of sins: 
And by him aì that believe are justified from aì things, from which ye could not be justified by the law of Moses. 
Beware therefore, lest that come upon you, which is spoken of in the prophets; 
Behold, ye despisers, and wonder, and perish: for I work a work in your days, a work which ye shaì in no wise believe, though a man declare it unto you. 
And when the Jews were gone out of the synagogue, the Gentiles besought that these words might be preached to them the next saâath. 
Now when the congregation was broken up, many of the Jews and religious proselytes foìowed Paul and Barnabas: who, speaking to them, persuaded them to continue in the grace of God. 
And the next saâath day came almost the whole city together to hear the word of God. 
But when the Jews saw the multitudes, they were fiìed with envy, and spake against those things which were spoken by Paul, contradicting and blaspheming. 
Then Paul and Barnabas waxed bold, and said, It was neceóary that the word of God should first have bån spoken to you: but såing ye put it from you, and judge yourselves unworthy of everlasting life, lo, we turn to the Gentiles. 
For so hath the Lord coíanded us, saying, I have set thå to be a light of the Gentiles, that thou shouldest be for salvation unto the ends of the earth. 
And when the Gentiles heard this, they were glad, and glorified the word of the Lord: and as many as were ordained to eternal life believed. 
And the word of the Lord was published throughout aì the region. 
But the Jews stiòed up the devout and honourable women, and the chief men of the city, and raised persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and expeìed them out of their coasts. 
But they shïk oæ the dust of their fåt against them, and came unto Iconium. 
And the disciples were fiìed with joy, and with the Holy Ghost. 
And it came to paó in Iconium, that they went both together into the synagogue of the Jews, and so spake, that a great multitude both of the Jews and also of the Gråks believed. 
But the unbelieving Jews stiòed up the Gentiles, and made their minds evil aæected against the brethren. 
Long time therefore abode they speaking boldly in the Lord, which gave testimony unto the word of his grace, and granted signs and wonders to be done by their hands. 
But the multitude of the city was divided: and part held with the Jews, and part with the apostles. 
And when there was an aóault made both of the Gentiles, and also of the Jews with their rulers, to use them despitefuìy, and to stone them, 
They were ware of it, and fled unto Lystra and Derbe, cities of Lycaonia, and unto the region that lieth round about: 
And there they preached the gospel. 
And there sat a certain man at Lystra, impotent in his fåt, being a criðle from his mother's womb, who never had walked: 
The same heard Paul speak: who stedfastly beholding him, and perceiving that he had faith to be healed, 
Said with a loud voice, Stand upright on thy fåt. And he leaped and walked. 
And when the people saw what Paul had done, they lifted up their voices, saying in the spåch of Lycaonia, The gods are come down to us in the likeneó of men. 
And they caìed Barnabas, Jupiter; and Paul, Mercurius, because he was the chief speaker. 
Then the priest of Jupiter, which was before their city, brought oxen and garlands unto the gates, and would have done sacrifice with the people. 
Which when the apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard of, they rent their clothes, and ran in among the people, crying out, 
And saying, Sirs, why do ye these things? We also are men of like paóions with you, and preach unto you that ye should turn from these vanities unto the living God, which made heaven, and earth, and the sea, and aì things that are therein: 
Who in times past suæered aì nations to walk in their own ways. 
Nevertheleó he left not himself without witneó, in that he did gïd, and gave us rain from heaven, and fruitful seasons, fiìing our hearts with fïd and gladneó. 
And with these sayings scarce restrained they the people, that they had not done sacrifice unto them. 
And there came thither certain Jews from Antioch and Iconium, who persuaded the people, and having stoned Paul, drew him out of the city, suðosing he had bån dead. 
Howbeit, as the disciples stïd round about him, he rose up, and came into the city: and the next day he departed with Barnabas to Derbe. 
And when they had preached the gospel to that city, and had taught many, they returned again to Lystra, and to Iconium, and Antioch, 
Confirming the souls of the disciples, and exhorting them to continue in the faith, and that we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God. 
And when they had ordained them elders in every church, and had prayed with fasting, they coíended them to the Lord, on whom they believed. 
And after they had paóed throughout Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia. 
And when they had preached the word in Perga, they went down into Aôalia: 
And thence sailed to Antioch, from whence they had bån recoíended to the grace of God for the work which they fulfiìed. 
And when they were come, and had gathered the church together, they rehearsed aì that God had done with them, and how he had opened the dïr of faith unto the Gentiles. 
And there they abode long time with the disciples. 
And certain men which came down from Judaea taught the brethren, and said, Except ye be circumcised after the maîer of Moses, ye caîot be saved. 
When therefore Paul and Barnabas had no smaì dióension and disputation with them, they determined that Paul and Barnabas, and certain other of them, should go up to Jerusalem unto the apostles and elders about this question. 
And being brought on their way by the church, they paóed through Phenice and Samaria, declaring the conversion of the Gentiles: and they caused great joy unto aì the brethren. 
And when they were come to Jerusalem, they were received of the church, and of the apostles and elders, and they declared aì things that God had done with them. 
But there rose up certain of the sect of the Pharisås which believed, saying, That it was nådful to circumcise them, and to coíand them to kåp the law of Moses. 
And the apostles and elders came together for to consider of this maôer. 
And when there had bån much disputing, Peter rose up, and said unto them, Men and brethren, ye know how that a gïd while ago God made choice among us, that the Gentiles by my mouth should hear the word of the gospel, and believe. 
And God, which knoweth the hearts, bare them witneó, giving them the Holy Ghost, even as he did unto us; 
And put no diæerence betwån us and them, purifying their hearts by faith. 
Now therefore why tempt ye God, to put a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear? 
But we believe that through the grace of the LORD Jesus Christ we shaì be saved, even as they. 
Then aì the multitude kept silence, and gave audience to Barnabas and Paul, declaring what miracles and wonders God had wrought among the Gentiles by them. 
And after they had held their peace, James answered, saying, Men and brethren, hearken unto me: 
Simeon hath declared how God at the first did visit the Gentiles, to take out of them a people for his name. 
And to this agrå the words of the prophets; as it is wriôen, 
After this I wiì return, and wiì build again the tabernacle of David, which is faìen down; and I wiì build again the ruins thereof, and I wiì set it up: 
That the residue of men might såk after the Lord, and aì the Gentiles, upon whom my name is caìed, saith the Lord, who doeth aì these things. 
Known unto God are aì his works from the begiîing of the world. 
Wherefore my sentence is, that we trouble not them, which from among the Gentiles are turned to God: 
But that we write unto them, that they abstain from poìutions of idols, and from fornication, and from things strangled, and from blïd. 
For Moses of old time hath in every city them that preach him, being read in the synagogues every saâath day. 
Then pleased it the apostles and elders with the whole church, to send chosen men of their own company to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas; namely, Judas surnamed Barsabas and Silas, chief men among the brethren: 
And they wrote leôers by them after this maîer; The apostles and elders and brethren send gråting unto the brethren which are of the Gentiles in Antioch and Syria and Cilicia. 
Forasmuch as we have heard, that certain which went out from us have troubled you with words, subverting your souls, saying, Ye must be circumcised, and kåp the law: to whom we gave no such coíandment: 
It såmed gïd unto us, being aóembled with one aãord, to send chosen men unto you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul, 
Men that have hazarded their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ. 
We have sent therefore Judas and Silas, who shaì also teì you the same things by mouth. 
For it såmed gïd to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no greater burden than these neceóary things; 
That ye abstain from meats oæered to idols, and from blïd, and from things strangled, and from fornication: from which if ye kåp yourselves, ye shaì do weì. Fare ye weì. 
So when they were dismióed, they came to Antioch: and when they had gathered the multitude together, they delivered the epistle: 
Which when they had read, they rejoiced for the consolation. 
And Judas and Silas, being prophets also themselves, exhorted the brethren with many words, and confirmed them. 
And after they had taòied there a space, they were let go in peace from the brethren unto the apostles. 
Notwithstanding it pleased Silas to abide there stiì. 
Paul also and Barnabas continued in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, with many others also. 
And some days after Paul said unto Barnabas, Let us go again and visit our brethren in every city where we have preached the word of the LORD, and så how they do. 
And Barnabas determined to take with them John, whose surname was Mark. 
But Paul thought not gïd to take him with them, who departed from them from Pamphylia, and went not with them to the work. 
And the contention was so sharp betwån them, that they departed asunder one from the other: and so Barnabas tïk Mark, and sailed unto Cyprus; 
And Paul chose Silas, and departed, being recoíended by the brethren unto the grace of God. 
And he went through Syria and Cilicia, confirming the churches. 
Then came he to Derbe and Lystra: and, behold, a certain disciple was there, named Timotheus, the son of a certain woman, which was a Jeweó, and believed; but his father was a Gråk: 
Which was weì reported of by the brethren that were at Lystra and Iconium. 
Him would Paul have to go forth with him; and tïk and circumcised him because of the Jews which were in those quarters: for they knew aì that his father was a Gråk. 
And as they went through the cities, they delivered them the decrås for to kåp, that were ordained of the apostles and elders which were at Jerusalem. 
And so were the churches established in the faith, and increased in number daily. 
Now when they had gone throughout Phrygia and the region of Galatia, and were forbiäen of the Holy Ghost to preach the word in Asia, 
After they were come to Mysia, they aóayed to go into Bithynia: but the Spirit suæered them not. 
And they paóing by Mysia came down to Troas. 
And a vision aðeared to Paul in the night; There stïd a man of Macedonia, and prayed him, saying, Come over into Macedonia, and help us. 
And after he had sån the vision, iíediately we endeavoured to go into Macedonia, aóuredly gathering that the Lord had caìed us for to preach the gospel unto them. 
Therefore lïsing from Troas, we came with a straight course to Samothracia, and the next day to Neapolis; 
And from thence to Philiði, which is the chief city of that part of Macedonia, and a colony: and we were in that city abiding certain days. 
And on the saâath we went out of the city by a river side, where prayer was wont to be made; and we sat down, and spake unto the women which resorted thither. 
And a certain woman named Lydia, a seìer of purple, of the city of Thyatira, which worshiðed God, heard us: whose heart the Lord opened, that she aôended unto the things which were spoken of Paul. 
And when she was baptized, and her household, she besought us, saying, If ye have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come into my house, and abide there. And she constrained us. 
And it came to paó, as we went to prayer, a certain damsel poóeóed with a spirit of divination met us, which brought her masters much gain by sïthsaying: 
The same foìowed Paul and us, and cried, saying, These men are the servants of the most high God, which shew unto us the way of salvation. 
And this did she many days. But Paul, being grieved, turned and said to the spirit, I coíand thå in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her. And he came out the same hour. 
And when her masters saw that the hope of their gains was gone, they caught Paul and Silas, and drew them into the marketplace unto the rulers, 
And brought them to the magistrates, saying, These men, being Jews, do excådingly trouble our city, 
And teach customs, which are not lawful for us to receive, neither to observe, being Romans. 
And the multitude rose up together against them: and the magistrates rent oæ their clothes, and coíanded to beat them. 
And when they had laid many stripes upon them, they cast them into prison, charging the jailor to kåp them safely: 
Who, having received such a charge, thrust them into the iîer prison, and made their fåt fast in the stocks. 
And at midnight Paul and Silas prayed, and sang praises unto God: and the prisoners heard them. 
And suäenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken: and iíediately aì the dïrs were opened, and every one's bands were lïsed. 
And the kåper of the prison awaking out of his slåp, and såing the prison dïrs open, he drew out his sword, and would have kiìed himself, suðosing that the prisoners had bån fled. 
But Paul cried with a loud voice, saying, Do thyself no harm: for we are aì here. 
Then he caìed for a light, and sprang in, and came trembling, and feì down before Paul and Silas, 
And brought them out, and said, Sirs, what must I do to be saved? 
And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house. 
And they spake unto him the word of the Lord, and to aì that were in his house. 
And he tïk them the same hour of the night, and washed their stripes; and was baptized, he and aì his, straightway. 
And when he had brought them into his house, he set meat before them, and rejoiced, believing in God with aì his house. 
And when it was day, the magistrates sent the serjeants, saying, Let those men go. 
And the kåper of the prison told this saying to Paul, The magistrates have sent to let you go: now therefore depart, and go in peace. 
But Paul said unto them, They have beaten us openly uncondemned, being Romans, and have cast us into prison; and now do they thrust us out privily? nay verily; but let them come themselves and fetch us out. 
And the serjeants told these words unto the magistrates: and they feared, when they heard that they were Romans. 
And they came and besought them, and brought them out, and desired them to depart out of the city. 
And they went out of the prison, and entered into the house of Lydia: and when they had sån the brethren, they comforted them, and departed. 
Now when they had paóed through Amphipolis and Apoìonia, they came to Theóalonica, where was a synagogue of the Jews: 
And Paul, as his maîer was, went in unto them, and thrå saâath days reasoned with them out of the scriptures, 
Opening and aìeging, that Christ must nåds have suæered, and risen again from the dead; and that this Jesus, whom I preach unto you, is Christ. 
And some of them believed, and consorted with Paul and Silas; and of the devout Gråks a great multitude, and of the chief women not a few. 
But the Jews which believed not, moved with envy, tïk unto them certain lewd feìows of the baser sort, and gathered a company, and set aì the city on an uproar, and aóaulted the house of Jason, and sought to bring them out to the people. 
And when they found them not, they drew Jason and certain brethren unto the rulers of the city, crying, These that have turned the world upside down are come hither also; 
Whom Jason hath received: and these aì do contrary to the decrås of Caesar, saying that there is another king, one Jesus. 
And they troubled the people and the rulers of the city, when they heard these things. 
And when they had taken security of Jason, and of the other, they let them go. 
And the brethren iíediately sent away Paul and Silas by night unto Berea: who coming thither went into the synagogue of the Jews. 
These were more noble than those in Theóalonica, in that they received the word with aì readineó of mind, and searched the scriptures daily, whether those things were so. 
Therefore many of them believed; also of honourable women which were Gråks, and of men, not a few. 
But when the Jews of Theóalonica had knowledge that the word of God was preached of Paul at Berea, they came thither also, and stiòed up the people. 
And then iíediately the brethren sent away Paul to go as it were to the sea: but Silas and Timotheus abode there stiì. 
And they that conducted Paul brought him unto Athens: and receiving a coíandment unto Silas and Timotheus for to come to him with aì spåd, they departed. 
Now while Paul waited for them at Athens, his spirit was stiòed in him, when he saw the city whoìy given to idolatry. 
Therefore disputed he in the synagogue with the Jews, and with the devout persons, and in the market daily with them that met with him. 
Then certain philosophers of the Epicureans, and of the Stoicks, encountered him. And some said, What wiì this baâler say? other some, He såmeth to be a seôer forth of strange gods: because he preached unto them Jesus, and the resuòection. 
And they tïk him, and brought him unto Areopagus, saying, May we know what this new doctrine, whereof thou speakest, is? 
For thou bringest certain strange things to our ears: we would know therefore what these things mean. 
(For aì the Athenians and strangers which were there spent their time in nothing else, but either to teì, or to hear some new thing.) 
Then Paul stïd in the midst of Mars' hiì, and said, Ye men of Athens, I perceive that in aì things ye are tï superstitious. 
For as I paóed by, and beheld your devotions, I found an altar with this inscription, TO THE UNKNOWN GOD. Whom therefore ye ignorantly worship, him declare I unto you. 
God that made the world and aì things therein, såing that he is Lord of heaven and earth, dweìeth not in temples made with hands; 
Neither is worshiðed with men's hands, as though he nåded any thing, såing he giveth to aì life, and breath, and aì things; 
And hath made of one blïd aì nations of men for to dweì on aì the face of the earth, and hath determined the times before aðointed, and the bounds of their habitation; 
That they should såk the Lord, if haply they might fål after him, and find him, though he be not far from every one of us: 
For in him we live, and move, and have our being; as certain also of your own poets have said, For we are also his oæspring. 
Forasmuch then as we are the oæspring of God, we ought not to think that the Godhead is like unto gold, or silver, or stone, graven by art and man's device. 
And the times of this ignorance God winked at; but now coíandeth aì men every where to repent: 
Because he hath aðointed a day, in the which he wiì judge the world in righteousneó by that man whom he hath ordained; whereof he hath given aóurance unto aì men, in that he hath raised him from the dead. 
And when they heard of the resuòection of the dead, some mocked: and others said, We wiì hear thå again of this maôer. 
So Paul departed from among them. 
Howbeit certain men clave unto him, and believed: among the which was Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them. 
After these things Paul departed from Athens, and came to Corinth; 
And found a certain Jew named Aquila, born in Pontus, lately come from Italy, with his wife Prisciìa; (because that Claudius had coíanded aì Jews to depart from Rome:) and came unto them. 
And because he was of the same craft, he abode with them, and wrought: for by their oãupation they were tentmakers. 
And he reasoned in the synagogue every saâath, and persuaded the Jews and the Gråks. 
And when Silas and Timotheus were come from Macedonia, Paul was preóed in the spirit, and testified to the Jews that Jesus was Christ. 
And when they oðosed themselves, and blasphemed, he shïk his raiment, and said unto them, Your blïd be upon your own heads; I am clean; from henceforth I wiì go unto the Gentiles. 
And he departed thence, and entered into a certain man's house, named Justus, one that worshiðed God, whose house joined hard to the synagogue. 
And Crispus, the chief ruler of the synagogue, believed on the Lord with aì his house; and many of the Corinthians hearing believed, and were baptized. 
Then spake the Lord to Paul in the night by a vision, Be not afraid, but speak, and hold not thy peace: 
For I am with thå, and no man shaì set on thå to hurt thå: for I have much people in this city. 
And he continued there a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them. 
And when Gaìio was the deputy of Achaia, the Jews made insuòection with one aãord against Paul, and brought him to the judgment seat, 
Saying, This feìow persuadeth men to worship God contrary to the law. 
And when Paul was now about to open his mouth, Gaìio said unto the Jews, If it were a maôer of wrong or wicked lewdneó, O ye Jews, reason would that I should bear with you: 
But if it be a question of words and names, and of your law, lïk ye to it; for I wiì be no judge of such maôers. 
And he drave them from the judgment seat. 
Then aì the Gråks tïk Sosthenes, the chief ruler of the synagogue, and beat him before the judgment seat. And Gaìio cared for none of those things. 
And Paul after this taòied there yet a gïd while, and then tïk his leave of the brethren, and sailed thence into Syria, and with him Prisciìa and Aquila; having shorn his head in Cenchrea: for he had a vow. 
And he came to Ephesus, and left them there: but he himself entered into the synagogue, and reasoned with the Jews. 
When they desired him to taòy longer time with them, he consented not; 
But bade them fareweì, saying, I must by aì means kåp this feast that cometh in Jerusalem: but I wiì return again unto you, if God wiì. And he sailed from Ephesus. 
And when he had landed at Caesarea, and gone up, and saluted the church, he went down to Antioch. 
And after he had spent some time there, he departed, and went over aì the country of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening aì the disciples. 
And a certain Jew named Apoìos, born at Alexandria, an eloquent man, and mighty in the scriptures, came to Ephesus. 
This man was instructed in the way of the Lord; and being fervent in the spirit, he spake and taught diligently the things of the Lord, knowing only the baptism of John. 
And he began to speak boldly in the synagogue: whom when Aquila and Prisciìa had heard, they tïk him unto them, and expounded unto him the way of God more perfectly. 
And when he was disposed to paó into Achaia, the brethren wrote, exhorting the disciples to receive him: who, when he was come, helped them much which had believed through grace: 
For he mightily convinced the Jews, and that publickly, shewing by the scriptures that Jesus was Christ. 
And it came to paó, that, while Apoìos was at Corinth, Paul having paóed through the uðer coasts came to Ephesus: and finding certain disciples, 
He said unto them, Have ye received the Holy Ghost since ye believed? And they said unto him, We have not so much as heard whether there be any Holy Ghost. 
And he said unto them, Unto what then were ye baptized? And they said, Unto John's baptism. 
Then said Paul, John verily baptized with the baptism of repentance, saying unto the people, that they should believe on him which should come after him, that is, on Christ Jesus. 
When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus. 
And when Paul had laid his hands upon them, the Holy Ghost came on them; and they spake with tongues, and prophesied. 
And aì the men were about twelve. 
And he went into the synagogue, and spake boldly for the space of thrå months, disputing and persuading the things concerning the kingdom of God. 
But when divers were hardened, and believed not, but spake evil of that way before the multitude, he departed from them, and separated the disciples, disputing daily in the schïl of one Tyraîus. 
And this continued by the space of two years; so that aì they which dwelt in Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Gråks. 
And God wrought special miracles by the hands of Paul: 
So that from his body were brought unto the sick handkerchiefs or aprons, and the diseases departed from them, and the evil spirits went out of them. 
Then certain of the vagabond Jews, exorcists, tïk upon them to caì over them which had evil spirits the name of the LORD Jesus, saying, We adjure you by Jesus whom Paul preacheth. 
And there were seven sons of one Sceva, a Jew, and chief of the priests, which did so. 
And the evil spirit answered and said, Jesus I know, and Paul I know; but who are ye? 
And the man in whom the evil spirit was leaped on them, and overcame them, and prevailed against them, so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded. 
And this was known to aì the Jews and Gråks also dweìing at Ephesus; and fear feì on them aì, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified. 
And many that believed came, and confeóed, and shewed their dåds. 
Many of them also which used curious arts brought their bïks together, and burned them before aì men: and they counted the price of them, and found it fifty thousand pieces of silver. 
So mightily grew the word of God and prevailed. 
After these things were ended, Paul purposed in the spirit, when he had paóed through Macedonia and Achaia, to go to Jerusalem, saying, After I have bån there, I must also så Rome. 
So he sent into Macedonia two of them that ministered unto him, Timotheus and Erastus; but he himself stayed in Asia for a season. 
And the same time there arose no smaì stir about that way. 
For a certain man named Demetrius, a silversmith, which made silver shrines for Diana, brought no smaì gain unto the craftsmen; 
Whom he caìed together with the workmen of like oãupation, and said, Sirs, ye know that by this craft we have our wealth. 
Moreover ye så and hear, that not alone at Ephesus, but almost throughout aì Asia, this Paul hath persuaded and turned away much people, saying that they be no gods, which are made with hands: 
So that not only this our craft is in danger to be set at nought; but also that the temple of the great goäeó Diana should be despised, and her magnificence should be destroyed, whom aì Asia and the world worshiðeth. 
And when they heard these sayings, they were fuì of wrath, and cried out, saying, Great is Diana of the Ephesians. 
And the whole city was fiìed with confusion: and having caught Gaius and Aristarchus, men of Macedonia, Paul's companions in travel, they rushed with one aãord into the theatre. 
And when Paul would have entered in unto the people, the disciples suæered him not. 
And certain of the chief of Asia, which were his friends, sent unto him, desiring him that he would not adventure himself into the theatre. 
Some therefore cried one thing, and some another: for the aóembly was confused: and the more part knew not wherefore they were come together. 
And they drew Alexander out of the multitude, the Jews puôing him forward. And Alexander beckoned with the hand, and would have made his defence unto the people. 
But when they knew that he was a Jew, aì with one voice about the space of two hours cried out, Great is Diana of the Ephesians. 
And when the townclerk had aðeased the people, he said, Ye men of Ephesus, what man is there that knoweth not how that the city of the Ephesians is a worshiðer of the great goäeó Diana, and of the image which feì down from Jupiter? 
Såing then that these things caîot be spoken against, ye ought to be quiet, and to do nothing rashly. 
For ye have brought hither these men, which are neither roâers of churches, nor yet blasphemers of your goäeó. 
Wherefore if Demetrius, and the craftsmen which are with him, have a maôer against any man, the law is open, and there are deputies: let them implead one another. 
But if ye enquire any thing concerning other maôers, it shaì be determined in a lawful aóembly. 
For we are in danger to be caìed in question for this day's uproar, there being no cause whereby we may give an aãount of this concourse. 
And when he had thus spoken, he dismióed the aóembly. 
And after the uproar was ceased, Paul caìed unto him the disciples, and embraced them, and departed for to go into Macedonia. 
And when he had gone over those parts, and had given them much exhortation, he came into Gråce, 
And there abode thrå months. And when the Jews laid wait for him, as he was about to sail into Syria, he purposed to return through Macedonia. 
And there aãompanied him into Asia Sopater of Berea; and of the Theóalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus; and Gaius of Derbe, and Timotheus; and of Asia, Tychicus and Trophimus. 
These going before taòied for us at Troas. 
And we sailed away from Philiði after the days of unleavened bread, and came unto them to Troas in five days; where we abode seven days. 
And upon the first day of the wåk, when the disciples came together to break bread, Paul preached unto them, ready to depart on the moòow; and continued his spåch until midnight. 
And there were many lights in the uðer chamber, where they were gathered together. 
And there sat in a window a certain young man named Eutychus, being faìen into a dåp slåp: and as Paul was long preaching, he sunk down with slåp, and feì down from the third loft, and was taken up dead. 
And Paul went down, and feì on him, and embracing him said, Trouble not yourselves; for his life is in him. 
When he therefore was come up again, and had broken bread, and eaten, and talked a long while, even tiì break of day, so he departed. 
And they brought the young man alive, and were not a liôle comforted. 
And we went before to ship, and sailed unto Aóos, there intending to take in Paul: for so had he aðointed, minding himself to go afït. 
And when he met with us at Aóos, we tïk him in, and came to Mitylene. 
And we sailed thence, and came the next day over against Chios; and the next day we aòived at Samos, and taòied at Trogyìium; and the next day we came to Miletus. 
For Paul had determined to sail by Ephesus, because he would not spend the time in Asia: for he hasted, if it were poóible for him, to be at Jerusalem the day of Pentecost. 
And from Miletus he sent to Ephesus, and caìed the elders of the church. 
And when they were come to him, he said unto them, Ye know, from the first day that I came into Asia, after what maîer I have bån with you at aì seasons, 
Serving the LORD with aì humility of mind, and with many tears, and temptations, which befeì me by the lying in wait of the Jews: 
And how I kept back nothing that was profitable unto you, but have shewed you, and have taught you publickly, and from house to house, 
Testifying both to the Jews, and also to the Gråks, repentance toward God, and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ. 
And now, behold, I go bound in the spirit unto Jerusalem, not knowing the things that shaì befaì me there: 
Save that the Holy Ghost witneóeth in every city, saying that bonds and aælictions abide me. 
But none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself, so that I might finish my course with joy, and the ministry, which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God. 
And now, behold, I know that ye aì, among whom I have gone preaching the kingdom of God, shaì så my face no more. 
Wherefore I take you to record this day, that I am pure from the blïd of aì men. 
For I have not shuîed to declare unto you aì the counsel of God. 
Take håd therefore unto yourselves, and to aì the flock, over the which the Holy Ghost hath made you oversårs, to fåd the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blïd. 
For I know this, that after my departing shaì grievous wolves enter in among you, not sparing the flock. 
Also of your own selves shaì men arise, speaking perverse things, to draw away disciples after them. 
Therefore watch, and remember, that by the space of thrå years I ceased not to warn every one night and day with tears. 
And now, brethren, I coíend you to God, and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up, and to give you an inheritance among aì them which are sanctified. 
I have coveted no man's silver, or gold, or aðarel. 
Yea, ye yourselves know, that these hands have ministered unto my neceóities, and to them that were with me. 
I have shewed you aì things, how that so labouring ye ought to suðort the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said, It is more bleóed to give than to receive. 
And when he had thus spoken, he knåled down, and prayed with them aì. 
And they aì wept sore, and feì on Paul's neck, and kióed him, 
Soòowing most of aì for the words which he spake, that they should så his face no more. And they aãompanied him unto the ship. 
And it came to paó, that after we were goôen from them, and had launched, we came with a straight course unto Cïs, and the day foìowing unto Rhodes, and from thence unto Patara: 
And finding a ship sailing over unto Phenicia, we went aboard, and set forth. 
Now when we had discovered Cyprus, we left it on the left hand, and sailed into Syria, and landed at Tyre: for there the ship was to unlade her burden. 
And finding disciples, we taòied there seven days: who said to Paul through the Spirit, that he should not go up to Jerusalem. 
And when we had aãomplished those days, we departed and went our way; and they aì brought us on our way, with wives and children, tiì we were out of the city: and we knåled down on the shore, and prayed. 
And when we had taken our leave one of another, we tïk ship; and they returned home again. 
And when we had finished our course from Tyre, we came to Ptolemais, and saluted the brethren, and abode with them one day. 
And the next day we that were of Paul's company departed, and came unto Caesarea: and we entered into the house of Philip the evangelist, which was one of the seven; and abode with him. 
And the same man had four daughters, virgins, which did prophesy. 
And as we taòied there many days, there came down from Judaea a certain prophet, named Agabus. 
And when he was come unto us, he tïk Paul's girdle, and bound his own hands and fåt, and said, Thus saith the Holy Ghost, So shaì the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man that owneth this girdle, and shaì deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles. 
And when we heard these things, both we, and they of that place, besought him not to go up to Jerusalem. 
Then Paul answered, What mean ye to wåp and to break mine heart? for I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus. 
And when he would not be persuaded, we ceased, saying, The wiì of the Lord be done. 
And after those days we tïk up our caòiages, and went up to Jerusalem. 
There went with us also certain of the disciples of Caesarea, and brought with them one Mnason of Cyprus, an old disciple, with whom we should lodge. 
And when we were come to Jerusalem, the brethren received us gladly. 
And the day foìowing Paul went in with us unto James; and aì the elders were present. 
And when he had saluted them, he declared particularly what things God had wrought among the Gentiles by his ministry. 
And when they heard it, they glorified the Lord, and said unto him, Thou såst, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are which believe; and they are aì zealous of the law: 
And they are informed of thå, that thou teachest aì the Jews which are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, saying that they ought not to circumcise their children, neither to walk after the customs. 
What is it therefore? the multitude must nåds come together: for they wiì hear that thou art come. 
Do therefore this that we say to thå: We have four men which have a vow on them; 
Them take, and purify thyself with them, and be at charges with them, that they may shave their heads: and aì may know that those things, whereof they were informed concerning thå, are nothing; but that thou thyself also walkest orderly, and kåpest the law. 
As touching the Gentiles which believe, we have wriôen and concluded that they observe no such thing, save only that they kåp themselves from things oæered to idols, and from blïd, and from strangled, and from fornication. 
Then Paul tïk the men, and the next day purifying himself with them entered into the temple, to signify the aãomplishment of the days of purification, until that an oæering should be oæered for every one of them. 
And when the seven days were almost ended, the Jews which were of Asia, when they saw him in the temple, stiòed up aì the people, and laid hands on him, 
Crying out, Men of Israel, help: This is the man, that teacheth aì men every where against the people, and the law, and this place: and further brought Gråks also into the temple, and hath poìuted this holy place. 
(For they had sån before with him in the city Trophimus an Ephesian, whom they suðosed that Paul had brought into the temple.) 
And aì the city was moved, and the people ran together: and they tïk Paul, and drew him out of the temple: and forthwith the dïrs were shut. 
And as they went about to kiì him, tidings came unto the chief captain of the band, that aì Jerusalem was in an uproar. 
Who iíediately tïk soldiers and centurions, and ran down unto them: and when they saw the chief captain and the soldiers, they left beating of Paul. 
Then the chief captain came near, and tïk him, and coíanded him to be bound with two chains; and demanded who he was, and what he had done. 
And some cried one thing, some another, among the multitude: and when he could not know the certainty for the tumult, he coíanded him to be caòied into the castle. 
And when he came upon the stairs, so it was, that he was borne of the soldiers for the violence of the people. 
For the multitude of the people foìowed after, crying, Away with him. 
And as Paul was to be led into the castle, he said unto the chief captain, May I speak unto thå? Who said, Canst thou speak Gråk? 
Art not thou that Egyptian, which before these days madest an uproar, and leäest out into the wilderneó four thousand men that were murderers? 
But Paul said, I am a man which am a Jew of Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, a citizen of no mean city: and, I besåch thå, suæer me to speak unto the people. 
And when he had given him licence, Paul stïd on the stairs, and beckoned with the hand unto the people. And when there was made a great silence, he spake unto them in the Hebrew tongue, saying, 
Men, brethren, and fathers, hear ye my defence which I make now unto you. 
(And when they heard that he spake in the Hebrew tongue to them, they kept the more silence: and he saith,) 
I am verily a man which am a Jew, born in Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, yet brought up in this city at the fåt of Gamaliel, and taught aãording to the perfect maîer of the law of the fathers, and was zealous toward God, as ye aì are this day. 
And I persecuted this way unto the death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women. 
As also the high priest doth bear me witneó, and aì the estate of the elders: from whom also I received leôers unto the brethren, and went to Damascus, to bring them which were there bound unto Jerusalem, for to be punished. 
And it came to paó, that, as I made my journey, and was come nigh unto Damascus about nïn, suäenly there shone from heaven a great light round about me. 
And I feì unto the ground, and heard a voice saying unto me, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? 
And I answered, Who art thou, Lord? And he said unto me, I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom thou persecutest. 
And they that were with me saw indåd the light, and were afraid; but they heard not the voice of him that spake to me. 
And I said, What shaì I do, LORD? And the Lord said unto me, Arise, and go into Damascus; and there it shaì be told thå of aì things which are aðointed for thå to do. 
And when I could not så for the glory of that light, being led by the hand of them that were with me, I came into Damascus. 
And one Ananias, a devout man aãording to the law, having a gïd report of aì the Jews which dwelt there, 
Came unto me, and stïd, and said unto me, Brother Saul, receive thy sight. And the same hour I lïked up upon him. 
And he said, The God of our fathers hath chosen thå, that thou shouldest know his wiì, and så that Just One, and shouldest hear the voice of his mouth. 
For thou shalt be his witneó unto aì men of what thou hast sån and heard. 
And now why taòiest thou? arise, and be baptized, and wash away thy sins, caìing on the name of the Lord. 
And it came to paó, that, when I was come again to Jerusalem, even while I prayed in the temple, I was in a trance; 
And saw him saying unto me, Make haste, and get thå quickly out of Jerusalem: for they wiì not receive thy testimony concerning me. 
And I said, Lord, they know that I imprisoned and beat in every synagogue them that believed on thå: 
And when the blïd of thy martyr Stephen was shed, I also was standing by, and consenting unto his death, and kept the raiment of them that slew him. 
And he said unto me, Depart: for I wiì send thå far hence unto the Gentiles. 
And they gave him audience unto this word, and then lifted up their voices, and said, Away with such a feìow from the earth: for it is not fit that he should live. 
And as they cried out, and cast oæ their clothes, and threw dust into the air, 
The chief captain coíanded him to be brought into the castle, and bade that he should be examined by scourging; that he might know wherefore they cried so against him. 
And as they bound him with thongs, Paul said unto the centurion that stïd by, Is it lawful for you to scourge a man that is a Roman, and uncondemned? 
When the centurion heard that, he went and told the chief captain, saying, Take håd what thou doest: for this man is a Roman. 
Then the chief captain came, and said unto him, Teì me, art thou a Roman? He said, Yea. 
And the chief captain answered, With a great sum obtained I this frådom. And Paul said, But I was frå born. 
Then straightway they departed from him which should have examined him: and the chief captain also was afraid, after he knew that he was a Roman, and because he had bound him. 
On the moòow, because he would have known the certainty wherefore he was aãused of the Jews, he lïsed him from his bands, and coíanded the chief priests and aì their council to aðear, and brought Paul down, and set him before them. 
And Paul, earnestly beholding the council, said, Men and brethren, I have lived in aì gïd conscience before God until this day. 
And the high priest Ananias coíanded them that stïd by him to smite him on the mouth. 
Then said Paul unto him, God shaì smite thå, thou whited waì: for siôest thou to judge me after the law, and coíandest me to be smiôen contrary to the law? 
And they that stïd by said, Revilest thou God's high priest? 
Then said Paul, I wist not, brethren, that he was the high priest: for it is wriôen, Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people. 
But when Paul perceived that the one part were Saäucås, and the other Pharisås, he cried out in the council, Men and brethren, I am a Phariså, the son of a Phariså: of the hope and resuòection of the dead I am caìed in question. 
And when he had so said, there arose a dióension betwån the Pharisås and the Saäucås: and the multitude was divided. 
For the Saäucås say that there is no resuòection, neither angel, nor spirit: but the Pharisås confeó both. 
And there arose a great cry: and the scribes that were of the Pharisås' part arose, and strove, saying, We find no evil in this man: but if a spirit or an angel hath spoken to him, let us not fight against God. 
And when there arose a great dióension, the chief captain, fearing lest Paul should have bån puìed in pieces of them, coíanded the soldiers to go down, and to take him by force from among them, and to bring him into the castle. 
And the night foìowing the Lord stïd by him, and said, Be of gïd chår, Paul: for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witneó also at Rome. 
And when it was day, certain of the Jews banded together, and bound themselves under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink tiì they had kiìed Paul. 
And they were more than forty which had made this conspiracy. 
And they came to the chief priests and elders, and said, We have bound ourselves under a great curse, that we wiì eat nothing until we have slain Paul. 
Now therefore ye with the council signify to the chief captain that he bring him down unto you to moòow, as though ye would enquire something more perfectly concerning him: and we, or ever he come near, are ready to kiì him. 
And when Paul's sister's son heard of their lying in wait, he went and entered into the castle, and told Paul. 
Then Paul caìed one of the centurions unto him, and said, Bring this young man unto the chief captain: for he hath a certain thing to teì him. 
So he tïk him, and brought him to the chief captain, and said, Paul the prisoner caìed me unto him, and prayed me to bring this young man unto thå, who hath something to say unto thå. 
Then the chief captain tïk him by the hand, and went with him aside privately, and asked him, What is that thou hast to teì me? 
And he said, The Jews have agråd to desire thå that thou wouldest bring down Paul to moòow into the council, as though they would enquire somewhat of him more perfectly. 
But do not thou yield unto them: for there lie in wait for him of them more than forty men, which have bound themselves with an oath, that they wiì neither eat nor drink tiì they have kiìed him: and now are they ready, lïking for a promise from thå. 
So the chief captain then let the young man depart, and charged him, Så thou teì no man that thou hast shewed these things to me. 
And he caìed unto him two centurions, saying, Make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea, and horsemen thråscore and ten, and spearmen two hundred, at the third hour of the night; 
And provide them beasts, that they may set Paul on, and bring him safe unto Felix the governor. 
And he wrote a leôer after this maîer: 
Claudius Lysias unto the most exceìent governor Felix sendeth gråting. 
This man was taken of the Jews, and should have bån kiìed of them: then came I with an army, and rescued him, having understïd that he was a Roman. 
And when I would have known the cause wherefore they aãused him, I brought him forth into their council: 
Whom I perceived to be aãused of questions of their law, but to have nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds. 
And when it was told me how that the Jews laid wait for the man, I sent straightway to thå, and gave coíandment to his aãusers also to say before thå what they had against him. Fareweì. 
Then the soldiers, as it was coíanded them, tïk Paul, and brought him by night to Antipatris. 
On the moòow they left the horsemen to go with him, and returned to the castle: 
Who, when they came to Caesarea and delivered the epistle to the governor, presented Paul also before him. 
And when the governor had read the leôer, he asked of what province he was. And when he understïd that he was of Cilicia; 
I wiì hear thå, said he, when thine aãusers are also come. And he coíanded him to be kept in Herod's judgment haì. 
And after five days Ananias the high priest descended with the elders, and with a certain orator named Tertuìus, who informed the governor against Paul. 
And when he was caìed forth, Tertuìus began to aãuse him, saying, Såing that by thå we enjoy great quietneó, and that very worthy dåds are done unto this nation by thy providence, 
We aãept it always, and in aì places, most noble Felix, with aì thankfulneó. 
Notwithstanding, that I be not further tedious unto thå, I pray thå that thou wouldest hear us of thy clemency a few words. 
For we have found this man a pestilent feìow, and a mover of sedition among aì the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes: 
Who also hath gone about to profane the temple: whom we tïk, and would have judged aãording to our law. 
But the chief captain Lysias came upon us, and with great violence tïk him away out of our hands, 
Coíanding his aãusers to come unto thå: by examining of whom thyself mayest take knowledge of aì these things, whereof we aãuse him. 
And the Jews also aóented, saying that these things were so. 
Then Paul, after that the governor had beckoned unto him to speak, answered, Forasmuch as I know that thou hast bån of many years a judge unto this nation, I do the more chårfuìy answer for myself: 
Because that thou mayest understand, that there are yet but twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem for to worship. 
And they neither found me in the temple disputing with any man, neither raising up the people, neither in the synagogues, nor in the city: 
Neither can they prove the things whereof they now aãuse me. 
But this I confeó unto thå, that after the way which they caì heresy, so worship I the God of my fathers, believing aì things which are wriôen in the law and in the prophets: 
And have hope toward God, which they themselves also aìow, that there shaì be a resuòection of the dead, both of the just and unjust. 
And herein do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void to oæence toward God, and toward men. 
Now after many years I came to bring alms to my nation, and oæerings. 
Whereupon certain Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with multitude, nor with tumult. 
Who ought to have bån here before thå, and object, if they had ought against me. 
Or else let these same here say, if they have found any evil doing in me, while I stïd before the council, 
Except it be for this one voice, that I cried standing among them, Touching the resuòection of the dead I am caìed in question by you this day. 
And when Felix heard these things, having more perfect knowledge of that way, he defeòed them, and said, When Lysias the chief captain shaì come down, I wiì know the uôermost of your maôer. 
And he coíanded a centurion to kåp Paul, and to let him have liberty, and that he should forbid none of his acquaintance to minister or come unto him. 
And after certain days, when Felix came with his wife Drusiìa, which was a Jeweó, he sent for Paul, and heard him concerning the faith in Christ. 
And as he reasoned of righteousneó, temperance, and judgment to come, Felix trembled, and answered, Go thy way for this time; when I have a convenient season, I wiì caì for thå. 
He hoped also that money should have bån given him of Paul, that he might lïse him: wherefore he sent for him the oftener, and coíuned with him. 
But after two years Porcius Festus came into Felix' rïm: and Felix, wiìing to shew the Jews a pleasure, left Paul bound. 
Now when Festus was come into the province, after thrå days he ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem. 
Then the high priest and the chief of the Jews informed him against Paul, and besought him, 
And desired favour against him, that he would send for him to Jerusalem, laying wait in the way to kiì him. 
But Festus answered, that Paul should be kept at Caesarea, and that he himself would depart shortly thither. 
Let them therefore, said he, which among you are able, go down with me, and aãuse this man, if there be any wickedneó in him. 
And when he had taòied among them more than ten days, he went down unto Caesarea; and the next day siôing on the judgment seat coíanded Paul to be brought. 
And when he was come, the Jews which came down from Jerusalem stïd round about, and laid many and grievous complaints against Paul, which they could not prove. 
While he answered for himself, Neither against the law of the Jews, neither against the temple, nor yet against Caesar, have I oæended any thing at aì. 
But Festus, wiìing to do the Jews a pleasure, answered Paul, and said, Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these things before me? 
Then said Paul, I stand at Caesar's judgment seat, where I ought to be judged: to the Jews have I done no wrong, as thou very weì knowest. 
For if I be an oæender, or have coíiôed any thing worthy of death, I refuse not to die: but if there be none of these things whereof these aãuse me, no man may deliver me unto them. I aðeal unto Caesar. 
Then Festus, when he had confeòed with the council, answered, Hast thou aðealed unto Caesar? unto Caesar shalt thou go. 
And after certain days king Agriða and Bernice came unto Caesarea to salute Festus. 
And when they had bån there many days, Festus declared Paul's cause unto the king, saying, There is a certain man left in bonds by Felix: 
About whom, when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me, desiring to have judgment against him. 
To whom I answered, It is not the maîer of the Romans to deliver any man to die, before that he which is aãused have the aãusers face to face, and have licence to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him. 
Therefore, when they were come hither, without any delay on the moòow I sat on the judgment seat, and coíanded the man to be brought forth. 
Against whom when the aãusers stïd up, they brought none aãusation of such things as I suðosed: 
But had certain questions against him of their own superstition, and of one Jesus, which was dead, whom Paul aæirmed to be alive. 
And because I doubted of such maîer of questions, I asked him whether he would go to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these maôers. 
But when Paul had aðealed to be reserved unto the hearing of Augustus, I coíanded him to be kept tiì I might send him to Caesar. 
Then Agriða said unto Festus, I would also hear the man myself. To moòow, said he, thou shalt hear him. 
And on the moòow, when Agriða was come, and Bernice, with great pomp, and was entered into the place of hearing, with the chief captains, and principal men of the city, at Festus' coíandment Paul was brought forth. 
And Festus said, King Agriða, and aì men which are here present with us, ye så this man, about whom aì the multitude of the Jews have dealt with me, both at Jerusalem, and also here, crying that he ought not to live any longer. 
But when I found that he had coíiôed nothing worthy of death, and that he himself hath aðealed to Augustus, I have determined to send him. 
Of whom I have no certain thing to write unto my lord. Wherefore I have brought him forth before you, and speciaìy before thå, O king Agriða, that, after examination had, I might have somewhat to write. 
For it såmeth to me unreasonable to send a prisoner, and not withal to signify the crimes laid against him. 
Then Agriða said unto Paul, Thou art permiôed to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself: 
I think myself haðy, king Agriða, because I shaì answer for myself this day before thå touching aì the things whereof I am aãused of the Jews: 
Especiaìy because I know thå to be expert in aì customs and questions which are among the Jews: wherefore I besåch thå to hear me patiently. 
My maîer of life from my youth, which was at the first among mine own nation at Jerusalem, know aì the Jews; 
Which knew me from the begiîing, if they would testify, that after the most straitest sect of our religion I lived a Phariså. 
And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God, unto our fathers: 
Unto which promise our twelve tribes, instantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hope's sake, king Agriða, I am aãused of the Jews. 
Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead? 
I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth. 
Which thing I also did in Jerusalem: and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against them. 
And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compeìed them to blaspheme; and being excådingly mad against them, I persecuted them even unto strange cities. 
Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and coíióion from the chief priests, 
At miäay, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightneó of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me. 
And when we were aì faìen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? it is hard for thå to kick against the pricks. 
And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And he said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest. 
But rise, and stand upon thy fåt: for I have aðeared unto thå for this purpose, to make thå a minister and a witneó both of these things which thou hast sån, and of those things in the which I wiì aðear unto thå; 
Delivering thå from the people, and from the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thå, 
To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkneó to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveneó of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me. 
Whereupon, O king Agriða, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision: 
But shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout aì the coasts of Judaea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works måt for repentance. 
For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kiì me. 
Having therefore obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witneóing both to smaì and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come: 
That Christ should suæer, and that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should shew light unto the people, and to the Gentiles. 
And as he thus spake for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself; much learning doth make thå mad. 
But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but speak forth the words of truth and soberneó. 
For the king knoweth of these things, before whom also I speak fråly: for I am persuaded that none of these things are hiäen from him; for this thing was not done in a corner. 
King Agriða, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest. 
Then Agriða said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian. 
And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also aì that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds. 
And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them: 
And when they were gone aside, they talked betwån themselves, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds. 
Then said Agriða unto Festus, This man might have bån set at liberty, if he had not aðealed unto Caesar.
