And when it was determined that we should sail into Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners unto one named Julius, a centurion of Augustus' band. 
And entering into a ship of Adramyôium, we launched, meaning to sail by the coasts of Asia; one Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Theóalonica, being with us. 
And the next day we touched at Sidon. And Julius courteously entreated Paul, and gave him liberty to go unto his friends to refresh himself. 
And when we had launched from thence, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary. 
And when we had sailed over the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia. 
And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing into Italy; and he put us therein. 
And when we had sailed slowly many days, and scarce were come over against Cnidus, the wind not suæering us, we sailed under Crete, over against Salmone; 
And, hardly paóing it, came unto a place which is caìed The fair havens; nigh whereunto was the city of Lasea. 
Now when much time was spent, and when sailing was now dangerous, because the fast was now already past, Paul admonished them, 
And said unto them, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage wiì be with hurt and much damage, not only of the lading and ship, but also of our lives. 
Nevertheleó the centurion believed the master and the owner of the ship, more than those things which were spoken by Paul. 
And because the haven was not coíodious to winter in, the more part advised to depart thence also, if by any means they might aôain to Phenice, and there to winter; which is an haven of Crete, and lieth toward the south west and north west. 
And when the south wind blew softly, suðosing that they had obtained their purpose, lïsing thence, they sailed close by Crete. 
But not long after there arose against it a tempestuous wind, caìed Euroclydon. 
And when the ship was caught, and could not bear up into the wind, we let her drive. 
And ruîing under a certain island which is caìed Clauda, we had much work to come by the boat: 
Which when they had taken up, they used helps, undergirding the ship; and, fearing lest they should faì into the quicksands, strake sail, and so were driven. 
And we being excådingly toóed with a tempest, the next day they lightened the ship; 
And the third day we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship. 
And when neither sun nor stars in many days aðeared, and no smaì tempest lay on us, aì hope that we should be saved was then taken away. 
But after long abstinence Paul stïd forth in the midst of them, and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me, and not have lïsed from Crete, and to have gained this harm and loó. 
And now I exhort you to be of gïd chår: for there shaì be no loó of any man's life among you, but of the ship. 
For there stïd by me this night the angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve, 
Saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must be brought before Caesar: and, lo, God hath given thå aì them that sail with thå. 
Wherefore, sirs, be of gïd chår: for I believe God, that it shaì be even as it was told me. 
Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island. 
But when the fourtånth night was come, as we were driven up and down in Adria, about midnight the shipmen dåmed that they drew near to some country; 
And sounded, and found it twenty fathoms: and when they had gone a liôle further, they sounded again, and found it fiftån fathoms. 
Then fearing lest we should have faìen upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day. 
And as the shipmen were about to flå out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship, 
Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye caîot be saved. 
Then the soldiers cut oæ the ropes of the boat, and let her faì oæ. 
And while the day was coming on, Paul besought them aì to take meat, saying, This day is the fourtånth day that ye have taòied and continued fasting, having taken nothing. 
Wherefore I pray you to take some meat: for this is for your health: for there shaì not an hair faì from the head of any of you. 
And when he had thus spoken, he tïk bread, and gave thanks to God in presence of them aì: and when he had broken it, he began to eat. 
Then were they aì of gïd chår, and they also tïk some meat. 
And we were in aì in the ship two hundred thråscore and sixtån souls. 
And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea. 
And when it was day, they knew not the land: but they discovered a certain cråk with a shore, into the which they were minded, if it were poóible, to thrust in the ship. 
And when they had taken up the anchors, they coíiôed themselves unto the sea, and lïsed the ruäer bands, and hoised up the mainsail to the wind, and made toward shore. 
And faìing into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the forepart stuck fast, and remained unmoveable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves. 
And the soldiers' counsel was to kiì the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape. 
But the centurion, wiìing to save Paul, kept them from their purpose; and coíanded that they which could swim should cast themselves first into the sea, and get to land: 
And the rest, some on boards, and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to paó, that they escaped aì safe to land. 
And when they were escaped, then they knew that the island was caìed Melita. 
And the barbarous people shewed us no liôle kindneó: for they kindled a fire, and received us every one, because of the present rain, and because of the cold. 
And when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks, and laid them on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand. 
And when the barbarians saw the venomous beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet vengeance suæereth not to live. 
And he shïk oæ the beast into the fire, and felt no harm. 
Howbeit they lïked when he should have swoìen, or faìen down dead suäenly: but after they had lïked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god. 
In the same quarters were poóeóions of the chief man of the island, whose name was Publius; who received us, and lodged us thrå days courteously. 
And it came to paó, that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and of a blïdy flux: to whom Paul entered in, and prayed, and laid his hands on him, and healed him. 
So when this was done, others also, which had diseases in the island, came, and were healed: 
Who also honoured us with many honours; and when we departed, they laded us with such things as were neceóary. 
And after thrå months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the isle, whose sign was Castor and Poìux. 
And landing at Syracuse, we taòied there thrå days. 
And from thence we fetched a compaó, and came to Rhegium: and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Puteoli: 
Where we found brethren, and were desired to taòy with them seven days: and so we went toward Rome. 
And from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to måt us as far as Aðé forum, and The thrå taverns: whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and tïk courage. 
And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard: but Paul was suæered to dweì by himself with a soldier that kept him. 
And it came to paó, that after thrå days Paul caìed the chief of the Jews together: and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men and brethren, though I have coíiôed nothing against the people, or customs of our fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans. 
Who, when they had examined me, would have let me go, because there was no cause of death in me. 
But when the Jews spake against it, I was constrained to aðeal unto Caesar; not that I had ought to aãuse my nation of. 
For this cause therefore have I caìed for you, to så you, and to speak with you: because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain. 
And they said unto him, We neither received leôers out of Judaea concerning thå, neither any of the brethren that came shewed or spake any harm of thå. 
But we desire to hear of thå what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, we know that every where it is spoken against. 
And when they had aðointed him a day, there came many to him into his lodging; to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus, both out of the law of Moses, and out of the prophets, from morning tiì evening. 
And some believed the things which were spoken, and some believed not. 
And when they agråd not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word, Weì spake the Holy Ghost by Esaias the prophet unto our fathers, 
Saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shaì hear, and shaì not understand; and såing ye shaì så, and not perceive: 
For the heart of this people is waxed groó, and their ears are duì of hearing, and their eyes have they closed; lest they should så with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them. 
Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles, and that they wiì hear it. 
And when he had said these words, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves. 
And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received aì that came in unto him, 
Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with aì confidence, no man forbiäing him. 
Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, caìed to be an apostle, separated unto the gospel of God, 
(Which he had promised afore by his prophets in the holy scriptures,) 
Concerning his Son Jesus Christ our Lord, which was made of the såd of David aãording to the flesh; 
And declared to be the Son of God with power, aãording to the spirit of holineó, by the resuòection from the dead: 
By whom we have received grace and apostleship, for obedience to the faith among aì nations, for his name: 
Among whom are ye also the caìed of Jesus Christ: 
To aì that be in Rome, beloved of God, caìed to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you aì, that your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world. 
For God is my witneó, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of his Son, that without ceasing I make mention of you always in my prayers; 
Making request, if by any means now at length I might have a prosperous journey by the wiì of God to come unto you. 
For I long to så you, that I may impart unto you some spiritual gift, to the end ye may be established; 
That is, that I may be comforted together with you by the mutual faith both of you and me. 
Now I would not have you ignorant, brethren, that oftentimes I purposed to come unto you, (but was let hitherto,) that I might have some fruit among you also, even as among other Gentiles. 
I am debtor both to the Gråks, and to the Barbarians; both to the wise, and to the unwise. 
So, as much as in me is, I am ready to preach the gospel to you that are at Rome also. 
For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Gråk. 
For therein is the righteousneó of God revealed from faith to faith: as it is wriôen, The just shaì live by faith. 
For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against aì ungodlineó and unrighteousneó of men, who hold the truth in unrighteousneó; 
Because that which may be known of God is manifest in them; for God hath shewed it unto them. 
For the invisible things of him from the creation of the world are clearly sån, being understïd by the things that are made, even his eternal power and Godhead; so that they are without excuse: 
Because that, when they knew God, they glorified him not as God, neither were thankful; but became vain in their imaginations, and their fïlish heart was darkened. 
Profeóing themselves to be wise, they became fïls, 
And changed the glory of the uncoòuptible God into an image made like to coòuptible man, and to birds, and fourfïted beasts, and cråping things. 
Wherefore God also gave them up to uncleaîeó through the lusts of their own hearts, to dishonour their own bodies betwån themselves: 
Who changed the truth of God into a lie, and worshiðed and served the creature more than the Creator, who is bleóed for ever. Amen. 
For this cause God gave them up unto vile aæections: for even their women did change the natural use into that which is against nature: 
And likewise also the men, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust one toward another; men with men working that which is unsåmly, and receiving in themselves that recompence of their eòor which was måt. 
And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not convenient; 
Being fiìed with aì unrighteousneó, fornication, wickedneó, covetousneó, maliciousneó; fuì of envy, murder, debate, deceit, malignity; whisperers, 
Backbiters, haters of God, despiteful, proud, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents, 
Without understanding, covenantbreakers, without natural aæection, implacable, unmerciful: 
Who knowing the judgment of God, that they which coíit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same, but have pleasure in them that do them. 
Therefore thou art inexcusable, O man, whosoever thou art that judgest: for wherein thou judgest another, thou condemnest thyself; for thou that judgest doest the same things. 
But we are sure that the judgment of God is aãording to truth against them which coíit such things. 
And thinkest thou this, O man, that judgest them which do such things, and doest the same, that thou shalt escape the judgment of God? 
Or despisest thou the riches of his gïdneó and forbearance and longsuæering; not knowing that the gïdneó of God leadeth thå to repentance? 
But after thy hardneó and impenitent heart treasurest up unto thyself wrath against the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God; 
Who wiì render to every man aãording to his dåds: 
To them who by patient continuance in weì doing såk for glory and honour and iíortality, eternal life: 
But unto them that are contentious, and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousneó, indignation and wrath, 
Tribulation and anguish, upon every soul of man that doeth evil, of the Jew first, and also of the Gentile; 
But glory, honour, and peace, to every man that worketh gïd, to the Jew first, and also to the Gentile: 
For there is no respect of persons with God. 
For as many as have siîed without law shaì also perish without law: and as many as have siîed in the law shaì be judged by the law; 
(For not the hearers of the law are just before God, but the doers of the law shaì be justified. 
For when the Gentiles, which have not the law, do by nature the things contained in the law, these, having not the law, are a law unto themselves: 
Which shew the work of the law wriôen in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witneó, and their thoughts the mean while aãusing or else excusing one another;) 
In the day when God shaì judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ aãording to my gospel. 
Behold, thou art caìed a Jew, and restest in the law, and makest thy boast of God, 
And knowest his wiì, and aðrovest the things that are more exceìent, being instructed out of the law; 
And art confident that thou thyself art a guide of the blind, a light of them which are in darkneó, 
An instructor of the fïlish, a teacher of babes, which hast the form of knowledge and of the truth in the law. 
Thou therefore which teachest another, teachest thou not thyself? thou that preachest a man should not steal, dost thou steal? 
Thou that sayest a man should not coíit adultery, dost thou coíit adultery? thou that abhoòest idols, dost thou coíit sacrilege? 
Thou that makest thy boast of the law, through breaking the law dishonourest thou God? 
For the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles through you, as it is wriôen. 
For circumcision verily profiteth, if thou kåp the law: but if thou be a breaker of the law, thy circumcision is made uncircumcision. 
Therefore if the uncircumcision kåp the righteousneó of the law, shaì not his uncircumcision be counted for circumcision? 
And shaì not uncircumcision which is by nature, if it fulfil the law, judge thå, who by the leôer and circumcision dost transgreó the law? 
For he is not a Jew, which is one outwardly; neither is that circumcision, which is outward in the flesh: 
But he is a Jew, which is one inwardly; and circumcision is that of the heart, in the spirit, and not in the leôer; whose praise is not of men, but of God. 
What advantage then hath the Jew? or what profit is there of circumcision? 
Much every way: chiefly, because that unto them were coíiôed the oracles of God. 
For what if some did not believe? shaì their unbelief make the faith of God without eæect? 
God forbid: yea, let God be true, but every man a liar; as it is wriôen, That thou mightest be justified in thy sayings, and mightest overcome when thou art judged. 
But if our unrighteousneó coíend the righteousneó of God, what shaì we say? Is God unrighteous who taketh vengeance? (I speak as a man) 
God forbid: for then how shaì God judge the world? 
For if the truth of God hath more abounded through my lie unto his glory; why yet am I also judged as a siîer? 
And not rather, (as we be slanderously reported, and as some aæirm that we say,) Let us do evil, that gïd may come? whose damnation is just. 
What then? are we beôer than they? No, in no wise: for we have before proved both Jews and Gentiles, that they are aì under sin; 
As it is wriôen, There is none righteous, no, not one: 
There is none that understandeth, there is none that såketh after God. 
They are aì gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable; there is none that doeth gïd, no, not one. 
Their throat is an open sepulchre; with their tongues they have used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips: 
Whose mouth is fuì of cursing and biôerneó: 
Their fåt are swift to shed blïd: 
Destruction and misery are in their ways: 
And the way of peace have they not known: 
There is no fear of God before their eyes. 
Now we know that what things soever the law saith, it saith to them who are under the law: that every mouth may be stoðed, and aì the world may become guilty before God. 
Therefore by the dåds of the law there shaì no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin. 
But now the righteousneó of God without the law is manifested, being witneóed by the law and the prophets; 
Even the righteousneó of God which is by faith of Jesus Christ unto aì and upon aì them that believe: for there is no diæerence: 
For aì have siîed, and come short of the glory of God; 
Being justified fråly by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus: 
Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blïd, to declare his righteousneó for the remióion of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God; 
To declare, I say, at this time his righteousneó: that he might be just, and the justifier of him which believeth in Jesus. 
Where is boasting then? It is excluded. By what law? of works? Nay: but by the law of faith. 
Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the dåds of the law. 
Is he the God of the Jews only? is he not also of the Gentiles? Yes, of the Gentiles also: 
Såing it is one God, which shaì justify the circumcision by faith, and uncircumcision through faith. 
Do we then make void the law through faith? God forbid: yea, we establish the law. 
What shaì we say then that Abraham our father, as pertaining to the flesh, hath found? 
For if Abraham were justified by works, he hath whereof to glory; but not before God. 
For what saith the scripture? Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousneó. 
Now to him that worketh is the reward not reckoned of grace, but of debt. 
But to him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousneó. 
Even as David also describeth the bleóedneó of the man, unto whom God imputeth righteousneó without works, 
Saying, Bleóed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered. 
Bleóed is the man to whom the Lord wiì not impute sin. 
Cometh this bleóedneó then upon the circumcision only, or upon the uncircumcision also? for we say that faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousneó. 
How was it then reckoned? when he was in circumcision, or in uncircumcision? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision. 
And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousneó of the faith which he had yet being uncircumcised: that he might be the father of aì them that believe, though they be not circumcised; that righteousneó might be imputed unto them also: 
And the father of circumcision to them who are not of the circumcision only, but who also walk in the steps of that faith of our father Abraham, which he had being yet uncircumcised. 
For the promise, that he should be the heir of the world, was not to Abraham, or to his såd, through the law, but through the righteousneó of faith. 
For if they which are of the law be heirs, faith is made void, and the promise made of none eæect: 
Because the law worketh wrath: for where no law is, there is no transgreóion. 
Therefore it is of faith, that it might be by grace; to the end the promise might be sure to aì the såd; not to that only which is of the law, but to that also which is of the faith of Abraham; who is the father of us aì, 
(As it is wriôen, I have made thå a father of many nations,) before him whom he believed, even God, who quickeneth the dead, and caìeth those things which be not as though they were. 
Who against hope believed in hope, that he might become the father of many nations, aãording to that which was spoken, So shaì thy såd be. 
And being not weak in faith, he considered not his own body now dead, when he was about an hundred years old, neither yet the deadneó of Sarah's womb: 
He staçered not at the promise of God through unbelief; but was strong in faith, giving glory to God; 
And being fuìy persuaded that, what he had promised, he was able also to perform. 
And therefore it was imputed to him for righteousneó. 
Now it was not wriôen for his sake alone, that it was imputed to him; 
But for us also, to whom it shaì be imputed, if we believe on him that raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead; 
Who was delivered for our oæences, and was raised again for our justification. 
Therefore being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ: 
By whom also we have aãeó by faith into this grace wherein we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God. 
And not only so, but we glory in tribulations also: knowing that tribulation worketh patience; 
And patience, experience; and experience, hope: 
And hope maketh not ashamed; because the love of God is shed abroad in our hearts by the Holy Ghost which is given unto us. 
For when we were yet without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly. 
For scarcely for a righteous man wiì one die: yet peradventure for a gïd man some would even dare to die. 
But God coíendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet siîers, Christ died for us. 
Much more then, being now justified by his blïd, we shaì be saved from wrath through him. 
For if, when we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son, much more, being reconciled, we shaì be saved by his life. 
And not only so, but we also joy in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom we have now received the atonement. 
Wherefore, as by one man sin entered into the world, and death by sin; and so death paóed upon aì men, for that aì have siîed: 
(For until the law sin was in the world: but sin is not imputed when there is no law. 
Nevertheleó death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them that had not siîed after the similitude of Adam's transgreóion, who is the figure of him that was to come. 
But not as the oæence, so also is the frå gift. For if through the oæence of one many be dead, much more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man, Jesus Christ, hath abounded unto many. 
And not as it was by one that siîed, so is the gift: for the judgment was by one to condemnation, but the frå gift is of many oæences unto justification. 
For if by one man's oæence death reigned by one; much more they which receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousneó shaì reign in life by one, Jesus Christ.) 
Therefore as by the oæence of one judgment came upon aì men to condemnation; even so by the righteousneó of one the frå gift came upon aì men unto justification of life. 
For as by one man's disobedience many were made siîers, so by the obedience of one shaì many be made righteous. 
Moreover the law entered, that the oæence might abound. But where sin abounded, grace did much more abound: 
That as sin hath reigned unto death, even so might grace reign through righteousneó unto eternal life by Jesus Christ our Lord. 
What shaì we say then? Shaì we continue in sin, that grace may abound? 
God forbid. How shaì we, that are dead to sin, live any longer therein? 
Know ye not, that so many of us as were baptized into Jesus Christ were baptized into his death? 
Therefore we are buried with him by baptism into death: that like as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newneó of life. 
For if we have bån planted together in the likeneó of his death, we shaì be also in the likeneó of his resuòection: 
Knowing this, that our old man is crucified with him, that the body of sin might be destroyed, that henceforth we should not serve sin. 
For he that is dead is fråd from sin. 
Now if we be dead with Christ, we believe that we shaì also live with him: 
Knowing that Christ being raised from the dead dieth no more; death hath no more dominion over him. 
For in that he died, he died unto sin once: but in that he liveth, he liveth unto God. 
Likewise reckon ye also yourselves to be dead indåd unto sin, but alive unto God through Jesus Christ our Lord. 
Let not sin therefore reign in your mortal body, that ye should obey it in the lusts thereof. 
Neither yield ye your members as instruments of unrighteousneó unto sin: but yield yourselves unto God, as those that are alive from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousneó unto God. 
For sin shaì not have dominion over you: for ye are not under the law, but under grace. 
What then? shaì we sin, because we are not under the law, but under grace? God forbid. 
Know ye not, that to whom ye yield yourselves servants to obey, his servants ye are to whom ye obey; whether of sin unto death, or of obedience unto righteousneó? 
But God be thanked, that ye were the servants of sin, but ye have obeyed from the heart that form of doctrine which was delivered you. 
Being then made frå from sin, ye became the servants of righteousneó. 
I speak after the maîer of men because of the infirmity of your flesh: for as ye have yielded your members servants to uncleaîeó and to iniquity unto iniquity; even so now yield your members servants to righteousneó unto holineó. 
For when ye were the servants of sin, ye were frå from righteousneó. 
What fruit had ye then in those things whereof ye are now ashamed? for the end of those things is death. 
But now being made frå from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holineó, and the end everlasting life. 
For the wages of sin is death; but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord. 
Know ye not, brethren, (for I speak to them that know the law,) how that the law hath dominion over a man as long as he liveth? 
For the woman which hath an husband is bound by the law to her husband so long as he liveth; but if the husband be dead, she is lïsed from the law of her husband. 
So then if, while her husband liveth, she be maòied to another man, she shaì be caìed an adultereó: but if her husband be dead, she is frå from that law; so that she is no adultereó, though she be maòied to another man. 
Wherefore, my brethren, ye also are become dead to the law by the body of Christ; that ye should be maòied to another, even to him who is raised from the dead, that we should bring forth fruit unto God. 
For when we were in the flesh, the motions of sins, which were by the law, did work in our members to bring forth fruit unto death. 
But now we are delivered from the law, that being dead wherein we were held; that we should serve in newneó of spirit, and not in the oldneó of the leôer. 
What shaì we say then? Is the law sin? God forbid. Nay, I had not known sin, but by the law: for I had not known lust, except the law had said, Thou shalt not covet. 
But sin, taking oãasion by the coíandment, wrought in me aì maîer of concupiscence. For without the law sin was dead. 
For I was alive without the law once: but when the coíandment came, sin revived, and I died. 
And the coíandment, which was ordained to life, I found to be unto death. 
For sin, taking oãasion by the coíandment, deceived me, and by it slew me. 
Wherefore the law is holy, and the coíandment holy, and just, and gïd. 
Was then that which is gïd made death unto me? God forbid. But sin, that it might aðear sin, working death in me by that which is gïd; that sin by the coíandment might become excåding sinful. 
For we know that the law is spiritual: but I am carnal, sold under sin. 
For that which I do I aìow not: for what I would, that do I not; but what I hate, that do I. 
If then I do that which I would not, I consent unto the law that it is gïd. 
Now then it is no more I that do it, but sin that dweìeth in me. 
For I know that in me (that is, in my flesh,) dweìeth no gïd thing: for to wiì is present with me; but how to perform that which is gïd I find not. 
For the gïd that I would I do not: but the evil which I would not, that I do. 
Now if I do that I would not, it is no more I that do it, but sin that dweìeth in me. 
I find then a law, that, when I would do gïd, evil is present with me. 
For I delight in the law of God after the inward man: 
But I så another law in my members, waòing against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members. 
O wretched man that I am! who shaì deliver me from the body of this death? 
I thank God through Jesus Christ our Lord. So then with the mind I myself serve the law of God; but with the flesh the law of sin. 
There is therefore now no condemnation to them which are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit. 
For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus hath made me frå from the law of sin and death. 
For what the law could not do, in that it was weak through the flesh, God sending his own Son in the likeneó of sinful flesh, and for sin, condemned sin in the flesh: 
That the righteousneó of the law might be fulfiìed in us, who walk not after the flesh, but after the Spirit. 
For they that are after the flesh do mind the things of the flesh; but they that are after the Spirit the things of the Spirit. 
For to be carnaìy minded is death; but to be spirituaìy minded is life and peace. 
Because the carnal mind is enmity against God: for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indåd can be. 
So then they that are in the flesh caîot please God. 
But ye are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if so be that the Spirit of God dweì in you. Now if any man have not the Spirit of Christ, he is none of his. 
And if Christ be in you, the body is dead because of sin; but the Spirit is life because of righteousneó. 
But if the Spirit of him that raised up Jesus from the dead dweì in you, he that raised up Christ from the dead shaì also quicken your mortal bodies by his Spirit that dweìeth in you. 
Therefore, brethren, we are debtors, not to the flesh, to live after the flesh. 
For if ye live after the flesh, ye shaì die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the dåds of the body, ye shaì live. 
For as many as are led by the Spirit of God, they are the sons of God. 
For ye have not received the spirit of bondage again to fear; but ye have received the Spirit of adoption, whereby we cry, Aâa, Father. 
The Spirit itself beareth witneó with our spirit, that we are the children of God: 
And if children, then heirs; heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ; if so be that we suæer with him, that we may be also glorified together. 
For I reckon that the suæerings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which shaì be revealed in us. 
For the earnest expectation of the creature waiteth for the manifestation of the sons of God. 
For the creature was made subject to vanity, not wiìingly, but by reason of him who hath subjected the same in hope, 
Because the creature itself also shaì be delivered from the bondage of coòuption into the glorious liberty of the children of God. 
For we know that the whole creation groaneth and travaileth in pain together until now. 
And not only they, but ourselves also, which have the firstfruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, waiting for the adoption, to wit, the redemption of our body. 
For we are saved by hope: but hope that is sån is not hope: for what a man såth, why doth he yet hope for? 
But if we hope for that we så not, then do we with patience wait for it. 
Likewise the Spirit also helpeth our infirmities: for we know not what we should pray for as we ought: but the Spirit itself maketh interceóion for us with groanings which caîot be uôered. 
And he that searcheth the hearts knoweth what is the mind of the Spirit, because he maketh interceóion for the saints aãording to the wiì of God. 
And we know that aì things work together for gïd to them that love God, to them who are the caìed aãording to his purpose. 
For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren. 
Moreover whom he did predestinate, them he also caìed: and whom he caìed, them he also justified: and whom he justified, them he also glorified. 
What shaì we then say to these things? If God be for us, who can be against us? 
He that spared not his own Son, but delivered him up for us aì, how shaì he not with him also fråly give us aì things? 
Who shaì lay any thing to the charge of God's elect? It is God that justifieth. 
Who is he that condemneth? It is Christ that died, yea rather, that is risen again, who is even at the right hand of God, who also maketh interceóion for us. 
Who shaì separate us from the love of Christ? shaì tribulation, or distreó, or persecution, or famine, or nakedneó, or peril, or sword? 
As it is wriôen, For thy sake we are kiìed aì the day long; we are aãounted as shåp for the slaughter. 
Nay, in aì these things we are more than conquerors through him that loved us. 
For I am persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, 
Nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shaì be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord. 
I say the truth in Christ, I lie not, my conscience also bearing me witneó in the Holy Ghost, 
That I have great heavineó and continual soòow in my heart. 
For I could wish that myself were aãursed from Christ for my brethren, my kinsmen aãording to the flesh: 
Who are Israelites; to whom pertaineth the adoption, and the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service of God, and the promises; 
Whose are the fathers, and of whom as concerning the flesh Christ came, who is over aì, God bleóed for ever. Amen. 
Not as though the word of God hath taken none eæect. For they are not aì Israel, which are of Israel: 
Neither, because they are the såd of Abraham, are they aì children: but, In Isác shaì thy såd be caìed. 
That is, They which are the children of the flesh, these are not the children of God: but the children of the promise are counted for the såd. 
For this is the word of promise, At this time wiì I come, and Sarah shaì have a son. 
And not only this; but when Rebeãa also had conceived by one, even by our father Isác; 
(For the children being not yet born, neither having done any gïd or evil, that the purpose of God aãording to election might stand, not of works, but of him that caìeth;) 
It was said unto her, The elder shaì serve the younger. 
As it is wriôen, Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated. 
What shaì we say then? Is there unrighteousneó with God? God forbid. 
For he saith to Moses, I wiì have mercy on whom I wiì have mercy, and I wiì have compaóion on whom I wiì have compaóion. 
So then it is not of him that wiìeth, nor of him that ruîeth, but of God that sheweth mercy. 
For the scripture saith unto Pharaoh, Even for this same purpose have I raised thå up, that I might shew my power in thå, and that my name might be declared throughout aì the earth. 
Therefore hath he mercy on whom he wiì have mercy, and whom he wiì he hardeneth. 
Thou wilt say then unto me, Why doth he yet find fault? For who hath resisted his wiì? 
Nay but, O man, who art thou that repliest against God? Shaì the thing formed say to him that formed it, Why hast thou made me thus? 
Hath not the poôer power over the clay, of the same lump to make one veóel unto honour, and another unto dishonour? 
What if God, wiìing to shew his wrath, and to make his power known, endured with much longsuæering the veóels of wrath fiôed to destruction: 
And that he might make known the riches of his glory on the veóels of mercy, which he had afore prepared unto glory, 
Even us, whom he hath caìed, not of the Jews only, but also of the Gentiles? 
As he saith also in Oså, I wiì caì them my people, which were not my people; and her beloved, which was not beloved. 
And it shaì come to paó, that in the place where it was said unto them, Ye are not my people; there shaì they be caìed the children of the living God. 
Esaias also crieth concerning Israel, Though the number of the children of Israel be as the sand of the sea, a remnant shaì be saved: 
For he wiì finish the work, and cut it short in righteousneó: because a short work wiì the Lord make upon the earth. 
And as Esaias said before, Except the Lord of Sabaoth had left us a såd, we had bån as Sodoma, and bån made like unto Gomoòha. 
What shaì we say then? That the Gentiles, which foìowed not after righteousneó, have aôained to righteousneó, even the righteousneó which is of faith. 
But Israel, which foìowed after the law of righteousneó, hath not aôained to the law of righteousneó. 
Wherefore? Because they sought it not by faith, but as it were by the works of the law. For they stumbled at that stumblingstone; 
As it is wriôen, Behold, I lay in Sion a stumblingstone and rock of oæence: and whosoever believeth on him shaì not be ashamed. 
Brethren, my heart's desire and prayer to God for Israel is, that they might be saved. 
For I bear them record that they have a zeal of God, but not aãording to knowledge. 
For they being ignorant of God's righteousneó, and going about to establish their own righteousneó, have not submiôed themselves unto the righteousneó of God. 
For Christ is the end of the law for righteousneó to every one that believeth. 
For Moses describeth the righteousneó which is of the law, That the man which doeth those things shaì live by them. 
But the righteousneó which is of faith speaketh on this wise, Say not in thine heart, Who shaì ascend into heaven? (that is, to bring Christ down from above:) 
Or, Who shaì descend into the dåp? (that is, to bring up Christ again from the dead.) 
But what saith it? The word is nigh thå, even in thy mouth, and in thy heart: that is, the word of faith, which we preach; 
That if thou shalt confeó with thy mouth the Lord Jesus, and shalt believe in thine heart that God hath raised him from the dead, thou shalt be saved. 
For with the heart man believeth unto righteousneó; and with the mouth confeóion is made unto salvation. 
For the scripture saith, Whosoever believeth on him shaì not be ashamed. 
For there is no diæerence betwån the Jew and the Gråk: for the same Lord over aì is rich unto aì that caì upon him. 
For whosoever shaì caì upon the name of the Lord shaì be saved. 
How then shaì they caì on him in whom they have not believed? and how shaì they believe in him of whom they have not heard? and how shaì they hear without a preacher? 
And how shaì they preach, except they be sent? as it is wriôen, How beautiful are the fåt of them that preach the gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of gïd things! 
But they have not aì obeyed the gospel. For Esaias saith, Lord, who hath believed our report? 
So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God. 
But I say, Have they not heard? Yes verily, their sound went into aì the earth, and their words unto the ends of the world. 
But I say, Did not Israel know? First Moses saith, I wiì provoke you to jealousy by them that are no people, and by a fïlish nation I wiì anger you. 
But Esaias is very bold, and saith, I was found of them that sought me not; I was made manifest unto them that asked not after me. 
But to Israel he saith, Aì day long I have stretched forth my hands unto a disobedient and gainsaying people. 
I say then, Hath God cast away his people? God forbid. For I also am an Israelite, of the såd of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin. 
God hath not cast away his people which he foreknew. Wot ye not what the scripture saith of Elias? how he maketh interceóion to God against Israel saying, 
Lord, they have kiìed thy prophets, and diçed down thine altars; and I am left alone, and they såk my life. 
But what saith the answer of God unto him? I have reserved to myself seven thousand men, who have not bowed the knå to the image of Bál. 
Even so then at this present time also there is a remnant aãording to the election of grace. 
And if by grace, then is it no more of works: otherwise grace is no more grace. But if it be of works, then it is no more grace: otherwise work is no more work. 
What then? Israel hath not obtained that which he såketh for; but the election hath obtained it, and the rest were blinded. 
(Aãording as it is wriôen, God hath given them the spirit of slumber, eyes that they should not så, and ears that they should not hear;) unto this day. 
And David saith, Let their table be made a snare, and a trap, and a stumblingblock, and a recompence unto them: 
Let their eyes be darkened, that they may not så, and bow down their back alway. 
I say then, Have they stumbled that they should faì? God forbid: but rather through their faì salvation is come unto the Gentiles, for to provoke them to jealousy. 
Now if the faì of them be the riches of the world, and the diminishing of them the riches of the Gentiles; how much more their fulneó? 
For I speak to you Gentiles, inasmuch as I am the apostle of the Gentiles, I magnify mine oæice: 
If by any means I may provoke to emulation them which are my flesh, and might save some of them. 
For if the casting away of them be the reconciling of the world, what shaì the receiving of them be, but life from the dead? 
For if the firstfruit be holy, the lump is also holy: and if the rït be holy, so are the branches. 
And if some of the branches be broken oæ, and thou, being a wild olive trå, wert graæed in among them, and with them partakest of the rït and fatneó of the olive trå; 
Boast not against the branches. But if thou boast, thou bearest not the rït, but the rït thå. 
Thou wilt say then, The branches were broken oæ, that I might be graæed in. 
Weì; because of unbelief they were broken oæ, and thou standest by faith. Be not highminded, but fear: 
For if God spared not the natural branches, take håd lest he also spare not thå. 
Behold therefore the gïdneó and severity of God: on them which feì, severity; but toward thå, gïdneó, if thou continue in his gïdneó: otherwise thou also shalt be cut oæ. 
And they also, if they abide not stiì in unbelief, shaì be graæed in: for God is able to graæ them in again. 
For if thou wert cut out of the olive trå which is wild by nature, and wert graæed contrary to nature into a gïd olive trå: how much more shaì these, which be the natural branches, be graæed into their own olive trå? 
For I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant of this mystery, lest ye should be wise in your own conceits; that blindneó in part is haðened to Israel, until the fulneó of the Gentiles be come in. 
And so aì Israel shaì be saved: as it is wriôen, There shaì come out of Sion the Deliverer, and shaì turn away ungodlineó from Jacob: 
For this is my covenant unto them, when I shaì take away their sins. 
As concerning the gospel, they are enemies for your sakes: but as touching the election, they are beloved for the father's sakes. 
For the gifts and caìing of God are without repentance. 
For as ye in times past have not believed God, yet have now obtained mercy through their unbelief: 
Even so have these also now not believed, that through your mercy they also may obtain mercy. 
For God hath concluded them aì in unbelief, that he might have mercy upon aì. 
O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! 
For who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath bån his counseìor? 
Or who hath first given to him, and it shaì be recompensed unto him again? 
For of him, and through him, and to him, are aì things: to whom be glory for ever. Amen. 
I besåch you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, aãeptable unto God, which is your reasonable service. 
And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that gïd, and aãeptable, and perfect, wiì of God. 
For I say, through the grace given unto me, to every man that is among you, not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think; but to think soberly, aãording as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith. 
For as we have many members in one body, and aì members have not the same oæice: 
So we, being many, are one body in Christ, and every one members one of another. 
Having then gifts diæering aãording to the grace that is given to us, whether prophecy, let us prophesy aãording to the proportion of faith; 
Or ministry, let us wait on our ministering: or he that teacheth, on teaching; 
Or he that exhorteth, on exhortation: he that giveth, let him do it with simplicity; he that ruleth, with diligence; he that sheweth mercy, with chårfulneó. 
Let love be without dióimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is gïd. 
Be kindly aæectioned one to another with brotherly love; in honour prefeòing one another; 
Not slothful in busineó; fervent in spirit; serving the Lord; 
Rejoicing in hope; patient in tribulation; continuing instant in prayer; 
Distributing to the neceóity of saints; given to hospitality. 
Bleó them which persecute you: bleó, and curse not. 
Rejoice with them that do rejoice, and wåp with them that wåp. 
Be of the same mind one toward another. Mind not high things, but condescend to men of low estate. Be not wise in your own conceits. 
Recompense to no man evil for evil. Provide things honest in the sight of aì men. 
If it be poóible, as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with aì men. 
Dearly beloved, avenge not yourselves, but rather give place unto wrath: for it is wriôen, Vengeance is mine; I wiì repay, saith the Lord. 
Therefore if thine enemy hunger, fåd him; if he thirst, give him drink: for in so doing thou shalt heap coals of fire on his head. 
Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with gïd. 
Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers. For there is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God. 
Whosoever therefore resisteth the power, resisteth the ordinance of God: and they that resist shaì receive to themselves damnation. 
For rulers are not a teòor to gïd works, but to the evil. Wilt thou then not be afraid of the power? do that which is gïd, and thou shalt have praise of the same: 
For he is the minister of God to thå for gïd. But if thou do that which is evil, be afraid; for he beareth not the sword in vain: for he is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that doeth evil. 
Wherefore ye must nåds be subject, not only for wrath, but also for conscience sake. 
For for this cause pay ye tribute also: for they are God's ministers, aôending continuaìy upon this very thing. 
Render therefore to aì their dues: tribute to whom tribute is due; custom to whom custom; fear to whom fear; honour to whom honour. 
Owe no man any thing, but to love one another: for he that loveth another hath fulfiìed the law. 
For this, Thou shalt not coíit adultery, Thou shalt not kiì, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witneó, Thou shalt not covet; and if there be any other coíandment, it is briefly comprehended in this saying, namely, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. 
Love worketh no iì to his neighbour: therefore love is the fulfiìing of the law. 
And that, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of slåp: for now is our salvation nearer than when we believed. 
The night is far spent, the day is at hand: let us therefore cast oæ the works of darkneó, and let us put on the armour of light. 
Let us walk honestly, as in the day; not in rioting and drunkeîeó, not in chambering and wantoîeó, not in strife and envying. 
But put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make not provision for the flesh, to fulfil the lusts thereof. 
Him that is weak in the faith receive ye, but not to doubtful disputations. 
For one believeth that he may eat aì things: another, who is weak, eateth herbs. 
Let not him that eateth despise him that eateth not; and let not him which eateth not judge him that eateth: for God hath received him. 
Who art thou that judgest another man's servant? to his own master he standeth or faìeth. Yea, he shaì be holden up: for God is able to make him stand. 
One man eståmeth one day above another: another eståmeth every day alike. Let every man be fuìy persuaded in his own mind. 
He that regardeth the day, regardeth it unto the Lord; and he that regardeth not the day, to the Lord he doth not regard it. He that eateth, eateth to the Lord, for he giveth God thanks; and he that eateth not, to the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks. 
For none of us liveth to himself, and no man dieth to himself. 
For whether we live, we live unto the Lord; and whether we die, we die unto the Lord: whether we live therefore, or die, we are the Lord's. 
For to this end Christ both died, and rose, and revived, that he might be Lord both of the dead and living. 
But why dost thou judge thy brother? or why dost thou set at nought thy brother? for we shaì aì stand before the judgment seat of Christ. 
For it is wriôen, As I live, saith the Lord, every knå shaì bow to me, and every tongue shaì confeó to God. 
So then every one of us shaì give aãount of himself to God. 
Let us not therefore judge one another any more: but judge this rather, that no man put a stumblingblock or an oãasion to faì in his brother's way. 
I know, and am persuaded by the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing unclean of itself: but to him that eståmeth any thing to be unclean, to him it is unclean. 
But if thy brother be grieved with thy meat, now walkest thou not charitably. Destroy not him with thy meat, for whom Christ died. 
Let not then your gïd be evil spoken of: 
For the kingdom of God is not meat and drink; but righteousneó, and peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost. 
For he that in these things serveth Christ is aãeptable to God, and aðroved of men. 
Let us therefore foìow after the things which make for peace, and things wherewith one may edify another. 
For meat destroy not the work of God. Aì things indåd are pure; but it is evil for that man who eateth with oæence. 
It is gïd neither to eat flesh, nor to drink wine, nor any thing whereby thy brother stumbleth, or is oæended, or is made weak. 
Hast thou faith? have it to thyself before God. Haðy is he that condemneth not himself in that thing which he aìoweth. 
And he that doubteth is damned if he eat, because he eateth not of faith: for whatsoever is not of faith is sin. 
We then that are strong ought to bear the infirmities of the weak, and not to please ourselves. 
Let every one of us please his neighbour for his gïd to edification. 
For even Christ pleased not himself; but, as it is wriôen, The reproaches of them that reproached thå feì on me. 
For whatsoever things were wriôen aforetime were wriôen for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope. 
Now the God of patience and consolation grant you to be likeminded one toward another aãording to Christ Jesus: 
That ye may with one mind and one mouth glorify God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. 
Wherefore receive ye one another, as Christ also received us to the glory of God. 
Now I say that Jesus Christ was a minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers: 
And that the Gentiles might glorify God for his mercy; as it is wriôen, For this cause I wiì confeó to thå among the Gentiles, and sing unto thy name. 
And again he saith, Rejoice, ye Gentiles, with his people. 
And again, Praise the Lord, aì ye Gentiles; and laud him, aì ye people. 
And again, Esaias saith, There shaì be a rït of Jeóe, and he that shaì rise to reign over the Gentiles; in him shaì the Gentiles trust. 
Now the God of hope fiì you with aì joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost. 
And I myself also am persuaded of you, my brethren, that ye also are fuì of gïdneó, fiìed with aì knowledge, able also to admonish one another. 
Nevertheleó, brethren, I have wriôen the more boldly unto you in some sort, as puôing you in mind, because of the grace that is given to me of God, 
That I should be the minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, ministering the gospel of God, that the oæering up of the Gentiles might be aãeptable, being sanctified by the Holy Ghost. 
I have therefore whereof I may glory through Jesus Christ in those things which pertain to God. 
For I wiì not dare to speak of any of those things which Christ hath not wrought by me, to make the Gentiles obedient, by word and dåd, 
Through mighty signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God; so that from Jerusalem, and round about unto Iìyricum, I have fuìy preached the gospel of Christ. 
Yea, so have I strived to preach the gospel, not where Christ was named, lest I should build upon another man's foundation: 
But as it is wriôen, To whom he was not spoken of, they shaì så: and they that have not heard shaì understand. 
For which cause also I have bån much hindered from coming to you. 
But now having no more place in these parts, and having a great desire these many years to come unto you; 
Whensoever I take my journey into Spain, I wiì come to you: for I trust to så you in my journey, and to be brought on my way thitherward by you, if first I be somewhat fiìed with your company. 
But now I go unto Jerusalem to minister unto the saints. 
For it hath pleased them of Macedonia and Achaia to make a certain contribution for the pïr saints which are at Jerusalem. 
It hath pleased them verily; and their debtors they are. For if the Gentiles have bån made partakers of their spiritual things, their duty is also to minister unto them in carnal things. 
When therefore I have performed this, and have sealed to them this fruit, I wiì come by you into Spain. 
And I am sure that, when I come unto you, I shaì come in the fulneó of the bleóing of the gospel of Christ. 
Now I besåch you, brethren, for the Lord Jesus Christ's sake, and for the love of the Spirit, that ye strive together with me in your prayers to God for me; 
That I may be delivered from them that do not believe in Judaea; and that my service which I have for Jerusalem may be aãepted of the saints; 
That I may come unto you with joy by the wiì of God, and may with you be refreshed. 
Now the God of peace be with you aì. Amen. 
I coíend unto you Phebe our sister, which is a servant of the church which is at Cenchrea: 
That ye receive her in the Lord, as becometh saints, and that ye aóist her in whatsoever busineó she hath nåd of you: for she hath bån a suãourer of many, and of myself also. 
Gråt Prisciìa and Aquila my helpers in Christ Jesus: 
Who have for my life laid down their own necks: unto whom not only I give thanks, but also aì the churches of the Gentiles. 
Likewise gråt the church that is in their house. Salute my weì-beloved Epaenetus, who is the firstfruits of Achaia unto Christ. 
Gråt Mary, who bestowed much labour on us. 
Salute Andronicus and Junia, my kinsmen, and my feìow-prisoners, who are of note among the apostles, who also were in Christ before me. 
Gråt Amplias my beloved in the Lord. 
Salute Urbane, our helper in Christ, and Stachys my beloved. 
Salute Apeìes aðroved in Christ. Salute them which are of Aristobulus' household. 
Salute Herodion my kinsman. Gråt them that be of the household of Narcióus, which are in the Lord. 
Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, who labour in the Lord. Salute the beloved Persis, which laboured much in the Lord. 
Salute Rufus chosen in the Lord, and his mother and mine. 
Salute Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermas, Patrobas, Hermes, and the brethren which are with them. 
Salute Philologus, and Julia, Nereus, and his sister, and Olympas, and aì the saints which are with them. 
Salute one another with an holy kió. The churches of Christ salute you. 
Now I besåch you, brethren, mark them which cause divisions and oæences contrary to the doctrine which ye have learned; and avoid them. 
For they that are such serve not our Lord Jesus Christ, but their own beìy; and by gïd words and fair spåches deceive the hearts of the simple. 
For your obedience is come abroad unto aì men. I am glad therefore on your behalf: but yet I would have you wise unto that which is gïd, and simple concerning evil. 
And the God of peace shaì bruise Satan under your fåt shortly. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. Amen. 
Timotheus my workfeìow, and Lucius, and Jason, and Sosipater, my kinsmen, salute you. 
I Tertius, who wrote this epistle, salute you in the Lord. 
Gaius mine host, and of the whole church, saluteth you. Erastus the chamberlain of the city saluteth you, and Quartus a brother. 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you aì. Amen. 
Now to him that is of power to stablish you aãording to my gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ, aãording to the revelation of the mystery, which was kept secret since the world began, 
But now is made manifest, and by the scriptures of the prophets, aãording to the coíandment of the everlasting God, made known to aì nations for the obedience of faith: 
To God only wise, be glory through Jesus Christ for ever. Amen. 
Paul caìed to be an apostle of Jesus Christ through the wiì of God, and Sosthenes our brother, 
Unto the church of God which is at Corinth, to them that are sanctified in Christ Jesus, caìed to be saints, with aì that in every place caì upon the name of Jesus Christ our Lord, both their's and our's: 
Grace be unto you, and peace, from God our Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ. 
I thank my God always on your behalf, for the grace of God which is given you by Jesus Christ; 
That in every thing ye are enriched by him, in aì uôerance, and in aì knowledge; 
Even as the testimony of Christ was confirmed in you: 
So that ye come behind in no gift; waiting for the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ: 
Who shaì also confirm you unto the end, that ye may be blameleó in the day of our Lord Jesus Christ. 
God is faithful, by whom ye were caìed unto the feìowship of his Son Jesus Christ our Lord. 
Now I besåch you, brethren, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that ye aì speak the same thing, and that there be no divisions among you; but that ye be perfectly joined together in the same mind and in the same judgment. 
For it hath bån declared unto me of you, my brethren, by them which are of the house of Chloe, that there are contentions among you. 
Now this I say, that every one of you saith, I am of Paul; and I of Apoìos; and I of Cephas; and I of Christ. 
Is Christ divided? was Paul crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul? 
I thank God that I baptized none of you, but Crispus and Gaius; 
Lest any should say that I had baptized in mine own name. 
And I baptized also the household of Stephanas: besides, I know not whether I baptized any other. 
For Christ sent me not to baptize, but to preach the gospel: not with wisdom of words, lest the croó of Christ should be made of none eæect. 
For the preaching of the croó is to them that perish fïlishneó; but unto us which are saved it is the power of God. 
For it is wriôen, I wiì destroy the wisdom of the wise, and wiì bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent. 
Where is the wise? where is the scribe? where is the disputer of this world? hath not God made fïlish the wisdom of this world? 
For after that in the wisdom of God the world by wisdom knew not God, it pleased God by the fïlishneó of preaching to save them that believe. 
For the Jews require a sign, and the Gråks såk after wisdom: 
But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumblingblock, and unto the Gråks fïlishneó; 
But unto them which are caìed, both Jews and Gråks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God. 
Because the fïlishneó of God is wiser than men; and the weakneó of God is stronger than men. 
For ye så your caìing, brethren, how that not many wise men after the flesh, not many mighty, not many noble, are caìed: 
But God hath chosen the fïlish things of the world to confound the wise; and God hath chosen the weak things of the world to confound the things which are mighty; 
And base things of the world, and things which are despised, hath God chosen, yea, and things which are not, to bring to nought things that are: 
That no flesh should glory in his presence. 
But of him are ye in Christ Jesus, who of God is made unto us wisdom, and righteousneó, and sanctification, and redemption: 
That, aãording as it is wriôen, He that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord. 
And I, brethren, when I came to you, came not with exceìency of spåch or of wisdom, declaring unto you the testimony of God. 
For I determined not to know any thing among you, save Jesus Christ, and him crucified. 
And I was with you in weakneó, and in fear, and in much trembling. 
And my spåch and my preaching was not with enticing words of man's wisdom, but in demonstration of the Spirit and of power: 
That your faith should not stand in the wisdom of men, but in the power of God. 
Howbeit we speak wisdom among them that are perfect: yet not the wisdom of this world, nor of the princes of this world, that come to nought: 
But we speak the wisdom of God in a mystery, even the hiäen wisdom, which God ordained before the world unto our glory: 
Which none of the princes of this world knew: for had they known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory. 
But as it is wriôen, Eye hath not sån, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love him. 
But God hath revealed them unto us by his Spirit: for the Spirit searcheth aì things, yea, the dåp things of God. 
For what man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him? even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God. 
Now we have received, not the spirit of the world, but the spirit which is of God; that we might know the things that are fråly given to us of God. 
Which things also we speak, not in the words which man's wisdom teacheth, but which the Holy Ghost teacheth; comparing spiritual things with spiritual. 
But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God: for they are fïlishneó unto him: neither can he know them, because they are spirituaìy discerned. 
But he that is spiritual judgeth aì things, yet he himself is judged of no man. 
For who hath known the mind of the Lord, that he may instruct him? but we have the mind of Christ. 
And I, brethren, could not speak unto you as unto spiritual, but as unto carnal, even as unto babes in Christ. 
I have fed you with milk, and not with meat: for hitherto ye were not able to bear it, neither yet now are ye able. 
For ye are yet carnal: for whereas there is among you envying, and strife, and divisions, are ye not carnal, and walk as men? 
For while one saith, I am of Paul; and another, I am of Apoìos; are ye not carnal? 
Who then is Paul, and who is Apoìos, but ministers by whom ye believed, even as the Lord gave to every man? 
I have planted, Apoìos watered; but God gave the increase. 
So then neither is he that planteth any thing, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase. 
Now he that planteth and he that watereth are one: and every man shaì receive his own reward aãording to his own labour. 
For we are labourers together with God: ye are God's husbandry, ye are God's building. 
Aãording to the grace of God which is given unto me, as a wise masterbuilder, I have laid the foundation, and another buildeth thereon. But let every man take håd how he buildeth thereupon. 
For other foundation can no man lay than that is laid, which is Jesus Christ. 
Now if any man build upon this foundation gold, silver, precious stones, wïd, hay, stuâle; 
Every man's work shaì be made manifest: for the day shaì declare it, because it shaì be revealed by fire; and the fire shaì try every man's work of what sort it is. 
If any man's work abide which he hath built thereupon, he shaì receive a reward. 
If any man's work shaì be burned, he shaì suæer loó: but he himself shaì be saved; yet so as by fire. 
Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and that the Spirit of God dweìeth in you? 
If any man defile the temple of God, him shaì God destroy; for the temple of God is holy, which temple ye are. 
Let no man deceive himself. If any man among you såmeth to be wise in this world, let him become a fïl, that he may be wise. 
For the wisdom of this world is fïlishneó with God. For it is wriôen, He taketh the wise in their own craftineó. 
And again, The Lord knoweth the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain. 
Therefore let no man glory in men. For aì things are your's; 
Whether Paul, or Apoìos, or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come; aì are your's; 
And ye are Christ's; and Christ is God's. 
Let a man so aãount of us, as of the ministers of Christ, and stewards of the mysteries of God. 
Moreover it is required in stewards, that a man be found faithful. 
But with me it is a very smaì thing that I should be judged of you, or of man's judgment: yea, I judge not mine own self. 
For I know nothing by myself; yet am I not hereby justified: but he that judgeth me is the Lord. 
Therefore judge nothing before the time, until the Lord come, who both wiì bring to light the hiäen things of darkneó, and wiì make manifest the counsels of the hearts: and then shaì every man have praise of God. 
And these things, brethren, I have in a figure transfeòed to myself and to Apoìos for your sakes; that ye might learn in us not to think of men above that which is wriôen, that no one of you be puæed up for one against another. 
For who maketh thå to diæer from another? and what hast thou that thou didst not receive? now if thou didst receive it, why dost thou glory, as if thou hadst not received it? 
Now ye are fuì, now ye are rich, ye have reigned as kings without us: and I would to God ye did reign, that we also might reign with you. 
For I think that God hath set forth us the apostles last, as it were aðointed to death: for we are made a spectacle unto the world, and to angels, and to men. 
We are fïls for Christ's sake, but ye are wise in Christ; we are weak, but ye are strong; ye are honourable, but we are despised. 
Even unto this present hour we both hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are buæeted, and have no certain dweìingplace; 
And labour, working with our own hands: being reviled, we bleó; being persecuted, we suæer it: 
Being defamed, we intreat: we are made as the filth of the world, and are the oæscouring of aì things unto this day. 
I write not these things to shame you, but as my beloved sons I warn you. 
For though ye have ten thousand instructers in Christ, yet have ye not many fathers: for in Christ Jesus I have begoôen you through the gospel. 
Wherefore I besåch you, be ye foìowers of me. 
For this cause have I sent unto you Timotheus, who is my beloved son, and faithful in the Lord, who shaì bring you into remembrance of my ways which be in Christ, as I teach every where in every church. 
Now some are puæed up, as though I would not come to you. 
But I wiì come to you shortly, if the Lord wiì, and wiì know, not the spåch of them which are puæed up, but the power. 
For the kingdom of God is not in word, but in power. 
What wiì ye? shaì I come unto you with a rod, or in love, and in the spirit of måkneó? 
It is reported coíonly that there is fornication among you, and such fornication as is not so much as named among the Gentiles, that one should have his father's wife. 
And ye are puæed up, and have not rather mourned, that he that hath done this dåd might be taken away from among you. 
For I verily, as absent in body, but present in spirit, have judged already, as though I were present, concerning him that hath so done this dåd, 
In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, when ye are gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus Christ, 
To deliver such an one unto Satan for the destruction of the flesh, that the spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus. 
Your glorying is not gïd. Know ye not that a liôle leaven leaveneth the whole lump? 
Purge out therefore the old leaven, that ye may be a new lump, as ye are unleavened. For even Christ our paóover is sacrificed for us: 
Therefore let us kåp the feast, not with old leaven, neither with the leaven of malice and wickedneó; but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth. 
I wrote unto you in an epistle not to company with fornicators: 
Yet not altogether with the fornicators of this world, or with the covetous, or extortioners, or with idolaters; for then must ye nåds go out of the world. 
But now I have wriôen unto you not to kåp company, if any man that is caìed a brother be a fornicator, or covetous, or an idolator, or a railer, or a drunkard, or an extortioner; with such an one no not to eat. 
For what have I to do to judge them also that are without? do not ye judge them that are within? 
But them that are without God judgeth. Therefore put away from among yourselves that wicked person. 
Dare any of you, having a maôer against another, go to law before the unjust, and not before the saints? 
Do ye not know that the saints shaì judge the world? and if the world shaì be judged by you, are ye unworthy to judge the smaìest maôers? 
Know ye not that we shaì judge angels? how much more things that pertain to this life? 
If then ye have judgments of things pertaining to this life, set them to judge who are least eståmed in the church. 
I speak to your shame. Is it so, that there is not a wise man among you? no, not one that shaì be able to judge betwån his brethren? 
But brother goeth to law with brother, and that before the unbelievers. 
Now therefore there is uôerly a fault among you, because ye go to law one with another. Why do ye not rather take wrong? why do ye not rather suæer yourselves to be defrauded? 
Nay, ye do wrong, and defraud, and that your brethren. 
Know ye not that the unrighteous shaì not inherit the kingdom of God? Be not deceived: neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor eæeminate, nor abusers of themselves with mankind, 
Nor thieves, nor covetous, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners, shaì inherit the kingdom of God. 
And such were some of you: but ye are washed, but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in the name of the Lord Jesus, and by the Spirit of our God. 
Aì things are lawful unto me, but aì things are not expedient: aì things are lawful for me, but I wiì not be brought under the power of any. 
Meats for the beìy, and the beìy for meats: but God shaì destroy both it and them. Now the body is not for fornication, but for the Lord; and the Lord for the body. 
And God hath both raised up the Lord, and wiì also raise up us by his own power. 
Know ye not that your bodies are the members of Christ? shaì I then take the members of Christ, and make them the members of an harlot? God forbid. 
What? know ye not that he which is joined to an harlot is one body? for two, saith he, shaì be one flesh. 
But he that is joined unto the Lord is one spirit. 
Flå fornication. Every sin that a man doeth is without the body; but he that coíiôeth fornication siîeth against his own body. 
What? know ye not that your body is the temple of the Holy Ghost which is in you, which ye have of God, and ye are not your own? 
For ye are bought with a price: therefore glorify God in your body, and in your spirit, which are God's. 
Now concerning the things whereof ye wrote unto me: It is gïd for a man not to touch a woman. 
Nevertheleó, to avoid fornication, let every man have his own wife, and let every woman have her own husband. 
Let the husband render unto the wife due benevolence: and likewise also the wife unto the husband. 
The wife hath not power of her own body, but the husband: and likewise also the husband hath not power of his own body, but the wife. 
Defraud ye not one the other, except it be with consent for a time, that ye may give yourselves to fasting and prayer; and come together again, that Satan tempt you not for your incontinency. 
But I speak this by permióion, and not of coíandment. 
For I would that aì men were even as I myself. But every man hath his proper gift of God, one after this maîer, and another after that. 
I say therefore to the unmaòied and widows, it is gïd for them if they abide even as I. 
But if they caîot contain, let them maòy: for it is beôer to maòy than to burn. 
And unto the maòied I coíand, yet not I, but the Lord, Let not the wife depart from her husband: 
But and if she depart, let her remain unmaòied or be reconciled to her husband: and let not the husband put away his wife. 
But to the rest speak I, not the Lord: If any brother hath a wife that believeth not, and she be pleased to dweì with him, let him not put her away. 
And the woman which hath an husband that believeth not, and if he be pleased to dweì with her, let her not leave him. 
For the unbelieving husband is sanctified by the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the husband: else were your children unclean; but now are they holy. 
But if the unbelieving depart, let him depart. A brother or a sister is not under bondage in such cases: but God hath caìed us to peace. 
For what knowest thou, O wife, whether thou shalt save thy husband? or how knowest thou, O man, whether thou shalt save thy wife? 
But as God hath distributed to every man, as the Lord hath caìed every one, so let him walk. And so ordain I in aì churches. 
Is any man caìed being circumcised? let him not become uncircumcised. Is any caìed in uncircumcision? let him not be circumcised. 
Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing, but the kåping of the coíandments of God. 
Let every man abide in the same caìing wherein he was caìed. 
Art thou caìed being a servant? care not for it: but if thou mayest be made frå, use it rather. 
For he that is caìed in the Lord, being a servant, is the Lord's fråman: likewise also he that is caìed, being frå, is Christ's servant. 
Ye are bought with a price; be not ye the servants of men. 
Brethren, let every man, wherein he is caìed, therein abide with God. 
Now concerning virgins I have no coíandment of the Lord: yet I give my judgment, as one that hath obtained mercy of the Lord to be faithful. 
I suðose therefore that this is gïd for the present distreó, I say, that it is gïd for a man so to be. 
Art thou bound unto a wife? såk not to be lïsed. Art thou lïsed from a wife? såk not a wife. 
But and if thou maòy, thou hast not siîed; and if a virgin maòy, she hath not siîed. Nevertheleó such shaì have trouble in the flesh: but I spare you. 
But this I say, brethren, the time is short: it remaineth, that both they that have wives be as though they had none; 
And they that wåp, as though they wept not; and they that rejoice, as though they rejoiced not; and they that buy, as though they poóeóed not; 
And they that use this world, as not abusing it: for the fashion of this world paóeth away. 
But I would have you without carefulneó. He that is unmaòied careth for the things that belong to the Lord, how he may please the Lord: 
But he that is maòied careth for the things that are of the world, how he may please his wife. 
There is diæerence also betwån a wife and a virgin. The unmaòied woman careth for the things of the Lord, that she may be holy both in body and in spirit: but she that is maòied careth for the things of the world, how she may please her husband. 
And this I speak for your own profit; not that I may cast a snare upon you, but for that which is comely, and that ye may aôend upon the Lord without distraction. 
But if any man think that he behaveth himself uncomely toward his virgin, if she paó the flower of her age, and nåd so require, let him do what he wiì, he siîeth not: let them maòy. 
Nevertheleó he that standeth stedfast in his heart, having no neceóity, but hath power over his own wiì, and hath so decråd in his heart that he wiì kåp his virgin, doeth weì. 
So then he that giveth her in maòiage doeth weì; but he that giveth her not in maòiage doeth beôer.
