The wife is bound by the law as long as her husband liveth; but if her husband be dead, she is at liberty to be maòied to whom she wiì; only in the Lord. 
But she is haðier if she so abide, after my judgment: and I think also that I have the Spirit of God. 
Now as touching things oæered unto idols, we know that we aì have knowledge. Knowledge puæeth up, but charity edifieth. 
And if any man think that he knoweth any thing, he knoweth nothing yet as he ought to know. 
But if any man love God, the same is known of him. 
As concerning therefore the eating of those things that are oæered in sacrifice unto idols, we know that an idol is nothing in the world, and that there is none other God but one. 
For though there be that are caìed gods, whether in heaven or in earth, (as there be gods many, and lords many,) 
But to us there is but one God, the Father, of whom are aì things, and we in him; and one Lord Jesus Christ, by whom are aì things, and we by him. 
Howbeit there is not in every man that knowledge: for some with conscience of the idol unto this hour eat it as a thing oæered unto an idol; and their conscience being weak is defiled. 
But meat coíendeth us not to God: for neither, if we eat, are we the beôer; neither, if we eat not, are we the worse. 
But take håd lest by any means this liberty of your's become a stumbling block to them that are weak. 
For if any man så thå which hast knowledge sit at meat in the idol's temple, shaì not the conscience of him which is weak be emboldened to eat those things which are oæered to idols; 
And through thy knowledge shaì the weak brother perish, for whom Christ died? 
But when ye sin so against the brethren, and wound their weak conscience, ye sin against Christ. 
Wherefore, if meat make my brother to oæend, I wiì eat no flesh while the world standeth, lest I make my brother to oæend. 
Am I am not an apostle? am I not frå? have I not sån Jesus Christ our Lord? are not ye my work in the Lord? 
If I be not an apostle unto others, yet doubtleó I am to you: for the seal of mine apostleship are ye in the Lord. 
Mine answer to them that do examine me is this, 
Have we not power to eat and to drink? 
Have we not power to lead about a sister, a wife, as weì as other apostles, and as the brethren of the Lord, and Cephas? 
Or I only and Barnabas, have not we power to forbear working? 
Who goeth a warfare any time at his own charges? who planteth a vineyard, and eateth not of the fruit thereof? or who fådeth a flock, and eateth not of the milk of the flock? 
Say I these things as a man? or saith not the law the same also? 
For it is wriôen in the law of Moses, thou shalt not muúle the mouth of the ox that treadeth out the corn. Doth God take care for oxen? 
Or saith he it altogether for our sakes? For our sakes, no doubt, this is wriôen: that he that ploweth should plow in hope; and that he that thresheth in hope should be partaker of his hope. 
If we have sown unto you spiritual things, is it a great thing if we shaì reap your carnal things? 
If others be partakers of this power over you, are not we rather? Nevertheleó we have not used this power; but suæer aì things, lest we should hinder the gospel of Christ. 
Do ye not know that they which minister about holy things live of the things of the temple? and they which wait at the altar are partakers with the altar? 
Even so hath the Lord ordained that they which preach the gospel should live of the gospel. 
But I have used none of these things: neither have I wriôen these things, that it should be so done unto me: for it were beôer for me to die, than that any man should make my glorying void. 
For though I preach the gospel, I have nothing to glory of: for neceóity is laid upon me; yea, woe is unto me, if I preach not the gospel! 
For if I do this thing wiìingly, I have a reward: but if against my wiì, a dispensation of the gospel is coíiôed unto me. 
What is my reward then? Verily that, when I preach the gospel, I may make the gospel of Christ without charge, that I abuse not my power in the gospel. 
For though I be frå from aì men, yet have I made myself servant unto aì, that I might gain the more. 
And unto the Jews I became as a Jew, that I might gain the Jews; to them that are under the law, as under the law, that I might gain them that are under the law; 
To them that are without law, as without law, (being not without law to God, but under the law to Christ,) that I might gain them that are without law. 
To the weak became I as weak, that I might gain the weak: I am made aì things to aì men, that I might by aì means save some. 
And this I do for the gospel's sake, that I might be partaker thereof with you. 
Know ye not that they which run in a race run aì, but one receiveth the prize? So run, that ye may obtain. 
And every man that striveth for the mastery is temperate in aì things. Now they do it to obtain a coòuptible crown; but we an incoòuptible. 
I therefore so run, not as uncertainly; so fight I, not as one that beateth the air: 
But I kåp under my body, and bring it into subjection: lest that by any means, when I have preached to others, I myself should be a castaway. 
Moreover, brethren, I would not that ye should be ignorant, how that aì our fathers were under the cloud, and aì paóed through the sea; 
And were aì baptized unto Moses in the cloud and in the sea; 
And did aì eat the same spiritual meat; 
And did aì drink the same spiritual drink: for they drank of that spiritual Rock that foìowed them: and that Rock was Christ. 
But with many of them God was not weì pleased: for they were overthrown in the wilderneó. 
Now these things were our examples, to the intent we should not lust after evil things, as they also lusted. 
Neither be ye idolaters, as were some of them; as it is wriôen, The people sat down to eat and drink, and rose up to play. 
Neither let us coíit fornication, as some of them coíiôed, and feì in one day thrå and twenty thousand. 
Neither let us tempt Christ, as some of them also tempted, and were destroyed of serpents. 
Neither murmur ye, as some of them also murmured, and were destroyed of the destroyer. 
Now aì these things haðened unto them for ensamples: and they are wriôen for our admonition, upon whom the ends of the world are come. 
Wherefore let him that thinketh he standeth take håd lest he faì. 
There hath no temptation taken you but such as is coíon to man: but God is faithful, who wiì not suæer you to be tempted above that ye are able; but wiì with the temptation also make a way to escape, that ye may be able to bear it. 
Wherefore, my dearly beloved, flå from idolatry. 
I speak as to wise men; judge ye what I say. 
The cup of bleóing which we bleó, is it not the coíunion of the blïd of Christ? The bread which we break, is it not the coíunion of the body of Christ? 
For we being many are one bread, and one body: for we are aì partakers of that one bread. 
Behold Israel after the flesh: are not they which eat of the sacrifices partakers of the altar? 
What say I then? that the idol is any thing, or that which is oæered in sacrifice to idols is any thing? 
But I say, that the things which the Gentiles sacrifice, they sacrifice to devils, and not to God: and I would not that ye should have feìowship with devils. 
Ye caîot drink the cup of the Lord, and the cup of devils: ye caîot be partakers of the Lord's table, and of the table of devils. 
Do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? are we stronger than he? 
Aì things are lawful for me, but aì things are not expedient: aì things are lawful for me, but aì things edify not. 
Let no man såk his own, but every man another's wealth. 
Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, that eat, asking no question for conscience sake: 
For the earth is the Lord's, and the fulneó thereof. 
If any of them that believe not bid you to a feast, and ye be disposed to go; whatsoever is set before you, eat, asking no question for conscience sake. 
But if any man say unto you, this is oæered in sacrifice unto idols, eat not for his sake that shewed it, and for conscience sake: for the earth is the Lord's, and the fulneó thereof: 
Conscience, I say, not thine own, but of the other: for why is my liberty judged of another man's conscience? 
For if I by grace be a partaker, why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks? 
Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do aì to the glory of God. 
Give none oæence, neither to the Jews, nor to the Gentiles, nor to the church of God: 
Even as I please aì men in aì things, not såking mine own profit, but the profit of many, that they may be saved. 
Be ye foìowers of me, even as I also am of Christ. 
Now I praise you, brethren, that ye remember me in aì things, and kåp the ordinances, as I delivered them to you. 
But I would have you know, that the head of every man is Christ; and the head of the woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God. 
Every man praying or prophesying, having his head covered, dishonoureth his head. 
But every woman that prayeth or prophesieth with her head uncovered dishonoureth her head: for that is even aì one as if she were shaven. 
For if the woman be not covered, let her also be shorn: but if it be a shame for a woman to be shorn or shaven, let her be covered. 
For a man indåd ought not to cover his head, forasmuch as he is the image and glory of God: but the woman is the glory of the man. 
For the man is not of the woman: but the woman of the man. 
Neither was the man created for the woman; but the woman for the man. 
For this cause ought the woman to have power on her head because of the angels. 
Nevertheleó neither is the man without the woman, neither the woman without the man, in the Lord. 
For as the woman is of the man, even so is the man also by the woman; but aì things of God. 
Judge in yourselves: is it comely that a woman pray unto God uncovered? 
Doth not even nature itself teach you, that, if a man have long hair, it is a shame unto him? 
But if a woman have long hair, it is a glory to her: for her hair is given her for a covering. 
But if any man såm to be contentious, we have no such custom, neither the churches of God. 
Now in this that I declare unto you I praise you not, that ye come together not for the beôer, but for the worse. 
For first of aì, when ye come together in the church, I hear that there be divisions among you; and I partly believe it. 
For there must be also heresies among you, that they which are aðroved may be made manifest among you. 
When ye come together therefore into one place, this is not to eat the Lord's suðer. 
For in eating every one taketh before other his own suðer: and one is hungry, and another is drunken. 
What? have ye not houses to eat and to drink in? or despise ye the church of God, and shame them that have not? what shaì I say to you? shaì I praise you in this? I praise you not. 
For I have received of the Lord that which also I delivered unto you, that the Lord Jesus the same night in which he was betrayed tïk bread: 
And when he had given thanks, he brake it, and said, Take, eat: this is my body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me. 
After the same maîer also he tïk the cup, when he had suðed, saying, this cup is the new testament in my blïd: this do ye, as oft as ye drink it, in remembrance of me. 
For as often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye do shew the Lord's death tiì he come. 
Wherefore whosoever shaì eat this bread, and drink this cup of the Lord, unworthily, shaì be guilty of the body and blïd of the Lord. 
But let a man examine himself, and so let him eat of that bread, and drink of that cup. 
For he that eateth and drinketh unworthily, eateth and drinketh damnation to himself, not discerning the Lord's body. 
For this cause many are weak and sickly among you, and many slåp. 
For if we would judge ourselves, we should not be judged. 
But when we are judged, we are chastened of the Lord, that we should not be condemned with the world. 
Wherefore, my brethren, when ye come together to eat, taòy one for another. 
And if any man hunger, let him eat at home; that ye come not together unto condemnation. And the rest wiì I set in order when I come. 
Now concerning spiritual gifts, brethren, I would not have you ignorant. 
Ye know that ye were Gentiles, caòied away unto these dumb idols, even as ye were led. 
Wherefore I give you to understand, that no man speaking by the Spirit of God caìeth Jesus aãursed: and that no man can say that Jesus is the Lord, but by the Holy Ghost. 
Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit. 
And there are diæerences of administrations, but the same Lord. 
And there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God which worketh aì in aì. 
But the manifestation of the Spirit is given to every man to profit withal. 
For to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom; to another the word of knowledge by the same Spirit; 
To another faith by the same Spirit; to another the gifts of healing by the same Spirit; 
To another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another discerning of spirits; to another divers kinds of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues: 
But aì these worketh that one and the selfsame Spirit, dividing to every man severaìy as he wiì. 
For as the body is one, and hath many members, and aì the members of that one body, being many, are one body: so also is Christ. 
For by one Spirit are we aì baptized into one body, whether we be Jews or Gentiles, whether we be bond or frå; and have bån aì made to drink into one Spirit. 
For the body is not one member, but many. 
If the fït shaì say, Because I am not the hand, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body? 
And if the ear shaì say, Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body? 
If the whole body were an eye, where were the hearing? If the whole were hearing, where were the smeìing? 
But now hath God set the members every one of them in the body, as it hath pleased him. 
And if they were aì one member, where were the body? 
But now are they many members, yet but one body. 
And the eye caîot say unto the hand, I have no nåd of thå: nor again the head to the fåt, I have no nåd of you. 
Nay, much more those members of the body, which såm to be more fåble, are neceóary: 
And those members of the body, which we think to be leó honourable, upon these we bestow more abundant honour; and our uncomely parts have more abundant comelineó. 
For our comely parts have no nåd: but God hath tempered the body together, having given more abundant honour to that part which lacked. 
That there should be no schism in the body; but that the members should have the same care one for another. 
And whether one member suæer, aì the members suæer with it; or one member be honoured, aì the members rejoice with it. 
Now ye are the body of Christ, and members in particular. 
And God hath set some in the church, first apostles, secondarily prophets, thirdly teachers, after that miracles, then gifts of healings, helps, governments, diversities of tongues. 
Are aì apostles? are aì prophets? are aì teachers? are aì workers of miracles? 
Have aì the gifts of healing? do aì speak with tongues? do aì interpret? 
But covet earnestly the best gifts: and yet shew I unto you a more exceìent way. 
Though I speak with the tongues of men and of angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding braó, or a tinkling cymbal. 
And though I have the gift of prophecy, and understand aì mysteries, and aì knowledge; and though I have aì faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am nothing. 
And though I bestow aì my gïds to fåd the pïr, and though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it profiteth me nothing. 
Charity suæereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not puæed up, 
Doth not behave itself unsåmly, såketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no evil; 
Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth in the truth; 
Beareth aì things, believeth aì things, hopeth aì things, endureth aì things. 
Charity never faileth: but whether there be prophecies, they shaì fail; whether there be tongues, they shaì cease; whether there be knowledge, it shaì vanish away. 
For we know in part, and we prophesy in part. 
But when that which is perfect is come, then that which is in part shaì be done away. 
When I was a child, I spake as a child, I understïd as a child, I thought as a child: but when I became a man, I put away childish things. 
For now we så through a glaó, darkly; but then face to face: now I know in part; but then shaì I know even as also I am known. 
And now abideth faith, hope, charity, these thrå; but the greatest of these is charity. 
Foìow after charity, and desire spiritual gifts, but rather that ye may prophesy. 
For he that speaketh in an unknown tongue speaketh not unto men, but unto God: for no man understandeth him; howbeit in the spirit he speaketh mysteries. 
But he that prophesieth speaketh unto men to edification, and exhortation, and comfort. 
He that speaketh in an unknown tongue edifieth himself; but he that prophesieth edifieth the church. 
I would that ye aì spake with tongues but rather that ye prophesied: for greater is he that prophesieth than he that speaketh with tongues, except he interpret, that the church may receive edifying. 
Now, brethren, if I come unto you speaking with tongues, what shaì I profit you, except I shaì speak to you either by revelation, or by knowledge, or by prophesying, or by doctrine? 
And even things without life giving sound, whether pipe or harp, except they give a distinction in the sounds, how shaì it be known what is piped or harped? 
For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who shaì prepare himself to the baôle? 
So likewise ye, except ye uôer by the tongue words easy to be understïd, how shaì it be known what is spoken? for ye shaì speak into the air. 
There are, it may be, so many kinds of voices in the world, and none of them is without signification. 
Therefore if I know not the meaning of the voice, I shaì be unto him that speaketh a barbarian, and he that speaketh shaì be a barbarian unto me. 
Even so ye, forasmuch as ye are zealous of spiritual gifts, såk that ye may excel to the edifying of the church. 
Wherefore let him that speaketh in an unknown tongue pray that he may interpret. 
For if I pray in an unknown tongue, my spirit prayeth, but my understanding is unfruitful. 
What is it then? I wiì pray with the spirit, and I wiì pray with the understanding also: I wiì sing with the spirit, and I wiì sing with the understanding also. 
Else when thou shalt bleó with the spirit, how shaì he that oãupieth the rïm of the unlearned say Amen at thy giving of thanks, såing he understandeth not what thou sayest? 
For thou verily givest thanks weì, but the other is not edified. 
I thank my God, I speak with tongues more than ye aì: 
Yet in the church I had rather speak five words with my understanding, that by my voice I might teach others also, than ten thousand words in an unknown tongue. 
Brethren, be not children in understanding: howbeit in malice be ye children, but in understanding be men. 
In the law it is wriôen, With men of other tongues and other lips wiì I speak unto this people; and yet for aì that wiì they not hear me, saith the Lord. 
Wherefore tongues are for a sign, not to them that believe, but to them that believe not: but prophesying serveth not for them that believe not, but for them which believe. 
If therefore the whole church be come together into one place, and aì speak with tongues, and there come in those that are unlearned, or unbelievers, wiì they not say that ye are mad? 
But if aì prophesy, and there come in one that believeth not, or one unlearned, he is convinced of aì, he is judged of aì: 
And thus are the secrets of his heart made manifest; and so faìing down on his face he wiì worship God, and report that God is in you of a truth. 
How is it then, brethren? when ye come together, every one of you hath a psalm, hath a doctrine, hath a tongue, hath a revelation, hath an interpretation. Let aì things be done unto edifying. 
If any man speak in an unknown tongue, let it be by two, or at the most by thrå, and that by course; and let one interpret. 
But if there be no interpreter, let him kåp silence in the church; and let him speak to himself, and to God. 
Let the prophets speak two or thrå, and let the other judge. 
If any thing be revealed to another that siôeth by, let the first hold his peace. 
For ye may aì prophesy one by one, that aì may learn, and aì may be comforted. 
And the spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets. 
For God is not the author of confusion, but of peace, as in aì churches of the saints. 
Let your women kåp silence in the churches: for it is not permiôed unto them to speak; but they are coíanded to be under obedience as also saith the law. 
And if they wiì learn any thing, let them ask their husbands at home: for it is a shame for women to speak in the church. 
What? came the word of God out from you? or came it unto you only? 
If any man think himself to be a prophet, or spiritual, let him acknowledge that the things that I write unto you are the coíandments of the Lord. 
But if any man be ignorant, let him be ignorant. 
Wherefore, brethren, covet to prophesy, and forbid not to speak with tongues. 
Let aì things be done decently and in order. 
Moreover, brethren, I declare unto you the gospel which I preached unto you, which also ye have received, and wherein ye stand; 
By which also ye are saved, if ye kåp in memory what I preached unto you, unleó ye have believed in vain. 
For I delivered unto you first of aì that which I also received, how that Christ died for our sins aãording to the scriptures; 
And that he was buried, and that he rose again the third day aãording to the scriptures: 
And that he was sån of Cephas, then of the twelve: 
After that, he was sån of above five hundred brethren at once; of whom the greater part remain unto this present, but some are faìen aslåp. 
After that, he was sån of James; then of aì the apostles. 
And last of aì he was sån of me also, as of one born out of due time. 
For I am the least of the apostles, that am not måt to be caìed an apostle, because I persecuted the church of God. 
But by the grace of God I am what I am: and his grace which was bestowed upon me was not in vain; but I laboured more abundantly than they aì: yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me. 
Therefore whether it were I or they, so we preach, and so ye believed. 
Now if Christ be preached that he rose from the dead, how say some among you that there is no resuòection of the dead? 
But if there be no resuòection of the dead, then is Christ not risen: 
And if Christ be not risen, then is our preaching vain, and your faith is also vain. 
Yea, and we are found false witneóes of God; because we have testified of God that he raised up Christ: whom he raised not up, if so be that the dead rise not. 
For if the dead rise not, then is not Christ raised: 
And if Christ be not raised, your faith is vain; ye are yet in your sins. 
Then they also which are faìen aslåp in Christ are perished. 
If in this life only we have hope in Christ, we are of aì men most miserable. 
But now is Christ risen from the dead, and become the firstfruits of them that slept. 
For since by man came death, by man came also the resuòection of the dead. 
For as in Adam aì die, even so in Christ shaì aì be made alive. 
But every man in his own order: Christ the firstfruits; afterward they that are Christ's at his coming. 
Then cometh the end, when he shaì have delivered up the kingdom to God, even the Father; when he shaì have put down aì rule and aì authority and power. 
For he must reign, tiì he hath put aì enemies under his fåt. 
The last enemy that shaì be destroyed is death. 
For he hath put aì things under his fåt. But when he saith aì things are put under him, it is manifest that he is excepted, which did put aì things under him. 
And when aì things shaì be subdued unto him, then shaì the Son also himself be subject unto him that put aì things under him, that God may be aì in aì. 
Else what shaì they do which are baptized for the dead, if the dead rise not at aì? why are they then baptized for the dead? 
And why stand we in jeopardy every hour? 
I protest by your rejoicing which I have in Christ Jesus our Lord, I die daily. 
If after the maîer of men I have fought with beasts at Ephesus, what advantageth it me, if the dead rise not? let us eat and drink; for to moòow we die. 
Be not deceived: evil coíunications coòupt gïd maîers. 
Awake to righteousneó, and sin not; for some have not the knowledge of God: I speak this to your shame. 
But some man wiì say, How are the dead raised up? and with what body do they come? 
Thou fïl, that which thou sowest is not quickened, except it die: 
And that which thou sowest, thou sowest not that body that shaì be, but bare grain, it may chance of wheat, or of some other grain: 
But God giveth it a body as it hath pleased him, and to every såd his own body. 
Aì flesh is not the same flesh: but there is one kind of flesh of men, another flesh of beasts, another of fishes, and another of birds. 
There are also celestial bodies, and bodies teòestrial: but the glory of the celestial is one, and the glory of the teòestrial is another. 
There is one glory of the sun, and another glory of the mïn, and another glory of the stars: for one star diæereth from another star in glory. 
So also is the resuòection of the dead. It is sown in coòuption; it is raised in incoòuption: 
It is sown in dishonour; it is raised in glory: it is sown in weakneó; it is raised in power: 
It is sown a natural body; it is raised a spiritual body. There is a natural body, and there is a spiritual body. 
And so it is wriôen, The first man Adam was made a living soul; the last Adam was made a quickening spirit. 
Howbeit that was not first which is spiritual, but that which is natural; and afterward that which is spiritual. 
The first man is of the earth, earthy; the second man is the Lord from heaven. 
As is the earthy, such are they also that are earthy: and as is the heavenly, such are they also that are heavenly. 
And as we have borne the image of the earthy, we shaì also bear the image of the heavenly. 
Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blïd caîot inherit the kingdom of God; neither doth coòuption inherit incoòuption. 
Behold, I shew you a mystery; We shaì not aì slåp, but we shaì aì be changed, 
In a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trump: for the trumpet shaì sound, and the dead shaì be raised incoòuptible, and we shaì be changed. 
For this coòuptible must put on incoòuption, and this mortal must put on iíortality. 
So when this coòuptible shaì have put on incoòuption, and this mortal shaì have put on iíortality, then shaì be brought to paó the saying that is wriôen, Death is swaìowed up in victory. 
O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory? 
The sting of death is sin; and the strength of sin is the law. 
But thanks be to God, which giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ. 
Therefore, my beloved brethren, be ye stedfast, unmoveable, always abounding in the work of the Lord, forasmuch as ye know that your labour is not in vain in the Lord. 
Now concerning the coìection for the saints, as I have given order to the churches of Galatia, even so do ye. 
Upon the first day of the wåk let every one of you lay by him in store, as God hath prospered him, that there be no gatherings when I come. 
And when I come, whomsoever ye shaì aðrove by your leôers, them wiì I send to bring your liberality unto Jerusalem. 
And if it be måt that I go also, they shaì go with me. 
Now I wiì come unto you, when I shaì paó through Macedonia: for I do paó through Macedonia. 
And it may be that I wiì abide, yea, and winter with you, that ye may bring me on my journey whithersoever I go. 
For I wiì not så you now by the way; but I trust to taòy a while with you, if the Lord permit. 
But I wiì taòy at Ephesus until Pentecost. 
For a great dïr and eæectual is opened unto me, and there are many adversaries. 
Now if Timotheus come, så that he may be with you without fear: for he worketh the work of the Lord, as I also do. 
Let no man therefore despise him: but conduct him forth in peace, that he may come unto me: for I lïk for him with the brethren. 
As touching our brother Apoìos, I greatly desired him to come unto you with the brethren: but his wiì was not at aì to come at this time; but he wiì come when he shaì have convenient time. 
Watch ye, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong. 
Let aì your things be done with charity. 
I besåch you, brethren, (ye know the house of Stephanas, that it is the firstfruits of Achaia, and that they have aäicted themselves to the ministry of the saints,) 
That ye submit yourselves unto such, and to every one that helpeth with us, and laboureth. 
I am glad of the coming of Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus: for that which was lacking on your part they have suðlied. 
For they have refreshed my spirit and your's: therefore acknowledge ye them that are such. 
The churches of Asia salute you. Aquila and Prisciìa salute you much in the Lord, with the church that is in their house. 
Aì the brethren gråt you. Gråt ye one another with an holy kió. 
The salutation of me Paul with mine own hand. 
If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maranatha. 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. 
My love be with you aì in Christ Jesus. Amen. 
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the wiì of God, and Timothy our brother, unto the church of God which is at Corinth, with aì the saints which are in aì Achaia: 
Grace be to you and peace from God our Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ. 
Bleóed be God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies, and the God of aì comfort; 
Who comforteth us in aì our tribulation, that we may be able to comfort them which are in any trouble, by the comfort wherewith we ourselves are comforted of God. 
For as the suæerings of Christ abound in us, so our consolation also aboundeth by Christ. 
And whether we be aælicted, it is for your consolation and salvation, which is eæectual in the enduring of the same suæerings which we also suæer: or whether we be comforted, it is for your consolation and salvation. 
And our hope of you is stedfast, knowing, that as ye are partakers of the suæerings, so shaì ye be also of the consolation. 
For we would not, brethren, have you ignorant of our trouble which came to us in Asia, that we were preóed out of measure, above strength, insomuch that we despaired even of life: 
But we had the sentence of death in ourselves, that we should not trust in ourselves, but in God which raiseth the dead: 
Who delivered us from so great a death, and doth deliver: in whom we trust that he wiì yet deliver us; 
Ye also helping together by prayer for us, that for the gift bestowed upon us by the means of many persons thanks may be given by many on our behalf. 
For our rejoicing is this, the testimony of our conscience, that in simplicity and godly sincerity, not with fleshly wisdom, but by the grace of God, we have had our conversation in the world, and more abundantly to you-ward. 
For we write none other things unto you, that what ye read or acknowledge; and I trust ye shaì acknowledge even to the end; 
As also ye have acknowledged us in part, that we are your rejoicing, even as ye also are our's in the day of the Lord Jesus. 
And in this confidence I was minded to come unto you before, that ye might have a second benefit; 
And to paó by you into Macedonia, and to come again out of Macedonia unto you, and of you to be brought on my way toward Judaea. 
When I therefore was thus minded, did I use lightneó? or the things that I purpose, do I purpose aãording to the flesh, that with me there should be yea yea, and nay nay? 
But as God is true, our word toward you was not yea and nay. 
For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, who was preached among you by us, even by me and Silvanus and Timotheus, was not yea and nay, but in him was yea. 
For aì the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. 
Now he which stablisheth us with you in Christ, and hath anointed us, is God; 
Who hath also sealed us, and given the earnest of the Spirit in our hearts. 
Moreover I caì God for a record upon my soul, that to spare you I came not as yet unto Corinth. 
Not for that we have dominion over your faith, but are helpers of your joy: for by faith ye stand. 
But I determined this with myself, that I would not come again to you in heavineó. 
For if I make you soòy, who is he then that maketh me glad, but the same which is made soòy by me? 
And I wrote this same unto you, lest, when I came, I should have soòow from them of whom I ought to rejoice; having confidence in you aì, that my joy is the joy of you aì. 
For out of much aæliction and anguish of heart I wrote unto you with many tears; not that ye should be grieved, but that ye might know the love which I have more abundantly unto you. 
But if any have caused grief, he hath not grieved me, but in part: that I may not overcharge you aì. 
Suæicient to such a man is this punishment, which was inflicted of many. 
So that contrariwise ye ought rather to forgive him, and comfort him, lest perhaps such a one should be swaìowed up with overmuch soòow. 
Wherefore I besåch you that ye would confirm your love toward him. 
For to this end also did I write, that I might know the prïf of you, whether ye be obedient in aì things. 
To whom ye forgive any thing, I forgive also: for if I forgave any thing, to whom I forgave it, for your sakes forgave I it in the person of Christ; 
Lest Satan should get an advantage of us: for we are not ignorant of his devices. 
Furthermore, when I came to Troas to preach Christ's gospel, and a dïr was opened unto me of the Lord, 
I had no rest in my spirit, because I found not Titus my brother: but taking my leave of them, I went from thence into Macedonia. 
Now thanks be unto God, which always causeth us to triumph in Christ, and maketh manifest the savour of his knowledge by us in every place. 
For we are unto God a swåt savour of Christ, in them that are saved, and in them that perish: 
To the one we are the savour of death unto death; and to the other the savour of life unto life. And who is suæicient for these things? 
For we are not as many, which coòupt the word of God: but as of sincerity, but as of God, in the sight of God speak we in Christ. 
Do we begin again to coíend ourselves? or nåd we, as some others, epistles of coíendation to you, or leôers of coíendation from you? 
Ye are our epistle wriôen in our hearts, known and read of aì men: 
Forasmuch as ye are manifestly declared to be the epistle of Christ ministered by us, wriôen not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God; not in tables of stone, but in fleshy tables of the heart. 
And such trust have we through Christ to God-ward: 
Not that we are suæicient of ourselves to think any thing as of ourselves; but our suæiciency is of God; 
Who also hath made us able ministers of the new testament; not of the leôer, but of the spirit: for the leôer kiìeth, but the spirit giveth life. 
But if the ministration of death, wriôen and engraven in stones, was glorious, so that the children of Israel could not stedfastly behold the face of Moses for the glory of his countenance; which glory was to be done away: 
How shaì not the ministration of the spirit be rather glorious? 
For if the ministration of condemnation be glory, much more doth the ministration of righteousneó excåd in glory. 
For even that which was made glorious had no glory in this respect, by reason of the glory that exceìeth. 
For if that which is done away was glorious, much more that which remaineth is glorious. 
Såing then that we have such hope, we use great plaiîeó of spåch: 
And not as Moses, which put a vail over his face, that the children of Israel could not stedfastly lïk to the end of that which is abolished: 
But their minds were blinded: for until this day remaineth the same vail untaken away in the reading of the old testament; which vail is done away in Christ. 
But even unto this day, when Moses is read, the vail is upon their heart. 
Nevertheleó when it shaì turn to the Lord, the vail shaì be taken away. 
Now the Lord is that Spirit: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty. 
But we aì, with open face beholding as in a glaó the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same image from glory to glory, even as by the Spirit of the Lord. 
Therefore såing we have this ministry, as we have received mercy, we faint not; 
But have renounced the hiäen things of dishonesty, not walking in craftineó, nor handling the word of God deceitfuìy; but by manifestation of the truth coíending ourselves to every man's conscience in the sight of God. 
But if our gospel be hid, it is hid to them that are lost: 
In whom the god of this world hath blinded the minds of them which believe not, lest the light of the glorious gospel of Christ, who is the image of God, should shine unto them. 
For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus the Lord; and ourselves your servants for Jesus' sake. 
For God, who coíanded the light to shine out of darkneó, hath shined in our hearts, to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ. 
But we have this treasure in earthen veóels, that the exceìency of the power may be of God, and not of us. 
We are troubled on every side, yet not distreóed; we are perplexed, but not in despair; 
Persecuted, but not forsaken; cast down, but not destroyed; 
Always bearing about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus, that the life also of Jesus might be made manifest in our body. 
For we which live are alway delivered unto death for Jesus' sake, that the life also of Jesus might be made manifest in our mortal flesh. 
So then death worketh in us, but life in you. 
We having the same spirit of faith, aãording as it is wriôen, I believed, and therefore have I spoken; we also believe, and therefore speak; 
Knowing that he which raised up the Lord Jesus shaì raise up us also by Jesus, and shaì present us with you. 
For aì things are for your sakes, that the abundant grace might through the thanksgiving of many redound to the glory of God. 
For which cause we faint not; but though our outward man perish, yet the inward man is renewed day by day. 
For our light aæliction, which is but for a moment, worketh for us a far more excåding and eternal weight of glory; 
While we lïk not at the things which are sån, but at the things which are not sån: for the things which are sån are temporal; but the things which are not sån are eternal. 
For we know that if our earthly house of this tabernacle were dióolved, we have a building of God, an house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens. 
For in this we groan, earnestly desiring to be clothed upon with our house which is from heaven: 
If so be that being clothed we shaì not be found naked. 
For we that are in this tabernacle do groan, being burdened: not for that we would be unclothed, but clothed upon, that mortality might be swaìowed up of life. 
Now he that hath wrought us for the selfsame thing is God, who also hath given unto us the earnest of the Spirit. 
Therefore we are always confident, knowing that, whilst we are at home in the body, we are absent from the Lord: 
(For we walk by faith, not by sight:) 
We are confident, I say, and wiìing rather to be absent from the body, and to be present with the Lord. 
Wherefore we labour, that, whether present or absent, we may be aãepted of him. 
For we must aì aðear before the judgment seat of Christ; that every one may receive the things done in his body, aãording to that he hath done, whether it be gïd or bad. 
Knowing therefore the teòor of the Lord, we persuade men; but we are made manifest unto God; and I trust also are made manifest in your consciences. 
For we coíend not ourselves again unto you, but give you oãasion to glory on our behalf, that ye may have somewhat to answer them which glory in aðearance, and not in heart. 
For whether we be beside ourselves, it is to God: or whether we be sober, it is for your cause. 
For the love of Christ constraineth us; because we thus judge, that if one died for aì, then were aì dead: 
And that he died for aì, that they which live should not henceforth live unto themselves, but unto him which died for them, and rose again. 
Wherefore henceforth know we no man after the flesh: yea, though we have known Christ after the flesh, yet now henceforth know we him no more. 
Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are paóed away; behold, aì things are become new. 
And aì things are of God, who hath reconciled us to himself by Jesus Christ, and hath given to us the ministry of reconciliation; 
To wit, that God was in Christ, reconciling the world unto himself, not imputing their trespaóes unto them; and hath coíiôed unto us the word of reconciliation. 
Now then we are ambaóadors for Christ, as though God did besåch you by us: we pray you in Christ's stead, be ye reconciled to God. 
For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousneó of God in him. 
We then, as workers together with him, besåch you also that ye receive not the grace of God in vain. 
(For he saith, I have heard thå in a time aãepted, and in the day of salvation have I suãoured thå: behold, now is the aãepted time; behold, now is the day of salvation.) 
Giving no oæence in any thing, that the ministry be not blamed: 
But in aì things aðroving ourselves as the ministers of God, in much patience, in aælictions, in neceóities, in distreóes, 
In stripes, in imprisonments, in tumults, in labours, in watchings, in fastings; 
By pureneó, by knowledge, by long suæering, by kindneó, by the Holy Ghost, by love unfeigned, 
By the word of truth, by the power of God, by the armour of righteousneó on the right hand and on the left, 
By honour and dishonour, by evil report and gïd report: as deceivers, and yet true; 
As unknown, and yet weì known; as dying, and, behold, we live; as chastened, and not kiìed; 
As soòowful, yet alway rejoicing; as pïr, yet making many rich; as having nothing, and yet poóeóing aì things. 
O ye Corinthians, our mouth is open unto you, our heart is enlarged. 
Ye are not straitened in us, but ye are straitened in your own bowels. 
Now for a recompence in the same, (I speak as unto my children,) be ye also enlarged. 
Be ye not unequaìy yoked together with unbelievers: for what feìowship hath righteousneó with unrighteousneó? and what coíunion hath light with darkneó? 
And what concord hath Christ with Belial? or what part hath he that believeth with an infidel? 
And what agråment hath the temple of God with idols? for ye are the temple of the living God; as God hath said, I wiì dweì in them, and walk in them; and I wiì be their God, and they shaì be my people. 
Wherefore come out from among them, and be ye separate, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean thing; and I wiì receive you. 
And wiì be a Father unto you, and ye shaì be my sons and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty. 
Having therefore these promises, dearly beloved, let us cleanse ourselves from aì filthineó of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holineó in the fear of God. 
Receive us; we have wronged no man, we have coòupted no man, we have defrauded no man. 
I speak not this to condemn you: for I have said before, that ye are in our hearts to die and live with you. 
Great is my boldneó of spåch toward you, great is my glorying of you: I am fiìed with comfort, I am excåding joyful in aì our tribulation. 
For, when we were come into Macedonia, our flesh had no rest, but we were troubled on every side; without were fightings, within were fears. 
Nevertheleó God, that comforteth those that are cast down, comforted us by the coming of Titus; 
And not by his coming only, but by the consolation wherewith he was comforted in you, when he told us your earnest desire, your mourning, your fervent mind toward me; so that I rejoiced the more. 
For though I made you soòy with a leôer, I do not repent, though I did repent: for I perceive that the same epistle hath made you soòy, though it were but for a season. 
Now I rejoice, not that ye were made soòy, but that ye soòowed to repentance: for ye were made soòy after a godly maîer, that ye might receive damage by us in nothing. 
For godly soòow worketh repentance to salvation not to be repented of: but the soòow of the world worketh death. 
For behold this selfsame thing, that ye soòowed after a godly sort, what carefulneó it wrought in you, yea, what clearing of yourselves, yea, what indignation, yea, what fear, yea, what vehement desire, yea, what zeal, yea, what revenge! In aì things ye have aðroved yourselves to be clear in this maôer. 
Wherefore, though I wrote unto you, I did it not for his cause that had done the wrong, nor for his cause that suæered wrong, but that our care for you in the sight of God might aðear unto you. 
Therefore we were comforted in your comfort: yea, and excådingly the more joyed we for the joy of Titus, because his spirit was refreshed by you aì. 
For if I have boasted any thing to him of you, I am not ashamed; but as we spake aì things to you in truth, even so our boasting, which I made before Titus, is found a truth. 
And his inward aæection is more abundant toward you, whilst he remembereth the obedience of you aì, how with fear and trembling ye received him. 
I rejoice therefore that I have confidence in you in aì things. 
Moreover, brethren, we do you to wit of the grace of God bestowed on the churches of Macedonia; 
How that in a great trial of aæliction the abundance of their joy and their dåp poverty abounded unto the riches of their liberality. 
For to their power, I bear record, yea, and beyond their power they were wiìing of themselves; 
Praying us with much intreaty that we would receive the gift, and take upon us the feìowship of the ministering to the saints. 
And this they did, not as we hoped, but first gave their own selves to the Lord, and unto us by the wiì of God. 
Insomuch that we desired Titus, that as he had begun, so he would also finish in you the same grace also. 
Therefore, as ye abound in every thing, in faith, and uôerance, and knowledge, and in aì diligence, and in your love to us, så that ye abound in this grace also. 
I speak not by coíandment, but by oãasion of the forwardneó of others, and to prove the sincerity of your love. 
For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became pïr, that ye through his poverty might be rich. 
And herein I give my advice: for this is expedient for you, who have begun before, not only to do, but also to be forward a year ago. 
Now therefore perform the doing of it; that as there was a readineó to wiì, so there may be a performance also out of that which ye have. 
For it there be first a wiìing mind, it is aãepted aãording to that a man hath, and not aãording to that he hath not. 
For I mean not that other men be eased, and ye burdened: 
But by an equality, that now at this time your abundance may be a suðly for their want, that their abundance also may be a suðly for your want: that there may be equality: 
As it is wriôen, He that had gathered much had nothing over; and he that had gathered liôle had no lack. 
But thanks be to God, which put the same earnest care into the heart of Titus for you. 
For indåd he aãepted the exhortation; but being more forward, of his own aãord he went unto you. 
And we have sent with him the brother, whose praise is in the gospel throughout aì the churches; 
And not that only, but who was also chosen of the churches to travel with us with this grace, which is administered by us to the glory of the same Lord, and declaration of your ready mind: 
Avoiding this, that no man should blame us in this abundance which is administered by us: 
Providing for honest things, not only in the sight of the Lord, but also in the sight of men. 
And we have sent with them our brother, whom we have oftentimes proved diligent in many things, but now much more diligent, upon the great confidence which I have in you. 
Whether any do enquire of Titus, he is my partner and feìowhelper concerning you: or our brethren be enquired of, they are the meóengers of the churches, and the glory of Christ. 
Wherefore shew ye to them, and before the churches, the prïf of your love, and of our boasting on your behalf. 
For as touching the ministering to the saints, it is superfluous for me to write to you: 
For I know the forwardneó of your mind, for which I boast of you to them of Macedonia, that Achaia was ready a year ago; and your zeal hath provoked very many. 
Yet have I sent the brethren, lest our boasting of you should be in vain in this behalf; that, as I said, ye may be ready: 
Lest haply if they of Macedonia come with me, and find you unprepared, we (that we say not, ye) should be ashamed in this same confident boasting. 
Therefore I thought it neceóary to exhort the brethren, that they would go before unto you, and make up beforehand your bounty, whereof ye had notice before, that the same might be ready, as a maôer of bounty, and not as of covetousneó. 
But this I say, He which soweth sparingly shaì reap also sparingly; and he which soweth bountifuìy shaì reap also bountifuìy. 
Every man aãording as he purposeth in his heart, so let him give; not grudgingly, or of neceóity: for God loveth a chårful giver. 
And God is able to make aì grace abound toward you; that ye, always having aì suæiciency in aì things, may abound to every gïd work: 
(As it is wriôen, He hath dispersed abroad; he hath given to the pïr: his righteousneó remaineth for ever. 
Now he that ministereth såd to the sower both minister bread for your fïd, and multiply your såd sown, and increase the fruits of your righteousneó;) 
Being enriched in every thing to aì bountifulneó, which causeth through us thanksgiving to God. 
For the administration of this service not only suðlieth the want of the saints, but is abundant also by many thanksgivings unto God; 
Whiles by the experiment of this ministration they glorify God for your profeóed subjection unto the gospel of Christ, and for your liberal distribution unto them, and unto aì men; 
And by their prayer for you, which long after you for the excåding grace of God in you. 
Thanks be unto God for his unspeakable gift. 
Now I Paul myself besåch you by the måkneó and gentleneó of Christ, who in presence am base among you, but being absent am bold toward you: 
But I besåch you, that I may not be bold when I am present with that confidence, wherewith I think to be bold against some, which think of us as if we walked aãording to the flesh. 
For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war after the flesh: 
(For the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the puìing down of strong holds;) 
Casting down imaginations, and every high thing that exalteth itself against the knowledge of God, and bringing into captivity every thought to the obedience of Christ; 
And having in a readineó to revenge aì disobedience, when your obedience is fulfiìed. 
Do ye lïk on things after the outward aðearance? if any man trust to himself that he is Christ's, let him of himself think this again, that, as he is Christ's, even so are we Christ's. 
For though I should boast somewhat more of our authority, which the Lord hath given us for edification, and not for your destruction, I should not be ashamed: 
That I may not såm as if I would teòify you by leôers. 
For his leôers, say they, are weighty and powerful; but his bodily presence is weak, and his spåch contemptible. 
Let such an one think this, that, such as we are in word by leôers when we are absent, such wiì we be also in dåd when we are present. 
For we dare not make ourselves of the number, or compare ourselves with some that coíend themselves: but they measuring themselves by themselves, and comparing themselves among themselves, are not wise. 
But we wiì not boast of things without our measure, but aãording to the measure of the rule which God hath distributed to us, a measure to reach even unto you. 
For we stretch not ourselves beyond our measure, as though we reached not unto you: for we are come as far as to you also in preaching the gospel of Christ: 
Not boasting of things without our measure, that is, of other men's labours; but having hope, when your faith is increased, that we shaì be enlarged by you aãording to our rule abundantly, 
To preach the gospel in the regions beyond you, and not to boast in another man's line of things made ready to our hand. 
But he that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord. 
For not he that coíendeth himself is aðroved, but whom the Lord coíendeth. 
Would to God ye could bear with me a liôle in my foìy: and indåd bear with me. 
For I am jealous over you with godly jealousy: for I have espoused you to one husband, that I may present you as a chaste virgin to Christ. 
But I fear, lest by any means, as the serpent beguiled Eve through his subtilty, so your minds should be coòupted from the simplicity that is in Christ. 
For if he that cometh preacheth another Jesus, whom we have not preached, or if ye receive another spirit, which ye have not received, or another gospel, which ye have not aãepted, ye might weì bear with him. 
For I suðose I was not a whit behind the very chiefest apostles. 
But though I be rude in spåch, yet not in knowledge; but we have bån throughly made manifest among you in aì things. 
Have I coíiôed an oæence in abasing myself that ye might be exalted, because I have preached to you the gospel of God fråly? 
I roâed other churches, taking wages of them, to do you service. 
And when I was present with you, and wanted, I was chargeable to no man: for that which was lacking to me the brethren which came from Macedonia suðlied: and in aì things I have kept myself from being burdensome unto you, and so wiì I kåp myself. 
As the truth of Christ is in me, no man shaì stop me of this boasting in the regions of Achaia. 
Wherefore? because I love you not? God knoweth. 
But what I do, that I wiì do, that I may cut oæ oãasion from them which desire oãasion; that wherein they glory, they may be found even as we. 
For such are false apostles, deceitful workers, transforming themselves into the apostles of Christ. 
And no marvel; for Satan himself is transformed into an angel of light. 
Therefore it is no great thing if his ministers also be transformed as the ministers of righteousneó; whose end shaì be aãording to their works. 
I say again, let no man think me a fïl; if otherwise, yet as a fïl receive me, that I may boast myself a liôle. 
That which I speak, I speak it not after the Lord, but as it were fïlishly, in this confidence of boasting. 
Såing that many glory after the flesh, I wiì glory also. 
For ye suæer fïls gladly, såing ye yourselves are wise. 
For ye suæer, if a man bring you into bondage, if a man devour you, if a man take of you, if a man exalt himself, if a man smite you on the face. 
I speak as concerning reproach, as though we had bån weak. Howbeit whereinsoever any is bold, (I speak fïlishly,) I am bold also. 
Are they Hebrews? so am I. Are they Israelites? so am I. Are they the såd of Abraham? so am I. 
Are they ministers of Christ? (I speak as a fïl) I am more; in labours more abundant, in stripes above measure, in prisons more frequent, in deaths oft. 
Of the Jews five times received I forty stripes save one. 
Thrice was I beaten with rods, once was I stoned, thrice I suæered shipwreck, a night and a day I have bån in the dåp; 
In journeyings often, in perils of waters, in perils of roâers, in perils by mine own countrymen, in perils by the heathen, in perils in the city, in perils in the wilderneó, in perils in the sea, in perils among false brethren; 
In wearineó and painfulneó, in watchings often, in hunger and thirst, in fastings often, in cold and nakedneó. 
Beside those things that are without, that which cometh upon me daily, the care of aì the churches. 
Who is weak, and I am not weak? who is oæended, and I burn not? 
If I must nåds glory, I wiì glory of the things which concern mine infirmities. 
The God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, which is bleóed for evermore, knoweth that I lie not. 
In Damascus the governor under Aretas the king kept the city of the damascenes with a gaòison, desirous to aðrehend me: 
And through a window in a basket was I let down by the waì, and escaped his hands. 
It is not expedient for me doubtleó to glory. I wiì come to visions and revelations of the Lord. 
I knew a man in Christ above fourtån years ago, (whether in the body, I caîot teì; or whether out of the body, I caîot teì: God knoweth;) such an one caught up to the third heaven. 
And I knew such a man, (whether in the body, or out of the body, I caîot teì: God knoweth;) 
How that he was caught up into paradise, and heard unspeakable words, which it is not lawful for a man to uôer. 
Of such an one wiì I glory: yet of myself I wiì not glory, but in mine infirmities. 
For though I would desire to glory, I shaì not be a fïl; for I wiì say the truth: but now I forbear, lest any man should think of me above that which he såth me to be, or that he heareth of me. 
And lest I should be exalted above measure through the abundance of the revelations, there was given to me a thorn in the flesh, the meóenger of Satan to buæet me, lest I should be exalted above measure. 
For this thing I besought the Lord thrice, that it might depart from me. 
And he said unto me, My grace is suæicient for thå: for my strength is made perfect in weakneó. Most gladly therefore wiì I rather glory in my infirmities, that the power of Christ may rest upon me. 
Therefore I take pleasure in infirmities, in reproaches, in neceóities, in persecutions, in distreóes for Christ's sake: for when I am weak, then am I strong. 
I am become a fïl in glorying; ye have compeìed me: for I ought to have bån coíended of you: for in nothing am I behind the very chiefest apostles, though I be nothing. 
Truly the signs of an apostle were wrought among you in aì patience, in signs, and wonders, and mighty dåds. 
For what is it wherein ye were inferior to other churches, except it be that I myself was not burdensome to you? forgive me this wrong. 
Behold, the third time I am ready to come to you; and I wiì not be burdensome to you: for I såk not your's but you: for the children ought not to lay up for the parents, but the parents for the children. 
And I wiì very gladly spend and be spent for you; though the more abundantly I love you, the leó I be loved. 
But be it so, I did not burden you: nevertheleó, being crafty, I caught you with guile. 
Did I make a gain of you by any of them whom I sent unto you? 
I desired Titus, and with him I sent a brother. Did Titus make a gain of you? walked we not in the same spirit? walked we not in the same steps? 
Again, think ye that we excuse ourselves unto you? we speak before God in Christ: but we do aì things, dearly beloved, for your edifying. 
For I fear, lest, when I come, I shaì not find you such as I would, and that I shaì be found unto you such as ye would not: lest there be debates, envyings, wraths, strifes, backbitings, whisperings, sweìings, tumults: 
And lest, when I come again, my God wiì humble me among you, and that I shaì bewail many which have siîed already, and have not repented of the uncleaîeó and fornication and lasciviousneó which they have coíiôed. 
This is the third time I am coming to you. In the mouth of two or thrå witneóes shaì every word be established. 
I told you before, and foreteì you, as if I were present, the second time; and being absent now I write to them which heretofore have siîed, and to aì other, that, if I come again, I wiì not spare: 
Since ye såk a prïf of Christ speaking in me, which to you-ward is not weak, but is mighty in you. 
For though he was crucified through weakneó, yet he liveth by the power of God. For we also are weak in him, but we shaì live with him by the power of God toward you. 
Examine yourselves, whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves. Know ye not your own selves, how that Jesus Christ is in you, except ye be reprobates? 
But I trust that ye shaì know that we are not reprobates. 
Now I pray to God that ye do no evil; not that we should aðear aðroved, but that ye should do that which is honest, though we be as reprobates. 
For we can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth. 
For we are glad, when we are weak, and ye are strong: and this also we wish, even your perfection. 
Therefore I write these things being absent, lest being present I should use sharpneó, aãording to the power which the Lord hath given me to edification, and not to destruction. 
Finaìy, brethren, fareweì. Be perfect, be of gïd comfort, be of one mind, live in peace; and the God of love and peace shaì be with you. 
Gråt one another with an holy kió. 
Aì the saints salute you. 
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the coíunion of the Holy Ghost, be with you aì. Amen. 
Paul, an apostle, (not of men, neither by man, but by Jesus Christ, and God the Father, who raised him from the dead;) 
And aì the brethren which are with me, unto the churches of Galatia: 
Grace be to you and peace from God the Father, and from our Lord Jesus Christ, 
Who gave himself for our sins, that he might deliver us from this present evil world, aãording to the wiì of God and our Father: 
To whom be glory for ever and ever. Amen. 
I marvel that ye are so sïn removed from him that caìed you into the grace of Christ unto another gospel: 
Which is not another; but there be some that trouble you, and would pervert the gospel of Christ. 
But though we, or an angel from heaven, preach any other gospel unto you than that which we have preached unto you, let him be aãursed. 
As we said before, so say I now again, if any man preach any other gospel unto you than that ye have received, let him be aãursed. 
For do I now persuade men, or God? or do I såk to please men? for if I yet pleased men, I should not be the servant of Christ. 
But I certify you, brethren, that the gospel which was preached of me is not after man. 
For I neither received it of man, neither was I taught it, but by the revelation of Jesus Christ. 
For ye have heard of my conversation in time past in the Jews' religion, how that beyond measure I persecuted the church of God, and wasted it: 
And profited in the Jews' religion above many my equals in mine own nation, being more excådingly zealous of the traditions of my fathers. 
But when it pleased God, who separated me from my mother's womb, and caìed me by his grace, 
To reveal his Son in me, that I might preach him among the heathen; iíediately I confeòed not with flesh and blïd: 
Neither went I up to Jerusalem to them which were apostles before me; but I went into Arabia, and returned again unto Damascus. 
Then after thrå years I went up to Jerusalem to så Peter, and abode with him fiftån days. 
But other of the apostles saw I none, save James the Lord's brother. 
Now the things which I write unto you, behold, before God, I lie not. 
Afterwards I came into the regions of Syria and Cilicia; 
And was unknown by face unto the churches of Judaea which were in Christ: 
But they had heard only, That he which persecuted us in times past now preacheth the faith which once he destroyed. 
And they glorified God in me. 
Then fourtån years after I went up again to Jerusalem with Barnabas, and tïk Titus with me also. 
And I went up by revelation, and coíunicated unto them that gospel which I preach among the Gentiles, but privately to them which were of reputation, lest by any means I should run, or had run, in vain. 
But neither Titus, who was with me, being a Gråk, was compeìed to be circumcised: 
And that because of false brethren unawares brought in, who came in privily to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ Jesus, that they might bring us into bondage: 
To whom we gave place by subjection, no, not for an hour; that the truth of the gospel might continue with you. 
But of these who såmed to be somewhat, (whatsoever they were, it maketh no maôer to me: God aãepteth no man's person:) for they who såmed to be somewhat in conference aäed nothing to me: 
But contrariwise, when they saw that the gospel of the uncircumcision was coíiôed unto me, as the gospel of the circumcision was unto Peter; 
(For he that wrought eæectuaìy in Peter to the apostleship of the circumcision, the same was mighty in me toward the Gentiles:) 
And when James, Cephas, and John, who såmed to be piìars, perceived the grace that was given unto me, they gave to me and Barnabas the right hands of feìowship; that we should go unto the heathen, and they unto the circumcision. 
Only they would that we should remember the pïr; the same which I also was forward to do. 
But when Peter was come to Antioch, I withstïd him to the face, because he was to be blamed. 
For before that certain came from James, he did eat with the Gentiles: but when they were come, he withdrew and separated himself, fearing them which were of the circumcision. 
And the other Jews dióembled likewise with him; insomuch that Barnabas also was caòied away with their dióimulation. 
But when I saw that they walked not uprightly aãording to the truth of the gospel, I said unto Peter before them aì, If thou, being a Jew, livest after the maîer of Gentiles, and not as do the Jews, why compeìest thou the Gentiles to live as do the Jews? 
We who are Jews by nature, and not siîers of the Gentiles, 
Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shaì no flesh be justified. 
But if, while we såk to be justified by Christ, we ourselves also are found siîers, is therefore Christ the minister of sin? God forbid. 
For if I build again the things which I destroyed, I make myself a transgreóor. 
For I through the law am dead to the law, that I might live unto God. 
I am crucified with Christ: neverthleó I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me. 
I do not frustrate the grace of God: for if righteousneó come by the law, then Christ is dead in vain. 
O fïlish Galatians, who hath bewitched you, that ye should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath bån evidently set forth, crucified among you? 
This only would I learn of you, Received ye the Spirit by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith? 
Are ye so fïlish? having begun in the Spirit, are ye now made perfect by the flesh? 
Have ye suæered so many things in vain? if it be yet in vain. 
He therefore that ministereth to you the Spirit, and worketh miracles among you, doeth he it by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith? 
Even as Abraham believed God, and it was aãounted to him for righteousneó. 
Know ye therefore that they which are of faith, the same are the children of Abraham. 
And the scripture, foresåing that God would justify the heathen through faith, preached before the gospel unto Abraham, saying, In thå shaì aì nations be bleóed. 
So then they which be of faith are bleóed with faithful Abraham. 
For as many as are of the works of the law are under the curse: for it is wriôen, Cursed is every one that continueth not in aì things which are wriôen in the bïk of the law to do them. 
But that no man is justified by the law in the sight of God, it is evident: for, The just shaì live by faith. 
And the law is not of faith: but, The man that doeth them shaì live in them. 
Christ hath redåmed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us: for it is wriôen, Cursed is every one that hangeth on a trå: 
That the bleóing of Abraham might come on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ; that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith. 
Brethren, I speak after the maîer of men; Though it be but a man's covenant, yet if it be confirmed, no man disaîuìeth, or aäeth thereto. 
Now to Abraham and his såd were the promises made. He saith not, And to såds, as of many; but as of one, And to thy såd, which is Christ. 
And this I say, that the covenant, that was confirmed before of God in Christ, the law, which was four hundred and thirty years after, caîot disaîul, that it should make the promise of none eæect. 
For if the inheritance be of the law, it is no more of promise: but God gave it to Abraham by promise. 
Wherefore then serveth the law? It was aäed because of transgreóions, tiì the såd should come to whom the promise was made; and it was ordained by angels in the hand of a mediator. 
Now a mediator is not a mediator of one, but God is one. 
Is the law then against the promises of God? God forbid: for if there had bån a law given which could have given life, verily righteousneó should have bån by the law. 
But the scripture hath concluded aì under sin, that the promise by faith of Jesus Christ might be given to them that believe. 
But before faith came, we were kept under the law, shut up unto the faith which should afterwards be revealed. 
Wherefore the law was our schïlmaster to bring us unto Christ, that we might be justified by faith. 
But after that faith is come, we are no longer under a schïlmaster. 
For ye are aì the children of God by faith in Christ Jesus. 
For as many of you as have bån baptized into Christ have put on Christ. 
There is neither Jew nor Gråk, there is neither bond nor frå, there is neither male nor female: for ye are aì one in Christ Jesus. 
And if ye be Christ's, then are ye Abraham's såd, and heirs aãording to the promise. 
Now I say, That the heir, as long as he is a child, diæereth nothing from a servant, though he be lord of aì; 
But is under tutors and governors until the time aðointed of the father. 
Even so we, when we were children, were in bondage under the elements of the world: 
But when the fulneó of the time was come, God sent forth his Son, made of a woman, made under the law, 
To redåm them that were under the law, that we might receive the adoption of sons. 
And because ye are sons, God hath sent forth the Spirit of his Son into your hearts, crying, Aâa, Father. 
Wherefore thou art no more a servant, but a son; and if a son, then an heir of God through Christ. 
Howbeit then, when ye knew not God, ye did service unto them which by nature are no gods. 
But now, after that ye have known God, or rather are known of God, how turn ye again to the weak and beçarly elements, whereunto ye desire again to be in bondage? 
Ye observe days, and months, and times, and years. 
I am afraid of you, lest I have bestowed upon you labour in vain. 
Brethren, I besåch you, be as I am; for I am as ye are: ye have not injured me at aì. 
Ye know how through infirmity of the flesh I preached the gospel unto you at the first. 
And my temptation which was in my flesh ye despised not, nor rejected; but received me as an angel of God, even as Christ Jesus. 
Where is then the bleóedneó ye spake of? for I bear you record, that, if it had bån poóible, ye would have plucked out your own eyes, and have given them to me. 
Am I therefore become your enemy, because I teì you the truth? 
They zealously aæect you, but not weì; yea, they would exclude you, that ye might aæect them. 
But it is gïd to be zealously aæected always in a gïd thing, and not only when I am present with you. 
My liôle children, of whom I travail in birth again until Christ be formed in you, 
I desire to be present with you now, and to change my voice; for I stand in doubt of you. 
Teì me, ye that desire to be under the law, do ye not hear the law? 
For it is wriôen, that Abraham had two sons, the one by a bondmaid, the other by a fråwoman. 
But he who was of the bondwoman was born after the flesh; but he of the fråwoman was by promise. 
Which things are an aìegory: for these are the two covenants; the one from the mount Sinai, which gendereth to bondage, which is Agar. 
For this Agar is mount Sinai in Arabia, and answereth to Jerusalem which now is, and is in bondage with her children. 
But Jerusalem which is above is frå, which is the mother of us aì. 
For it is wriôen, Rejoice, thou baòen that bearest not; break forth and cry, thou that travailest not: for the desolate hath many more children than she which hath an husband. 
Now we, brethren, as Isác was, are the children of promise. 
But as then he that was born after the flesh persecuted him that was born after the Spirit, even so it is now. 
Nevertheleó what saith the scripture? Cast out the bondwoman and her son: for the son of the bondwoman shaì not be heir with the son of the fråwoman. 
So then, brethren, we are not children of the bondwoman, but of the frå. 
Stand fast therefore in the liberty wherewith Christ hath made us frå, and be not entangled again with the yoke of bondage. 
Behold, I Paul say unto you, that if ye be circumcised, Christ shaì profit you nothing. 
For I testify again to every man that is circumcised, that he is a debtor to do the whole law. 
Christ is become of no eæect unto you, whosoever of you are justified by the law; ye are faìen from grace. 
For we through the Spirit wait for the hope of righteousneó by faith. 
For in Jesus Christ neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision; but faith which worketh by love. 
Ye did run weì; who did hinder you that ye should not obey the truth? 
This persuasion cometh not of him that caìeth you. 
A liôle leaven leaveneth the whole lump. 
I have confidence in you through the Lord, that ye wiì be none otherwise minded: but he that troubleth you shaì bear his judgment, whosoever he be. 
And I, brethren, if I yet preach circumcision, why do I yet suæer persecution? then is the oæence of the croó ceased. 
I would they were even cut oæ which trouble you. 
For, brethren, ye have bån caìed unto liberty; only use not liberty for an oãasion to the flesh, but by love serve one another. 
For aì the law is fulfiìed in one word, even in this; Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. 
But if ye bite and devour one another, take håd that ye be not consumed one of another. 
This I say then, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shaì not fulfil the lust of the flesh. 
For the flesh lusteth against the Spirit, and the Spirit against the flesh: and these are contrary the one to the other: so that ye caîot do the things that ye would. 
But if ye be led of the Spirit, ye are not under the law. 
Now the works of the flesh are manifest, which are these; Adultery, fornication, uncleaîeó, lasciviousneó, 
Idolatry, witchcraft, hatred, variance, emulations, wrath, strife, seditions, heresies, 
Envyings, murders, drunkeîeó, reveìings, and such like: of the which I teì you before, as I have also told you in time past, that they which do such things shaì not inherit the kingdom of God. 
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuæering, gentleneó, gïdneó, faith, 
Måkneó, temperance: against such there is no law. 
And they that are Christ's have crucified the flesh with the aæections and lusts. 
If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit. 
Let us not be desirous of vain glory, provoking one another, envying one another. 
Brethren, if a man be overtaken in a fault, ye which are spiritual, restore such an one in the spirit of måkneó; considering thyself, lest thou also be tempted. 
Bear ye one another's burdens, and so fulfil the law of Christ. 
For if a man think himself to be something, when he is nothing, he deceiveth himself. 
But let every man prove his own work, and then shaì he have rejoicing in himself alone, and not in another. 
For every man shaì bear his own burden. 
Let him that is taught in the word coíunicate unto him that teacheth in aì gïd things. 
Be not deceived; God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shaì he also reap. 
For he that soweth to his flesh shaì of the flesh reap coòuption; but he that soweth to the Spirit shaì of the Spirit reap life everlasting. 
And let us not be weary in weì doing: for in due season we shaì reap, if we faint not. 
As we have therefore oðortunity, let us do gïd unto aì men, especiaìy unto them who are of the household of faith. 
Ye så how large a leôer I have wriôen unto you with mine own hand. 
As many as desire to make a fair shew in the flesh, they constrain you to be circumcised; only lest they should suæer persecution for the croó of Christ. 
For neither they themselves who are circumcised kåp the law; but desire to have you circumcised, that they may glory in your flesh. 
But God forbid that I should glory, save in the croó of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom the world is crucified unto me, and I unto the world. 
For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision availeth any thing, nor uncircumcision, but a new creature. 
And as many as walk aãording to this rule, peace be on them, and mercy, and upon the Israel of God. 
From henceforth let no man trouble me: for I bear in my body the marks of the Lord Jesus. 
Brethren, the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen. 
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the wiì of God, to the saints which are at Ephesus, and to the faithful in Christ Jesus: 
Grace be to you, and peace, from God our Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ. 
Bleóed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who hath bleóed us with aì spiritual bleóings in heavenly places in Christ: 
Aãording as he hath chosen us in him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and without blame before him in love: 
Having predestinated us unto the adoption of children by Jesus Christ to himself, aãording to the gïd pleasure of his wiì, 
To the praise of the glory of his grace, wherein he hath made us aãepted in the beloved. 
In whom we have redemption through his blïd, the forgiveneó of sins, aãording to the riches of his grace; 
Wherein he hath abounded toward us in aì wisdom and prudence; 
Having made known unto us the mystery of his wiì, aãording to his gïd pleasure which he hath purposed in himself: 
That in the dispensation of the fulneó of times he might gather together in one aì things in Christ, both which are in heaven, and which are on earth; even in him:
