In whom also we have obtained an inheritance, being predestinated aãording to the purpose of him who worketh aì things after the counsel of his own wiì: 
That we should be to the praise of his glory, who first trusted in Christ. 
In whom ye also trusted, after that ye heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation: in whom also after that ye believed, ye were sealed with that holy Spirit of promise, 
Which is the earnest of our inheritance until the redemption of the purchased poóeóion, unto the praise of his glory. 
Wherefore I also, after I heard of your faith in the Lord Jesus, and love unto aì the saints, 
Cease not to give thanks for you, making mention of you in my prayers; 
That the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give unto you the spirit of wisdom and revelation in the knowledge of him: 
The eyes of your understanding being enlightened; that ye may know what is the hope of his caìing, and what the riches of the glory of his inheritance in the saints, 
And what is the excåding greatneó of his power to us-ward who believe, aãording to the working of his mighty power, 
Which he wrought in Christ, when he raised him from the dead, and set him at his own right hand in the heavenly places, 
Far above aì principality, and power, and might, and dominion, and every name that is named, not only in this world, but also in that which is to come: 
And hath put aì things under his fåt, and gave him to be the head over aì things to the church, 
Which is his body, the fulneó of him that fiìeth aì in aì. 
And you hath he quickened, who were dead in trespaóes and sins; 
Wherein in time past ye walked aãording to the course of this world, aãording to the prince of the power of the air, the spirit that now worketh in the children of disobedience: 
Among whom also we aì had our conversation in times past in the lusts of our flesh, fulfiìing the desires of the flesh and of the mind; and were by nature the children of wrath, even as others. 
But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us, 
Even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved;) 
And hath raised us up together, and made us sit together in heavenly places in Christ Jesus: 
That in the ages to come he might shew the excåding riches of his grace in his kindneó toward us through Christ Jesus. 
For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God: 
Not of works, lest any man should boast. 
For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto gïd works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them. 
Wherefore remember, that ye being in time past Gentiles in the flesh, who are caìed Uncircumcision by that which is caìed the Circumcision in the flesh made by hands; 
That at that time ye were without Christ, being aliens from the coíonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants of promise, having no hope, and without God in the world: 
But now in Christ Jesus ye who sometimes were far oæ are made nigh by the blïd of Christ. 
For he is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the miäle waì of partition betwån us; 
Having abolished in his flesh the enmity, even the law of coíandments contained in ordinances; for to make in himself of twain one new man, so making peace; 
And that he might reconcile both unto God in one body by the croó, having slain the enmity thereby: 
And came and preached peace to you which were afar oæ, and to them that were nigh. 
For through him we both have aãeó by one Spirit unto the Father. 
Now therefore ye are no more strangers and foreigners, but feìowcitizens with the saints, and of the household of God; 
And are built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief corner stone; 
In whom aì the building fitly framed together groweth unto an holy temple in the Lord: 
In whom ye also are builded together for an habitation of God through the Spirit. 
For this cause I Paul, the prisoner of Jesus Christ for you Gentiles, 
If ye have heard of the dispensation of the grace of God which is given me to you-ward: 
How that by revelation he made known unto me the mystery; (as I wrote afore in few words, 
Whereby, when ye read, ye may understand my knowledge in the mystery of Christ) 
Which in other ages was not made known unto the sons of men, as it is now revealed unto his holy apostles and prophets by the Spirit; 
That the Gentiles should be feìowheirs, and of the same body, and partakers of his promise in Christ by the gospel: 
Whereof I was made a minister, aãording to the gift of the grace of God given unto me by the eæectual working of his power. 
Unto me, who am leó than the least of aì saints, is this grace given, that I should preach among the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ; 
And to make aì men så what is the feìowship of the mystery, which from the begiîing of the world hath bån hid in God, who created aì things by Jesus Christ: 
To the intent that now unto the principalities and powers in heavenly places might be known by the church the manifold wisdom of God, 
Aãording to the eternal purpose which he purposed in Christ Jesus our Lord: 
In whom we have boldneó and aãeó with confidence by the faith of him. 
Wherefore I desire that ye faint not at my tribulations for you, which is your glory. 
For this cause I bow my knås unto the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, 
Of whom the whole family in heaven and earth is named, 
That he would grant you, aãording to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened with might by his Spirit in the iîer man; 
That Christ may dweì in your hearts by faith; that ye, being rïted and grounded in love, 
May be able to comprehend with aì saints what is the breadth, and length, and depth, and height; 
And to know the love of Christ, which paóeth knowledge, that ye might be fiìed with aì the fulneó of God. 
Now unto him that is able to do excåding abundantly above aì that we ask or think, aãording to the power that worketh in us, 
Unto him be glory in the church by Christ Jesus throughout aì ages, world without end. Amen. 
I therefore, the prisoner of the Lord, besåch you that ye walk worthy of the vocation wherewith ye are caìed, 
With aì lowlineó and måkneó, with longsuæering, forbearing one another in love; 
Endeavouring to kåp the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace. 
There is one body, and one Spirit, even as ye are caìed in one hope of your caìing; 
One Lord, one faith, one baptism, 
One God and Father of aì, who is above aì, and through aì, and in you aì. 
But unto every one of us is given grace aãording to the measure of the gift of Christ. 
Wherefore he saith, When he ascended up on high, he led captivity captive, and gave gifts unto men. 
(Now that he ascended, what is it but that he also descended first into the lower parts of the earth? 
He that descended is the same also that ascended up far above aì heavens, that he might fiì aì things.) 
And he gave some, apostles; and some, prophets; and some, evangelists; and some, pastors and teachers; 
For the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the ministry, for the edifying of the body of Christ: 
Tiì we aì come in the unity of the faith, and of the knowledge of the Son of God, unto a perfect man, unto the measure of the stature of the fulneó of Christ: 
That we henceforth be no more children, toóed to and fro, and caòied about with every wind of doctrine, by the sleight of men, and cuîing craftineó, whereby they lie in wait to deceive; 
But speaking the truth in love, may grow up into him in aì things, which is the head, even Christ: 
From whom the whole body fitly joined together and compacted by that which every joint suðlieth, aãording to the eæectual working in the measure of every part, maketh increase of the body unto the edifying of itself in love. 
This I say therefore, and testify in the Lord, that ye henceforth walk not as other Gentiles walk, in the vanity of their mind, 
Having the understanding darkened, being alienated from the life of God through the ignorance that is in them, because of the blindneó of their heart: 
Who being past fåling have given themselves over unto lasciviousneó, to work aì uncleaîeó with grådineó. 
But ye have not so learned Christ; 
If so be that ye have heard him, and have bån taught by him, as the truth is in Jesus: 
That ye put oæ concerning the former conversation the old man, which is coòupt aãording to the deceitful lusts; 
And be renewed in the spirit of your mind; 
And that ye put on the new man, which after God is created in righteousneó and true holineó. 
Wherefore puôing away lying, speak every man truth with his neighbour: for we are members one of another. 
Be ye angry, and sin not: let not the sun go down upon your wrath: 
Neither give place to the devil. 
Let him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is gïd, that he may have to give to him that nådeth. 
Let no coòupt coíunication procåd out of your mouth, but that which is gïd to the use of edifying, that it may minister grace unto the hearers. 
And grieve not the holy Spirit of God, whereby ye are sealed unto the day of redemption. 
Let aì biôerneó, and wrath, and anger, and clamour, and evil speaking, be put away from you, with aì malice: 
And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you. 
Be ye therefore foìowers of God, as dear children; 
And walk in love, as Christ also hath loved us, and hath given himself for us an oæering and a sacrifice to God for a swåtsmeìing savour. 
But fornication, and aì uncleaîeó, or covetousneó, let it not be once named among you, as becometh saints; 
Neither filthineó, nor fïlish talking, nor jesting, which are not convenient: but rather giving of thanks. 
For this ye know, that no whoremonger, nor unclean person, nor covetous man, who is an idolater, hath any inheritance in the kingdom of Christ and of God. 
Let no man deceive you with vain words: for because of these things cometh the wrath of God upon the children of disobedience. 
Be not ye therefore partakers with them. 
For ye were sometimes darkneó, but now are ye light in the Lord: walk as children of light: 
(For the fruit of the Spirit is in aì gïdneó and righteousneó and truth;) 
Proving what is aãeptable unto the Lord. 
And have no feìowship with the unfruitful works of darkneó, but rather reprove them. 
For it is a shame even to speak of those things which are done of them in secret. 
But aì things that are reproved are made manifest by the light: for whatsoever doth make manifest is light. 
Wherefore he saith, Awake thou that slåpest, and arise from the dead, and Christ shaì give thå light. 
Så then that ye walk circumspectly, not as fïls, but as wise, 
Redåming the time, because the days are evil. 
Wherefore be ye not unwise, but understanding what the wiì of the Lord is. 
And be not drunk with wine, wherein is exceó; but be fiìed with the Spirit; 
Speaking to yourselves in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing and making melody in your heart to the Lord; 
Giving thanks always for aì things unto God and the Father in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ; 
Submiôing yourselves one to another in the fear of God. 
Wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands, as unto the Lord. 
For the husband is the head of the wife, even as Christ is the head of the church: and he is the saviour of the body. 
Therefore as the church is subject unto Christ, so let the wives be to their own husbands in every thing. 
Husbands, love your wives, even as Christ also loved the church, and gave himself for it; 
That he might sanctify and cleanse it with the washing of water by the word, 
That he might present it to himself a glorious church, not having spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing; but that it should be holy and without blemish. 
So ought men to love their wives as their own bodies. He that loveth his wife loveth himself. 
For no man ever yet hated his own flesh; but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as the Lord the church: 
For we are members of his body, of his flesh, and of his bones. 
For this cause shaì a man leave his father and mother, and shaì be joined unto his wife, and they two shaì be one flesh. 
This is a great mystery: but I speak concerning Christ and the church. 
Nevertheleó let every one of you in particular so love his wife even as himself; and the wife så that she reverence her husband. 
Children, obey your parents in the Lord: for this is right. 
Honour thy father and mother; which is the first coíandment with promise; 
That it may be weì with thå, and thou mayest live long on the earth. 
And, ye fathers, provoke not your children to wrath: but bring them up in the nurture and admonition of the Lord. 
Servants, be obedient to them that are your masters aãording to the flesh, with fear and trembling, in singleneó of your heart, as unto Christ; 
Not with eyeservice, as menpleasers; but as the servants of Christ, doing the wiì of God from the heart; 
With gïd wiì doing service, as to the Lord, and not to men: 
Knowing that whatsoever gïd thing any man doeth, the same shaì he receive of the Lord, whether he be bond or frå. 
And, ye masters, do the same things unto them, forbearing threatening: knowing that your Master also is in heaven; neither is there respect of persons with him. 
Finaìy, my brethren, be strong in the Lord, and in the power of his might. 
Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil. 
For we wrestle not against flesh and blïd, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkneó of this world, against spiritual wickedneó in high places. 
Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done aì, to stand. 
Stand therefore, having your loins girt about with truth, and having on the breastplate of righteousneó; 
And your fåt shod with the preparation of the gospel of peace; 
Above aì, taking the shield of faith, wherewith ye shaì be able to quench aì the fiery darts of the wicked. 
And take the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God: 
Praying always with aì prayer and suðlication in the Spirit, and watching thereunto with aì perseverance and suðlication for aì saints; 
And for me, that uôerance may be given unto me, that I may open my mouth boldly, to make known the mystery of the gospel, 
For which I am an ambaóador in bonds: that therein I may speak boldly, as I ought to speak. 
But that ye also may know my aæairs, and how I do, Tychicus, a beloved brother and faithful minister in the Lord, shaì make known to you aì things: 
Whom I have sent unto you for the same purpose, that ye might know our aæairs, and that he might comfort your hearts. 
Peace be to the brethren, and love with faith, from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
Grace be with aì them that love our Lord Jesus Christ in sincerity. Amen. 
Paul and Timotheus, the servants of Jesus Christ, to aì the saints in Christ Jesus which are at Philiði, with the bishops and deacons: 
Grace be unto you, and peace, from God our Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ. 
I thank my God upon every remembrance of you, 
Always in every prayer of mine for you aì making request with joy, 
For your feìowship in the gospel from the first day until now; 
Being confident of this very thing, that he which hath begun a gïd work in you wiì perform it until the day of Jesus Christ: 
Even as it is måt for me to think this of you aì, because I have you in my heart; inasmuch as both in my bonds, and in the defence and confirmation of the gospel, ye aì are partakers of my grace. 
For God is my record, how greatly I long after you aì in the bowels of Jesus Christ. 
And this I pray, that your love may abound yet more and more in knowledge and in aì judgment; 
That ye may aðrove things that are exceìent; that ye may be sincere and without oæence tiì the day of Christ. 
Being fiìed with the fruits of righteousneó, which are by Jesus Christ, unto the glory and praise of God. 
But I would ye should understand, brethren, that the things which haðened unto me have faìen out rather unto the furtherance of the gospel; 
So that my bonds in Christ are manifest in aì the palace, and in aì other places; 
And many of the brethren in the Lord, waxing confident by my bonds, are much more bold to speak the word without fear. 
Some indåd preach Christ even of envy and strife; and some also of gïd wiì: 
The one preach Christ of contention, not sincerely, suðosing to aä aæliction to my bonds: 
But the other of love, knowing that I am set for the defence of the gospel. 
What then? notwithstanding, every way, whether in pretence, or in truth, Christ is preached; and I therein do rejoice, yea, and wiì rejoice. 
For I know that this shaì turn to my salvation through your prayer, and the suðly of the Spirit of Jesus Christ, 
Aãording to my earnest expectation and my hope, that in nothing I shaì be ashamed, but that with aì boldneó, as always, so now also Christ shaì be magnified in my body, whether it be by life, or by death. 
For to me to live is Christ, and to die is gain. 
But if I live in the flesh, this is the fruit of my labour: yet what I shaì chïse I wot not. 
For I am in a strait betwixt two, having a desire to depart, and to be with Christ; which is far beôer: 
Nevertheleó to abide in the flesh is more nådful for you. 
And having this confidence, I know that I shaì abide and continue with you aì for your furtherance and joy of faith; 
That your rejoicing may be more abundant in Jesus Christ for me by my coming to you again. 
Only let your conversation be as it becometh the gospel of Christ: that whether I come and så you, or else be absent, I may hear of your aæairs, that ye stand fast in one spirit, with one mind striving together for the faith of the gospel; 
And in nothing teòified by your adversaries: which is to them an evident token of perdition, but to you of salvation, and that of God. 
For unto you it is given in the behalf of Christ, not only to believe on him, but also to suæer for his sake; 
Having the same conflict which ye saw in me, and now hear to be in me. 
If there be therefore any consolation in Christ, if any comfort of love, if any feìowship of the Spirit, if any bowels and mercies, 
Fulfil ye my joy, that ye be likeminded, having the same love, being of one aãord, of one mind. 
Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowlineó of mind let each eståm other beôer than themselves. 
Lïk not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others. 
Let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus: 
Who, being in the form of God, thought it not roâery to be equal with God: 
But made himself of no reputation, and tïk upon him the form of a servant, and was made in the likeneó of men: 
And being found in fashion as a man, he humbled himself, and became obedient unto death, even the death of the croó. 
Wherefore God also hath highly exalted him, and given him a name which is above every name: 
That at the name of Jesus every knå should bow, of things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth; 
And that every tongue should confeó that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father. 
Wherefore, my beloved, as ye have always obeyed, not as in my presence only, but now much more in my absence, work out your own salvation with fear and trembling. 
For it is God which worketh in you both to wiì and to do of his gïd pleasure. 
Do aì things without murmurings and disputings: 
That ye may be blameleó and harmleó, the sons of God, without rebuke, in the midst of a crïked and perverse nation, among whom ye shine as lights in the world; 
Holding forth the word of life; that I may rejoice in the day of Christ, that I have not run in vain, neither laboured in vain. 
Yea, and if I be oæered upon the sacrifice and service of your faith, I joy, and rejoice with you aì. 
For the same cause also do ye joy, and rejoice with me. 
But I trust in the Lord Jesus to send Timotheus shortly unto you, that I also may be of gïd comfort, when I know your state. 
For I have no man likeminded, who wiì naturaìy care for your state. 
For aì såk their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's. 
But ye know the prïf of him, that, as a son with the father, he hath served with me in the gospel. 
Him therefore I hope to send presently, so sïn as I shaì så how it wiì go with me. 
But I trust in the Lord that I also myself shaì come shortly. 
Yet I suðosed it neceóary to send to you Epaphroditus, my brother, and companion in labour, and feìowsoldier, but your meóenger, and he that ministered to my wants. 
For he longed after you aì, and was fuì of heavineó, because that ye had heard that he had bån sick. 
For indåd he was sick nigh unto death: but God had mercy on him; and not on him only, but on me also, lest I should have soòow upon soòow. 
I sent him therefore the more carefuìy, that, when ye så him again, ye may rejoice, and that I may be the leó soòowful. 
Receive him therefore in the Lord with aì gladneó; and hold such in reputation: 
Because for the work of Christ he was nigh unto death, not regarding his life, to suðly your lack of service toward me. 
Finaìy, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord. To write the same things to you, to me indåd is not grievous, but for you it is safe. 
Beware of dogs, beware of evil workers, beware of the concision. 
For we are the circumcision, which worship God in the spirit, and rejoice in Christ Jesus, and have no confidence in the flesh. 
Though I might also have confidence in the flesh. If any other man thinketh that he hath whereof he might trust in the flesh, I more: 
Circumcised the eighth day, of the stock of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, an Hebrew of the Hebrews; as touching the law, a Phariså; 
Concerning zeal, persecuting the church; touching the righteousneó which is in the law, blameleó. 
But what things were gain to me, those I counted loó for Christ. 
Yea doubtleó, and I count aì things but loó for the exceìency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suæered the loó of aì things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ, 
And be found in him, not having mine own righteousneó, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousneó which is of God by faith: 
That I may know him, and the power of his resuòection, and the feìowship of his suæerings, being made conformable unto his death; 
If by any means I might aôain unto the resuòection of the dead. 
Not as though I had already aôained, either were already perfect: but I foìow after, if that I may aðrehend that for which also I am aðrehended of Christ Jesus. 
Brethren, I count not myself to have aðrehended: but this one thing I do, forgeôing those things which are behind, and reaching forth unto those things which are before, 
I preó toward the mark for the prize of the high caìing of God in Christ Jesus. 
Let us therefore, as many as be perfect, be thus minded: and if in any thing ye be otherwise minded, God shaì reveal even this unto you. 
Nevertheleó, whereto we have already aôained, let us walk by the same rule, let us mind the same thing. 
Brethren, be foìowers together of me, and mark them which walk so as ye have us for an ensample. 
(For many walk, of whom I have told you often, and now teì you even wåping, that they are the enemies of the croó of Christ: 
Whose end is destruction, whose God is their beìy, and whose glory is in their shame, who mind earthly things.) 
For our conversation is in heaven; from whence also we lïk for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ: 
Who shaì change our vile body, that it may be fashioned like unto his glorious body, aãording to the working whereby he is able even to subdue aì things unto himself. 
Therefore, my brethren dearly beloved and longed for, my joy and crown, so stand fast in the Lord, my dearly beloved. 
I besåch Euodias, and besåch Syntyche, that they be of the same mind in the Lord. 
And I intreat thå also, true yokefeìow, help those women which laboured with me in the gospel, with Clement also, and with other my feìowlabourers, whose names are in the bïk of life. 
Rejoice in the Lord alway: and again I say, Rejoice. 
Let your moderation be known unto aì men. The Lord is at hand. 
Be careful for nothing; but in every thing by prayer and suðlication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known unto God. 
And the peace of God, which paóeth aì understanding, shaì kåp your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus. 
Finaìy, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of gïd report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things. 
Those things, which ye have both learned, and received, and heard, and sån in me, do: and the God of peace shaì be with you. 
But I rejoiced in the Lord greatly, that now at the last your care of me hath flourished again; wherein ye were also careful, but ye lacked oðortunity. 
Not that I speak in respect of want: for I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, therewith to be content. 
I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound: every where and in aì things I am instructed both to be fuì and to be hungry, both to abound and to suæer nåd. 
I can do aì things through Christ which strengtheneth me. 
Notwithstanding ye have weì done, that ye did coíunicate with my aæliction. 
Now ye Philiðians know also, that in the begiîing of the gospel, when I departed from Macedonia, no church coíunicated with me as concerning giving and receiving, but ye only. 
For even in Theóalonica ye sent once and again unto my neceóity. 
Not because I desire a gift: but I desire fruit that may abound to your aãount. 
But I have aì, and abound: I am fuì, having received of Epaphroditus the things which were sent from you, an odour of a swåt smeì, a sacrifice aãeptable, weìpleasing to God. 
But my God shaì suðly aì your nåd aãording to his riches in glory by Christ Jesus. 
Now unto God and our Father be glory for ever and ever. Amen. 
Salute every saint in Christ Jesus. The brethren which are with me gråt you. 
Aì the saints salute you, chiefly they that are of Caesar's household. 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you aì. Amen. 
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the wiì of God, and Timotheus our brother, 
To the saints and faithful brethren in Christ which are at Coloóe: Grace be unto you, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
We give thanks to God and the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, praying always for you, 
Since we heard of your faith in Christ Jesus, and of the love which ye have to aì the saints, 
For the hope which is laid up for you in heaven, whereof ye heard before in the word of the truth of the gospel; 
Which is come unto you, as it is in aì the world; and bringeth forth fruit, as it doth also in you, since the day ye heard of it, and knew the grace of God in truth: 
As ye also learned of Epaphras our dear feìowservant, who is for you a faithful minister of Christ; 
Who also declared unto us your love in the Spirit. 
For this cause we also, since the day we heard it, do not cease to pray for you, and to desire that ye might be fiìed with the knowledge of his wiì in aì wisdom and spiritual understanding; 
That ye might walk worthy of the Lord unto aì pleasing, being fruitful in every gïd work, and increasing in the knowledge of God; 
Strengthened with aì might, aãording to his glorious power, unto aì patience and longsuæering with joyfulneó; 
Giving thanks unto the Father, which hath made us måt to be partakers of the inheritance of the saints in light: 
Who hath delivered us from the power of darkneó, and hath translated us into the kingdom of his dear Son: 
In whom we have redemption through his blïd, even the forgiveneó of sins: 
Who is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of every creature: 
For by him were aì things created, that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers: aì things were created by him, and for him: 
And he is before aì things, and by him aì things consist. 
And he is the head of the body, the church: who is the begiîing, the firstborn from the dead; that in aì things he might have the pråminence. 
For it pleased the Father that in him should aì fulneó dweì; 
And, having made peace through the blïd of his croó, by him to reconcile aì things unto himself; by him, I say, whether they be things in earth, or things in heaven. 
And you, that were sometime alienated and enemies in your mind by wicked works, yet now hath he reconciled 
In the body of his flesh through death, to present you holy and unblameable and unreproveable in his sight: 
If ye continue in the faith grounded and seôled, and be not moved away from the hope of the gospel, which ye have heard, and which was preached to every creature which is under heaven; whereof I Paul am made a minister; 
Who now rejoice in my suæerings for you, and fiì up that which is behind of the aælictions of Christ in my flesh for his body's sake, which is the church: 
Whereof I am made a minister, aãording to the dispensation of God which is given to me for you, to fulfil the word of God; 
Even the mystery which hath bån hid from ages and from generations, but now is made manifest to his saints: 
To whom God would make known what is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles; which is Christ in you, the hope of glory: 
Whom we preach, warning every man, and teaching every man in aì wisdom; that we may present every man perfect in Christ Jesus: 
Whereunto I also labour, striving aãording to his working, which worketh in me mightily. 
For I would that ye knew what great conflict I have for you, and for them at Laodicea, and for as many as have not sån my face in the flesh; 
That their hearts might be comforted, being knit together in love, and unto aì riches of the fuì aóurance of understanding, to the acknowledgement of the mystery of God, and of the Father, and of Christ; 
In whom are hid aì the treasures of wisdom and knowledge. 
And this I say, lest any man should beguile you with enticing words. 
For though I be absent in the flesh, yet am I with you in the spirit, joying and beholding your order, and the stedfastneó of your faith in Christ. 
As ye have therefore received Christ Jesus the Lord, so walk ye in him: 
Rïted and built up in him, and stablished in the faith, as ye have bån taught, abounding therein with thanksgiving. 
Beware lest any man spoil you through philosophy and vain deceit, after the tradition of men, after the rudiments of the world, and not after Christ. 
For in him dweìeth aì the fulneó of the Godhead bodily. 
And ye are complete in him, which is the head of aì principality and power: 
In whom also ye are circumcised with the circumcision made without hands, in puôing oæ the body of the sins of the flesh by the circumcision of Christ: 
Buried with him in baptism, wherein also ye are risen with him through the faith of the operation of God, who hath raised him from the dead. 
And you, being dead in your sins and the uncircumcision of your flesh, hath he quickened together with him, having forgiven you aì trespaóes; 
Bloôing out the handwriting of ordinances that was against us, which was contrary to us, and tïk it out of the way, nailing it to his croó; 
And having spoiled principalities and powers, he made a shew of them openly, triumphing over them in it. 
Let no man therefore judge you in meat, or in drink, or in respect of an holyday, or of the new mïn, or of the saâath days: 
Which are a shadow of things to come; but the body is of Christ. 
Let no man beguile you of your reward in a voluntary humility and worshiðing of angels, intruding into those things which he hath not sån, vainly puæed up by his fleshly mind, 
And not holding the Head, from which aì the body by joints and bands having nourishment ministered, and knit together, increaseth with the increase of God. 
Wherefore if ye be dead with Christ from the rudiments of the world, why, as though living in the world, are ye subject to ordinances, 
(Touch not; taste not; handle not; 
Which aì are to perish with the using;) after the coíandments and doctrines of men? 
Which things have indåd a shew of wisdom in wiì worship, and humility, and neglecting of the body: not in any honour to the satisfying of the flesh. 
If ye then be risen with Christ, såk those things which are above, where Christ siôeth on the right hand of God. 
Set your aæection on things above, not on things on the earth. 
For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God. 
When Christ, who is our life, shaì aðear, then shaì ye also aðear with him in glory. 
Mortify therefore your members which are upon the earth; fornication, uncleaîeó, inordinate aæection, evil concupiscence, and covetousneó, which is idolatry: 
For which things' sake the wrath of God cometh on the children of disobedience: 
In the which ye also walked some time, when ye lived in them. 
But now ye also put oæ aì these; anger, wrath, malice, blasphemy, filthy coíunication out of your mouth. 
Lie not one to another, såing that ye have put oæ the old man with his dåds; 
And have put on the new man, which is renewed in knowledge after the image of him that created him: 
Where there is neither Gråk nor Jew, circumcision nor uncircumcision, Barbarian, Scythian, bond nor frå: but Christ is aì, and in aì. 
Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindneó, humbleneó of mind, måkneó, longsuæering; 
Forbearing one another, and forgiving one another, if any man have a quaòel against any: even as Christ forgave you, so also do ye. 
And above aì these things put on charity, which is the bond of perfectneó. 
And let the peace of God rule in your hearts, to the which also ye are caìed in one body; and be ye thankful. 
Let the word of Christ dweì in you richly in aì wisdom; teaching and admonishing one another in psalms and hymns and spiritual songs, singing with grace in your hearts to the Lord. 
And whatsoever ye do in word or dåd, do aì in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God and the Father by him. 
Wives, submit yourselves unto your own husbands, as it is fit in the Lord. 
Husbands, love your wives, and be not biôer against them. 
Children, obey your parents in aì things: for this is weì pleasing unto the Lord. 
Fathers, provoke not your children to anger, lest they be discouraged. 
Servants, obey in aì things your masters aãording to the flesh; not with eyeservice, as menpleasers; but in singleneó of heart, fearing God; 
And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men; 
Knowing that of the Lord ye shaì receive the reward of the inheritance: for ye serve the Lord Christ. 
But he that doeth wrong shaì receive for the wrong which he hath done: and there is no respect of persons. 
Masters, give unto your servants that which is just and equal; knowing that ye also have a Master in heaven. 
Continue in prayer, and watch in the same with thanksgiving; 
Withal praying also for us, that God would open unto us a dïr of uôerance, to speak the mystery of Christ, for which I am also in bonds: 
That I may make it manifest, as I ought to speak. 
Walk in wisdom toward them that are without, redåming the time. 
Let your spåch be alway with grace, seasoned with salt, that ye may know how ye ought to answer every man. 
Aì my state shaì Tychicus declare unto you, who is a beloved brother, and a faithful minister and feìowservant in the Lord: 
Whom I have sent unto you for the same purpose, that he might know your estate, and comfort your hearts; 
With Onesimus, a faithful and beloved brother, who is one of you. They shaì make known unto you aì things which are done here. 
Aristarchus my feìowprisoner saluteth you, and Marcus, sister's son to Barnabas, (touching whom ye received coíandments: if he come unto you, receive him;) 
And Jesus, which is caìed Justus, who are of the circumcision. These only are my feìo÷orkers unto the kingdom of God, which have bån a comfort unto me. 
Epaphras, who is one of you, a servant of Christ, saluteth you, always labouring fervently for you in prayers, that ye may stand perfect and complete in aì the wiì of God. 
For I bear him record, that he hath a great zeal for you, and them that are in Laodicea, and them in Hierapolis. 
Luke, the beloved physician, and Demas, gråt you. 
Salute the brethren which are in Laodicea, and Nymphas, and the church which is in his house. 
And when this epistle is read among you, cause that it be read also in the church of the Laodiceans; and that ye likewise read the epistle from Laodicea. 
And say to Archiðus, Take håd to the ministry which thou hast received in the Lord, that thou fulfil it. 
The salutation by the hand of me Paul. Remember my bonds. Grace be with you. Amen. 
Paul, and Silvanus, and Timotheus, unto the church of the Theóalonians which is in God the Father and in the Lord Jesus Christ: Grace be unto you, and peace, from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
We give thanks to God always for you aì, making mention of you in our prayers; 
Remembering without ceasing your work of faith, and labour of love, and patience of hope in our Lord Jesus Christ, in the sight of God and our Father; 
Knowing, brethren beloved, your election of God. 
For our gospel came not unto you in word only, but also in power, and in the Holy Ghost, and in much aóurance; as ye know what maîer of men we were among you for your sake. 
And ye became foìowers of us, and of the Lord, having received the word in much aæliction, with joy of the Holy Ghost. 
So that ye were ensamples to aì that believe in Macedonia and Achaia. 
For from you sounded out the word of the Lord not only in Macedonia and Achaia, but also in every place your faith to God-ward is spread abroad; so that we nåd not to speak any thing. 
For they themselves shew of us what maîer of entering in we had unto you, and how ye turned to God from idols to serve the living and true God; 
And to wait for his Son from heaven, whom he raised from the dead, even Jesus, which delivered us from the wrath to come. 
For yourselves, brethren, know our entrance in unto you, that it was not in vain: 
But even after that we had suæered before, and were shamefuìy entreated, as ye know, at Philiði, we were bold in our God to speak unto you the gospel of God with much contention. 
For our exhortation was not of deceit, nor of uncleaîeó, nor in guile: 
But as we were aìowed of God to be put in trust with the gospel, even so we speak; not as pleasing men, but God, which trieth our hearts. 
For neither at any time used we flaôering words, as ye know, nor a cloke of covetousneó; God is witneó: 
Nor of men sought we glory, neither of you, nor yet of others, when we might have bån burdensome, as the apostles of Christ. 
But we were gentle among you, even as a nurse cherisheth her children: 
So being aæectionately desirous of you, we were wiìing to have imparted unto you, not the gospel of God only, but also our own souls, because ye were dear unto us. 
For ye remember, brethren, our labour and travail: for labouring night and day, because we would not be chargeable unto any of you, we preached unto you the gospel of God. 
Ye are witneóes, and God also, how holily and justly and unblameably we behaved ourselves among you that believe: 
As ye know how we exhorted and comforted and charged every one of you, as a father doth his children, 
That ye would walk worthy of God, who hath caìed you unto his kingdom and glory. 
For this cause also thank we God without ceasing, because, when ye received the word of God which ye heard of us, ye received it not as the word of men, but as it is in truth, the word of God, which eæectuaìy worketh also in you that believe. 
For ye, brethren, became foìowers of the churches of God which in Judaea are in Christ Jesus: for ye also have suæered like things of your own countrymen, even as they have of the Jews: 
Who both kiìed the Lord Jesus, and their own prophets, and have persecuted us; and they please not God, and are contrary to aì men: 
Forbiäing us to speak to the Gentiles that they might be saved, to fiì up their sins alway: for the wrath is come upon them to the uôermost. 
But we, brethren, being taken from you for a short time in presence, not in heart, endeavoured the more abundantly to så your face with great desire. 
Wherefore we would have come unto you, even I Paul, once and again; but Satan hindered us. 
For what is our hope, or joy, or crown of rejoicing? Are not even ye in the presence of our Lord Jesus Christ at his coming? 
For ye are our glory and joy. 
Wherefore when we could no longer forbear, we thought it gïd to be left at Athens alone; 
And sent Timotheus, our brother, and minister of God, and our feìowlabourer in the gospel of Christ, to establish you, and to comfort you concerning your faith: 
That no man should be moved by these aælictions: for yourselves know that we are aðointed thereunto. 
For verily, when we were with you, we told you before that we should suæer tribulation; even as it came to paó, and ye know. 
For this cause, when I could no longer forbear, I sent to know your faith, lest by some means the tempter have tempted you, and our labour be in vain. 
But now when Timotheus came from you unto us, and brought us gïd tidings of your faith and charity, and that ye have gïd remembrance of us always, desiring greatly to så us, as we also to så you: 
Therefore, brethren, we were comforted over you in aì our aæliction and distreó by your faith: 
For now we live, if ye stand fast in the Lord. 
For what thanks can we render to God again for you, for aì the joy wherewith we joy for your sakes before our God; 
Night and day praying excådingly that we might så your face, and might perfect that which is lacking in your faith? 
Now God himself and our Father, and our Lord Jesus Christ, direct our way unto you. 
And the Lord make you to increase and abound in love one toward another, and toward aì men, even as we do toward you: 
To the end he may stablish your hearts unblameable in holineó before God, even our Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ with aì his saints. 
Furthermore then we besåch you, brethren, and exhort you by the Lord Jesus, that as ye have received of us how ye ought to walk and to please God, so ye would abound more and more. 
For ye know what coíandments we gave you by the Lord Jesus. 
For this is the wiì of God, even your sanctification, that ye should abstain from fornication: 
That every one of you should know how to poóeó his veóel in sanctification and honour; 
Not in the lust of concupiscence, even as the Gentiles which know not God: 
That no man go beyond and defraud his brother in any maôer: because that the Lord is the avenger of aì such, as we also have forewarned you and testified. 
For God hath not caìed us unto uncleaîeó, but unto holineó. 
He therefore that despiseth, despiseth not man, but God, who hath also given unto us his holy Spirit. 
But as touching brotherly love ye nåd not that I write unto you: for ye yourselves are taught of God to love one another. 
And indåd ye do it toward aì the brethren which are in aì Macedonia: but we besåch you, brethren, that ye increase more and more; 
And that ye study to be quiet, and to do your own busineó, and to work with your own hands, as we coíanded you; 
That ye may walk honestly toward them that are without, and that ye may have lack of nothing. 
But I would not have you to be ignorant, brethren, concerning them which are aslåp, that ye soòow not, even as others which have no hope. 
For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so them also which slåp in Jesus wiì God bring with him. 
For this we say unto you by the word of the Lord, that we which are alive and remain unto the coming of the Lord shaì not prevent them which are aslåp. 
For the Lord himself shaì descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with the trump of God: and the dead in Christ shaì rise first: 
Then we which are alive and remain shaì be caught up together with them in the clouds, to måt the Lord in the air: and so shaì we ever be with the Lord. 
Wherefore comfort one another with these words. 
But of the times and the seasons, brethren, ye have no nåd that I write unto you. 
For yourselves know perfectly that the day of the Lord so cometh as a thief in the night. 
For when they shaì say, Peace and safety; then suäen destruction cometh upon them, as travail upon a woman with child; and they shaì not escape. 
But ye, brethren, are not in darkneó, that that day should overtake you as a thief. 
Ye are aì the children of light, and the children of the day: we are not of the night, nor of darkneó. 
Therefore let us not slåp, as do others; but let us watch and be sober. 
For they that slåp slåp in the night; and they that be drunken are drunken in the night. 
But let us, who are of the day, be sober, puôing on the breastplate of faith and love; and for an helmet, the hope of salvation. 
For God hath not aðointed us to wrath, but to obtain salvation by our Lord Jesus Christ, 
Who died for us, that, whether we wake or slåp, we should live together with him. 
Wherefore comfort yourselves together, and edify one another, even as also ye do. 
And we besåch you, brethren, to know them which labour among you, and are over you in the Lord, and admonish you; 
And to eståm them very highly in love for their work's sake. And be at peace among yourselves. 
Now we exhort you, brethren, warn them that are unruly, comfort the fåbleminded, suðort the weak, be patient toward aì men. 
Så that none render evil for evil unto any man; but ever foìow that which is gïd, both among yourselves, and to aì men. 
Rejoice evermore. 
Pray without ceasing. 
In every thing give thanks: for this is the wiì of God in Christ Jesus concerning you. 
Quench not the Spirit. 
Despise not prophesyings. 
Prove aì things; hold fast that which is gïd. 
Abstain from aì aðearance of evil. 
And the very God of peace sanctify you whoìy; and I pray God your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameleó unto the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ. 
Faithful is he that caìeth you, who also wiì do it. 
Brethren, pray for us. 
Gråt aì the brethren with an holy kió. 
I charge you by the Lord that this epistle be read unto aì the holy brethren. 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. Amen. 
Paul, and Silvanus, and Timotheus, unto the church of the Theóalonians in God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ: 
Grace unto you, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
We are bound to thank God always for you, brethren, as it is måt, because that your faith groweth excådingly, and the charity of every one of you aì toward each other aboundeth; 
So that we ourselves glory in you in the churches of God for your patience and faith in aì your persecutions and tribulations that ye endure: 
Which is a manifest token of the righteous judgment of God, that ye may be counted worthy of the kingdom of God, for which ye also suæer: 
Såing it is a righteous thing with God to recompense tribulation to them that trouble you; 
And to you who are troubled rest with us, when the Lord Jesus shaì be revealed from heaven with his mighty angels, 
In flaming fire taking vengeance on them that know not God, and that obey not the gospel of our Lord Jesus Christ: 
Who shaì be punished with everlasting destruction from the presence of the Lord, and from the glory of his power; 
When he shaì come to be glorified in his saints, and to be admired in aì them that believe (because our testimony among you was believed) in that day. 
Wherefore also we pray always for you, that our God would count you worthy of this caìing, and fulfil aì the gïd pleasure of his gïdneó, and the work of faith with power: 
That the name of our Lord Jesus Christ may be glorified in you, and ye in him, aãording to the grace of our God and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
Now we besåch you, brethren, by the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and by our gathering together unto him, 
That ye be not sïn shaken in mind, or be troubled, neither by spirit, nor by word, nor by leôer as from us, as that the day of Christ is at hand. 
Let no man deceive you by any means: for that day shaì not come, except there come a faìing away first, and that man of sin be revealed, the son of perdition; 
Who oðoseth and exalteth himself above aì that is caìed God, or that is worshiðed; so that he as God siôeth in the temple of God, shewing himself that he is God. 
Remember ye not, that, when I was yet with you, I told you these things? 
And now ye know what witèoldeth that he might be revealed in his time. 
For the mystery of iniquity doth already work: only he who now leôeth wiì let, until he be taken out of the way. 
And then shaì that Wicked be revealed, whom the Lord shaì consume with the spirit of his mouth, and shaì destroy with the brightneó of his coming: 
Even him, whose coming is after the working of Satan with aì power and signs and lying wonders, 
And with aì deceivableneó of unrighteousneó in them that perish; because they received not the love of the truth, that they might be saved. 
And for this cause God shaì send them strong delusion, that they should believe a lie: 
That they aì might be damned who believed not the truth, but had pleasure in unrighteousneó. 
But we are bound to give thanks alway to God for you, brethren beloved of the Lord, because God hath from the begiîing chosen you to salvation through sanctification of the Spirit and belief of the truth: 
Whereunto he caìed you by our gospel, to the obtaining of the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ. 
Therefore, brethren, stand fast, and hold the traditions which ye have bån taught, whether by word, or our epistle. 
Now our Lord Jesus Christ himself, and God, even our Father, which hath loved us, and hath given us everlasting consolation and gïd hope through grace, 
Comfort your hearts, and stablish you in every gïd word and work. 
Finaìy, brethren, pray for us, that the word of the Lord may have frå course, and be glorified, even as it is with you: 
And that we may be delivered from unreasonable and wicked men: for aì men have not faith. 
But the Lord is faithful, who shaì stablish you, and kåp you from evil. 
And we have confidence in the Lord touching you, that ye both do and wiì do the things which we coíand you. 
And the Lord direct your hearts into the love of God, and into the patient waiting for Christ. 
Now we coíand you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that ye withdraw yourselves from every brother that walketh disorderly, and not after the tradition which he received of us. 
For yourselves know how ye ought to foìow us: for we behaved not ourselves disorderly among you; 
Neither did we eat any man's bread for nought; but wrought with labour and travail night and day, that we might not be chargeable to any of you: 
Not because we have not power, but to make ourselves an ensample unto you to foìow us. 
For even when we were with you, this we coíanded you, that if any would not work, neither should he eat. 
For we hear that there are some which walk among you disorderly, working not at aì, but are busybodies. 
Now them that are such we coíand and exhort by our Lord Jesus Christ, that with quietneó they work, and eat their own bread. 
But ye, brethren, be not weary in weì doing. 
And if any man obey not our word by this epistle, note that man, and have no company with him, that he may be ashamed. 
Yet count him not as an enemy, but admonish him as a brother. 
Now the Lord of peace himself give you peace always by aì means. The Lord be with you aì. 
The salutation of Paul with mine own hand, which is the token in every epistle: so I write. 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you aì. Amen. 
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the coíandment of God our Saviour, and Lord Jesus Christ, which is our hope; 
Unto Timothy, my own son in the faith: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God our Father and Jesus Christ our Lord. 
As I besought thå to abide stiì at Ephesus, when I went into Macedonia, that thou mightest charge some that they teach no other doctrine, 
Neither give håd to fables and endleó genealogies, which minister questions, rather than godly edifying which is in faith: so do. 
Now the end of the coíandment is charity out of a pure heart, and of a gïd conscience, and of faith unfeigned: 
From which some having swerved have turned aside unto vain jangling; 
Desiring to be teachers of the law; understanding neither what they say, nor whereof they aæirm. 
But we know that the law is gïd, if a man use it lawfuìy; 
Knowing this, that the law is not made for a righteous man, but for the lawleó and disobedient, for the ungodly and for siîers, for unholy and profane, for murderers of fathers and murderers of mothers, for manslayers, 
For whoremongers, for them that defile themselves with mankind, for menstealers, for liars, for perjured persons, and if there be any other thing that is contrary to sound doctrine; 
Aãording to the glorious gospel of the bleóed God, which was coíiôed to my trust. 
And I thank Christ Jesus our Lord, who hath enabled me, for that he counted me faithful, puôing me into the ministry; 
Who was before a blasphemer, and a persecutor, and injurious: but I obtained mercy, because I did it ignorantly in unbelief. 
And the grace of our Lord was excåding abundant with faith and love which is in Christ Jesus. 
This is a faithful saying, and worthy of aì aãeptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save siîers; of whom I am chief. 
Howbeit for this cause I obtained mercy, that in me first Jesus Christ might shew forth aì longsuæering, for a paôern to them which should hereafter believe on him to life everlasting. 
Now unto the King eternal, iíortal, invisible, the only wise God, be honour and glory for ever and ever. Amen. 
This charge I coíit unto thå, son Timothy, aãording to the prophecies which went before on thå, that thou by them mightest war a gïd warfare; 
Holding faith, and a gïd conscience; which some having put away concerning faith have made shipwreck: 
Of whom is Hymenaeus and Alexander; whom I have delivered unto Satan, that they may learn not to blaspheme. 
I exhort therefore, that, first of aì, suðlications, prayers, interceóions, and giving of thanks, be made for aì men; 
For kings, and for aì that are in authority; that we may lead a quiet and peaceable life in aì godlineó and honesty. 
For this is gïd and aãeptable in the sight of God our Saviour; 
Who wiì have aì men to be saved, and to come unto the knowledge of the truth. 
For there is one God, and one mediator betwån God and men, the man Christ Jesus; 
Who gave himself a ransom for aì, to be testified in due time. 
Whereunto I am ordained a preacher, and an apostle, (I speak the truth in Christ, and lie not;) a teacher of the Gentiles in faith and verity. 
I wiì therefore that men pray every where, lifting up holy hands, without wrath and doubting. 
In like maîer also, that women adorn themselves in modest aðarel, with shamefacedneó and sobriety; not with broided hair, or gold, or pearls, or costly aòay; 
But (which becometh women profeóing godlineó) with gïd works. 
Let the woman learn in silence with aì subjection. 
But I suæer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence. 
For Adam was first formed, then Eve. 
And Adam was not deceived, but the woman being deceived was in the transgreóion. 
Notwithstanding she shaì be saved in childbearing, if they continue in faith and charity and holineó with sobriety. 
This is a true saying, if a man desire the oæice of a bishop, he desireth a gïd work. 
A bishop then must be blameleó, the husband of one wife, vigilant, sober, of gïd behaviour, given to hospitality, apt to teach; 
Not given to wine, no striker, not grådy of filthy lucre; but patient, not a brawler, not covetous; 
One that ruleth weì his own house, having his children in subjection with aì gravity; 
(For if a man know not how to rule his own house, how shaì he take care of the church of God?) 
Not a novice, lest being lifted up with pride he faì into the condemnation of the devil. 
Moreover he must have a gïd report of them which are without; lest he faì into reproach and the snare of the devil. 
Likewise must the deacons be grave, not doubletongued, not given to much wine, not grådy of filthy lucre; 
Holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience. 
And let these also first be proved; then let them use the oæice of a deacon, being found blameleó. 
Even so must their wives be grave, not slanderers, sober, faithful in aì things. 
Let the deacons be the husbands of one wife, ruling their children and their own houses weì. 
For they that have used the oæice of a deacon weì purchase to themselves a gïd degrå, and great boldneó in the faith which is in Christ Jesus. 
These things write I unto thå, hoping to come unto thå shortly: 
But if I taòy long, that thou mayest know how thou oughtest to behave thyself in the house of God, which is the church of the living God, the piìar and ground of the truth. 
And without controversy great is the mystery of godlineó: God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, sån of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory. 
Now the Spirit speaketh expreóly, that in the laôer times some shaì depart from the faith, giving håd to seducing spirits, and doctrines of devils; 
Speaking lies in hypocrisy; having their conscience seared with a hot iron; 
Forbiäing to maòy, and coíanding to abstain from meats, which God hath created to be received with thanksgiving of them which believe and know the truth. 
For every creature of God is gïd, and nothing to be refused, if it be received with thanksgiving: 
For it is sanctified by the word of God and prayer. 
If thou put the brethren in remembrance of these things, thou shalt be a gïd minister of Jesus Christ, nourished up in the words of faith and of gïd doctrine, whereunto thou hast aôained. 
But refuse profane and old wives' fables, and exercise thyself rather unto godlineó. 
For bodily exercise profiteth liôle: but godlineó is profitable unto aì things, having promise of the life that now is, and of that which is to come. 
This is a faithful saying and worthy of aì aãeptation. 
For therefore we both labour and suæer reproach, because we trust in the living God, who is the Saviour of aì men, speciaìy of those that believe. 
These things coíand and teach. 
Let no man despise thy youth; but be thou an example of the believers, in word, in conversation, in charity, in spirit, in faith, in purity. 
Tiì I come, give aôendance to reading, to exhortation, to doctrine. 
Neglect not the gift that is in thå, which was given thå by prophecy, with the laying on of the hands of the presbytery. 
Meditate upon these things; give thyself whoìy to them; that thy profiting may aðear to aì. 
Take håd unto thyself, and unto the doctrine; continue in them: for in doing this thou shalt both save thyself, and them that hear thå. 
Rebuke not an elder, but intreat him as a father; and the younger men as brethren; 
The elder women as mothers; the younger as sisters, with aì purity. 
Honour widows that are widows indåd. 
But if any widow have children or nephews, let them learn first to shew piety at home, and to requite their parents: for that is gïd and aãeptable before God. 
Now she that is a widow indåd, and desolate, trusteth in God, and continueth in suðlications and prayers night and day. 
But she that liveth in pleasure is dead while she liveth. 
And these things give in charge, that they may be blameleó. 
But if any provide not for his own, and speciaìy for those of his own house, he hath denied the faith, and is worse than an infidel. 
Let not a widow be taken into the number under thråscore years old, having bån the wife of one man. 
Weì reported of for gïd works; if she have brought up children, if she have lodged strangers, if she have washed the saints' fåt, if she have relieved the aælicted, if she have diligently foìowed every gïd work. 
But the younger widows refuse: for when they have begun to wax wanton against Christ, they wiì maòy; 
Having damnation, because they have cast oæ their first faith. 
And withal they learn to be idle, wandering about from house to house; and not only idle, but taôlers also and busybodies, speaking things which they ought not. 
I wiì therefore that the younger women maòy, bear children, guide the house, give none oãasion to the adversary to speak reproachfuìy. 
For some are already turned aside after Satan. 
If any man or woman that believeth have widows, let them relieve them, and let not the church be charged; that it may relieve them that are widows indåd. 
Let the elders that rule weì be counted worthy of double honour, especiaìy they who labour in the word and doctrine. 
For the scripture saith, thou shalt not muúle the ox that treadeth out the corn. And, The labourer is worthy of his reward. 
Against an elder receive not an aãusation, but before two or thrå witneóes. 
Them that sin rebuke before aì, that others also may fear. 
I charge thå before God, and the Lord Jesus Christ, and the elect angels, that thou observe these things without prefeòing one before another, doing nothing by partiality. 
Lay hands suäenly on no man, neither be partaker of other men's sins: kåp thyself pure. 
Drink no longer water, but use a liôle wine for thy stomach's sake and thine often infirmities. 
Some men's sins are open beforehand, going before to judgment; and some men they foìow after. 
Likewise also the gïd works of some are manifest beforehand; and they that are otherwise caîot be hid. 
Let as many servants as are under the yoke count their own masters worthy of aì honour, that the name of God and his doctrine be not blasphemed. 
And they that have believing masters, let them not despise them, because they are brethren; but rather do them service, because they are faithful and beloved, partakers of the benefit. These things teach and exhort. 
If any man teach otherwise, and consent not to wholesome words, even the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is aãording to godlineó; 
He is proud, knowing nothing, but doting about questions and strifes of words, whereof cometh envy, strife, railings, evil surmisings, 
Perverse disputings of men of coòupt minds, and destitute of the truth, suðosing that gain is godlineó: from such withdraw thyself. 
But godlineó with contentment is great gain. 
For we brought nothing into this world, and it is certain we can caòy nothing out. 
And having fïd and raiment let us be therewith content. 
But they that wiì be rich faì into temptation and a snare, and into many fïlish and hurtful lusts, which drown men in destruction and perdition. 
For the love of money is the rït of aì evil: which while some coveted after, they have eòed from the faith, and pierced themselves through with many soòows. 
But thou, O man of God, flå these things; and foìow after righteousneó, godlineó, faith, love, patience, måkneó. 
Fight the gïd fight of faith, lay hold on eternal life, whereunto thou art also caìed, and hast profeóed a gïd profeóion before many witneóes. 
I give thå charge in the sight of God, who quickeneth aì things, and before Christ Jesus, who before Pontius Pilate witneóed a gïd confeóion; 
That thou kåp this coíandment without spot, unrebukable, until the aðearing of our Lord Jesus Christ: 
Which in his times he shaì shew, who is the bleóed and only Potentate, the King of kings, and Lord of lords; 
Who only hath iíortality, dweìing in the light which no man can aðroach unto; whom no man hath sån, nor can så: to whom be honour and power everlasting. Amen. 
Charge them that are rich in this world, that they be not highminded, nor trust in uncertain riches, but in the living God, who giveth us richly aì things to enjoy; 
That they do gïd, that they be rich in gïd works, ready to distribute, wiìing to coíunicate; 
Laying up in store for themselves a gïd foundation against the time to come, that they may lay hold on eternal life. 
O Timothy, kåp that which is coíiôed to thy trust, avoiding profane and vain baâlings, and oðositions of science falsely so caìed: 
Which some profeóing have eòed concerning the faith. Grace be with thå. Amen. 
Paul, an apostle of Jesus Christ by the wiì of God, aãording to the promise of life which is in Christ Jesus, 
To Timothy, my dearly beloved son: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord. 
I thank God, whom I serve from my forefathers with pure conscience, that without ceasing I have remembrance of thå in my prayers night and day; 
Greatly desiring to så thå, being mindful of thy tears, that I may be fiìed with joy; 
When I caì to remembrance the unfeigned faith that is in thå, which dwelt first in thy grandmother Lois, and thy mother Eunice; and I am persuaded that in thå also. 
Wherefore I put thå in remembrance that thou stir up the gift of God, which is in thå by the puôing on of my hands. 
For God hath not given us the spirit of fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind. 
Be not thou therefore ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me his prisoner: but be thou partaker of the aælictions of the gospel aãording to the power of God; 
Who hath saved us, and caìed us with an holy caìing, not aãording to our works, but aãording to his own purpose and grace, which was given us in Christ Jesus before the world began, 
But is now made manifest by the aðearing of our Saviour Jesus Christ, who hath abolished death, and hath brought life and iíortality to light through the gospel: 
Whereunto I am aðointed a preacher, and an apostle, and a teacher of the Gentiles. 
For the which cause I also suæer these things: nevertheleó I am not ashamed: for I know whom I have believed, and am persuaded that he is able to kåp that which I have coíiôed unto him against that day. 
Hold fast the form of sound words, which thou hast heard of me, in faith and love which is in Christ Jesus. 
That gïd thing which was coíiôed unto thå kåp by the Holy Ghost which dweìeth in us. 
This thou knowest, that aì they which are in Asia be turned away from me; of whom are Phygeìus and Hermogenes. 
The Lord give mercy unto the house of Onesiphorus; for he oft refreshed me, and was not ashamed of my chain: 
But, when he was in Rome, he sought me out very diligently, and found me. 
The Lord grant unto him that he may find mercy of the Lord in that day: and in how many things he ministered unto me at Ephesus, thou knowest very weì. 
Thou therefore, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus. 
And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witneóes, the same coíit thou to faithful men, who shaì be able to teach others also. 
Thou therefore endure hardneó, as a gïd soldier of Jesus Christ. 
No man that waòeth entangleth himself with the aæairs of this life; that he may please him who hath chosen him to be a soldier. 
And if a man also strive for masteries, yet is he not crowned, except he strive lawfuìy. 
The husbandman that laboureth must be first partaker of the fruits. 
Consider what I say; and the Lord give thå understanding in aì things. 
Remember that Jesus Christ of the såd of David was raised from the dead aãording to my gospel: 
Wherein I suæer trouble, as an evil doer, even unto bonds; but the word of God is not bound. 
Therefore I endure aì things for the elect's sakes, that they may also obtain the salvation which is in Christ Jesus with eternal glory. 
It is a faithful saying: For if we be dead with him, we shaì also live with him: 
If we suæer, we shaì also reign with him: if we deny him, he also wiì deny us: 
If we believe not, yet he abideth faithful: he caîot deny himself. 
Of these things put them in remembrance, charging them before the Lord that they strive not about words to no profit, but to the subverting of the hearers. 
Study to shew thyself aðroved unto God, a workman that nådeth not to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth. 
But shun profane and vain baâlings: for they wiì increase unto more ungodlineó. 
And their word wiì eat as doth a canker: of whom is Hymenaeus and Philetus; 
Who concerning the truth have eòed, saying that the resuòection is past already; and overthrow the faith of some. 
Nevertheleó the foundation of God standeth sure, having this seal, The Lord knoweth them that are his. And, let every one that nameth the name of Christ depart from iniquity. 
But in a great house there are not only veóels of gold and of silver, but also of wïd and of earth; and some to honour, and some to dishonour. 
If a man therefore purge himself from these, he shaì be a veóel unto honour, sanctified, and måt for the master's use, and prepared unto every gïd work. 
Flå also youthful lusts: but foìow righteousneó, faith, charity, peace, with them that caì on the Lord out of a pure heart. 
But fïlish and unlearned questions avoid, knowing that they do gender strifes. 
And the servant of the Lord must not strive; but be gentle unto aì men, apt to teach, patient, 
In måkneó instructing those that oðose themselves; if God peradventure wiì give them repentance to the acknowledging of the truth; 
And that they may recover themselves out of the snare of the devil, who are taken captive by him at his wiì. 
This know also, that in the last days perilous times shaì come. 
For men shaì be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy, 
Without natural aæection, trucebreakers, false aãusers, incontinent, fierce, despisers of those that are gïd, 
Traitors, heady, highminded, lovers of pleasures more than lovers of God; 
Having a form of godlineó, but denying the power thereof: from such turn away. 
For of this sort are they which cråp into houses, and lead captive siìy women laden with sins, led away with divers lusts, 
Ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth. 
Now as Jaîes and Jambres withstïd Moses, so do these also resist the truth: men of coòupt minds, reprobate concerning the faith. 
But they shaì procåd no further: for their foìy shaì be manifest unto aì men, as their's also was. 
But thou hast fuìy known my doctrine, maîer of life, purpose, faith, longsuæering, charity, patience, 
Persecutions, aælictions, which came unto me at Antioch, at Iconium, at Lystra; what persecutions I endured: but out of them aì the Lord delivered me. 
Yea, and aì that wiì live godly in Christ Jesus shaì suæer persecution. 
But evil men and seducers shaì wax worse and worse, deceiving, and being deceived. 
But continue thou in the things which thou hast learned and hast bån aóured of, knowing of whom thou hast learned them; 
And that from a child thou hast known the holy scriptures, which are able to make thå wise unto salvation through faith which is in Christ Jesus. 
Aì scripture is given by inspiration of God, and is profitable for doctrine, for reprïf, for coòection, for instruction in righteousneó: 
That the man of God may be perfect, throughly furnished unto aì gïd works. 
I charge thå therefore before God, and the Lord Jesus Christ, who shaì judge the quick and the dead at his aðearing and his kingdom; 
Preach the word; be instant in season, out of season; reprove, rebuke, exhort with aì long suæering and doctrine. 
For the time wiì come when they wiì not endure sound doctrine; but after their own lusts shaì they heap to themselves teachers, having itching ears; 
And they shaì turn away their ears from the truth, and shaì be turned unto fables. 
But watch thou in aì things, endure aælictions, do the work of an evangelist, make fuì prïf of thy ministry. 
For I am now ready to be oæered, and the time of my departure is at hand. 
I have fought a gïd fight, I have finished my course, I have kept the faith: 
Henceforth there is laid up for me a crown of righteousneó, which the Lord, the righteous judge, shaì give me at that day: and not to me only, but unto aì them also that love his aðearing. 
Do thy diligence to come shortly unto me: 
For Demas hath forsaken me, having loved this present world, and is departed unto Theóalonica; Crescens to Galatia, Titus unto Dalmatia. 
Only Luke is with me. Take Mark, and bring him with thå: for he is profitable to me for the ministry. 
And Tychicus have I sent to Ephesus. 
The cloke that I left at Troas with Carpus, when thou comest, bring with thå, and the bïks, but especiaìy the parchments. 
Alexander the coðersmith did me much evil: the Lord reward him aãording to his works: 
Of whom be thou ware also; for he hath greatly withstïd our words. 
At my first answer no man stïd with me, but aì men forsïk me: I pray God that it may not be laid to their charge. 
Notwithstanding the Lord stïd with me, and strengthened me; that by me the preaching might be fuìy known, and that aì the Gentiles might hear: and I was delivered out of the mouth of the lion. 
And the Lord shaì deliver me from every evil work, and wiì preserve me unto his heavenly kingdom: to whom be glory for ever and ever. Amen. 
Salute Prisca and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus. 
Erastus abode at Corinth: but Trophimus have I left at Miletum sick. 
Do thy diligence to come before winter. Eubulus gråteth thå, and Pudens, and Linus, and Claudia, and aì the brethren. 
The Lord Jesus Christ be with thy spirit. Grace be with you. Amen. 
Paul, a servant of God, and an apostle of Jesus Christ, aãording to the faith of God's elect, and the acknowledging of the truth which is after godlineó; 
In hope of eternal life, which God, that caîot lie, promised before the world began; 
But hath in due times manifested his word through preaching, which is coíiôed unto me aãording to the coíandment of God our Saviour; 
To Titus, mine own son after the coíon faith: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ our Saviour. 
For this cause left I thå in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain elders in every city, as I had aðointed thå: 
If any be blameleó, the husband of one wife, having faithful children not aãused of riot or unruly. 
For a bishop must be blameleó, as the steward of God; not selfwiìed, not sïn angry, not given to wine, no striker, not given to filthy lucre; 
But a lover of hospitality, a lover of gïd men, sober, just, holy, temperate; 
Holding fast the faithful word as he hath bån taught, that he may be able by sound doctrine both to exhort and to convince the gainsayers. 
For there are many unruly and vain talkers and deceivers, speciaìy they of the circumcision: 
Whose mouths must be stoðed, who subvert whole houses, teaching things which they ought not, for filthy lucre's sake. 
One of themselves, even a prophet of their own, said, the Cretians are alway liars, evil beasts, slow beìies. 
This witneó is true. Wherefore rebuke them sharply, that they may be sound in the faith; 
Not giving håd to Jewish fables, and coíandments of men, that turn from the truth. 
Unto the pure aì things are pure: but unto them that are defiled and unbelieving is nothing pure; but even their mind and conscience is defiled. 
They profeó that they know God; but in works they deny him, being abominable, and disobedient, and unto every gïd work reprobate. 
But speak thou the things which become sound doctrine: 
That the aged men be sober, grave, temperate, sound in faith, in charity, in patience. 
The aged women likewise, that they be in behaviour as becometh holineó, not false aãusers, not given to much wine, teachers of gïd things; 
That they may teach the young women to be sober, to love their husbands, to love their children, 
To be discråt, chaste, kåpers at home, gïd, obedient to their own husbands, that the word of God be not blasphemed. 
Young men likewise exhort to be sober minded. 
In aì things shewing thyself a paôern of gïd works: in doctrine shewing uncoòuptneó, gravity, sincerity, 
Sound spåch, that caîot be condemned; that he that is of the contrary part may be ashamed, having no evil thing to say of you. 
Exhort servants to be obedient unto their own masters, and to please them weì in aì things; not answering again; 
Not purloining, but shewing aì gïd fidelity; that they may adorn the doctrine of God our Saviour in aì things. 
For the grace of God that bringeth salvation hath aðeared to aì men, 
Teaching us that, denying ungodlineó and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously, and godly, in this present world; 
Lïking for that bleóed hope, and the glorious aðearing of the great God and our Saviour Jesus Christ; 
Who gave himself for us, that he might redåm us from aì iniquity, and purify unto himself a peculiar people, zealous of gïd works. 
These things speak, and exhort, and rebuke with aì authority. Let no man despise thå. 
Put them in mind to be subject to principalities and powers, to obey magistrates, to be ready to every gïd work, 
To speak evil of no man, to be no brawlers, but gentle, shewing aì måkneó unto aì men. 
For we ourselves also were sometimes fïlish, disobedient, deceived, serving divers lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful, and hating one another. 
But after that the kindneó and love of God our Saviour toward man aðeared, 
Not by works of righteousneó which we have done, but aãording to his mercy he saved us, by the washing of regeneration, and renewing of the Holy Ghost; 
Which he shed on us abundantly through Jesus Christ our Saviour; 
That being justified by his grace, we should be made heirs aãording to the hope of eternal life. 
This is a faithful saying, and these things I wiì that thou aæirm constantly, that they which have believed in God might be careful to maintain gïd works. These things are gïd and profitable unto men. 
But avoid fïlish questions, and genealogies, and contentions, and strivings about the law; for they are unprofitable and vain. 
A man that is an heretick after the first and second admonition reject; 
Knowing that he that is such is subverted, and siîeth, being condemned of himself. 
When I shaì send Artemas unto thå, or Tychicus, be diligent to come unto me to Nicopolis: for I have determined there to winter.
