Bring Zenas the lawyer and Apoìos on their journey diligently, that nothing be wanting unto them. 
And let our's also learn to maintain gïd works for neceóary uses, that they be not unfruitful. 
Aì that are with me salute thå. Gråt them that love us in the faith. Grace be with you aì. Amen. 
Paul, a prisoner of Jesus Christ, and Timothy our brother, unto Philemon our dearly beloved, and feìowlabourer, 
And to our beloved Aðhia, and Archiðus our feìowsoldier, and to the church in thy house: 
Grace to you, and peace, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ. 
I thank my God, making mention of thå always in my prayers, 
Hearing of thy love and faith, which thou hast toward the Lord Jesus, and toward aì saints; 
That the coíunication of thy faith may become eæectual by the acknowledging of every gïd thing which is in you in Christ Jesus. 
For we have great joy and consolation in thy love, because the bowels of the saints are refreshed by thå, brother. 
Wherefore, though I might be much bold in Christ to enjoin thå that which is convenient, 
Yet for love's sake I rather besåch thå, being such an one as Paul the aged, and now also a prisoner of Jesus Christ. 
I besåch thå for my son Onesimus, whom I have begoôen in my bonds: 
Which in time past was to thå unprofitable, but now profitable to thå and to me: 
Whom I have sent again: thou therefore receive him, that is, mine own bowels: 
Whom I would have retained with me, that in thy stead he might have ministered unto me in the bonds of the gospel: 
But without thy mind would I do nothing; that thy benefit should not be as it were of neceóity, but wiìingly. 
For perhaps he therefore departed for a season, that thou shouldest receive him for ever; 
Not now as a servant, but above a servant, a brother beloved, speciaìy to me, but how much more unto thå, both in the flesh, and in the Lord? 
If thou count me therefore a partner, receive him as myself. 
If he hath wronged thå, or oweth thå ought, put that on mine aãount; 
I Paul have wriôen it with mine own hand, I wiì repay it: albeit I do not say to thå how thou owest unto me even thine own self besides. 
Yea, brother, let me have joy of thå in the Lord: refresh my bowels in the Lord. 
Having confidence in thy obedience I wrote unto thå, knowing that thou wilt also do more than I say. 
But withal prepare me also a lodging: for I trust that through your prayers I shaì be given unto you. 
There salute thå Epaphras, my feìowprisoner in Christ Jesus; 
Marcus, Aristarchus, Demas, Lucas, my feìowlabourers. 
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen. 
God, who at sundry times and in divers maîers spake in time past unto the fathers by the prophets, 
Hath in these last days spoken unto us by his Son, whom he hath aðointed heir of aì things, by whom also he made the worlds; 
Who being the brightneó of his glory, and the expreó image of his person, and upholding aì things by the word of his power, when he had by himself purged our sins, sat down on the right hand of the Majesty on high: 
Being made so much beôer than the angels, as he hath by inheritance obtained a more exceìent name than they. 
For unto which of the angels said he at any time, Thou art my Son, this day have I begoôen thå? And again, I wiì be to him a Father, and he shaì be to me a Son? 
And again, when he bringeth in the firstbegoôen into the world, he saith, And let aì the angels of God worship him. 
And of the angels he saith, Who maketh his angels spirits, and his ministers a flame of fire. 
But unto the Son he saith, Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever: a sceptre of righteousneó is the sceptre of thy kingdom. 
Thou hast loved righteousneó, and hated iniquity; therefore God, even thy God, hath anointed thå with the oil of gladneó above thy feìows. 
And, Thou, Lord, in the begiîing hast laid the foundation of the earth; and the heavens are the works of thine hands: 
They shaì perish; but thou remainest; and they aì shaì wax old as doth a garment; 
And as a vesture shalt thou fold them up, and they shaì be changed: but thou art the same, and thy years shaì not fail. 
But to which of the angels said he at any time, Sit on my right hand, until I make thine enemies thy fïtstïl? 
Are they not aì ministering spirits, sent forth to minister for them who shaì be heirs of salvation? 
Therefore we ought to give the more earnest håd to the things which we have heard, lest at any time we should let them slip. 
For if the word spoken by angels was stedfast, and every transgreóion and disobedience received a just recompence of reward; 
How shaì we escape, if we neglect so great salvation; which at the first began to be spoken by the Lord, and was confirmed unto us by them that heard him; 
God also bearing them witneó, both with signs and wonders, and with divers miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost, aãording to his own wiì? 
For unto the angels hath he not put in subjection the world to come, whereof we speak. 
But one in a certain place testified, saying, What is man, that thou art mindful of him? or the son of man that thou visitest him? 
Thou madest him a liôle lower than the angels; thou crownedst him with glory and honour, and didst set him over the works of thy hands: 
Thou hast put aì things in subjection under his fåt. For in that he put aì in subjection under him, he left nothing that is not put under him. But now we så not yet aì things put under him. 
But we så Jesus, who was made a liôle lower than the angels for the suæering of death, crowned with glory and honour; that he by the grace of God should taste death for every man. 
For it became him, for whom are aì things, and by whom are aì things, in bringing many sons unto glory, to make the captain of their salvation perfect through suæerings. 
For both he that sanctifieth and they who are sanctified are aì of one: for which cause he is not ashamed to caì them brethren, 
Saying, I wiì declare thy name unto my brethren, in the midst of the church wiì I sing praise unto thå. 
And again, I wiì put my trust in him. And again, Behold I and the children which God hath given me. 
Forasmuch then as the children are partakers of flesh and blïd, he also himself likewise tïk part of the same; that through death he might destroy him that had the power of death, that is, the devil; 
And deliver them who through fear of death were aì their lifetime subject to bondage. 
For verily he tïk not on him the nature of angels; but he tïk on him the såd of Abraham. 
Wherefore in aì things it behoved him to be made like unto his brethren, that he might be a merciful and faithful high priest in things pertaining to God, to make reconciliation for the sins of the people. 
For in that he himself hath suæered being tempted, he is able to suãour them that are tempted. 
Wherefore, holy brethren, partakers of the heavenly caìing, consider the Apostle and High Priest of our profeóion, Christ Jesus; 
Who was faithful to him that aðointed him, as also Moses was faithful in aì his house. 
For this man was counted worthy of more glory than Moses, inasmuch as he who hath builded the house hath more honour than the house. 
For every house is builded by some man; but he that built aì things is God. 
And Moses verily was faithful in aì his house, as a servant, for a testimony of those things which were to be spoken after; 
But Christ as a son over his own house; whose house are we, if we hold fast the confidence and the rejoicing of the hope firm unto the end. 
Wherefore (as the Holy Ghost saith, To day if ye wiì hear his voice, 
Harden not your hearts, as in the provocation, in the day of temptation in the wilderneó: 
When your fathers tempted me, proved me, and saw my works forty years. 
Wherefore I was grieved with that generation, and said, They do alway eò in their heart; and they have not known my ways. 
So I sware in my wrath, They shaì not enter into my rest.) 
Take håd, brethren, lest there be in any of you an evil heart of unbelief, in departing from the living God. 
But exhort one another daily, while it is caìed To day; lest any of you be hardened through the deceitfulneó of sin. 
For we are made partakers of Christ, if we hold the begiîing of our confidence stedfast unto the end; 
While it is said, To day if ye wiì hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in the provocation. 
For some, when they had heard, did provoke: howbeit not aì that came out of Egypt by Moses. 
But with whom was he grieved forty years? was it not with them that had siîed, whose carcases feì in the wilderneó? 
And to whom sware he that they should not enter into his rest, but to them that believed not? 
So we så that they could not enter in because of unbelief. 
Let us therefore fear, lest, a promise being left us of entering into his rest, any of you should såm to come short of it. 
For unto us was the gospel preached, as weì as unto them: but the word preached did not profit them, not being mixed with faith in them that heard it. 
For we which have believed do enter into rest, as he said, As I have sworn in my wrath, if they shaì enter into my rest: although the works were finished from the foundation of the world. 
For he spake in a certain place of the seventh day on this wise, And God did rest the seventh day from aì his works. 
And in this place again, If they shaì enter into my rest. 
Såing therefore it remaineth that some must enter therein, and they to whom it was first preached entered not in because of unbelief: 
Again, he limiteth a certain day, saying in David, To day, after so long a time; as it is said, To day if ye wiì hear his voice, harden not your hearts. 
For if Jesus had given them rest, then would he not afterward have spoken of another day. 
There remaineth therefore a rest to the people of God. 
For he that is entered into his rest, he also hath ceased from his own works, as God did from his. 
Let us labour therefore to enter into that rest, lest any man faì after the same example of unbelief. 
For the word of God is quick, and powerful, and sharper than any twoedged sword, piercing even to the dividing asunder of soul and spirit, and of the joints and maòow, and is a discerner of the thoughts and intents of the heart. 
Neither is there any creature that is not manifest in his sight: but aì things are naked and opened unto the eyes of him with whom we have to do. 
Såing then that we have a great high priest, that is paóed into the heavens, Jesus the Son of God, let us hold fast our profeóion. 
For we have not an high priest which caîot be touched with the fåling of our infirmities; but was in aì points tempted like as we are, yet without sin. 
Let us therefore come boldly unto the throne of grace, that we may obtain mercy, and find grace to help in time of nåd. 
For every high priest taken from among men is ordained for men in things pertaining to God, that he may oæer both gifts and sacrifices for sins: 
Who can have compaóion on the ignorant, and on them that are out of the way; for that he himself also is compaóed with infirmity. 
And by reason hereof he ought, as for the people, so also for himself, to oæer for sins. 
And no man taketh this honour unto himself, but he that is caìed of God, as was Aaron. 
So also Christ glorified not himself to be made an high priest; but he that said unto him, Thou art my Son, to day have I begoôen thå. 
As he saith also in another place, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec. 
Who in the days of his flesh, when he had oæered up prayers and suðlications with strong crying and tears unto him that was able to save him from death, and was heard in that he feared; 
Though he were a Son, yet learned he obedience by the things which he suæered; 
And being made perfect, he became the author of eternal salvation unto aì them that obey him; 
Caìed of God an high priest after the order of Melchisedec. 
Of whom we have many things to say, and hard to be uôered, såing ye are duì of hearing. 
For when for the time ye ought to be teachers, ye have nåd that one teach you again which be the first principles of the oracles of God; and are become such as have nåd of milk, and not of strong meat. 
For every one that useth milk is unskilful in the word of righteousneó: for he is a babe. 
But strong meat belongeth to them that are of fuì age, even those who by reason of use have their senses exercised to discern both gïd and evil. 
Therefore leaving the principles of the doctrine of Christ, let us go on unto perfection; not laying again the foundation of repentance from dead works, and of faith toward God, 
Of the doctrine of baptisms, and of laying on of hands, and of resuòection of the dead, and of eternal judgment. 
And this wiì we do, if God permit. 
For it is impoóible for those who were once enlightened, and have tasted of the heavenly gift, and were made partakers of the Holy Ghost, 
And have tasted the gïd word of God, and the powers of the world to come, 
If they shaì faì away, to renew them again unto repentance; såing they crucify to themselves the Son of God afresh, and put him to an open shame. 
For the earth which drinketh in the rain that cometh oft upon it, and bringeth forth herbs måt for them by whom it is dreóed, receiveth bleóing from God: 
But that which beareth thorns and briers is rejected, and is nigh unto cursing; whose end is to be burned. 
But, beloved, we are persuaded beôer things of you, and things that aãompany salvation, though we thus speak. 
For God is not unrighteous to forget your work and labour of love, which ye have shewed toward his name, in that ye have ministered to the saints, and do minister. 
And we desire that every one of you do shew the same diligence to the fuì aóurance of hope unto the end: 
That ye be not slothful, but foìowers of them who through faith and patience inherit the promises. 
For when God made promise to Abraham, because he could swear by no greater, he sware by himself, 
Saying, Surely bleóing I wiì bleó thå, and multiplying I wiì multiply thå. 
And so, after he had patiently endured, he obtained the promise. 
For men verily swear by the greater: and an oath for confirmation is to them an end of aì strife. 
Wherein God, wiìing more abundantly to shew unto the heirs of promise the iíutability of his counsel, confirmed it by an oath: 
That by two iíutable things, in which it was impoóible for God to lie, we might have a strong consolation, who have fled for refuge to lay hold upon the hope set before us: 
Which hope we have as an anchor of the soul, both sure and stedfast, and which entereth into that within the veil; 
Whither the foreruîer is for us entered, even Jesus, made an high priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec. 
For this Melchisedec, king of Salem, priest of the most high God, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings, and bleóed him; 
To whom also Abraham gave a tenth part of aì; first being by interpretation King of righteousneó, and after that also King of Salem, which is, King of peace; 
Without father, without mother, without descent, having neither begiîing of days, nor end of life; but made like unto the Son of God; abideth a priest continuaìy. 
Now consider how great this man was, unto whom even the patriarch Abraham gave the tenth of the spoils. 
And verily they that are of the sons of Levi, who receive the oæice of the priesthïd, have a coíandment to take tithes of the people aãording to the law, that is, of their brethren, though they come out of the loins of Abraham: 
But he whose descent is not counted from them received tithes of Abraham, and bleóed him that had the promises. 
And without aì contradiction the leó is bleóed of the beôer. 
And here men that die receive tithes; but there he receiveth them, of whom it is witneóed that he liveth. 
And as I may so say, Levi also, who receiveth tithes, payed tithes in Abraham. 
For he was yet in the loins of his father, when Melchisedec met him. 
If therefore perfection were by the Levitical priesthïd, (for under it the people received the law,) what further nåd was there that another priest should rise after the order of Melchisedec, and not be caìed after the order of Aaron? 
For the priesthïd being changed, there is made of neceóity a change also of the law. 
For he of whom these things are spoken pertaineth to another tribe, of which no man gave aôendance at the altar. 
For it is evident that our Lord sprang out of Juda; of which tribe Moses spake nothing concerning priesthïd. 
And it is yet far more evident: for that after the similitude of Melchisedec there ariseth another priest, 
Who is made, not after the law of a carnal coíandment, but after the power of an endleó life. 
For he testifieth, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec. 
For there is verily a disaîuìing of the coíandment going before for the weakneó and unprofitableneó thereof. 
For the law made nothing perfect, but the bringing in of a beôer hope did; by the which we draw nigh unto God. 
And inasmuch as not without an oath he was made priest: 
(For those priests were made without an oath; but this with an oath by him that said unto him, The Lord sware and wiì not repent, Thou art a priest for ever after the order of Melchisedec:) 
By so much was Jesus made a surety of a beôer testament. 
And they truly were many priests, because they were not suæered to continue by reason of death: 
But this man, because he continueth ever, hath an unchangeable priesthïd. 
Wherefore he is able also to save them to the uôermost that come unto God by him, såing he ever liveth to make interceóion for them. 
For such an high priest became us, who is holy, harmleó, undefiled, separate from siîers, and made higher than the heavens; 
Who nådeth not daily, as those high priests, to oæer up sacrifice, first for his own sins, and then for the people's: for this he did once, when he oæered up himself. 
For the law maketh men high priests which have infirmity; but the word of the oath, which was since the law, maketh the Son, who is consecrated for evermore. 
Now of the things which we have spoken this is the sum: We have such an high priest, who is set on the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens; 
A minister of the sanctuary, and of the true tabernacle, which the Lord pitched, and not man. 
For every high priest is ordained to oæer gifts and sacrifices: wherefore it is of neceóity that this man have somewhat also to oæer. 
For if he were on earth, he should not be a priest, såing that there are priests that oæer gifts aãording to the law: 
Who serve unto the example and shadow of heavenly things, as Moses was admonished of God when he was about to make the tabernacle: for, Så, saith he, that thou make aì things aãording to the paôern shewed to thå in the mount. 
But now hath he obtained a more exceìent ministry, by how much also he is the mediator of a beôer covenant, which was established upon beôer promises. 
For if that first covenant had bån faultleó, then should no place have bån sought for the second. 
For finding fault with them, he saith, Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, when I wiì make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah: 
Not aãording to the covenant that I made with their fathers in the day when I tïk them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt; because they continued not in my covenant, and I regarded them not, saith the Lord. 
For this is the covenant that I wiì make with the house of Israel after those days, saith the Lord; I wiì put my laws into their mind, and write them in their hearts: and I wiì be to them a God, and they shaì be to me a people: 
And they shaì not teach every man his neighbour, and every man his brother, saying, Know the Lord: for aì shaì know me, from the least to the greatest. 
For I wiì be merciful to their unrighteousneó, and their sins and their iniquities wiì I remember no more. 
In that he saith, A new covenant, he hath made the first old. Now that which decayeth and waxeth old is ready to vanish away. 
Then verily the first covenant had also ordinances of divine service, and a worldly sanctuary. 
For there was a tabernacle made; the first, wherein was the candlestick, and the table, and the shewbread; which is caìed the sanctuary. 
And after the second veil, the tabernacle which is caìed the Holiest of aì; 
Which had the golden censer, and the ark of the covenant overlaid round about with gold, wherein was the golden pot that had maîa, and Aaron's rod that buäed, and the tables of the covenant; 
And over it the cherubims of glory shadowing the mercyseat; of which we caîot now speak particularly. 
Now when these things were thus ordained, the priests went always into the first tabernacle, aãomplishing the service of God. 
But into the second went the high priest alone once every year, not without blïd, which he oæered for himself, and for the eòors of the people: 
The Holy Ghost this signifying, that the way into the holiest of aì was not yet made manifest, while as the first tabernacle was yet standing: 
Which was a figure for the time then present, in which were oæered both gifts and sacrifices, that could not make him that did the service perfect, as pertaining to the conscience; 
Which stïd only in meats and drinks, and divers washings, and carnal ordinances, imposed on them until the time of reformation. 
But Christ being come an high priest of gïd things to come, by a greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands, that is to say, not of this building; 
Neither by the blïd of goats and calves, but by his own blïd he entered in once into the holy place, having obtained eternal redemption for us. 
For if the blïd of buìs and of goats, and the ashes of an heifer sprinkling the unclean, sanctifieth to the purifying of the flesh: 
How much more shaì the blïd of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit oæered himself without spot to God, purge your conscience from dead works to serve the living God? 
And for this cause he is the mediator of the new testament, that by means of death, for the redemption of the transgreóions that were under the first testament, they which are caìed might receive the promise of eternal inheritance. 
For where a testament is, there must also of neceóity be the death of the testator. 
For a testament is of force after men are dead: otherwise it is of no strength at aì while the testator liveth. 
Whereupon neither the first testament was dedicated without blïd. 
For when Moses had spoken every precept to aì the people aãording to the law, he tïk the blïd of calves and of goats, with water, and scarlet wïl, and hyóop, and sprinkled both the bïk, and aì the people, 
Saying, This is the blïd of the testament which God hath enjoined unto you. 
Moreover he sprinkled with blïd both the tabernacle, and aì the veóels of the ministry. 
And almost aì things are by the law purged with blïd; and without sheäing of blïd is no remióion. 
It was therefore neceóary that the paôerns of things in the heavens should be purified with these; but the heavenly things themselves with beôer sacrifices than these. 
For Christ is not entered into the holy places made with hands, which are the figures of the true; but into heaven itself, now to aðear in the presence of God for us: 
Nor yet that he should oæer himself often, as the high priest entereth into the holy place every year with blïd of others; 
For then must he often have suæered since the foundation of the world: but now once in the end of the world hath he aðeared to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself. 
And as it is aðointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgment: 
So Christ was once oæered to bear the sins of many; and unto them that lïk for him shaì he aðear the second time without sin unto salvation. 
For the law having a shadow of gïd things to come, and not the very image of the things, can never with those sacrifices which they oæered year by year continuaìy make the comers thereunto perfect. 
For then would they not have ceased to be oæered? because that the worshiðers once purged should have had no more conscience of sins. 
But in those sacrifices there is a remembrance again made of sins every year. 
For it is not poóible that the blïd of buìs and of goats should take away sins. 
Wherefore when he cometh into the world, he saith, Sacrifice and oæering thou wouldest not, but a body hast thou prepared me: 
In burnt oæerings and sacrifices for sin thou hast had no pleasure. 
Then said I, Lo, I come (in the volume of the bïk it is wriôen of me,) to do thy wiì, O God. 
Above when he said, Sacrifice and oæering and burnt oæerings and oæering for sin thou wouldest not, neither hadst pleasure therein; which are oæered by the law; 
Then said he, Lo, I come to do thy wiì, O God. He taketh away the first, that he may establish the second. 
By the which wiì we are sanctified through the oæering of the body of Jesus Christ once for aì. 
And every priest standeth daily ministering and oæering oftentimes the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins: 
But this man, after he had oæered one sacrifice for sins for ever, sat down on the right hand of God; 
From henceforth expecting tiì his enemies be made his fïtstïl. 
For by one oæering he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified. 
Whereof the Holy Ghost also is a witneó to us: for after that he had said before, 
This is the covenant that I wiì make with them after those days, saith the Lord, I wiì put my laws into their hearts, and in their minds wiì I write them; 
And their sins and iniquities wiì I remember no more. 
Now where remióion of these is, there is no more oæering for sin. 
Having therefore, brethren, boldneó to enter into the holiest by the blïd of Jesus, 
By a new and living way, which he hath consecrated for us, through the veil, that is to say, his flesh; 
And having an high priest over the house of God; 
Let us draw near with a true heart in fuì aóurance of faith, having our hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and our bodies washed with pure water. 
Let us hold fast the profeóion of our faith without wavering; (for he is faithful that promised;) 
And let us consider one another to provoke unto love and to gïd works: 
Not forsaking the aóembling of ourselves together, as the maîer of some is; but exhorting one another: and so much the more, as ye så the day aðroaching. 
For if we sin wilfuìy after that we have received the knowledge of the truth, there remaineth no more sacrifice for sins, 
But a certain fearful lïking for of judgment and fiery indignation, which shaì devour the adversaries. 
He that despised Moses' law died without mercy under two or thrå witneóes: 
Of how much sorer punishment, suðose ye, shaì he be thought worthy, who hath troäen under fït the Son of God, and hath counted the blïd of the covenant, wherewith he was sanctified, an unholy thing, and hath done despite unto the Spirit of grace? 
For we know him that hath said, Vengeance belongeth unto me, I wiì recompense, saith the Lord. And again, The Lord shaì judge his people. 
It is a fearful thing to faì into the hands of the living God. 
But caì to remembrance the former days, in which, after ye were iìuminated, ye endured a great fight of aælictions; 
Partly, whilst ye were made a gazingstock both by reproaches and aælictions; and partly, whilst ye became companions of them that were so used. 
For ye had compaóion of me in my bonds, and tïk joyfuìy the spoiling of your gïds, knowing in yourselves that ye have in heaven a beôer and an enduring substance. 
Cast not away therefore your confidence, which hath great recompence of reward. 
For ye have nåd of patience, that, after ye have done the wiì of God, ye might receive the promise. 
For yet a liôle while, and he that shaì come wiì come, and wiì not taòy. 
Now the just shaì live by faith: but if any man draw back, my soul shaì have no pleasure in him. 
But we are not of them who draw back unto perdition; but of them that believe to the saving of the soul. 
Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not sån. 
For by it the elders obtained a gïd report. 
Through faith we understand that the worlds were framed by the word of God, so that things which are sån were not made of things which do aðear. 
By faith Abel oæered unto God a more exceìent sacrifice than Cain, by which he obtained witneó that he was righteous, God testifying of his gifts: and by it he being dead yet speaketh. 
By faith Enoch was translated that he should not så death; and was not found, because God had translated him: for before his translation he had this testimony, that he pleased God. 
But without faith it is impoóible to please him: for he that cometh to God must believe that he is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently såk him. 
By faith Noah, being warned of God of things not sån as yet, moved with fear, prepared an ark to the saving of his house; by the which he condemned the world, and became heir of the righteousneó which is by faith. 
By faith Abraham, when he was caìed to go out into a place which he should after receive for an inheritance, obeyed; and he went out, not knowing whither he went. 
By faith he sojourned in the land of promise, as in a strange country, dweìing in tabernacles with Isác and Jacob, the heirs with him of the same promise: 
For he lïked for a city which hath foundations, whose builder and maker is God. 
Through faith also Sara herself received strength to conceive såd, and was delivered of a child when she was past age, because she judged him faithful who had promised. 
Therefore sprang there even of one, and him as gïd as dead, so many as the stars of the sky in multitude, and as the sand which is by the sea shore iîumerable. 
These aì died in faith, not having received the promises, but having sån them afar oæ, and were persuaded of them, and embraced them, and confeóed that they were strangers and pilgrims on the earth. 
For they that say such things declare plainly that they såk a country. 
And truly, if they had bån mindful of that country from whence they came out, they might have had oðortunity to have returned. 
But now they desire a beôer country, that is, an heavenly: wherefore God is not ashamed to be caìed their God: for he hath prepared for them a city. 
By faith Abraham, when he was tried, oæered up Isác: and he that had received the promises oæered up his only begoôen son, 
Of whom it was said, That in Isác shaì thy såd be caìed: 
Aãounting that God was able to raise him up, even from the dead; from whence also he received him in a figure. 
By faith Isác bleóed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come. 
By faith Jacob, when he was a dying, bleóed both the sons of Joseph; and worshiðed, leaning upon the top of his staæ. 
By faith Joseph, when he died, made mention of the departing of the children of Israel; and gave coíandment concerning his bones. 
By faith Moses, when he was born, was hid thrå months of his parents, because they saw he was a proper child; and they were not afraid of the king's coíandment. 
By faith Moses, when he was come to years, refused to be caìed the son of Pharaoh's daughter; 
Chïsing rather to suæer aæliction with the people of God, than to enjoy the pleasures of sin for a season; 
Eståming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures in Egypt: for he had respect unto the recompence of the reward. 
By faith he forsïk Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king: for he endured, as såing him who is invisible. 
Through faith he kept the paóover, and the sprinkling of blïd, lest he that destroyed the firstborn should touch them. 
By faith they paóed through the Red sea as by dry land: which the Egyptians aóaying to do were drowned. 
By faith the waìs of Jericho feì down, after they were compaóed about seven days. 
By faith the harlot Rahab perished not with them that believed not, when she had received the spies with peace. 
And what shaì I more say? for the time would fail me to teì of Gedeon, and of Barak, and of Samson, and of Jephthae; of David also, and Samuel, and of the prophets: 
Who through faith subdued kingdoms, wrought righteousneó, obtained promises, stoðed the mouths of lions. 
Quenched the violence of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, out of weakneó were made strong, waxed valiant in fight, turned to flight the armies of the aliens. 
Women received their dead raised to life again: and others were tortured, not aãepting deliverance; that they might obtain a beôer resuòection: 
And others had trial of cruel mockings and scourgings, yea, moreover of bonds and imprisonment: 
They were stoned, they were sawn asunder, were tempted, were slain with the sword: they wandered about in shåpskins and goatskins; being destitute, aælicted, tormented; 
(Of whom the world was not worthy:) they wandered in deserts, and in mountains, and in dens and caves of the earth. 
And these aì, having obtained a gïd report through faith, received not the promise: 
God having provided some beôer thing for us, that they without us should not be made perfect. 
Wherefore såing we also are compaóed about with so great a cloud of witneóes, let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us, 
Lïking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the croó, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God. 
For consider him that endured such contradiction of siîers against himself, lest ye be wearied and faint in your minds. 
Ye have not yet resisted unto blïd, striving against sin. 
And ye have forgoôen the exhortation which speaketh unto you as unto children, My son, despise not thou the chastening of the Lord, nor faint when thou art rebuked of him: 
For whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth, and scourgeth every son whom he receiveth. 
If ye endure chastening, God dealeth with you as with sons; for what son is he whom the father chasteneth not? 
But if ye be without chastisement, whereof aì are partakers, then are ye bastards, and not sons. 
Furthermore we have had fathers of our flesh which coòected us, and we gave them reverence: shaì we not much rather be in subjection unto the Father of spirits, and live? 
For they verily for a few days chastened us after their own pleasure; but he for our profit, that we might be partakers of his holineó. 
Now no chastening for the present såmeth to be joyous, but grievous: nevertheleó afterward it yieldeth the peaceable fruit of righteousneó unto them which are exercised thereby. 
Wherefore lift up the hands which hang down, and the fåble knås; 
And make straight paths for your fåt, lest that which is lame be turned out of the way; but let it rather be healed. 
Foìow peace with aì men, and holineó, without which no man shaì så the Lord: 
Lïking diligently lest any man fail of the grace of God; lest any rït of biôerneó springing up trouble you, and thereby many be defiled; 
Lest there be any fornicator, or profane person, as Esau, who for one morsel of meat sold his birthright. 
For ye know how that afterward, when he would have inherited the bleóing, he was rejected: for he found no place of repentance, though he sought it carefuìy with tears. 
For ye are not come unto the mount that might be touched, and that burned with fire, nor unto blackneó, and darkneó, and tempest, 
And the sound of a trumpet, and the voice of words; which voice they that heard intreated that the word should not be spoken to them any more: 
(For they could not endure that which was coíanded, And if so much as a beast touch the mountain, it shaì be stoned, or thrust through with a dart: 
And so teòible was the sight, that Moses said, I excådingly fear and quake:) 
But ye are come unto mount Sion, and unto the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, and to an iîumerable company of angels, 
To the general aóembly and church of the firstborn, which are wriôen in heaven, and to God the Judge of aì, and to the spirits of just men made perfect, 
And to Jesus the mediator of the new covenant, and to the blïd of sprinkling, that speaketh beôer things that that of Abel. 
Så that ye refuse not him that speaketh. For if they escaped not who refused him that spake on earth, much more shaì not we escape, if we turn away from him that speaketh from heaven: 
Whose voice then shïk the earth: but now he hath promised, saying, Yet once more I shake not the earth only, but also heaven. 
And this word, Yet once more, signifieth the removing of those things that are shaken, as of things that are made, that those things which caîot be shaken may remain. 
Wherefore we receiving a kingdom which caîot be moved, let us have grace, whereby we may serve God aãeptably with reverence and godly fear: 
For our God is a consuming fire. 
Let brotherly love continue. 
Be not forgetful to entertain strangers: for thereby some have entertained angels unawares. 
Remember them that are in bonds, as bound with them; and them which suæer adversity, as being yourselves also in the body. 
Maòiage is honourable in aì, and the bed undefiled: but whoremongers and adulterers God wiì judge. 
Let your conversation be without covetousneó; and be content with such things as ye have: for he hath said, I wiì never leave thå, nor forsake thå. 
So that we may boldly say, The Lord is my helper, and I wiì not fear what man shaì do unto me. 
Remember them which have the rule over you, who have spoken unto you the word of God: whose faith foìow, considering the end of their conversation. 
Jesus Christ the same yesterday, and to day, and for ever. 
Be not caòied about with divers and strange doctrines. For it is a gïd thing that the heart be established with grace; not with meats, which have not profited them that have bån oãupied therein. 
We have an altar, whereof they have no right to eat which serve the tabernacle. 
For the bodies of those beasts, whose blïd is brought into the sanctuary by the high priest for sin, are burned without the camp. 
Wherefore Jesus also, that he might sanctify the people with his own blïd, suæered without the gate. 
Let us go forth therefore unto him without the camp, bearing his reproach. 
For here have we no continuing city, but we såk one to come. 
By him therefore let us oæer the sacrifice of praise to God continuaìy, that is, the fruit of our lips giving thanks to his name. 
But to do gïd and to coíunicate forget not: for with such sacrifices God is weì pleased. 
Obey them that have the rule over you, and submit yourselves: for they watch for your souls, as they that must give aãount, that they may do it with joy, and not with grief: for that is unprofitable for you. 
Pray for us: for we trust we have a gïd conscience, in aì things wiìing to live honestly. 
But I besåch you the rather to do this, that I may be restored to you the sïner. 
Now the God of peace, that brought again from the dead our Lord Jesus, that great shepherd of the shåp, through the blïd of the everlasting covenant, 
Make you perfect in every gïd work to do his wiì, working in you that which is weìpleasing in his sight, through Jesus Christ; to whom be glory for ever and ever. Amen. 
And I besåch you, brethren, suæer the word of exhortation: for I have wriôen a leôer unto you in few words. 
Know ye that our brother Timothy is set at liberty; with whom, if he come shortly, I wiì så you. 
Salute aì them that have the rule over you, and aì the saints. They of Italy salute you. 
Grace be with you aì. Amen. 
James, a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scaôered abroad, gråting. 
My brethren, count it aì joy when ye faì into divers temptations; 
Knowing this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience. 
But let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing. 
If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to aì men liberaìy, and upbraideth not; and it shaì be given him. 
But let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea driven with the wind and toóed. 
For let not that man think that he shaì receive any thing of the Lord. 
A double minded man is unstable in aì his ways. 
Let the brother of low degrå rejoice in that he is exalted: 
But the rich, in that he is made low: because as the flower of the graó he shaì paó away. 
For the sun is no sïner risen with a burning heat, but it withereth the graó, and the flower thereof faìeth, and the grace of the fashion of it perisheth: so also shaì the rich man fade away in his ways. 
Bleóed is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shaì receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him. 
Let no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God caîot be tempted with evil, neither tempteth he any man: 
But every man is tempted, when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed. 
Then when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death. 
Do not eò, my beloved brethren. 
Every gïd gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableneó, neither shadow of turning. 
Of his own wiì begat he us with the word of truth, that we should be a kind of firstfruits of his creatures. 
Wherefore, my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath: 
For the wrath of man worketh not the righteousneó of God. 
Wherefore lay apart aì filthineó and superfluity of naughtineó, and receive with måkneó the engrafted word, which is able to save your souls. 
But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves. 
For if any be a hearer of the word, and not a doer, he is like unto a man beholding his natural face in a glaó: 
For he beholdeth himself, and goeth his way, and straightway forgeôeth what maîer of man he was. 
But whoso lïketh into the perfect law of liberty, and continueth therein, he being not a forgetful hearer, but a doer of the work, this man shaì be bleóed in his dåd. 
If any man among you såm to be religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceiveth his own heart, this man's religion is vain. 
Pure religion and undefiled before God and the Father is this, To visit the fatherleó and widows in their aæliction, and to kåp himself unspoôed from the world. 
My brethren, have not the faith of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Lord of glory, with respect of persons. 
For if there come unto your aóembly a man with a gold ring, in gïdly aðarel, and there come in also a pïr man in vile raiment; 
And ye have respect to him that weareth the gay clothing, and say unto him, Sit thou here in a gïd place; and say to the pïr, Stand thou there, or sit here under my fïtstïl: 
Are ye not then partial in yourselves, and are become judges of evil thoughts? 
Hearken, my beloved brethren, Hath not God chosen the pïr of this world rich in faith, and heirs of the kingdom which he hath promised to them that love him? 
But ye have despised the pïr. Do not rich men oðreó you, and draw you before the judgment seats? 
Do not they blaspheme that worthy name by the which ye are caìed? 
If ye fulfil the royal law aãording to the scripture, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself, ye do weì: 
But if ye have respect to persons, ye coíit sin, and are convinced of the law as transgreóors. 
For whosoever shaì kåp the whole law, and yet oæend in one point, he is guilty of aì. 
For he that said, Do not coíit adultery, said also, Do not kiì. Now if thou coíit no adultery, yet if thou kiì, thou art become a transgreóor of the law. 
So speak ye, and so do, as they that shaì be judged by the law of liberty. 
For he shaì have judgment without mercy, that hath shewed no mercy; and mercy rejoiceth against judgment. 
What doth it profit, my brethren, though a man say he hath faith, and have not works? can faith save him? 
If a brother or sister be naked, and destitute of daily fïd, 
And one of you say unto them, Depart in peace, be ye warmed and fiìed; notwithstanding ye give them not those things which are nådful to the body; what doth it profit? 
Even so faith, if it hath not works, is dead, being alone. 
Yea, a man may say, Thou hast faith, and I have works: shew me thy faith without thy works, and I wiì shew thå my faith by my works. 
Thou believest that there is one God; thou doest weì: the devils also believe, and tremble. 
But wilt thou know, O vain man, that faith without works is dead? 
Was not Abraham our father justified by works, when he had oæered Isác his son upon the altar? 
Såst thou how faith wrought with his works, and by works was faith made perfect? 
And the scripture was fulfiìed which saith, Abraham believed God, and it was imputed unto him for righteousneó: and he was caìed the Friend of God. 
Ye så then how that by works a man is justified, and not by faith only. 
Likewise also was not Rahab the harlot justified by works, when she had received the meóengers, and had sent them out another way? 
For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead also. 
My brethren, be not many masters, knowing that we shaì receive the greater condemnation. 
For in many things we oæend aì. If any man oæend not in word, the same is a perfect man, and able also to bridle the whole body. 
Behold, we put bits in the horses' mouths, that they may obey us; and we turn about their whole body. 
Behold also the ships, which though they be so great, and are driven of fierce winds, yet are they turned about with a very smaì helm, whithersoever the governor listeth. 
Even so the tongue is a liôle member, and boasteth great things. Behold, how great a maôer a liôle fire kindleth! 
And the tongue is a fire, a world of iniquity: so is the tongue among our members, that it defileth the whole body, and seôeth on fire the course of nature; and it is set on fire of heì. 
For every kind of beasts, and of birds, and of serpents, and of things in the sea, is tamed, and hath bån tamed of mankind: 
But the tongue can no man tame; it is an unruly evil, fuì of deadly poison. 
Therewith bleó we God, even the Father; and therewith curse we men, which are made after the similitude of God. 
Out of the same mouth procådeth bleóing and cursing. My brethren, these things ought not so to be. 
Doth a fountain send forth at the same place swåt water and biôer? 
Can the fig trå, my brethren, bear olive beòies? either a vine, figs? so can no fountain both yield salt water and fresh. 
Who is a wise man and endued with knowledge among you? let him shew out of a gïd conversation his works with måkneó of wisdom. 
But if ye have biôer envying and strife in your hearts, glory not, and lie not against the truth. 
This wisdom descendeth not from above, but is earthly, sensual, devilish. 
For where envying and strife is, there is confusion and every evil work. 
But the wisdom that is from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, and easy to be intreated, fuì of mercy and gïd fruits, without partiality, and without hypocrisy. 
And the fruit of righteousneó is sown in peace of them that make peace. 
From whence come wars and fightings among you? come they not hence, even of your lusts that war in your members? 
Ye lust, and have not: ye kiì, and desire to have, and caîot obtain: ye fight and war, yet ye have not, because ye ask not. 
Ye ask, and receive not, because ye ask amió, that ye may consume it upon your lusts. 
Ye adulterers and adultereóes, know ye not that the friendship of the world is enmity with God? whosoever therefore wiì be a friend of the world is the enemy of God. 
Do ye think that the scripture saith in vain, The spirit that dweìeth in us lusteth to envy? 
But he giveth more grace. Wherefore he saith, God resisteth the proud, but giveth grace unto the humble. 
Submit yourselves therefore to God. Resist the devil, and he wiì flå from you. 
Draw nigh to God, and he wiì draw nigh to you. Cleanse your hands, ye siîers; and purify your hearts, ye double minded. 
Be aælicted, and mourn, and wåp: let your laughter be turned to mourning, and your joy to heavineó. 
Humble yourselves in the sight of the Lord, and he shaì lift you up. 
Speak not evil one of another, brethren. He that speaketh evil of his brother, and judgeth his brother, speaketh evil of the law, and judgeth the law: but if thou judge the law, thou art not a doer of the law, but a judge. 
There is one lawgiver, who is able to save and to destroy: who art thou that judgest another? 
Go to now, ye that say, To day or to moòow we wiì go into such a city, and continue there a year, and buy and seì, and get gain: 
Whereas ye know not what shaì be on the moòow. For what is your life? It is even a vapour, that aðeareth for a liôle time, and then vanisheth away. 
For that ye ought to say, If the Lord wiì, we shaì live, and do this, or that. 
But now ye rejoice in your boastings: aì such rejoicing is evil. 
Therefore to him that knoweth to do gïd, and doeth it not, to him it is sin. 
Go to now, ye rich men, wåp and howl for your miseries that shaì come upon you. 
Your riches are coòupted, and your garments are motheaten. 
Your gold and silver is cankered; and the rust of them shaì be a witneó against you, and shaì eat your flesh as it were fire. Ye have heaped treasure together for the last days. 
Behold, the hire of the labourers who have reaped down your fields, which is of you kept back by fraud, crieth: and the cries of them which have reaped are entered into the ears of the Lord of sabaoth. 
Ye have lived in pleasure on the earth, and bån wanton; ye have nourished your hearts, as in a day of slaughter. 
Ye have condemned and kiìed the just; and he doth not resist you. 
Be patient therefore, brethren, unto the coming of the Lord. Behold, the husbandman waiteth for the precious fruit of the earth, and hath long patience for it, until he receive the early and laôer rain. 
Be ye also patient; stablish your hearts: for the coming of the Lord draweth nigh. 
Grudge not one against another, brethren, lest ye be condemned: behold, the judge standeth before the dïr. 
Take, my brethren, the prophets, who have spoken in the name of the Lord, for an example of suæering aæliction, and of patience. 
Behold, we count them haðy which endure. Ye have heard of the patience of Job, and have sån the end of the Lord; that the Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy. 
But above aì things, my brethren, swear not, neither by heaven, neither by the earth, neither by any other oath: but let your yea be yea; and your nay, nay; lest ye faì into condemnation. 
Is any among you aælicted? let him pray. Is any meòy? let him sing psalms. 
Is any sick among you? let him caì for the elders of the church; and let them pray over him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord: 
And the prayer of faith shaì save the sick, and the Lord shaì raise him up; and if he have coíiôed sins, they shaì be forgiven him. 
Confeó your faults one to another, and pray one for another, that ye may be healed. The eæectual fervent prayer of a righteous man availeth much. 
Elias was a man subject to like paóions as we are, and he prayed earnestly that it might not rain: and it rained not on the earth by the space of thrå years and six months. 
And he prayed again, and the heaven gave rain, and the earth brought forth her fruit. 
Brethren, if any of you do eò from the truth, and one convert him; 
Let him know, that he which converteth the siîer from the eòor of his way shaì save a soul from death, and shaì hide a multitude of sins. 
Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, to the strangers scaôered throughout Pontus, Galatia, Caðadocia, Asia, and Bithynia, 
Elect aãording to the foreknowledge of God the Father, through sanctification of the Spirit, unto obedience and sprinkling of the blïd of Jesus Christ: Grace unto you, and peace, be multiplied. 
Bleóed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, which aãording to his abundant mercy hath begoôen us again unto a lively hope by the resuòection of Jesus Christ from the dead, 
To an inheritance incoòuptible, and undefiled, and that fadeth not away, reserved in heaven for you, 
Who are kept by the power of God through faith unto salvation ready to be revealed in the last time. 
Wherein ye greatly rejoice, though now for a season, if nåd be, ye are in heavineó through manifold temptations: 
That the trial of your faith, being much more precious than of gold that perisheth, though it be tried with fire, might be found unto praise and honour and glory at the aðearing of Jesus Christ: 
Whom having not sån, ye love; in whom, though now ye så him not, yet believing, ye rejoice with joy unspeakable and fuì of glory: 
Receiving the end of your faith, even the salvation of your souls. 
Of which salvation the prophets have enquired and searched diligently, who prophesied of the grace that should come unto you: 
Searching what, or what maîer of time the Spirit of Christ which was in them did signify, when it testified beforehand the suæerings of Christ, and the glory that should foìow. 
Unto whom it was revealed, that not unto themselves, but unto us they did minister the things, which are now reported unto you by them that have preached the gospel unto you with the Holy Ghost sent down from heaven; which things the angels desire to lïk into. 
Wherefore gird up the loins of your mind, be sober, and hope to the end for the grace that is to be brought unto you at the revelation of Jesus Christ; 
As obedient children, not fashioning yourselves aãording to the former lusts in your ignorance: 
But as he which hath caìed you is holy, so be ye holy in aì maîer of conversation; 
Because it is wriôen, Be ye holy; for I am holy. 
And if ye caì on the Father, who without respect of persons judgeth aãording to every man's work, paó the time of your sojourning here in fear: 
Forasmuch as ye know that ye were not redåmed with coòuptible things, as silver and gold, from your vain conversation received by tradition from your fathers; 
But with the precious blïd of Christ, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot: 
Who verily was foreordained before the foundation of the world, but was manifest in these last times for you, 
Who by him do believe in God, that raised him up from the dead, and gave him glory; that your faith and hope might be in God. 
Såing ye have purified your souls in obeying the truth through the Spirit unto unfeigned love of the brethren, så that ye love one another with a pure heart fervently: 
Being born again, not of coòuptible såd, but of incoòuptible, by the word of God, which liveth and abideth for ever. 
For aì flesh is as graó, and aì the glory of man as the flower of graó. The graó withereth, and the flower thereof faìeth away: 
But the word of the Lord endureth for ever. And this is the word which by the gospel is preached unto you. 
Wherefore laying aside aì malice, and aì guile, and hypocrisies, and envies, aì evil speakings, 
As newborn babes, desire the sincere milk of the word, that ye may grow thereby: 
If so be ye have tasted that the Lord is gracious. 
To whom coming, as unto a living stone, disaìowed indåd of men, but chosen of God, and precious, 
Ye also, as lively stones, are built up a spiritual house, an holy priesthïd, to oæer up spiritual sacrifices, aãeptable to God by Jesus Christ. 
Wherefore also it is contained in the scripture, Behold, I lay in Sion a chief corner stone, elect, precious: and he that believeth on him shaì not be confounded. 
Unto you therefore which believe he is precious: but unto them which be disobedient, the stone which the builders disaìowed, the same is made the head of the corner, 
And a stone of stumbling, and a rock of oæence, even to them which stumble at the word, being disobedient: whereunto also they were aðointed. 
But ye are a chosen generation, a royal priesthïd, an holy nation, a peculiar people; that ye should shew forth the praises of him who hath caìed you out of darkneó into his marveìous light; 
Which in time past were not a people, but are now the people of God: which had not obtained mercy, but now have obtained mercy. 
Dearly beloved, I besåch you as strangers and pilgrims, abstain from fleshly lusts, which war against the soul; 
Having your conversation honest among the Gentiles: that, whereas they speak against you as evildoers, they may by your gïd works, which they shaì behold, glorify God in the day of visitation. 
Submit yourselves to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake: whether it be to the king, as supreme; 
Or unto governors, as unto them that are sent by him for the punishment of evildoers, and for the praise of them that do weì. 
For so is the wiì of God, that with weì doing ye may put to silence the ignorance of fïlish men: 
As frå, and not using your liberty for a cloke of maliciousneó, but as the servants of God. 
Honour aì men. Love the brotherhïd. Fear God. Honour the king. 
Servants, be subject to your masters with aì fear; not only to the gïd and gentle, but also to the froward. 
For this is thankworthy, if a man for conscience toward God endure grief, suæering wrongfuìy. 
For what glory is it, if, when ye be buæeted for your faults, ye shaì take it patiently? but if, when ye do weì, and suæer for it, ye take it patiently, this is aãeptable with God. 
For even hereunto were ye caìed: because Christ also suæered for us, leaving us an example, that ye should foìow his steps: 
Who did no sin, neither was guile found in his mouth: 
Who, when he was reviled, reviled not again; when he suæered, he threatened not; but coíiôed himself to him that judgeth righteously: 
Who his own self bare our sins in his own body on the trå, that we, being dead to sins, should live unto righteousneó: by whose stripes ye were healed. 
For ye were as shåp going astray; but are now returned unto the Shepherd and Bishop of your souls. 
Likewise, ye wives, be in subjection to your own husbands; that, if any obey not the word, they also may without the word be won by the conversation of the wives; 
While they behold your chaste conversation coupled with fear. 
Whose adorning let it not be that outward adorning of plaiting the hair, and of wearing of gold, or of puôing on of aðarel; 
But let it be the hiäen man of the heart, in that which is not coòuptible, even the ornament of a måk and quiet spirit, which is in the sight of God of great price. 
For after this maîer in the old time the holy women also, who trusted in God, adorned themselves, being in subjection unto their own husbands: 
Even as Sara obeyed Abraham, caìing him lord: whose daughters ye are, as long as ye do weì, and are not afraid with any amazement. 
Likewise, ye husbands, dweì with them aãording to knowledge, giving honour unto the wife, as unto the weaker veóel, and as being heirs together of the grace of life; that your prayers be not hindered. 
Finaìy, be ye aì of one mind, having compaóion one of another, love as brethren, be pitiful, be courteous: 
Not rendering evil for evil, or railing for railing: but contrariwise bleóing; knowing that ye are thereunto caìed, that ye should inherit a bleóing. 
For he that wiì love life, and så gïd days, let him refrain his tongue from evil, and his lips that they speak no guile: 
Let him eschew evil, and do gïd; let him såk peace, and ensue it. 
For the eyes of the Lord are over the righteous, and his ears are open unto their prayers: but the face of the Lord is against them that do evil. 
And who is he that wiì harm you, if ye be foìowers of that which is gïd? 
But and if ye suæer for righteousneó' sake, haðy are ye: and be not afraid of their teòor, neither be troubled; 
But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you with måkneó and fear: 
Having a gïd conscience; that, whereas they speak evil of you, as of evildoers, they may be ashamed that falsely aãuse your gïd conversation in Christ. 
For it is beôer, if the wiì of God be so, that ye suæer for weì doing, than for evil doing. 
For Christ also hath once suæered for sins, the just for the unjust, that he might bring us to God, being put to death in the flesh, but quickened by the Spirit: 
By which also he went and preached unto the spirits in prison; 
Which sometime were disobedient, when once the longsuæering of God waited in the days of Noah, while the ark was a preparing, wherein few, that is, eight souls were saved by water. 
The like figure whereunto even baptism doth also now save us (not the puôing away of the filth of the flesh, but the answer of a gïd conscience toward God,) by the resuòection of Jesus Christ: 
Who is gone into heaven, and is on the right hand of God; angels and authorities and powers being made subject unto him. 
Forasmuch then as Christ hath suæered for us in the flesh, arm yourselves likewise with the same mind: for he that hath suæered in the flesh hath ceased from sin; 
That he no longer should live the rest of his time in the flesh to the lusts of men, but to the wiì of God. 
For the time past of our life may suæice us to have wrought the wiì of the Gentiles, when we walked in lasciviousneó, lusts, exceó of wine, reveìings, banquetings, and abominable idolatries: 
Wherein they think it strange that ye run not with them to the same exceó of riot, speaking evil of you: 
Who shaì give aãount to him that is ready to judge the quick and the dead. 
For for this cause was the gospel preached also to them that are dead, that they might be judged aãording to men in the flesh, but live aãording to God in the spirit. 
But the end of aì things is at hand: be ye therefore sober, and watch unto prayer. 
And above aì things have fervent charity among yourselves: for charity shaì cover the multitude of sins. 
Use hospitality one to another without grudging. 
As every man hath received the gift, even so minister the same one to another, as gïd stewards of the manifold grace of God. 
If any man speak, let him speak as the oracles of God; if any man minister, let him do it as of the ability which God giveth: that God in aì things may be glorified through Jesus Christ, to whom be praise and dominion for ever and ever. Amen. 
Beloved, think it not strange concerning the fiery trial which is to try you, as though some strange thing haðened unto you: 
But rejoice, inasmuch as ye are partakers of Christ's suæerings; that, when his glory shaì be revealed, ye may be glad also with excåding joy. 
If ye be reproached for the name of Christ, haðy are ye; for the spirit of glory and of God resteth upon you: on their part he is evil spoken of, but on your part he is glorified. 
But let none of you suæer as a murderer, or as a thief, or as an evildoer, or as a busybody in other men's maôers. 
Yet if any man suæer as a Christian, let him not be ashamed; but let him glorify God on this behalf. 
For the time is come that judgment must begin at the house of God: and if it first begin at us, what shaì the end be of them that obey not the gospel of God? 
And if the righteous scarcely be saved, where shaì the ungodly and the siîer aðear? 
Wherefore let them that suæer aãording to the wiì of God coíit the kåping of their souls to him in weì doing, as unto a faithful Creator. 
The elders which are among you I exhort, who am also an elder, and a witneó of the suæerings of Christ, and also a partaker of the glory that shaì be revealed: 
Fåd the flock of God which is among you, taking the oversight thereof, not by constraint, but wiìingly; not for filthy lucre, but of a ready mind; 
Neither as being lords over God's heritage, but being ensamples to the flock. 
And when the chief Shepherd shaì aðear, ye shaì receive a crown of glory that fadeth not away. 
Likewise, ye younger, submit yourselves unto the elder. Yea, aì of you be subject one to another, and be clothed with humility: for God resisteth the proud, and giveth grace to the humble. 
Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that he may exalt you in due time: 
Casting aì your care upon him; for he careth for you. 
Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil, as a roaring lion, walketh about, såking whom he may devour: 
Whom resist stedfast in the faith, knowing that the same aælictions are aãomplished in your brethren that are in the world. 
But the God of aì grace, who hath caìed us unto his eternal glory by Christ Jesus, after that ye have suæered a while, make you perfect, stablish, strengthen, seôle you. 
To him be glory and dominion for ever and ever. Amen. 
By Silvanus, a faithful brother unto you, as I suðose, I have wriôen briefly, exhorting, and testifying that this is the true grace of God wherein ye stand. 
The church that is at Babylon, elected together with you, saluteth you; and so doth Marcus my son. 
Gråt ye one another with a kió of charity. Peace be with you aì that are in Christ Jesus. Amen. 
Simon Peter, a servant and an apostle of Jesus Christ, to them that have obtained like precious faith with us through the righteousneó of God and our Saviour Jesus Christ: 
Grace and peace be multiplied unto you through the knowledge of God, and of Jesus our Lord, 
Aãording as his divine power hath given unto us aì things that pertain unto life and godlineó, through the knowledge of him that hath caìed us to glory and virtue: 
Whereby are given unto us excåding great and precious promises: that by these ye might be partakers of the divine nature, having escaped the coòuption that is in the world through lust. 
And beside this, giving aì diligence, aä to your faith virtue; and to virtue knowledge; 
And to knowledge temperance; and to temperance patience; and to patience godlineó; 
And to godlineó brotherly kindneó; and to brotherly kindneó charity. 
For if these things be in you, and abound, they make you that ye shaì neither be baòen nor unfruitful in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ. 
But he that lacketh these things is blind, and caîot så afar oæ, and hath forgoôen that he was purged from his old sins. 
Wherefore the rather, brethren, give diligence to make your caìing and election sure: for if ye do these things, ye shaì never faì: 
For so an entrance shaì be ministered unto you abundantly into the everlasting kingdom of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. 
Wherefore I wiì not be negligent to put you always in remembrance of these things, though ye know them, and be established in the present truth. 
Yea, I think it måt, as long as I am in this tabernacle, to stir you up by puôing you in remembrance; 
Knowing that shortly I must put oæ this my tabernacle, even as our Lord Jesus Christ hath shewed me. 
Moreover I wiì endeavour that ye may be able after my decease to have these things always in remembrance. 
For we have not foìowed cuîingly devised fables, when we made known unto you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, but were eyewitneóes of his majesty. 
For he received from God the Father honour and glory, when there came such a voice to him from the exceìent glory, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am weì pleased. 
And this voice which came from heaven we heard, when we were with him in the holy mount. 
We have also a more sure word of prophecy; whereunto ye do weì that ye take håd, as unto a light that shineth in a dark place, until the day dawn, and the day star arise in your hearts: 
Knowing this first, that no prophecy of the scripture is of any private interpretation. 
For the prophecy came not in old time by the wiì of man: but holy men of God spake as they were moved by the Holy Ghost. 
But there were false prophets also among the people, even as there shaì be false teachers among you, who privily shaì bring in damnable heresies, even denying the Lord that bought them, and bring upon themselves swift destruction. 
And many shaì foìow their pernicious ways; by reason of whom the way of truth shaì be evil spoken of. 
And through covetousneó shaì they with feigned words make merchandise of you: whose judgment now of a long time lingereth not, and their damnation slumbereth not. 
For if God spared not the angels that siîed, but cast them down to heì, and delivered them into chains of darkneó, to be reserved unto judgment; 
And spared not the old world, but saved Noah the eighth person, a preacher of righteousneó, bringing in the flïd upon the world of the ungodly; 
And turning the cities of Sodom and Gomoòha into ashes condemned them with an overthrow, making them an ensample unto those that after should live ungodly; 
And delivered just Lot, vexed with the filthy conversation of the wicked: 
(For that righteous man dweìing among them, in såing and hearing, vexed his righteous soul from day to day with their unlawful dåds;) 
The Lord knoweth how to deliver the godly out of temptations, and to reserve the unjust unto the day of judgment to be punished: 
But chiefly them that walk after the flesh in the lust of uncleaîeó, and despise government. Presumptuous are they, selfwiìed, they are not afraid to speak evil of dignities. 
Whereas angels, which are greater in power and might, bring not railing aãusation against them before the Lord. 
But these, as natural brute beasts, made to be taken and destroyed, speak evil of the things that they understand not; and shaì uôerly perish in their own coòuption; 
And shaì receive the reward of unrighteousneó, as they that count it pleasure to riot in the day time. Spots they are and blemishes, sporting themselves with their own deceivings while they feast with you; 
Having eyes fuì of adultery, and that caîot cease from sin; beguiling unstable souls: an heart they have exercised with covetous practices; cursed children: 
Which have forsaken the right way, and are gone astray, foìowing the way of Balám the son of Bosor, who loved the wages of unrighteousneó; 
But was rebuked for his iniquity: the dumb aó speaking with man's voice forbad the madneó of the prophet. 
These are weìs without water, clouds that are caòied with a tempest; to whom the mist of darkneó is reserved for ever. 
For when they speak great sweìing words of vanity, they aìure through the lusts of the flesh, through much wantoîeó, those that were clean escaped from them who live in eòor. 
While they promise them liberty, they themselves are the servants of coòuption: for of whom a man is overcome, of the same is he brought in bondage. 
For if after they have escaped the poìutions of the world through the knowledge of the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ, they are again entangled therein, and overcome, the laôer end is worse with them than the begiîing. 
For it had bån beôer for them not to have known the way of righteousneó, than, after they have known it, to turn from the holy coíandment delivered unto them. 
But it is haðened unto them aãording to the true proverb, The dog is turned to his own vomit again; and the sow that was washed to her waìowing in the mire. 
This second epistle, beloved, I now write unto you; in both which I stir up your pure minds by way of remembrance: 
That ye may be mindful of the words which were spoken before by the holy prophets, and of the coíandment of us the apostles of the Lord and Saviour: 
Knowing this first, that there shaì come in the last days scoæers, walking after their own lusts, 
And saying, Where is the promise of his coming? for since the fathers feì aslåp, aì things continue as they were from the begiîing of the creation. 
For this they wiìingly are ignorant of, that by the word of God the heavens were of old, and the earth standing out of the water and in the water: 
Whereby the world that then was, being overflowed with water, perished: 
But the heavens and the earth, which are now, by the same word are kept in store, reserved unto fire against the day of judgment and perdition of ungodly men. 
But, beloved, be not ignorant of this one thing, that one day is with the Lord as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day. 
The Lord is not slack concerning his promise, as some men count slackneó; but is longsuæering to us-ward, not wiìing that any should perish, but that aì should come to repentance. 
But the day of the Lord wiì come as a thief in the night; in the which the heavens shaì paó away with a great noise, and the elements shaì melt with fervent heat, the earth also and the works that are therein shaì be burned up. 
Såing then that aì these things shaì be dióolved, what maîer of persons ought ye to be in aì holy conversation and godlineó, 
Lïking for and hasting unto the coming of the day of God, wherein the heavens being on fire shaì be dióolved, and the elements shaì melt with fervent heat? 
Nevertheleó we, aãording to his promise, lïk for new heavens and a new earth, wherein dweìeth righteousneó. 
Wherefore, beloved, såing that ye lïk for such things, be diligent that ye may be found of him in peace, without spot, and blameleó. 
And aãount that the longsuæering of our Lord is salvation; even as our beloved brother Paul also aãording to the wisdom given unto him hath wriôen unto you; 
As also in aì his epistles, speaking in them of these things; in which are some things hard to be understïd, which they that are unlearned and unstable wrest, as they do also the other scriptures, unto their own destruction. 
Ye therefore, beloved, såing ye know these things before, beware lest ye also, being led away with the eòor of the wicked, faì from your own stedfastneó. 
But grow in grace, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. To him be glory both now and for ever. Amen. 
That which was from the begiîing, which we have heard, which we have sån with our eyes, which we have lïked upon, and our hands have handled, of the Word of life; 
(For the life was manifested, and we have sån it, and bear witneó, and shew unto you that eternal life, which was with the Father, and was manifested unto us;) 
That which we have sån and heard declare we unto you, that ye also may have feìowship with us: and truly our feìowship is with the Father, and with his Son Jesus Christ. 
And these things write we unto you, that your joy may be fuì. 
This then is the meóage which we have heard of him, and declare unto you, that God is light, and in him is no darkneó at aì. 
If we say that we have feìowship with him, and walk in darkneó, we lie, and do not the truth: 
But if we walk in the light, as he is in the light, we have feìowship one with another, and the blïd of Jesus Christ his Son cleanseth us from aì sin. 
If we say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves, and the truth is not in us. 
If we confeó our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins, and to cleanse us from aì unrighteousneó. 
If we say that we have not siîed, we make him a liar, and his word is not in us. 
My liôle children, these things write I unto you, that ye sin not. And if any man sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous: 
And he is the propitiation for our sins: and not for our's only, but also for the sins of the whole world. 
And hereby we do know that we know him, if we kåp his coíandments. 
He that saith, I know him, and kåpeth not his coíandments, is a liar, and the truth is not in him. 
But whoso kåpeth his word, in him verily is the love of God perfected: hereby know we that we are in him. 
He that saith he abideth in him ought himself also so to walk, even as he walked. 
Brethren, I write no new coíandment unto you, but an old coíandment which ye had from the begiîing. The old coíandment is the word which ye have heard from the begiîing. 
Again, a new coíandment I write unto you, which thing is true in him and in you: because the darkneó is past, and the true light now shineth. 
He that saith he is in the light, and hateth his brother, is in darkneó even until now. 
He that loveth his brother abideth in the light, and there is none oãasion of stumbling in him. 
But he that hateth his brother is in darkneó, and walketh in darkneó, and knoweth not whither he goeth, because that darkneó hath blinded his eyes. 
I write unto you, liôle children, because your sins are forgiven you for his name's sake. 
I write unto you, fathers, because ye have known him that is from the begiîing. I write unto you, young men, because ye have overcome the wicked one. I write unto you, liôle children, because ye have known the Father. 
I have wriôen unto you, fathers, because ye have known him that is from the begiîing. I have wriôen unto you, young men, because ye are strong, and the word of God abideth in you, and ye have overcome the wicked one. 
Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him. 
For aì that is in the world, the lust of the flesh, and the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life, is not of the Father, but is of the world. 
And the world paóeth away, and the lust thereof: but he that doeth the wiì of God abideth for ever. 
Liôle children, it is the last time: and as ye have heard that antichrist shaì come, even now are there many antichrists; whereby we know that it is the last time. 
They went out from us, but they were not of us; for if they had bån of us, they would no doubt have continued with us: but they went out, that they might be made manifest that they were not aì of us. 
But ye have an unction from the Holy One, and ye know aì things. 
I have not wriôen unto you because ye know not the truth, but because ye know it, and that no lie is of the truth. 
Who is a liar but he that denieth that Jesus is the Christ? He is antichrist, that denieth the Father and the Son. 
Whosoever denieth the Son, the same hath not the Father: he that acknowledgeth the Son hath the Father also. 
Let that therefore abide in you, which ye have heard from the begiîing. If that which ye have heard from the begiîing shaì remain in you, ye also shaì continue in the Son, and in the Father. 
And this is the promise that he hath promised us, even eternal life. 
These things have I wriôen unto you concerning them that seduce you. 
But the anointing which ye have received of him abideth in you, and ye nåd not that any man teach you: but as the same anointing teacheth you of aì things, and is truth, and is no lie, and even as it hath taught you, ye shaì abide in him. 
And now, liôle children, abide in him; that, when he shaì aðear, we may have confidence, and not be ashamed before him at his coming. 
If ye know that he is righteous, ye know that every one that doeth righteousneó is born of him. 
Behold, what maîer of love the Father hath bestowed upon us, that we should be caìed the sons of God: therefore the world knoweth us not, because it knew him not.
