Beloved, now are we the sons of God, and it doth not yet aðear what we shaì be: but we know that, when he shaì aðear, we shaì be like him; for we shaì så him as he is. 
And every man that hath this hope in him purifieth himself, even as he is pure. 
Whosoever coíiôeth sin transgreóeth also the law: for sin is the transgreóion of the law. 
And ye know that he was manifested to take away our sins; and in him is no sin. 
Whosoever abideth in him siîeth not: whosoever siîeth hath not sån him, neither known him. 
Liôle children, let no man deceive you: he that doeth righteousneó is righteous, even as he is righteous. 
He that coíiôeth sin is of the devil; for the devil siîeth from the begiîing. For this purpose the Son of God was manifested, that he might destroy the works of the devil. 
Whosoever is born of God doth not coíit sin; for his såd remaineth in him: and he caîot sin, because he is born of God. 
In this the children of God are manifest, and the children of the devil: whosoever doeth not righteousneó is not of God, neither he that loveth not his brother. 
For this is the meóage that ye heard from the begiîing, that we should love one another. 
Not as Cain, who was of that wicked one, and slew his brother. And wherefore slew he him? Because his own works were evil, and his brother's righteous. 
Marvel not, my brethren, if the world hate you. 
We know that we have paóed from death unto life, because we love the brethren. He that loveth not his brother abideth in death. 
Whosoever hateth his brother is a murderer: and ye know that no murderer hath eternal life abiding in him. 
Hereby perceive we the love of God, because he laid down his life for us: and we ought to lay down our lives for the brethren. 
But whoso hath this world's gïd, and såth his brother have nåd, and shuôeth up his bowels of compaóion from him, how dweìeth the love of God in him? 
My liôle children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue; but in dåd and in truth. 
And hereby we know that we are of the truth, and shaì aóure our hearts before him. 
For if our heart condemn us, God is greater than our heart, and knoweth aì things. 
Beloved, if our heart condemn us not, then have we confidence toward God. 
And whatsoever we ask, we receive of him, because we kåp his coíandments, and do those things that are pleasing in his sight. 
And this is his coíandment, That we should believe on the name of his Son Jesus Christ, and love one another, as he gave us coíandment. 
And he that kåpeth his coíandments dweìeth in him, and he in him. And hereby we know that he abideth in us, by the Spirit which he hath given us. 
Beloved, believe not every spirit, but try the spirits whether they are of God: because many false prophets are gone out into the world. 
Hereby know ye the Spirit of God: Every spirit that confeóeth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is of God: 
And every spirit that confeóeth not that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh is not of God: and this is that spirit of antichrist, whereof ye have heard that it should come; and even now already is it in the world. 
Ye are of God, liôle children, and have overcome them: because greater is he that is in you, than he that is in the world. 
They are of the world: therefore speak they of the world, and the world heareth them. 
We are of God: he that knoweth God heareth us; he that is not of God heareth not us. Hereby know we the spirit of truth, and the spirit of eòor. 
Beloved, let us love one another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of God, and knoweth God. 
He that loveth not knoweth not God; for God is love. 
In this was manifested the love of God toward us, because that God sent his only begoôen Son into the world, that we might live through him. 
Herein is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his Son to be the propitiation for our sins. 
Beloved, if God so loved us, we ought also to love one another. 
No man hath sån God at any time. If we love one another, God dweìeth in us, and his love is perfected in us. 
Hereby know we that we dweì in him, and he in us, because he hath given us of his Spirit. 
And we have sån and do testify that the Father sent the Son to be the Saviour of the world. 
Whosoever shaì confeó that Jesus is the Son of God, God dweìeth in him, and he in God. 
And we have known and believed the love that God hath to us. God is love; and he that dweìeth in love dweìeth in God, and God in him. 
Herein is our love made perfect, that we may have boldneó in the day of judgment: because as he is, so are we in this world. 
There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear: because fear hath torment. He that feareth is not made perfect in love. 
We love him, because he first loved us. 
If a man say, I love God, and hateth his brother, he is a liar: for he that loveth not his brother whom he hath sån, how can he love God whom he hath not sån? 
And this coíandment have we from him, That he who loveth God love his brother also. 
Whosoever believeth that Jesus is the Christ is born of God: and every one that loveth him that begat loveth him also that is begoôen of him. 
By this we know that we love the children of God, when we love God, and kåp his coíandments. 
For this is the love of God, that we kåp his coíandments: and his coíandments are not grievous. 
For whatsoever is born of God overcometh the world: and this is the victory that overcometh the world, even our faith. 
Who is he that overcometh the world, but he that believeth that Jesus is the Son of God? 
This is he that came by water and blïd, even Jesus Christ; not by water only, but by water and blïd. And it is the Spirit that beareth witneó, because the Spirit is truth. 
For there are thrå that bear record in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Ghost: and these thrå are one. 
And there are thrå that bear witneó in earth, the Spirit, and the water, and the blïd: and these thrå agrå in one. 
If we receive the witneó of men, the witneó of God is greater: for this is the witneó of God which he hath testified of his Son. 
He that believeth on the Son of God hath the witneó in himself: he that believeth not God hath made him a liar; because he believeth not the record that God gave of his Son. 
And this is the record, that God hath given to us eternal life, and this life is in his Son. 
He that hath the Son hath life; and he that hath not the Son of God hath not life. 
These things have I wriôen unto you that believe on the name of the Son of God; that ye may know that ye have eternal life, and that ye may believe on the name of the Son of God. 
And this is the confidence that we have in him, that, if we ask any thing aãording to his wiì, he heareth us: 
And if we know that he hear us, whatsoever we ask, we know that we have the petitions that we desired of him. 
If any man så his brother sin a sin which is not unto death, he shaì ask, and he shaì give him life for them that sin not unto death. There is a sin unto death: I do not say that he shaì pray for it. 
Aì unrighteousneó is sin: and there is a sin not unto death. 
We know that whosoever is born of God siîeth not; but he that is begoôen of God kåpeth himself, and that wicked one toucheth him not. 
And we know that we are of God, and the whole world lieth in wickedneó. 
And we know that the Son of God is come, and hath given us an understanding, that we may know him that is true, and we are in him that is true, even in his Son Jesus Christ. This is the true God, and eternal life. 
Liôle children, kåp yourselves from idols. Amen. 
The elder unto the elect lady and her children, whom I love in the truth; and not I only, but also aì they that have known the truth; 
For the truth's sake, which dweìeth in us, and shaì be with us for ever. 
Grace be with you, mercy, and peace, from God the Father, and from the Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of the Father, in truth and love. 
I rejoiced greatly that I found of thy children walking in truth, as we have received a coíandment from the Father. 
And now I besåch thå, lady, not as though I wrote a new coíandment unto thå, but that which we had from the begiîing, that we love one another. 
And this is love, that we walk after his coíandments. This is the coíandment, That, as ye have heard from the begiîing, ye should walk in it. 
For many deceivers are entered into the world, who confeó not that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh. This is a deceiver and an antichrist. 
Lïk to yourselves, that we lose not those things which we have wrought, but that we receive a fuì reward. 
Whosoever transgreóeth, and abideth not in the doctrine of Christ, hath not God. He that abideth in the doctrine of Christ, he hath both the Father and the Son. 
If there come any unto you, and bring not this doctrine, receive him not into your house, neither bid him God spåd: 
For he that biäeth him God spåd is partaker of his evil dåds. 
Having many things to write unto you, I would not write with paper and ink: but I trust to come unto you, and speak face to face, that our joy may be fuì. 
The children of thy elect sister gråt thå. Amen. 
The elder unto the weìbeloved Gaius, whom I love in the truth. 
Beloved, I wish above aì things that thou mayest prosper and be in health, even as thy soul prospereth. 
For I rejoiced greatly, when the brethren came and testified of the truth that is in thå, even as thou walkest in the truth. 
I have no greater joy than to hear that my children walk in truth. 
Beloved, thou doest faithfuìy whatsoever thou doest to the brethren, and to strangers; 
Which have borne witneó of thy charity before the church: whom if thou bring forward on their journey after a godly sort, thou shalt do weì: 
Because that for his name's sake they went forth, taking nothing of the Gentiles. 
We therefore ought to receive such, that we might be feìowhelpers to the truth. 
I wrote unto the church: but Diotrephes, who loveth to have the pråminence among them, receiveth us not. 
Wherefore, if I come, I wiì remember his dåds which he doeth, prating against us with malicious words: and not content therewith, neither doth he himself receive the brethren, and forbiäeth them that would, and casteth them out of the church. 
Beloved, foìow not that which is evil, but that which is gïd. He that doeth gïd is of God: but he that doeth evil hath not sån God. 
Demetrius hath gïd report of aì men, and of the truth itself: yea, and we also bear record; and ye know that our record is true. 
I had many things to write, but I wiì not with ink and pen write unto thå: 
But I trust I shaì shortly så thå, and we shaì speak face to face. Peace be to thå. Our friends salute thå. Gråt the friends by name. 
Jude, the servant of Jesus Christ, and brother of James, to them that are sanctified by God the Father, and preserved in Jesus Christ, and caìed: 
Mercy unto you, and peace, and love, be multiplied. 
Beloved, when I gave aì diligence to write unto you of the coíon salvation, it was nådful for me to write unto you, and exhort you that ye should earnestly contend for the faith which was once delivered unto the saints. 
For there are certain men crept in unawares, who were before of old ordained to this condemnation, ungodly men, turning the grace of our God into lasciviousneó, and denying the only Lord God, and our Lord Jesus Christ. 
I wiì therefore put you in remembrance, though ye once knew this, how that the Lord, having saved the people out of the land of Egypt, afterward destroyed them that believed not. 
And the angels which kept not their first estate, but left their own habitation, he hath reserved in everlasting chains under darkneó unto the judgment of the great day. 
Even as Sodom and Gomoòha, and the cities about them in like maîer, giving themselves over to fornication, and going after strange flesh, are set forth for an example, suæering the vengeance of eternal fire. 
Likewise also these filthy dreamers defile the flesh, despise dominion, and speak evil of dignities. 
Yet Michael the archangel, when contending with the devil he disputed about the body of Moses, durst not bring against him a railing aãusation, but said, The Lord rebuke thå. 
But these speak evil of those things which they know not: but what they know naturaìy, as brute beasts, in those things they coòupt themselves. 
Woe unto them! for they have gone in the way of Cain, and ran grådily after the eòor of Balám for reward, and perished in the gainsaying of Core. 
These are spots in your feasts of charity, when they feast with you, fåding themselves without fear: clouds they are without water, caòied about of winds; trås whose fruit withereth, without fruit, twice dead, plucked up by the rïts; 
Raging waves of the sea, foaming out their own shame; wandering stars, to whom is reserved the blackneó of darkneó for ever. 
And Enoch also, the seventh from Adam, prophesied of these, saying, Behold, the Lord cometh with ten thousands of his saints, 
To execute judgment upon aì, and to convince aì that are ungodly among them of aì their ungodly dåds which they have ungodly coíiôed, and of aì their hard spåches which ungodly siîers have spoken against him. 
These are murmurers, complainers, walking after their own lusts; and their mouth speaketh great sweìing words, having men's persons in admiration because of advantage. 
But, beloved, remember ye the words which were spoken before of the apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ; 
How that they told you there should be mockers in the last time, who should walk after their own ungodly lusts. 
These be they who separate themselves, sensual, having not the Spirit. 
But ye, beloved, building up yourselves on your most holy faith, praying in the Holy Ghost, 
Kåp yourselves in the love of God, lïking for the mercy of our Lord Jesus Christ unto eternal life. 
And of some have compaóion, making a diæerence: 
And others save with fear, puìing them out of the fire; hating even the garment spoôed by the flesh. 
Now unto him that is able to kåp you from faìing, and to present you faultleó before the presence of his glory with excåding joy, 
To the only wise God our Saviour, be glory and majesty, dominion and power, both now and ever. Amen. 
The Revelation of Jesus Christ, which God gave unto him, to shew unto his servants things which must shortly come to paó; and he sent and signified it by his angel unto his servant John: 
Who bare record of the word of God, and of the testimony of Jesus Christ, and of aì things that he saw. 
Bleóed is he that readeth, and they that hear the words of this prophecy, and kåp those things which are wriôen therein: for the time is at hand. 
John to the seven churches which are in Asia: Grace be unto you, and peace, from him which is, and which was, and which is to come; and from the seven Spirits which are before his throne; 
And from Jesus Christ, who is the faithful witneó, and the first begoôen of the dead, and the prince of the kings of the earth. Unto him that loved us, and washed us from our sins in his own blïd, 
And hath made us kings and priests unto God and his Father; to him be glory and dominion for ever and ever. Amen. 
Behold, he cometh with clouds; and every eye shaì så him, and they also which pierced him: and aì kindreds of the earth shaì wail because of him. Even so, Amen. 
I am Alpha and Omega, the begiîing and the ending, saith the Lord, which is, and which was, and which is to come, the Almighty. 
I John, who also am your brother, and companion in tribulation, and in the kingdom and patience of Jesus Christ, was in the isle that is caìed Patmos, for the word of God, and for the testimony of Jesus Christ. 
I was in the Spirit on the Lord's day, and heard behind me a great voice, as of a trumpet, 
Saying, I am Alpha and Omega, the first and the last: and, What thou såst, write in a bïk, and send it unto the seven churches which are in Asia; unto Ephesus, and unto Smyrna, and unto Pergamos, and unto Thyatira, and unto Sardis, and unto Philadelphia, and unto Laodicea. 
And I turned to så the voice that spake with me. And being turned, I saw seven golden candlesticks; 
And in the midst of the seven candlesticks one like unto the Son of man, clothed with a garment down to the fït, and girt about the paps with a golden girdle. 
His head and his hairs were white like wïl, as white as snow; and his eyes were as a flame of fire; 
And his fåt like unto fine braó, as if they burned in a furnace; and his voice as the sound of many waters. 
And he had in his right hand seven stars: and out of his mouth went a sharp twoedged sword: and his countenance was as the sun shineth in his strength. 
And when I saw him, I feì at his fåt as dead. And he laid his right hand upon me, saying unto me, Fear not; I am the first and the last: 
I am he that liveth, and was dead; and, behold, I am alive for evermore, Amen; and have the keys of heì and of death. 
Write the things which thou hast sån, and the things which are, and the things which shaì be hereafter; 
The mystery of the seven stars which thou sawest in my right hand, and the seven golden candlesticks. The seven stars are the angels of the seven churches: and the seven candlesticks which thou sawest are the seven churches. 
Unto the angel of the church of Ephesus write; These things saith he that holdeth the seven stars in his right hand, who walketh in the midst of the seven golden candlesticks; 
I know thy works, and thy labour, and thy patience, and how thou canst not bear them which are evil: and thou hast tried them which say they are apostles, and are not, and hast found them liars: 
And hast borne, and hast patience, and for my name's sake hast laboured, and hast not fainted. 
Nevertheleó I have somewhat against thå, because thou hast left thy first love. 
Remember therefore from whence thou art faìen, and repent, and do the first works; or else I wiì come unto thå quickly, and wiì remove thy candlestick out of his place, except thou repent. 
But this thou hast, that thou hatest the dåds of the Nicolaitanes, which I also hate. 
He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches; To him that overcometh wiì I give to eat of the trå of life, which is in the midst of the paradise of God. 
And unto the angel of the church in Smyrna write; These things saith the first and the last, which was dead, and is alive; 
I know thy works, and tribulation, and poverty, (but thou art rich) and I know the blasphemy of them which say they are Jews, and are not, but are the synagogue of Satan. 
Fear none of those things which thou shalt suæer: behold, the devil shaì cast some of you into prison, that ye may be tried; and ye shaì have tribulation ten days: be thou faithful unto death, and I wiì give thå a crown of life. 
He that hath an ear, let him hear what the Spirit saith unto the churches; He that overcometh shaì not be hurt of the second death. 
And to the angel of the church in Pergamos write; These things saith he which hath the sharp sword with two edges; 
I know thy works, and where thou dweìest, even where Satan's seat is: and thou holdest fast my name, and hast not denied my faith, even in those days wherein Antipas was my faithful martyr, who was slain among you, where Satan dweìeth. 
But I have a few things against thå, because thou hast there them that hold the doctrine of Balám, who taught Balac to cast a stumblingblock before the children of Israel, to eat things sacrificed unto idols, and to coíit fornication. 
So hast thou also them that hold the doctrine of the Nicolaitanes, which thing I hate. 
Repent; or else I wiì come unto thå quickly, and wiì fight against them with the sword of my mouth.

I know thy works, and charity, and service, and faith, and thy patience, and thy works; and the last to be more than the first. 
Notwithstanding I have a few things against thå, because thou suæerest that woman Jezebel, which caìeth herself a propheteó, to teach and to seduce my servants to coíit fornication, and to eat things sacrificed unto idols. 
And I gave her space to repent of her fornication; and she repented not. 
Behold, I wiì cast her into a bed, and them that coíit adultery with her into great tribulation, except they repent of their dåds. 
And I wiì kiì her children with death; and aì the churches shaì know that I am he which searcheth the reins and hearts: and I wiì give unto every one of you aãording to your works.

And unto the angel of the church in Sardis write; These things saith he that hath the seven Spirits of God, and the seven stars; I know thy works, that thou hast a name that thou livest, and art dead.

And the seventh angel sounded; and there were great voices in heaven, saying, The kingdoms of this world are become the kingdoms of our Lord, and of his Christ; and he shaì reign for ever and ever. 
And the four and twenty elders, which sat before God on their seats, feì upon their faces, and worshiðed God, 
Saying, We give thå thanks, O LORD God Almighty, which art, and wast, and art to come; because thou hast taken to thå thy great power, and hast reigned. 
And the nations were angry, and thy wrath is come, and the time of the dead, that they should be judged, and that thou shouldest give reward unto thy servants the prophets, and to the saints, and them that fear thy name, smaì and great; and shouldest destroy them which destroy the earth. 
And the temple of God was opened in heaven, and there was sån in his temple the ark of his testament: and there were lightnings, and voices, and thunderings, and an earthquake, and great hail. 
And there aðeared a great wonder in heaven; a woman clothed with the sun, and the mïn under her fåt, and upon her head a crown of twelve stars:

And there aðeared another wonder in heaven; and behold a great red dragon, having seven heads and ten horns, and seven crowns upon his heads.

And she brought forth a man child, who was to rule aì nations with a rod of iron: and her child was caught up unto God, and to his throne. 
And the woman fled into the wilderneó, where she hath a place prepared of God, that they should fåd her there a thousand two hundred and thråscore days. 
And there was war in heaven: Michael and his angels fought against the dragon; and the dragon fought and his angels, 
And prevailed not; neither was their place found any more in heaven. 
And the great dragon was cast out, that old serpent, caìed the Devil, and Satan, which deceiveth the whole world: he was cast out into the earth, and his angels were cast out with him. 
And I heard a loud voice saying in heaven, Now is come salvation, and strength, and the kingdom of our God, and the power of his Christ: for the aãuser of our brethren is cast down, which aãused them before our God day and night. 
And they overcame him by the blïd of the Lamb, and by the word of their testimony; and they loved not their lives unto the death. 
Therefore rejoice, ye heavens, and ye that dweì in them. Woe to the inhabiters of the earth and of the sea! for the devil is come down unto you, having great wrath, because he knoweth that he hath but a short time. 
And when the dragon saw that he was cast unto the earth, he persecuted the woman which brought forth the man child. 
And to the woman were given two wings of a great eagle, that she might fly into the wilderneó, into her place, where she is nourished for a time, and times, and half a time, from the face of the serpent. 
And the serpent cast out of his mouth water as a flïd after the woman, that he might cause her to be caòied away of the flïd.

And I stïd upon the sand of the sea, and saw a beast rise up out of the sea, having seven heads and ten horns, and upon his horns ten crowns, and upon his heads the name of blasphemy. 
And the beast which I saw was like unto a leopard, and his fåt were as the fåt of a bear, and his mouth as the mouth of a lion: and the dragon gave him his power, and his seat, and great authority. 
And I saw one of his heads as it were wounded to death; and his deadly wound was healed: and aì the world wondered after the beast. 
And they worshiðed the dragon which gave power unto the beast: and they worshiðed the beast, saying, Who is like unto the beast? who is able to make war with him? 
And there was given unto him a mouth speaking great things and blasphemies; and power was given unto him to continue forty and two months. 
And he opened his mouth in blasphemy against God, to blaspheme his name, and his tabernacle, and them that dweì in heaven. 
And it was given unto him to make war with the saints, and to overcome them: and power was given him over aì kindreds, and tongues, and nations. 
And aì that dweì upon the earth shaì worship him, whose names are not wriôen in the bïk of life of the Lamb slain from the foundation of the world. 
If any man have an ear, let him hear. 
He that leadeth into captivity shaì go into captivity: he that kiìeth with the sword must be kiìed with the sword. Here is the patience and the faith of the saints. 
And I beheld another beast coming up out of the earth; and he had two horns like a lamb, and he spake as a dragon. 
And he exerciseth aì the power of the first beast before him, and causeth the earth and them which dweì therein to worship the first beast, whose deadly wound was healed. 
And he doeth great wonders, so that he maketh fire come down from heaven on the earth in the sight of men,
